此		this here				2201			シ	これ、 この、 ここ	I'm not going to use 'this here' as a primitive because it's too vague. But 'stop and sit down', usually tied to a tour guide explaining scenery works for me.//<em>Stop</em> and <em>sit down</em> to have a look at<strong> this here</strong>.	"A wildlife explorer, let's call him Steve Irwin, the sadly passed away wildlife expert, is tracking down an animal in a forest. He finds a <em>footprint</em>, and gets out a <em>spoon</em> to taste it. He scrapes the spoon over the floor and tries it. ""Now,<strong> this here</strong> is a crocodile footprint"" he announces."					RTK3
柴		brushwood				2202			サイ、 シ	しば	(From mantixen's) I'll <em>stop</em> and <em>sit down</em> on <em>this here tree</em>, which happens to be<strong> brushwood</strong>. Now I have to <em>brush wood</em> off my butt.	I'll <em>stop</em> and <em>sit down</em> on <em>this here tree</em>, which happens to be<strong> brushwood</strong>.					RTK3
些		whit				2203			サ、 シャ	ち.と、 ち.っと、 いささか	Those two tourists from my tour group don't have a<strong> whit</strong> of common sense. They never <em>stop and sit down</em> when the tour guide tells them to!	<em>Two</em>-year-olds don't have a<strong> whit</strong> of interest to <em>stop and sit down</em>. They'd likely explode with all that energy.					RTK3
砦		fort				2204			サイ	とりで	"<em>Stop and sit down</em> to listen to the tour guide's story. "(Grammar and story adjustment from astridtops story) You STOP AND SIT DOWN to listen to the tour guides story. 禽		fowl				2206			キン	とり、 とりこ	"The villain from <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%9B%A2"">離</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1492</span>) and <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%92%83"">璃</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2048</span>). Being a Terrorist on the FBI most wanted list, <em>Bin Laden</em> must constantly move from place to place and is never quite certain where is going to sleep. Sometimes he can count on a loyal supporter to let him stay in a spare room, but when traveling to more remote parts of Arabia, he is sometimes forced to sleep under an <em>umbrella</em> with the <strong>fowl</strong>. 兎		rabbit				2235			ト、 ツ	うさぎ	"A real<strong> rabbit</strong> always leaves DROPs of poo pellets behind, and his ears are no longer bound up (compere <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%85%8D"">免</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2126</span>)), so they flap above like helicopter blades (pictograph), and his MOUTH still is wide-open with the STAFF-like tongue, and his powerful LEGS still look like a human's." 也		est				2236			ヤ、 エ	なり、 か、 また	"This is the kanji for the classical form of ""is"". I think Heisig's keyword ""est"" is the old english or latin word for ""is"". The Scorpion this <strong>est</strong>!"	"""Est"" is the latin third person singular of the verb ""esse"" (to be) in Latin. So, this word has been chosen to point out that this character is found chiefly in Classical Japanese (also names). I imagine an incredibly haughty Latin <em>Scorpion</em>, looking down at his vast <strong>est</strong>ate and saying ""Mihi<strong> est</strong>"". This literally mean ""It is to me"" and means ""It's mine"" ... this is gramatically similar to how Japanese express possession too, incidentally."					RTK3
巴		comma-design				2237			ハ	ともえ、 うずまき	"The ""comma-design"" referred to: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomoe."	This is a<strong> comma-design</strong> outlaid in mosaic on the floor.					RTK3

莫		shalt				2242			バク、 ボ、 マク、 モ、 ナイ	くれ、 なか.れ、 なし	"""Thou<strong> shalt</strong> not kill"", 'cause the <em>graveyard</em> is full. There's no room left to dispose of the evidence!"	"莫大<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%8E%AB"">莫</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2242</span>)バク <strong>Graveyard Primitive</strong> RTK＃228.9 ... Parts:艹, 日, 大 ... Note: Heisig got this backwards. It is <strong>shalt not</strong>. But it is an unused Kanji anyway, so..It means the same thing as 勿<a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%8B%BF"">勿</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1128</span>). ... Story: Thou<strong> Shalt</strong> not argue with RTK keywords, or angry mobs will put you in <strong>Graveyards</strong> ... 熟語:莫逆, 落莫, ... cf: 慕う, 幕府, 漢字."					RTK3

侠		chivalry				2245			キョウ	きゃん、 おとこだて	"<em>Mr T</em> approaches the knights and stabs his <em>scissors</em> into the table they're seated at. ""I pity the fool who questions my<strong> chivalry</strong>!"""	<em>Mr. T</em> believes in<strong> chivalry</strong> - so whenever he plays a game of rock, paper, scissors, he always throws <em>scissors</em> to let the other person win. Note that this has nothing to do with women at all (hence the absence of women in this kanji) - just with everybody being weaker than <em>Mr T</em>.					RTK3

佃		work a field				2248			テン、 デン	つくだ	Not so long ago, if <em>Mr T</em> was <strong>working in a field</strong>, he would have been a slave.	The first television show that <em>Mr T</em> ever worked on was a slavery period drama. Operating on the assumption that all black people look alike, the director decided to save on his budget by just hiring one black person. In each scene requiring slaves in the background to<strong> work a field</strong>, he would put <em>Mr T</em> in the rice paddy in the background. Then when they changed the scene, he would simply put <em>Mr T</em> there too - no changing clothes, no CG - just the same dude in the background of EVERY scene.					RTK3
仔		animal offspring				2249			シ	こ、 た.える	"Remember that sordid <a href=""/study/kanji/%E4%BB%B6"">件</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1032</span>) when <em>Mr. T</em> was caught having relations with a cow? Well, some months later the heifer drops off the <em>child</em> at T's place. A <em>child</em> does instead! Ewww, someone in the villiage has been behaving badly.					RTK3

儲		make a profit				2252			チョ	もう.ける、 もう.かる、 もうけ、 たくわ.える	Faith, lovedoll: Mr T, having <em>faith</em> in the word of God, prayed really hard for the girlfriend he could never get in the regular way. 僑		emigrant				2253			キョウ		Mr T, angel: Believe it or not, but <em>mr T</em> is actually an <em>angel</em>. He <strong>emigrated</strong> from heavens to right the wrongs on planet earth.	When people emigrate, they believe they are going to some better place, a place which to them, is heaven-high.					RTK3
倶		mate				2254			グ、 ク	とも.に	"""Oy, <strong>mate</strong>"", the carpenter calls out to <em>Mr. T</em>, ""where did you leave my <em>tools</em>, <strong>mate</strong>?"" <em>Mr. T</em> just hates it when people call him <strong>mate</strong>. It inspires him to misuse their <em>tools</em>."	A<strong> mate</strong> is a <em>person</em> who lends you a <em>tool</em> when you need. (Just remember to return it if you want him to stay your<strong> mate</strong>.)					RTK3
侃		forthright				2255			カン	つよ.い	<em>Mr. T</em> is a man of <strong>integrity</strong>. Every time he opens his <em>mouth</em>, <strong>integrity</strong> just seems to <em>stream</em> out.	<em>Mr T</em>'s structural integrity has been compromised. Blood and guts is <em>flowing</em> from his <em>mouth</em>.					RTK3
偲		memorial				2256			サイ、 シ	しの.ぶ	"At a<strong> memorial</strong> service for <em>Mr. T</em>, everyone is <em>thinking</em> ""I pity that foo""."	A<strong> memorial</strong> service is something that makes you <em>think</em> about a <em>person</em> who has died.					RTK3
侭		as is				2257			ジン	まま、 ことごとく	<em>Mr. T</em> is <em>exhausted</em>!<strong> As is</strong> the woman who just gave him <em>shakuhachi</em>.	"You see <em>person</em> holding the <em>exhaust</em> pipe which has just dropped off their new car, and say, ""You should return that and get your money back!"". ""Trouble is,"" they reply, ""I bought it<strong> as is</strong>""."					RTK3
脩		dried meat				2258			シュウ	おさ.める、 なが.い、 ほじし	"Once again, <em>Mr. T</em> ventured out into the remote area to visit his <em>old taskmaster</em> (see <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%82%A0"">悠</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1031</span>)). However, the <em>old taskmaster</em> has become very weak. His <em>flesh</em> looks like<strong> dried meat</strong> and his heart almost stopped (no heart). He stayed a whole <em>month</em> to take care about his former teacher."	<em>Mr. T</em> doesn't like <strong>dried meat</strong>. He's been known to take a <em>walking stick</em> to the <em>taskmaster</em> trying to hand him a piece of <em>meat</em> that had been dried out. No, <em>Mr. T</em> doesn't like <strong>dried meat</strong> a-t a-l-l!					RTK3
倅		my son				2259			サイ、 ソツ、 ソチ	せがれ	"""<strong>My son</strong>"", sniffs <em>Mr. T</em>, ""I'm so glad that you are now a college <em>graduate</em>"" he said."	"Important note: Instead of the keyword ""my son,"" the keyword ""good for nothing son"" may be more appropriate. This word is one of the examples of depreciating titles for family members. This word is used to refer to your son when you especially want to lower his status. So, keep that in mind when deciding on a story or when making your own. I suggest CountPacula's story, since it involves that ""good for nothing son"" meaning a little more."					RTK3
做		make do				2260			サ、 サク、 ソ	な.す、 つく.る	"Note that the meaning of this (rare) kanji is ""<strong>make</strong> (something) / <strong>do</strong> (something)"", not ""get by with"". Story: <em>Mr. T</em> doesn't rely on <em>happenstance</em>, he <strong>makes</strong> things <strong>do</strong> what he wants. Edit: In fact three Japanese kanji dictionaries I checked all list 做 as an alternative to 作 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E4%BD%9C"">作</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1224</span>), so ""<strong>make (alt)</strong>"" might be the best keyword. Story: <em>Mr. T</em> by <em>happenstance</em> found an <strong>alt</strong>ernative way to <strong>make</strong> things. (See also bennyb &amp; faneca's notes)."	(food for thought) I know this is RTK3 and all, but this kanji seems almost completely useless. The two most common phrases it's included in are 言い做す to speak as though something were actually the case and 見なす to regard (as equivalent). Both of which USUALLY just write なすin kana, and neither of which have anything to do with the meaning. In fact I can't find any trace of Katsuo's suggestion of this meaning. Anyone care to enlighten me? Perhaps this one's worth skipping.					RTK3
冴		sharp				2261			ゴ、 コ	さ.える、 こお.る、 ひ.える	(Note that per Heisig, this doesn't mean 'able to cut'; it means mentally<strong> sharp</strong>, adept, or 'on your toes'!) During the <em>Ice</em> Age, cavemen had to be especially careful around the woolly mammoth, because they were more mentally <em>sharp</em> than they looked. If the cavemen weren't careful, they could end up impaled on the mammoths' <em>tusks</em>!	A<strong> sharp</strong> tusk pointing out of the ice. Probably belongs to a mammoth.					RTK3
凋		wilt				2262			チョウ	しぼ.む	You don't want the lettuce to <strong>wilt</strong>, do you? So, you put <em>ice</em> around the <em>circumference</em> of the serving tray, and then the lettuce on top of that, so it cannot <strong>wilt</strong>.	Plants<strong> wilt</strong>, wither and die when <em>ice</em> envelopes the <em>circumference</em> of their roots.					RTK3
凌		pull through				2263			リョウ	しの.ぐ	"On their <em>walk</em> to the Promised Land (<a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%99%B8"">陸</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1631</span>)), our brave <em>rice-seedlings</em> are faced with an unforeseen obstacle: An <em>ice</em> glacier the size of a rain puddle. Will they be able to<strong> pull through</strong>?"	In a very harsh turn of the weather, the water of the rice fields has turned to <em>ice</em>! The farmers are strutting around the little <em>rice seedlings</em> anxiously on their <em>walking legs</em>, hoping that the plants will<strong> pull through</strong> and survive!					RTK3
凛		stately				2264			リン	きびし.い	Much more <strong>stately</strong> than that soil podium, this is made of <em>ice</em>. This<strong> stately</strong> home in Brittain has been used for winter weddings <em>many times</em>. A reverend in a <em>top hat</em> stands behind the <em>altar</em> in the home's chapel, which is adorned with <em>ice</em> sculptures. Very romantic.					RTK3
凧		kite				2265				いかのぼり、 たこ	"I'm drying myself at the 露天風呂 (outdoor hot spring) when a sudden gust of <em>wind</em> catches my <em>towel</em> and blows it into the air. 夙		earlybird				2267			シュク	つとに、 はやい	The<strong> earlybird</strong>s always get all the best food at the buffets, and all the latecomers get are just leftover bones, you can almost see the wind and tumbleweeds rolling over it. 厭		despondent				2272			エン、 オン、 アン、 オウ、 ユウ、 ヨウ	いや、 あ.きる、 いと.う、 おさ.える	The poor <em>chihuahua</em> who had fallen down a <em>cliff</em> was totally<strong> despondent</strong> about his position. He saw the <em>sun</em> and the <em>moon</em> pass by, but expected no rescue any more.	While you may know the story of Hachikou, this is about a <em>chihuahua</em> that lost its master. They used to play a game - <em>Sun</em> and <em>Moon</em> - where the master would stand at the top of a cliff and wave his hands as if to resemble sunrays, and the dog would lie on the ground in a crescent shape - then they would switch. But one day the master fell! The dog, for years after, would go to the spot where he fell at <em>sun</em> and <em>moon</em> rise and look<strong> despondent</strong>. Imagine the<strong> despondent</strong> puppydog eyes.					RTK3
雁		wild goose				2273			ガン	かり、 かりがね	<em>Mr T</em> is sent on a mission to find a<strong> wild goose</strong> that swallowed some important, top-secret chemicals (they were in a baggie, so he has to find it before it dissolves!). After searching for clues and tracks, he finds it - and backs it up against a cliff. In a heroic move, <em>Mr T</em> jumps off the <em>cliff</em>, grabs the<strong> wild goose</strong>, and lands on the ground on his back, protecting the volatile<strong> wild goose</strong>. He then looks at it - wait - this isn't the<strong> wild goose</strong>, this is a mere <em>turkey</em>! Sent on a<strong> wild goose</strong> chase!	I've been sent to chase the <strong>wild goose</strong>! I'm here at the top of the <em>cliff</em>, and I can hear <em>Mr. T</em> and that tricky <em>turkey</em> down there sniggering about sending me on a search for the <strong>wild goose</strong>. 啄		peck at				2287			タク、 ツク、 トク	ついば.む、 つつ.く	Just like the ones on a rhinoceros, there are little birds who like to<strong> peck at</strong> the skin near the <em>mouth</em> of a <em>sow</em> and clean it. 埴		clay				2299			ショク	はに、 へな	"This one rhymes: ""If you fights wiz Cassius <strong>Clay</strong>, you'll hit the <em>soil</em>, boy, <em>straightaway</em>!"""	A special type of<strong> clay</strong>, this <em>soil</em> will cook into porcelain <em>straightaway</em>.					RTK3
坤		autochthonous				2300			コン	つち、 ひつじさる	"While ""<strong>autochthonous</strong>"" can mean ""indigenous"" in ENGLISH, that is NOT one of the potential meanings of this character (thus, the majority of these stories will not help you with meaning). Rather, the kanji is ""autochthonous"" in the sense of being Earthly, mystic, and portentous (the ancient, primitive, sacred power of DIRT and SOIL). A vague, poorly-chosen keyword all around. Mantixen's story does the best job of conveying accurate meaning--&gt; ""A <em>monkey</em> likes the <strong>earthy/autochthonous</strong> feel of <em>soil</em>""."	A <em>monkey</em> likes the <strong>earthy</strong> feel of <em>soil</em>.					RTK3
壕		dugout				2301			コウ、 ゴウ	ほり	"A<strong> DUGOUT</strong> is a dry moat found around Japanese castles. The SOIL is arranged so as to OVERPOWER (or give the advantage to OVERPOWER) an attacking army. If dug in a low lying area it fills with water and becomes a moat (濠 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%BF%A0"">濠</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2400</span>))."	As they constructed the visiting team <strong>dugout</strong>, they removed a quantity of <em>soil</em> when there was an <em>overpowering</em> stench. Nobody will want to use this <strong>dugout</strong>!					RTK3
垢		blemish				2302			コウ、 ク	あか、 はじ	Big consternation in the court! A little bit of <em>soil</em> in the garden touched the <em>empress</em>' face and left a<strong> blemish</strong> there. 埠		wharf				2304			フ、 ホ	つか、 はとば	He came to finding himself down at the <strong>wharf</strong> with <em>soil</em> all over his tuxedo. The <em>maestro</em> can only guess that he'd been drugged by some <em>needle</em> sharp dart, since the last thing that he recalled was feeling a prick on the bottom, before waking up at the <strong>wharf</strong>.	"If you build a<strong> wharf</strong> on a <em><a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%98%9C"">阜</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1360</span>)</em>, the vessels should be able to sail the <em>soil</em>."					RTK3
堰		dam				2305			エン	せき、 せ.く	Soil, box, sun, woman: In Peru, they were constructing a<strong> dam</strong> and to this end, <em>soil</em> was gathered from the surrounds. During the excavations, they found a <em>box</em>, containing little statue of the <em>sun</em> <em>woman</em> (godess). A nice archeological find, but detrimental for the<strong> dam</strong> building efforts, since the work was to be halted.	To build the<strong> dam</strong>, <em>soil</em> was collected and carried in <em>cardboard boxes</em>. And when the <em>sun</em> got hot, they made the <em>women</em> do it.					RTK3

嬰		suckling infant				2307			エイ	ふ.れる、 みどりご、 あかご	The <em>woman</em> removes the <em>two shells</em> covering her breasts (for modesty) and then attaches the<strong> suckling infant</strong>. 娼		harlot				2311			ショウ	あそびめ	<strong>Harlot</strong>s are <em>women</em> who make a lot of money, usually, so they or their pimps are quite <em>prosperous</em>. 妓		courtesan				2312			ギ、 キ	わざおぎ、 うたいめ	In the 平安時代（へいあんじだい）, the<strong> courtesan</strong>s (women who lived in the royal courts) often stayed in the side portions of the palaces, the section that branched off the main building. 娃		fair				2313			ア、 アイ、 ワ	うつく.しい	The photographer took a picture of this<strong> fair</strong> <em>woman</em> framed by <em>ivy</em>.	Come on, think of Rapunzel. 孕		expecting				2320			ヨウ	はら.む	A woman says to me “I’m <strong>expecting</strong> – there’s a child in here (pointing to her stomach)” I put my ear to her stomach and suddenly the <em>child</em> punches me – I see the shape of its <em>fist</em> in the stomach wall. “Well, you might be <strong>expecting</strong>, but I certainly wasn’t <strong>expecting</strong> that” I reply. 宏		extensive				2324			コウ	ひろ.い	During an<strong> extensive</strong> search of a murderer's <em>house</em> of horror, homocide detectives found an <em>elbow</em> body part <em>by the side</em> of another body. Surely there were even more victims than they imagined.	Thanks to Katsuo: BY ONE'S SIDE and ELBOW can be SUPERMAN (think of the George Reeve's SUPERMAN pose for a mental image). Well, that fortress of solitude is very<strong> EXTENSIVE</strong>. Would you expect SUPERMAN's HOUSE to anything less?					RTK3
牢		jail				2325			ロウ	かた.い、 ひとや	For a <em>cow</em> used to free-grazing, being stuck in a <em>house</em> is equivalent to being in<strong> jail</strong>. 宋		Sung dynasty				2326			ソウ		The<strong> Sung dynasty</strong> was so-called because people kept <em>trees</em> in their <em>houses</em> and as a consequence birds <strong>sung</strong> in them. 宍		venison				2327			ニク、 ジク	しし	I was once served<strong> venison</strong> at <em>home</em>, but the only way I could eat it was to down a <em>six</em> pack first. 屠		butchering				2328			ト、 チョ	ほふ.る	Generals usually see their soldiers as mere <em>puppets</em> in their war game. These poor sods are given a <em>flag</em> and told to fight for their country. 屁		fart				2329			ヒ	へ、 おなら	You haven't smelled a <strong>fart</strong> like his! His were so bad, that when he cut one, they had to wave a <em>flag</em> to keep folks away. 屑		rubbish				2330			セツ	くず、 いさぎよ.い	You aren't supposed to throw an American <em>flag</em> out with the<strong> rubbish</strong>. The proper way to get rid of a flag is to burn it, shown here by holding a <em>candle</em> underneath it.	Japanese society has always been quite environmentally conscious. Even back in the Edo period, they had an ingenious method for punishing people that didn't properly separate their<strong> rubbish</strong>. If, for example, you threw your ペットボトル into the paper can, a large <em>Semaphore Flag</em> would fly up out of nowhere and alert people, and a <em>candle</em> would fly out of the can and catch you on fire, so that people would know immediately who the perpetrator was. 嵩		high-reaching				2334			スウ、 シュウ	かさ、 かさ.む、 たか.い	<strong>High-reaching</strong> aspirations usually revolve around the <em>mountain</em> that is the <em>tallest</em>. 廓		licensed quarters				2342			カク	くるわ、 とりで	The Fight Club had no<strong> licensed quarters</strong>, so they battled it out in the <em>enclosure</em> down inside a <em>cave</em>. "This is an<strong> assortment</strong> of chocolate <em>fingers</em> all pointing <em>south-east</em> (巽 is <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%B7%BD"">巽</a>) i.e. all angled towards the lower-right corner of the box." You finally<strong> muster</strong>ed up enough courage to point your finger at the bully in front of you and tell him what an *** he is. Hope you can run fast.					RTK3

托		receptacle				2363			タク	たく.する、 たの.む	"The keyword in the book is ""receptacle"" (which is an actual word unlike receptable). 洵		swirling waters				2387			ジュン、 シュン	の.ぶ、 まこと.に	You have got a really, really plugged up bathtub - so plugged up, as a matter of fact, that when you get out of the bath, it takes an entire <em>decameron</em> for the gently<strong> swirling waters</strong> to go all the way down. It clears the clog right up, and the <em>swirling waters</em> zip right on down! 晋		progress				2514			シン	すす.む	The churches teach that if we eliminate <em>horniness</em> as a <em>universal</em> trait, we can make<strong> progress</strong> as a society.	Is read シン and refers to the Jin (or Tsin) Dynasty in China in the 3rd century. Then there was a Later Jin Dynasty and other Jins using the character 金. Appears in name of Shansi province. RTK3
晒		bleaching				2521			サイ、 シ	さら.す、 さらし	In the <em>Old West</em>, the <em>sun</em> was the only method for<strong> bleaching</strong> hair.	Sun, west: The Japanese like to <strong>bleach</strong> their hairs until these shine in the <em>sun</em>. It has to do with their obsession for the <em>West</em>.					RTK3
晃		limpid				2522			コウ	あきらか	The <em>sun's rays</em> passed through to the very bottom of the<strong> limpid</strong> pond.	If something is<strong> limpid</strong> (meaning clear, transparent, free of obscurity), then, by definition, the rays of the sun can shine down through it.					RTK3
曝		air out				2523			バク、 ホク、 ボク	さら.す	An <em>outburst</em> of <em>sun</em> is a good time to<strong> air out</strong> your things.	Being suddenly blinded by the <em>sun</em>, a crew member of the International Space Station (ISS) has an <em>outburst</em> after losing an important round in Counter-Strike, he accidentally hits the button for the vents and let the <strong>air out</strong>.					RTK3
曙		dawn				2524			ショ	あけぼの	At<strong> DAWN</strong>, the SUN starts it's DAY of work, yes? So doesn't it need to SIGN IN with with SIGNATURE? Just picture that silly image for this kanji.	"I go out at the crack of<strong> dawn</strong> to buy a newspaper (The <em>Sun</em>), and bump into ex-sumo wrestler Akebono (曙) who is doing the same. Of course I ask for his <em>signature</em> on my copy of The <em>Sun</em>, which he signs ""<strong>Dawn</strong> (Akebono)""."					RTK3
昂		elevate				2525			コウ、 ゴウ	あ.がる、 たか.い、 たか.ぶる	Sending mail to the <em>sun</em>. It would take a whole <em>box of stamps</em> to<strong> elevate</strong> it that high.	A <em>sunny day</em> to a depressed person is just like a <em>box of stamps</em> to a stamp otaku: both have the ability to<strong> elevate</strong> spirits!					RTK3
昏		dusk				2526			コン	くら.い、 くれ	At<strong> dusk</strong> every day I go out in one of those airplanes that leaves a vapour trail and write my <em>family name</em> just above the setting <em>sun</em>. (I have to wait until<strong> dusk</strong> so that the sun is low enough in the sky).	"The WOMAN abandoned her <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%A9%9A"">婚</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1972</span>) as soon as<strong> dusk</strong> came."					RTK3
晦		last day of the month				2527			カイ	つごもり、 くら.い、 みそか、 くら.む	<em>Every</em> month, there is one <em>day</em> that is the<strong> last day of the month</strong>.	If only <em>every day</em> could be the<strong> last day of the month</strong>, I'd be filing for paychecks all the time.					RTK3
膿		pus				2528			ノウ、 ドウ	う.む、 うみ	If your <em>flesh</em> gets stung by the thorns of certain plants while doing <em>agriculture</em> work, your wound may infect and show<strong> pus</strong>.	Forget Manure, the best thing for <em>agriculture</em> is<strong> pus</strong>, freshly squeezed from some rancid <em>flesh</em>.					RTK3
腑		viscera				2529			フ	はらわた	That <em>municipality</em> is so unsafe, thugs will attack you and cut the<strong> viscera</strong> out of your <em>flesh</em> to sell them on the black organs market.	Your<strong> viscera</strong> are like a <em>municipality</em> of <em>body parts</em> working together with different roles.					RTK3
胱		bladder				2530			コウ		It starts in the<strong> bladder</strong>, passes through a certain <em>body part</em> and then appears like a <em>ray</em> of golden light!	The <em>part of the body</em> that golden <em>rays of light</em> seem to pour out from.					RTK3
胚		embryo				2531			ハイ	はらみ、 はら.む	When she took the pregnancy test because she thought she was carrying the <em>flesh</em> of an<strong> embryo</strong>, the test was <em>negative</em> and she dropped it on the <em>floor</em>.	"When a baby is born, he or she is considered ""age zero"". After a year of life, he or she is only then considered one year old. Since an<strong> embryo</strong> is found within a woman, it is effectively <em>part of the body</em> of that person. However, it is not yet zero years old - in fact, its age is <em>negative one</em> (i.e. -1 years old)! 胚性幹細胞　－　はいせいかんさいぼう　＝　embryonic stem cell."					RTK3
肛		anus				2532			コウ		The<strong> anus</strong> is the <em>part of the body</em> where <em>crafty</em> smugglers often hide small valuables.	<em>Moon</em>ing is the <em>craft</em> of baring one's<strong> anus</strong>.					RTK3
脆		fragile				2533			ゼイ、 セイ、 セツ	もろ.い、 よわい	If you're a<strong> fragile</strong> person, lots of things are <em>dangerous</em> and will hurt your <em>flesh</em>.	Doing <em>dangerous</em> things reminds us that our <em>flesh</em> is<strong> fragile</strong>.					RTK3
肋		rib				2534			ロク	あばら	Without<strong> rib</strong>s, our <em>flesh</em> wouldn't have the <em>power</em> to stay upright.	Flesh, power: According to the bible, the <em>part of the body</em> that gave <em>power</em> to womankind was the mans'<strong> rib</strong>. Without it, they wouldn't exist.					RTK3
腔		body cavity				2535			コウ		A<strong> body cavity</strong> is an <em>empty</em> space within your <em>flesh</em>.	During a <strong>body cavity</strong> search, the police check certain <em>parts of your body</em> to make sure they're <em>empty</em> of things like cocaine, etc..					RTK3
肱		armrest				2536			コウ	かいな、 ひじ、 まるい	An<strong> armrest</strong> is something that lets you rest the <em>flesh</em> of your arm by keeping your <em>elbow by your side</em>.	"The primitive on the left I call the ""SUPERMAN POSE"" (he stand with his elbows to the side), well here you see he is actually using the part of his BODY, the hips, as an<strong> ARMREST</strong> when he does the SUPERMAN POSE."					RTK3
胡		uncivilized				2537			ウ、 コ、 ゴ	なんぞ	Only<strong> uncivilized</strong> people eat <em>old flesh</em>.	"Tip:<strong> uncivilized</strong> appears as part of four other kanji in Heisig, but is not named as such in the text. REF: <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%B9%96"">湖</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#159</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%91%9A"">瑚</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2615</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%B3%8A"">糊</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2692</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%86%90"">醐</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2776</span>). (P.S. As a primitive I call this ""zombie"", because when the <em>moon</em> shines on the <em>gravestones</em> the <em>zombies</em> arise. And, zombies do tend to be<strong> uncivilized</strong>.)"					RTK3
楓		maple tree				2538			フウ	かえで	How do you know if a tree is a<strong> maple tree</strong>? Easy: Just stand next to the <em>tree</em> on a <em>wind</em>y day, and if you get covered in maple syrup, it's a<strong> maple tree</strong>.	"Hint: Do not confuse between the <em>wind</em> primitive and the <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%A2%A8"">風</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#563</span>) kanji. The latter I call <em>wind with gnats</em>. (+Katsuo). How do you know if a tree is a<strong> maple tree</strong>? Easy: Just stand next to the <em>tree</em> on a <em>wind</em>y day, and if you get covered in of maple syrup and <em>gnats</em>, it's a<strong> maple tree</strong>."					RTK3
楊		purple willow				2539			ヨウ	やなぎ	Because it's easy to spot, a<strong> purple willow</strong> is the <em>tree</em> that marks where my <em>piggy bank</em> is.	"I hid my <em>piggy bank</em> under a <strong>willow</strong> <em>tree</em>. Then I thought 'how am I gonna find it later?' So I painted the <strong>willow purple</strong>. 'Wait a sec, now everyone's gonna be able to find it!"" So I painted all the other willows purple as well. Now I'm in trouble..."					RTK3
椋		Oriental elm				2540			リョウ	むく	The<strong> Oriental elm</strong> is, of course, a <em>tree</em> fairly representative of the Orient and thus it is common in the <em>capital</em> in order to show ambassadors what the Orient is all about.	"In the Japanese remake ""A Nightmare on<strong> Oriental Elm</strong> Street"", an anthropomorphic <em>tree</em> wreaks havoc on <em>Kyoto</em>. They should never have sold the film rights."					RTK3
榛		hazel				2541			シン、 ハン	はしばみ、 はり	"Tip: <em>bonsai</em> and <em>wheat</em> are later combined into <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%A7%A6"">秦</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2889</span>). Story: I come across lots of <em>trees</em> all planted in the <em>Manchu dynasty</em>. Then I notice every single one is a<strong> hazel</strong> tree. I wonder why? In the <em>Manchu dynasty</em> people must have been<strong> hazel</strong> nuts."	I love<strong> hazel</strong>nuts so much that I had a<strong> hazel</strong> <em>tree</em> installed in my backyard. Mostly it's just for decoration, like a <em>bonsai</em> plant, but I harvest it like <em>wheat</em> every so often: there's just nothing better than homemade Nutella.					RTK3
櫛		comb				2542			シツ	くし、 くしけず.る	This magic<strong> comb</strong> will<strong> comb</strong> the <em>nodes</em> out of <em>wood/trees</em> (and make the grain straight).	Simply put: A<strong> comb</strong> is a wooden tool that removes nodes in the hair.					RTK3
槌		wooden hammer				2543			ツイ	つち	Sick of being <em>chased</em>, the <em>maestro</em> grabs a <strong><em>wooden</em> hammer</strong> to fight back with.	When the <em>trees</em> rebel, they will chase us with <strong>wooden hammers</strong>.					RTK3
樵		mallet				2544			ショウ	きこ.る、 こ.る、 きこり	<strong>Mallet</strong> seems to be a poor word choice for this A <strong>lumberjack</strong> won't cut down a <em>charred tree</em> as they're not useful for anything.	A <em>charred tree</em> can be toppled with a<strong> mallet</strong>.					RTK3
梯		ladder				2545			テイ、 タイ	はしご	The <em>tree</em> was a little too high, but, hey, no problem, I'll just use my <em>younger brother</em> as a<strong> ladder</strong>! 杭		picket				2547			コウ	くい	Use<strong> picket</strong>s to hold down the <em>tree</em> in times of <em>whirlwind</em>.	After the <em>whirlwind</em> hit, the <em>wooden</em> <strong>pickets</strong> from his fence were scattered all over his yard.					RTK3
柊		holly				2548			シュ、 シュウ	ひいらぎ	The<strong> holly</strong> <em>tree</em> has leaves which are always green. This is very practical in <em>winter</em>, when so much isn't, so that's why it became very popular as christmas decoration. "In keeping with the move to greener autos Citroën has introduced its new line which instead of 油 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%B2%B9"">油</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1107</span>) runs on an extract from<strong> citron</strong> <em>trees</em>."					RTK3
椀		wooden bowl				2550			ワン	はち	<strong>Wooden bowl</strong>s made of <em>wood</em> have the <em>address</em> of the maker on the on the side.	This is a specially hand-crafted <em>wooden</em> bowl. If you turn is over, you can see the <em>address</em> of the craftsman on the bottom.					RTK3
栂		hemlock				2551				つが、 とが	The <em>tree</em> your <em>mother</em> warned you about is the<strong> hemlock</strong>.	"This is not a poison<strong> hemlock</strong>! It is a tree from genus Tsuga (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga_sieboldii). According to Wikipedia ""The common name<strong> hemlock</strong> is derived from a perceived similarity in the smell of its crushed foliage to that of the unrelated plant poison<strong> hemlock</strong>. Unlike poison<strong> hemlock</strong> (conium), the species of Tsuga are not poisonous."" Story: In ancient Japan <em>mother</em>s planted<strong> hemlock</strong> <em>tree</em> in their gardens when child was born."					RTK3
柾		spindle tree				2552				まさ、 まさめ、 まさき	Give the<strong> spindle tree</strong> a spin, if you can guess where it lands <em>correctly</em>, you'll get a prize!	"<strong>Spindle tree</strong> or Euonymus japonicus (botanical name). Far from being ""spindly"", this tree is bushy and evergreen, thus making ideal hedging for those seeking privacy. So if you want to be anonymous, ""Euonymus"" is the <em>correct tree</em> to choose."					RTK3
榊		sacred tree				2553				さかき	The sacred Shinto tree is a <em>tree</em> of the <em>gods</em>.	"This kanji is a 国字 (こくじ) i.e. created in Japan. Logically it combines <em>tree</em> 木 + <em>gods</em> 神 giving us a ""tree of the gods"" (<strong>sacred Shinto tree</strong>). Note: 榊 (さかき) has 2 variants where middle element is either 礻or 示."					RTK3
樫		evergreen oak				2554				かし	The<strong> evergreen oak</strong> is a <em>tree</em> most <em>strict</em> with its leaves: they must be <strong>evergreen</strong>, or else!	A very <em>strict</em> master dictates that the slaves must ensure that the <strong>evergreen oaks</strong> are ever green. One day a slave notices, to his terror, that one of them has turned brown! Not wanting to get buried up to his crotch in soil, he quickly pulls out a can of green spray paint and paints the entire <em>tree</em>. Even if that tree wasn't ever green before, it certainly is now!					RTK3
槙		black pine				2555			テン、 シン	まき、 こずえ	The tree of white lies is the Chinese white pine. The <em>tree</em> of <em>truth</em> is the Chinese<strong> black pine</strong>.	"<em>Truth</em> is that all <strong>Chinese</strong> secretly <strong>pine</strong> for <strong>black</strong> ""<em>trees</em>"" if you get what I mean!"					RTK3
楢		Japanese oak				2556			シュウ、 ユウ	なら	The special brand <em>Horned Whiskey</em> is riped in special oak caskets made of the<strong> Japanese oak</strong> <em>tree</em>.	"<em>Wood</em> from the<strong> Japanese oak</strong> is very valuable. That's why the <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%85%8B"">酋</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2915</span>) demands that his house be made from the<strong> Japanese oak</strong>."					RTK3
橘		mandarin orange				2557			キツ	たちばな	"The tachibana, or<strong> mandarin orange</strong>, is a type of <em>tree</em> which sometimes yields poor quality fruit. In such times, instead of simply <em>standing up</em> and inviting customers to <em>make a deal</em>, you must force the sale of your<strong> mandarin orange</strong>s by brandishing a <em>halberd</em> and forcing the customer to <em>make a deal</em> with you by purchasing your substandard fruit. [Note: along with 柚 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%9F%91"">柑</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2546</span>), this is used to describe all citrus plants - 柑橘類 かんきつるい means 'citrus fruit'.]"	The peddlar who likes to <em>make a deal</em> stepped off his motorcycle helmet and took his <em>halberd</em> to try and get some<strong> mandarin orange</strong>s off the <em>tree</em>.					RTK3
桧		Japanese cypress				2558			カイ	ひのき、 ひ	"According to the Wikipedia article,<strong> Japanese cypress</strong> (hinoki) is grown for its high-quality <em>wood</em>, which is used in the building of ""temples, shrines, traditional noh theatres, baths"" etc. So, this tree is vital to the construction of many of the major <em>meeting places</em> in Japanese society. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamaecyparis_obtusa."	Japanese science fiction company CyPress have the weekly staff <em>meeting</em> under the <strong>Japanese cypress</strong> <em>tree</em> (its symbolic).					RTK3
棲		roost				2559			セイ	す.む	My <em>wife</em> wanted a special place to<strong> roost</strong>, so I built her one - on the top of that <em>tree</em>.	"Better meaning is ""habitat"" since this doesn't imply anything bird or nest related. Usual habitat for the wife is in a wood structure of some sort (avoiding using house to keep it out of the kanji)."					RTK3
栖		nestle				2560			セイ	す.む	For <strong>nestling</strong>, the <em>west</em> side of the <em>tree</em> is best – otherwise you get woken up by the sun in the morning. Remember: West is best for your nest.	Its a secret that <strong>Nestlé</strong> chocolate syrup is drawn from chocolate <em>trees</em> that are found in the <em>west</em>.					RTK3
桔		bellflower				2561			キツ、 ケツ		When you see<strong> bellflower</strong>s next to a <em>tree</em>, ring them for <em>good luck</em>.	When you see<strong> bellflower</strong>s growing under a <em>tree</em>, it means <em>good luck</em>.					RTK3
杜		temple grove				2562			ト、 トウ、 ズ	もり、 ふさ.ぐ、 やまなし	A normal grove is 林, so in a<strong> temple grove</strong> half the <em>trees</em> have been removed and replaced by <em>soil</em> (presumably for graves).	"杜氏, 杜撰, 鎮守の杜, 杜絶=途絶 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%9D%9C"">杜</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2562</span>) ズ, トウ, ト, もり ... Parts:木, 土 (cf 社<a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%A4%BE"">社</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1173</span>)) ... Note: Important unrelated usage: 杜氏 <strong>Master Brewer</strong> ... Story:A simple Zen<strong> temple grove</strong>: A single <em>tree</em> with <em>soil</em>. in the Zen tradition, things are said by what is said as well as what is not said, and things have an esoteric and exoteric meaning. Thus the single tree stands for a grove (exoteric) as well as reading as it it were a forest (esoteric)　."					RTK3
杷		grain rake				2563			ハ	つか	All the grain that was spilled under the <em>tree</em> looked like a <em>mosaic</em>, but someone took a<strong> grain rake</strong> and disposed of it.	Dad gave me a<strong> grain rake</strong> and told me to go and rake the grain, but since this is the most boring task in the whole world, I climbed a <em>tree</em> and played with my <em>Rubik's cube</em> instead. 梶		oar				2564			ビ	かじ、 こずえ	An<strong> oar</strong> looks a little like a <em>wooden tail</em>.	An otter's <em>tail</em> like an<strong> oar</strong>, which he uses to help move <em>trees</em> into his dam.					RTK3
杵		wooden pestle				2565			ショ、 ソ	きね	Tree, horse: At cooking school, I learned that there's always a relation between the item you will pestle and the size of the pestle itself. 杖		cane				2566			ジョウ	つえ	<em>Wood</em> of a certain <em>length</em> can be used as a<strong> cane</strong>. 樽		barrel				2567			ソン	たる	The most <em>revered tree</em> is one that can be used as a wine<strong> barrel</strong>.	The <em>revered</em> horned whiskey is riped in special<strong> barrel</strong>s made out of Japanese Oak <em>trees</em>.					RTK3

橿		sturdy oak				2569			キョウ	かし、 もちのき	A<strong> sturdy oak</strong> was the <em>tree</em> I tried to build with my <em>stack of pancakes and waffles</em>, but it didn't turn out to be so sturdy. 杓		wooden ladle				2570			シャク、 チョウ、 テキ、 ヒョウ	ひしゃく	A<strong> wooden ladle</strong> is of course a <em>ladle</em> made out of <em>wood</em>.	A<strong> wooden ladle</strong> is a<strong> wooden ladle</strong> is a<strong> wooden ladle</strong>.					RTK3

棉		raw cotton				2572			メン	わた	"Before <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%B6%BF"">綿</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1467</span>) is made into thread for Spider-Man's <em>white towels</em>, it simply grows on a <em>tree</em> as<strong> raw cotton</strong>." 楯		escutcheon				2573			ジュン	たて	<strong>Escutcheon</strong>s are noble <em>shields</em> that depict the coat of arms of a family. They are usually made out of <em>wood</em>.	<strong>Escutcheons</strong> are heraldic displays, often found on <em>shields</em> and made of <em>wood</em>.					RTK3
榎		hackberry				2574			カ	えのき	A Japanese<strong> hackberry</strong> <em>tree</em> is a type of tree that only has full foliage in the <em>summer</em>. It loses its foliage in the winter. 樺		birch				2575			カ	かば、 かんば	A<strong> birch</strong> <em>tree</em> can have a great aura of <em>splendor</em> with it's shiny white coated trunk. 槍		lance				2576			ソウ、 ショウ	やり	When Sir<strong> Lance</strong>lot wants a new<strong> lance</strong> he goes down to the <em>godown</em> (they have a nice selection for sale) and tries some out by thrusting them into a nearby <em>tree</em>.	Sir<strong> Lance</strong>lot gets wood when she godowns. -or-<strong> Lance</strong> Bass gets wood thinking about Sir<strong> Lance</strong>lot godowning on him.					RTK3
柘		wild mulberry				2577			シャ、 ジャク	そ、 つげ、 やまぐわ	"The <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A1%91"">桑</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#754</span>) may be nice and let you dance around it, but if it were a<strong> wild mulberry</strong> <em>tree</em> it would try to protectiself by throwing <em>rock</em>s at you."	If you smoke the leaves of the<strong> wild mulberry</strong> <em>tree</em>, you'll get <em>stoned</em> fo sho coz that tree is wild, brother.					RTK3
梱		bale				2578			コン	こう.る、 こうり、 こり、 しきみ	How do make a<strong> bale</strong>? Simple. You take a <em>tree</em>, like the one on the left, and you <em>pent it up</em> like the one on the right. Just like that.	You would be in a <em>quandary</em> if you had to<strong> bale</strong> <em>trees</em>.					RTK3
枇		loquat				2579			ビ、 ヒ		A<strong> loquat</strong> is a tropical fruit <em>tree</em>, that <em>compared</em> to other trees has an odd seasonal pattern: it's fruit is ripe in late winter or early spring.	The<strong> loquat</strong> tree is very rare. To<strong> loquat</strong>e it, you need to <em>compare</em> it to the <em>trees</em> next to it.					RTK3
樋		downspout				2580			トウ	ひ、 とい	"A<strong> downspout</strong> is made by hollowing out a <em>tree</em> and placing it to carry water ""<em>traffic</em>"" from your rooftop down to the ground."	"My<strong> downspout</strong> empties into a <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A1%B6"">桶</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2590</span>) 桶 beside the <em>road</em>."					RTK3

栞		bookmark				2583			カン	しおり	"<em>Two</em> birds high up in a <em>tree</em> <em>drying</em> out after flying through a storm. ""How will we get back on track? I love to use dried leaves as<strong> bookmark</strong>s. Every time I go by a tree, I pluck off a couple of leaves and then dry them to later use as<strong> bookmark</strong>s.					RTK3
椰		coconut tree				2584			ヤ	やし	"(Note: <em>ear</em> + <em>city walls</em> = <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%80%B6"">耶</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2720</span>)). I see a <em>tree</em> with an <em>exclamation</em> mark painted on it. ""Why is that?"" I think, ""An <em>exclamation</em> mark indicates danger, but it's only a <em>tree</em>"". Then a coconut drops on my head. Ah, it's a<strong> coconut tree</strong>."	"A<strong> coconut tree</strong> drops a coconut on your head, causing you to make an obscene <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%80%B6"">耶</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2720</span>)."					RTK3

樗		sumac				2586			チョ	おおち、 おうち	We were seeking shelter for the <em>rain</em> under the plotosid <em>tree</em>, but someone had put a <em>double snare</em> there. As if that foul smelling tree wasn't enough trouble already.	~~ Keyword should be <strong>sumac</strong> ~~ <strong>Sumacs</strong> are worthless <em>trees</em>. They don't protect from <em>rain</em> so you shouldn't use them for a <em>ceiling</em> - and they stink so you can't use them to make <em>snares</em>.					RTK3

椙		cryptomeria				2588				すぎ	Due its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the<strong> cryptomeria</strong> has been a fairly <em>prosperous tree</em> whereas all the other <em>trees</em> have already fallen prey to espionage.	The<strong> cryptomeria</strong> （すぎ） is a <em>tree</em> that enjoys <em>prosperity</em> in Japan because it's written kanji is like an encrypted form of the more infamous スギ（杉） which causes hay fever. When successful it makes a very satisfying ""clang"". (Note: new primitive <em>pogo stick</em> = <em>chop seal</em> + <em>utilize</em>, for explanation see my entry at <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%80%9A"">通</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1408</span>).)" 樒		star-anise				2592			ミツ	しきみ、 じんこう	The<strong> star-anise</strong> is an evergreen <em>tree</em> kept in <em>secrecy</em> for it's aromatic oil.	This kanji 樒 (しきみ・しきび) refers to Japanese<strong> star-anise</strong>. Its evergreen branches are popular for placing at graves. It’s very poisonous. The edible spice of the same name 八角 (はっかく) is from the closely related Chinese<strong> star-anise</strong> 大茴香 (ダイウイキョウ). Both species produce almost identical fruits. STORY: A batch of Chinese<strong> star-anise</strong> was adulterated with its poisonous Japanese namesake. Great <em>secrecy</em> surrounds the incident. Was it an innocent <em>tree</em> mixup or coverup?					RTK3

燿		twinkle				2594			ヨウ	かがや.く、 ひかり	New primitive; let <em>futon</em> = <em>feathers</em> + <em>turkey</em> (i.e. my futon is made with turkey feathers). Then:<strong> Twinkle</strong>,<strong> twinkle</strong> little star, oops my <em>futon</em> is on <em>fire</em>.	Tuesday is <strong>twinkle</strong> day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 火 + 曜 = 燿 + 日. 玖		jet				2617			キュウ、 ク		I spent <em>a long time</em> polishing the <em>king</em>'s jewelry until it was all<strong> jet</strong>-black just like he ordered. 瑛		crystal stone				2618			エイ		He who possesses the<strong> crystal stone</strong> is the rightful <em>king</em> of <em>England</em>.	[+Aerin] Pretty much everything in <em>England</em> is fake. That includes the power of the <em>king</em> (it's a queen now, I know, but still) - everything is handled by the real government, and that post is just a symbol. Appropriately, then, the PM gets all the real diamonds, while the royalty gets the<strong> crystal stone</strong> decorated items.<strong> Crystal stone</strong>, of course, is just a nice way of saying rhinestones. 玲		tinkling				2619			レイ		When the <em>king</em> barks out his <em>orders</em>, all the chandeliers and other ornaments in the palace start<strong> tinkling</strong>. 畢		lastly				2620			ヒツ	おわ.る、 あみ、 おわ.り、 ことごとく	First, we sow the <em>rice field</em>, then we plant the <em>flowers</em>, and<strong> lastly</strong> we plant the <em>corn</em>. 畦		paddy-field ridge				2621			ケイ	あぜ、 うね	<em>Ivy</em> grows on the<strong> paddy-field ridge</strong> encircling the <em>rice field</em> as opposed to the intra-field paddy ridge that divides it in half.	"[+mantixen] The ordinary 畔 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%95%94"">畔</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1288</span>) dissects the <em>field</em> by dividing it in <em>half</em>, but the<strong> paddy-field ridge</strong> runs around the outside &amp; is covered in <em>ivy</em>. Disambiguate by noting that the hyphen in 'paddy-ridge' divides the word itself in <em>half</em> (five letters each side) but 'paddy-field ridge' has five extra letters on the right, the ridge itself, in fact, the part covered in <em>ivy</em>."					RTK3
痒		itch				2622			ヨウ	かゆ.がる、 かさ、 かゆ.い	If you think wearing a wool sweater is<strong> itch</strong>y, just think of how <em>sheep</em> must feel! 癌		cancer				2626			ガン		The SICKNESS called<strong> cancer</strong> works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more &amp; more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you-- that's the tumor, the awful sign of<strong> cancer</strong>. 眸		apple of the eye				2628			ボウ、 ム	ひとみ	Here you have a picture of him with his<strong> apple of the eye</strong>: you see him keeping an <em>eye</em> upon his favourite <em>cow</em>, while leaning on it with his <em>elbow</em>. 眩		dizzy				2629			ゲン、 カン	げん.す、 くるめ.く、 まぶ.しい、 くら.む、 まど.う、 めま.い、 まばゆ.い、 くれ.る、 ま.う	If you see <em>mysterious</em> things in front of your <em>eyes</em> you're definitely<strong> dizzy</strong>. 磐		crag				2632			バン、 ハン	いわ	If you want to take all the <em>stones</em> out of this<strong> crag</strong>, you'll need a large <em>carrier</em>.	Last time I was on <em>crag's list</em>, I found someone selling an <em>aircraft carrier</em> they carved out of <em>stone</em>! A crazy lawn ornament I suppose.					RTK3
碇		grapnel				2633			テイ	いかり	A<strong> grapnel</strong> is a small anchor with several hooks, used for anchoring small boats, or to pull up sunken objects (it looks very much like a grappling hook). The position of <em>stones</em> underwater <em>determines</em> where the<strong> grapnel</strong> will catch.	He was <em>determined</em> to climb this <em>rock</em>, so he used a<strong> grapnel</strong>.					RTK3
碧		blue-green				2634			ヘキ、 ヒャク		"Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means ""amber"". Story for both: A bus is stopped at some traffic lights in Japan. Inside, <em>King</em> Henry VIII and Barry <em>White</em> are arguing over whether the lights are yellow or <em>amber</em>. The lights change to ""Go"", and Mick Jagger (<em>stone</em>) then joins a new argument over whether the lights are blue or green. They compromise on<strong> blue-green</strong>."	The rarest form of <em>amber</em> is a<strong> blue-green</strong> <em>stone</em>. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_amber).					RTK3
硯		inkstone				2635			ケン、 ゲン	すずり	This is not an ordinary <em>rock</em>, if you look carefully you will <em>see</em> that it is an ancient<strong> inkstone</strong>.	A magical<strong> inkstone</strong> was made in ancient China that was able to mix invisible ink. When the ink dried, the surface it adhered to became invisible. Unfortunately, someone used it once and forgot to wash the <em>stone</em> thoroughly afterwards, and when the ink dried the magical<strong> inkstone</strong> was never <em>seen</em> again.					RTK3
砥		grindstone				2636			シ、 テイ、 キイ、 チ	と、 といし、 と.ぐ、 みが.く	In Bedrock, people had <em>business cards</em> made of <em>rock</em> and engraved using a<strong> grindstone</strong>. (Big ups to Katsuo).	My <em>calling card</em> is made of <em>rock</em>, which is a bit inconvenient because it is so big &amp; heavy. So I’m using a<strong> grindstone</strong> to grind it down in size.					RTK3
碗		teacup				2637			ワン	こばち	<strong>Teacup</strong>s at the Japanese restaurant are usually made of stone and have the name and address of the restaurant written on them.	"Similarly to the <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A4%80"">椀</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2550</span>), the<strong> teacup</strong> made of <em>stone</em> has it's makers <em>address</em> carved into the bottom." 碍		obstacle				2638			ガイ、 ゲ	さまた.げる	Those gremlins! At <em>night break</em> they insist on coming out and <em>gluing</em> <em>stones</em> all over the place. These<strong> obstacle</strong>s make it nearly impossible for me to get to work!	"You <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%BE%97"">得</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#941</span>) 得 when you make forward progress. If you encounter a <em>rock</em>, you <em>cannot go</em> forward. Perhaps you can go round. This is an<strong> obstacle</strong>."					RTK3
碩		illustrious				2639			セキ	おお.きい	Mount Rushmore is a place in the US where the <em>heads</em> of<strong> illustrious</strong> presidents are carved into the <em>stone</em> of a cliff.	The<strong> illustrious</strong> <em>stone heads</em> of Easter Island.					RTK3
磯		rocky beach				2640			キ	いそ	To qualify as a<strong> rocky beach</strong> (as opposed to a sandy beach), <em>how many stones</em> does the beach need?	"""<em>How many stones</em> can you find at a<strong> rocky beach</strong>?"" the Zen Master asked his baffled pupil."					RTK3
砺		whetstone				2641			レイ	あらと、 みが.く	What<em>stone</em> would make the best<strong> whetstone</strong>? I wandered <em>ten thousand cliffs</em> in search of an answer.	A<strong> whetstone</strong> so notorious that it had destroyed <em>ten thousand cliffs</em>.					RTK3
碓		mill				2642			カク、 タイ	たし.か、 かく.たる	Some<strong> mill</strong>s use an animal, typically an ox or donkey, to rotate the stone. But in this<strong> mill</strong> the <em>stone</em> is being pulled round by a <em>turkey</em>.	I can tell you, it was a big mess when a <em>turkey</em> accidentally came between the <em>stones</em> of the wind<strong> mill</strong>. We had to clean the blood and feathers away for ages. 禦		fend off				2643			ギョ、 ゴ	ふせ.ぐ	The beautiful woman has to<strong> fend off</strong> <em>honorable</em> admirers every day, who want to drag her to the <em>altar</em> and marry her.	Tired of <strong>fending off</strong> your pregnant girlfriend's remarks, you do the <em>honorable</em> thing and take her to the <em>altar</em>.					RTK3
祷		beseech				2644			トウ	いの.る、 いの.り、 まつ.る	If you want <em>longevity</em>, go to an <em>altar</em> and<strong> beseech</strong> the gods.	Altar, longevity: Having seen all his friends and family die so long ago, the ancient sage visited the <em>altar</em> and <strong>beseeched</strong> the gods to put an end to his <em>longevity</em>. 祐		ancestral tablet				2645			ユウ、 ウ	たす.ける	Picture a Japanese <em>altar</em> that contains<strong> ancestral tablet</strong>s, placed on the <em>right</em> (on the left would be the incense).	<strong>Divine intervention</strong> is what happens when things go <em>right</em> at the <em>altar</em>.					RTK3
祇		local god				2646			ギ、 キ、 シ	くにつかみ、 ただ、 まさに	"From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto: Whenever a child is born in Japan, a local Shinto shrine adds the child's name to a list kept at the shrine and declares him or her a ""family child"" (氏子 ujiko?). After death an ujiko becomes a ""family spirit"", or ""family kami"" (氏神 ujigami?). Therefore, if your <em>family name</em> is inscribed in the <em>altar</em>, then you will become a <strong>local god</strong>."	The <em>altar</em> dedicated to this<strong> local god</strong> has the <em>family names</em> of all the villagers inscribed in it, so that the god knows whom he should favour.					RTK3
祢		ancestral shrine				2647			ネ、 デイ、 ナイ		The<strong> ancestral shrine</strong> has an <em>altar</em> that shows <em>little</em> <em>reclining</em> figurines of ancestors.	Just a note: This is a rarely used kanji, the unsimplified version, 禰 , is far more common, and seeing as we're trying to be kanji masters, we'd all might as well use the traditional (correct) version.					RTK3
禄		salarium				2648			ロク	さいわ.い、 ふち	Ancient Japanese officials collected their<strong> salarium</strong> in the shrines. A priest would collect their <em>rice grains</em> with a <em>broom</em>, and sweep it unto the <em>altar</em>, where the officials could collect their rice.	Rather than cold hard cash, the <em>rice</em> that the <em>altar</em> boys could <em>sweep</em> up became their<strong> salarium</strong>.					RTK3
禎		felicitation				2649			テイ	さいわ.い	When the wheelchair-bound Felicity was healed at the <em>altar</em> (by one of those healer priests), she was finally able to stand <em>upright</em> and was overcome by<strong> felicitation</strong>.	On the special festival day, the <em>altar</em> of the local shrine contains the<strong> felicitation</strong>s of local <em>upright</em> citizens, thanking their local gods for doing such a good job.					RTK3
秤		balancing scales				2650			ショウ、 ヒン、 ビン	はかり	I use<strong> balancing scales</strong> to make sure everyone gets an <em>even</em> amount of <em>Wheaties</em>.	Before the technology of<strong> balancing scales</strong> was widely available, farmers used to sell their <em>wheat</em> grain using the following method: customers would visit, and shovel as much <em>wheat</em> grain as they could onto a giant <em>lilypad</em>. They were allowed as much as they could pile on, and they were charged according to the number of <em>lilypads</em> they filled. This ensured that the greedy were punished, because if the lilypad sunk under the weight, they were still charged for the grain.					RTK3
黍		millet				2651			ショ	きび	"<strong>Millet</strong> is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by <em>wheat</em>, and in the East (""under the bamboo <em>umbrella</em>""), by <em>rice</em>."	"黍, 砂糖黍, 唐黍, 黍団子(吉備団子), 玉蜀黍, <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%BB%8D"">黍</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2651</span>) キビ ... Parts: 禾, 人, 氺... OR ノ, 漆-氵 (cf: 漆<a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%BC%86"">漆</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1001</span>), 黎明<a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%BB%8E"">黎</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2942</span>), 膝<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%86%9D"">膝</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1002</span>), 鳥黐<a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%BB%90"">黐</a>) ... Note:Historical Radical 部首＃202 ... Backwards Story:<em>Lacquer</em>漆 is actually made from<strong> millet</strong>: It's<strong> Millet</strong> with the <em>husk removed</em> (-ノ), then mixed with <em>water</em> (+氵)."					RTK3
禿		bald				2652			トク	ちび.る、 かむろ、 は.げる、 はげ	The dude was so upset about going<strong> bald</strong> that he covered himself with a <em>wheat</em> sack so that only his <em>legs</em> were showing.	A<strong> bald</strong> man uses some wheat as a toupee. The wheat is a bit long, so only his legs show underneath.					RTK3
稔		bear fruit				2653			ネン、 ジン、 ニン	みの.る、 みのり	Every day, the farmer works in his <em>wheat</em> field, making a <em>wish</em> that his hard labor will<strong> bear fruit</strong>.	I <em>wish</em> <em>Wheaties</em> would<strong> bear fruit</strong>... Then I wouldn't have to add any myself!					RTK3
稗		crabgrass				2654			ハイ、 ヒ	ひえ	<strong>Crabgrass</strong> is <em>lowly</em> wild grass, quickly spreading with nasty roots, and difficult to remove out of your <em>wheat</em> field.	<strong>Japanese barnyard millet</strong> (Echinochloa utilis). In Japan's past, this type of millet was grown where conditions were not suitable for rice paddies. It was far more common than <em>wheat</em> and helped to alleviate starvation when rice was damaged by cold weather. However since then it has become quite a <em>lowly</em> grain and is only grown in northern Iwate-ken.					RTK3
穣		bumper crop				2655			ジョウ	わら、 ゆたか	A<strong> bumper crop</strong> is a very full crop. In this particular case, the<strong> bumper crop</strong> is a <em>wheat</em> crop, grown by this excentric guy in a <em>grass skirt</em>, who has gone completely native, but knows the secrets of how to get a good crop!	The <em>hula girl</em> dances around the <em>wheat</em>, and this appeases the deities so they give them a<strong> bumper crop</strong>.					RTK3
稜		imperial authority				2656			リョウ、 ロウ	いつ、 かど	Wheat, rice seedling, walking legs: The next hurdle for mission of the <em>rice seedlings with walking legs</em> was the<strong> imperial authority</strong>. They had to cross through a <em>wheat</em> field, but the<strong> imperial authority</strong> didn't give permission for rice seedlings and wheat to mix. How to solve this...?	"I changed the keyword to <strong>ridge</strong> because it seems to be more often used in mountain ridge and so many medical words for body parts involving a crest or ridge. (I use ""tripping on shrooms"" as the keyword for 夌 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%A4%8C"">夌</a>.) Story: After <em>tripping on shrooms</em>, the <strong>ridge</strong> seemed to be a good place to plant <em>wheat</em>."					RTK3
稀		sparse				2657			キ、 ケ	まれ、 まばら	This region only has<strong> sparse</strong> agriculture. The few farmers <em>hope</em> their <em>wheat</em> crops will do well, but the soil isn't really good.	Food is<strong> sparse</strong>, so the <em>wheat</em> crops are now their only <em>hope</em>.					RTK3
穆		obeisant				2658			ボク、 モク	やわ.らぐ	I'm being<strong> obeisant</strong> to Doctor's orders -- trying to get into <em>shape</em> by eating only <em>wheat</em> and drinking only from that <em>spring</em>. 窄		tight				2660			サク	すぼ.める、 つぼ.める、 せま.い	That <em>hole</em> is still too<strong> tight</strong>. Bring the <em>saw</em> to enlarge it! Pfft, just use this here <em>tusk</em> as a<strong> drill</strong> and make all the <em>holes</em> you can!					RTK3
竃		kitchen stove				2662			ソウ	かまど、 かま、 へっつい	The original Japanese<strong> kitchen stove</strong>s were powered by <em>electric eels</em> (hey, Edison never made it to the far east!), so a small <em>hole</em> had to be placed in the <em>dirt</em> under the stove (for the <em>eels</em> to swim around in). 竪		longness				2663			ジュ	たて、 た.てる、 こども	When you're a <em>slave</em> to your <em>crotch</em> like me, you're often afraid to <em>stand</em> because you don't want people to see your<strong> longness</strong>. 妾		concubine				2667			ショウ	めかけ、 そばめ、 わらわ	"It's a<strong> concubine</strong>: feel free to <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%8E%A5"">接</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#725</span>) her all you want."	A<strong> concubine</strong> is a <em>woman</em> you can <em>stand</em> on and walk all over. She does not have the same status as a wife. The contrast can be seen in the compound: 妻妾 (one's wife and mistresses). Both are <em>women</em>; however, the wife gets a <em>brush</em> for her hair; whereas the<strong> concubine</strong> is <em>stood</em> upon and trampled.					RTK3
衿		lapel				2668			キン、 コン	えり	Cloak, clock: The <em>cloaks</em> of Muslims have a tiny <em>clock</em> on their<strong> lapel</strong>, so that they can keep track on when to pray... 袷		lined kimono				2669			コウ、 キョウ	あわせ	Cloak, fit: The<strong> lined kimono</strong> was lined in such a way that it made people appear to be slimmer than they really were. Girls all <strong>lined</strong> up in front of the <em>cloakroom</em> in the department store to be <em>fitted</em> with <strong>lined kimonos</strong> for their coming of age ceremony.					RTK3
袴		pleated skirt				2670			コ、 ク	はかま、 ずぼん	"You can 誇 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%AA%87"">誇</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1332</span>) with words, or you can instead show off your expensive <em>cloak</em> and <strong>hakama</strong>."	"袴, 紋付羽織袴, (人名: 袴田) <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A2%B4"">袴</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2670</span>) はかま ... Parts:衤, 夸 (cf: 跨ぐ<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%B7%A8"">跨</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2772</span>), 誇る<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%AA%87"">誇</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1332</span>) ... Note: The RHS 夸 (not a Kanji itself), actually appears in other Kanji (袴(桍)<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A2%B4"">袴</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2670</span>), 跨<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%B7%A8"">跨</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2772</span>), 誇<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%AA%87"">誇</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1332</span>), 胯). So a primitive of Dog Catcher (Dog on the floor caught in a snare)? ... 襖		sliding door				2671			オウ	ふすま、 あお	Before you open the<strong> sliding door</strong> to the <em>core</em> of the nuclear reactor, you'd better put on your anti-radioactivity <em>cloak</em>.	The safety violations at Japanese nuclear power plants are egregious! Not only are they built inside ancient Japanese castles, there are no considerations for contamination. I was visiting last month when I opened a <strong>sliding door</strong> to reveal the <em>cloak</em> room. All the scientists had haphazardly piled their <em>cloaks</em> on the <em>CORE</em> itself!					RTK3
笙		Chinese panpipe				2672			ショウ、 ソウ	ふえ	The<strong> Chinese panpipe</strong> is an old musical instrument made of <em>bamboo</em>. People practiced the<strong> Chinese panpipe</strong> their whole <em>life</em> just so that they could play for the emperor, often a bad performance would have the emperor take their <em>life</em> away from them.	Pan plays a <strong>Chinese panpipe</strong>, fashioned of <em>bamboo</em>, to instill <em>life</em> within the people.					RTK3
筏		raft				2673			バツ、 ハツ、 ボチ	いかだ	The <em>bamboo</em> was <em>felled</em> to make a<strong> raft</strong>.	Bamboo, fell: To escape the forestfire, the pandas <em>felled</em> some of the <em>bamboo</em> to make a<strong> raft</strong> and escape.					RTK3
簾		bamboo blinds				2674			レン	すだれ、 す	I see a load of <em>bamboo</em> for sale at a <em>bargain</em> price and decide it’s so cheap that I’ll buy it and make my own<strong> bamboo blinds</strong>.	<strong>Bamboo blinds</strong> are pretty shitty so you can usually find them at <em>bargain</em> prices. 箆		spatula				2677			ヘイ、 ハイ	へら、 の、 くし	"<em>Compared</em> to before when Japanese mothers used to throw a <em>hood</em> over their naughty kids and beat them bloody with <em>bamboo</em>, the modern ""kitchen-discipline by <strong>spatula</strong>"" seems much more civilized."	<em>Compare</em> the effectiveness of beating a <em>person</em> with <em>bamboo</em>, a <em>belt</em>, and a<strong> spatula</strong>. 箔		foil				2678			ハク	すだれ	If I have any <em>bamboo</em> shoots left over from my stirfry I wrap them up in <em>foil</em> to keep them moist <em>overnight</em>. Then I can use them the next day. 笥		wardrobe				2679			ス、 シ	け、 はこ	"The film director is making a new low budget version of ""The Lion the Witch and the<strong> Wardrobe</strong>"". 箭		arrow shaft				2680			セン	や	Bamboo, in front: Martial arts movie. 筑		ancient harp				2681			チク		I can't play this<strong> ancient harp</strong>! It's <em>craft</em>smanship is so <em>mediocre</em>! The <em>bamboo</em> is hard and stiff! 篠		slender bamboo				2682			ゾウ、 ショウ	しの、 ささ、 すず	Mr T uses a stick of<strong> slender bamboo</strong> to beat his taskmaster that he chased up into the tree.	The <em>wise sensei</em> instructs <em>Mr. T</em> while they perch atop a <em>tree</em>: Oh, you must be supple and thin like the<strong> slender bamboo</strong>!					RTK3
纂		redaction				2683			サン	あつ.める	"During post-production of a movie,<strong> redaction</strong> is required for ""red action"", or action that results in a bloody accident, like when they mis<em>calculated</em> how <em>large</em> an object <em>Spider-Man</em> could hold up with both hands."	Calculate, st bernard, venom: <em>Venom</em> had made an insidious plan to strike at the <strong>redaction</strong> office of the Daily Bugle, to scare the free press. He plans to leave corpses of dead <em>St.Bernards</em> on every desk of the news office. Now, he still needs to <em>calculate</em> how many <em>St. Bernards</em> are required...					RTK3
竺		bamboo cane				2684			ジク、 チク、 トク		My<strong> bamboo cane</strong> is collapsible. It can fold into <em>two</em> separate <em>bamboo</em> sticks. 箕		winnowing fan				2685			キ	み	The hard working peasants get a little annoyed watching the aristocrats sitting around playing <em>chess</em>, so they start a revolt and whack the chess board and pieces away with their <em>bamboo</em> <em>winnowing baskets.</em>	The <em>chess</em> player has a <em>bamboo</em> fan that he brings along to his matches for good luck. It has the power to make the user WIN NOW. Thus it is a<strong> winnowing fan</strong>.					RTK3
笈		backpack				2686			キュウ		I see a panda wearing a<strong> backpack</strong>, and every so often something inside the<strong> backpack</strong> <em>reaches out</em> and grabs <em>bamboo</em>. (it’s acutally a baby panda reaching out to grab bamboo to eat). 篇		livraison				2687			ヘン		Each<strong> livraison</strong> (installment) of the <em>scrapbook</em> is delivered by post, and sits resting on your <em>doorstep</em> for when you get home. Of course, it might blow away so the postman has put heavy <em>bamboo blocks</em> on top of it.	Bamboo, konbini hentai: The special issue of the popular <em>konbini hentai</em> is divided into different <strong>livraisons</strong> (installment). Each comes with a small piece of <em>bamboo</em>, which are - after obtaining all <strong>livraisons</strong>- combined in a <em>bamboo</em> nude statue the female main character!					RTK3
筈		should				2688			カツ	はず、 やはず	<strong>Should</strong> you put <em>bamboo</em> through your <em>tongue</em>? If you don't already know the answer yourself, you <strong>shouldn't</strong> even ask.	"Note: Mantixen has the right idea with his story. This<strong> should</strong> is not a moral obligation (eg, something you ""should"" do), but rather something that is expected (eg, my keys ""should"" be around here somewhere...). If you know some intermediate Japanese grammar, you'll be familiar with it as <strong>はず</strong>. Story: 「私の舌は竹から作られているよ！」「そんな<strong>はず</strong>ないでしょう！｣."					RTK3
簸		winnow				2689			ハ	ひ.る	To<strong> winnow</strong> you need two things: a <em>winnowing fan</em> (no. 2643 箕) and a <em>pelt</em> (to use as a bag to collect the grain you<strong> winnow</strong>ed). 紬		pongee				2708			チュウ	つむぎ、 つむ.ぐ	<em>Spiderman</em> decides to try a new diet of <em>sprouts</em> to see how it affects the consistency of his web. 聯		strung together				2716			レン	つら.なる、 つら.ねる	My friend's new dangly <em>ear</em>rings are interesting--<em>cacti</em><strong> strung together</strong> with butterfly <em>cocoons</em>. 聘		summons				2718			ヘイ	へい.する、 と.う、 め.す	Ear, sprout, snare: When the<strong> summons</strong> reached his <em>ears</em>, he sprang up and started running. 蚤		flea				2721			ソウ	のみ、 はやい	<strong>Flea</strong>s jump onto your <em>crotch</em>, take <em>two drops</em> of blood, and then go on their merry way: what vile <em>insects</em>!	"Right side of <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%A8%92"">騒</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2139</span>) (but without the drops there). A<strong> flea</strong> is an insect that is depicted here as jumping from (or to) a crotch (the two drops). Note: this is indeed<strong> flea</strong>, not louse, which has its own character (虱). I'm not sure of the stroke order, but by the rule of drawing from top to bottom, the crotch drop should come first. The louse (虱) then is of course a drop-like insect that attaches itself to body hairs by little hooks."					RTK3

蝦		shrimp				2728			カ、 ゲ	えび	<strong>Shrimp</strong> are the only “<em>insects</em>” that I can eat in my <em>spare time</em>: anything else requires way too much willpower. Parts: 虫, Hobby (暇<a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%9A%87"">暇</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2027</span>) - 日) ... Tip: Many different Kanji for<strong> shrimp</strong>: 蝦,海老, 鰕､蛯. This Kanji is the old name for the Ainu: Ezo 蝦夷, and their land Ezochi 蝦夷地 (now Hokkaido). (It also has meant Frog as well.) ...<strong> Shrimp</strong> on menus and such is 海老. 蛸		octopus				2729			ソウ、 ショウ	たこ	The<strong> octopus</strong> holds up two of his legs so that they look like antennas and then walks on the other six. 螺		screw				2730			ラ	にし、 にな	螺　(にし) is a fresh water mollusk with a shell like a<strong> screw</strong>. When the mollusk has died the shell is used by <em>insects</em> like a house. Thus, <em>insects accumulate</em> in the<strong> screw</strong> shell.	<em>Insects accumulate</em> if a<strong> screw</strong> is missing.					RTK3

蛾		moth				2733			ギ、 ガ	ひむし	The<strong> moth</strong> is an <em>insect</em> with an <em>ego</em> -- always looking for the (lime)light.	The<strong> moth</strong> is an <em>insect</em> that affects your <em>ego</em> by eating holes in your clothes.					RTK3
蛤		clam				2734			コウ	はまぐり	An <em>insect</em> <em>fits</em> right into the<strong> clam</strong>'s mouth before it<strong> clam</strong>ps shut.	Certain species of <em>insect</em> live in<strong> clam</strong>s, they just have to find one that <em>fits</em>.					RTK3
蛭		leech				2735			シツ、 チツ	ひる	The<strong> leech</strong> is an <em>insect</em> that sucks on you, but good luck reaching <em>climax</em> with all that blood being lost.	The <em>climax</em> of this little <em>insect</em>'s life is sucking your blood. <strong>Leech</strong>es suck.					RTK3
蛎		oyster				2736			レイ	かき	An <em>insect</em> crosses <em>ten thousand cliffs</em> to make it to sea, only to be eaten by an<strong> oyster</strong>.	"牡蛎=牡蠣=蠣=蛎=硴, <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%9B%8E"">蛎</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2736</span>) レイ(励), かき ... Parts: 虫, Cliff/Drag, 万 (cf. 栃木県<a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A0%83"">栃</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#553</span>), 励ます<a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%8A%B1"">励</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#931</span>), 砺<a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%A0%BA"">砺</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2641</span>)) ... Note: 旧字体-牡蠣=牡蛎, with 萬 for 万 ... similars: (cf 蝦<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%9D%A6"">蝦</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2728</span>), 蛎<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%9B%8E"">蛎</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2736</span>), 蛤<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%9B%A4"">蛤</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2734</span>)) ... Story: When you are all <em>out of power</em> to <em>encourage</em>(励-力) your friends, or maybe you are feeling all whet (砺-石), just remember, the world is your <strong>oyster</strong>. Aw shucks."					RTK3
罫		ruled lines				2737			ケイ、 カイ、 ケ		Keeping my <em>eye</em> fixed directly over the paper, I hold down the <em>ivy</em> and melt the strands with my <em>magic wand</em>. Viola,<strong> ruled lines</strong> are created! I bet most people think a machine does it.	The <em>cyclops</em> couldn't make<strong> ruled lines</strong> with his wooden <em>wand</em> because it wasn't smooth, so he had to use a <em>square jewel</em>.					RTK3
袈		stole				2738			ケ、 カ		"In Japanese RPGs, you are well advised to <em>add</em> a<strong> stole</strong> to your <em>clothing</em> as a ""freebie"" way to <em>add</em> defensive points without swapping out some other <em>garment</em>. But since you can't find them in the shops, you have to ""stole"" that<strong> stole</strong> from a glamorous NPC who is ostensibly there to aid your quest."	This<strong> stole</strong> really adds something to your garment, it's the final touch.					RTK3
裟		monk’s sash				2739			サ、 シャ		A monk's sash is a <em>garment</em> that has <em>grains of sand</em> in it from beachside meditations.	"袈裟, 大袈裟な<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A3%9F"">裟</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2739</span>)サ ... Parts:沙<a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%B2%99"">沙</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#151</span>), 衣 ... Note: 袈裟 only compound for 袈<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A2%88"">袈</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2738</span>)裟<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A3%9F"">裟</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2739</span>) ... Story: Like <em>Grains of Sand</em> through the hourglass measures time, a <strong>Monk's Sash</strong>ay through the abbey can mark the time for the initiates. Each time through he removes another Garment, till he is a sky-clad monk. Well except for the <strong>Monk's Sash</strong>. That he keeps on."					RTK3
截		incision				2740			セツ、 サイ	き.る、 た.つ	I’ll do the honors! So, I grabbed the knife and made an<strong> incision</strong> into the <em>Thanksgiving turkey</em>.	On Soviet <em>Thanksgiving</em>, <em>turkey</em> make<strong> incision</strong> in YOU!					RTK3

誼		familiarity				2751			ギ	よしみ、 よい	"After someone moves into the <em>house</em> next door, and after you give them a <em>best regards</em> gift (something they can fill their <em>shelves</em> with) the <em>words</em> you can now speak are those of<strong> familiarity</strong>. 謬		fallible				2752			ビュウ、 ビョウ、 ミュウ	あやま.る	"Check-up (<a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%A8%BA"">診</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1724</span>)), feathers: When, during the <em>check-up</em>, I noticed that the doctor had feathers sticking out of different bodyparts, I decided that his diagnosis would be<strong> fallible</strong>, since he obviously was a nut." 訝		wary				2753			ガ、 ゲ	いぶか.る	<strong>doubtful</strong>: <em>word</em>, <em>tusk</em>: (During a safari). 諜		secret agent				2757			チョウ	ちょう.ずる、 うかが.う、 しめ.す	Words, generation, tree: You see that guy over there having <em>words</em> with that <em>tree</em>? That's a<strong> secret agent</strong>. 賎		despicable				2765			セン、 ゼン	いや.しい、 いや.しむ、 いや.しめる、 しず、 やす.い	When they toss metal, that's all fine and dandy, but when those <em>broken dagger-axe</em> people toss down <em>shellfish</em>, ugh!, that's just<strong> despicable</strong>! 醇		strong saké				2777			ジュン、 シュン	もっぱら、 こい、 あつい	Whiskey bottle, receive: When you <em>receive</em> a <em>bottle of whiskey</em> from a Japanese person, large chance it is strong saké. It seems that giving 'sissy' saké is considered impolite.	"Now we know why the <em>tall child</em> is so 諄 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%AB%84"">諄</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2743</span>) &amp; 惇 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%83%87"">惇</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2378</span>): the effect of the the strong saké. He <em>receives</em> it at cost in the 廓 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%BB%93"">廓</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2342</span>) he set up in the cave, of course."					RTK3
麹		malt				2778			キク	こうじ	<strong>Malt</strong> made from <em>barley</em> is often <em>bound up</em> with <em>rice</em> for brewing.	This means kouji mould, so I think <strong>malt</strong> is a poor keyword. Sake, shochu and other East Asian spirits use this mould in place of yeast, which is used to make most other alcoholic spirits in the world. Mould and yeast are two different types of fungus. <strong>Yeast</strong> might have been a better keyword, as it is the organism doing the fermenting. Story: <strong>Kouji mould</strong> is grown on <em>rice specially bound up</em> to form a starter culture. To make <em>mugi</em>shochu, the starter culture is added to a <em>barley</em> mash.					RTK3
釦		button				2779			コウ、 ク	ぼたん	A<strong> button</strong> is <em>metal</em> that requires an <em>opening</em> in order to function.	A shirt in the clothes shop has<strong> button</strong>s of solid <em>gold</em>, so you bite them off and try to smuggle them out hidden in your <em>mouth</em>. (Note: Main use of 釦 <strong>is</strong> for clothing, although katakana ボタン is more common.)					RTK3
銚		keg				2780			チョウ、 ヨウ	なべ	A big <em>metal</em><strong> keg</strong> <em>portends</em> a good party.	The most expensive<strong> keg</strong> ever made: solid <em>gold</em> with <em>tortoise-shell</em> inlay.					RTK3
鋤		plow				2781			ジョ、 ショ、 ソ	す.く、 すき、 くわ	Tilling a field by hand is very tough. A handy piece of <em>metal</em> to <em>help</em> get the job done, is the <strong>plow</strong>.	15 strokes, not 14!					RTK3
鋸		handsaw				2782			キョ、 コ	のこ、 のこぎり	A handsaw is a piece of <em>metal</em> that helps you fix up the place you <em>reside</em> in.	Metal, reside: In that mansion <em>resides</em> a creepy man. In the last year, a few people have gone missing, so at one night we decided to sneak into his toolshed. There we found a <em>metal</em> handsaw and other equipment, all covered with bloodstains...					RTK3

鋲		rivet				2785				びょう	In medieval times, <em>soldiers</em> used <em>metal</em> <strong>rivets</strong> to build their suits of armor.	<em>Metal soldiers</em> (toy ones) make good<strong> rivet</strong>s.					RTK3
錫		tin				2786			セキ、 シャク	すず、 たま.う	<strong>Tin</strong> is soft, bends easily, and melts at a low temperature. 鑓		javelin				2789				やり	A<strong> javelin</strong> is a piece of <em>metal</em> used for <em>dispatching</em> enemies – or athletics judges if they’re not careful.	"What was not reported in RtK1 is that it was with a<strong> javelin</strong> that finally they were able to 遣 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%81%A3"">遣</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1910</span>) the <em>conductor</em> who had dropped his baton as he ran down the <em>road</em> with that lady's <em>purse</em>.
