鋒		sword’s point				2790			ホウ	きっさき、 とかり、 ほこさき	"A <em>pointy</em> (see my explanation in 峰 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%B3%B0"">峰</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1683</span>)) bit of <em>metal</em> is a <strong>sword's point</strong>."	A <em>metal</em> sword's point is pointed at the lovers having a <em>tryst</em>. Looks like someone got caught!					RTK3
鎚		hammer				2791			ツイ、 タイ	つち	"The<strong> hammer</strong> is the same as the <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A7%8C"">槌</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2543</span>), except it's made out of <em>metal</em>."	The <em>maestro</em> grabs a <em>metal</em><strong> hammer</strong> to get back at those <em>chasing</em> him down the <em>road</em>.					RTK3
鉦		carillion				2792			セイ、 ショウ	かね	The church<strong> carillion</strong> was composed of <em>metal</em> bells that informed when it was the <em>correct</em> time to go to church.	"Wtf is a<strong> carillion</strong>? How about ""gong"" instead. Picture a game show where they bang on the gong every time you get the correct answer. Or, if you want to go with the book explanation,<strong> carillion</strong> is the ""western"" bell which is struck from the inside rather than outside. Story: just like everything else in the East (writing, utensils, etc) bells are harder to work than necessary, being hit from the outside and all. The correct way is to put the gong on the inside, makes it so much easier."					RTK3

閤		side gate				2798			コウ	くぐりど	If you can't <em>fit</em> through the <em>gates</em> due to your size, try the<strong> side gate</strong>.	太閤　たいこう　This refers to Toyotomi Hideyoshi, an important Japanese historical figure who ruled Japan for awhile. His secret to surviving in the warring states period was to always have a<strong> side gate</strong> for a quick escape. He built this gate so only he would fit through, and anyone chasing him couldn't follow.					RTK3

翰		quill				2801			カン	はね、 ふで、 やまどり、 ふみ	How to obtain<strong> quill</strong>s for free: Wait for a misty day, then under cover of the <em>mist</em> creep up on an unsuspecting bird and quickly cover it with your <em>umbrella</em>. The bird will flap around wildly trying to escape and while doing so will shed a number of <em>feathers</em>. You can use these as<strong> quill</strong>s. 頗		exceedingly				2811			ハ	すこぶ.る、 かたよ.る	Donald Trump is<strong> exceedingly</strong> wealthy, but wears a really bad toupee -- he has an<strong> exceedingly</strong> large collection of <em>pelts</em> to place on his <em>head</em>. 騙		cheat				2821			ヘン	かた.る、 だま.す	This character is だます, which means to trick or fool someone. 馴		tame				2822			ジュン、 シュン、 クン	な.れる、 な.らす、 したが.う	The guy who said that you can take a <em>horse</em> to a <em>river</em>, but you can't make it drink obviously has never encountered a<strong> tame</strong> <em>horse</em>.	"The process to getting a<strong> tame</strong> horse is a bit like getting a<strong> tame</strong> Christian - baptizization! you take it into the <em>river</em> at a young age (just after it's born is best) and dunk it in until it is almost drowned. Then at the last possible moment, when its life is flashing before its eyes (good baptizers know when this is), you pull it back above water. The first thing it sees is its ""rescuer"" and ""savior"", and it will be<strong> tame</strong> and follow you for the rest of its life."					RTK3
駁		rebuttal				2823			ハク、 バク	ぶち、 まじ.る、 まだら	<em>Wolverine</em>'s had charges placed on him for murdering a <em>horse</em>, but he make's a<strong> rebuttal</strong> stating that he couldn't have been in two different places at the same time (i.e. There cannot exist <em>two Wolverines</em>). He was having dinner with his Aunt Margaret at the time, it's impossible.	Trojan horse, 2 sheafs: Proponents of taking the <em>Trojan Horse</em> into the city employed convincing arguments in their<strong> rebuttal</strong>. They put <em>2 sheafs</em> next to the <em>Trojan Horse</em> and put them on fire. 'You see, if it were a trap, and enemies were inside, they would surely come out right now.' However, during the<strong> rebuttal</strong>, nobody noticed the caughing coming from inside the <em>Trojan Horse</em>....					RTK3

鮎		sweet smelt				2832			デン、 ネン	あゆ、 なまず	"A <em>fish</em> arrives at the <em>fortune-teller's</em> who, without looking, says ""Welcome,<strong> Sweet Smelt</strong>"". 鰹		bonito				2837			ケン	かつお	The<strong> bonito</strong> is a <em>fish</em> with <em>strict</em> preparation procedures for making 出汁（だし） and 鰹節（かつおぶし）. RTK3
鰍		bullhead				2838			シュウ、 シュ	かじか、 いなだ、 どじょう	"Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: ""You are <strong>bullheaded</strong> if you think you can catch a<strong> bullhead</strong> <em>fish</em> in the middle of <em>autumn</em>. It's out of season!"""	Perhaps a bit of a misnomer.<strong> Bullhead</strong> is a river fish (カジカ). This kanji is most likely to refer to young Japanese yellowtail or <strong>amberjack</strong>. It is a fish of many names depending on age: fry (もじゃこ), young (鰍・いなだ or 魬・はまち), mature (鰤・ぶり). I suppose these kanji might crop up on a fish menu. STORY: Young <strong>Amberjack</strong> is not at its best in summer. Eat from <strong>autumn</strong> onwards (when it becomes more fatty). Also its tail is amber - the colour of <em>autumn</em> leaves.					RTK3
鰐		alligator				2839			ガク	わに	"""Dude! What happened to your <em>chin</em>?"" ""Well, I was out <em>fishing</em>..."""	Saltwater <strong>crocs</strong> swim in the sea like <em>fish</em>. Right side = <em>crocodile</em> primative. Pictograph - 2 big eyes and <em>one</em> massive <em>snare</em> for a mouth.					RTK3
鮒		crucian carp				2840			ホ、 フ、 ブ	ふな	The crucian <em>fish</em> <em>adhere</em>s strongly to Crucianism principles.	"<strong>Crucian carp</strong> (ふな) is a freshwater fish most well known for its use in 鮒鮓 (ふなずし) which is an ancient forerunner to modern sushi.The fish is salted and allowed to ferment over a period of months. STORY: The crucian chefs prepare the <em>fish</em> for funazushi by <em>adhering</em> to the ancient ways. Note: This old way of preserving fish, known generally as なれずし (馴れ鮓 or 熟れ鮓), uses a rare kanji for すし - <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%AE%93"">鮓</a> 鮓."					RTK3
鮨		sushi				2841			シ、 キ	すし	Japanese consider <em>fish</em> to be most <em>delicious</em> when eaten as<strong> sushi</strong>. (Note: In practice,<strong> sushi</strong> is more often written 寿司, but occasionally 鮨).	They have a perfectly good kanji, yet they use the ateji 寿司 most of the time.					RTK3
鰭		fish fin				2842			キ、 ギ	ひれ	Fish, old man, sun: An ominous<strong> fish fin</strong> approaches the <em>old man</em>, who went for a swim as the <em>sun</em> was going down. Soon, he'll sleep with the <em>fishes</em>.	The <em>old man</em> thinks<strong> fish fin</strong> <em>sushi</em> is <em>delicious</em>.					RTK3
鴎		seagull				2843			オウ	かもめ	A <em>bird</em> that goes to the inland <em>wards</em> for food is the<strong> seagull</strong>.	There's a new <em>Xbox</em> game called Extreme <em>Bird</em> Chase, where you chase flocks of <strong>seagulls</strong> on the beach. Soon we truly will never need to leave the house.					RTK3
鵬		roc				2844			ホウ	おおとり	Companion, bird:<strong> Roc</strong>, the mythical <em>bird</em>, was searching for a <em>companion</em> for as long as he existed. Little did he know that he was the only one of his kind.	The<strong> roc</strong> is a huge mythical <em>bird</em> that just wants a <em>companion</em>.					RTK3
鸚		parakeet				2845			イン、 オウ、 ヨウ		The<strong> parakeet</strong> is a <em>bird</em> that acts like a <em>suckling infant</em> when it drinks from the water dropper.	A<strong> parakeet</strong> is a <em>bird</em> that like a <em>suckling infant</em> likes a parateets.					RTK3
鵡		parrot				2846			ブ、 ム		A<strong> parrot</strong> is a <em>bird</em> of the <em>warrior</em>, for example pirates.	A<strong> parrot</strong> makes a terrible <em>bird</em> for any <em>warrior</em>. As soon as the <em>warrior</em> tries to sneak up on its enemy, Polly wants a freaking cracker.					RTK3
鵜		cormorant				2847			テイ、 ダイ	う	[+brose] The<strong> cormorant</strong> was historically used in Japan and China to catch fish. The fisher would use some rope or something to tie its throat so that it could only swallow small fish. If it caught something too big to swallow, it would take it back to the fisher's boat and the fisher would take it out. This particular<strong> cormorant</strong> is going after bigger and bigger prey - but one day it goes too far, and tries to swallow your <em>little brother</em>! Imagine trying to yank your brother out of its throat.	The<strong> cormorant</strong> is a <em>bird</em> you use like your <em>younger brother</em> to fetch things for you.					RTK3
鷺		heron				2848			ロ	さぎ	The<strong> heron</strong> <em>bird</em> took the <em>path</em> to heroin, regrettably.	As I was walking I noticed <strong>hair-on</strong> the <em>path</em>! When I bent to see what was up, I realized that they were in fact fine feathers poking through - someone had paved over a large <em>bird</em>!					RTK3
鷲		eagle				2849			シュウ、 ジュ	わし	Concerning, bird: The US senate had a meeting <em>concerning</em> the<strong> eagle</strong>. Although symbol of the US, this <em>bird</em> is close to extinction.	Timing fail: at precisely the moment the meeting began at the nation's <em>capital</em> <em>concerning</em> the fate of the national <em>bird</em>, the<strong> eagle</strong>, the only<strong> eagle</strong> in the national zoo broke free from its cage &amp; made off with the only <em>chihuahua with a human leg</em> on display anywhere in the world.					RTK3
鴨		wild duck				2850			オウ	かも、 あひる	Due to its waterproof <em>armor</em>, the<strong> wild duck</strong> is a <em>bird</em> that resurfaces even if you push it underwater.	かも, or<strong> wild duck</strong>, is a Japanese term that means an easy mark or a sucker because<strong> wild duck</strong>s are considered to be easy to catch. This kanji shows a duck that is wearing some <em>armor</em> to avoid being an easy mark.					RTK3
鳶		black kite				2851			エン	とび、 とんび	The kite falcon is a majestic <em>bird</em> that flies in the sky as fast as an <em>arrow</em>. So much so that its feathers are often used to make arrows.	Arrow, bird: The <strong>black kite</strong> is a <em>bird</em> of prey (like the raptor). You can see it approaching its target, like an <em>arrow</em> speeding through the air.					RTK3
梟		owl				2852			キョウ	ふくろう	The<strong> owl</strong>, being wise, is hiding its tail feathers in a <em>tree</em> so that its prey can't tell what kind of <em>bird</em> it is.	The<strong> owl</strong> is a very snooty bird, one could say that it has a tree stuck up it's ass. キョウ.					RTK3
塵		dust				2853			チン、 ジン	ちり、 ごみ	A <em>deer</em> stomps on the <em>soil</em> and<strong> dust</strong> rises from the ground. (big ups mantixen).	This is actually the kanji for garbage, which for some reason is often written in katakana (ゴミ). If you find the whole body of a dead <em>deer</em> outside your apartment, with muddy <em>soil</em> clinging to its fur and its eyeballs covered in<strong> dust</strong>, make sure you put it in the municipally-supplied printed bag marked 燃やせるゴミ (incinerable waste).					RTK3
麒		giraffe				2854			キ		A<strong> giraffe</strong> is like a <em>deer</em> except that when it plays <em>chess</em> it has a better overview of the board.	A <em>deer</em> with a <em>rook</em>-shaped neck probably is a<strong> giraffe</strong>.					RTK3
舅		father-in-law				2855			キュウ	しゅうと	"(from astridtops) ""Real <em>men</em> don't use <em>mortars</em>"", said my<strong> father-in-law</strong>, as he began to grind some stones down using only his fists."	"My<strong> father-in-law</strong> is more fun than my blood father. My<strong> father-in-law</strong> is a hillbilly with an arsenal of army gear. He gave me the <em>mortar</em> launcher and said: ""Be a <em>man</em>! Blow up a chunk of Planet Earth!"" And so I did..."					RTK3
鼠		mouse				2856			ソ、 ショ	ねずみ、 ねず	You are chasing the famous three blind <strong>mice</strong> and try to catch them by slamming a <em>mortar</em> on top of them. Success! You can see their <em>three tails</em> sticking out from under the mortar. In fact the impact has broken the first two tails, as you can see from the sharp angle they bend at, and the <em>two drops</em> (blood) on each. The third tail still curves nicely though, and hence has no drops of blood on it.	Mighty<strong> Mouse</strong> is so tough you can hit him with a <em>mortar</em>, double <em>plows</em> coated with <em>4 drops</em> of rat poison, and you'll still never <em>hook</em> him.					RTK3
鑿		bore				2857			サク	のみ、 うが.つ	This is pretty much only used in the word 鑿(のみ), chisel. Missile + metal is obviously a hammer being swung. The needle is the chisel and the mortar represents the impressions left (<strong>bored</strong>) by the chisel. For some reason the chisel is used to make a row of such impressions here, and the work is done in such a difficult place that it has to be done upside down. Perhaps this is some sort of sabotage, done in a place that is not readily visible to the outside.	Hanging <em>upside down in a row</em> are <em>ten</em> <em>mortar</em>s. You must shoot chisel tipped <em>missile</em>s into all of them and successfully<strong> bore</strong> holes through them in order to get the prize of <em>gold</em>. Talk about a messed up county fair game!					RTK3
艘		small craft				2858			ショウ、 シュウ、 ソウ	ふね	In military terms, a <strong>small craft</strong> is a <em>boat</em> that only has enough room for a <em>mortar</em> that fires <em>walking sticks</em> - which is pretty useless unless you hit the enemy in the <em>crotch</em>.	In a<strong> small craft</strong>, the <em>boat</em> is so small that you hit yourself in the <em>crotch</em> when trying to use a <em>mortar</em> and <em>walking stick</em> (as a pestle).					RTK3
瞑		close the eyes				2859			メイ、 ベン、 ミョウ、 ミン、 メン	めい.する、 つぶ.る、 つむ.る、 くら.い	When you wake up in <em>Hades</em>, you<strong> close the eyes</strong> and try to pretend it isn't happening.	When you<strong> close the eyes</strong> of someone who just died...					RTK3
暝		murky				2860			メイ、 ミョウ	くら.い	<em>Hades</em> is normally very dark, and even when the <em>sun</em> shines in it is still<strong> murky</strong>.	The Sunshine looks<strong> Murky</strong> in Hades.					RTK3
坐		sitting in meditation				2861			ザ、 サ	すわ.る、 おわす、 そぞろに、 まします	The cave was too dark for my tastes, so I went out to <strong>sit in mediation</strong>.	<em>2 people</em> sitting in mediation on the <em>dirt</em>.					RTK3
朔		first day of the month				2862			サク	ついたち	"On the<strong> first day of the month</strong> a mountain goat lets out a ""Baah"" as it jumps over the moon."	The female <em>mountain goat</em> can only give milk on one day of the <em>month</em>: on the<strong> first day of the month</strong>. Her milk cycles are controlled by the <em>moon</em>.					RTK3
曳		tow				2863			エイ	ひ.く	The <em>day</em> seems to drag when it keeps you from having a <em>dagger-axe</em>.	"Bored with the <em>sun</em> always going the same way (“it’s such a drag”), I tuck the <em>sun under my arm</em> and try to drag it in the opposite direction to usual. EDIT: Notes (1): <em>tucked under the arm</em> is reversed here, i.e. a mirror image of the usual primitive. Note (2): <strong>Tow</strong> might be a better keyword: see my note at <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%B4%A9"">洩</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2864</span>)."					RTK3
洩		dribble out				2864			エイ、 セツ	も.らす、 の.びる、 も.れる	(re: Katsuo) If you <em>tow water</em> in a wheelbarrow, some of it is sure to<strong> dribble out</strong>.	"Tip: Heisig has duplicated a primitive name here by calling the right side <em>drag</em>. We already have a two-stroke primitive called <em>drag</em> (see numbers 1853-1861 盾,派,脈,逓,后). I suggest calling 曳 ""<em>tow</em>"" instead."					RTK3
彗		comet				2865			スイ、 エ、 ケイ、 セイ	ほうき	A<strong> comet</strong> flew by and knocked down <em>two bushes</em>, so I went out there and <em>swept</em> up the mess, cursing astrological bodies along the way.	Broom is ヨ. The lower primitive here resembles a rake 肀 without a handle (vertical stroke). STORY:<strong> Comet</strong>s actually have <em>2 bush</em>y tails (http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/image/9703/halebopp4_aac.jpg). Imagine a NASA probe with an attachment like a <em>rake head</em> designed to catch (rake up) the fine particles streaming from the tails for later analysis.					RTK3
慧		astute				2866			ケイ、 エ	さとい	"Comet, heart: Heisig: ""The<strong> astute</strong> reader will notice that the second stroke in the broom element of <em>comet</em> doesn't pass through. The<strong> astute</strong> reader will take this observation to <em>heart</em>""."	The<strong> astute</strong> astral observer Edmond Halley put his heart into his work. And in return, we named a comet for him.					RTK3
爾		let it be				2867			ジ、 ニ	なんじ、 しかり、 その、 のみ、 おれ、 しか	"Story by katsuo (but not yet posted) - At a small concert for the Beatles I was hanging <em>eight towels</em> from the <em>celing</em>. I asked Paul if he wanted me to <em>stitch</em> them together but he said ""<strong>Let It Be</strong>""."	No matter what <em>tool</em> you use, this <em>towel</em> is beyond repair, even with <em>stitching</em>. Better<strong> let it be</strong>.					RTK3
嘉		applaud				2868			カ	よみ.する、 よい	<em>Add</em> a <em>drum</em> when you really want to<strong> applaud</strong>.	The drummer wasn't very good so he had a speaker built into the bottom of the <em>drum</em> which automatically <em>added</em> <strong>applause</strong>.					RTK3
兇		evil				2869			キョウ	おそ.れる、 わる.い	The <strong>evil</strong> <em>villain</em>'s favorite hobby is breaking <em>human legs</em>.	Think of Mike Myers' Dr.<strong> Evil</strong> standing in an identity the fifth of intergalactic criminals.<strong> Evil</strong> is the only <em>villain</em> with <em>human legs</em>.					RTK3
兜		helmet				2870			トウ、 ト	かぶと	The overly-cautious <em>white</em> geek protects his entire upper body with a special<strong> helmet</strong> he constructed out of <em>two cardboard boxes</em>, unfortunately his <em>human legs</em> could still be easy targets for bullies.	The perfect image for this kanji: http://bit.ly/stormtrooperhelmet How to make a lousy stormtrooper costume: take <em>two cardboard boxes</em> - one will be for your<strong> helmet</strong> and the other will cover your trunk. Paint them <em>white</em>. Find something to cover your <em>human legs</em>. Ta-da!					RTK3
靄		mist				2871			アイ	もや	The <em>muchacho</em> about to give a speech to his <em>audience</em>, only to be interrupted by a sudden <em>rain</em>, accompanied by very thick <strong>mist</strong>.	<strong>Mist</strong>:<strong> Mist</strong> from the RAIN makes the air thick; the MUCHACHO wakes up and calls for help but no one can hear his WORDS. 劫		kalpa				2872			コウ、 ゴウ、 キョウ	おびや.かす	"<strong>kalpa</strong> is a Sanskrit word for a long period of time, sort of like ""aeon."" Once a <strong>kalpa</strong> has <em>gone</em> (passed), there will be no more fossil fuels for <em>power</em>."	When a<strong> kalpa</strong> passes, all forms of <em>power</em> we see today will be <em>gone</em>.					RTK3
歎		bemoan				2873			タン	なげ.く、 なげ.き	A <em>scarecrow</em><strong> bemoan</strong>s that it <em>lacks</em> legs.	"(I use ""kanji"" for the scarecrow primitive.) I<strong> bemoan</strong> the huge number of <em>kanji</em> I must memorize, but I plod on despite my tired <em>yawn</em>s."					RTK3
輿		palanquin				2874			ヨ	かご、 こし	I hop into my<strong> palanquin</strong>, my <em>car</em> of sorts, such that I may be transported to my next location of <em>entertainment</em>.	A<strong> palanquin</strong> is a <em>car</em> used for the <em>entertainment</em> of royalty when they want to take a joyride.					RTK3
歪		warped				2875			ワイ、 エ	いが.む、 いびつ、 ひず.む、 ゆが.む	In the debate, your political opponent's has such a <strong>warped</strong> sense of perspective, that he believes the <em>negative</em> is actually <em>correct</em>.	<strong>Warped</strong> is a combination of <em>not</em> and <em>correct</em>. If a piece of wood is described as<strong> warped</strong>, that means it is <em>not</em> the <em>correct</em> shape, according to a particular standard we have in mind. The <em>correct</em> Kanji points us to the standard; while the <em>not</em> or <em>un-</em> Kanji denotes that the standard is not met. Hence, whatever we are talking about is not standard - i.e. it is <em>not correct</em> or <em>not regular</em>. In other words, it is<strong> warped</strong>.					RTK3
翠		jade green				2876			スイ	かわせみ、 みどり	You're so jaded by the time you <em>graduate</em> that when you finally spread your wings, your <em>feathers</em> are all<strong> jade green</strong>.	This what the valedictorian wears in Chinese high school <em>graduation</em>s. It's a beautiful cap with<strong> jade green</strong> <em>feathers</em> covering it. No tassel, just those pretty <em>feathers</em>.					RTK3
黛		blue-black				2877			タイ	まゆずみ	A good <em>substitute</em> for <em>black</em> is<strong> blue-black</strong>, like the color women try to <em>substitute</em> for their <em>black</em> eyebrows with a pencil.	<em>Substitute </em> + <em>black</em>=<strong> blue-black</strong> or <strong>blackened-eyebrows</strong>. A close <em>substitute</em> for the color <em>black</em> is the color<strong> blue-black</strong>. Also, women in Japan sometimes have <strong>blackened-eyebrows</strong>, since their color is naturally a faint<strong> blue-black</strong>.					RTK3
鼎		tripod				2878			テイ	かなえ	Here we have two people sitting on chairs, trying to set up their camera on a<strong> tripod</strong> and periodically checking the viewfinder with their <em>eyes</em>.	"(NB: I use <strong>THREE-LEGGED KETTLE</strong> for 鼎, and reserve <strong>TRIPOD</strong> for 鬲 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E9%AC%B2"">鬲</a>.) This <strong>THREE-LEGGED KETTLE</strong> is used for sacrificial incense-burning. 鼎 shows a watchful <em>EYE</em> carefully putting the offering material in the opening of the <strong>KETTLE</strong>, which is shown as being squarely supported <em>ON EACH SIDE</em>."					RTK3
鹵		rocksalt				2879			ロ	しお、 しおち、 たて	The <em>fortune-teller</em> tells <em>Wolverine</em> that in a past life, she sees him covered in<strong> rocksalt</strong> from working in a salt mine. (Note: Let ladybird = sheaf + four drops. It's pictographic: the sheaf showing the curved back and the four drops the spots on the ladybird).					RTK3
鹸		lye				2880			ケン、 カン、 セン	あ.く	<strong>Lye</strong> is white like <em>rocksalt</em> and can be broken up with an <em>ice pick</em>.	"(Agreed with Hissatsu, <strong>Soap</strong> it is!) 燕		swallow				2882			エン	つばめ、 つばくら、 つばくろ	<em>Twenty</em> birds (swallows) are perched at the <em>north exit</em> (北口) of the station. I light a <em>fire</em> underneath them, and as they wilt and fall in the heat, passing commuters<strong> swallow</strong> them whole. Well, they are<strong> swallow</strong>s.	<em>Twenty</em><strong> swallow</strong>s are perched atop the station's 北口 raining <em>droppings</em> all over everyone. Keep your <em>mouth</em> closed so you don't<strong> swallow</strong> any. (Thanks Katsuo).					RTK3
嘗		lick				2883			ショウ、 ジョウ	かつ.て、 こころ.みる、 な.める	There are things in the <em>outhouse</em> that may appear <em>delicious</em>, and you may even want to<strong> lick</strong> them, but I assure you: they ain't <em>delicious</em>. 齬		discord				2888			ゴ		"<strong>crooked teeth</strong>: (during a crooked teeth anonymous meeting in England). "[This kanji is included in RTK 3 third edition with the keyword 'discord'] [continuing the story from disagree (#40799)] The factory manager thought he'd resolved the disagreement between the two assembly lines, but there was still some<strong> discord</strong> among those on the floor below making the shovels. 秦		Manchu dynasty				2889			シン	はた	(thx Katsuo) The so-called 'mighty' <strong>Qin dynasty</strong> died a nasty death from starvation because they focused on growing <em>bonsai</em> instead of <em>wheat</em>. 雀		sparrow				2890			ジャク、 ジャン、 サク、 シャク	すずめ	There are relatively <em>few</em> <em>turkeys</em> compared to the widely familiar<strong> sparrow</strong>.	There are <em>few turkeys</em> available this Christmas/Thanksgiving, so we're having to make do with<strong> sparrow</strong>.					RTK3
隼		peregrine falcon				2891			シュン、 ジュン	はやぶさ	The<strong> peregrine falcon</strong> is the fastest animal in the world. It can reach speeds of over 322 km/h in a dive - over <em>ten</em> times as fast as a <em>turkey</em>!	"My<strong> peregrine falcon</strong> recently has been having confidence issues - recently it dives out of the sky and misses the target completely. To boost its confidence, I got a nice, fat <em>turkey</em>, killed it, and then set it up on a big <em>needle</em> so it looked like it was still alive - just loafing about. Then I went to my<strong> peregrine falcon</strong> - ""hey buddy, look! A nice fat <em>turkey</em>. I bet you can get it!"" It goes for it, but it spears itself on the <em>needle</em>!!"					RTK3
耀		shimmering				2892			ヨウ	かがや.く、 ひかり	Rays of light hit the futon, making it shimmer. Think maybe somebody wet the futon last night..	<strong>Shimmering</strong> <em>rays</em> of light awaken me as I lay on my <em>turkey feather futon</em>.					RTK3
夷		ebisu				2893			イ	えびす、 えみし、 ころ.す、 たい.らげる	When passing through<strong> Ebisu</strong> in Tokyo, (one stop south of Shibuya) you see an<strong> ebisu</strong> (= a barbarian/savage) whose pet <em>St. Bernard</em> has swallowed his <em>bow</em>; you can see the shape of the bow sticking through its skin. Notes: 1. I'm locating this in<strong> Ebisu</strong> to reinforce the sound; the place name<strong> Ebisu</strong> is actually written with different kanji. 2. As Meconium mentions, stroke order is 一、弓、人.	I don't like the way Heisig doesn't list stroke order in RTK3, like it's not important or something. This is written <em>one</em>, <em>bow</em>, <em>person</em>, not <em>large</em> then <em>person</em>. It's annoying to have to check each time. Note the second leg of <em>person</em> comes from the bottom of <em>bow</em>, not from <em>one</em>.					RTK3
嚢		cyst				2894			ノウ、 ドウ	ふくろ	Grass skirt, middle, crown: The girl wearing the <em>grass skirt</em> had a<strong> cyst</strong> growing in the <em>middle</em> of her head, seeming like a <em>crown</em>. A sign she will be the new village elder, I heard later.	"The <em>hula girl</em> got a<strong> cyst</strong> on her lips after she placed her <em>mouth</em> on my ""<em>crown</em>"" <em>ten</em> times."					RTK3
暢		carefree				2895			チョウ	のび.る	The <em>monkey</em> is<strong> carefree</strong> with his <em>piggy bank</em>, tossing it at whatever financial opportunity he stumbles upon.	I am the most<strong> carefree</strong> person in the world! I'm even going to entrust my <em>piggybank</em> with my life savings in it to this <em>monkey</em>!					RTK3
廻		circling				2896			カイ、 エ	まわ.る、 まわ.す、 もとお.る、 めぐ.る、 めぐ.らす	A dishonest taxi driver is<strong> circling</strong> to increase the fare -- trying to <em>stretch out</em> the ride, going around the block many <em>times</em>.	A taxi driver <em>stretches</em> out the time it takes to get to <em>Times</em> Square by<strong> circling</strong> around it (thanks mcfate).					RTK3
欣		elation				2897			キン、 ゴン、 コン	よろこ.ぶ、 よろこ.び	I feel<strong> elation</strong> when I realize the <em>axe</em> murderer is <em>lacking</em> his axe.	I was bored, <em>yawn</em>ing and such, so I picked up my <em>axe</em> and was suddenly filled with much<strong> elation</strong>.					RTK3
毅		stalwart				2898			キ、 ギ	つよ.い	A<strong> stalwart</strong> <em>sow stands</em> up against a <em>missile</em>.	Stand up, sow, missile: See our<strong> stalwart</strong> hunter <em>standing upon</em> the <em>sow</em> he just shot, his <em>missile</em> launcher still smoking. (Nothing much left of the <em>sow</em> by the way).					RTK3
斯		this				2899			シ	か、 こう、 か.く、 この、 これ、 ここに	"Tip: Learn ""this"" 斯 and ""that"" 其 at the same time. (""that"", 其 , is not in Heisig, but is probably more common than 斯). Stories:<strong> This</strong> <em>bushel basket</em> comes with an <em>axe</em> to open it, but <strong>that</strong> one doesn't."	(Thx Kats)<strong> THIS</strong> AXE can beat any CHESS peice... except for maybe THAT ROOK.					RTK3
匙		wooden spoon				2900			シ	さじ	"After you get the<strong> wooden spoon</strong> in the ""egg &amp; spoon"" race another competitor explains that you need to hold the <em>spoon</em> ""<em>just so</em>""."	A <em>spoon</em> used to measure ingredients <em>just so</em> is a <strong>measuring spoon</strong>.					RTK3
匡		set straight				2901			キョウ、 オウ	すく.う	After the revolution, the <em>king</em> was put into a <em>box</em> so that the government could be<strong> set straight</strong>.	"Walking through the park, I see many large <em>box</em>es where homeless people live. But there's one guy dressed as a <em>king</em>, who seems to be arranging them all, i.e. he's <strong>set</strong>ting the boxes <strong>straight</strong>. ""Surely you're not a real <em>king</em>?"" I ask. He replies, ""Let me <strong>set</strong> you <strong>straight</strong>, I'm <em>king</em> of the <em>boxes</em>""."					RTK3
肇		founding				2902			チョウ、 ジョウ、 トウ	はじ.める、 はじめ	<strong>Founding</strong> of a nation is usually done by the taskmasters in charge behind closed doors. They sign some papers with their writing brushes and voila..	Everyone seems to think that the<strong> Founding</strong> Fathers of the United States (the ones who signed the Declaration of Independence) were doing it out of their own free will. Truth is, George Washington, that hard old <em>taskmaster</em>, wouldn't let people out the <em>door</em> of the Pennsylvania State House until they had signed their name, and passed on the <em>writing brush</em> to the next person.					RTK3
麿		Utamaro				2903				まろ	Bending over constantly to cut all those woodblocks has given<strong> Utamaro</strong> a bad back. Now he smokes <em>hemp</em> while he works to ease the pain in in his <em>spine</em>.	歌麿 うた-<strong>まろ</strong>: The poor guy with leukaemia smokes <em>hemp</em> to ease the pain from all the bone <strong>マロ</strong> that has to be injected into his <em>spine</em>. [Note: probably not medically accurate.]					RTK3
叢		conglomerate				2904			ソウ、 ス	くさむら、 むら.がる、 むら	I have a huge<strong> conglomerate</strong> (collection) of old books I'm looking to get rid of. They're not in any particular order... some are <em>upside down in a row</em>, some are <em>soiled</em>... just look through them and <em>take</em> whatever you want.	"This is similar to 業 <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A5%AD"">業</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1931</span>), with ""not yet"" replaced by ""take."" A giant company that <em>takes</em> up many companies with different <em>professions</em>, is called a <strong>conglomerate</strong>."					RTK3
肴		entreat				2905			コウ	さかな	"Tip: ""snack"" or ""appetizer"" would be better keywords for this kanji."	<em>Wolverine</em> <em>possess</em>es his own <strong>snacks</strong> when he goes out drinking.					RTK3
斐		symetrically patterned				2906			ヒ、 イ		The murderer who carved <strong>symmetrical patterns</strong> into all his victims was <em>sentenced</em> life in a <em>jailcell</em>. (thanks tomusan).	In <em>jail</em>, everyone wears symetrically patterned clothes - usually stripes. In this, particularly fashionable <em>Scottish</em> jail, however, they have you wear <em>plaid</em>. It makes sense if you think about it - most jails have vertical bars, which translates into stripes - while this <em>Scottish</em> joint has squarish, symetrically patterned bars that go very well with <em>plaid</em>.					RTK3
卿		magistrate				2907			ケイ、 キョウ	きみ	British<strong> magistrate</strong>s wear wigs made of silver hair. But picture an eccentric<strong> magistrate</strong> who instead wears a <em>silver hare</em> on his head.	For all his righteousness in court, the<strong> magistrate</strong> is really a horny guy. How do I know this? I accidentally found his stash of Playboy magazines, and there was some <em>silver</em> liquid on the <em>sign of the hare</em>.					RTK3
翫		fiddle with				2908			ガン	もてあそ.ぶ	In the <em>beginning</em> you <em>learn</em> by <strong>fiddling with</strong> things.	Emperor Nero <strong>fiddled with</strong> his fiddle while Rome burned. When he was later asked to explain himself he said, “Well, I was <em>learn</em>ing how to play this piece and had to keep going back to the <em>beginning</em>”.					RTK3
於		within				2909			オ、 ヨ	おい.て、 お.ける、 ああ、 より	Image: An Arctic explorer frozen<strong> within</strong> <em>ice</em>,<strong> within</strong> his hands are an <em>umbrella</em> and a <em>compass</em>.	"""At"" seems like a better keyword for this one. You're freezing under your umbrella and using a compass to figure out where you're at."					RTK3
套		hackneyed				2910			トウ	かさ.ねる	"The <strong>hackneyed</strong> hangover cure is to have ""some <em>hair</em> of the <em>dog</em> that bit you."""	You may think you're being original by sporting an afro, but it's<strong> hackneyed</strong> to have <em>big</em> poofy <em>long hair</em>.					RTK3
叛		rebellion				2911			ハン、 ホン	そむ.く	The <em>half</em> that was <em>anti-</em> started a<strong> rebellion</strong>.	A<strong> rebellion</strong> is when the <em>anti</em> half starts pushing against the other <em>half</em>. (Like in this kanji).					RTK3
尖		sharp point				2912			セン	とが.る、 さき、 するど.い	A <em>small</em> tip on something <em>large</em> creates a<strong> sharp point</strong>.	Little, St Bernard: In primary school, I had a pencil sharpener shaped as a <em>little St. Bernard</em>. I put in my blunt pencil, and it came out with a<strong> sharp point</strong>.					RTK3
壷		crock				2913			コ	つぼ	The <em>samurai</em>'s<strong> crock</strong> was so old it was a <em>crowned</em> a heritage item of <em>Asia</em>, and he wouldn't sell it.	"The E-mail read: ""Hello, my name is Ubuntu Nonga, <em>crowned</em> <em>samurai</em> of a small <em>Asian</em> country. I have $5 million that I need to move to a safe place ..."" But I knew that advance-fee scams are a <strong>crock</strong>."					RTK3
叡		sapience				2914			エイ	あき.らか	Magic wand, crown, 1-eyed valley, crotch: The archeologist was searching for the birthplace of the homo<strong> sapience</strong>. Wearing his <em>magic wand</em> and his divining <em>crown</em>, he was able to located it in the <em>1-eyed valley</em>, somewhere in Bolivia. His <em>crotch</em> got all excited, thinking on all the publicity of finding the birthplace of homo<strong> sapience</strong>.	"The <em>magic wand</em> in a guy's <em>crotch</em> is <em>crowned</em> with <em>one</em> <em>eye</em>, and <em>contains</em> a certain <strong>sapience</strong>... but they should try not to ""think with the little head.""" 酋		chieftain				2915			シュウ、 ジュ	おさ、 ふるざけ、 さけのつかさ	"I have used <em>Red Bull</em> as a primitive since <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%8C%B6"">猶</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#1438</span>), so now it is easy to remember the<strong> chieftain</strong>'s name: Chief Red Bull!"	Only the<strong> chieftain</strong> could drink <em>horned whiskey</em> since he was the one responsible for procreation.					RTK3
鴬		nightingale				2916			オウ	うぐいす	The<strong> nightingale</strong> is a <em>bird</em> that goes to a <em>schoolhouse</em> at night to learn to sing.	This character is actually a 俗字 (unofficial simplification) of the character 鶯. As such, it is actually far less common than the traditional character according to a google search. Story for the correct character: The<strong> nightingale</strong> is bird with a crown (mane) as bright as a deep fire (two fires).					RTK3
赫		incandescent				2917			カク	あかい、 あか、 かがや.く	<strong>Incandescent</strong> red is naturally twice as bright as ordinary red (赤). Alternatively, this is a picture of spreading (already doubled),<strong> incandescent</strong> red fire. Note: This is used by far most commonly to write 赫(あか)い, although dictionaries do not recognize such a reading (except for kanji dictionaries).	<strong>Incandescent</strong> light bulbs work by passing an electric current through a filament, heating it so it produces light by incandescence. When you think of something heating up so it glows, it usually turns red (toaster coils, embers, etc.). An<strong> incandescent</strong> bulb is much brighter, so it's DOUBLE RED.					RTK3
臥		supinate				2918			ガ	ふせ.る、 ふ.せる、 ふ.す	If a <em>person</em> has <em>retainers</em>, then he can spend his life<strong> supinate</strong> (i.e. lying on his back doing nothing). (note: for the writing order think: <strong>S</strong>u<strong>P</strong>inate = <strong>S</strong>lave-<strong>P</strong>erson).	<em>Slaves</em> are made to<strong> supinate</strong> before common <em>people</em>.					RTK3
甥		nephew				2919			セイ、 ソウ、 ショウ	おい、 むこ	A<strong> nephew</strong> is someone you can watch grow into a <em>man</em> over his <em>life</em>time.	Life, male: During a visit to your family, you meet your<strong> nephew</strong>. You find out that in his short <em>life</em>, your<strong> nephew</strong> already has collected a great many <em>male</em> things in his room, such as 'dirty' magazines, etc.					RTK3
瓢		gourd				2920			ヒョウ	ひさご、 ふくべ	I enter a <em>ballot</em> to try to win a <em>melon</em>, but end up with a<strong> gourd</strong>.	With its protective hard rind, a<strong> gourd</strong> is a <em>melon</em> used to deposit <em>ballots</em> in during elections.					RTK3

叉		forked				2923			サ、 シャ、 サイ	また	"Think of this as ""tuning fork"" (音叉). Then, touching a vibrating <strong>tuning fork</strong> against a <em>crotch</em> causes it to drip <em>drop</em>s."	You are looking for a bathroom, but the path in front is<strong> forked</strong> and you don't know which way to go. 乖		disobey				2924			カイ	そむ.く、 もとる	<strong>oppose</strong>: The opposing army of one thousand went north up the mountain to strike Hamlet in his castle up the top.	I was told in no uncertain terms to put my <em>thousand yen note</em> in my savings account. I chose instead to <strong>disobey</strong> and place it between a pair of <em>back to back spoons</em> (you know - the ones that always face <em>north</em>). The <em>thousand yen note</em> is still there, even if it has rather dropped in value. I probably ought just to spend it! [乖離 【かいり】 (n,vs) divergence; alienation; deviation; estrangement; separation; detachment].					RTK3
畠		dry field				2925				はたけ、 はた	"You see a <em>white dove</em> about to land in a <em>paddyfield</em>, and, believing that field to be under water, expect to hear a ""plop"". But the plop doesn't come, so you think to yourself, ""Ah, that must be a<strong> dry field</strong>""."	The<strong> dry field</strong> is the <em>rice field</em> that has dried up into <em>white</em> dust.					RTK3
圃		vegetable patch				2926			ホ、 フ	はたけ、 にわ	Think of a<strong> vegetable patch</strong> owned by a perfectionist, where every group of crops is <em>pent in</em> and separated accordingly, and every single crop is <em>dogtagged</em> and earmarked.	My <em>offspring</em> is supposed to be weeding my<strong> vegetable patch</strong>, but he keeps running off to play. So I put an electric fence around the veggie patch to <em>pent him in</em>. Now he's hard at work in there!					RTK3

疏		transcription				2930			ソ、 ショ	あら.い、 うと.い、 うと.む、 とお.る、 とお.す、 まばら	The <em>zoo</em> needed a<strong> transcription</strong> of the accident report involving the <em>infant</em> caught in the <em>flood</em>.	Imagine spending your whole summer learning two ancient arts - first, the art of speaking to animals at the <em>zoo</em> (this is a bunch of different languages - no small feat), and the art of writing your name in urine (you go see the <em>Mannequin de Pis</em> for this - just sitting there and observing for hours on end). Anyway, you decide to put these two together, and go to a <em>zoo cage</em>, and ask the animal to tell its story. You then open your fly and proceed to do a full<strong> transcription</strong> of what it is saying.					RTK3

牒		label				2934			チョウ、 ジョウ	ふだ	"Tip: New primitive: Let <em>Tarzan</em> = <em>generation</em> + <em>tree</em> -- because <em>Tarzan</em> lives with several <em>generation</em>s of his family at the top of a <em>tree</em>. (This combination appears five times: <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%91%89"">葉</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#243</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%9D%B6"">蝶</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#560</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E5%96%8B"">喋</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2280</span>), <a href=""/study/kanji/%E8%AB%9C"">諜</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2757</span>),<strong> label</strong> (FRAME 2926)). 敦		empathetic				2938			トン、 タイ、 ダン、 チョウ	あつ.い	A <em>taskmaster</em> can be<strong> empathetic</strong> if she <em>receives</em> something. 奎		Andromeda				2939			ケイ、 キ		(From Greek mythology). When Perseus goes to rescue<strong> Andromeda</strong>, he finds he's made a mistake. 翔		soar				2940			ショウ	かけ.る、 と.ぶ	If a <em>sheep</em> had <em>feathers</em>, it could<strong> soar</strong>.	[+mantixen] If a <em>sheep</em> had <em>feathers</em> it could<strong> soar</strong>. 赳		bold				2943			キュウ		Run, cornucopia: The thief was<strong> bold</strong>, but stupid. He was <em>running</em> away with the <em>cornucopia</em> he just stole from the feudal lord. However, he was leaving an easy track to follow as the <em>cornucopia</em> was pouring out its riches. So,<strong> bold</strong>, but stupid.	A marathon <em>runner</em><strong> bold</strong> enough to race the <em>Fantastic Four</em>.					RTK3
已		stop short				2944			イ	や.む、 すで.に、 のみ、 はなはだ	This character would be the <em>sign of the snake</em> if the last stroke didn't<strong> stop short</strong>. 珈		jeweled hairpin				2967			カ	かみかざり	"This and <a href=""/study/kanji/%E7%90%B2"">琲</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2963</span>) only seem to occur in the word 珈琲 (コーヒー) where they are used phonetically. So, in practice, it might be easier to remember them as a pair and not worry about their literal meanings. STORY: For 珈: An assassin <em>adds</em> poison to the <em>king</em>'s <strong>coffee</strong>. For 琲: However, fearing a plot against him, the <em>king</em>, summons a hapless convict from a <em>jail cell</em> to sample the <strong>coffee</strong> first." "珈 (2962) and 琲 (2963) are mainly used for their phonetic readings in 珈琲 コーヒー coffee. To help remember the word and the two kanji, the right sides of these two kanji can be read as ""カロ""+""ヒ"". Coffee, the <em>king</em> of pick me up beverages, is low calorie."					RTK3
檜		Japanese cypress [old]				2969			カイ	ひのき、 ひ	It used to be that for a meeting [old] you'd <em>meet</em> for a <em>day</em> to get the <em>small</em> details <em>pent in</em>. "For <strong>Meeting (old) </strong>會 at <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%9C%83"">會</a>. <em>Pent-in + small</em> is pictograph of ""a pair of glasses with windscreen wipers"" like something out of a joke shop. STORY: In the olden days we couldn't afford a roof, so we would <em>meet</em> alfresco. Our <em>spectacles had built in wipers</em> so we could continue working during inclement weather. The <strong>meetings (old)</strong> were long and would often last until <em>sundown</em>. Those were the days! Note: So for<strong> Japanese cypress</strong> (old) simply replace 会 in <a href=""/study/kanji/%E6%A1%A7"">桧</a> (<span class=""frnr"">#2558</span>) with 會."					RTK3

龍		dragon [old]				2985			リュウ、 リョウ、 ロウ	たつ	An ancient Japanese<strong> dragon</strong>, beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese<strong> dragon</strong> has three toes, unlike other Asian<strong> dragon</strong>s. Asian<strong> dragon</strong>s generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a<strong> dragon</strong>!)	(insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese<strong> Dragon</strong>, now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. The column describes how the last Japanese<strong> Dragon</strong> was killed by a party of adventurers, who struck its SNAKE body simultaneously with a SLINGSHOT and THREE swords.					RTK3

鼈		snapping turtle				3000			ベツ、 ヘツ	すっぽん	"The<strong> snapping turtle</strong> is ordering lunch at a restaurant, ""I'll have the <em>shredded old eel</em> -- and make it snappy!"". (Picture the waiter putting old eels through the shredder before serving them)."	3000... im so proud.					RTK3
一		one	In Chinese characters, the number <b>one</b> is laid on its side, unlike the Roman numeral I which stands upright. As you would expect, it is written from left to right.	* As a primitive element, the key-word meaning is discarded, and the single horizontal stroke takes on the meaning of <i>floor</i> or <i>ceiling</i>, depending on its position: if it stands above another primitive, it means <i>ceiling</i>; if below, <i>floor</i>.	1	1	1	1	イチ、イツ	ひと-、ひと.つ	<strong>One</strong> down, 2041 to go. ;).	"To learn this<strong> one</strong> kanji, I <a href=""../v4/2000.html"">recommend</a> (#2000 薦) this story : <em>Bambi</em> is in a <em>cave</em>, eating a side-dish of <em>salad</em> when trying to learn the kanjis. As he succeed to learn the kanji for ""one"", you get jealous and decide to shoot him with a <em>slingshot</em>. At this moment you hear the police coming, so you hurriedly burn all the proofs into a <em>fire</em> (so you remove the key-words <em>Bambi</em>, <em>slingshot</em> and <em>fire</em> from <em>recommend</em>). So that when the police arrives, the only remaining clue is a single horizontal bar."	This<strong> one</strong> is too difficult to remember. If the other Kanji are this difficult, I'm giving up.	A sleeping Roman I. ;).	"Tips for your journey:1)check the keywords (for example with saiga-jp kanji dict or jisho.org or <a href=""http://dic.yahoo.co.jp"">http://dic.yahoo.co.jp</a> + rikaichan). heisig messes up a lot. 2)you'll get mixed up if you use too many penis euphemisms. i try to stick with just ""crotch"" for penis. 3)try to use the right meaning of the keyword in your stories. for example 抄 ""extract"" is like an excerpt, not the verb extract."		
二		two	Like the Roman numeral II, which reduplicates the numeral I, the kanji for <b>two</b> is a simple reduplication of the horizontal stroke that means one. The order of writing goes from above to below, with the first stroke slightly shorter.		2	2	2	1	ニ、ジ	ふた、ふた.つ、ふたた.び	<strong>Two</strong> lines.	Roman numeral II, written on its side.	No wonder the hotel room only cost<strong> TWO</strong> yen, all it had was a <em>ceiling</em> and a <em>floor</em>.	With this one, I have doubled the number of kanjis I know. Next please ;).	1+1 = 2.		
三		three	"And like the Roman numeral III, which triples the numeral I, the kanji for <b>three</b> simply triples the single horizontal stroke. In writing it, think of ""1 + 2 = 3"" (一 + 二 = 三) in order to keep the middle stroke shorter."		3	3	3	1	サン、ゾウ	み、み.つ、みっ.つ	One + two =<strong> three</strong>.	<strong>THREE</strong> measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.	"A<strong> three</strong>some: a Roman girl getting sandwitched by two blokes yelling ""me too!"" (みつ)."	A Roman family sleeping together horizontally.Can't you see the kid between his parents?	One ( 一 ) on top of two ( 二 ), gives<strong> three</strong> ( 三 ).		
四		four	"This character is composed of two primitive elements, <i>mouth</i> and <i>human legs</i>,  both of which we will meet in the coming lessons. Assuming that you already knew how to write this kanji, we will pass over the ""story"" connected with it until later. Note how the second stroke is written left-to-right and then top-to-bottom. This is consistent with what we have already seen in the first three numbers and leads us to a general principle that will be helpful when we come to more complicated kanji later on: write north-to-south, west-to-east, northwest-to-southeast."		5	4	4	1	シ	よ、よ.つ、よっ.つ、よん	<strong>FOUR</strong> year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.	I imagine a giant devouring a human in<strong> four</strong> bites. First the giant bites off the person's head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the<strong> four</strong>th bite falling in there?	This is a picture of a slab in the morgue. It is pulled out from the drawer, and it is showing only the dead person's feet. Clearly <em>shi</em> means DEATH.	A man inside<strong> four</strong> walls.	<strong>Four</strong> are the <em>legs</em> of the Schrödinger Cat, which is kept in a <em>box</em>, and you don't know if the cat is dead or alive until you open it.		
五		five	As with <i>four</i>, we shall postpone learning the primitive elements that make up this character. Note how the general principle we just learned in the preceding frame applies to the writing of the character for <b>five</b>.		4	5	5	1	ゴ	いつ、いつ.つ	三 + two vertical lines = 5.	"This Kanji looks like a ""3"" Kanji with two added vertical lines. 3+2= 5."	<strong>Five</strong> - has a THREE, and a small 'h'… 'high<strong> five</strong>'.	The letter 'F' is skiing for the 'five' trophies.	"The <em>King</em> (<a href=""../v4/255.html"">king</a> (#255 王)) leaned on the magical <em>walking stick</em> in his left hand which the wizard said would let him ""go"" (ゴ) through the <strong>fifth</strong> dimension."		
六		six	The primitives here are <i>top hat</i> and <i>animal legs</i>. Once again, we glide over them until later.		4	6	6	1	ロク、リク	む、む.つ、むっ.つ、むい	Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.	The Devil, always a gentleman, wears a top hat, but his goat legs, betray the Beast. 666 is his number.	<strong>Six</strong>-Six-SIX ((666)) Mark of the Beast!! Imagine that dapper old beastly fellow summoning his top hat to himself. See it scamper over to him on a little pair of beastly legs.	"Someone lying spread-eagle, ready for ""sex"" (<strong> SIX</strong> ). —or— Hey, everyone! Come see! I just trapped a<strong> SIX</strong>-inch gremlin under my <em>top-hat</em>!"	The<strong> six</strong> members of a person, however the torso was eat by the devil (666).		
七		seven	"Note that the first stroke ""cuts"" through the second. This distinguishes <b>seven</b> from the character for <i>spoon</i> (Frame 476), in which the horizontal stroke stops short."	"* As a primitive, this form takes on the meaning of <i>diced</i>, i.e., ""cut"" into little pieces, consistent both with the way the character is written and with its association with the kanji for <i>cut</i> to be learned in a later lesson (Frame 89)."	2	7	7	1	シチ	なな、なな.つ、なの	This kanji is our good old<strong> seven</strong>, turned upside down.	I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.	Almost katakana SE =<strong> SEVEN</strong>.	I <em>crossed</em> it out because I wrote this<strong> SEVEN</strong> <em>upside down</em>.	If you take the line in the middle out, it's an upside down<strong> seven</strong>, Ta-da!		
八		eight	"Just as the Arabic numeral ""8"" is composed of a small circle followed by a larger one, so the kanji for <b>eight</b> is composed of a short line followed by a longer line, slanting towards it but not touching it. And just as the ""lazy 8"" is the mathematical symbol for ""infinity,"" so the expanse opened up below these two strokes is associated by the Japanese with the sense of an infinite expanse or something ""all-encompassing."""		2	8	8	1	ハチ	や、や.つ、やっ.つ、よう	"""Hachi"" (eight) begins with the sound of the <strong>katakana ""ha""</strong>, and it's approximately the same character."	The valcano hasn't erupted for 8 years.	The curtains close at<strong> eight</strong>.	I<strong> eight</strong> something so large, it bent my chopsticks.	I<strong> eight</strong> a volcano! now I got heart burn.		
九		nine	If you take care to remember the stroke order of this kanji, you will not have trouble later keeping it distinct from the kanji for <i>power</i> (Frame 922).	* As a primitive, we shall use this kanji to mean <i>baseball team</i> or simply <i>baseball</i>. The meaning, of course, is derived from the <i>nine</i> players who make up a team.	2	9	9	1	キュウ、ク	ここの、ここの.つ	<em>Warning - naughty reminder</em> A woman in the doggie style position, waiting for my<strong> NINE</strong> inches.	"Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1 一 with the kanji of 8 八 added. So think of it as <a href=""midori://search?text=%E4%B8%80%EF%BC%8B%E5%85%AB%EF%BC%9D%E4%B9%9D"">一＋八＝九</a> ."	"It looks like an elaborate letter ""n"" for<strong> nine</strong>."	Girl waiting in doggy-style position for her boyfriend. If only she knew back then she would get pregnant and would have to carry a baby for<strong> nine</strong> months!	<strong>Nine</strong> baseball players, bowing low on the ground on hands and knees, before the game starts. おねがいします！.		
十		ten	Turn this character 45 degrees either way and you have the x used for the Roman numeral <b>ten</b>.	* As a primitive, this character sometimes keeps its meaning of <i>ten</i> and sometimes signifies <i>needle</i>, this latter derived from the kanji for <i>needle</i> (Frame 292). Since the primitive is used in the kanji itself, there is no need to worry about confusing the two. In fact, we shall be following this procedure regularly.	2	10	10	1	ジュウ、ジッ、ジュッ	とお、と	Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for<strong> ten</strong> (rotated 45 degrees).	I scared away<strong> ten</strong> vampires with a single cross!	<strong>Ten</strong> looks like a plus sign.	A roman<strong> ten</strong> (X) standing on one leg.	T for<strong> ten</strong>.		
口		mouth	Like several of the first characters we shall learn, the kanji for <b>mouth</b> is a clear pictograph. Since there are no circular shapes in the kanji, the square must be used to depict the circle.	* As a primitive, this form also means <i>mouth</i>. Any of the range of possible images that the word suggests - an opening or entrance to a cave, a river, a bottle, or even the largest hole in your head - can be used for the primitive meaning.	3	11	11	1	コウ、ク	くち	Looks like a huge open<strong> mouth</strong>.	When you sneeze, your<strong> MOUTH</strong> forms a square, and you make a noise that sounds like (KUCHI).	"If you say ""kuchi"" one more time, I'm going to <em>box</em> you in the<strong> mouth</strong>. (""kuchi"" is how your pronounce this kanji, box is the memory symbol )."	"Momma used to say: ""Keep your trap shut!"" This thing is shaped like a trap door."	Sponge Bob Square<strong> Mouth</strong>.		
日		day	"This kanji is intended to be a pictograph of the sun. Recalling what we said in the previous frame about round forms, it is easy to detect the circle and the big smile that characterize our simplest drawings of the sun - like those yellow badges with the words, ""Have a nice <b>day</b>!"""	"* Used as a primitive, this kanji can mean <i>sun</i> or <i>day</i> or a <i>tongue wagging in the mouth</i>. This latter meaning, incidentally, derives from an old character outside the standard list meaning something like ""sayeth"" and written almost exactly the same, except that the stroke in the middle does not touch the right side (Frame 620)."	4	12	12	1	ニチ、ジツ	ひ、-び、-か	Open the window, new<strong> day</strong>.	Picture two halves of a 24-hr period:<strong> Day</strong> & Night.	Open window because its a <em>sunny</em><strong> day</strong>.	On Sun<strong>day</strong>, church-goers sings hymns, their <em>tongues wagging in their mouths</em>.	"=sun;<strong> day</strong>： Each time the SUN rises a new<strong> DAY</strong> begins. <a href=""../v4/12.html"">day</a> (#12 日) is a picture of the sun. Normally we draw the sun with a circle(ㅇ) surrounded by many strokes. But there are no “round” shaped Kanji so we take <a href=""../v4/11.html"">mouth</a> (#11 口) instead, and one stroke in the middle (one (#1 一)) representing all. 日本 Japan, 日曜日 （ニチジヨウび）Sunday, 毎日 （マイニチ）everyday, 母の日 （ははのひ）mother's<strong> day</strong>, 日記 （ニッキ）diary, 三日 （ミッカ）three<strong> day</strong>s."		
月		month	"This character is actually a picture of the moon, with the two horizontal lines representing the left eye and mouth of the mythical ""man in the moon."" (Actually, the Japanese see a hare in the moon, but it is a little farfetched to find one in the kanji.) And one <b>month</b>, of course, is one cycle of the moon."	* As a primitive element, this character can take on the sense of <i>moon</i>, <i>flesh</i>, or <i>part of the body</i>. The reasons for the latter two meanings will be explained in a later chapter.	4	13	13	1	ゲツ、ガツ	つき	A<strong> month</strong> is longer than a day.	"Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air ""mooning"" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of<strong> month</strong>, considering that<strong> month</strong>s were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning ""ass"" part of it connects well to Hesig's seemingly unconnected ""flesh"" or ""part of the body"" meaning (when used in primitive form)."	<strong>Month</strong> - every MOON cycle, werewolves eat FLESH, and other PARTs OF THE BODY.	Once a<strong> month</strong>, the moon is full.	A<strong> month</strong> is longer than a day.		
田		rice field	Another pictograph, this kanji looks like a bird's-eye view of a <b>rice field</b> divided into four plots. Be careful when writing this character to get the order of the strokes correct. You will find that it follows perfectly the principle stated in frame 4.	* When used as a primitive element, the meaning of <i>rice field</i> is most common, but now and again it will take the meaning of <i>brains</i> from the fact that it looks a bit like that tangle of gray matter nestled under our skulls.	5	14	14	1	デン	た	A<strong> rice field</strong> divided into four parts.	<em>Ten</em> people use their <em>mouths</em> to eat the yield of the <strong>rice fields</strong>.	<em>Ten</em><strong> rice field</strong>s can feed many <em>mouths</em>.	A farmer must use his <em>brain</em> to measure out a 4-plot <strong>rice field</strong>.	One day the farmer is neatly digging his<strong> rice field</strong> chopping down with his spade in two directions at 90 degrees, when suddenly there is a crunching sound as he has chopped twice into the skull of a dead body exposing the <strong>brain</strong>s sliced into four pieces. Ughhh !		
目		eye	Here again, if we round out the corners of this kanji and curve the middle strokes upwards and downwards respectively, we get something resembling an <b>eye</b>.	* As a primitive, the kanji keeps its sense of <i>eye</i>, or more specifically, an <i>eyeball</i>. When placed in the surroundings of a complex kanji, the primitive will sometimes be turned on its side.	5	15	15	1	モク、ボク	め、-め、ま-	目 _ 目 .	There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your<strong> eye</strong>. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.	This one comes from an ancient character that was an<strong> eye</strong>. It is an<strong> eye</strong> rotated in 90 degree but got squared (think about anime style<strong> eye</strong>s).	目 _ 目 .	( 目 _ 目 ).		
古		old	"The primitive elements that compose this character are <i>ten</i> and <i>mouth</i>, but you may find it easier to remember it as a pictograph of a tombstone with a cross on top. Just think back to one of those graveyards you have visited, or better still, used to play in as a child, with <b>old</b> inscriptions on the tombstones. This departure from the primitive elements in favor of a pictograph will take place now and again at these early stages, and almost never after that. So you need not worry about cluttering up your memory with too many character ""drawings."""	* Used as a primitive element, this kanji keeps its key-word sense of <i>old</i>, but care should be taken to make that abstract notion as graphic as possible.	5	16	16	2	コ	ふる.い、ふる-、-ふる.す	Tombstone and cross on an<strong> old</strong> man's grave.	You get<strong> OLD</strong> fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.	<strong>Old</strong> people tend to talk a lot. Almost as if they had TEN MOUTHS!	The<strong> old</strong> man had only <em>10</em> teeth in his <em>mouth</em>.	A story is<strong> OLD</strong> when it has been told by <em>TEN MOUTH</em>s.		
吾		I	"There are actually a number of kanji for the word <b>I</b>, but the others tend to be more specific than this one. The key word here should be taken in the general psychological sense of the ""perceiving subject."" Now the one place in our bodies that all <i>five</i> senses are concentrated in is the head, which has no less than <i>five mouths</i>: 2 nostrils, 2 ears, and 1 mouth. Hence, <i>five mouths</i> = <b>I</b>."		7	17	17	2	ゴ	われ、わが-、あ-	I have 5 senses.	I eat five times at day.	<strong>I</strong> consist of <em>five</em> senses to observe, one <em>mouth</em> to speak. <em>For order, remember that observing through the senses should be done before using one's mouth</em>.	I have two eyes, nose, two ears = 5 plus one mouth.	I can fit all five of my fingers in my mouth! :D.		
冒		risk	Remember when you were young and your mother told you never to look directly into the <i>sun</i> for fear you might burn out your <i>eyes</i>? Probably you were foolish enough to <b>risk</b> a quick glance once or twice; but just as probably, you passed that bit of folk wisdom on to someone else as you grew older. Here, too, the kanji that has a <i>sun</i> above and an <i>eye</i> right below looking up at it has the meaning of <b>risk</b> (see frame 12).		9	18	18	2	ボウ	おか.す	Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's<strong> risk</strong>y!	You'll<strong> risk</strong> your eyesight if you look up at the sun.	"Looking up at the big sun is a<strong> risk</strong> to your eye. To remember that the sun primitive is bigger than the eye primitive, imagine making your eyes little (squinting) when you go out in the bright sun to reduce the<strong> risk</strong> of getting sun blindness. READING: imagine a kid saying ""oh that's ぼう (bull as in B.S.), looking at the sun is no<strong> risk</strong>!"" [he's blind now]."	Staring into the big <em>sun</em> can<strong> risk</strong> your <em>eye</em>sight! HINT: It looks like a pipe from Super Mario Bros. It might be<strong> risk</strong>y to go down it. :p.	If you look at the <em>sun</em> high in the sky directly with your <em>eyes</em> below, you're taking a big<strong> risk</strong>.		
朋		companion	"The first <b>companion</b> that God made, as the Bible story goes, was Eve. Upon seeing her, Adam exclaimed, ""<i>Flesh</i> of my <i>flesh</i>!"" And that is precisely what this character says in so many strokes."		8	19	19	2	ホウ	とも	My<strong> companion</strong> and I are like two moons side by side.	One moon is lonely. Two moons are<strong> companion</strong>s.	Under the twin moons of Tatooine, Luke had no<strong> COMPANION</strong>.	Two bodies next to each other;<strong> companion</strong>s.	Real<strong> companion</strong>s stay together during dark times, under many MOONS, or many MONTHS…		
明		bright	Among nature's <b>bright</b> lights, there are two that the biblical myth has God set in the sky: the <i>sun</i> to rule over the day and the <i>moon</i> to rule the night. Each of them has come to represent one of the common connotations of this key word: the <i>sun</i>, the <b>bright</b> insight of the clear thinker, and the <i>moon</i>, the <b>bright</b> intuition of the poet and the seer (see frame 13).		8	20	20	2	メイ、ミョウ、ミン	あ.かり、あか.るい、あか.るむ、あか.らむ、あき.らか、あ.ける、-あ.け、あ.く、あ.くる、あ.かす	The sun makes the moon<strong> bright</strong>.	The sun and the moon are<strong> bright</strong>est objects in the day and night, respectively.	"In the long run, the REAL trouble here is distinguishing it from ""shining""/""sparkle"". Choose a story to learn how to write 明 . To distinguish it, remember the Japanese word 明日 (ashita, ""tomorrow"") and think of Orphan Annie singing ""<em>Tomorrow</em> is a<strong> bright</strong>er day""."	The SUN is<strong> BRIGHT</strong>ER than the MOON.	"About the order of the primitives: The phrase that I usually hear is ""the sun and moon,"" so to help me remember the order, I'll remember that phrase. Oh! Better yet, I'll put them <em>in order of<strong> bright</strong>ness</em>."		
唱		chant	This one is easy! You have one <i>mouth</i> making no noise (the choirmaster) and two <i>mouths with wagging tongues</i> (the minimum for a chorus). So think of the key word, <b>chant</b>, as monastery singing and the kanji is yours forever (see frame 11).		11	21	21	2	ショウ	とな.える	Someone<strong> chant</strong>ing with their mouth open for two consecutive days.	<strong>Chant</strong>s from our mouths are meant to reach the sun and the stars. Stars are just suns just further away so they seem smaller.	His <em>mouth</em><strong> chant</strong>s always when <em>prosperous</em>.	The monk opened his month and<strong> chant</strong>ed for two days.	"A yogi opens his <em>mouth</em> and<strong> chant</strong>s for <em>two straight days</em>! [So, did you reach nirvana? ""Nah, got a wicked sore throat, though.""]."		
晶		sparkle	"What else can the word <b>sparkle</b> suggest if not a diamond? And if you've ever held a diamond up to the light, you will have noticed how every facet of it becomes like a miniature <i>sun</i>. This kanji is a picture of a tiny <i>sun</i> in three places (that is, ""everywhere""), to give the sense of something that <b>sparkles</b> on all sides. Just like a diamond. In writing the primitive elements three times, note again how the rule for writing given in frame 4 holds true not only for the strokes in each individual element but also for the disposition of the elements in the character as a whole."		12	22	22	2	ショウ		A diamond<strong> sparkle</strong>s as brightly as three suns.	"<strong>Sparkle</strong> is a <a href=""../v4/197.html"">forest</a> (#197 森) of <em>suns</em>!"	<strong>Sparkle</strong>, three suns sparkling like zelda pyramids ;-).	Nothing<strong> sparkle</strong>s like <em>3 suns</em>!	Wow - Has been ages since I got this character up in a review, I failed it because I thought of a different kanji. Anyway this Kanji has a lot to do with crystals and crystal structure 液晶 liquid crystal, 結晶 crystal, crystallization, crystallisation, 結晶学 crystallography. So the connotation of 'diamond' is really good - maintain that and it will easily let you fall back to its main usage of crystals.		
品		goods	"As in the character for <i>sparkle</i>, the triplication of a single element in this character indicates ""everywhere"" or ""heaps of."" When we think of <b>goods</b> in modern industrial society, we think of what has been mass-produced - that is to say, produced for the ""masses"" of open <i>mouths</i> waiting like fledglings in a nest to ""consume"" whatever comes their way."		9	23	23	2	ヒン、ホン	しな	<em>Three boxes</em> of<strong> goods</strong> are devoured by the hungry <em>mouths</em> of waiting consumers.	Three hungry mouths waiting for the<strong> goods</strong> to come.	Boxes of<strong> goods</strong> stacked on top of the other.	Three stacked crates of <em>mouth</em>-watering<strong> GOODS</strong>, ready for delivery to the restaurant.	Three MOUTHs talk about these <em>three boxes</em> of<strong> GOODS</strong> : the producer’s, the supplier’s and the customer’s.		
呂		spine	This character is rather like a picture of two of the vertebrae in the <b>spine</b> linked by a single stroke.		7	24	24	2	ロ、リョ	せぼね	<strong>Spine</strong> connects head and body.	The<strong> spine</strong> goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (genitals). Just think of these openings being enlarged to represent the head and the body. The bottom is bigger because the body is bigger than the face.	The<strong> spine</strong> goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (in your ass).	I looks like two vertebrae connected by nerve threads.	"In ""The Human Centipede"", one<strong> spine</strong> connects two mouths to keep the food circulating."		
昌		prosperous	"What we mentioned in the previous two frames about 3 of something meaning ""everywhere"" or ""heaps of"" was not meant to be taken lightly. In this kanji we see <i>two suns</i>, one atop the other, which, if we are not careful, is easily confused in memory with the <i>three suns</i> of <i>sparkle</i>. Focus on the number this way: since we speak of <b>prosperous</b> times as <i>sunny</i>, what could be more <b>prosperous</b> than a sky with <i>two suns</i> in it? Just be sure to actually SEE them there."		8	25	25	2	ショウ	さかん	If you work from Sun UP to Sun DOWN you will be<strong> prosperous</strong>.	I kept getting this mixed up with meanings like 'fortune', so here is a fool proof story! Remember the Vulcan salute from 'Star Trek' (a fiction of the sci-fi genre in which heavenly bodies such as SUNS play a huge role) used with the phrase 'live long and PROSPER'? If that's not enough of a visual reminder, the Vulcan salute shows the fingers parted in to 2 sets of 2, and visually kind of looks like this kanji if you think about it.	When you are<strong> prosperous</strong>, your gold shines as brightly as two suns.	The Egyptians were<strong> prosperous</strong> because every two days, they worshiped the sun god at the sun pyramid. (Thanks for the idea adhmm, for a while I have had trouble remembering which sun is biggest. Got it now!).	If you work from <em>sun up</em> to <em>sun down</em> you will be<strong> prosperous</strong>.		
早		early	This kanji is actually a picture of the first flower of the day, which we shall, in defiance of botanical science, call the <i>sun</i>flower, since it begins with the element for <i>sun</i> and is held upon a stem with leaves (the pictographic representation of the final two strokes). This time, however, we shall ignore the pictograph and imagine <i>sun</i>flowers with <i>needles</i> for stems, which can be plucked and used to darn your socks. The sense of <b>early</b> is easily remembered if one thinks of the <i>sun</i>flower as the <b>early</b> riser in the garden, because the <i>sun</i>, showing favoritism towards its namesake, shines on it before all the others (see frame 10).	* As a primitive element, this kanji takes the meaning of <i>sunflower</i>, which was used to make the abstract key word <i>early</i> more graphic.	6	26	26	2	ソウ、サッ	はや.い、はや、はや-、はや.まる、はや.める、さ-	The <em>sun</em> up is<strong> early</strong>, well before <em>ten</em>.	An<strong> early</strong> sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.	<strong>EARLY</strong>, is when you have to start your <em>day</em> before <em>10</em>..	The <em>sun</em> rises<strong> early</strong> - before <em>ten</em>.	Sun flower blossom<strong> early</strong>.		
旭		rising sun	This character is a sort of nickname for the Japanese flag with its well-known emblem of the <b>rising sun</b>. If you can picture two seams running down that great red <i>sun</i>, and then imagine it sitting on a <i>baseball</i> bat for a flagpole, you have a slightly irreverent - but not altogether inaccurate - picture of how the sport has caught on in the Land of the <b>Rising Sun</b>.		6	27	27	2	キョク	あさひ	9am carries with it the<strong> rising sun</strong>.	<em>Nine planets</em> revolve around our<strong> rising sun</strong>.	The sun rises before 9am.	When the clock says <em>9</em> on the left, you can see the <strong>rising <em>sun</em></strong> in the east (right).	A baseball player hits the sun and it becomes the<strong> rising sun</strong>.		
世		generation	"We generally consider one <b>generation</b> as a period of thirty (or <i>ten</i> plus <i>ten</i> plus <i>ten</i>) years. If you look at this kanji in its completed form - not in its stroke order - you will see three <i>tens</i>. When writing it, think of the lower horizontal lines as ""addition"" lines written under numbers to add them up. Thus: <i>ten</i> ""plus"" <i>ten</i> ""plus"" <i>ten</i> = thirty. Actually, it's a lot easier doing it with a pencil than reading it in a book."		5	28	28	2	セイ、セ、ソウ	よ、さんじゅう	3 tens =<strong> generation</strong>.	"They <strong>SAY</strong> a<strong> generation</strong> is <em>ten</em>+<em>ten</em>+<em>ten</em> years, with the big first <em>ten</em> providing a <em>grounding</em>, and the next <em>ten</em> providing a little more <em>grounding</em> for the final <em>ten</em>. But I wish the next<strong> generation</strong> didn't always <strong>SAY</strong> ""<strong>yo!</strong>"". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo)."	The next<strong> generation</strong> is carried by the previous ones.	That swing has been in that tree for<strong> generation</strong>s.	This looks like a picture of a test tube in a holder. Maybe it will be used to create test tube babies for a future<strong> generation</strong>.		
胃		stomach	"You will need to refer back to frames 13 and 14 here for the special meaning of the two primitive elements that make up this character: <i>flesh</i> (<i>part of the body</i>) and <i>brain</i>. What the kanji says, if you look at it, is that the <i>part of the body</i> that keeps the <i>brain</i> in working order is the <b>stomach</b>. To keep the elements in proper order, when you write this kanji think of the <i>brain</i> as being ""held up"" by the <i>flesh</i>."		9	29	29	2	イ		The <em>rice field</em> is harvested once a <em>month</em> to get food for our<strong> stomach</strong>.	The<strong> stomach</strong> is the part of the body that digests food (which, in Japan, is mainly rice).	The<strong> stomach</strong> is the part of the body ( 月 ）that tells my brain ( 田 ) when to eat rice.	The astronaut had an empty <em>stomach</em> because you can't grow <strong>rice</strong> <em>on the</em> <strong>moon</strong>.	A field of rice could fill my<strong> stomach</strong> for over a month.		
旦		nightbreak	"While we normally refer to the start of the day as ""daybreak,"" Japanese commonly refers to it as the ""opening up of night"" into day. Hence the choice of this rather odd key word, <b>nightbreak</b>. The single stroke at the bottom represents the <i>floor</i> (have a peek again at frame 1) or the horizon over which the <i>sun</i> is poking its head"		5	30	30	2	タン、ダン	あき.らか、あきら、ただし、あさ、あした	A<strong> nightbreak</strong> happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).	"It may be easier to think of the keyword ""DAYBREAK"" or ""MORNING"" for this kanji (other kanji dictionaries do). Then the mnemonic phrase ""SUN rising over the HORIZON"" works better. It is an infrequent kanji, but can be found in: 旦夕 （たんせき） morning and evening, or 元旦 （がんたん） New Year's Day."	The <em>sun</em> rising over the horizon is giving the <strong>night</strong> a <strong>break</strong>. -<strong>nightbreak</strong>.	"HINT: You can substitute <strong>sunrise</strong> in your stories if you don't like the rare (and ambiguous) ""nightbreak"". Note that <a href=""../v4/1201.html"">daybreak</a> (#1201 暁) is already taken. Don't confuse with <a href=""../v4/27.html"">rising sun</a> (#27 旭), which is the sun itself, rather than the time of the day."	<strong>Nightbreak</strong>s when the <em>sun</em> peeks over the <em>horizon</em> at dawn.		
胆		gall bladder	"The pieces in this character should be easily recognizable: on the left, the element for <i>part of the body</i>, and on the right, the character for <i>nightbreak</i>, which we have just met. What all of this has to do with the <b>gall bladder</b> is not immediately clear. But all we need to do is give a slight twist to the traditional biblical advice about not letting the sun set on your anger (which ancient medicine associated with the choler or bile that the <b>gall bladder</b> is supposed to filter out), and change it to ""not letting the <i>night break</i> on your anger"" (or your <b>gall</b>) - and the work of remembering the kanji is done. And the improvement is not a bad piece of advice in its own right, since anger, like so many other things, can often be calmed by letting the sun set on it and then ""sleeping it off."""		9	31	31	2	タン	きも	The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.	All the <em>month</em> long I have to start working at <em>nightbreak</em>. This really activates my<strong> gall bladder</strong> (=I get angry).	For a month（ 月 ）, I was up until nightbreak（ 旦 ） because of my<strong> gall bladder</strong>（ 胆 ）.	The<strong> gall bladder</strong> digests the flesh (meat) before nightbreak so you are ready to start your new day.	If you drink all night long (moon), until the night break your<strong> gall bladder</strong> will have problems…		
亘		span	"""Sunrise, sunset, sunrise, sunset..."" goes the song of the Fiddler on the Roof. You can almost see the journey of the sun as it moves from one horizon (the <i>floor</i>) to its noonday heights in the sky overhead (<i>ceiling</i>) and then disappears over the other horizon - day after day, marking the <b>span</b> of our lives."		6	32	32	2	コウ、カン	わた.る、もと.める	The sun<strong> span</strong>s from horizon to horizon in a day.	The<strong> span</strong> of the day is the time between the sun goes up and comes down.	The sunlight<strong> span</strong>s from the floor to the ceiling.	The sun<strong> span</strong>s the heaven and the earth.	A sun<strong> span</strong>-wich.		
凹		concave	"You couldn't have asked for a better key word for this kanji! Just have a look at it: a perfect image of a <b>concave</b> lens (remembering, of course, that the kanji square off rounded things), complete with its own little ""cave."" Now all you have to do is learn how to write it."		5	33	33	2	オウ	くぼ.む、へこ.む、ぼこ	"The letter ""U"" is<strong> concave</strong>ly written."	<strong>Concave</strong> has a<strong> concave</strong> shape.	Stroke order: I took a step down into the cave. A park ranger threw down a line to me from the opposite top ridge, then waited. My friend went down to the lowest passage to look for me, then the ranger threw another line down to her.	<strong>Concave</strong> is like a vagina.	Her<strong> CONCAVE</strong> 凹 pussy was fucked by my convex 凸 cock.		
凸		convex	Maybe this helps you see how the Japanese have no trouble keeping <b>convex</b> distinct from <i>concave</i>. Note the odd feeling of the third stroke. If it doesn't feel all that strange now, by the time you are done with this book, it will. There are very few times you will have to write it.		5	34	34	2	トツ	でこ	When I get <em>vex</em>ed, I give people the middle finger.	<strong>Convex</strong> has a<strong> convex</strong> shape. 旧		olden times	"A <i>walking stick</i> is needed for <i>days</i> of <b>olden times</b>, since <i>days</i>, too, get old - at least insofar as we refer to them as the ""good old days."" The main thing here is to think of ""good old days"" when you hear the key word <b>olden times</b>. The rest will take care of itself."		5	35	35	3	キュウ	ふる.い、もと	Age 18 =<strong> olden times</strong>.
