In the<strong> olden times</strong> the sun used a walking stick, cursing and swinging at planets as they whizzed by.	The number 18 on an<strong> olden times</strong> calculator.		
自		oneself	You can think of this kanji as a stylized pictograph of the nose, that little <i>drop</i> that Mother Nature set between your <i>eyes</i>. The Japanese refer to themselves by pointing a finger at their nose - giving us an easy way to remember the kanji for <b>oneself</b>.	* The same meaning of <i>oneself</i> can be kept when this kanji is used as a primitive element, but you will generally find it better to give it the meaning of <i>nose</i> or <i>nostrils</i>, both because it accords with the story above and because it is the first part of the kanji for <i>nose</i> (Frame 733).	6	36	36	3	ジ、シ	みずか.ら、おの.ずから、おの.ずと	To use an eyedropper by<strong> oneself</strong>, aim from <em>above</em> to put a <em>drop</em> into the <em>eye</em>.	Faced with his clone, our hero valiantly cut a <em>mark</em> on his forehead right above his <em>eye</em> so that his comrades could tell his true<strong> oneself</strong> from the enemy.	"I know this, but I am an idiot and forgot…. The way I remember this is to think of the way in which Japanese people point to themselves if they are unsure of who is being spoken to. In the west, we usually say, ""me?"" and point to ourselves (pointing to the chest), but in Japan, people say, ""ore/boku/atashi?"" and point directly at their nose, the drop between their eyes. True story."	Eyedrops are applied by<strong> ONESELF</strong>.	Me, myself and eye.		
白		white	The color <b>white</b> is a mixture of all the primary colors, both for pigments and for light, as we see when a prism breaks up the rays of the sun. Hence, a single <i>drop</i> of <i>sun</i> spells <b>white</b>.	* As a primitive, this character can either retain its meaning of <i>white</i> or take the more graphic meaning of a <i>white bird</i> or <i>dove</i>. This latter stems from the fact that it appears at the top of the kanji for <i>bird</i>, which we shall get to later (Frame 2091).	5	37	37	3	ハク、ビャク	しろ、しら-、しろ.い	A<strong> white</strong> ray is a drop of sun.	Even a small drop (') of the sun ( 日 ) would make you see nothing but<strong> white</strong>.	It's a nice DAY for a<strong> WHITE</strong> wedding.	<strong>WHITE</strong> is a drop of sun.	A <em>drop</em> one <em>day</em> fell from above; it was<strong> white</strong> and from a <em>dove</em>… gross.		
百		hundred	"The Japanese refer to a person's 99th birthday as a ""<i>white</i> year"" because <i>white</i> is the kanji you are left with if you subtract <i>one</i> from a <b>hundred</b>."		6	38	38	3	ヒャク、ビャク	もも	100 turned sideways. sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said.	That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a<strong> hundred</strong> times!	<strong>Hundred</strong> is 1 0 0 written from top to bottom. 一 is connected with the two concatenated 口 because the latter would otherwise fall off.	"The ""white year"" (99) plus one more. 100!"	Two O hung on one.		
中		in	The elements here are a <i>walking stick</i> and a <i>mouth</i>. Remember the trouble your mother had getting medicine <b>in</b> your <i>mouth</i>? Chances are it crossed her mind more than once to grab something handy, like your grandfather's <i>walking stick</i>, to pry open your jaws while she performed her duty. Keep the image of getting something <b>in</b> from the outside, and the otherwise abstract sense of this key word should be a lot easier than trying to spoon castor oil <b>in</b>to a baby's mouth.		4	39	39	3	チュウ	なか、うち、あた.る	Pocky goes<strong> in</strong> the mouth.	My GF lets me come<strong> in</strong> her mouth (pictogram).	It's my dick<strong> in</strong> a box! 千		thousand	This kanji is almost too simple to pull apart, but for the sake of practice, have a look at the <i>drop</i> above and the <i>ten</i> below. Now put the elements together by thinking of squeezing two more zeros out of an <i>eyedropper</i> alongside the number <i>ten</i> to make it a <b>thousand</b>.		3	40	40	3	セン	ち	It takes many drops of ten to get to a<strong> thousand</strong>.	<em>One</em> T = one<strong> thousand</strong>.	<strong>1000</strong> = <em>10</em>^3 (<em>3 strokes</em>).	The primitives of <em>drop</em> and <em>needles</em> are at work here. One drop from this needle could save <strong>thousands</strong> of lives!	The number ten bought a fancy hat for a<strong> THOUSAND</strong> yen!		
舌		tongue	"The primitive for <i>mouth</i> and the character for <i>thousand</i> naturally form the idea of <b>tongue</b> if one thinks of a <i>thousand mouths</i> able to speak the same language, or as we say, ""sharing a common <b>tongue</b>."" It is easy to see the connection between the idiom and the kanji if you take its image literally: a single <b>tongue</b> being passed around from <i>mouth</i> to <i>mouth</i>."		6	41	41	3	ゼツ	した	What is in a <em>mouth</em> that permits it to speak a <em>thousand</em> things? Yes, a <strong>tongue</strong>.	A <em>thousand mouths</em> speak the same<strong> TONGUE</strong>.	Kissing a <em>thousand</em> <em>mouths</em> eventually gets you some<strong> tongue</strong>.	Thousand mouths, a thousand<strong> tongue</strong>s.	"When you <em>drop</em> because you are <a href=""../v4/16.html"">old</a> (#16 古), you stick your<strong> tongue</strong> out."		
升		measuring box	This is the character for the little wooden box that the Japanese use for measuring things, as well as for drinking saké out of. Simply imagine the outside as spiked with a <i>thousand</i> sharp <i>needles</i>, and the quaint little <b>measuring box</b> becomes a drinker's nightmare! Be very careful when you write this character not to confuse it with the writing of <i>thousand</i>. The reason for the difference gives us a chance to clarify another general principle of writing that supersedes the one we mentioned in frame 4: when a single stroke runs vertically through the middle of a character, it is written last.		4	42	42	3	ショウ	ます	It is a thousand or ten? I need my<strong> measuring box</strong>.	I can fit a thousand needles into my<strong> measuring box</strong>, but only if I bend the thousand.	A<strong> measuring box</strong> is a square wooden box that was used to measure one thousand grains of rice (needles) in feudal Japan. It was supposed to be enough to feed a working man for one day.	Be careful when drinking sake out of a deep<strong> measuring box</strong>. The hangover can feel like a thousand needles.	Give me a thousand smacks with a walking stick if I forget the Kanji for<strong> measuring box</strong> again!		
昇		rise up	"Our image here is made up of two primitive elements: a <i>sun</i> and a <i>measuring box</i>. Just as the <i>sun</i> can be seen <b>rising up</b> in the morning from - where else - the Land of the Rising Sun, this kanji has the <i>sun</i> <b>rising up</b> out of a Japanese <i>measuring box</i> - the ""<i>measuring box</i> of the <b>rising-up</b> <i>sun</i>."""		8	43	43	3	ショウ	のぼ.る	"This kanji does not mean ""get up"" or ""awake."" It means rising, like the rising of a salary, or a promotion. STORY: You know that your salary has RISEN UP when your MEASURING BOX has enough dollar bills in it to reach the SUN."	We Measure the Sun to decide when we should<strong> Rise Up</strong> out of bed.	If the <em>sun</em> sat on the <em>measuring box</em> made of a thousand needles he would<strong> rise up</strong> very quickly.	In old Japan the villagers used to put their measuring box on an east facing window ledge so that the sun would<strong> rise up</strong> above it and hence would be the first thing they saw in the morning. This was to remind them to use the box to measure out their kome for asagohan and ensure their store of rice would last the whole week.	"""When sun<strong> RISE UP</strong>, get sake cup.""."		
丸		round	"We speak of ""<b>round</b> numbers,"" or ""<b>rounding</b> a number off,"" meaning to add an insignificant amount to bring it to the nearest 10. For instance, if you add just a wee bit, the tiniest <i>drop</i>, to <i>nine</i>, you end up with a <b>round</b> number."	* As a primitive, this element takes the meaning of a <i>fat man</i>. Think of a grotesquely <i>fat man</i> whose paunch so covers the plate that he is always getting hit by the pitch. Hence a <i>round baseball player</i> becomes a <i>fat man</i>.	3	44	44	3	ガン	まる、まる.める、まる.い	Nine plus a drop<strong> round</strong>s it off to ten!	"Watch out for <a href=""../v4/120.html"">plump</a> (#120 太). Here Heisig could have added a ""t"" and we would have had a much better keyword : <strong>rotund</strong>. <strong>Rotund</strong> is more specific than ""round"" which begs for confusion with <a href=""../v4/1811.html"">circle</a> (#1811 円). A dictionary search on ""fat"" or ""round"" doesn't yield this kanji, but ""rotund"" does! Primitive suggestion: the <em>Laughing Buddha</em> is often depicted as a <strong>rotund</strong>, smiling bald man in robes with a largely exposed pot belly stomach (symbolizing plenitude)."	NINE plus a little DROP to <strong>round</strong> up to ten.	Cut the tail off of a 9 and it will be<strong> round</strong>.	In nine months a drop of sperm can make a woman very<strong> round</strong>.		
寸		measurement	This kanji actually stood for a small <b>measurement</b> used prior to the metric system, a bit over an inch in length, and from there acquired the sense of <b>measurement</b>. In the old system, it was one-<i>tenth</i> of a <i>shaku</i> (whose kanji we shall meet in frame 1151). The picture, appropriately, represents one <i>drop</i> of a <i>ten</i> (with a hook!).	* As a primitive, we shall use this to mean <i>glue</i> or <i>glued to</i>. There is no need to devise a story to remember this, since the primitive will appear so often you would have to struggle hard NOT to remember it.	3	45	45	3	スン		The decimal system uses <em>drops</em> of <em>ten</em> as a<strong> measurement</strong>.	Glue two sticks together to make the best<strong> measurement</strong>. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).	Use two lines (X axis and Y axis) to measure the dot (on the graph).	Take your medicine, exactly <em>ten</em> <em>drops</em>. Picture yourself <strong>measuring</strong> it out with a pipette.	A single shaku is divided into 10 sun ( 寸 ). The original definition for shaku was the average distance between growth nodes on a bamboo. Thus a <em>tenth</em> of a shaku is a<strong> measurement</strong>.		
肘		elbow	"Instead of the familiar ""grease"" we usually associate with the <b>elbow</b> of someone hard at work, the kanji gives us a <i>part of the body</i> that has been <i>glued to</i> its task."		7	46	2464	3	チュウ	ひじ	Sometimes I get carried away and do<strong> elbow</strong> curls until the point where my forearm snaps off! When that happens I simply pull out the <em>glue</em> and re-attach the<strong> elbow</strong> to my <em>flesh</em>.	Picture two Siamese twins glued together at the<strong> elbow</strong>.	The<strong> elbow</strong> is the <em>flesh</em> that <em>glues</em> together the upper and lower arm.	A <em>body part</em> that's used as a <em>measurement</em> in former days: the <strong>elbow</strong>.	"A <em>body part</em> used in the expression ""<strong>Elbow</strong> room"" as a <em>measure</em> of how much space exists around us."		
専		specialty	"<i>Ten</i> . . . <i>rice fields</i> . . . <i>glue</i>. That is how one would read the primitive elements of this kanji from top to bottom. Now if we make a simple sentence out of these elements, we get: ""<i>Ten rice fields glued</i> together."" A <b>specialty</b>, of course, refers to one's special ""<i>field</i>"" of endeavor or competence. In fact, few people remain content with a single <b>specialty</b> and usually extend themselves in other <i>fields</i> as well. This is how we come to get the picture of <i>ten fields glued</i> together to represent a <b>specialty</b>."		9	47	46	3	セン	もっぱ.ら	After you have chosen your <em>10</em> <em>fields</em> of study, <em>measure</em> how good you are at each to find out your<strong> specialty</strong>.	10 brains glued together allows you to specialize in any<strong> specialty</strong> that you want. Imagine each brain having its own<strong> specialty</strong>.	She's so good at her <strong>speciality</strong>, it's like <em>ten</em> <em>brains</em> <em>glue</em>d together.	I'm a Rice Field Measurer! That is, my<strong> specialty</strong> is 'measuring' 'ten' 'rice fields' at a time.	A person's<strong> specialty</strong> or <em>field</em>, may change <em>up</em> to <em>ten</em> times before they finally settle <em>down</em> and <em>stick</em> with their liking.		
博		Dr.	At the left we have the <i>needle</i>; at the right, the kanji for <i>specialty</i>, plus an extra <i>drop</i> at the top. Think of a <b>Dr.</b> who is a <i>specialist</i> with a <i>needle</i> (an acupuncturist) and let the <i>drop</i> at the top represent the period at the end of <b>Dr.</b> In principle we are trying to avoid this kind of device, which plays on abstract grammatical conventions; but I think you will agree, after you have had occasion to use the right side of this kanji in forming other kanji, that the exception is merited in this case.	* The primitive form of this kanji eliminates the <i>needle</i> on the left and gets the meaning of an <i>acupuncturist</i>.	12	48	47	3	ハク、バク		<em>Ten specialties</em> grants you the title of<strong> Dr.</strong> with a dot.	"Watch for <a href=""../v4/1694.html"">doctor</a> (#1694 医), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well ""learned"", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 (""doctor"") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as ""Dr. Who"", ""Dr. Jekyll"", even ""Dr. Dobb's"" if you're into programming."	<em>Needles</em> are a<strong> Dr.</strong>'s <em>specialty</em>.	"<strong>Dr</strong>. Who weaves like a <em>needle</em> through the fabric of time, to <em>drop</em> in unexpectedly has become his <a href=""../v4/46.html"">specialty</a> (#46 専) ."	Note: Use <strong>Ph.D.</strong> rather than <strong>Dr.</strong> to avoid confusion with <strong>doctor</strong> and to be more in line with common use of this kanji. <em>Ten</em> <em>specialities</em> grants you the title of <strong>Ph.D.</strong> with a <em>dot</em>.		
占		fortune-telling	This is one of those kanji that is a real joy of simplicity: a <i>divining rod</i> with a <i>mouth</i> - which translate directly into <b>fortune-telling</b>. Note how the movement from top to bottom (the movement in which the kanji are written) is also the order of the elements which make up our story and of the key word itself: first <i>divining rod</i>, then <i>mouth</i>. This will not always be possible, but where it is, memory has almost no work at all to do.		5	49	48	3	セン	し.める、うらな.う	<strong>Fortune-telling</strong>: using a mouth as a divining rod.	"A great number of people who do<strong> fortune-telling</strong> are ""almost old""."	To do<strong> fortune-telling</strong> put a <em>magic wand</em> in your <em>mouth</em>.	The mouth of a fortune-teller is a superior (above) mouth.	The old fortune teller was missing an arm.		
上		above	"The two directions, <b>above</b> and below, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a <i>magic wand</i> standing <b><i>above</i></b> a <i>floor</i> - ""magically,"" you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words <b>above</b> and <i>below</i> suggest each other."		3	50	49	3	ジョウ、ショウ、シャン	うえ、-うえ、うわ-、かみ、あ.げる、-あ.げる、あ.がる、-あ.がる、あ.がり、-あ.がり、のぼ.る、のぼ.り、のぼ.せる、のぼ.す、よ.す	A <em>magic wand</em> standing on<strong> above</strong> the floor.	The <em>divining rod</em> is<strong> above</strong> the <em>floor</em>.	Water Faucet is<strong> ABOVE</strong> the Ground.	Whoa, that <em>magic wand</em> is<strong> above</strong> the <em>floor</em> by itself!	"I hold my hand<strong> above</strong> my broom as I cry ""UP!""."		
下		below	Here we see our famous miraculous <i>magic wand</i> hanging, all on its own, <b>below</b> the <i>ceiling</i>, as you probably already guessed would happen. In addition to giving us two new kanji, the two shapes given in this and the preceding frame also serve to fix the use of the primitives for <i>ceiling</i> and <i>floor</i>, by drawing our attention successively to the line standing above and <b>below</b> the primitive element to which it is related.		3	51	50	3	カ、ゲ	した、しも、もと、さ.げる、さ.がる、くだ.る、くだ.り、くだ.す、-くだ.す、くだ.さる、お.ろす、お.りる	Roots are<strong> below</strong> the ground.	A <em>magic wand</em> hanging<strong> below</strong> the ceiling.	"Peeing off a cliff ""Watch out<strong> BELOW</strong>!""."	A T with it's wang<strong> below</strong>.	This time the DIVINING ROD has been pushed<strong> below</strong> the ceiling deforming its handle.		
卓		eminent	The word <b>eminent</b> suggests a famous or well-known person. So all you need to do - given the primitives of a <i>magic wand</i> and a <i>sunflower</i> - is to think of the world's most <b>eminent</b> magician as one who uses a <i>sunflower</i> for a <i>magic wand</i> (like a flower-child who goes around turning the world into peace and love).		8	52	51	3	タク		The most<strong> eminent</strong> magician is he who learned to use his <em>magic wand early</em> in life.	The world's most <strong>eminent</strong> sourcerer, Harry Potter, used his <em>magic wand early</em> in life.	The<strong> eminent</strong> sunflower is the one that stands above the others.	"When a car ( 車 ) <a href=""../v4/286.html"">car</a> (#286 車) loses a wheel, disaster is<strong> eminent</strong>."	The world's most<strong> eminent</strong> fortune-teller is also the earliest of all. He produces his predictions amazingly fast.		
朝		morning	On the right we see the <i>moon</i> fading off into the first light of <b>morning</b>, and to the left, the <i>mist</i> that falls to give nature a shower to prepare it for the coming heat. If you can think of the <i>moon</i> tilting over to spill <i>mist</i> on your garden, you should have no trouble remembering which of all the elements in this story are to serve as primitives for constructing the character.		12	53	52	3	チョウ	あさ	There is mist as the moon fades away in the<strong> morning</strong>.	"<strong>Morning</strong> has come ""ten"" hours ""early""!!! The ""moon"" is still in the sky!"	In the<strong> morning</strong>, god picks the <em>sun</em> up to the sky with two <em>needles</em> (because it's too hot to touch by hands) to replace the <em>moon</em>.	The<strong> morning</strong> <em>mist</em> is the <em>moon</em>'s parting tears–sprinkling <em>ten early flowers</em> with dew when she leaves the sky each day.	In the<strong> morning</strong> the <em>mist</em> and <em>moon</em> fades away.		
嘲		derision	The bad feeling created by words spoken in <b>derision</b> often leaves a bad taste in the <i>mouth</i> of the one who speaks them, kind of like the foul aftertaste that follows a night before of too much of the wrong stuff - or what we call <i>morning mouth</i>.		15	54	2155	3	チョウ、トウ	あざけ.る	When I wake up, I am always late, so I hurry to work. With a bad case of perpetual morning breath, I am the subject of<strong> derision</strong> at my office whenever I open my mouth.	If <em>morning</em> breath emanates from your <em>mouth</em>, you are subject to<strong> derision</strong>!	Truly the epic mother-in-law who, at the very crack of <em>morning</em>, already possesses a <em>mouth</em> full of<strong> derision</strong>.	Your <em>mouth</em> is full of<strong> derision</strong> in the <em>morning</em> because you're grumpy.	When I opened my <em>mouth</em> to suggest an early <em>morning</em> meeting, my suggestion was met with<strong> derision</strong>.		
只		only	"When we run across abstract key words like this one, the best way to get an image it to recall some common but suggestive phrase in which the word appears. For instance, we can think of the expression ""it's the <b>only</b> one of its kind."" Then we imagine a barker at a side-show advertising some strange pac-manlike creature he has inside his tent, with only a gigantic <i>mouth</i> and two wee <i>animal legs</i>."		5	55	53	4	シ	ただ	Imagine an animal with<strong> only</strong> a <em>mouth</em> and <em>leg</em>s.	My girlfriend insists that the <em>only</em> thing I want from her is what's between her legs.. She's drawn me this pictograph to demonstrate. It's a <em>head</em> and two legs spread apart.. I explain that I also love her breasts, and then she smacks me in the face. I'll never understand women.. (I keep failing this kanji, hopefully this silly story will help me!).	<strong>Only</strong> your mouth runs faster than your legs.	Men<strong> only</strong> want that mouth between the legs.	<strong>Tada</strong>!… <strong>SHE</strong> is the<strong> only</strong> animal with<strong> only</strong> a <em>mouth</em> on <em>legs</em> and no body! (Kun reading tada, ON reading SHI).		
貝		shellfish	To remember the primitive elements that make up this kanji, an <i>eye</i> and <i>animal legs</i>, you might be tempted to think of it as a pictograph of a <b>shellfish</b> with its ridged shell at the top and two little <i>legs</i> sticking out of the bottom. But that might not help you recall later just how many ridges to put on the shell. Better to imagine a freakish <b>shellfish</b> with a single, gigantic <i>eye</i> roaming the beaches on its slender little <i>legs</i>, scaring the wits out of the sunbathers.	* When used as a primitive, in addition to <i>shells</i>, the meanings <i>oyster</i> and <i>clam</i> will often come in handy.	7	56	54	4	バイ	かい	<em>Eye</em> thought I saw a<strong> shellfish</strong> <em>legging</em> it down the beach!	Stare at the<strong> shellfish</strong>, it looks like an eye with legs.	Remove the <em>eyes</em> and the <em>legs</em>, and a<strong> shellfish</strong> tastes great!	The <strong>guy</strong> couldn't <strong>BUY</strong> any<strong> shellfish</strong> which had one giant <em>eye</em> and walked on <em>animal legs</em>, so he went out in his <strong>kay</strong>ak to catch some. (Kun readings are kai or gai, ON reading is BAI).	<strong>SHELLFISH</strong> look like big <em>eyes</em> with <em>legs</em>.		
唄		pop song	"There is a lot of money to be made of one's <b>songs</b> are ""<b>pop</b>ular."" This is depicted here as a stream of <i>clams</i> spewing out of the <i>mouth</i> of someone performing a <b>pop song</b>."		10	57	2178	4	バイ	うた、うた.う	The new generation of <strong>pop songs</strong> have no depth. They just <em>mouth</em> empty lyrics to get <em>money</em>. Not like the <strong>pop songs</strong> of my day.	A new way for sluts to use their mouths to make alot of money.	Out of the <em>mouth</em> comes a<strong> pop song</strong> and in rolls the <em>money</em>.	Critics of popular music often complain that pop music doesn't require technique. They say that any idiot who opens his <em>mouth</em> and sings a<strong> pop song</strong> will make <em>money</em>.	Think Milli Vanilli - Guys <em>mouthing</em><strong> pop song</strong>s just to make <em>money</em>.		
貞		upright	Now take the last primitive, the <i>shellfish</i>, and set a <i>magic wand</i> over it, and you have the kanji for <b>upright</b>. After all, the <i>clam</i> and the <i>oyster</i> are incapable of walking <b>upright</b>. It would take a magician with his <i>wand</i> to pull off such a feat - which is precisely what we have in this kanji.		9	58	55	4	テイ	さだ	A <em>magic wand</em> is needed to make a <em>clam</em> stand<strong> upright</strong>.	Just the thought of my <em>magic wand</em> on her <em>clam</em> makes my <em>magic wand</em> stand<strong> upright</strong>.	"貞 【てい】 (n) (1) firm adherence to one's principles; (2) chastity (of a woman) what this has to do with ""upright""… not sure. but heres a story for CHASTITY: ""a magician uses his MAGIC WAND to shut the crotch of a maiden as tight as a CLAM, to protect her CHASTITY""."	To get the <em>shellfish</em> to stand<strong> upright</strong>, just poke it with a <em>magic wand</em>!	An<strong> UPRIGHT</strong> person is <em>above</em> ( 上 ) petty disputes, and always holds their head <em>up</em> ( 上 ). Since they live on principle, they are as hard or firm as a <em>shell</em> in their beliefs of what is right and what is wrong. They are wise, because they find the pearls of wisdom in the <em>shells</em> of life; 童貞 (virginity); 不貞 (unfaithful); 貞はる (harp too long on a subject); 貞淑 (chastity, virtue); 貞女 (virtuous woman); 不貞寝 (stay in bed out of spite); .		
員		employee	How do we get a <i>mouth</i> over a <i>shellfish</i> to mean an <b>employee</b>? Simple. Just remember the advice new <b>employees</b> get about keeping their <i>mouths</i> shut and doing their job, and then make that more graphic by picturing an office building full of white collar workers scurrying around with <i>clams</i> pinched to their <i>mouths</i>.		10	59	56	4	イン		An<strong> employee</strong> (<strong>member</strong> of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!	An<strong> employee</strong> is basically a shellfish with a mouth.	An<strong> employee</strong> is a worker. They lend their <em>mouth</em> ( 口 ) to spread a message & sell products; <em>eyes</em> ( 目 ) to watch competitors & find customers; and <em>eight</em> ( 八 ) hours a day. Alt., an<strong> employee</strong> is a <em>shell</em> ( 貝 ) in the ocean of a company; it looks up to the boss's <em>mouth</em> ( 口 ) for orders. 医員 (doctor); 一員 (member); 駅員 (station attendant); 委員 (committee member); 会社員 (company<strong> employee</strong>); 海員 (sailor); 楽員 (band member); 期間契約社員 (fixed term contractor).	An<strong> employee</strong> is not a robot (Calculon's friend), he's got a <em>mouth</em> to feed. Pay him more than a few <em>clams</em>!	<strong>Employee</strong>s work and earn clams so that they can feed their mouths.		
貼		post a bill	The key word in this frame has do with <b>posting bills</b> to a billboard. In this case, the billboard is standing at the exit to a Chinese restaurant displaying the latest alternative to the tradition <i>fortune-telling</i> cookies. Look closely and you will see rows of leftover shells of <i>clams</i> with little slips of paper sticking out of them <b>posted</b> to the billboard.		12	60	2736	4	テン、チョウ	は.る、つ.く	Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to<strong> affix</strong> it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and<strong> affix</strong>ing it to the fortune.	"To prevent confusion with <a href=""../v4/1303.html"">affixed</a> (#1303 附) I changed this to ""paste (v.)"" or ""cut and paste"" because it is the character for pasting in a PC and in graphic design. Careful <a href=""../v4/2650.html"">paste</a> (#2650 糊) Story: You pay money and the fortune teller cuts and pastes a good fortune and prints it out for you on his notebook PC. 切り貼り きりはり cut and paste, 貼る はる to stick/to paste, 貼付け はりつけ (computer file) paste."	I gots <strong>a fix</strong> for your current bad luck: just pass some extra <em>clams</em> over to the <em>fortune teller</em>, and they will make sure you have a very bright fate instore.	"To make cash (<em>clams</em>) the gypsy <strong>affixed a note / posted a bill</strong> to a billboard advertising her <em>fortune telling</em> services (contrast with <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/673"">put up (a notice)</a> (#673 掲))."	(in the new RTK1 supplement as <strong>post a bill</strong>) Under the Sea, clams are used for clips to hang papers, so The Little Mermaid found the Sea Witch after seeing a <strong>posted bill</strong><strong> affix</strong>ed in a <em>clam</em> advertising <em>fortune-telling</em>.		
見		see	The elements that compose the character for <b>see</b> are the <i>eye</i> firmly fixed to a pair of <i>human legs</i>. Surely, somewhere in your experience, there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up to help you remember this character....		7	61	57	4	ケン	み.る、み.える、み.せる	As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant <em>eyeball</em> with <em>legs</em>…) Makes for <em>easy</em> stories later on.	Eyes and legs are all you need to<strong> see</strong> the world.	Men's <em>eyes</em> open wide when they<strong> see</strong> the <em>legs</em> of a beautiful woman. (Alternatively, women's <em>eyes</em> open wide when they<strong> see</strong> the <em>legs</em> of a handsome guy ;) ).	The large <em>eye</em> on <em>human legs</em> <strong>see</strong>s all!	I<strong> see</strong> best when I am walking!		
児		newborn babe	"The top part of the kanji in this frame, you will remember, is the character for <i>olden times</i>, those <i>days</i> so old they needed a <i>walking stick</i> to get around. Western mythical imagination has old ""Father Time"" leaning on his sickle with a <b>newborn babe</b> crawling around his <i>legs</i>, the idea being that the circle of birth and-death goes on. This is the first of three times that the kanji for <i>olden times</i> will appear as a primitive element in another kanji, so try to make the most of it."		7	62	58	4	ジ、ニ、ゲイ	こ、-こ、-っこ	In the <em>olden times</em>, a<strong> newborn babe</strong> came out <em>leg</em>s first.	In the <em>olden times</em>, a<strong> newborn babe</strong> came from between the <em>leg</em>s. Now we have cesarean section. [modified rakutenka's story].	In <em>olden times</em><strong> newborn babe</strong>s were strapped to their mothers' backs, leaving both their legs dangling.	The man from <strong>olden times</strong> has been reincarnated with a new pair of <strong>human legs</strong>.	A<strong> newborn babe</strong> is an 18 year commitment that will have you <em>running</em> for <em>olden times</em>!		
元		beginning	"""In the <b>beginning</b>..."" starts that marvelous shelf of books we call the Bible. It talks about how all things were made, and tells us that when the Creator came to humanity she made <i>two</i> of them, man and woman. While we presume she made <i>two</i> of every other animal as well, we are not told as much. Hence we need only <i>two</i> and a pair of <i>human legs</i> come to the kanji that means <b>beginning</b>."		4	63	59	4	ゲン、ガン	もと	In the<strong> beginning</strong> were just <em>two</em> who walked on <em>human legs</em>.	"In the<strong> beginning</strong> God created woman, and God asked her how she liked his work. Woman replied, ""Well, you know how I have <em>two</em> eyes, <em>two</em> arms, <em>two legs</em>… it seems redundant to have three breasts. It would look more symmetrical with <em>two</em>."" God nodded, and the middle breast fell off… and it was good. Woman picked up the breast and said, ""Thank you, God! But what do I do with this useless boob?"" And God created man. That's why the women today only have <em>two</em> boobs to match their <em>two human legs</em>."	Every journey begins with your two legs.	"Grandpa Woody always began stories from his youth with ""In the<strong> beginning</strong>, when I had <em>two</em> <em>legs</em>…""."	In the<strong> beginning</strong> we start out with nothing but our own two legs.		
頁		page	"What we have to do here is turn a <i>shellfish</i> into a <b>page</b> of a book. The <i>one</i> at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book, in fact only <i>one</i> <b>page</b>. Imagine a title printed on the shell of an <i>oyster</i>, let us say ""Pearl of Wisdom,"" and then open the quaint book to its <i>one</i> and only <b>page</b>, on which you find a single, radiant <i>drop of</i> wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of nature."	* As a primitive, this kanji takes the unrelated meaning of a <i>head</i> (preferably one detached from its body), derived from the character for <i>head</i> (Frame 1549).	9	64	60	4	ケツ	ぺえじ、おおがい、かしら	A <em>shellfish</em> carrying a<strong> page</strong> balanced on its <em>head</em>.	<em>One</em> <em>drop</em> of ink from a <em>shellfish</em> can fill a whole<strong> page</strong>.	A <em>shellfish</em> dangles from the <em>ceiling</em> Mission-Impossible style, desperate to recover the<strong> page</strong> of revealing images that were taken from him.	"頁岩 , 頁 , <a href=""../v4/60.html"">page</a> (#60 頁) ケツ, ページ … Parts: 一 , 丶, 自 , ハor 一 , 丶, 貝 (cf: 順番 , お願い , 頭 , 頂く , etc.) … Tip: This is a never used Kanji, but you are going to see it a few hundred more times in RTK as a primitive. Here's something that I figured out way too late. This is <em>ALWAYS</em> <em>ALWAYS</em> on the right hand side (RHS) of the characters it is a part of. <em>Always</em>.. Learn this primitive cold, and remember, always on the RHS."	<em>One</em><strong> page</strong> may not seem like much, but if it contains <em>drop</em> of wisdom, it is worth the <em>clams</em> you <em>shell</em>ed out for it.		
頑		stubborn	"This character refers to the block<i>headed</i>, persistent <b>stubbornness</b> of one who sticks to an idea or a plan just the way it was at the <i>beginning</i>, without letting anything that comes up along the way alter things in the least. The explanation makes ""sense,"" but is hard to remember because the word ""<i>beginning</i> ""is too abstract. Back up to the image we used two frames ago - Adam and Eve in their Eden - and try again: The root of all <b>stubbornness</b> goes back to the <i>beginning</i>, with two brothers each <b>stubbornly</b> defending his own way of life and asking their God to bless it favorably. Abel stuck to agriculture, Cain to animal-raising. Picture these two with their giant, swelled <i>heads</i>, each vying for the favors of heaven, a <b>stubborn</b> grimace on their faces. No wonder something unfortunate happened!"		13	65	61	4	ガン	かたく	A<strong> stubborn</strong> person in the <em>beginning</em> gets something into their <em>head</em> and can't change their mind.	Picture a<strong> STUBBORN</strong> schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.	He's so<strong> stubborn</strong>, he won't read past the beginning page!	<strong>Stubborn</strong>ness begins in the head.	I tend to be<strong> STUBBORN</strong> if the first (<em>beginning</em>) <em>page</em> of a book is not good.		
凡		mediocre	"While we refer to something insignificant as a ""<i>drop</i> in the bucket,"" the kanji for <b>mediocre</b> suggests the image of a ""<i>drop</i> in the <i>wind</i>."""		3	66	62	4	ボン、ハン	およ.そ、おうよ.そ、すべ.て	Is there anything as<strong> mediocre</strong> as a drop of piss in the wind?	A <em>drop</em> of breeze is naught but a<strong> mediocre</strong> <em>wind</em>.	A drop of rain in the wind… what a<strong> mediocre</strong> rainy season…	<strong>Mediocre</strong> people hide under the table.	All we are is Dust in the Wind- a great example of a<strong> mediocre</strong> song.		
負		defeat	Above we have the condensed form of <i>bound up</i>, and below the familiar <i>shellfish</i>. Now imagine two <i>oysters</i> engaged in <i>shell</i>-to-<i>shell</i> combat, the one who is <b>defeated</b> being <i>bound and gagged</i> with seaweed, the victor towering triumphantly over it. The <i>bound shellfish</i> thus becomes the symbol for <b>defeat</b>.		9	67	63	4	フ	ま.ける、ま.かす、お.う	<em>Tied up</em>, the <em>shellfish</em> had to accept<strong> defeat</strong>!	The <em>shellfish</em> admitted <strong>defeat</strong> when they placed a <em>hook</em> on top of his head.	<strong>Defeat</strong> is defined by a shellfish in binds.	A <em>shellfish bound up</em> in a fisherman's net has been<strong> defeat</strong>ed.	If you are<strong> DEFEAT</strong>ED you are BOUND into slavery and the world will not be your OYSTER.		
万		ten thousand	"Japanese counts higher numbers in units of <b>ten thousand</b>, unlike the West, which advances according to units of one thousand. (Thus, for instance, 40,000 would be read ""four <b>ten-thousands</b>"" by a Japanese.) Given that the comma is used in larger numbers to <i>bind up</i> a numerical unit of one thousand, the elements for <i>one</i> and <i>bound up</i> naturally come to form <b>ten thousand</b>. The order of strokes here needs special attention, both because it falls outside the general principles we have learned already, and because it involves writing the element for <i>bound up</i> in an order opposite to the one we learned. If it is any consolation, this exception is consistent every time these three strokes come together."		3	68	64	4	マン、バン	よろず	I <em>bound</em><strong> ten thousand</strong> dollars together and hid it under the <em>floor</em>.	IT'S OVER 9000!!!!!!	It looks like a T and an H put together.	"We have ""one"" at the top and if you turn the kanji 90 degrees you will see arabic 4 shich means it has four zeros in front of it!"	Think of Tao:<strong> ten thousand</strong> things are all <em>bound up</em> into <em>one</em>.		
句		phrase	By combining the two primitives <i>bound up</i> and <i>mouth</i>, we can easily see how this character can get the meaning of a <b>phrase</b>. After all, a <b>phrase</b> is nothing more than a number of words <i>bound up</i> tightly and neatly so that they will fit in your <i>mouth</i>.		5	69	65	4	ク		Some Japanese <strong>phrase</strong>s are difficult to <em>wrap</em> your <em>mouth</em> around.	A bound mouth cannot utter a single<strong> phrase</strong>.	A<strong> phrase</strong> is a bunch of bound up words coming out of a mouth.	I use my <em>mouth</em> to <em>bind</em> words together, thus forming a<strong> phrase</strong> or sentence ( 句 ).	<em>Bind</em> your <em>mouth</em> in case the wrong<strong> phrase</strong> gets out.		
肌		texture	"Ever notice how the <b>texture</b> of your face and hands is affected by the <i>wind</i>? A day's skiing or sailing makes them rough and dry, and in need of a good soft cream to soothe the burn. So whenever a <i>part of the body</i> gets exposed to the <i>wind</i>, its <b>texture</b> is affected. (If it is any help, the Latin word hiding inside <b>texture</b> connotes how something is ""to the touch."")"		6	70	66	4	キ	はだ	When you expose your <em>flesh</em> to the <em>wind</em> it gets <strong>textured</strong>: goosebumps!	The <em>moon</em>'s lack of <em>wind</em> preserves its<strong> texture</strong>.	Because the <em>moon</em> has no <em>wind</em> the<strong> texture</strong> of it's cratered surface never changes or erodes.	The Moon And The Wind Create The Sea's Wavey <strong>Texture</strong>!	A month of wind changes the<strong> texture</strong> of your skin.		
旬		decameron	There simply is not a good phrase in English for the block often days which this character represents. So we resurrect the classical phrase, <b>decameron</b>, whose connotations the tales of Boccaccio have done much to enrich. Actually, it refers to a journey of ten <i>days</i> taken by a band of people - that is, a group of people <i>bound together</i> for the <i>days</i> of the <b>decameron</b>.		6	71	67	4	ジュン、シュン		"Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a<strong> decameron</strong>) for calling this Kanji<strong> DECAMERON</strong>. See <a href=""../v4/809.html"">martyrdom</a> (#809 殉)."	"<strong>Hint:</strong> <em>Here's info from Wikipedia regarding why this kanji exists, which helped me remember it:</em> [Japan also divides the month roughly into three 10-day periods. Each is called a jun ( 旬 ). The first is jōjun ( 上旬 ); the second, chūjun ( 中旬 ); the last, gejun ( 下旬 ). These are frequently used to indicate approximate times, for example, ""the temperatures are typical of the jōjun of April""; ""a vote on a bill is expected during the gejun of this month.""]."	What the fuck?	If you bind up ten days, you get a<strong> decameron</strong>.	For producing Titanic, James<strong> deCameron</strong> should be bound for 10 days.		
勺		ladle	If you want to <i>bind up drops</i> of anything - water, soup, lemonade - you use something to scoop these <i>drops</i> up, which is what we call a <b>ladle</b>. See the last <i>drop</i> left inside the <b>ladle</b>?		3	72	68	4	シャク		A<strong> ladle</strong> binds drops together.	Forget about the primative 'bound up'. Imagine instead the shape of a<strong> ladle</strong> and holding it upside down to drink the last DROP (of water).	The last <em>drop</em> stays <em>bound</em> to the<strong> LADLE</strong>.	I'm bound and determined to get that last drop with this<strong> ladle</strong>!	A<strong> ladle</strong> holding a tiny fart.		
的		bull's eye	"The elements <i>white bird</i> and <i>ladle</i> easily suggest the image of a <b>bull's eye</b> if you imagine a rusty old <i>ladle</i> with a <b>bull's eye</b> painted on it in the form of a tiny <i>white bird</i>, who lets out a little ""peep"" every time you hit the target."		8	73	69	4	テキ	まと	I managed to hit the bull's eye by throwing my white ladle.	"A <em>white</em>, <em>bound up</em>, <em>drop</em> in the center is the bull's eye. (why Heisig had to use ""ladle"" instead of the original two primitives that make up ""ladle"" I'll never understand!)."	"You're outside at a BBQ making the white sauce to go with whats on the grill. You lift the ladle to your lips. Right after you close your eyes to take a taste, a drop of white bird shit falls into the ladle - "" Bull's Eye! "" the bird says. Not seeing the incident, you proceed to taste your 'white sauce'."	He scooped out the <strong>bull's eye</strong> with a <em>white laddle</em>.	A <em>white</em>, <em>bound up</em>, <em>drop</em> in the center is the <strong>bull's eye</strong>.		
首		neck	"Reading this kanji from the top down, we have: <i>horns</i> . . . <i>nose</i>. Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose-head hanging on the den wall, with its great <i>horns</i> and long <i>nose</i>. Now while we would speak of cutting off a moose's ""head"" to hang on the wall, the Japanese speak of cutting off its <b>neck</b>. It's all a matter of how you look at it. Anyway, if you let the word <b>neck</b> conjure up the image of a moose with a very l-o-n-g <b>neck</b> hanging over the fireplace, whose <i>horns</i> you use for a coat-rack and whose <i>nose</i> has spigots left and right for scotch and water, you should have no trouble with the character. Here we get a good look at what we mentioned when we first introduced the element for <i>horns</i>: that they can never be left floating free and require an extra horizontal stroke to prevent that from happening, as is the case here."		9	74	70	4	シュ	くび	The V shape is your <strong>neck</strong> on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. <em>Yourself</em>, or the rest of your body is below that!	The mooses<strong> neck</strong> supports it's big horns and long nose.	One has a strong<strong> NECK</strong> if one can carry HORNS on ONESELF.	There are no goddamn animal legs in the Kanji for<strong> neck</strong>. Stop thinking there are animal legs in the Kanji for<strong> neck</strong>. There are NONE!	With horns on oneself, you need a strong<strong> neck</strong>.		
乙		fish guts	"The kanji shown here actually represents the ""second"" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are ""pure,"" ""tasteful,"" ""quaint,"" and - get this! - <b>fish guts</b>. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word."	* We will keep <i>fishhook</i> as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.	1	75	71	5	オツ、イツ	おと-、きのと	This is a fish hook, that pulls out the<strong> fishguts</strong>.	You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its <strong>fish guts</strong> silly!	"""Knife goes in, guts come out"" (-Bart Simpson's mantra as he guts fish in ""30 Minutes Over Tokyo""). To be more specific: first, cut a 乙 -shape in the belly of the fish, <strong>second</strong>, pull the<strong> fishguts</strong> out. (Note that the most common meaning of this kanji is not 'fishguts' as Heisig connotates, but 'second')."	Fishgutz.	"Really this will rarely be seen as<strong> fishguts</strong> as a Kanji, usually it's 2nd party, or latter, generally always meaning 2nd in some way. It's easy to remember this as ""2nd"" since it looks like a 2. Then just remember it's a fishhook primitive like any other kanji that changes it's meaning as a primitive."		
乱		riot	"In a <b>riot</b>, manners are laid aside and tempers get short, even in so courtesy-conscious a land as Japan. This kanji shows what happens to a <b>rioting</b> <i>tongue</i>: it gets ""barbed"" like a <i>fishhook</i>, and sets to attacking the opposition, to <i>hook</i> them as it were."		7	76	72	5	ラン、ロン	みだ.れる、みだ.る、みだ.す、みだ、おさ.める、わた.る	The<strong> riot</strong> police broke up the<strong> riot</strong> by dragging the<strong> riot</strong>ers away by their <em>tongues</em> with <em>fishooks</em>.	A <em>tongue</em> with a <em>hook</em> can cause a<strong> riot</strong>.	If my daughter took her <em>tongue</em> and pierced it with a <em>fishhook</em>, that would cause her mother and I to<strong> riot</strong>!	During a <em>riot</em> in a totalitarian country, the leftist's <em>tongues</em> are <em>fishhooked</em> by the police ( a way for me to remember that tongue is on the left of the kanji).	<strong>Riot</strong>ers are punks with fish hooks in their tongues.		
直		straightaway	Begin with the top two primitives, <i>needle</i> and <i>eye</i>. Together they represent the <i>eye of a needle</i>. Below them is a <i>fishhook</i> that has been <b>straightened out</b> and its barb removed so that it can pass through the <i>eye of the needle</i>.		8	77	73	5	チョク、ジキ、ジカ	ただ.ちに、なお.す、-なお.す、なお.る、なお.き、す.ぐ	If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital<strong> straightaway</strong>.	I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back<strong> straightaway</strong>.	"""Cross my heart, hope to die, stick a <em>needle</em> in my <em>eye</em>""… and sit on a <em>fish hook</em> if I ever tell a lie! Slight variant on what kids say<strong> straightaway</strong> if their word is put in doubt."	Ten eyes knew<strong> straightaway</strong> that there is something wrong with the hook.	The hook goes<strong> straightaway</strong> through the eye of a needle.		
具		tool	Here is the full kanji on which the last frame is based. If you can think of a table full of carpenter's <b>tools</b> of all sorts, each equipped with its own <i>eye</i> so that it can keep a watch over what you are doing with it, you won't have trouble later keeping the primitive and the kanji apart.		8	78	74	5	グ	そな.える、つぶさ.に	Keep an eye on your<strong> tool</strong>s while you work at the table.	One<strong> tool</strong> nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.	You need a strong<strong> tool</strong> to remove the legs from a shellfish.	You need a strong a<strong> tool</strong> to separate the legs from a shellfish.	Like my shop teacher always said… In order to use any<strong> tool</strong> at your <em>workbench</em> you must first make sure to wear your safety goggles to protect your <em>eyes</em>.		
真		true	Here again we meet the composite element, <i>eye of the needle</i>, which here combines with <i>tool</i> to give us a measure of what is <b>true</b> and what is not.		10	79	75	5	シン	ま、ま-、まこと	A compass is a <em>tool</em> with a <em>needle</em> on top that points to<strong> true</strong> north.	<em>Ten</em> <em>tools</em> are all a<strong> true</strong> craftsman needs.	It's<strong> true</strong> that I got a needle stuck in my eye once. Luckily, we had a tool to pull the needle out from my eye.<strong> True</strong> story.	Ten eyes working together are the best tools to see what's<strong> true</strong>.	Cross my heart and hope to die, stick a <em>needle</em> in my <em>eye</em> is a <em>tool</em> used by children to affirm what they said as being<strong> true</strong>.		
工		craft	The pictograph of an I beam, like the kind used in heavy construction work on buildings and bridges, gives us the character for <b>craft</b> in general.	* As a primitive element, the key word retains the meaning of <i>craft</i> and also takes on the related meanings of <i>I beam</i> and <i>artificial</i>.	3	80	76	5	コウ、ク、グ		I consider<strong> craft</strong> to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I've personified it as Bender the<strong> craft</strong>y robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.	I<strong> craft</strong>y.	Icraft, beautifully<strong> craft</strong>ed by apple!	I-beams are used to<strong> CRAFT</strong> skyscrapers.	I<strong> CRAFT</strong>ed an <em>artificial I-beam</em>.		
左		left	"By combining the primitive and the kanji of the last two frames and reading the results, we get: <i>by one's side</i> . . . <i>craft</i>. Conveniently, the <b>left</b> has traditionally been considered the ""sinister"" <i>side</i>, where dark and occult <i>crafts</i> are cultivated. Note how the second stroke droops over to the <b>left</b> and is longer than the first."		5	81	77	5	サ、シャ	ひだり	The<strong> LEFT</strong> <em>side</em> of my brain <em>posesses</em> the faculties needed for logical <em>crafts</em>, like engineering.	The<strong> left</strong> <em>side</em> of my brain, is for <em>crafts</em>.	"<strong>FOR THOSE ABOUT TO PUZZLE OVER THE CHANGING STROKE ORDER, IT'S THIS SIMPLE:</strong> Look at the second primitive! Here, the first stroke of <em>by one's side</em> should match the first stroke of <em>craft</em> so that the stroke direction alternates in writing. So 左 is written horizontal, vertical, horizontal… 右 is written vertical, horizontal, vertical… 有 is vertical, horizontal, vertical… etc. (The ONLY exception to this rule comes with elbow [<a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/743"">masculine/male</a> (#743 雄) 雄 ], which is written horizontal, vertical, vertical(ish)…)."	"To remember which one is right/left, think ""(l)Eft"", as it contains the katakana ""e""."	Sinister craft is done with the<strong> left</strong> hand.		
右		right	When thinking of the key word <b>right</b>, in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame, take advantage of the double meaning here, too. Imagine a little <i>mouth</i> hanging down by your <i>side</i> - like a little voice of conscience - telling you the <b>right</b> thing to do. Here the second stroke should reach out to the <b>right</b> and be drawn slightly longer than the first.		5	82	78	5	ウ、ユウ	みぎ	The<strong> right</strong> hand is for putting food in your <em>mouth</em>. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!). 左右 (さゆう) : left and<strong> right</strong>, influence, control, domination; 右 (みぎ) :<strong> right</strong> hand side.	The<strong> right</strong> <em>side</em> of my brain is for <em>speaking</em>.	Always keep your<strong> right</strong> to free speech (mouth) by your side!	<em>By my side</em> is a big <em>mouth</em> who thinks they're always<strong> right</strong>.	A voice of reason <em>by your side</em> steers you<strong> right</strong>.		
有		possess	The picture here is of someone with a slab of <i>meat</i> dangling <i>by the side</i>, perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist. Think of it as an evil spirit in <b>possession</b> of one's soul, who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh <i>meat</i> to hang <i>by one's side</i> until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs. Take careful note of the stroke order.		6	83	79	5	ユウ、ウ	あ.る	<strong>Possess</strong>ed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.	By my side I<strong> POSSESS</strong> a <em> moon of flesh</em>, better known as your big ass!	To<strong> possess</strong> = have or own something. In the fight for survival in prehistoric times, the most important thing to<strong> possess</strong> was meat by your side which could be eaten at any time. Imagine a caveman after a hunt having meat by his side.	The moon stood by my side: I was<strong> possess</strong>ed, a lunatic.	With the moon at my side I transform into a werewolf. Oh no, I am<strong> possess</strong>ed.		
賄		bribe	To the left we have the primitive for a <i>shellfish</i>, and to the right the kanji we just learned for <i>possess</i>. Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word <i>possess</i>, and now expand your image of <i>shells</i> to include the ancient value they had as money (a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now one who is <i>possessed</i> by <i>shells</i> is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easiest ones to <b>bribe</b> with a few extra <i>shells</i>.		13	84	80	5	ワイ	まかな.う	To<strong> bribe</strong> someone, money is a necessary possession.	If you possess enough shellfish, you can<strong> bribe</strong> anyone.	In order to<strong> bribe</strong> me you will have to give me all the <em>clams</em> you <em>possess</em>.	A <strong>shellfish</strong> is not the 'right' <strong>possession</strong> to<strong> bribe</strong> with. (It's on the left).	If money is what possesses you, you will accept many<strong> bribe</strong>s.		
貢		tribute	A <b>tribute</b> has a kind of double-meaning in English: honor paid freely and <i>money</i> collected by coercion. Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard-earned <i>money</i>. Little wonder that this ancient <i>craft</i> of getting <i>money</i> by calling it a <b>tribute</b> has given way to a name closer to how it feels to those who pay it: a tax.		10	85	81	5	コウ、ク	みつ.ぐ	"""This next song is a<strong> TRIBUTE</strong> to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table.""."	<strong>Tribute</strong> is the craft of raising money.	I gladly pay my<strong> tribute</strong> to the tax collector: but what he doesn't know is that this is carely <em>craft</em>ed <em>money</em> - counterfeit!	"<strong>Tribute</strong> is another form of taxation - a <em>craft</em>y way of collecting ""<em>clams</em>"" (money). 貢献 (こうけん) : contribution, services; 西貢 さいごん Saigon."	We must pay<strong> tribute</strong> to the crafty shellfish who always appears in our kanji.		
項		paragraph	"To the right we see a <i>head</i> and to the left an element that means <i>craft</i>. When we think of a <b>paragraph</b>, we immediately think of a <i>heading</i> device to break a text into parts. (Think of the elaborate <i>heads</i> often seen at the start of medieval manuscripts and the task becomes easier still.) Just where and how to do it belongs to the writer's <i>craft</i>. Hence, we define <b>paragraphing</b> as the ""<i>heading craft</i>"" to remember this character."		12	86	82	5	コウ	うなじ	To write a<strong> paragraph</strong> is the <em>craft</em> of grouping sentences on a <em>page</em>.	To <em>craft</em> a <em>page</em> well, we need<strong> paragraph</strong>s.	Page and craft = pacraft -> paracraft; said properly as<strong> paragraph</strong>.	Well, I tried using craft and headings and pages and none of it stuck, so: Reading a block of text that isn't broken down into<strong> paragraph</strong>s makes me want to hit myself in the head with an I-beam.	A well CRAFTED PAGE is full of beautiful<strong> PARAGRAPH</strong>S.		
刀		sword	Although this character no longer looks very much like a <b>sword</b>, it does have some resemblance to the handle of the <b>sword</b>. This is to our advantage, in that it helps us keep make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji.	* In the form of the kanji, this primitive means a <i>dagger</i>. When it appears to the right of another element, it is commonly stretched out and takes the sense of a great and flashing <i>saber</i>, a meaning it gets from a character we shall learn later (Frame 1801).	2	87	83	5	トウ	かたな、そり	This<strong> SWORD</strong> is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.	If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there<strong> sword</strong> in his ass!	Samurai carry two<strong> sword</strong>s on their belt: a curved katana and a straighter, shorter wakizashi.	Looks like the handle on a pirate cutlass, a kind of<strong> sword</strong>.	"Note : this is the kanji for the famous Japanese<strong> sword</strong>, also pronounced かたな (katana). As a primitive when it is compressed on the right of a kanji, its meaning becomes ""saber"". In that case I like to associate the image of a ninja, making sure to keep it distinct from the ""samurai"". The samurai would be the historical japanese warrior, while the ninja would be the more stealthy character popularised through modern martial arts movies."		
刃		blade	Think of using a <i>dagger</i> as a razor <b>blade</b>, and it shouldn't be hard to imagine cutting yourself. See the little <i>drop of</i> blood clinging to the <b>blade</b>?		3	88	84	5	ジン、ニン	は、やいば、き.る	The part of a <em>sword</em> where a <em>drop of blood</em> can usually be found is the<strong> blade</strong>.	<strong>A drop of</strong> blood on the<strong> blade</strong> of my sword.	Imagine<strong> Blade</strong> (Wesley Snipes) wiping the <em>drops</em> of blood from his <em>sword</em> after killing some vampires.	How do you know it is a real <em>sword</em>? There is a <em>drop</em> of blood on the <strong>blade</strong>.	There's a <em>drop</em> of blood on the<strong> blade</strong> of the <em>sword</em>.		
切		cut	To the right we see the <i>dagger</i> and next to it the number <i>seven</i> whose primitive meaning we decided would be <i>diced</i> (Frame 7). It is hard to think of <b>cutting</b> anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs. Only let us say that he has had too much to drink at a party, grabs a <i>dagger</i> lying on the mantelpiece and starts <i>dicing</i> up everything insight, starting with the hors d'oeuvres and going on to the furniture and the carpets....		4	89	85	5	セツ、サイ	き.る、-き.る、き.り、-き.り、-ぎ.り、き.れる、-き.れる、き.れ、-き.れ、-ぎ.れ	The seven samurai used their swords to<strong> cut</strong> their opponents.	Seven swords<strong> cut</strong> better than one.	The <em>seven</em> samurai used their <em>swords</em> to<strong> cut</strong> vegetables. (Easier to remember if it's a little silly. Imagine the seven samurai flailing about the kitchen dangerously swinging their katanas about, to<strong> cut</strong> stuff up for dinner.).	"Actors filming ""The Seven Samurai"" respond to the director's command, ""CUT!"" by wielding their swords."	Be careful!!! Snow White has gone insane and<strong> CUT</strong> up the SEVEN dwarfs with a DAGGER.		
召		seduce	"A <i>sword</i> or <i>dagger</i> posed over a <i>mouth</i> is how the character for ""beckoning"" is written. The related but less tame key word <b>seduce</b> was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the - how shall we put it? - Freudian implications of the kanji. (Observe if you will that it is not sure whether the long slender object is <b>seducing</b> the small round one or vice versa.)"	* The primitive meaning remains the same: <i>seduce</i>. Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image.	5	90	86	5	ショウ	め.す	"A man is easily<strong> seduce</strong>d by a mouth to his ""sword.""."	When you<strong> seduce</strong> a girl you can put your sword in her mouth.	To<strong> seduce</strong> is to make a <em>sword</em> of one's <em>mouth</em>.	To<strong> seduce</strong> is to accomplish with the <em>mouth</em> what cannot (or should not) be done with a <em>sword</em>.	召す 【めす】 (v5s,vt) (1) to call; to send for; (2) to put on; to wear; to take (a bath); to ride in; to buy; to eat; to drink; to catch (a cold); (P) This kanji isn't anything sexual or anything. It means SUMMON/TO SEND/CALL FOR (as well as honorific form of eat/drink). STORY: A king is having a hard time EATING a piece of of meat b/c it can't fit in his MOUTH, so he CALLS FOR/SUMMONS someone to bring him his SWORD. (this keeps the eat/drink meaning of the kanji true as well).		
昭		shining	Let the key word suggest <b>shining</b> one's shoes, the purpose of which is to <i>seduce</i> the <i>sun</i> down on them for all to see.		9	91	87	5	ショウ		<strong>Shining</strong> is the sun's seduction.	The sun was<strong> shining</strong> so bright that it seduced Icarus and he flew too close.	Edward Cullen SEDUCES Bella when she sees him<strong> SHINING</strong> in the SUN. That sparkly bastard.	The knight in<strong> shining</strong> armour was seduced in just one day.	The Sun Seduces with its<strong> Shining</strong> light.		
則		rule	The character depicts a <i>clam</i> alongside a great and flashing <i>saber</i>. Think of digging for <i>clams</i> in an area where there are gaming <b>rules</b> governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it. So you take your trusty <i>saber</i>, which you have carefully notched like a yardstick, crack open a <i>clam</i> and then measure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the <b>rules</b> say it has to be.		9	92	88	5	ソク	のっと.る	When you have both <em>money</em> and the power of the <em>sword</em>, you can make the <strong>rules</strong>.	If you've got CRABs on your SABER, then you didn't follow the<strong> rule</strong>s of safe sex!	The world is<strong> rule</strong>d by <em>money</em> and <em>sword</em>.	A shellfish with a sword <strong>rule</strong>s.	Screw the <strong>rules</strong>, I have <em>money</em> and a <em>saber</em>.		
副		vice-	The key word <b>vice</b> has the sense of someone second-in-command. The great and flashing <i>saber</i> to the right (its usual location, so you need not worry about where to put it from now on) and the <i>wealth</i> on the left combine to create an image of dividing one's property to give a share to one's <b>vice</b>-<i>wealth</i> holder.		11	93	89	5	フク		The <em>wealthy</em> guy with the <em>sword</em> standing next to the king, that's the<strong> vice-</strong>roy who does all the dirty work.	<strong>Vice-</strong>president Cheney: a wealthy saber rattler.	<strong>Vice-</strong>President Cheney shot a man in the face while hunting, as is common knowledge, I imagine. So think of it like a Clue answer and you will remember the symbol order as well. <em>One</em> shot, in the <em>mouth</em>, on a <em>field</em>, with a <em>gun</em> (a modern-day sword).	The Shogun's second in command, handling the wages: One mouth controlling the rice fields to pay for the swords (Japanese samurai got paid in rice).	The VICE president protected my WEALTH with his army of SABER wielding soldiers.		
別		separate	In the Old East, the samurai and his <i>saber</i> were never <b>separated</b>. They were constant companions, like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of <b>separation</b>-anxiety for a samurai: to be <i>bound up with a rope</i> and unable to get at his <i>saber</i> leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that <i>mouth</i> bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for <i>tied up</i> is written - just as it had been with the character for <i>ten thousand</i>.		7	94	90	5	ベツ	わか.れる、わ.ける	I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be<strong> separate</strong>d from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.	A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their <em>mouths bound up</em> to keep them quiet) in a<strong> separate</strong> room from his <em>sabers</em>. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.	The prisoner with the BOUND MOUTH was<strong> separate</strong>d from his SABRE.	They<strong> separate</strong>d me from the group. They gagged my <em>mouth</em>, <em>bound</em> me up, and threatened me with a <em>saber</em>.	"In Empire Strikes Back, Luke was hanging upside down, muttered with his <em>mouth</em> ""Ben, Ben, Ben"", his feet <em>bound</em> in ice, he was <strong>separated</strong> from his light <em>sabre</em>. And he could hear the monster coming for him."		
丁		street	The picture here is of a <b>street</b> sign on a long pole: Hollywood and Vine, if you please, or any <i>street</i> that immediately conjure sup the image of a <b>street</b> sign to you.	* Used as a primitive, we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape to signify a <i>nail</i> or a <i>spike</i>. Should it happen, on reviewing, that you find the pictographs get jumbled, then think of jerking a <i>street</i> sign out of the ground and using it as a <i>nail</i> to repair your garage roof.	2	95	91	5	チョウ、テイ、チン、トウ、チ	ひのと	"Today, the program ""Sesame<strong> Street</strong>"" is brought to you by the letter ""T""."	Two<strong> street</strong>s make a T-intersection.	Any<strong> street</strong> with <em>nails</em> on it had best be avoided.	The<strong> street</strong> sign is nailed with a spike.	"The word on the<strong> street</strong> is, ""Mr. T is a bad-ass!""."		
町		town	<i>Street</i> signs standing at the corner of the <i>rice fields</i> depict the <b>town</b>&nbsp;limits. (Remember what was said earlier: when used as a primitive, a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word.)		7	96	92	5	チョウ	まち	Actually this means <strong>town</strong>, like one that has lots of <em>streets</em> and is surrounded by all the <em>rice fields</em>.	"Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. ""Pillage the<strong> village</strong>, for the <em>rice</em> and and the <em>tea</em>."" the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'."	"Note: the keywords of <a href=""../v4/92.html"">village</a> (#92 町) and <a href=""../v4/208.html"">town</a> (#208 村) swap places in translated editions of RTK I. In fact, according to different dictionaries, 町 is closer to 'town' whereas 村 is closer to 'village'."	<em>Streets</em> through <em>rice fields</em> are only found in small <strong>villages</strong>.	チョウ　まち A<strong> village</strong>/TOWN is nothing more than rice fields connected by streets.		
可		can	"Remember the story about the ""Little Engine that <b>Could</b>"" when you hear this key word, and the rest is simple. See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain - ""I think I <b>can</b>, I think I <b>can</b>...."" - spitting railroad <i>spikes</i> out of its <i>mouth</i> as it chews up the line to the top."		5	97	93	5	カ、コク	-べ.き	"A mouth on the street asking for things: ""Can I get some help?!<strong> Can</strong> I get directions,<strong> Can</strong> I have some money?<strong> Can</strong> you please speak English?!""."	I<strong> can</strong> eat nails.	"On Main STREET America, what you hear in people's MOUTHs is ""Yes We<strong> CAN</strong>!""."	A square box<strong> can</strong> fit in a corner.	<strong>Can</strong> you <em>speak</em> <em>street</em>? (as in street <em>talk</em>).		
頂		place on the head	"The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning ""humble acceptance."" Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing, we have: <i>nail</i> . . . <i>head</i>. As in ""hitting the <i>nail</i> on the <i>head</i>."" Now one presumes that most people can handle metaphors, but if you were to run into a dimwit working in a hardware store who only knew the literal meaning of things, and were to ask him, in your best Japanese, to <b>place on your head</b> a nail, he might miss the point and cause you considerable torment."		11	98	94	5	チョウ	いただ.く、いただき	If I put a <em>street sign</em> on my <em>head</em> what do I get ? A<strong> place on the head</strong> !	<em>NAILS</em> - <strong>place directly on the <em>fore</em>head</strong>, <em>NAILS</em> - <strong>place directly on the <em>fore</em>head</strong>, <em>NAILS</em> - <strong>place directly on the <em>fore</em>head</strong>, The <strong>HEAD ON</strong> commercial <em>nail</em>s it into your <em>head</em>……	"You've probably noticed that even the rudest and crudest Japanese say ""Itadakimasu"" before every meal. Why? Because each person who failed to say it as a child had a <em>nail</em> driven straight into that tender<strong> PLACE ON THE HEAD</strong> (i.e. the very top of the head). That's a lesson no one will forget!"	Driving down the STREET, looking at a PAGE in the map, I hit another car, and started bleeding from a<strong> place on the head</strong>.	<em>Nail</em> the <em>page</em> to the wall! <em>Place</em> a Bounty <em>On the head</em>.		
子		child	This kanji is a pictograph of a <b>child</b> wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young <b>children</b> who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.	* As a primitive, the meaning of <i>child</i> is retained, though you might imagine a little older <i>child</i>, able to run around and get into more mischief.	3	99	95	6	シ、ス、ツ	こ、-こ、ね	A<strong> child</strong> who is <em>ten</em> will still ask for his <em>ma</em> (top looks a bit like katakana ma).	A pictograph of a<strong> child</strong>, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).	A ten year old<strong> child</strong> with a baseball cap.	A<strong> child</strong>, from one to ten, before becoming a teen.	I'd imagine most people knew this long before starting RTK. When they were still a <strong>child</strong> of kanji, perhaps?		
孔		cavity	"Probably the one thing most <i>children</i> fear more than anything else is the dentist's chair. Once a <i>child</i> has seen a dentist holding the x-rays up to the light and heard that ominous word <b>cavity</b>, even though it is not likely to know that the word means ""hole"" until it is much older, it will not be long before those two syllables get associated with the drill and that row of shiny <i>hooks</i> the dentist uses to torture people who are too small to fight back."		4	100	96	6	コウ	あな	The child's arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his<strong> cavity</strong>.	I warned him about <strong>cavities</strong>, but the <em>child</em> is still <em>hooked</em> on sweets.	When a <em>child</em> falls into a <strong>cavity</strong> we need a <em>hook</em> to get them out.	A <em>child hooked</em> on candy canes (sweets) is bound to get a<strong> cavity</strong>.	"コウ　//　HOLE　// ""Confucius pulled the child out of the hole using a big hook."" 鼻孔 （びこう）nostril. 孔子 （こうし）Confucius."		
了		complete	"Learn this character by returning to frame 99 and the image given there. The only difference is that the ""arms"" have been left off (actually, only tucked inside). Thus a <i>child</i> with its arms wrapped up into the back-sack is the picture of a job successfully <b>completed</b>."		2	101	97	6	リョウ		The experiment was a<strong> complete</strong> failure! The child was made without any arms!	A child with the arms inside the blanket will be<strong> complete</strong>ly wrapped up.	The child in not<strong> complete</strong>. He's got no arms!	Don't be tempted to write another stroke and make 子 . This kanji, 了 , is already<strong> complete</strong>.	No parent can say their child rearing is<strong> complete</strong> until the child stops holding out his hand for money.		
女		woman	You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting <b>woman</b> drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy; being able to write it beautifully is another thing.	* The primitive meaning is the same: <i>woman</i>.	3	102	98	6	ジョ、ニョ、ニョウ	おんな、め	"To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a ""kunoichi"". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一 (kanji, ichi=one)."	My mother taught me that a<strong> woman</strong> should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).	The<strong> woman</strong> has her legs crossed.	When a<strong> woman</strong> becomes a ninja she is called a kunoichi (<strong>くノ一</strong>).	"To remember the stroke order, a female ninja is called a "" くノ一 ""."		
好		fond	"The phrase ""to be <b>fond</b> of someone"" has a natural gentleness about it, and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giving us the related term ""to <b>fondle</b>."" The character likens it to a <i>woman</i> <b>fondling</b> her <i>child</i>."		6	103	99	6	コウ	この.む、す.く、よ.い、い.い	A <em>woman</em> is<strong> fond</strong> of her <em>child</em>.	Women are<strong> fond</strong> of children.	If you are<strong> fond</strong> of a <em>woman</em>, she will make you a <em>child</em>.	Your wife and child: the thing you are most<strong> fond</strong> of.	There is no <strong>fond</strong>ness greater than what a <em>woman</em> feels for her <em>child</em>.		
如		likeness	Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again, but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette. For instance, the fact that things like the <i>mouth</i> of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a <i>woman</i> gives birth. Hence, in order to be reborn as an adult, one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb, that is, something that bears a <b>likeness</b> to the <i>opening</i> of the <i>woman</i> from whom you were born.		6	104	100	6	ジョ、ニョ	ごと.し	<em>Women</em> share a common<strong> likeness</strong>. Their <em>mouth</em>s are always open, whining about this and that.	"A <em>woman</em>'s <em>mouth</em> has the<strong> likeness</strong> of a vaccum cleaner, it's noisy and all it's good for is sucking. Do not confuse with <a href=""../v4/114.html"">resemblance</a> (#114 肖).<strong> Likeness</strong> is purely conceptual, whereas resemblance refers to actual physical similarities."	From a woman's other 口 comes a baby with a perfect<strong> likeness</strong>.	As a woman with a big mouth, Angelina Jolie was a perfect<strong> likeness</strong> for Lara Croft.	Women share one<strong> likeness</strong>: They have a big mouth! (I don't actually hold this view at all, but it does make it easy to remember).		
母		mama	Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for <i>woman</i> in it, the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a <b>mama</b>. Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother's breast has afforded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language groups.	* As a primitive we shall add the meaning of <i>breasts</i> in accord with the explanation given above. Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this kanji serves as a primitive, the final two dots joining together to form a longer stroke. An example follows in the next frame.	5	105	101	6	ボ	はは、も	The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.	This<strong> mama</strong> had twins, one <em>mouth</em> for each <em>nipple</em>.	"To remember strokes: it's a <em>breast</em> exam: 1)start like a <em>woman</em> 2) cross your heart (the lower right is crossed) 3) check your ""nipples"" 4) lift and separate (the last stroke parts the two ""breasts"")."	"<em>L7</em>… To remember the strokes: this begins by writing ""L7"", which is 50s slang for ""square"" or uncool. (As a teenager I thought my<strong> mama</strong> was really square) Add the ""nipples"" and then use the last stroke to part the two ""breasts""… 母 [はは] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E3%81%8A%E6%AF%8D%E3%81%95%E3%82%93"">、お母さん</a> [おかあさん] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E6%AF%8D%E4%B9%B3"">、母乳</a> [ぼにゅう] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E4%BC%AF%E6%AF%8D"">、伯母</a> /叔母[おば]."	The<strong> mama</strong> has two babies (drops) in the cradle.		
貫		pierce	If one is asked to think of associations for the word <b>pierce</b>, among the first to come to mind is that of <b>piercing</b> one's ears to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that has survived into the 21st century. The kanji here is read, top to bottom: <i>mama</i> . . . <i>oyster</i>. All you need to do is imagine <b>piercing</b> an ear so that it can hold a mother-of-pearl (actually, a <i>mama</i>-of-pearl) you have just wrested from an <i>oyster</i>.		11	106	102	6	カン	つらぬ.く、ぬ.く、ぬき	Ariel the Little Mermaid's <em>clamshell</em> bra was held to her <em>breasts</em> by <strong>piercings</strong>.	The sad fate of <em>Mama</em> <em>shellfish</em> was to be captured and <strong>pierced</strong> to make an earring.	<em>mama</em> <strong>pierces</strong> her ears in order to wear pearl earrings (which come from <em>shellfish</em>).	Boobs<strong> PIERCE</strong>D by shellfish! AAAH!!!	"""Mama"" sat on a ""shellfish"" and it<strong> pierce</strong>d her bottom! Ow!"		
兄		elder brother	"By now kanji like this one should ""look like"" something to you even though it is more of an ""ideogram"" than a ""pictograph."" The large <i>mouth</i> on top and the <i>human legs</i> below almost jump off the page as a caricature of <b>elder brother</b>, the one with the big <i>mouth</i> (or if you prefer a kinder image, the one who ""has the say"" among all the children)."	* As a primitive this character will take the meaning of <i>teenager</i>, in accord with the familiar image of the big <i>mouth</i> and the gangling, clumsy <i>legs</i>.	5	107	103	6	ケイ、キョウ	あに	My<strong> elder brother</strong> was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.	The pac man's ( 只 )<strong> elder brother</strong> has to have longer legs than his junior.	Older teenage brothers have big mouths and long, awkward legs.	My<strong> elder brother</strong> has a big MOUTH and LONG LEGS.	My <strong>elder brother</strong> always let his <em>mouth</em> <em>run</em>.		
呪		curse	For some reason, the inventor of this kanji associated a <b>curse</b> with the <i>mouth</i> of an <i>older brother</i>. I leave it to you to decide if he is on the giving or receiving end of the sorcery.		8	108	2169	6	ジュ、シュ、シュウ、ズ	まじな.う、のろ.い、まじな.い、のろ.う	Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a<strong> curse</strong> on my <em>elder brother</em> so that he can never open his <em>mouth</em>.	Your <em>older brother</em>'s <em>mouth</em> often <strong>curses</strong>.	There's an ancient<strong> curse</strong> in this region whereby the firstborn son, i.e. the <em>elder brother</em>, is always born with an extra <em>mouth</em>. And regardless of the elder brother's own personality, the extra mouth is bad tempered and always <strong>cursing</strong>.	A <em>mouthy teenager</em> is<strong> curse</strong>d to get into trouble time and time again.
