"It's interesting how Halparn, Henshall and ""Kanji Learners Dictionary"" all forfeit to include this kanji, yet kana-heavy games like Final Fantasy assumes their gamer has knowledge of this kanji. Just sayin'. Story: I put a <strong>curse</strong> on the <em>mouth</em> of my <em>older brother</em> to shut him up. He's an annoying bugger, after all."		
克		overcome	"In this frame we get a chance to use the kanji we just learned in its primitive meaning of <i>teenager</i>. The <i>needle</i> on top indicates one of the major problems confronting the <i>teenager</i> growing up in today's world: drugs. Many of them will fall under the shadow of the <i>needle</i> at some time during those tender years, but only when a whole generation rises up and decides that ""We Shall <b>Overcome</b>"" the plague, will the <i>needle</i> cease to hangover their heads, as it does in this character."		7	109	104	6	コク	か.つ	Ten elder brothers can<strong> overcome</strong> anything.	A <strong>teenager</strong> addicted to heroine must <strong>overcome</strong> the <em>needle</em>.	<strong>Overcome</strong> your <em>elder brother</em> with a <em>needle</em> to his head.	Having <strong>ten</strong> older brothers would be hard to<strong> overcome</strong>. <strong>Ten</strong> mouths, and <strong>ten</strong> sets of legs kicking the crap out of you.	<em>Ten teenagers</em> were chosen to<strong> OVERCOME</strong> all odds and save the world. The start of almost every JRPG.		
小		little	"The sense of <b>little</b> that this character represents is not the same as ""a little bit."" That meaning comes in the next frame. Here <b>little</b> means ""small"" or ""tiny."" The image is one of three <b>little</b> <i>drops</i>, the first of which (the one in the middle) is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it. The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in: <b>little</b>, <b>little</b>, nothing but <b>little</b>."	* The primitive of the same shape keeps the same meaning. Written above a horizontal line, its form is slightly altered, the last two strokes turning inwards.	3	110	105	7	ショウ	ちい.さい、こ-、お-、さ-	A<strong> little</strong> penguin with its wings at its side.	A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too<strong> little</strong> to ride the roller coaster.	Hold something<strong> little</strong> in-between your fingertips and it'll look like this Kanji here. :).	<strong>Little</strong><strong> little</strong><strong> little</strong> drops…	Ohh, how cute - a<strong> little</strong> penguin!		
少		few	First we need to look at the fourth stroke, the <i>drop</i> at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left. This happens because a single, isolated drop will NEVER appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size, for fear it would drop off and get lost. As for the meaning, let the tiny <i>drop</i> indicate a further belittling of what is already <i>little</i> - thus making it a <b>few</b> of something <i>little</i>.		4	111	106	7	ショウ	すく.ない、すこ.し	Only a<strong> few</strong> people can make an ugly face like that.	<strong>Few</strong> usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.	A happy grin, after a<strong> few</strong> drinks.	That playground has a<strong> few</strong> little ones sliding down the slide.	A<strong> few</strong> <em>little penguins</em> slide belly-first down an ice <em>slide</em>.		
大		large	Here we have a simple pictograph of a person, taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of <b>large</b>. It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms.	* As a primitive, we need a different meaning, since the element representing the human person will come up later. Therefore, this shape will become a <i>large dog</i> or, if you prefer, a <i>St. Bernard dog</i>. In frame 253 we will explain why this choice was made.	3	112	107	7	ダイ、タイ	おお-、おお.きい、-おお.いに	A person stretching their arms and legs to look<strong> large</strong> and scare a bear away.	How<strong> large</strong>? This<strong> large</strong>!	Think of a<strong> large</strong> St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.	A person ( 人 -fr.951) showing itself<strong> large</strong>r widening its arms.	That volcano is so big, or<strong> large</strong>, it goes over the clouds (the clouds being the horizontal line).		
多		many	"""<b>Many</b> <i>moons</i> ago,"" begins much of Amerindian folklore - a colorful way of saying ""Once upon a time"" and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji. Here we have two <i>moons</i> (three of them would take us back to the beginning of time, which is further than we want to go), lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time."		6	113	108	7	タ	おお.い、まさ.に、まさ.る	<em>Two evenings</em> too<strong> many</strong>!	"This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: ""He who eats<strong> many</strong> prunes sits on toilet<strong> many</strong> <em>moons</em>""."	"These look like the katakana ""ta"" therefore; There are<strong> MANY</strong> tatas! WOO~~~!"	The ninja waited<strong> many</strong> evenings for the right moment to strike.	<strong>Many</strong> <em>moons</em> ago.. or perhaps it was just a couple of <em>evenings</em>, I can't remember.		
夕		evening	"Just as the word <b>evening</b> adds a touch of formality or romanticism to the ordinary word ""night,"" so the kanji for <b>evening</b> takes the ordinary looking <i>moon</i> in the night sky and has a cloud pass over it (as we saw in the last frame)."	* The primitive keeps the same meaning and connotation as the kanji.	3	114	109	7	セキ	ゆう	The<strong> evening</strong> is young, the <em>moon</em> is not full.	In the<strong> evening</strong>, the crescent <em>moon</em> hangs in the sky.	"In the<strong> evening</strong>, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for ""TA"" (ie. ""ta ta!"")."	When I come back home from work in the<strong> evening</strong> I say <em>ta</em>daima.	This<strong> EVENING</strong>, there is only a half-<em>moon</em>.		
汐		eventide	In the next lesson we will meet the character for morning-<i>tide</i> and the element for <i>drops of water</i>. Meantime we have a perfect blend of picture and idea in this kanji to play on the English word for nightfall, <b>eventide</b>: <i>drops of water</i> inching their way up the shore in the <i>evening</i>.		6	115	110	7	セキ	しお、うしお、せい	<strong>Eventide</strong> is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.	<em>Drops</em> of water shower the beach as the <em>evening</em> tide approaches:<strong> eventide</strong>.	<strong>Eventide</strong> is when the drops of water are attracted to the moon. This is the tide which occurs in the evening.	In the<strong> eventide</strong> (nightfall), drops of water start forming in the evening.	The viking hordes arrive on the<strong> eventide</strong>, water spashes as the evening sky turn red with blood.		
外		outside	On the left, the primitive for <i>evening</i>, and on the right, that for the <i>magic wand</i>. Now, as every magician worth his abracadabra knows, bringing your <i>magic wand</i> out into the <i>evening</i> air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors. Hence, <i>evening</i> and <i>magic wand</i> takes you naturally <b>outside</b>.		5	116	111	7	ガイ、ゲ	そと、ほか、はず.す、はず.れる、と-	"A young magician likes to practice<strong> outside</strong> in the <em>evening</em> with his <em>magic wand</em> (as opposed to the old magician who wakes <em>early</em> to practice with his <em>wand</em> in <a href=""../v4/51.html"">eminent</a> (#51 卓))."	<strong>Outside</strong> in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.	Your <em>evening</em> is successful if you get to pull your <em>wand</em><strong> outside</strong> your pants.	Fairies live<strong> outside</strong>, and only come out in the <em>evening</em>. When they do, they wave their <em>magic wands</em> as they dance.	"All the gaikokujin ( 外国人 =""<strong>outside</strong> country person"") guys in Roppongi on a Saturday <em>evening</em> are looking to get their <em>magic wands</em> polished… 外す [はずす] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E5%A4%96"">、外</a> [そと] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E5%A4%96%E5%9B%BD%E4%BA%BA"">、外国人</a> [がいこくじん]."		
名		name	Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into its ear the <b>name</b> he has chosen for it, before making his choice public. It is an impressive <b>naming</b> custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed: <i>evening</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>. At <i>evening</i> time, a <i>mouth</i> pronounces the <b>name</b> that will accompany one throughout life.		6	117	112	7	メイ、ミョウ	な、-な	In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your<strong> name</strong> so that people can recognise you.	In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my<strong> name</strong>.	Because it's dark in the <em>evening</em>, you need to open your <em>mouth</em> and speak your<strong> name</strong> to identify yourself. (This is a traditional mnemonic for this kanji).	In African tradition, the father sneaks up to the baby in the EVENING, and whispers using his MOUTH the<strong> NAME</strong> which the baby will carry for his entire life.	My real<strong> name</strong> is eveningmouth, but you can call me Bob :).		
石		stone	With a <i>mouth</i> under a <i>cliff</i>, what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great <b>stone</b> has been rolled so that none may enter. Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the <i>Arabian Nights</i> should be enough to push the <b>stone</b> aside. But take care - the <i>cliff</i> is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below. This is the one and only time that the second stroke in <i>cliff</i> will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of.	* The <i>stone</i> is a quite common primitive element, which is not restricted to great boulders but used of <i>stones</i> or <i>rocks</i> of any size or shape.	5	118	113	7	セキ、シャク、コク	いし	Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of <em>cliff</em> just in time to evade the huge<strong> STONE</strong> rolling out of the <em>mouth</em> of the cave!	There's a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the <em>cliff</em> thing isn't working for you… Just see it as a<strong> stone</strong> [いし] being <em>hammered</em> by a miner searching for jewel<strong> stone</strong>s [ほう<strong>せき</strong>] ;).	If you pick the <em>right</em><strong> stone</strong>, and hit the kanji 右 <em>right</em> on its head really hard, you can chip off the upper stroke from it.	"A <a href=""../v4/11.html"">mouth</a> (#11 口) open beneath a cliff is bound to swallow some<strong> stone</strong>."	A<strong> stone</strong> covers the entrance to a cave hidden under a cliff.		
肖		resemblance	"The word <b>resemblance</b> should suggest, among other things, a son's <b>resemblance</b> to his father. A ""chip off the old block"" is the way we often put it, but the character is more simple. It speaks of a <i>little</i> bit of <i>flesh</i>."	* When used as a primitive, the sense of <i>resemblance</i> is replaced by that of <i>spark</i> or <i>candle</i>. (If you want an explanation: the kanji for <i>moon</i> also carries a secondary sense of <i>fire</i>, which we omitted because we are keeping that meaning for other primitives.)	7	119	114	7	ショウ	あやか.る	Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the <strong>resemblence</strong> between family members.	Hey baby, it might be a <em>little</em> bit of <em>flesh</em> now, but in a moment it'll bear a strong <strong>resemblance</strong> to a <em>candlestick</em>.(nudge nudge, wink wink).	This kanji bears a<strong> resemblance</strong> to sparks on a candle. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).	<em><strong>あやか-る</strong></em>: to share, goodluck—Resemblance = To have LITTLE difference in the FLESH.	God breathing a <em>sparkle</em> of life into <em>flesh</em> to make human <strong>resemblant</strong> to him.		
硝		nitrate	The word <b>nitrate</b> should immediately suggest a beaker of <b>nitric</b> acid, which, as every high-school chemistry student knows, can eat its way through some pretty tough substances. Here we imagine pouring it over a <i>rock</i> and watching the <i>sparks</i> fly as it bores a hole through the rock.		12	120	115	7	ショウ		That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured<strong> nitrate</strong> acid on it.	"Salpetre is the common name for<strong> Nitrate</strong> coming from Latin ""sal petrae"" or <em>stone</em> salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a <em>candle</em> in this kanji can be quite explosive!"	People I study Kanji with kept talking about some<strong> nitrate</strong>. I didn't even know what<strong> nitrate</strong> is, so I hit them with a stone so hard there were sparks flying everywhere. Months later my cell-mate in jail told me it's some sort of acid, but I didn't care any more… Thanks to this Kanji I got 30 years, thank you.	That stone resembles<strong> nitrate</strong>.	A stone containing<strong> nitrate</strong> and a candle are not good together.		
砕		smash	We begin with the two elements on the right, <i>baseball</i> and <i>needle</i>. Since they will be coming together from time to time, let us give the two of them the sense of a <i>game of cricket</i> in which a <i>needle</i> is laid across the wicket. Then imagine using a <i>rock</i> for a ball. A <b>smash</b> hit would probably splinter the bat in all directions, and a <b>smashing</b> pitch would do the same with the <i>needle</i> wicket.		9	121	116	7	サイ	くだ.く、くだ.ける	To<strong> SMASH</strong> a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.	The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they've done a new<strong> SMASH</strong> hit!	"Hulk<strong> smash</strong>! Hulk<strong> smash</strong> <em>stone</em>! Hulk decimate <em>stone</em>! What does ""decimate"" mean, Hulk? Uh, means destroy <em>nine</em> <em>tenths</em> of.<strong> SMASH</strong>!"	A <em>stone</em> will<strong> smash</strong> a car-window <em>nine</em> times out of <em>ten</em>.	Hulk<strong> SMASH</strong>! Hulk throw ROCK! Hulk hit 9 people! No! Hulk hit 10 people! Bad people! Hulk<strong> smash</strong>!		
砂		sand	Good <b>sand</b> for beaches has <i>few</i> or no <i>stones</i> in it. That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don't have to watch our step as we cavort about.		9	122	117	7	サ、シャ	すな	Here's how I remember that <em>stone</em> is on the left. This is because<strong> sand</strong> starts as <em>stones</em>, and only later they become <em>few</em>.	In good<strong> SAND</strong>, <em>stones</em> are <em>few</em>, if any.	Over time, <em>rocks</em> are worn down into just a <em>few</em> grains of<strong> sand</strong>.	To make<strong> sand</strong>, start by grinding a few stones.	<strong>Sand</strong> has <em>stones</em> <em>few</em> and far between. 砂 【すな】 (n)<strong> sand</strong>; grit; 砂糖 【さとう】 (n) sugar;.		
妬		jealous	It should not be hard to leep from the key word to the image of a <i>woman</i> who is <b>jealous</b> of the <i>rock</i> that another <i>woman</i> is sporting on the third finger of her left hand.		8	123	2195	7	ト、ツ	ねた.む、そね.む、つも.る、ふさ.ぐ	The<strong> jealous</strong> <em>woman</em> bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a <em>stone</em>.	WOMEN are<strong> JEALOUS</strong> of the STONE on my wife's ring.	I'm<strong> jealous</strong> that my <em>woman</em> has a crush on <em>The Rock</em>.	A<strong> jealous</strong> <em>woman</em> is as cold and hard as a <em>rock</em>.	The <em>woman</em> is<strong> jealous</strong> of her man, the <em>rock</em> star.		
削		plane	Long before the invention of the carpenter's <b>plane</b>, people used knives and machetes (or here, <i>sabers</i>) to smooth out their woodwork. If you have ever seen the process, you will have been amazed at the speed and agility with which the adept can <b>plane</b> a hunk of wood into shape. Indeed, you can almost see the <i>sparks</i> fly from their <i>sabers</i>.		9	124	118	7	サク	けず.る、はつ.る、そ.ぐ	<em>Sparks</em> will fly if you attempt to<strong> PLANE</strong> your <em>sabre</em>.	With today's strict air regulations, carrying a <em>sabre</em> onto a<strong> plane</strong> could <em>spark</em> quite a commotion.	"Not ""<em>a <strong>plane</strong>""</em>, but <em>""to <strong>plane</strong>""</em>. To carve a sculpture from wooden block, you cut it (with a <em>sword</em>) little by little, until there is <em>resemblance</em> with whatever it was meant to <em>resemble</em>."	The carpenter's<strong> plane</strong> <em>resembles</em> a <em>saber</em>.	<em>sparks</em> fly from the <em>blade</em> as they <strong>plane</strong> the surface to perfection.		
光		ray	"There are really only 2 primitives here, <i>little</i> and <i>human legs</i>. The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your beginner's eye.) Now if you have wondered what those little particles of ""dust"" are that dance around in the light-<b>rays</b> that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as <i>little</i> and disembodied <i>human legs</i>, and you should have no trouble with this character."		6	125	119	7	コウ	ひか.る、ひかり	A<strong> ray</strong> of light is not a wave but made of <em>little</em> photons with <em>human legs</em>.	The<strong> ray</strong> from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people <em>little</em> - ha! look at them run around on their tiny <em>legs</em>!	Imagine a<strong> ray</strong> gun shooting someone and their body exploding (sparks) and just their legs left.	<strong>Little legs</strong> at play are a<strong> ray</strong> of light in my day.	<strong>Ray</strong> is <em>tiny</em> <em>legs</em> of light…		
太		plump	"""<b>Plump</b>"" is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning. No sooner do you hear it than you think of a round and ample-bodied person falling into a sofa like a <i>large drop</i> of oil plopping into a fishbowl - kerrrr-<b>plump</b>!"		4	126	120	7	タイ、タ	ふと.い、ふと.る	A <em>large</em> person with a big <em>drop</em> of sweat dripping off of him because he is so<strong> plump</strong>.	"Fat(""plump"") men always have small penises…..the kanji is a combination of ""large"" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs)."	A big,<strong> plump</strong> sumo wrestler with a loincloth covering his little drop. (Thanks Fabrice).	"To keep this distinct from the primitive meaning of ""round"" (""fat man"") I suggest to use a specific image, such as that of a<strong> plump</strong> Japanese sumo wrestler, and let the <em>drop</em> between the legs be the loincloth (which compared to their <em>large</em> body size, is quite a <em>drop</em>). To illustrate the importance of this, have a look at the kanji for ""tenacious"" (frame 1506) and ""burdensome"" (frame 1986)."	The<strong> plump</strong> <em>dog</em> <em>drop</em>ped its tail between its legs.		
器		utensil	The picture in this kanji is not a pleasant one. It shows a large and fluffy <i>St. Bernard dog</i> stretched out on a table all stuffed and stewed and garnished with vegetables, its paws in the air and an apple in its mouth. At each corner of the table sits an eager but empty <i>mouth</i>, waiting for the <b>utensils</b> to arrive so the feast can begin.		15	127	121	7	キ	うつわ	Imagine four hungry <em>mouths</em> all sitting around the table. They are all banging their <strong>utensils</strong> on the table waiting for a <em>big</em> meal to be placed in the centre.	"Note: 器 by itself means <strong>container/caliber/vessel</strong>. And 食器 means eating<strong> utensil</strong>s (""food container"", hehe)."	Four <em>mouths</em> sit at the four corners of the table, waiting for their<strong> utensil</strong>s, ready to devour the large, spread eagled St. Bernard stretched out on the table!	I swear RevTK has got too politically correct, I mean people on here are copying Heisig's original story only shortening it which is fine, yet they are getting dislikes, only due to the fact its about eating a dog!? Four jgirl's mouths surrounding my large<strong> utensil</strong>.		
臭		stinking	This character is a bit friendlier to the animal world. Our friend the <i>St. Bernard</i> is alive and well, its <i>nose</i> in the air sniffing suspiciously after something <b>stinking</b> somewhere or other.		9	128	122	7	シュウ	くさ.い、-くさ.い、にお.う、にお.い	The ST. BERNARD DOG lifted his large NOSE high in the air to find out where the<strong> stinking</strong> smell comes from.	When <em>I</em> is <em>big</em>, Ego<strong> stinking</strong>.	<em>I</em> have just done a <em>big</em> one. It's really<strong> stinking</strong>.	If you put your NOSE directly on top of a ST. BERNARD, you'd surely be able to smell it's<strong> stinking</strong> wet fur.	Should one let <em>oneself</em> get too <em>large</em>, bodily functions may start<strong> stinking</strong>!		
嗅		sniff	You have seen those scratch'n'<b>sniff</b> advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a <i>mouth</i>wash that replaces one <i>stinking</i> oder with another.		12	129	3008	7	キュウ	か.ぐ	"<strong>Smell</strong>. <em>Mouth</em> agape, <em>nose</em> in the air, a <em>chihuahua</em> <strong>smells</strong> some BBQ miles away. NOTE: Assigned keyword ""sniff"" in RTK Newly Approved General Use Kanji Supplement."	<strong>smell</strong>: You open your mouth and gasp for air, that stinking (notice the chihuahua instead) smell is too much.
