額		forehead	As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's <i>guests</i>, but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the <b>forehead</b> of your <i>guest</i>.		18	316	295	13	ガク	ひたい	Sign the <em>guest</em>book <em>page</em> with your <strong>forehead</strong>. (Picture a guestbook full of<strong> forehead</strong> prints like thumbprints).	In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their<strong> forehead</strong>s together.	Thankful <em>guests</em> bow so much, you never see their entire <em>heads</em>, just their <strong>foreheads</strong>.	The <strong>guest</strong> lowers his<strong> forehead</strong> as he turns the <strong>page</strong> in a <strong>guest</strong>book.	As a <em>guest</em> in Japan, being too tall for their standards, I have to bow my <em>head</em> every time I enter someone's house, or else I'll smack my<strong> forehead</strong>.		
夏		summer	"In the <b>summer</b>, fatigued by the heat, your <i>head</i> hangs down nearly as far as your <i>walking legs</i>, or rather, your ""dragging legs."" Note how the <i>walking legs</i> (instead of ""animal legs"") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for <i>page</i> (Frame 64)."		10	317	296	13	カ、ガ、ゲ	なつ	In<strong> SUMMER</strong> you are hot from the top of your <em>head</em> down to your <em>walking legs</em>.	<em>One</em> <em>drop</em> of sweat runs into my <em>eye</em>, when I go <em>walking</em> on a hot<strong> summer</strong> day.	I personally think it was too confusing to try and use <em>head</em> as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the <em>animal legs</em> are replaced with <em>walking legs</em> instead of <em>human legs</em>?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot<strong> summer</strong> and you want to keep <em>oneself</em> under a <em>ceiling</em> not out <em>jogging</em> around.	"Tip:Don't use Head/Page( 頁 ) as a primitive, or it will just screw up. 頁 is used hundreds of times as primitive, and <em>always</em> needs the animal legs. Repetition makes RTK work. Little changes make life hard … The smell of sweat in<strong> Summer</strong> rises to the <em>ceiling</em>, leading you to take your 自 <em>nose</em> out on 夂<em>walking legs</em> for fresh cool air. Remember a set with 冬 <a href=""../v4/427.html"">winter</a> (#427 冬) where the sweat (<em>two drops</em> in fact), has fallen down and frozen below those same <em>walking legs</em>."	The heat of<strong> summer</strong> is so powerful, it swells your <em>head</em> so big, you need a bigger set of <em>walking legs</em> to hold it up.		
処		dispose	Both the stretching out of the <i>walking legs</i> and the little bit of <i>wind</i> tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or <b>dispose</b> of it.		5	318	297	13	ショ	ところ、-こ、お.る	The best way to<strong> dispose</strong> of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.	To <strong>dispose</strong> of rubbish you should <em>walk</em> it to the bin not throw it to the <em>wind</em>.	"Contrast this with <a href=""../v4/655.html"">discard</a> (#655 捨). Disposing of something implies a degree of care, whereas discarding something is generally careless. You want to associate this with a careful way to get rid of something. You throw a piece of garbage into the <em>wind</em> to get rid of it, but remember that you should<strong> dispose</strong> of it responsibly and your walking legs carry you off to fetch it."	To <strong>dispose</strong> of something you can either kick it away with your <em>walking legs</em> or you can wait for the <em>wind</em> to blow it away.	I thought to<strong> dispose</strong> of my <em>wind</em> secretly, but it appears I 'left' a trail behind whilst <em>walking</em> away.		
条		twig	"Geppetto made <i>walking legs</i> for his little Pinocchio from two <b>twigs</b> of a <i>tree</i>, giving him a set of ""<b>twiggy</b>"" shanks."		7	319	298	13	ジョウ、チョウ、デキ	えだ、すじ	They all say they have a <em>TREE</em> between their <em>WALKING LEGS</em> but most only have a <strong>TWIG</strong>.	Don't confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping<strong> twig</strong>s. A<strong> twig</strong> is always the kind of <em>wood</em> that snaps when the hunter's <em>walking legs</em> just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter's presence.	I don't believe this means<strong> twig</strong> as in a tree<strong> twig</strong>. 条 【じょう】 (n) (1) article (in document); provision; (2) stripe; streak; line. STORY: If TREES had WALKING LEGS they would march right up to congress and demand they put in a new ARTICLE into the constitution against deforestation.	(Doesn't mean<strong> twig</strong>!) I read an <strong>article</strong> in the Weekly World News about a <em>walking</em> <em>tree</em>.	I once read an <strong>ARTICLE</strong> about a guy who shoved a <strong>TREE</strong> between his <em>WALKING LEGS</em>. he was pulling out<strong> TWIG</strong>s for a long time.		
落		fall	When <i>water</i> <b>falls</b>, it splats and splashes; when <i>flower</i> petals <b>fall</b>, they float gently in the breeze. To <i>each</i> thing its own way of <b>falling</b>.		12	320	299	13	ラク	お.ちる、お.ち、お.とす	Water each flower or the petals will wither and<strong> fall</strong>.	"[It's been suggested on the forum (<a href=""http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079"">http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079</a>) that <em>flower</em> across the full width of the kanji and <em>water</em> on the left below it should have its own keyword; <em>seaweed</em> is a popular choice. See also <a href=""../v4/227.html"">dilute</a> (#227 薄), <a href=""../v4/1912.html"">clan</a> (#1912 藩), <a href=""../v4/2035.html"">seaweed</a> (#2035 藻). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers <strong>fall</strong>ing through the sky – suddenly <em>each</em> one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori <em>seaweed</em> to carry them safely down."	"""Flowers"" need ""water"" ""each"" day or they'll bend and<strong> fall</strong> over (helps with the order of writing)."	The <em>flowers</em><strong> FALL</strong> over the <em>water each</em> hanami season.	"""each"" is impossible to visualize, instead I picture a guy<strong> fall</strong>ing down with his mouth open in a scream and his walking legs above him flailing as he's<strong> fall</strong>ing. Works well for this kanji if you imagine him<strong> fall</strong>ing from a waterfall. At first he's holding on to some flowers, but they finally give and he tumbles into the water below."		
冗		superfluous	Picture a <i>weather vane</i> beneath a regal <i>crown</i>, spinning round and round. It is not only <b>superfluous</b> but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it.		4	321	300	14	ジョウ		"The king's crown was blown off by the wind. ""Oh well,"" he said, ""it's just a<strong> superfluous</strong> symbol.""."	"The court jester wears a <em>crown</em> and is full of <em>wind</em> with bad jokes. He is<strong> superfluous</strong> to the King's court. This kanji is read as ""JOU"" and commonly used to create the compound for <em>jou-dan</em> 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also <em>jou-go</em> 冗語 (redundancy) and <em>jou-in</em> 冗員 (useless workers) 員 -<a href=""../v4/56.html"">employee</a> (#56 員)."	Trying to put a <em>crown</em> on the <em>wind</em> is like gilding the lily: entirely<strong> superfluous</strong>.	The <em>wind</em> bags who wear the <em>crown</em> are almost always<strong> SUPERFLUOUS</strong> to the governance of their countries.	Instead of just fluous, like the flow of the wind, I crown you<strong> superfluous</strong>.		
冥		Hades	"The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the ""dwarf planet"" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the <i>crowning</i> deed of <i>day six</i> of the creation."		10	322	2841	14	メイ、ミョウ	くら.い	The beast of <strong>hades</strong> one <em>day</em> will wear a <em>crown</em>, and the number of the beast is <em>666</em>.	In<strong> Hades</strong> you have to work <em>six days</em> a week before <em>crowning</em> it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that's Japan.	In <strong>Hades</strong>, as punishment, souls are forced to wear <em>crowns</em> as hot as the <em>sun</em> for <em>6</em>66 days.	If you can survive<strong> Hades</strong> for <em>six days</em> they give you a <em>crown</em> as a reward.	It's dark in<strong> Hades</strong>, for the <em>sun</em> is covered by a <em>crown</em>. Oh, yeah, and the number <em>six</em> is just a wee bit popular down there.		
軍		army	"The <i>crowned vehicle</i> depicted here is a ""<i>chariot</i>,"" symbol of an <b>army</b>."	* Used as a primitive this kanji means only <i>chariot</i>.	9	323	301	14	グン		British <strong>army</strong> <em>cars</em> are at the service of the <em>crown</em>.	Imagine a <em>crown</em> is the hood ornament on every<strong> army</strong> <em>car</em>.	"The<strong> army</strong> has <em>cars</em> that are under the command of the <em>crown</em> - in ancient days these would have been <em>chariots</em>. (NB: ""under"" to help remember placement of the primitives.)."	A <em>vehicle</em> <em>crowned</em> with a turret is a tank – and obviously a tank belongs in the<strong> army</strong>!	There is an<strong> army</strong> of taxi drivers in Japan driving the Toyota Crown model of car.		
輝		radiance	Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the <i>ray</i> of light to the left. Now add the glittering <i>chariot</i> that is emitting those <i>rays</i> and you have <b>radiance</b>.		15	324	302	14	キ	かがや.く	Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot =<strong> radiance</strong>. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!	<strong>Radiance</strong> is an army of rays.	<strong>Radiance</strong> isn't just a few <em>rays</em>, but a whole <em>army</em> of them.	When I think of<strong> radiance</strong> I think of the greek god Zeus - picture him throwing <em>rays</em> of lightning (hence the extra jaggedness of the character) from atop his <em>chariot</em> riding through the heavens.	Ray's little legs joined the army - so Ray-did-a-dance (radiance).		
運		carry	"A long string of ""sweet"" <i>chariots</i> ""swinging low"" to our <i>roads</i> is a sure sign that the Lord is ""comin' for to <b>carry</b>"" someone home."		12	325	303	14	ウン	はこ.ぶ	Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to<strong> carry</strong> military supplies (sorry no room for you).	Roads<strong> carry</strong> armies (in contrast to seas<strong> carry</strong>ing navies or skies<strong> carry</strong>ing air forces).	"""swing low, sweet <em>chariot</em>, coming for to<strong> carry</strong> me hoooommmee."	In the past, <em>road</em>s were established mainly to<strong> carry</strong> the <em>army</em>.	"The difference between <a href=""../v4/289.html"">transport</a> (#289 輸), <a href=""../v4/287.html"">take along</a> (#287 連) and <a href=""../v4/303.html"">carry</a> (#303 運)? Transport 輸 = when your car moves big items, like meat and sabers for that one butcher's hut. Take Along 連 = when you take a guest in your car on the road.<strong> Carry</strong> 運 = the luck you<strong> carry</strong> when the king's carriage is out on the road, tossing gold coins to bystanders."		
冠		crown	By having the <b>crown</b> pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself <i>glued</i> to its <i>beginnings</i>.		9	326	304	14	カン	かんむり	"Remember the SUPERFLUOUS<strong> CROWN</strong> that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying ""i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING""."	A <strong>crown</strong>, from the <em>beginning</em> of the new king's life, is <em>glued</em> to him. He must inherit it.	That<strong> crown</strong> was <strong>glued</strong> together from the <strong>beginning</strong>…I swear!	<strong>Crown</strong>ing is when the child <em>begins</em> to emerge from the vagina, covered in <em>gluey</em> mucus.	"I liked wasurenaide's story, but the superfluous and wind bits just confused me, so changed it a bit: Remember the<strong> CROWN</strong> that kept falling off the kings big shiny bald head while he's making a long speech? Well now the king is saying ""i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING""."		
夢		dream	"To have a <b>dream</b> after going to bed is really the <i>crown</i> to a perfect <i>evening</i>. The <i>flower</i> petals over the <i>eyes</i> (instead of the ""sand"" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant <b>dream</b> suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji."		13	327	305	14	ム、ボウ	ゆめ、ゆめ.みる、くら.い	Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a<strong> dream</strong>. She even laid <em>flowers</em> over my <em>eyes</em> to <em>crown</em> the perfect <em>evening</em>.	In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to<strong> DREAM</strong> about his daughter's friend and have a <em>rose petal</em> fall onto his <em>eye</em> from the <em>ceiling</em>. He did this lying in his bed each <em>evening</em>. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.	Sweet<strong> dream</strong>s like flowers for the eye are the crown of a perfect evening.	"In Japan, ""flowers over your eyes"" is a metaphor for falling asleep and<strong> dream</strong>ing (just as the sandman is in the West). So we can make a little poem: <em>Flowers</em> over your <em>eyes</em>, The <em>crown</em> of a perfect <em>evening</em>."	"I like to think of the sideways eye as a <em>cyclops</em>, either the monster of Greek mythology or the X-Men character. The primitive reappears in <a href=""../v4/400.html"">demolition</a> (#400 壊) and others. So: Odysseus and his mates carefully hang magical <em>flowers</em> above the evil <em>cyclops</em>. These allow them to take the monster's <em>crown</em> and escape in the <em>evening</em>, while the monster is peacefully <strong>dreaming</strong>."		
坑		pit	A <i>whirlwind</i> begins to dig its way into the <i>soil</i> like a drill until it makes a deep <b>pit</b>.		7	328	306	14	コウ		A <em>whirlwind</em> digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of <em>dirt</em> until it ends up with a giant <strong>pit</strong>.	Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a<strong> pit</strong> into the soil. Note: Take care difference between<strong> pit</strong> and rut.	All the <em>soil</em> was thrown to the left as the Tasmanian Devil's <em>whirlwind</em> swirled out a<strong> PIT</strong>.	Down in the earth, there's a<strong> pit</strong> where you'll find miners in top hats constantly breaking wind.	"A<strong> pit</strong> is cut into the <em>soil</em> by a magician archaeologist. He uses a <em>whirlwind</em>. (and for the primitive:) A <strong>whirlwind</strong> is made by a magician from his <em>top hat</em>, he holds it up and a ferocious <em>wind</em> whirls out of it, messing up the attire of everyone in the front row. <em>[RTK2 #221, pure group, コウ. signal primitive </em>whirlwind<em> is コウ because you will get コウght in it unless you are at the very コウ=core]</em>."		
高		tall	Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the <i>mouth</i> under the extraterrestrial's glass <i>hood</i>, and then the <i>mouth</i> under the <i>top hat</i> of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much <b>taller</b> than everyone else.	* As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of <i>tall</i> and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes.	10	329	307	14	コウ	たか.い、たか、-だか、たか.まる、たか.める	Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and <em>top hat</em>, trying to look<strong> TALL</strong>. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.	Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a<strong> TALL</strong> hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).	Woody and Buzz-light year. Woody (in the cowboy <strong>hat</strong>) being<strong> Tall</strong>er than Buzz ( in the <strong>space helmet</strong>) both with big <em>mouths</em>. Thx Minlawc! (adjusted for clarity).	This is the classic two children trying to be<strong> tall</strong> enough to get on a fairground ride. The lower child hides under a <em>cover</em> while the upper child stands on his shoulders and talks like he's an adult. But they're still not<strong> tall</strong> enough! So the top child gets a <em>top hat</em> which j-u-s-t pokes above the 'you must be this<strong> tall</strong>' line. (and they both have hungry <em>mouths</em> for eating candyfloss once the deception is complete).	"A cowboy (here represented by a ""top hat"" revealing only his ""mouth"") looks always<strong> tall</strong> against a ninja wrapped up in his ""hood"" that reveals only his ""mouth""."		
享		receive	<i>Tall children</i> <b>receive</b> more attention. <i>Tall children</i> grow up to make better wide <b>receivers</b>. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular <i>tall child</i> in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames.		8	330	308	14	キョウ、コウ	う.ける	In basketball however, tall children<strong> receive</strong> all the attention.	<em>Tall children</em><strong> receive</strong> all the attention. They also make great<strong> receive</strong>rs in football… this kanji also means 'catch' (therefore a football<strong> receive</strong>r is a great image).	Kinda weird but I remember the weird ones best: A giant MOUTH wearing a TOPHAT<strong> RECEIVE</strong>S its next victim to munch on. This time its a small CHILD whimpering under the figure on the floor, scared of what is to come.	"A word of warning: With Heisig's story I keep associating this with ""attention""! I use something closer tied to the word<strong> receive</strong>: Imagine a bunch of kids finding an old radio. It's antenna is broken, so the <em>tallest</em> <em>kid</em> has to hold it up, and becomes the designated <strong>receiver</strong>."	"Usually in yaoi couples the short guy is the one who ""receives"". But here we see how the <strong>tall boy</strong> is <em>receiving</em> and he <em>enjoys it</em> ( 享楽する ）. RTK2:　キョウ 享楽主義 きょうらくしゅぎ(hedonism)."		
塾		cram school	<b>Cram schools</b> are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the <i>tall children</i> who are out on the school <i>grounds</i> practicing sports, and the <i>fat</i> ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the <b>cram schools</b>, rather than those who do.		14	331	309	14	ジュク		Welcome to our<strong> cram school</strong>: you will <em>receive</em> a <em>rounded</em> education on our <em>grounds</em>.	"""You can <em>receive</em> a well-<em>rounded</em> education if you study at our<strong> cram school</strong>"" says the advertisement. ""Just come to our school <em>grounds</em> and check it out yourself!""."	In <strong>cram schools</strong> <em>tall</em> kids treat the <em>round</em> ones like <em>dirt</em>.	<em>Tall children</em> who are well <em>round</em>ed play on the <em>ground</em>s and go to<strong> cram school</strong>.	Tall and Round kids go to<strong> Cram School</strong> on Saturday. I use Saturday instead of ground in this one since it is the first part of 土曜日 【どようび】.		
熟		mellow	The <i>tall</i> and <i>fat children</i> from the last frame are here cast into a cauldron over an <i>oven flame</i> until they have sufficiently <b>mellowed</b> that they can return to the normal life of a student.		15	332	310	14	ジュク	う.れる	Imagine <em>tall children</em> sitting <em>round</em> the <em>fire</em> toasting marsh-<strong>mellow</strong>s.	The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the <em>tall</em> and <em>fat</em> ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they<strong> mellow</strong>. (Note that here the keyword 'mellow' only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of 'chill out').	"<strong>Mello</strong>, from Death Note, was the more <em>fiery</em> student at the <a href=""../v4/309.html"">cram school</a> (#309 塾)-like orphanage. He <em>receive</em>d a well <em>round</em>ed education there, in order to succeed L."	Even if<strong> mellow</strong>, shy children <em>receive</em> a well-<em>rounded</em> education, they too will have a chance to <em>burn</em> brightly and succeed.	Thank goodness, the <em>cram school's</em> on fire. Life is all<strong> mellow</strong> and stress-free once again, now that the stress of cram school is over with.		
亭		pavilion	Think of all the <b>pavilions</b> at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering <i>tall crowned nail</i> (the <i>crown</i> being a revolving restaurant) - that architectural monstrosity that has become a symbol of science and technology at such events.		9	333	311	14	テイ、チン		The <em>tall</em>est<strong> Pavilion</strong> <em>crowns</em> the <em>street</em>.	The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.	"The upper<strong> pavilion</strong> of Tokyo Tower is very <em>tall</em>. Godzilla attacks Tokyo Tower, wears the upper<strong> pavilion</strong> of Tokyo Tower as a <em>crown</em>, and then uses the rest of the tower as a spike to skewer some other monster. Avoid <a href=""../v4/254.html"">pagoda</a> (#254 塔): pagodas are for fitting flowers above the ground,<strong> pavilion</strong>s are from Tokyo Tower to wear as a crown."	The king's<strong> PAVILION</strong> is easy to notice. It's the <em>TALL</em> one with a <em>CROWN</em> <strong>nailed</strong> at the entrance…	The <em>tall</em><strong> PAVILION</strong> <em>crowns</em> the <em>street</em>.		
京		capital	When we think of a <b>capital</b> city today we think of <i>tall</i> skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of <i>little</i> folk scurrying here and there about their business.		8	334	312	14	キョウ、ケイ、キン	みやこ	Tokyo,<strong> capital</strong> of Japan: <em>tall</em> buildings, <em>small</em> people (compared to the buildings).	The<strong> capital</strong> is where the powerful act formal wearing <em>top hats</em>, open their <em>mouth</em>s, and get <em>little</em> done.	Both the tall and the small are found in the<strong> capital</strong>.	The<strong> capital</strong> letter in a word is the <em>tall</em> one, the one that's higher then the other <em>little</em> letters.	Kyoto ( 京都 ), the old<strong> capital</strong>: <em>tall</em> pagodas, <em>small</em> town mentality.		
涼		refreshing	Since few things are as <b>refreshing</b> on a warm day as a cool shower (the <i>water</i>), here we picture an entire <i>capital</i> city treating itself to one, and in full view of everyone.		11	335	313	14	リョウ	すず.しい、すず.む、すず.やか、うす.い、ひや.す、まことに	When you're a tourist in the <em>capital</em> during the heat of summer, finding a <em>water</em> fountain is oh, so<strong> refreshing</strong>.	The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so<strong> refreshing</strong>!	"Imagine a British guy praising his drink. ""This <em>water</em> is absolutely <em>Capital</em>! .. How<strong> refreshing</strong>!"" NOTE: This isn't intended to be disrespectful."	It is a well known fact that the most<strong> refreshing</strong> <em>water</em> of a country can be found in the <em>capital</em>.	This means<strong> REFRESHING</strong> and COOL (such as temperature). STORY: During those hot summers in the CAPITAL of Japan (Tokyo) WATER from the sky (rain) can be<strong> REFRESHING</strong> and COOL despite getting soaked.		
景		scenery	<b>Scenery</b> is depicted as a <i>sun</i> rising over a <i>capital</i> city, which is a bit of natural <b>scenery</b> the city dwellers themselves rarely get to see!		12	336	314	14	ケイ		Imaging the sun rising over the capital–classic postcard<strong> scenery</strong>.	Anyone who's been to Kyoto doesn't need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a <em>sunny</em> day in the old <em>capital</em>, and there's no better<strong> scenery</strong>.	There's no<strong> scenery</strong> quite so nice as the sun setting over China's ancient <em>capital</em>, the forbidden city.	The <em>sun</em> shining <em>over the capital</em> is a nice<strong> scenery</strong> indeed.	When the SUN rises over the CAPITAL, the<strong> SCENERY</strong> is just amazing.		
鯨		whale	The <b>whale</b> swallows a whole school of fish, who turn their new abode into a proper little <i>fish-capital</i>.		19	337	315	14	ゲイ	くじら	If <em>fish</em> were cities, the<strong> whale</strong> would surely be the <em>capital</em>.	When the <em>whale</em> was first discovered it was the biggest <em>fish</em> people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire <em>capital</em> city!	When you're saying a<strong> whale</strong> is just a <em>fish</em>, you're making a <em>capital</em> mistake!	Remember when a<strong> whale</strong> swam up the Thames. Everyone thought there was a big <em>fish</em> in the <em>capital</em>, but it was really a<strong> whale</strong>.	"A<strong> whale</strong> is like a <a href=""../v4/171.html"">fish</a> (#171 魚) except it is as big as the <a href=""../v4/312.html"">capital</a> (#312 京)."		
舎		cottage	A <i>lidded crock</i> with an <i>umbrella</i> overhead gives us a mixture of the modern and the nostalgic in this design for a <b>cottage</b>.		8	338	316	14	シャ、セキ	やど.る	The<strong> cottage</strong> is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.	Picture a <em>lidded crock</em> full of tasty<strong> cottage</strong> cheese… yum! Now all we need is an <em>umbrella</em> over it to protect the<strong> cottage</strong> cheese from the sun.	"The homeless man stuck an <em>umbrella</em> over his <em>lidded crock</em> in the country side and declared it his<strong> cottage</strong>. It looks just like a shack (しゃ) though! Under local government legislation, after 7 years, the ""cottage"" and land were his."	I call it my<strong> cottage</strong>, but it's really just an <em>umbrella</em> over a <em>dirty hole</em> in the ground.	To further Heisig's explanation, imagine a<strong> cottage</strong> made out of a giant lidded crock and an umbrella. The mouth can also represent a door.		
周		circumference	Look more closely at your <i>lidded crock</i> and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the <b>circumference</b> of your <i>motorcycle helmet</i>: just begin at a fixed point and turn the <i>lidded crock</i> around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the <i>helmet</i>, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your <i>lidded crock</i> made, you now know the <b>circumference</b>.	* As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a <i>lap</i>.	8	339	317	14	シュウ	まわ.り	If my LIDDED CROCK has the same<strong> CIRCUMFERENCE</strong> as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.	When the <em>ground</em> has an <em>opening</em> (a hole), you need to cover the entire<strong> circumference</strong> or you will fall in.	You're at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the<strong> circumference</strong> of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.	The<strong> CIRCUMFERENCE</strong> of the Earth's soil <em>surface</em> ( 土 ) has been the <em>same</em> ( 同 ) for a long time.	There's a <em>hole</em> (mouth) in the <em>ground</em>, so the men at work have put a <em>barrier tape</em> (hood) forming a circunference, to prevent people from falling into it.		
週		week	Picture a circular <i>road</i> with 7 markers on it, one for each day of the <b>week</b>. When you have walked one complete <i>lap</i> on this <i>road</i>, you shall have completed one <b>week</b>.		11	340	318	14	シュウ		Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a<strong> week</strong> to travel the circumference of the earth.	"Actually the<strong> week</strong> is like a never ending <em>road</em> where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the <em>circumference</em> is always the same. <a href=""../v4/317.html"">circumference</a> (#317 周) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth – all important for measuring all kinds of time periods."	This city is so big, it takes a<strong> week</strong> to travel around its <em>circumference</em> by <em>road</em>.	"It takes a<strong> WEEK</strong> to walk the ""circumference"" of this ""road""."	The <em>circumference</em> of Japan would take at least a<strong> week</strong> on the <em>road</em> to navigate.		
士		gentleman	The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for <i>soil</i> by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's <b>gentlemen</b>.	* The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the <i>samurai</i>, Japan's warrior class.	3	341	319	14	シ		What a handsome<strong> gentleman</strong>. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!	A<strong> gentleman</strong> has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.	The<strong> gentleman</strong> stretches his arms wide to balance so he doesn't fall onto the ground and get mixed up in it.	Gentlemen are the opposite of dirty.	A samurai<strong> gentleman</strong> starts a duel with open arms to show he has no personal grudges against the challenger.

壮		robust	<b>Robust</b> is seen as a <i>turtle</i> turned <i>samurai</i>.		6	343	321	14	ソウ	さかん	The image is a<strong> robust</strong> green bulging-muscle cartoon turtle. 売		sell	A <i>samurai</i>, out of a job, is going door-to-door <b>selling</b> little windup <i>crowns</i> with <i>human legs</i> that run around on the floor looking like headless monarchs.		7	345	323	14	バイ	う.る、う.れる	The <em>samurai</em> happened to find an extra large <em>crown</em> that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his <em>legs</em>. 覚		memorize	The idea of <b>memorizing</b> things is easily related to the <i>schoolhouse</i>; and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that <b>memorizing</b> involves <i>seeing</i> things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together.		12	347	325	15	カク	おぼ.える、さ.ます、さ.める、さと.る	In a <em>schoolhouse</em> in class: 1) you <em>see</em> something on the blackboard, then 2) you<strong> memorize</strong> it. When you are in the <em>schoolhouse</em> you must <strong>memorise</strong> what you <em>see</em>.	In the Heisig <em>School</em> of learning Kanji we<strong> memorize</strong> how to write the kanji by <em>seeing</em> a story in our minds.		
栄		flourish	The botanical connotations of the word <b>flourish</b> (to bud and burst into bloom, much as a <i>tree</i> does) are part of the ideal of the <i>schoolhouse</i> as well.		9	348	326	15	エイ、ヨウ	さか.える、は.え、-ば.え、は.える、え	The TREES<strong> FLOURISH</strong> in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more. This is a very special <em>schoolhouse</em>, were <em>trees</em> are taught how to<strong> FLOURISH</strong>. It is important to imagine the image of <em>trees</em> sitting down and taking classes on<strong> FLOURISH</strong>ING in a <em>schoolhouse</em>. You could even use an actual <em>schoolhouse</em> to make your mental image more realistic. You would even imagine the graduation ceremony of a class of sakura flowering all at the same time while holding their diplomas.

With a brush, it takes all day to<strong> write</strong> anything. Rita Skeeter, from Harry Potter, has a magic brush that<strong> write</strong>s anything that comes from the tongue wagging in her mouth.		
津		haven	Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks, the All-Merciful took its <i>brush</i> and drew little inlets of <i>water</i> where the hapless creatures might seek shelter. A<strong> haven</strong> is somewhere you can pull your boat out of the <em>water</em> and use a <em>brush</em> to repaint it.		
牧		breed	When it is time to <b>breed</b> new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the <i>cow</i> is often not. Thus the <i>taskmaster</i> to the right forces the <i>cow</i> into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can <b>breed</b>.		8	351	329	15	ボク	まき	"Imagine a <em>taskmaster</em> giving a <em>cow</em> the command to ""start <strong>breed</strong>ing, and start doing it now!"", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to<strong> breed</strong> with. Hence, you see the <em>taskmaster</em> running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the <em>cow</em>."	Hint: This is the kanji from which <em>taskmaster</em> is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with<strong> breed</strong>, and a lot to do with <strong>pastures</strong> and <strong>shepherds</strong> (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don't differenciate between animals). Think of a <em>cowboy</em> (taskmaster) who brings his <em>cows</em> to the <strong>pasture</strong>.	"I think of Hitler for the taskmaster primitive. This has worked really well. Hitler can be the real person (and works well for kanji such as 激 <a href=""../v4/497.html"">violent</a> (#497 激)). Or it can be more comical, such as a homosexual man dressed as Hitler for a costume party. As in, a homosexual Hitler has no hope of<strong> breed</strong>ing. (Here you imagine him wearing leather bondage bands). *Also, the taskmaster primitive seems to generally be on the right side of kanji in this book."	"Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to ""start<strong> breed</strong>ing, and start doing it now!"", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to<strong> breed</strong> with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow."	The <em>cow</em> is forced by the <em>taskmaster</em> to<strong> breed</strong>.		
攻		aggression	The special <i>craft</i> of successful <i>taskmasters</i> is their ability to remain constantly on the <b>aggressive</b>, never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter-<b>aggression</b> of their own.		7	352	330	15	コウ	せ.める	<strong>AGGRESSION</strong> is a well-honed <em>craft</em> for any decent <em>taskmaster</em>.	<strong>Aggression</strong> is the <em>craft</em> of a good <em>dominatrix</em>. 枚		a sheet of	English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in <b>sheets</b>. 故		happenstance	Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, <b>happenstance</b> is the <i>oldest taskmaster</i> we know. It nearly always has its way.		9	355	333	15	コ	ゆえ、ふる.い、もと	An <em>OLD TASKMASTER</em> is no<strong> happenstance</strong> (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.	"Need to disambiguate from <a href=""../v4/443.html"">enemy</a> (#443 敵) as it's easy to mix up <strong>antique</strong> and <strong>old</strong> here. Let's think of an accidental president – he is an <strong>old</strong> <strong>taskmaster</strong> who has managed to win the election by<strong> happenstance</strong> ."	"Only an old taskmaster uses a stupid word like ""happenstance"" instead of the many less pretentious synonyms for luck or chance."	It's not just a<strong> happenstance</strong> that the taskmaster looks old before his time.	I recently ran into my <em>old taskmaster</em> purely by<strong> happenstance</strong>.		
敬		awe	"Standing in <b>awe</b> of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in <i>flowery phrases</i> out of veneration or fear. If you don't talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.	Hitler's flowery phrases held the nation in<strong> awe</strong>. If you're a girl you can try to woo your <em>taskmaster</em> with <em>flower</em>y <em>phrases</em> to get an<strong> awe</strong>some grade.		
言		say	Of all the things we can do with our <i>mouths</i>, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for <b>say</b> has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.	* This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean <i>saying</i>, <i>speech</i>, or <i>words</i>, depending on which is most useful.	7	357	335	15	ゲン、ゴン	い.う、こと	A pictogram of someone <strong>saying</strong> a <em>four</em> letter word from their <em>mouth</em> after the censors have gotten a hold of it.	This is simple a pictogram of a <em>mouth</em><strong> SAY</strong>ing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.	This is such a hard one for me to remember in stories so I use Socrates to personify<strong> say</strong> since he is an orator. Just make Socrates the subject of your stories and whenever Socrates shows up you'll know this character should be written. Just picture him in his toga with a hand up in the air looking philisophical. You can try some other well spoken individual as long as they bring to mind speech, words, or<strong> say</strong>.	Before you<strong> say</strong> something in chinese, make sure you master the <em>4 tones</em> that can come out of your <em>mouth</em> so that you don't embarrass yourself.	Facciamo <strong>quattro chiacchere..</strong>.		
警		admonish	Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being <b>admonished</b> for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in <i>awe</i> of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary <i>words</i>.		19	358	336	15	ケイ	いまし.める	To<strong> admonish</strong> is to enforce <em>awe</em> by means of <em>words</em>.	Watch in <em>awe</em> as mom<strong> admonish</strong>es the rude clerk with <em>words</em> that you've never heard her use before.	Japanese police officers prefer to<strong> admonish</strong> perpetrators by <em>awe</em>ing them with their <em>words</em>. You've never had a talking down to, until you've been a Japanese high school student caught littering in a small Japanese town. Just imagine the talking to that kid would get! Incidentally, this kanji is the first kanji in the word for police.	"I will now<strong> admonish</strong> every person here who used WORD as a keyword in this story. There is no WORD ( 語 ) in this kanji! I know Heisig himself teaches it that way. Doesn't make it right, does it? This is about <em>SAY</em>ing something that inspires <em>AWE</em>. You will regret it when you get to <a href=""../v4/347.html"">word</a> (#347 語)! ;)… 警察 [けいさつ] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E8%AD%A6%E5%91%8A"">、警告</a> [けいこく] warning."	To<strong> ADMONISH</strong> is to simply <em>say&amp; a lot of </em>awe*ful words (excuse the liberties taken with spelling).		
計		plot	<i>Words</i> and a meter's <i>needle</i> combine to form the sense of <b>plot</b>: to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action.		9	359	337	15	ケイ	はか.る、はか.らう	A<strong> plot</strong> is a summary of a book that can be given in <em>ten</em> <em>words</em>.	<em>Say-ten</em>'s (satan's) evil<strong> plot</strong>.	"This does NOT mean a ""summary of a book."" It means plan, project, or to measure. STORY: A TEN WORD PLAN is a very efficient PLAN."	It took only the <em>words</em> of <em>ten</em> men to<strong> plot</strong> the downfall of Caesar.	"I have only <em>ten words</em> to say about this kanji: ""Remember, remember the fifth of November, gunpowder treason and<strong> plot</strong>""."		
詮		elucidate	Think of <b>elucidating</b> as presenting something in <i>whole words</i>, as distinct from broken fragmented sentences.		13	360	2717	15	セン	せん.ずる、かい、あき.らか	<em>Words</em> that tell you the results of the <em>whole</em> story really<strong> elucidate</strong>.	<strong>Elucidate</strong> me. Tell me, in your own <em>words</em>, the <em>whole</em> story.	"Imagine a grumpy old guy wishing those darn kids would <strong>elucidate</strong> their texting <strong>discussions</strong> on their <em>cellphones</em> by writing in <em>whole</em> <em>words</em>. Of course, the kids don't even know what ""<strong>elucidate</strong>"" means…"	The <em>whole words</em> of the trendy name of the new Chinese dating service,<strong> elucidate</strong>.com, are 'electronic lucky dating service company'.	<em>Saying</em> the <em>whole</em> thing should<strong> elucidate</strong> it for me…		
獄		prison	Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for <i>dog</i> is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with <i>dogs</i>. The <b>prison</b> here depicts a <i>pack of wild dogs</i> (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little c<i>hihuahua</i> (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened <i>words</i>.		14	361	338	15	ゴク		The wild dog family visits their cousin in<strong> prison</strong>. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.	The only thing keeping the new <em>chihuahua</em> inmate from being 'initiated' by the <em>pack of wild dogs</em> were his quick <em>words</em> in <strong>prison</strong>.	<strong>Prison</strong> is a dog-say-dog world.	"<strong>PRISON</strong> is a place where WILD DOGS SAY ""DOG!!"" to eachother and fight like animals."	Where men talk like beasts and fight like dogs.		
訂		revise	"After completing the first draft, you <b>revise</b> it by <i>nailing</i> down your <i>words</i> and ""hammering"" them into shape."		9	362	339	15	テイ		<strong>Revise</strong>,<strong> revise</strong> and<strong> revise</strong> until you have all the words nailed down.	Remember how Martin Luther <strong>revised</strong> the <em>words</em> of the catholic church and <em>nailed</em> his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?	The signmaker first carves all of his <em>words</em>. He then arranges them. But he will only <em>nail</em> them into place (thus making them final) when he has had the chance to sufficiently<strong> revise</strong> the message.	You must<strong> revise</strong> your speech until you've <em>nail</em>ed it.	Keep <strong>revising</strong> your words until you have what you want to <em>say</em> really <em>nailed</em> down.		
訃		obituary	The <i>words</i> of this <b>obituary</b> work like a <i>magic wand</i>, conjuring up the desceased.		9	363	3010	15	フ	しらせ	<strong>Obituary</strong>. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the <em>words</em> of his <strong>obituary</strong> until a magician, with a wave of his <em>wand</em>, restored the man back to health.	In the Harry Potter world,<strong> obituary</strong>'s are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!	<strong>obituary</strong>: Harry Potter's<strong> obituary</strong> was just a few <em>words</em> long: 'Guy who killed Voldemort'. He was buried with his favourite <em>magic wand</em> that he used to perform all of his <em>augury</em>.	If you know how people <em>talked</em> about someone before his death, and then read the <em>words</em> in his <strong>obituary</strong>, it seems as if by means of a <em>magic wand</em> their opinion of this person has changed over night.	Harry Potter can bring people back from the dead by reading the <em>words</em> on an <strong>obituary</strong> while waving his <em>magic wand</em> ( 訃報 ).		
討		chastise	<i>Words</i> spoken to <b>chastise</b> us stick to us like <i>glue</i> in a way no other <i>words</i> can.		10	364	340	15	トウ	う.つ	I said some bad words, and my mother<strong> chastise</strong>d me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!	"In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had <em>words</em> <em>glued</em> to them. A famous example is the ""A"" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, <em>words</em> <em>glued</em> to you are supposed to<strong> chastise</strong> you and prevent further breaches of chastity."	If you<strong> chastise</strong> someone correctly the words will stick like glue.	I said some bad <em>words</em> and my mom <em>glue</em>d my mouth shut to<strong> chastise</strong> me.	Chastising <em>words</em> <em>stick</em> to your mind.		
訓		instruction	"The personalism connoted by the word <b>instruction</b>, as opposed to ""teaching"" or ""discipline,"" suits the picture here of <i>words</i> guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a <i>stream</i>. Even the etymology of the word <b>instruction</b> suggests the sense of ""pouring into""."		10	365	341	15	クン、キン	おし.える、よ.む、くん.ずる	The best type of Japanese<strong> INSTRUCTION</strong> is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the <em>stream</em> of <em>words</em> that surrounds you every day.	Listen carefully to the <em>words</em> of<strong> instruction</strong> before you try swimming in the <em>river</em>.	The best teachers and those we remember most are those that are most patient with us, their WORDS as gentle as a STREAM.	(technical) A <em>stream</em> of <em>words</em> (byte pairs) carries assembly <strong>instructions</strong> that are executed upon reception.	"This is the first half of the kanji combination with <a href=""../v4/129.html"">obey</a> (#129 順). Watch at the person's <em>words</em>, their <strong>instructions</strong>, turn into a <em>stream</em> which then can be put into the subjects head for them to <a href=""../v4/129.html"">obey</a> (#129 順)."		
詔		imperial edict	The <b>imperial edict</b>, spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of <i>words</i> intended to <i>seduce</i> the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently.		12	366	342	15	ショウ	みことのり	"The mnemonic ""words to seduce the masses"" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the<strong> imperial edict</strong> to the masses, thus ""seducing"" the masses."	The emperor did not need an <strong>imperial edict</strong>; his <em>words</em> were more than enough to <em>seduce</em> Anakin to the dark side.	The <em>WORDS</em> of an<strong> IMPERIAL EDICT</strong> are meant to <em>SEDUCE</em> the people and make them obey.	Palpatine's<strong> imperial edict</strong> is a propaganda <em>speech</em> to attempt to <em>seduce</em> the masses to the Dark Side. (If you need extra help to remember the <em>seduce</em> part, think about some sexy photos of Darth Vader being included in it as well. The resulting image should be seared into your mind forever.).	The Patriot Act is the modern day version of an<strong> imperial edict</strong>. It uses a lot of fancy <em>words</em> to <em>seduce</em> people into giving up their freedoms.		
詰		packed	"A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as ""<b>packed</b>."" The character sees the <i>words</i> as sealed tightly inside an <i>aerosol can</i>."		13	367	343	15	キツ、キチ	つ.める、つ.め、-づ.め、つ.まる、つ.む	WORDS of GOOD LUCK are<strong> PACKED</strong> into fortune cookies.	Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of <em>words</em> and <em>aerosol cans</em> and then makes sure the words get tightly<strong> packed</strong> inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!	Words<strong> packed</strong> into an aerosol can: the tool of the graffiti artist.	<em>Sayings</em> of <em>good luck</em> are<strong> packed</strong> into little things like fortune cookies.	"Once the samauri had<strong> packed</strong> his things, his wife would say ""Good Luck""."		
話		tale	"That the <i>words</i> of the <i>tongue</i> should come to mean a <b>tale</b> is clear from the etymology: a <b><i>tale</i></b> is something ""talked,"" not something read from a book."		13	368	344	15	ワ	はな.す、はなし	<strong>Tale</strong>s are always spoken, not written, and because of this, <em>words</em> fly out of your <em>tongue</em>, rather than your pen.	<strong>Tale</strong>s are <em>spoken words</em>, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a <em>thousand mouths</em>.	<strong>Tale</strong>s are words from the tongue.	<strong>Tale</strong>s are Told from Tongues (TTT mnemonic).	Beowulf is an epic<strong> TALE</strong> composed of <em>WORDS</em> in a foreign <em>TONGUE</em>.		
詠		recitation	Listening to the <i>words</i> of poets <b>reciting</b> their poetry is like being transported for a moment into <i>eternity</i> where the rules of everyday life have been suspended.		12	369	345	15	エイ	よ.む、うた.う	If you study some <em>words</em> for a<strong> recitation</strong>, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all <em>eternity</em>.	"Listening to the <em>words</em> in a<strong> recitation</strong> of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an <em>eternity</em> in hell. [<strong>Note:</strong> I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with <a href=""../v4/346.html"">poem</a> (#346 詩) but how can you confuse <em>Vogon poetry</em> with an actual <em>poem</em>? Anyway, it's the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight… Or maybe there's a kanji for <em>Vogon</em> in RTK3?]."	"Don't confuse with <a href=""../v4/346.html"">poem</a> (#346 詩). Focus on the re- part of re-citation: making a citation of <em>words</em> over, and over, and over, and over, and over again, until <em>eternity</em>."	[for catholics only:] During the <strong>recitation</strong> of the holy rosary, the <em>words</em> feel like they will take an <em>eternity</em> to say…it takes soooo long.	For me, the keyword suggests something not as pleasant as in James's Heisig story. In my mind, a<strong> recitation</strong> is when someone reads out loud something that they have read, without the slightest bit of improvisation or impersonation, in a very monotonous, and extremely dull manner. Hence, a<strong> recitation</strong> is a long-winded <em>speech</em> that seems to go on for an <em>eternity</em> (because it's so dull and you're so bored).		
詩		poem	Since silence is treasured so highly at a <i>Buddhist temple</i> the <i>words</i> spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like <b>poems</b>. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept <b>poem</b> and <i>recitation</i> distinct in your mind.		13	370	346	15	シ	うた	A<strong> poem</strong> is a <em>temple</em> of <em>words</em>.	I'm saying this<strong> poem</strong> just for you, I built this temple from dirt and glue.	WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That's why most people will speak using a<strong> poem</strong> if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.	A<strong> poem</strong> isn't made up of <em>words</em> that come from nowhere; they are derived after deep meditation at your local <em>Buddhist Temple</em>!	Reciting a good<strong> poem</strong> is like <em>saying</em> a prayer in the <em>temple</em> of language. 悪魔の詩 (Satanic verses). 英詩 (English poetry). 狂詩 (Kyoushi, Edo era humorous<strong> poem</strong>). 詩を作る (compose a<strong> poem</strong>). 詩才 (poetic genius). 詩想 (poetical imagination). 詩文 (poetry & prose). 詩的正義 (poetic justice).		
語		word	Whereas the character for <i>say</i> focused on the actual talking, that for <b>words</b> stresses the fact that although it is <i>I</i> who <i>say</i> them, the <b>words</b> of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between <i>I</i> and <b>words</b> just by looking at the kanji.		14	371	347	15	ゴ	かた.る、かた.らう	The simplest <strong>word</strong> to <em>say</em> is <em>I</em>.	"Jesus said, ""I am the<strong> WORD</strong>.""."	May I say a<strong> word</strong> about that?	"The rap group, the <em>Five</em> <em>Mouths</em>, always go around <em>saying</em> ""word""."	<em>I</em>, the perceiving subject, need all <em>five senses</em> to learn the <strong>WORDS</strong> and <strong>language</strong> of Japanese…. holistic learning, not just rote memory work!		
読		read	In the age of advertising, most <i>words</i> we <b>read</b> are out to <i>sell</i> some product or point of view.		14	372	348	15	ドク、トク、トウ	よ.む、-よ.み	People will <em>say</em> ( 言 ) almost anything to make a <em>sale</em> ( 売 ); don't believe everything you <strong>read</strong> ( 読 ).	<strong>Read</strong> the WORDS used to SELL things.	Extra! extra!<strong> Read</strong> all about it! words for sale here.	Most of the <em>words</em> that we<strong> read</strong> are meant to <em>sell</em> something.	I'm a freelance journalists, so the <em>words</em> I <em>sell</em> are the words you <strong>read</strong>.		
調		tune	A complete <b>tune</b> is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one <i>lap</i> of the <i>words</i> that go with it.		15	373	349	15	チョウ	しら.べる、しら.べ、ととの.う、ととの.える	To<strong> tune</strong> an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the <em>circumference</em>, until you can clearly hear what's being <em>said</em>.	<em>words </em> + <em> circumference</em> The most catchy <strong>tunes</strong> are <em>words</em> the go round and round the <em>circuference</em> of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.	The <em>words</em> to this catchy<strong> tune</strong> run around the <em>circumference</em> of my head.	"This kanji also means ""to investigate, check up, to search."" STORY: You ever get a<strong> TUNE</strong> stuck in your head that someone was SPEAKING earlier in the day? It runs LAPS around your head and you cannot get relief until you 調べる the song online, download it, and listen t it."	This is the song that never ends, yes it goes on and on my friends! Some people started singing it not knowing what it was, and they'll continue singing it forever just because this is the song that never ends… The words go around in a lap in this<strong> tune</strong>, in case you didn't notice…		
談		discuss	"In almost every attempt to <b>discuss</b> an issue, the fervor of one's convictions comes to the surface and creates an <i>inflammation</i> of <i>words</i> (if you will, the ""cuss"" in <b>discuss</b>)."		15	374	350	15	ダン		Think of an online <strong>discuss</strong>ion group where misunderstanding someone's <em>words</em> leads to <em>flaming</em>. An angry <strong>discuss</strong>ion = <em>inflamed</em> <em>words</em>.	Internet<strong> discuss</strong>ions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!	<strong>Discuss</strong>ing politics on the Internet always leads to heated <em>words</em> and <em>flame</em> wars.	When people<strong> DISCUSS</strong> politics, the things they SAY often shed more HEAT than LIGHT.	I hate to<strong> DISCUSS</strong> religion or politics because people's <em>WORDS</em> always become <em>INFLAMED</em>.		
諾		consent	"The <i>words</i> of the <i>young</i> do not have legal validity unless backed up by ""parental <b>consent</b>."""		15	375	351	15	ダク		The <em>words</em> of the very <em>young</em> are useless without<strong> CONSENT</strong> from their elders.	"Delores might <em>say</em>, ""Yes!"", but she's way too <em>young</em> give any legal <strong>consent</strong>."	<strong>Consent</strong> is <em>words</em> given to the <em>young</em>.	You may get her <strong>consent</strong> if you <em>say</em> romantic things and she is too <em>young</em> to know any better.	Picture a cute loli holding flowers in her right hand, and you want to go over and talk to her, but you need parental<strong> CONSENT</strong> otherwise you will go to jail.		
諭		rebuke	"The stern tone of a <b>rebuke</b> is seen here in the image of <i>words</i> spoken at a <i>meeting</i> of <i>butchers</i> (See frame 307) waving their choppers at one another and ""cutting one another down"" as only <i>butchers</i> can."		16	376	352	15	ユ	さと.す	A PETA activist <em>speaks</em> at a <em>meeting</em> of <em>butchers</em> to<strong> rebuke</strong> them.	I imagine <em>Socrates</em> gate-crashing a <em>meeting of butchers</em> and REBUKING them: 'You've been killing things again; you have, haven't you?' while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.	I had to SPEAK to the MEETING OF BUTCHERS and<strong> REBUKE</strong> them for mad cow disease, e-coli, and the bird flu.	To<strong> rebuke</strong> is to take what someone <em>says</em>, and <em>butcher</em> it.	諭す 【さとす】 (v5s,vt) to admonish; to persuade; to warn; to remonstrate; (P) STORY: Be careful what you SAY at the BUTCHERS MEETING because they only give you one WARNING and then you become part of a hot dog.		
式		style	"Take <b>style</b> in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element <i>arrow</i> and <i>craft</i> stand for the well-known <b>style</b> of shirts known as ""<i>Arrow</i> shirts"" because of the little <i>arrow</i> sewn on each one."		6	377	353	16	シキ		Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain<strong> style</strong>..	The latest<strong> style</strong> is shirts crafted out of arrows.	To say someone has<strong> STYLE</strong> is to say they <em>craft</em> their image as sharp as an <em>arrow</em> .	Legolas mastered the CRAFT of shooting ARROWS, so shoots with<strong> style</strong>.	When you've <em>crafted</em> your look to be as sharp as an <em>arrow</em>, then you've got<strong> STYLE</strong>, baby ;o) !		
試		test	When a manufacturer produces a new <i>style</i> for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a <b>test</b> on consumers, asking them to <i>speak</i> their opinions frankly about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the kanji was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember.		13	378	354	16	シ	こころ.みる、ため.す	In an essay<strong> test</strong>, you are judged on both your choice of <em>words</em> and your writing <em>style</em>.	The Japanese oral exam was a <strong>test</strong> of my <em>speaking</em> <em>style</em>.	Think about rap: the real<strong> test</strong> is if the <em>words</em> are as good as the <em>style</em>.	"Tip: This kanji and a few others have keywords whose meanings overlap in English which may be confusing - <a href=""../v4/354.html"">test</a> (#354 試) 試 :<strong> test</strong> (the water), try (and see), <a href=""../v4/1278.html"">exam</a> (#1278 校) 校 : examine (text), <a href=""../v4/1673.html"">examination</a> (#1673 検) 検 : examine, inspect (not a school exam or<strong> test</strong>), <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1724"">check-up</a> (#1724 診) 診 : (medical) check-up, <a href=""../v4/1980.html"">verification</a> (#1980 験) 験 : examination, experiment (similar to 試 ) ."	Your <em>speaking style</em> is NOT<strong> test</strong>ed on the JLPT (the JLPT is a little more concrete as a<strong> test</strong> for me).		
弐		II (two)	We use the Roman numeral II here to stress that this kanji is an older form of the kanji for <i>two</i>. Think of <i>two</i> arrows in a <i>quiver</i>, standing up like the numeral II.		6	379	355	16	ニ、ジ	ふた.つ、そえ	<strong>II</strong> (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).	Once you have <em>two</em> old arrows left in your <em>quiver</em>, you better start running…!	<strong>II</strong>: To remember this Roman numeral, give each soldier <em>I quiver</em> and<strong> II</strong> <em>arrows</em>.	"For some reason i'm using the kanji for I to remember the<strong> II</strong> kanji. Its just Arrow + single stroke under the arms, there is no 'quiver' stroke, why? because you dont need a quiver to hold ONE arrow. As a result of the above explanation for the old kanji for ONE (which is never used) you need a QUIVER to hold 2 Arrows. <a href=""http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BC%8C"">http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BC%8C</a> Thats the character for the old I incase you cant picture what im saying."	<strong>II</strong> Roman soldiers carry <em>two</em> <em>quivers.</em>.		
域		range	From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a <b>range</b> has also come to mean a grazing <i>land</i> where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming <i>fiesta</i> like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the <b>range</b>, the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the <i>mouth</i> on the <i>floor</i>), and then get on with the <i>fiesta</i>.		11	380	356	16	イキ		An astronaut lands back at the launch<strong> range</strong>, kisses the <em>earth</em> beneath him with his <em>mouth</em>, then heads off to a <em>fiesta</em> to celebrate a safe flight.	"Instead of Heisig's ""Fiesta"" I use ""Spear"". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域 ,<strong> range</strong> actually means<strong> range</strong> as in limits/boundary/border sort of<strong> range</strong>(In a box it was the old meaning for Country 國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the<strong> RANGE</strong> of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear's have<strong> range</strong>)."	When the <em>land</em> was within <strong>range</strong>, the pirates <em>kissed the deck</em> and had a <em>fiesta</em>.	Dora and her party must travel over the<strong> range</strong> of earth, find the mouth of a cave on the ground, and then enter within to get to the fiesta. Remember: Land, Mouth on the ground, Fiesta!	Dirty mexicans like to kiss the floor at the fiestas on the<strong> range</strong>.		
賊		burglar	From a <b>burglar's</b> point of view, a <i>fiesta</i> is an occasion to takeout the old lock picking <i>needle</i> and break into the unattended safe filled with the family <i>shells</i> (the old form of money, as we saw in frames 84 and 206).		13	381	357	16	ゾク		<strong>Burglar</strong>s… those guys!!!<strong> Burglar</strong>s only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!	After the <em>fiesta</em>, we found out that some<strong> burglar</strong> had stolen our <em>money</em>, probably breaking in with a lockpick <em>needle</em>…	The<strong> burglar</strong> tried to steal my <em>money</em> by using a lockpicking <em>needle</em>, so I impaled him to the wall with my <em>spear</em>.	I had trouble remembering if this was during a <em>fiesta</em> or a <em>parade</em> / <em>march</em> - so I've pictured the<strong> burglar</strong> escaping from the scene of the crime in a clapped-out old Ford <em>Fiesta</em>.	The<strong> BURGLAR</strong> tried to steal my <em>CLAMS</em> so I impaled him with <em>TEN SPEARS</em>.		
栽		plantation	On a fruit <b>plantation</b> it is the <i>trees</i> that one is particularly grateful for at the time of <i>Thanksgiving</i>. Imagine yourself inviting a few representative <i>trees</i> from the fields and orchards to join you around the table to give thanks.		10	382	358	16	サイ		The<strong> plantation</strong> is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.	During <em>Thanksgiving</em>, all the <em>trees</em> on the <strong>plantation</strong> celebrate the harvest. It's a good time for them, too.	During the <em>harvest festival</em>, all the <em>trees</em> on the <strong>plantation</strong> celebrate what a good job they did producing fruit.	All <em>ten trees</em> at the<strong> plantation</strong> rebelled and destroyed their human owners. They then had a <em>festive</em> celebration for their new found freedom.	On Thanksgiving day Kunta Kinte tied to a tree being slapped because he tried to flee from the<strong> plantation</strong> while the master was distracted with dinner.		
載		load	One <b>loads</b> bales on a wagon or <i>cart</i> in preparation for the great Hay Ride that follows the <i>Thanksgiving</i> dinner each year.		13	383	359	16	サイ	の.せる、の.る	After eating a big <em>Thanksgiving</em> dinner, you have to be careful in the <em>car</em> ride home not to drop a<strong> load</strong> in your pants.	After 'Thanksgiving' dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my 'load' and 'soiled' the 'car'. But it was<strong> LOAD</strong>S of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :).	<strong>Load</strong> the crops into the <em>wagon</em> in preparation for the <em>harvest festival</em>.	Every November I<strong> load</strong> my car with turkey, ham, sweet potatoes, dressing, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, gravy, corn, rolls. There's so much food, it sticks out the windows. I drive to my family's house for–that's right–a Thanksgiving dinner feast!	Imagine a <em>thanksgiving</em> dinner where a <em>car</em> is<strong> load</strong>ed onto the table instead of turkey.		
茂		overgrown	The sense of the key word <b>overgrown</b> is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole <i>parade</i> of weeds (outcast <i>flowers</i>). By way of exception, the <i>flowers</i> take their normal place over the enclosure.		8	384	360	16	モ	しげ.る	The <em>gay parade</em> looks astonishing, as if<strong> overgrown</strong> with <em>flowers</em>.	When your garden gets<strong> OVERGROWN</strong>, it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!	At the flower parade, (hippies' parade) all I can see is walking masses of<strong> overgrown</strong> hair!	It's important that the word<strong> overgrown</strong> leads to the elements, rather than have the elements lead to<strong> overgrown</strong> as I see too often in the other examples. So I turned one of the other stories around. STORY:<strong> OVERGROWN</strong> hair appears the most in a <em>FLOWER</em> power <em>PARADE</em> (of the hippies in the late 60's).	I use <em>scythe</em> as a primitive instead of <em>parade</em>. A <em>scythe</em> is like a <em>spear</em> (see [356]) whose tip has been bent to use for scything. When <em>flowers</em> have<strong> overgrown</strong> your front yard, use a <em>scythe</em> to cut them!		
戚		relatives	If you think of a <i>parade</i> of particularly disagreeable <b>relatives</b>, it should not be hard to imagine them as large bodies with <i>little</i> pea-brains <i>above</i>.		11	385	2882	16	ソク、セキ	いた.む、うれ.える、みうち	"Your <em>half-uncle</em> is leading a <em>parade</em> of your<strong> relatives</strong>. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of ""uncle"" 叔 , so I've called it ""half-uncle"".)."	"(Using the RTK1 supplement so I haven't had ""uncle"" yet.) When you take visiting<strong> relatives</strong> to a <em>parade</em>, hold the <em>little</em> ones <em>up above</em> so they can see over the crowd."	Your <em>uncle</em> organizes a <em>parade</em> of all your<strong> relatives</strong>, which he himself is only half in because he's busy taking pictures of it.	All my<strong> relatives</strong> seems to be here .They even organized a PARADE for me .Wait a minute : my UNCLE isn't here! oh I got it , I just noticed where he is but he has been forbid to scratch his crotch as usual and so I had trouble to recognize him ;.	People carry their <em>small</em><strong> relatives</strong> <em>above</em> their shoulders so they can see the parade.		
成		turn into	"Let the phrase ""<b>turn into</b>"" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the <i>parade</i> marching down main street <b>turns into</b> a <i>dagger</i>-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change."		6	386	361	16	セイ、ジョウ	な.る、な.す、-な.す	It only takes a single stroke of a <em>dagger</em> for a <em>parade</em> to<strong> TURN INTO</strong> a bloodbath.	The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.	The peaceful protest parade turned into an ugly riot when some idiot pulled out a knife and started to threaten the police.	"Let us beat swords into plowshares and <strong>turn</strong> <em>daggers</em> <strong>into</strong> <em>scythes</em>. (see my story for <a href=""../v4/360.html"">overgrown</a> (#360 茂))."	The glorious socialist <em>parade</em> <strong>turns into</strong> a <em>knife</em> fight between Fidel and Raul Castro after they both give 3-hour speeches.		
城		castle	In this frame, we see a mound of <i>dirt</i> that is being <i>turned into</i> a <b>castle</b> (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach).		9	387	362	16	ジョウ	しろ	"The sand <strong>castle</strong> is just the <a href=""../v4/150.html"">soil</a> (#150 土) that <em>turns into</em> a <strong>castle</strong>."	"""Someday this mound of <em>dirt</em> here will <em>turn into</em> our<strong> CASTLE</strong>"", the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill."	Sand sculptors can <em>turn</em> even the most ordinary <em>soil</em> <em>into</em> the most beautiful<strong> castle</strong>s.	A <strong>castle</strong> is just <em>land</em> that has been <em>turned into</em> something else: stone walls, a keep, armouries, barracks, etc. 城下 (じょうか) : land near the<strong> castle</strong>; 城 (しろ) :<strong> castle</strong>.	A<strong> castle</strong> is built on the ground where a parade was turned into a bloodbath.		
誠		sincerity	The sure sign of <b>sincerity</b> is that one's mere <i>words</i> are <i>turned into</i> deeds.		13	388	363	16	セイ	まこと	<strong>Sincerity</strong> happens when what you <em>say</em> actually <em>turns into</em> something.	<strong>Sincerity</strong> is <em>turn</em>ing your <em>word</em>s into actions.	<em>Words</em> <em>turning into</em> actions is a sign of true <strong>sincerity</strong> . You do what you say (せい) you will. Marco and (まこと) his Brazilian friends need to learn this - they say they won't smoke pot inside anymore, but still do it – that's not being very <strong>sincere</strong>.	When your <em>words</em> <em>turn into</em> something of true meaning, that is<strong> sincerity</strong>. [Not sure why this was reported twice… 'words' is perfectly OK here….].	"Socrates said "" If said with<strong> sincerity</strong>, words can turn in to anything"". Very similar to ""castle"", #362."

滅		destroy	Picture a <i>march</i> of <i>flames</i> demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to <b>destroy</b>, but being doused with <i>water</i> by the police riot squads.		13	390	365	16	メツ	ほろ.びる、ほろ.ぶ、ほろ.ぼす	Water flows down to<strong> destroy</strong> the march of fire. Lord of the Rings: Orcs, all carrying <em>torches</em> (in the night, for visuals) and intent on <em>destroying</em> everything in their path, are utterly<strong> destroy</strong>ed by the releasing of the waters (by the Ents). 減		dwindle	A group of unquenchable <i>mouths</i> sets out on a <i>march</i> across the country, drinking <i>water</i> wherever they find it until the <i>water</i> supply has <b>dwindled</b> to a trickle, triggering a national disaster.		12	391	366	16	ゲン	へ.る、へ.らす	When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to<strong> DWINDLE</strong>.	When water supplies<strong> dwindle</strong>d, the population became a horde of dry <em>mouths</em>, <em>marching</em> to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.	When <em>water</em> supplies<strong> dwindle</strong>d, <em>one</em> <em>mouth</em> raised a cry and led a <em>march</em> on the city! 蔑		revile	The verbal abuse involved in <b>reviling</b> those who do not deserve it can be compared to a <i>march of flowers</i> in full boom having an <i>eyeball</i> of nastiness cast over them (literally, of course).		14	392	2390	16	ベツ	ないがしろ、なみ.する、くらい、さげす.む	They gays were <strong>reviled</strong> by society, so they put <em>flowers</em> above their <em>eyes</em> and <em>marched</em> around.	"Note: Whether you see a ""drop"" or a ""one"" in the bottom left of 蔑 depends on the font your computer is using at the time. Newer fonts prefer the ""one""."	The <em>gay pride parade</em> (flowers + march) was going smoothly until it caught the <em>eye</em> of the religious right, who<strong> revile</strong>d the demonstration so much that they tried to interrupt it.	Flower, eye, march: After the Trojans had defeated the cyclops, they planted <em>flowers</em> in his only <em>eye</em> (blinding him) and then <em>marched</em> him back to Troy to be marched around and <strong>reviled</strong> by the citizens.	In Northern Ireland, bitter religious groups<strong> revile</strong> their opponents by <em>marching</em> defiantly under their very <em>eye</em>, holding <em>flowers</em> that symbolize their beliefs.		
桟		scaffold	Prior to the use of metal, <i>trees</i> were once cut down and bound together for use as <b>scaffolding</b> material. In the case of this kanji, what is being constructed is not a skyscraper but a simple <i>float</i>.		10	393	367	16	サン、セン	かけはし	"Japanese festival <em>floats</em> are often so tall they need <em>wood</em> <strong>scaffolds</strong> to be completed. (<a href=""http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html"">http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html</a>)."	You need a<strong> SCAFFOLD</strong> made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.	"HINT: Near as I can tell from the Zhongwen site, the figure that Heisig designates as a ""float"", actually means ""lances broken into pieces"" (though there's a third stroke in the Japanese version of the kanji rather than two in the Chinese), thus I'm using <em>broken into pieces</em> to identify that particular pictograph. STORY: A<strong> scaffold</strong> is made of <em>WOOD BROKEN INTO PIECES</em>."	Not using Heisigs float. im extending the meaning of my Spear (see previous kanji).Think a VERY LONG SPEAR/TRIDENT (Trident as this is like an ARROW with 3 spikes) or, a LONG SPEAR because its just a SPEAR with TWO extra arrow lengths. STORY:<strong> SCAFFOLD</strong>s' are made of VERY LONG SPEARS's as tall as TREES that allow us to build huge structures.Tridents allow TRIPLE interlocking between each other, making their use in<strong> SCAFFOLD</strong>S good enough to be able to build structures as strong and naturally perfect as TREES.	A<strong> scaffold</strong> is where you hang witches. In order to know whether they're witches or not, you put them on a scale to see whether they whether they weigh more than <strong>wood</strong>, a duck, or other things that <strong>float</strong>, like very small rocks. (Monty Python: Search for the Holy Grail).

止		stop	The character for <b>stop</b> is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.	* Although the meaning of <i>stop</i> will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of <i>footprint</i>.	4	396	370	17	シ	と.まる、-ど.まり、と.める、-と.める、-ど.め、とど.める、とど.め、とど.まる、や.める、や.む、-や.む、よ.す、-さ.す、-さ.し	If you find in the <em>ground</em> a <em>walking stick</em> with a <em>magic wand</em>,<strong> STOP</strong>! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.	This looks like a little police officer sticking his hand out (first two strokes) signaling for cars to<strong> stop</strong> as a schoolboy/girl is following behind (third stroke). The final stroke is the road.	If you don't remember this one from the 10,000,000<strong> STOP</strong> signs on roads all over Japan, you're beyyond help!	<strong>STOP</strong>! I put my foot down.	"Gandalf took his <em>magic wand</em>, which looked like an old <em>walking stick</em>, and stuck it in the <em>ground</em>, before bellowing, ""<strong> STOP</strong>! YOU SHALL NOT PASS!""."		
歩		walk	<i>Footprints</i> that follow one another a <i>few</i> at a time indicate <b>walking</b>.		8	397	371	17	ホ、ブ、フ	ある.く、あゆ.む	When<strong> walk</strong>ing your pet, you must <em>stop </em>a<em> few</em> times along the way when nature calls.	When you learn to<strong> walk</strong>, you take your <em>steps</em> a <em>few</em> at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every <em>few</em> <em>steps</em> but keeps getting up to try again.	When you take a<strong> walk</strong> you should <em>stop</em> a <em>few</em> times to smell the roses.	When you<strong> walk</strong> you leave a <em>few</em> <em>footprints</em>.. not as many as when you run.	To <strong>walk</strong> is to <em>stop</em> a <em>little</em> now and then while going somewhere. (not exactly true, but that made it stick for me!).

肯		agreement	Seeing <i>footprints</i> on someone's <i>flesh</i> indicates a rather brutal way of having secured that person's <b>agreement</b>.		8	400	374	17	コウ	がえんじ.る	A secret<strong> agreement</strong> between a covert gov't agency and aliens states that we will not step <em>foot</em> on the <em>moon</em> again in return for alien technology. 企		undertake	To <b>undertake</b> a project is to take some idea floating in the air and <i>stop</i> it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality.
