歴		curriculum	That same <i>grove of trees</i> we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for <b>curriculum</b> (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the <b>curriculum</b> vitae). Instead of the <i>grove</i> making its way slowly through the surface of the <i>cliff</i> as before, here we see it <i>stopped</i>, much the same as a <b>curriculum</b> vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past.		14	402	376	17	レキ、レッキ		A<strong> CURRICULUM</strong> is a <em>calendar</em> that replaces days with reasons to <em>stop</em> having fun.	A little like a <em>calendar</em>, your <strong>CV</strong> records your <em>footsteps</em> through time.	"A<strong> curriculum</strong> (vitae) is similar to a <em>calendar</em> except that, instead of mentioning every <em>day</em> in your life, it only mentions the main <em>stop</em>s. (Compare <a href=""../v4/213.html"">calendar</a> (#213 暦))."	Stop underneath a grove of trees by the cliffs to sit down and write your CV.	When the school<strong> CURRICULUM</strong> started covering TREES that grow in cliffs, I decided to STOP attending.		
武		warrior	With a <i>quiver</i> of <i>arrows</i> set on one's back, the goal of the <b>warrior</b> depicted here is not to attack but merely to <i>stop</i> the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history!		8	403	377	17	ブ、ム	たけ.し	ONE-ARROW can STOP a<strong> warrior</strong>.	A great<strong> warrior</strong> can <em>stop</em> any 0pponent with <em>one arrow</em>.	The traditional<strong> warrior</strong> carries a quiver of ARROWS. But the<strong> warrior</strong> must never forget his real purpose: to STOP conflict, not cause it.	"Remember the story of ""Achilles the<strong> Warrior</strong>,"" who was put down by <em>one</em> <em>arrow</em> (the drop in the quiver) among many <em>quivers</em> which hit just above his <em>foot</em>."	<em>Lord of the Rings:</em> It took a <em>quiver</em> of arrows to <em>stop</em> the <strong>warrior</strong> Boromir in Fellowship of the Ring.		
賦		levy	A certain portion of <i>shells</i> (money) is collected by the <i>warrior</i> from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a <b>levy</b>.		15	404	378	17	フ、ブ		A <em>warrior</em> stands guard at a bridge collecting <em>shells</em> as a <strong>levy</strong> for any who want to pass.	"""Drove my Chevy to the<strong> levy</strong> but the<strong> levy</strong> was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you'll die. Pay up the clams or you'll die…""."	A<strong> levy</strong> is <em>money</em> collected to fund kingdom's <em>warriors</em>.	"""Gimme some <em>clams</em>"" said the <em>warrior,</em> collecting his <strong>levy.</strong>."	Bush always used the excuse that the <em>money</em> from the Iraq<strong> levy</strong> was to support America's <em>warriors</em> overseas.		
正		correct	"""A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step,"" says the Chinese proverb. Here we see <i>one footprint</i>, complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made <b>correctly</b>, the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in <b>correcting</b> their students, and parents in <b>correcting</b> their children."		5	405	379	17	セイ、ショウ	ただ.しい、ただ.す、まさ、まさ.に	If you do it<strong> correct</strong> on the <em>first</em> attempt you can <em>stop</em>.	My (Japanese) wife tells me that Japanese people use this kanji to tally up numbers (instead of 4 vertical lines and a diagonal across). I remember this one by writing the kanji while counting out the strokes to myself and saying this is the<strong> correct</strong> way to tally numbers.	The<strong> correct</strong> way of learning Japanese? <em>First</em>, <em>stop</em> everything you're doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig's book and work from there.	The<strong> correct</strong> way to tackle any problem is <em>one</em> <em>step</em> at a time.	You want a<strong> correct</strong> answer in one stop? Google is your friend…		
証		evidence	"<i>Words</i> that testify to the <i>correctness</i> of some fact are classified as <b>evidence</b>. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the ""strong"" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.)"		12	406	380	17	ショウ	あかし	Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as<strong> evidence</strong>.	"""If what you <em>say</em> is indeed <em>correct</em>, we could use use your testimony as<strong> evidence</strong>""."	The<strong> evidence</strong> you find at the crime scene is misspelled WORDS scrawled everywhere– think of Se7en. But you can't resist, and you have to CORRECT their spelling.	<strong>Evidence</strong> proves that your words are correct.	"<strong>Evidence</strong> proves that what you <a href=""../v4/335.html"">say</a> (#335 言) is <a href=""../v4/379.html"">correct</a> (#379 正)."		
政		politics	To the many definitions for <b>politics</b> that already exist, this character offers yet another: <i>correct taskmastering</i>. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that <b>politics</b> has to do with <i>taskmastering</i>, maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed <i>correctly</i> if only the right candidate is given a chance.		9	407	381	17	セイ、ショウ	まつりごと、まん	Those involved in<strong> politics</strong> are always trying to elect the <em>correct</em> <em>taskmaster</em>.	Insane political <em>correctness</em> on the left, and facists <em>taskmasters</em> on the right- thats<strong> politics</strong> in a nutshell right there.	The Left is careful to be politically correct in speech. The Right whips people into a frenzy of outrage!	Insane political <em>correctness</em> on the left, and a fascist <em>Hitler</em> on the right – thats<strong> politics</strong> in a nutshell right there.	"I like immacolata's ""chief whip"" (helps if you are British!) as <em>taskmaster</em>. But let us not forget <strong>policital</strong> <em>correct</em>ness. The <em>taskmaster</em> (chief whip) is there to see that party members observe <strong>political</strong> <em>correct</em>ness at all times, especially in a socialist party, <em>correct</em>ness is on the left!"		
定		determine	<b>Determination</b>, in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to <i>mending</i> one's <i>house</i>.		8	408	382	17	テイ、ジョウ	さだ.める、さだ.まる、さだ.か	In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.	Prior to buying a home, the <em>home</em> inspector will come into your house and<strong> determine</strong> everything that needs <em>mending</em>.	"People who decide to renovate (ooh, that's a fancy word, let's say <em>""mend""</em>) their <em>houses</em> must be very<strong> determine</strong>d DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see<strong> DEtermine</strong>)."	"定める 【さだめる】 (v1,vt) to decide; to establish; to<strong> determine</strong>; (P)The primitive ""mend"" is too arbitrary and I can never remember it. New primitive meaning: CORRECT PERSON: Do you see the 4th and 5th stroke? They look like the kanji for ""person."" Therefore, CORRECT + PERSON = CORRECT PERSON. STORY: I DECIDED/DETERMINED I would fix my HOUSE this summer but am still looking for the CORRECT PERSON to do it (i.e. a contractor)."	"The Determinator Arnold Schwarzenegger has <strong>determined</strong> to get out the ladder and the tools and start <em>mending</em> the <em>roof.</em> ""I'll be back - after mending the roof,"" he utters dramatically."		
錠		lock	<i>Metal</i> of itself doesn't <b>lock</b>. It needs to be so <i>determined</i> by a <b>lock</b>smith. Now make a concrete image of that.		16	409	383	17	ジョウ		Even if you<strong> lock</strong> up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.	The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let's try this one: My girlfriend wears a <em>metal</em> chastity belt with a <strong>lock</strong> but I am <em>determined</em> to open it! I must get inside!	A<strong> LOCK</strong> is <em>metal</em> that is <em>determined</em> to keep intruders out.	A<strong> lock</strong> is a piece of <em>metal</em> that will <em>determine</em> who can or can't get in.	A METAL<strong> LOCK</strong> DETERMINES who can get in.		
走		run	<b>Running</b>, we are told here, <i>mends</i> the <i>soil</i>. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for <i>road</i> does; and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened.		7	410	384	17	ソウ	はし.る	Hint: This kanji is NOT <em>soil</em> on top of <em>mend</em>, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is <em>10</em> on top of <em>mend</em>. So my story is: If you<strong> run</strong> <em>10</em> miles, you will need to <em>mend</em> your socks!	The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been<strong> RUN</strong>NING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.	The <em>soil</em> needs <em>mending</em> after the cross-country<strong> run</strong>.	If you<strong> run</strong> <em>10</em> miles you'll need to <em>mend</em> your socks.	With ten things to mend, you've got to<strong> run</strong> to get it all done.		
超		transcend	When one is <i>running</i> after something, the goal that <i>seduces</i> one is said to <b>transcend</b> the seeker.		12	411	385	17	チョウ	こ.える、こ.す	A successful marathon runner needs to be able to<strong> transcend</strong> seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.	To<strong> transcend</strong> to a higher path you need to <em>run</em> from the <em>seduction</em> of earthly desires.	To<strong> transcend</strong> oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to<strong> transcend</strong> his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and….	Pamela Anderson was able to<strong> transcend</strong> the Television world and become a superstar after her years of <em>seductive running</em> on the beaches of Baywatch.	To<strong> transcend</strong> life you must run from anything that seduces you.		
赴		proceed	In <b>proceeding</b> to a new city or a new job, something in you <i>runs</i> ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a <i>divining rod</i> built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly.		9	412	386	17	フ	おもむ.く	"""Don't <em>run</em> into trouble,"" Dumbledore tells Harry. ""<strong>Proceed</strong> with caution with your <em>wand</em> out.""."	"You go through airport security. ""Proceed,"" mumbles the guard after he wands you. You run like crazy, because you're late for your flight."	While running, my magic wand tells me where to<strong> proceed</strong>.	I've got to run and take a piss before<strong> proceed</strong>ing.	In a relay race, the baton (<em>wand</em>) must<strong> proceed</strong> from one <em>runner</em> to the next.		
越		surpass	"Here we see two <i>parades</i> in competition, each trying to <b>surpass</b> the other by <i>running</i> at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little ""hook"" at the end of the first stroke of the element for <i>parade</i>. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book."		12	413	387	17	エツ、オツ	こ.す、-こ.す、-ご.し、こ.える、-ご.え	The person in charge of <em>running</em> the <em>parade</em><strong> surpass</strong>ed all our expectations (by just a extra drop…).	The <em>parade</em> of <em>runners</em> are all trying to<strong> SURPASS</strong> each other - and they end up running all the way to <em>Vietnam</em> (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).	A RUNNER will always<strong> SURPASS</strong> a PARADE.	"This kanji is read the same way as # 385 ""transcend."" The difference is that this kanji talks about<strong> surpass</strong>ing or crossing over a mountain (or the like) while 385 is used when<strong> surpass</strong>ing or transcending a amount of money, an expectation, etc. STORY: Some punk kids dared one of their friends to PASS/SURPASS the PARADE. So the kid got a RUNNING start but slipped on a DROP of something and landed face first in front of the PARADE ruining it."	"To make the marathon more challenging for the runners, they made them try to out-<a href=""../v4/384.html"">run</a> (#384 走) a parade going down the same path. The runners must come out before the parade, and<strong> SURPASS</strong> it, to win a shopping spree at Mitsukoshi or a trip to Vietnam. Oddly, this is a kanji in Mitsukoshi Dept store ( 三越 ) and Vietnam ( 越 )."		
是		just so	"In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire <i>day</i> at <i>mending</i> one stocking, because they want the job done ""<b>just so</b>."" Be sure to make a clear image of a finicky old fusspot to make the abstract idea as concrete as possible."		9	414	388	17	ゼ、シ	これ、この、ここ	'Sun' 'Mend' - It<strong> just so</strong> happens that <em>sun</em>shine can <em>mend</em> your gloomy spirits.	My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all <em>day</em> obsessively <em>mending</em> the code so this page looks <strong>just so…</strong>.	I spent all <em>day</em> <em>mending</em> to make things<strong> just so</strong>.	It takes me aaaaallll flipping day to mend these stories so they're<strong> just so</strong>!	是 【ぜ】 (n) righteousness; justice; right. 是か非か 【ぜかひか】 (exp) right or wrong; 是非 【ぜひ】 (adv,n) (1) (uk) certainly; without fail; (2) right and wrong; pros and cons; (P) STORY: See 382: Only someone who practices RIGHTEOUSNESS and JUSTICE every DAY is the CORRECT PERSON for Presidential position.		
題		topic	In many kinds of research, one can find information on a given <b>topic</b> only if the <i>headings</i> are prepared <i>just so</i>.		18	415	389	17	ダイ		"The ""TOPIC"" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention."	You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The<strong> topic</strong>—FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!	The<strong> TOPIC</strong> is written as the <em>heading</em> of the <em>page just so</em> readers know what the article is about.	This<strong> topic</strong> is just so boring turn the page…!	It <strong>JUST SO</strong> happens that girls giving <strong>HEAD</strong> seems to be the number 1 <strong>TOPIC</strong> of high school gossip.		
堤		dike	A <b>dike</b> is a successful bit of engineering only if the amount of <i>earth</i> piled up is measured <i>just so</i> for the height and pressure of the water it is meant to contain.		12	416	390	17	テイ	つつみ	Making a<strong> dike</strong> is all about arranging the <em>soil just so…</em>.	The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the<strong> dike</strong>, and that's the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in <strong>just so</strong> - there, I think it's good enough. Pull it out —–yes! Success!	Imagine Indiana Jones replacing a gemstone with a small bag of soil. If he doesn't weigh the soil just so, a huge<strong> dike</strong> behind the wall will break, washing him away.	<strong>Dike</strong>s are just so dirty.	The<strong> dike</strong> was very close to breaking. The people worked all <em>day</em> bringing <em>earth/soil</em> to <em>mend</em> it.		
建		build	To construct a <b>building</b>, you first draw a set of plans (the writing <i>brush</i>) and then <i>s-t-r-e-t-c-h </i>your drawing out to scale in reality.		9	417	391	17	ケン、コン	た.てる、た.て、-だ.て、た.つ	<strong>Build</strong> is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in<strong> build</strong>ing. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.	A construction worker's classic morning. <em>Stretch, brush</em> his teeth, and then start to<strong> build</strong>.	To<strong> build</strong> a skyscraper, you have to stretch it upwards until it brushes the sky.	To<strong> build</strong> your Kanji ability, you must <em>brush away</em> the cobwebs from your head and <em>stretch</em> your imagination.	<strong>Building</strong> seen through the architect's eyes: Step 1: draw blueprints with best <em>brush</em> Step 2: <em>stretch</em> out on a lawn chair while other people<strong> build</strong> it!		
鍵		key	"The <i>golden</i> <b>key</b> you have been presented by the mayor gives you access to all the <i style='""font-weight:' bold>buildings</i> in the city."		17	418	2761	17	ケン	かぎ	The <em>metal</em> thing you need in order to enter things you <em>build</em> is a<strong> key</strong>. 延		prolong	This character is a kind of pictographic image of how <b>prolonging</b> is a clever way of <i>stopping</i> things by trying to <i>stretch</i> them out a little bit at a time (the extra <i>drop</i> at the top of <i>stop</i>). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself <b>prolonging</b> something you can really, physically, <i>stretch</i>.		8	419	392	17	エン	の.びる、の.べる、の.べ、の.ばす	<em>Stretch</em>ing <em>correct</em>ly <strong>prolong</strong>s life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching…	If you want to<strong> prolong</strong> your sexual encounters, the best way to <em>stretch</em> them out is to <em>stop</em> your orgasm after just one <em>drop</em> has come out. (with inspiration from gorgon).	"Here's a great mnemonic: ""stop, drop, and stretch (!?)."" Now let's associate it with 'prolong': if you're ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just<strong> PROLONG</strong> the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it'll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!"	The inquisitor<strong> prolong</strong>ed the torture because his victim didn't answer the question <em>correctly</em>. He turned the wheel <em>stretching</em> out his limbs even further.	To<strong> prolong</strong> means to stretch time for a drop (a little while) because you do not want something to stop.		
誕		nativity	The key word of course calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the <b>nativity</b> we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history: it represents the <i>prolongation</i> of the eternal <i>Word</i> in time and space.		15	420	393	17	タン		<strong>Nativity</strong> = born, being born. Think of <strong>birth</strong> as a painful and <em>prolong</em>ed event. And of course, all the <em>words</em> and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!	When you are being born ( <strong>nativity</strong> ), your mother's WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!).	The<strong> nativity</strong> story: A child born to a virgin mother? Sounds to me like the <em>words</em> have <em>stretch</em>ed what is sensibly <em>correct</em>. Sadly, those <em>words</em> have continued to be spread through the <em>prolonged</em> use of the bible.	At<strong> Nativity</strong> (christmas), the priest says more Words (sermon) than the rest of the time, Prolonging mass duration.	誕生日 【たんじょうび】 (n) birthday; (P) 誕生石 【たんじょうせき】 (n) a birthstone STORY: On your BIRTHDAY people say WORDS of good luck and fortune to PROLONG your life.		
礎		cornerstone	"This character depicts a <b>cornerstone</b> as a <i>stone</i> set at the end of a wildlife preserve (the ""<i>zoo</i> in the<i> grove</i>"")."		18	421	394	17	ソ	いしずえ	Features like <em>stones</em> and <em>groves of trees</em> are the<strong> cornerstone</strong>s of a happy <em>zoo</em>.	A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the<strong> cornerstone</strong> has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious <em>mending</em>.).	<em>Stone Grove Zoo</em> is the new<strong> cornerstone</strong> in animal exhibits! If you love animals you need to check out <em>Stone Grove Zoo!</em>.	How am I the only one who doesn't see how mend turned into zoo with one stroke.	To make room for the new <em>zoo</em>, they use dynamite sending all the <em>grove's</em> trees flying in the air. That big <em>stone</em> on the left now serves as<strong> cornerstone</strong>. (Variation on ziggr's story, with more emphasis on placement that was giving me trouble).		
婿		bridegroom	"What makes a man a <b>bridegroom</b> is obviously a <i>woman</i> and her dowry, here presented as a small <i>zoo</i> (animals were often used for this purpose in earlier societies) and a <i>month</i> away from it all (the ""honey<i>moon</i>"")."		12	422	395	17	セイ	むこ	The virgin<strong> bridegroom</strong> tries to understand the new, mysterious <em>part of</em> his <em>woman's body</em> - but with little success. It's a <em>zoo</em> down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is 'down there' - the woman is 'left' unsatisfied).	The only reason anyone talks about a<strong> bridegroom</strong> is if they're about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your <em>woman</em> to the <em>zoo</em> for a <em>month.</em> Pretty cool honeymoon.	Imagine a<strong> bridegroom</strong> having his wedding with his <em>woman</em> in a <em>zoo</em> on the <em>moon.</em> That will impress her! Fill out the details with the bride and groom floating with a menagerie of animals with astronaut helmets floating, bumping and attacking one another.	How did the eccentric<strong> bridegroom</strong> convince the <em>woman</em> to marry him? He built a <em>zoo</em> in the surface of the <em>moon</em> just for her!	The <strong>bridegroom</strong> will take his <em>woman</em> to the <em>zoo</em> for a <em>month</em> long honeymoon. (Simplifying dihutenosa).		
衣		garment	"At the top we see the <i>top hat</i>, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a <b>garment</b>. If you break the ""4-fold"" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember."	"* Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of <i>cloak</i> or <i>scarf</i> will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here. When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean <i>cloak</i>. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the <i>top hat</i>) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a <i>scarf</i>. On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a <i>top hat and scarf</i>. And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of <i>garment</i> in general. Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is ""unhooked."""	6	423	396	18	イ、エ	ころも、きぬ、-ぎ	The only<strong> garment</strong>s allowed in this club are <em>top hat</em> and <em>scarf</em>.	The<strong> garment</strong>s most commonly associated with the <em>craft</em> of a magician are the <em>top hat</em> and the <em>magic wand</em>. (It's a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).	Dr. Who always wore a TOPHAT and SCARF, his most memorable<strong> GARMENT</strong>S.	A TOPHAT and a SCARF form a<strong> GARMENT</strong> that makes you barf.	A snowman wears a <em>top hat</em> and a <em>scarf</em> for <em><strong>garments&lt;/em&gt;</strong>.</em>		
裁		tailor	You might think here of <i>garment</i> that have been specially <b>tailored</b> for <i>Thanksgiving</i> celebrations to look like traditional Pilgrim garb.		12	424	397	18	サイ	た.つ、さば.く	The<strong> tailor</strong> was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best <em>garments</em> for <em>thanksgiving</em>.	The<strong> tailor</strong> worked hard after <em>thanksgiving</em> to alter <em>garments</em> so they'd fit people who'd eaten too much at their <em>thanksgiving</em> dinners.	If you can make ten garments then you qualify as<strong> tailor</strong> and we will have a party to celebrate. Congratulations! You are all invited to the TenGarmentFiesta.	My<strong> TAILOR</strong> made me <em>10 garments</em> for the upcoming <em>fiestas</em>.	The<strong> TAILOR</strong> was invited to THANKSGIVING so he could sew up the turkey after the stuffing was put in. Too bad his GARMENT got dirty during the process. They should have killed the turkey first.		
装		attire	"The character for <b>attire</b> can be remembered as a picture of what we may call a ""<i>turtle-samurai</i>"" sweater. However, it's too difficult for them to find proper <em>garments</em> because they bodies are so <em>robust</em>! The TMNT tried to enter an expensive restaurant wearing nothing - they were told to come back with the appropriate<strong> attire</strong>. Not understanding the word<strong> attire</strong> nor how to wear clothes, they put on some clothes and, instead of buttoning stuff up, they put on <strong>a tire</strong> to hold their clothes up (inspired by synewave's story).		
裏		back	An innocent looking <i>top hat and scarf</i> lying there in front of you, turned over, reveal a hidden <i>computer</i> sewn into the <b>back</b> of each - obviously the tools of a master spy. Such experiences teach one always to have a look at the <b>back</b> side of things.		13	426	399	18	リ	うら	The <em>computer</em> had carefully dressed up in <em>clothes</em> to look human. It was n't until I looked at the<strong> back</strong> and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.	Can computers be gay? I'm not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its<strong> back</strong> door port is always open…	I'll be<strong> back</strong> ! says the <em>computer</em> Terminator, disguised with a <em>top hat and a scarf</em>.	The COMPUTER wore a TOP HAT and SCARF to hide it's cables at the<strong> BACK</strong>. ( 裏 うら　bottom/back/reverse).	I was looking at porn on my <em>computer</em> and my roommate came in the room, so I hit the<strong> back</strong> button on the browser and pretended to be shopping for <em>top hats</em> and <em>scarves</em>.		
壊		demolition	The right half of this character shows a <i>garment</i> woven so fine that it can pass through the <i>eye</i> of a <i>needle</i>, fittingly draped around the slithering, ethereal form of a poltergeist. In this frame, our eerie visitor brushes its robes against a nearby block of apartments and completely <b>demolishes</b> them, razing them to the <i>ground</i>.		16	427	400	18	カイ、エ	こわ.す、こわ.れる、やぶ.る	If you stand too close to a<strong> DEMOLITION</strong> site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.	Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.	During<strong> demolition</strong>, <em>dirt</em> and debris can feel like <em>needles in your eyes</em> if you're not wearing ther proper <em>garments</em>.	The dirt to the left is all that remains of the WTC on 9/11. On the right we have george bush wearing a perfectly clean and expensive suit/garment putting eyedrops in his eye to force an emotion over the victims of 9/11. He has to fake this emotion since 9/11 was a controlled<strong> demolition</strong>.	The<strong> demolition</strong> expert doesn't want DIRT in his 10 EYES, so he covers them with a SCARF.		
哀		pathetic	A drunken sod in a tattered <i>top hat</i> and soiled silk <i>scarf</i> with a giant <i>mouth</i> guzzling something or other gives us a <b>pathetic</b> character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home.		9	428	401	18	アイ	あわ.れ、あわ.れむ、かな.しい	One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a <em>tophat</em> and a <em>scarf</em> so that you can't see his whole face but only his <em>mouth</em>. He thinks it's cool. I think it's<strong> pathetic</strong>.	"A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is<strong> pathetic</strong>– in the original sense of the noun ""pathos."" The tattered <em>tophat and scarf</em> he wears only adds to the pathos."	"Other definitions include grief, sorrow, pathos, pity, and sympathize. IMO the english word<strong> pathetic</strong> is often used nowadays to mean a sort of ""contemptuous pity"" but I think we need a more compasionate definition to understand 哀 , now and especially later when it starts being combined with other words…So, here's the top part of frame 308 享 (receive) but where the child was is now replaced by a scarf. Whatever fate befell the child is up to your imagination. grief, sorrow, pathos, sympathy,<strong> pathetic</strong>."	"That <em>tall</em> guy with the <em>scarf</em> is just so<strong> pathetic</strong>! (I can't help but see ""tall"" when I look at this kanji)."	A hat, a mouth and a cloak, I think that's all that beggar owns. How<strong> pathetic</strong>!		
遠		distant	A <b>distant</b> figure on the <i>road</i> is such a blur it looks like a <i>lidded crock</i> wearing a silk <i>scarf</i>.		13	429	402	18	エン、オン	とお.い	Keep<strong> distant</strong> from a <em>lidded crock</em> on the<em> road</em> wrapped in a <em>scarf</em>. It might be a bomb.	When traveling to a<strong> distant</strong> land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?	(NOTE: I am combining <em>lidded crock</em> and <em>scarf</em> into one NEW PRIMITIVE: <em>picnic</em>. As in, a <em>lidded crock</em> is filled with the food and the <em>scarf</em> is the picnic blanket.) When I'm on the <em>road</em> to <strong>distant</strong> lands and know there will be quite a <strong>distance</strong> between proper <em>road</em>side stops, I'm always extra careful and bring a <em>picnic</em>.	In a game called 'spin the <em>lidded-crock</em>', contestants see how far<strong> distant</strong> they can roll a crock down the <em>road</em> by wrapping it in a <em>scarf</em> and spinning it like a top; the only rule is that the lid must stay on the crock. Picture a referee measuring the distance on the <em>road</em> to see how far<strong> distant</strong> you've spun the crock. 猿		monkey	This clever little <b>monkey</b> has captured an entire pack of <i>wild dogs</i>, locked them inside a <i>lidded crock</i>, and wrapped the whole thing up in a silk <i>scarf</i> to present to the dogcatcher.		13	430	403	18	エン	さる	The<strong> MONKEY</strong> likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.	To catch a <strong>monkey</strong>, chase him with <em>wild dogs</em> into a <em>lidded crock</em>, then tie it with a <em>scarf</em>.	"Honestly, I hate the ""Lidded Crock with a scarf"" metaphor. It makes no sense, and I just can't get an image that ""sticks"" with it, at all. Besides, it sounds retarded. The original meaning of the whole right side of this Kanji is ""Long Kimono."" So, put a wild dog in a kimono, stand him on two legs, and you've got something that looks like a man but still feral - a<strong> monkey</strong>."	We should be starring the 2009– stories, The 2006–2007 stories totally have a monopoly. GIVE THE NEW GUYS A CHANCE! ;) All you new guys star this.	"The upper right part means long kimono. 袁 is not in Heisig list, but if you remember it, you have an easier time later on. ""Long kimono"" is easier than ""lidded crock with scarf."" For its story look at Kanji 34945. Story for 猿 : If you put wild dogs in long kimonos, they look like<strong> monkey</strong> really."

錦		brocade	A strip of <i>white towel</i> and some scraps of <i>metal</i> have the makings of a primitive kind of <b>brocade</b>.		16	439	411	18	キン	にしき	<strong>Brocade</strong> is the art of sewing <em>gold</em> on a <em>white towel</em>. Here it is written as a <em>towel</em> woven with <em>gold</em> and <em>white</em>." I carried my<strong> brocade</strong> to the airport and the GOLD set off the METAL detector! 帯		sash	The part of the <i>apron</i> where one finds the <i>buckle</i> (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the <b>sash</b>.		10	444	415	18	タイ	お.びる、おび	"First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of <em>one</em> and <em>mountain</em>. Of course, the ""<em>number 1</em>"" <em>mountain</em> in Japan is <em>Mt.</em> Fuji. The bottom half, under <em>Mt.</em> Fuji, consists of <em>crown</em> and <em>towel</em>. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under <em>Mt.</em> Fuji (Japan's <em>#1</em> <em>mountain</em>) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it's royal because of the <em>crown</em>) discover what looks like a <em>towel</em>, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal <em>sash</em> for the king's kimono."	WARNING: Try to avoid thinking of the upper element as a combination of <em>one</em> and <em>mountain</em>, because in this case you will get used to the incorrect stroke order.	"Beautiful ""Miss Housewife Japan"" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the <em>number one</em> <em>mountain</em>) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an <em>apron</em> tied with a<strong> sash</strong>. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.)."	"The <em>buckle</em> is on the<strong> sash</strong> of the <em>apron</em>. (Note that according to the dictionary, breaking down this Kanji includes only the radicals for ""walking stick"", ""one"", ""crown"" and ""towel"". Hence, ""mountain"" is not part of the radicals.)."	Heisig fails to go into detail about the top kanji, but, It's not a mountain like everyone is saying. It actually means <em>Thirty</em> 丗 the stroke order starts with a <em>One</em>, then draw in the three vertical lines from left to right. Then the last stroke at the bottom closing it up. Then comes the <em>Apron</em> which makes up a<strong> Sash</strong>. (-Story: I made a<strong> Sash</strong> out of <em>Thirty</em> cut up <em>Aprons</em>.		
滞		stagnate	"People that have been ""<i>sashed</i>"" to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like <i>water</i> that has stopped moving: they start to <b>stagnate</b>."		13	445	416	18	タイ、テイ	とどこお.る	History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean <em>water</em>, so samurai usually had to wash their <em>sashes</em> in <strong>stagnant</strong> puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja???? "WATER that is ""tied up"" as if with a SASH and unable to flow properly will become<strong> stagnate</strong>."	This is one I keep missing, and always because of the right-hand side. From washrag, I will make the association with <em>sash</em>.	The <em>water</em> became<strong> stagnate</strong> because the drain was clogged with a <em>sash</em>.

制		system	This kanji show a unique <b>system</b> for leading <i>cows</i> to the slaughterer's <i>saber</i>: one ties a <i>belt</i> about their waist and fixes that <i>belt</i> to an overhead cable, pulling the <i>cow</i> up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it.		8	447	418	18	セイ		The<strong> system</strong> for making leather <em>belts</em> involves slicing up a <em>cow</em> with a <em>sword</em>. 製		made in... A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have<strong> MADE IN</strong> on the label.	We have a <em>system</em> in the US where all <em>garments</em> have labels saying what country they are <strong>made in</strong>.	You find a curious toy: a <em>cow</em> wearing a <em>belt</em> and a <em>saber</em>, and also <em>clothes</em> under them. You look at it wondering where it was <strong>made in</strong>.		
転		revolve	As the wheels of the <i>car</i> <b>revolve</b>, they kick up small <i>rising clouds</i> of dust and debris behind them.		11	449	420	18	テン	ころ.がる、ころ.げる、ころ.がす、ころ.ぶ、まろ.ぶ、うたた、うつ.る、くる.めく	The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with<strong> REVOLVE</strong>R blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.	"Just a note to remember the <em>cloud</em> primative: The name of Goku's pet <em>cloud</em> that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is <em>Nimbus</em> [ <a href=""http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg"">http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg</a> ]. The katakana-ization of this is <strong>ニム</strong>バス, so the <em>rising cloud</em> primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style."	Burnout! As the car's wheels <em>revolve</em> the rubber burns making a <em>rising cloud</em> of smoke!	You could just think of someone smoking their tires before taking off. They're staying in one place, but the wheels of the car keep revolving round and round as a cloud of burnt rubber rise from them. To keep distinct from rotation (1046), think of rpms (revolutions per minute).	The <em>car</em>'s wheels<strong> revolve</strong>, sending up a <em>rising cloud</em> of dust.		
芸		technique	The secret <b>technique</b> of making a <i>rising cloud</i> of smoke turn into a bouquet of <i>flowers</i> is shown here.		7	450	421	18	ゲイ、ウン	う.える、のり、わざ	"Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: ""Try my <em>rising cloud</em> <em>flower</em><strong> technique</strong>!!!"" <em> smash </em> <em> pow </em> <em> crack!! </em>."	One<strong> technique</strong> to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.	I've mastered a<strong> TECHNIQUE</strong> for making my farts (the <em>cloud</em>) smell like roses (the <em>flower</em>).	David Copperfield throws a bouquet of flowers into the air, whereupon they turn into a rising cloud of smoke. The audience gasps in admiration of his<strong> technique</strong>.	"Think of the ""Daisy"" ad used against Goldwater in the 1964 campaign. A little girl counts as she picks petals off a FLOWER, then you hear a countdown and see a mushroom CLOUD. It's one of the most famous examples of advertising<strong> technique</strong>."		
雨		rain	This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the <b>rain</b> collected there and waiting to fall.	* As a primitive it can mean either <i>rain</i> or <i>weather</i> in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown.	8	451	422	18	ウ	あめ、あま-、-さめ	From the <em>ceiling</em> hangs a <em>towel</em> dripping four <em>drops</em> like<strong> RAIN</strong>.	The<strong> rain</strong> falls from the sky, landing like teardrops on my windows.	It<strong> rain</strong>ed so hard that we had to put a <em>towel</em> under the <em>ceiling</em> to contain the <em>drops</em> that came through.	Towel hung out on a line to ….oops, it's<strong> rain</strong>.	A pictograph of a window with<strong> rain</strong> falling outside.		
雲		cloud	Here is the full character for <b>cloud</b> from which the primitive for a <i>rising cloud</i> derives. <i>Clouds</i> begin with vapors <i>rising</i> up in small <i>clouds</i> from the surface of the earth, and then gathering to make <b>clouds</b> that eventually dump their <i>rain</i> back on the earth.		12	452	423	18	ウン	くも、-ぐも	Every <em>rising<strong> cloud</strong></em> is a potential <em>rain</em><strong> cloud</strong>. (Thanks astridtops).	Every<strong> cloud</strong> is a potential <em>rain</em><strong> cloud</strong>.	A<strong> cloud</strong> represents the stage of the earth's water cycle between when <em>rising <strong>clouds</strong></em> of water vapor head for the sky and when <em>rain</em> falls.	That's a funny<strong> cloud</strong>… it seems to be shooting rain up above it instead of letting it drop to the earth…	This kanji shows the weather cycle. Rain falls from the rain<strong> cloud</strong>s, and then becomes a<strong> cloud</strong> of vapour that rises up and the whole thing begins again.		
曇		cloudy weather	We refer to days when the <i>sun</i> is covered by the <i>clouds</i> as <b>cloudy weather</b>.		16	453	424	18	ドン	くも.る	<strong>Cloudy weather</strong> is when a <em>cloud</em> blocks the <em>sun</em> (up above).	I have difficulty remembering that the rain is ABOVE the clouds, which is not its logical spot. This is<strong> cloudy weather</strong>, not rainy weather. So I imagine the <em>sun</em> <em>raining</em> down on the <em>clouds</em> instead.	DO NOT MISTAKE CLOUD AND<strong> CLOUDY WEATHER</strong> . Remember that CLOUD is a smaller kanji, as well as a smaller keyword. Also in Japanese it is smaller (kumo vs. kumori).	The <em>sun</em> is above the <em>clouds</em>, the definition of<strong> cloudy weather</strong>.	<strong>Cloudy weather</strong> is actually the English weather: <em>sunny</em>, <em>rainy</em> and <em>cloudy</em> at the same time.		
雷		thunder	The full rumble and roar and terror of <b>thunder</b> is best felt not with your head tucked under your pillow safe in bed, but out in an open <i>rice field</i> where you can get the real feel of the <i>weather</i>.		13	454	425	18	ライ	かみなり	If it's <em>raining</em> and you're standing in the middle of a <em>rice field</em>, you're sure to soon become acquainted with the<strong> thunder</strong> up close and personal.	<strong>Thunder</strong> is a sure sign of <em>rain</em> coming. When you hear the<strong> thunder</strong>, you've got time to get out of the <em>field</em> before it starts <em>raining</em>.	I've been told by Japanese people that this word, 雷 （かみなり）　means BOTH<strong> thunder</strong> and lightning together. Though there is no individual word for<strong> thunder</strong>, there is for lightning (いなずま）, so I understand where Heisig is coming from. Just remember a powerful storm over an empty field and you're sure to remember this kanji.	It's the<strong> Thunder</strong> with the <em>rain</em> that'll rattle your <em>brain</em>.	In the Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, once you obtain the third Spiritual Stone, you head to the castle to see the Princess. By the time you get there, RAIN is lashing down on Hyrule FIELD and<strong> thunder</strong> crashes overhead. And then you're nearly flattened by a horse, attacked by a madman and made to jump into a moat! Life's tough.		
霜		frost	Think of <b>frost</b> as a cooperative venture, an <i>inter</i>-action of the malevolent forces of <i>weather</i> that sit around a conference table and finally decide to allow a very light amount of moisture to fall just before a short and sudden freeze.		17	455	426	18	ソウ	しも	<strong>FROST</strong> is kind of an <em>inter</em>-<em>weather</em>, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.	The freezing RAIN formed<strong> FROST</strong> on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want,<strong> frost</strong>-y then think<strong> Frost</strong> Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY:<strong> FROST</strong>Y the snowman? It's RAIN that<strong> FROST</strong>S that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.	"<strong>rain</strong> changes <strong>""inter""</strong><strong> frost</strong>."	The <em>inter</em>-action between <em>rain</em> and cold makes<strong> frost</strong>.	It was <em>raining</em> outside onto the trees, and you dared your friend to stick his tongue out on the tree (you weren't quite sure if it would stick, like your tongue will to metal when it gets cold). Your friend decided to one-up you and stick his <em>eye</em> on the <em>tree</em>, and just then, it got super cold and a layer of<strong> frost</strong> covered the city. Your friend's <em>eye</em> got stuck on the <em>tree</em>, but he had to go home to do his homework, so he dashed off with his <em>eye</em> stuck there on the tree.		
冬		winter	<i>Walking legs</i> slipping on the <i>ice</i> are a sure sign of <b>winter</b>.		5	456	427	18	トウ	ふゆ	Don't slip off your legs in<strong> winter</strong>, strap two skis to your feet. In<strong> WINTER</strong>, I always slip on ICE with my WALKING LEGS.		
天		heavens	This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the <b>Heavens</b>. (You may, of course, use the elements <i>ceiling</i> and <i>St. Bernard</i> instead.)	* The primitive can mean either the <i>heaven</i> of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the <i>heavens</i>. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a <i>witch</i>.	4	457	428	18	テン	あまつ、あめ、あま-	If you think of the sky as a <em>ceiling</em> above our heads, here you have the<strong> heavens</strong> as the <em>largest ceiling</em> you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the <em>ceiling</em> primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.	The <em>ceiling</em> that all <em>large dogs</em> aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, <em>All Dogs Go to Heaven</em>.	The BIG ONE lives upstairs, in the<strong> heavens</strong>…	Tip: 天 and 夭 (<em>heavens</em> and <em>sapling</em>) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing <em>angel</em> 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369).	"Not all dogs go to heaven - only <em>one</em> <em>St. Bernard</em> gets to go (because he's a ""Saint"" Bernard)."		
妖		bewitched	You are <b>bewitched</b> by a <i>woman</i> who is, of course, a <i>witch</i>.		7	458	2078	18	ヨウ	あや.しい、なま.めく、わざわ.い	If you don't want to get <strong>bewitched</strong> (and who would?), then avoid any <em>woman</em> you see carrying what might appear to be a <em>sapling</em>. It's really a wand in disguise, and if you're not aware you might get <strong>bewitched</strong>.	I was<strong> bewitched</strong> by the <em>woman fairy</em> (like an angel, but not as tall).	Primitive: fallen angel.	<em>sigh</em>. For some reason, Heisig never seems to understand the difference between 夭 and 天 . This uses the former, which means young/sapling. Surely it's not hard to imagine a young witch messing up a spell and accidentally bewitching everyone around her?	<strong>Bewitched</strong> <em>women</em> can't come into the <em>heavens</em>.		
沃		irrigate	Suffering from a drought, the farmers call on a <i>witch</i> who conjures up <i>water</i> to <b>irrigate</b> their crops.		7	459	2079	18	ヨウ、ヨク、オク	そそ.ぐ	You use <em>water</em> to<strong> irrigate</strong> your <em>saplings</em>. Apologies for the rudeness, but that's what it's about.	At the beginning of <strong>Star Wars VI: Return of the Jedi</strong>, Luke Skywalker is <em>standing</em> at the edge of a giant sand pit, awaiting to to be consumed by the Sarlacc, a giant ant lion-like creature that lives in the pit. While Luke is standing there, <em>legs</em> dangling over the huge mouth of the creature, he makes a last plea with Jabba the Hut to<strong> make a deal</strong>, but Jabba only laughs.		
嫡		legitimate wife	"The phrase <b>legitimate wife</b> would have no meaning if there were not such things as ""illegitimate wives,"" taken because one's legal <i>woman</i> has turned into an <i>antique</i>. The very offense of the idea should help you remember the kanji."		14	472	440	18	チャク、テキ		Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.	Your<strong> legitimate wife</strong> is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes…	The <em>woman</em> you'll want to be with even when you're both <em>antique</em> should be your<strong> LEGITIMATE WIFE</strong>.	When the <strong>legitimate wife</strong> finds her husband flirting with another <em>woman</em>, she'll take the valuable <em>antique Ming-vase</em> and whacks him with it over the head. That should teach him a lesson!	The<strong> legitimate wife</strong> is the woman who gets your antiques when you die!		
適		suitable	Can you imagine anything less <b>suitable</b> to do with one's precious <i>antiques</i> than to display them in the middle of a crowded <i>road-way</i>?		14	473	441	18	テキ	かな.う	"Think of the term from televison ""suitable for all audiences"" to get the sense of the word. That old thing in your attic might be<strong> suitable</strong> to be shown on the <em>Antiques</em> <em>Road</em>show.	That <strong>antique road</strong> isn't<strong> suitable</strong> for travel.

敵		enemy	Picture your most precious <i>antique</i> (it doesn't matter how old it really is, so long as it is the oldest thing YOU own) being knocked over by your most unlikeable <i>taskmaster</i>, and you have a good picture of how people make themselves <b>enemies</b> for life.		15	475	443	18	テキ	かたき、あだ、かな.う	The <em>taskmaster</em> became my<strong> enemy</strong> for life when he smashed the <em>antique vase</em> holding my wife's ashes. 匕		spoon	This character, a pictograph of a <b>spoon</b>, is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for <i>seven</i>, where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second.	* As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone <i>sitting on the ground</i>, of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly.	2	476	444	18	ヒ	さじ、さじのひ	"To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku…with a<strong> spoon</strong>. <a href=""http://tinyurl.com/co48k"">http://tinyurl.com/co48k</a>."	Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the <em>direction</em> of a stroke. In both 'spoon' and 'seven', the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in 'seven' it is a strong line from left to right.	Just remember it.	I sat on the ground, feeding myself jelly with a<strong> spoon</strong>.	Imagine Winnie the Pooh sitting on the ground eating honey with a<strong> spoon</strong>.		
叱		scold	Recall some particularly harsh <b>scolding</b> you got as a child in school. This character has you <i>sitting on the ground</i> in the corner as your teacher stands over you, her <i>mouth</i> wide open as she reprimands you in front of the entire class.		5	477	2179	18	シツ、シチ	しか.る	A kid gets<strong> scold</strong>ed if they don't put the <em>spoon</em> properly into their <em>mouth</em> when eating.	Kids get<strong> scold</strong>ed if they don't open their MOUTH to take their SPOONFUL of medicine.	Here's a story I read many years ago in a magazine. It was about a girl who was lonely and wanting and decided to play with a banana. While doing this, she suddenly heard her parents returning home, and being startled, the banana broke inside her. Her mom then had to use a spoon to get the banana out of this poor girl while she was being <strong>scolded</strong>. So actually, this is a pictograph..	Well, how do you picture getting<strong> SCOLD</strong>ED? You listen to that MOUTH while you have to SIT DOWN there and take it.	"This is NOT spoon. The first stroke of the RHS goes beyond the second stroke. It's diced. STORY: When I try to make dinner, my wife<strong> scold</strong>s me because of my poor dicing technique. ""This is too big! It will never fit in our mouths! Dice it again!""."

Your girlfriend comes up from behind you in bed on a cold winter's night and <em>spoons</em> you. She gets the blankets and tucks them in on both sides so the two of you are <em>bound up</em> tightly. Everything's perfect, until you release your foul<strong> aroma</strong> - silent but deadly, like a ninja. 北		north	The cold air from the <b>north</b> is so strong that we see <i>two people sitting on the ground</i> back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!	In the<strong> north</strong>, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.	Codexus wrote: <strong>Warning:</strong> The left part is NOT the primitive <em>turtle</em>! The stroke order is different. My 'story': There are NO <em>turtles</em> at the <strong>North</strong> Pole. What looks like turtle-backs are actually Igloos, so small you can barely <em>sit</em> inside them. Just stick to the people sitting back to back in the cold<strong> north</strong>.

昆		descendants	"By <i>comparing</i> apes with anthropoids, we not only discover the latter have <b>descended</b> from those progenitors educated in the higher branches, but that the very idea of seeing everything <b>descended</b> from everything else, one way or another, means that there is ""nothing new UNDER the <i>sun</i>."""		8	483	448	18	コン		Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their<strong> DESCENDANTS</strong>.	Japanese people have compared themselves as being<strong> descendants</strong> of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing =<strong> descendants</strong>.	Ask a Japanese person what this kanji means, and they will surely spout 昆布 (konbu, seaweed)　and 昆虫 (konchu, insect) - but beyond that they will likely be mystified. Here's my best crack at it: imagine a grandfather watching his DESCENDENTS (grandkids) playing outside under the <em>sun</em>, silently <em>comparing</em> them, considering which of them will grow up and make him proud. Suddenly, grandma calls them in for a snack of 昆布 and for a re-application of repellent to keep the 昆虫 away.	My official rebuttal to racism: We're all<strong> descendants</strong> of the <em>sun</em> - there's no reason to <em>compare</em> us.	"We're all <strong>descendants</strong> of chimps, get over it, don't spend all <a href=""../v4/12.html"">day</a> (#12 日) trying to <a href=""../v4/447.html"">compare</a> (#447 比) various religious fairytales."		
皆		all	"Think of the housewives in TV commercials ""<i>comparing</i> the <i>whiteness</i>"" of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as <b>All</b>. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases ""<b>all</b>-purpose detergent"" or ""<b>all</b>-temperature detergent."")"		9	484	449	18	カイ	みな、みんな	If you <em>compare</em> colors, you will find that <em>white</em> is produced from the mix of<strong> all</strong> the others.	Sometimes, Dr. Heisig's keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn't mean<strong> all</strong>, it means <strong>everyone</strong>!! Picture two ku klux klansmen <em>comparing</em> whose <em>skin</em> is whiter…finally, they agree that <strong>everyone</strong> there is white.	<strong>皆</strong>さん、<strong>みんな</strong>さん, lets <strong>all</strong> <em>compare</em> our <em>whites</em>! This could be a line from a Japanese soap commercial or analysis the Republican presidential candidates….. But you can save lots of cash when you realize that they're <strong>all</strong> ok.		
楷		block letters	The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here <b>block letters</b> are pictured as tidy rows of <i>trees</i> that are <i>all</i> the same size and can be read easily by <i>all</i>, whatever calligraphic skills they possess.		13	485	3011	18	カイ		"<strong>Print-style writing</strong> (as opposed to cursive): <em>All</em> <strong>print-style writing</strong> looks rather <em>wooden</em> to me. I prefer the fancy curves of cursive. (Note: Heisig gives this character the official keyword ""block letters,"" but based on what I've read about the meaning of the character in the Yahoo! Japan Dictionary, I prefer ""print-style writing"")."	<strong>Block letters</strong> (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like <em>wood</em>; they're <em>all</em> the same size so that <em>all</em> can read them.	"<em>all</em> the hiragana are in ""block letters"" on <em>wooden</em> blocks, like children's toys."	Literally the <strong>block letters</strong> on children's blocks, carved into <em>wood</em> so clearly that <em>all</em> can read them.	"At the base of the tree, in white<strong> block letters</strong> is written the following; ""In 1911, 3 men sat here and compared the whiteness of their skins. In the end it was determined that they were all white.""."		
諧		orderliness	"The harmoney of ""a place for everything and everything in its place"" is applied here to the <b>orderliness</b> of <i>all</i> the <i>words</i> one speaks."		16	486	3012	18	カイ	かな.う、 やわ.らぐ	<strong>harmonious</strong>: If a choir is to be <strong>harmonious</strong>, <em>all</em> the voices need to combine to hit the right notes, and say the right <em>words</em>.	Think of a chat in which <em>everyone</em> is writing <em>words</em> at once, of the lack of<strong> orderliness</strong> of such a chat.	To have<strong> orderliness</strong>, your <em>words</em> must be in <em>all</em> the right places.	起立 (きりつ)！ Hearing these <em>words</em>, <em>all</em> the students immediately stand at attention. The <strong>orderliness</strong> of classes in Japan is incredible.	"<strong>to be in sync</strong>: The <em>words</em> a choir sings must <em>all</em> <strong>be in sync</strong>. ~~~ (Note: According to Yahoo! 辞書 , this character means something like ""to harmonize/to mitigate."" I chose <strong>to be in sync</strong> as the keyword to both avoid conflicting with other keywords and to capture the general meaning of the kanji that can be applied to the various compounds that use it.)."		
混		mix	<b>Mixed</b> marriages, this character suggests, <i>water</i> down the quality of one's <i>descendants</i> - the oldest racial nonsense in the world!		11	487	450	18	コン	ま.じる、-ま.じり、ま.ざる、ま.ぜる、こ.む	People have to<strong> mix</strong> their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.	<strong>Mixed</strong> kids are <em>watered</em> down <em>descendants</em>. "This whole series is easy to me if you picture Cheech as the man taking the Siesta. ""He man, you gotta drinka water man? I am like so<strong> thirst</strong>y I could die man.""."	If anyone is having difficulty creating stories with the primitive <em>siesta</em>, try changing it to <em>beggar</em> - a <em>beggar</em> sits in his box begging for food/money under a hot sun. I have used <em>beggar</em> as a primitive in several frames and it works like a charm. Here a <em>beggar</em> develops a deep<strong> thirst</strong> for <em>water</em> as he crouches in his box under the hot sun.	Have some <em>water</em> before you take a <em>siesta</em>, or you will wake up<strong> thirst</strong>y!

His assistant says, ""Sorry about your<strong> audience</strong>, but you won't get a <em>word</em> out of him while he's having his <em>siesta</em>""." 褐		brown	The color of the serape or <i>cloak</i> of our muchacho on <i>siesta</i> is a dull <b>brown</b>, the color this kanji indicates.		13	490	453	18	カツ		Why is my package late? Now my clothes are all<strong> brown</strong> man…""."	"If you break up SIESTA into <em>tongue wagging in mouth</em>, <em>bound up</em>, <em>sitting man</em>, you have somewhat the image of a prisoner begging. (btw, chinese etymology: the bottom part of siesta means to beg)."		
喝		hoarse	When the muchacho on <i>siesta</i> looks up at you and opens his <i>mouth</i> to talk, his voice is so <b>hoarse</b> that you cannot understand him.		11	491	454	18	カツ		If you have a <em>siesta</em> with your <em>mouth</em>open, you will wake up with a<strong> hoarse</strong> voice. 葛		kudzu	"<b>Kudzu</b> is a word taken over from Japanese to name the crawling vines that creep up and completely take over trees. Seeing it at its worst in the Georgia countryside makes it easy to understand why it has a reputation as the ""plague of the South."" From there it should not be hard to arrange the primitives, <i>flowers</i> and <i>siesta</i> into a memorable image."		11	492	2398	18	カツ、カチ	つづら、くず	Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a <em>siesta</em> in the<strong> kudzu</strong> field. The<strong> kudzu</strong> grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the<strong> kudzu</strong> <em>flowers</em> mark his grave.	The muchacho takes a <em>siesta</em> under the <em>flowers</em> of the<strong> kudzu</strong>.	<strong>Kudzu</strong> is a <em>flowering</em> plant that never takes a <em>siesta</em>…it grows constantly and has already overtaken most of the southeastern United States. Beware the<strong> kudzu</strong>!	Ok so I don't know about anyone else, but the bottom part of this kanji does not look like <em>siesta</em> on this site. In the supplement pdf it does, but not here so I came up with this:<strong> Kudzu</strong> vines and <em>flowers</em> grow so fast by <em>day</em> that by night they have <em>bound up</em> all the <em>animal legs</em> in the forest like <em>fish hooks</em> bind fish. It is long and convoluted, but it contains everything similar to the elements here.	"My Windows font is displaying the traditional form of this character, however the bottom primitive is <em>siesta</em> as listed. A couple of links to confirm: <a href=""http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/845b/browsertest.htm"">http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/845b/browsertest.htm</a> <a href=""http://jisho.org/kanji/details/%E8%91%9B"">http://jisho.org/kanji/details/%E8%91%9B</a> Also I'd never heard of<strong> kudzu</strong> before, so thought I might as well rename this to <strong>くず</strong> and learn the reading too."		
旨		delicious	Something is so downright <b>delicious</b> that one spends the entire <i>day</i> with a <i>spoon</i> in hand gobbling it up.		6	493	455	18	シ	むね、うま.い	Use a <em>spoon</em> to eat a<strong> DELICIOUS</strong> hot fudge <em>sun</em>dae. Duh..	It's sooo<strong> delicious</strong> I could <em>spoon</em> it in all <em>day</em>.	Instructions for <strong>delicious</strong>: 1. Find said <strong>delicious</strong> 2. Get <em>spoon</em> 3. Spend all <em>day</em> eating.	In Japan, you basically have to <em>wag your tongue</em> after each <em>spoonful</em> you eat in order to talk about how<strong> delicious</strong> the food is. To learn this just watch Japanese television, on basically any channel, for 15 minutes. Girls say 'oishii', but guys usually use 'umai,' which is written with this very kanji: 旨い (うまい).	That girl was so<strong> delicious</strong> I could spoon her all day :P.		
脂		fat	This kanji tells us that if you feed the <i>flesh</i> with too many <i>delicious</i> things, it soon picks up a thick layer of <b>fat</b>.		10	494	456	18	シ	あぶら	Every chef will tell you,<strong> fat</strong> is what make the meat taste delicious.	"<strong>Fat</strong> is the most <em>delicious</em> part of the <em>flesh</em>. (Note this refers to physical<strong> fat</strong>, not the concept of obesity <a href=""../v4/494.html"">obese</a> (#494 肪))."	Well, after months with nothing else but delicious food - of course you get<strong> fat</strong>!	Delicious SUNdaes will put some<strong> fat</strong> on your FLESH.	Think of the famous kobe beef: why is its <em>flesh</em> so <em>delicious</em>? Why, it is so finely marbled with<strong> fat</strong>!

""Oooooh, how absolutely <em>delicious</em>!""." The only reason for me to <strong>visit a shrine</strong> is to see those <em>deliciously</em> young shrine maidens. Oh, did I <em>say</em> that out loud?		
壱		I (one)	"The Roman numeral I - like that for II we met earlier in frame 379 - is only rarely used now. The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.	"Imagine Neo (a futuristic <em>samurai</em> aka <em>The One</em>) wearing a Burger King crown, in the famous scene from the Matrix where he's told ""There is no <em>spoon</em>.""."	Amidst all the rich <em>gentlemen</em> the one with a <em>crown</em> was born with a silver <em>spoon</em> in his mouth, setting his place as the number I (one) richest person in the room.	"For those that live in Japan- There is a Curry shop chain called ""CoCo ichiban"", and they use this kanji on their sign. So…….. Picture an ancient CoCo ichiban, and the samurai get together for a ""Super Number I Curry eating champion challenge."" 腹		abdomen	If you <i>double back</i> (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the <i>part of the body</i> where the crease comes is the <b>abdomen</b>.		13	503	464	18	フク	はら	The only <strong>body</strong> part that <strong>doubles over</strong>.	Imagine getting punched in the<strong> abdomen</strong>, a fairly tender part of <em>flesh</em>, and instead of doubling forward, you <em>double back</em>. That would be pretty painful.	The <em>part of the body (flesh)</em> that is exercised when we lie down and bring our <em>walking legs</em> toward the <em>sun</em> is the<strong> abdomen</strong> (aka: leglifts).	"Try not to confuse the primitive 'double back' and <a href=""../v4/1130.html"">fold</a> (#1130 折). After I <em>backtracked</em> from a long day of hiking, my <strong>abdomen</strong> was hungry for <em>flesh</em>, so I ate a huge steak."	Well, flesh doubled over..and over .. think of the guts …in the<strong> abdomen</strong>.		
複		duplicate	In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to <b>duplicate</b> something means to <i>double</i> it <i>back</i> with a fold, like the fold of a <i>cloak</i>.		14	504	465	18	フク		My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!	"In <em>Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</em>, Hermione uses a device called a ""time-turner"" to <em>double back</em> in time, but this creates<strong> duplicate</strong>s. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione's time-turner with Harry's invisibility cloak. That way, one could <em>double back</em> in time without creating any visible<strong> duplicate</strong>s."	The magician took his CLOAK, FOLDED IT (DOUBLE BACKED IT) and <strong>DUPLICATED</strong> it!! Amaaaazing.	St. Martin took his <em>cloak</em>, <em>doubled it back</em>, and cut it into two pieces effectively making a<strong> duplicate</strong> of his cape (duplicape) for the beggar.	My girlfriend noticed that someone was wearing an exact<strong> duplicate</strong> of the <em>cloak</em> she was told was one of a kind! So, she <em>laid</em> there, <em>tongue wagging</em>, <em>legs</em> kicking throwing a right hissy fit![[I have trouble remembering 'double back'.. hope this helps anyone else who has the same problem! 欠		lack	The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a <b>lack</b> of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.	* As a primitive, it can mean either <i>yawn</i> or <i>lack</i>.	4	505	466	18	ケツ、ケン	か.ける、か.く、あくび	To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who<strong> lack</strong>s a head.	When your body<strong> lack</strong>s oxygen you <em>yawn</em>.	A PERSON BOUND UP due to work is tired and<strong> LACK</strong>S sleep, hence YAWNS.	I <em>yawn</em> when I<strong> lack</strong> interest.	A <em>bound up</em> <em>person</em><strong> lack</strong>s his freedom.		
吹		blow	To <b>blow</b> is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's <i>mouth lack</i> all the air that is in it.		7	506	467	18	スイ	ふ.く	This is clearly a<strong> BLOW</strong>JOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).	How am I supposed to<strong> BLOW</strong> if I <em>lack</em> a <em>mouth</em>? (Imagine a kid at his own birthday party, and - like Neo in the Matrix - had no oriface where his mouth was to be. And yet, the people cruelly cheer him on to<strong> blow</strong> out his candles…).	"I keep confusing this with <a href=""../v4/689.html"">suck</a> (#689 吸). Consider someone<strong> blow</strong>ing bubbles using their chewing gum because they're <em>lack</em>ing attention in class."	After your <em>mouth opens</em> and you <em>yawn</em>, you<strong> BLOW</strong> out a lot of air.	<strong>Blowing</strong> makes your <em>mouth</em> <em>lack</em> air.		
炊		cook	Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing <i>fire</i> and an inattentive, <i>yawning</i> <b>cook</b> who let things get out of control.		8	507	468	18	スイ	た.く、-だ.き	Japanese<strong> cook</strong>ing sometimes <em>lacks</em> <em>fire</em>, e.g., sashimi.	This character shows the difference between a <strong>cook</strong> and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a <strong>cook</strong> only stands there with a pan over a <em>fire</em>, with no passion and just <em>yawning</em>.	How can you<strong> cook</strong> something when you lack fire?	This is the first kanji for rice<strong> cook</strong>er ( 炊飯器 ). The reason they came up with that device is the sheer amount of incidents of people's morning rice going up in flames while they were yawning, trying to keep awake.	"Tip : if you have seen Hayao Miyazaki 's animated movie ""Howl's moving castle"" (Le Château Ambulant), you may use the image of the flame demon Calcifer for the fire primitive. 次		next	"This key word connotes the ""<b>next</b> in line"" of a succession of people or things. 茨		briar	"Earlier we made mention of the story of <b>Briar</b> Rose (or ""Sleeping Beauty,"" as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the <b>briar</b> hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the <i>second</i> part of the story, these <b>briars</b> blossomed into <i>flowers</i>. Hence her name, <b>Briar</b> Rose.
