諮		consult with	To seek the <i>words</i> of a <i>second mouth</i> is to <b>consult with</b> someone about something.		16	514	475	18	シ	はか.る	Having a <em>word</em> with the <em>next mouth</em> over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to<strong> consult with</strong> somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.	"""Consulting with"" is having <em>words</em> with the <em>next mouth</em>."	Don't like the <em>words</em> of the first one?<strong> Consult with</strong> the <em>next mouth</em> available.	If you've ever had to deal with <strong>consultants</strong> in business, you'll find that once you bring in one, there's always a reason to drag in more; a real drain on your resources. So I see this as the constant steam of <em>words</em> from the <em>next mouth</em>, all telling you that you need more <strong>conultants</strong>.	Tim Allen always used to <em>speak</em> and<strong> consult with</strong> his <em>next</em> door neighbor, Wilson. You could never see Wilson's whole face, just his <em>mouth</em>.		
賠		compensation	Picture a <i>clam</i> used as a <i>muzzle</i> to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking <b>compensation</b> for her husband lost at sea.		15	515	476	19	バイ		<strong>Compensation</strong> is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).	<strong>Compensation</strong> is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that <em>muzzles</em>.	I expect<strong> compensation</strong> for the bite I recieved when you didn't <em>muzzle</em> your dog.	"In ""compensated dating"", Japanese girls earn <em>shells</em> from oyaji. The oyajis' members <em>stand</em> at attention and the girls use their <em>mouths</em> to earn their<strong> compensation</strong>."	When I see this keyword I think of 'compensated dating' (AKA enjo kosai). A man hands over his <em>money</em> to the girl and then <em>stands up</em>, and she then opens up her <em>mouth</em> to <strong>compensate</strong> him. If that girl's parents want to fix her problem, they are going to need to put a <em>muzzle</em> on her!		
培		cultivate	The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of <b>cultivating</b> bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of <i>muzzling</i> the <i>soil</i>.		11	516	477	19	バイ	つちか.う	To<strong> cultivate</strong> the <em>land</em> is to tame it, control it. In short, you <em>muzzle</em> it's unruly, chaotic nature. 培う つちかう to<strong> cultivate</strong>, to foster; 栽培 (さいばい) : cultivation.	The illegal immigrants<strong> cultivate</strong> the <em>land</em> but are socially and politically <em>muzzled</em> (wear muzzles while they work too).	In olden times the <em>land (soil)</em> was<strong> cultivate</strong>d by farmers who were <em>muzzled</em> by the land owners: they were prevented from expressing their opinions.	The SOIL is MUZZLED to stop it screaming as it is<strong> CULTIVATE</strong>D (torn up with blades).	Image people <strong>cultivating</strong> , <em>standing in a hole in the ground</em>, preparing the soil to receive the next crop.		
剖		divide	"To ""<b>divide</b> and conquer"" you use a <i>saber</i> and a <i>muzzle</i>."		10	517	478	19	ボウ		When you<strong> DIVIDE</strong> someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That's why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.	<strong>Divide</strong> and Conquer: Shut 'em Up and Cut 'em Up.	<strong>Divide</strong> and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).	The two women keep arguing about whose baby it is. So Solomon muzzles the both of them, pulls out a sword, and prepares to<strong> divide</strong> the child between the two.	In order to MUZZLE the two complaining women, Solomon offered to<strong> divide</strong> the child with a SABER.		
音		sound	The kanji for <b>sound</b> depicts something <i>standing</i> in the air over a <i>tongue wagging in a mouth</i>, much the same as a <b>sound</b> does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.	* The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound.	9	518	479	19	オン、イン、ノン	おと、ね	If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making<strong> sound</strong>.	The <em>tongue wagging in a mouth</em> produces a very high-pitched <strong>sound</strong>, breaking a nearby <em>vase</em>.	Imagine the<strong> SOUND</strong>s a woman makes as she is STANDing above a WAGGING TOUNGE.	Note that<strong> sound</strong> is very close to the <strong>muzzle</strong> primitive (it has the <em>sun</em> instead of the <em>mouth</em> at the bottom) - but in meaning they are precisely opposite!	I STAND UP every DAY to the<strong> SOUND</strong> of [insert<strong> sound</strong> here].		
暗		darkness	"When ""<b>darkness</b> covered the earth"" at the beginning of time, there was neither <i>sun</i> nor <i>sound</i>."		13	519	480	19	アン	くら.い、くら.む、くれ.る	Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then…nothing. Everything would plunge into<strong> darkness</strong>.	"In places of complete <strong>darkness</strong>, such as caves where the <em>sun</em> can't reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by <em>sound</em> rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming ""Marco!"" and ""Polo!"" all the time."	Total<strong> darkness</strong> lacks <em>sun</em> and <em>sound</em>.	In the <strong>darkness</strong> of that dank solitary confinement cell, all you can do is fantasize about <em>sun</em> and <em>sound</em>.	"Heisig was careless with his story for <a href=""../v4/240.html"">silence</a> (#240 黙). i have a really hard time confusing it for this one now."		
韻		rhyme	"Poetry restricted to verses that <b>rhyme</b> often finds it has to abandon clarity of thought in order to make the <b>rhyme</b> of the words work. In this kanji's picture, one becomes a kind of ""<i>sound-employee</i>."""		19	520	481	19	イン		What is a<strong> RHYME</strong> but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.	"Dr Seuss's <em>employee</em> finally rebels against him: ""I'm tired of odd <em>sounds</em> all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in<strong> RHYME</strong>!""."	A<strong> rhyme</strong> is the <em>sound</em> of an <em>employee</em> going off to work. Everyone knows that ever since 'Snow White' in 1937 all employees sing 'hi ho, hi ho, it's off to work I go' (because it's so catchy! And it's so catchy because 'ho'<strong> rhyme</strong>s with 'go'!).	"""<em>Sound</em> as a pound"" is a<strong> rhyme</strong> that fits the kanji. <em>Sound</em> + pound. Pounds being what you make when you're an <em>employee</em> (living in the UK that is)."	Employees of The Ministry of Sound are paid to<strong> rhyme</strong> every day.		
識		discriminating	A person of <b>discriminating</b> intellect can tell the difference between mere <i>kazoo</i>-buzzing and <i>words</i> spoken wisely.		19	521	482	19	シキ	し.る、しる.す	<em>Words</em> are difficult to discriminate/discern from <em>sounds</em> in the middle of a <em>fiesta</em>.	I have<strong> discriminating</strong> taste. I'd rather listen to the <em>words</em> of a lecture than attend a <em>kazoo</em> concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).	I wonder why Heisig didn't use <strong>discernment</strong> for this kanji. It fits the meaning equally and it is not as loaded as <strong>discrimination</strong>. // It is quite hard to <strong>discern</strong> <em>words</em> in the middle of a <em>noisy fiesta</em>.	<strong>Discriminating</strong> someone's <em>words</em> from other sounds is hard to do in the middle of a <em>noisy fiesta</em>. (Thanks esaulgd).	Socrates has apparently joined the KKK, and is actively<strong> discriminating</strong> against Black people. But to add a bit of artistic flair, as the ancient Greeks were wont to do, he says his racist words through a kazoo. <em>Socrates</em> humming the n-<em>word</em> through a <em>kazoo</em> - who would have thought?		
鏡		mirror	After lakes but before glass, polished <i>metal</i> was used for <b>mirrors</b>. These <i>metal mirrors</i> are recalled in this character for a <b>mirror</b>.		19	522	483	19	キョウ、ケイ	かがみ	<strong>Mirror</strong> should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a <em>Golden</em><strong> mirror</strong> so she can <em>stand</em> in front of it all <em>day</em> vainly admiring her lovely <em>human legs</em>.	"The <em>metal</em><strong> mirror</strong> makes a <em>sound</em> - it's answering the question ""who has the fairest <em>human legs</em> of all?""."	<em>metal + stand up + sun + legs </em> remember the legend of <strong>Amaterasu</strong> who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a <strong>MIRROR</strong> made of polished <strong> METAL</strong> at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was <strong>STANDING UP</strong> saw her image of the <strong>SUN </strong> and began to dance with her <strong>LEGS</strong>.	"Remember how Archimedes burnt an approaching fleet with<strong> mirror</strong>s?<strong> Mirror</strong>s then were <em>metal</em> and the sailors must have thought: ""What're those <em>metal </em> things up there, <em>standing</em> on the city walls? They look like <em>little suns</em> on <em>human legs</em>. Warm today isn't it?""."	"WARNING: Be extra careful not to confuse the <em>sun/tongue-wagging mouth</em> and <em>human legs</em> part of the<strong> mirror</strong> primitive with 見 <a href=""../v4/57.html"">see</a> (#57 見)."		
境		boundary	Imagine the <b>boundary</b> of a plot of <i>land</i> marked with gigantic <i>mirrors</i> enabling the landowner to keep trespassers in sight at all times.		14	523	484	19	キョウ、ケイ	さかい	In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put <em>mirrors</em> on the<strong> boundary</strong> of his <em>land</em> so it feels much bigger.	This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the<strong> boundary</strong> of your land and theirs. When they approach the<strong> boundary</strong>, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn't any better than their own and they head back home.	<strong>Boundaries</strong> and borders (another meaning of this kanji) used to be protected by daggers and swords (see <strong>environs</strong>, frame 284); but today our <em>lands</em> are protected by one-way <em>mirrors</em> at airport customs with video cameras and interrogation rooms behind them.	In Japan, you often see MIRRORS at intersections. That's because the walls that form the<strong> boundary</strong> of people's LAND make it hard to see around corners.	"Be aware the right-hand character 竟 really means ""endpoint"" or ""finally""; it's commonly read ""つい"" (as in ""ついに"") and usually written in kana alone. A<strong> boundary</strong> represents a country's <em>land</em>'s <em>endpoint</em> (awkward phrasing for order) ."		
亡		deceased	A <i>top hat</i> hanging on a <i>hook</i> in the front hall, right where the <b>deceased</b> left it the day he died, reminds us of him and his kanji.	* In addition to <i>deceased</i>, the primitive meaning of <i>to perish</i> will also be used for this character.	3	524	485	19	ボウ、モウ	な.い、な.き-、ほろ.びる、ほろ.ぶ、ほろ.ぼす	The <em>top hat</em> hanging on a <em>hook</em> belonged to the now<strong> deceased</strong> Charlie Chaplin.	The recently<strong> DECEASED</strong> are said to hang their <em>hats</em> on a <em>hook</em> by the door to the afterlife.	Tophat resting on top of a tombstone. The horizontal bottom line is the shadow of the tombstone (and/or hat) on the ground.	I think of this as a pictograph of a coffin.	The <strong>deceased</strong>'s <em>top hat</em> still hangs on his old <em>fish hook</em>… It makes me sad every time I see it, but I will never take that hat down.		
盲		blind	If one's <i>eyes perish</i> before death, one remains <b>blind</b> for the rest of life.		8	525	486	19	モウ	めくら	Deceased eyes! Easy ;).	A person with <em>deceased</em> <em>eyes</em> is<strong> blind</strong>.	"Rather than ""dead eyes,"" break down DECEASED into TOPHAT and FISHHOOK, and picture each<strong> blind</strong> person's EYES as being unable to see because their eyes are covered with a TOP HAT, that's attached to a FISHHOOK stabbed in their eyeballs."	I keep messing up the order of the primitives here. To emphasise the position, imagine the<strong> blind</strong> person wanting to take his <em>top hat</em> off the <em>hook</em>. Before he does that, though, he needs to re-attach his <em>eye</em>balls, which are rolling around on the floor.	The<strong> blind</strong> man could not see anything with his EYES, but he claimed, when he looked up, he could see the DECEASED existing above.		
妄		delusion	"The ""ideal <i>woman</i>"" one daydreams about is no more than a <b>delusion</b>. So, here's my story: The<strong> delusion</strong>al woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back." Well, she is under the<strong> DELUSION</strong> that someday someone will marry her. Too bad that nobody wants to marry a <strong>dead</strong> <strong>woman</strong> ."	Romeo held the<strong> delusion</strong> that Juliet was a <em>deceased woman</em>.	He cared for her so much that he had<strong> delusion</strong>s that the <em>deceased</em> <em>woman</em>, who was 6 feet under, was still with him.		
荒		laid waste	The <i>flowers</i> that <i>perish</i> in the <i>flood</i> are taken here as symbols of an area that has been <b>laid waste</b>.		9	527	488	19	コウ	あら.い、あら-、あ.れる、あ.らす、-あ.らし、すさ.む	After Godzilla<strong> laid waste</strong> to the city, the survivors put some <em>flowers</em> on the bodies of the <em>deceased</em> and floated their bodies down the <em>stream</em>.	"<strong>Laying waste</strong> is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like <em>flowers</em>, more like <em>deceased flowers</em>, and it's flushed down into a <em>stream</em> of sewage. Use ""waste"" to avoid <a href=""../v4/365.html"">destroy</a> (#365 滅) <a href=""../v4/400.html"">demolition</a> (#400 壊)."	Hurricane Katrina<strong> laid waste</strong> to New Orleans….as a result, a <em>stream</em> of <em>dead flowers</em> floated into the sea.	I <strong>laid</strong> my <strong>waste</strong> in the toilet, sprayed some <em>flower</em>-scented air freshener, then <em>perished</em> the <strong>waste</strong> I <strong>laid</strong> with the toilet's <em>stream</em>.	The army that<strong> laid waste</strong> the entire region left nothing but <em>flowers</em> marking where thousands <em>perish</em>ed and blood flowed in <em>streams</em>. 荒い あらい rough, rude, wild; 荒っぽい (あらっぽい) : rough, rude; 荒廃 (こうはい) : ruin; 荒らす (あらす) : to lay waste, to devastate, to damage, to invade, to break into; 荒れる (あれる) : be stormy, lose one's temper.		
望		ambition	"The story of <b>ambition</b> talks of a <i>king</i> walking under the <i>perishing</i> (or ""waning"") <i>moon</i> dreaming great dreams about his kingdom. (The roots of <b>ambition</b> are from the same word as ""ambulate,"" meaning to walk about.)"		11	528	489	19	ボウ、モウ	のぞ.む、もち	You're <em>dead meat</em>, buddy, my<strong> ambition</strong> is to be <em>king</em>.	The <strong>ambitions</strong> of <em>kings</em> often result in <em>dead</em> <em>bodies</em>.	The <em>king</em> had great<strong> ambition</strong> to have a son, but after certain <em>part of his body</em> <em>perished</em> he lost all hope.	The <em>king</em>'s one<strong> ambition</strong>, before he <em>perishes</em>, is to go to the <em>moon</em>.	He who has<strong> ambition</strong> must be prepared to walk over the <em>dead</em> <em>body</em> of the previous <em>king</em>.		
方		direction	Spinning a <i>dagger</i> about on its hilt on the top of a <i>top hat</i> - waiting to see in which <b>direction</b> it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.	* As a primitive, this character will take the sense of a <i>compass</i>, the instrument used to determine <i>direction</i>.	4	529	490	19	ホウ	かた、-かた、-がた	"Note: The primitives are <em>top hat</em> and <em>bound up</em>. Compare <a href=""../v4/64.html"">ten thousand</a> (#64 万). Story: A rich man wearing a <em>top hat</em> and <em>bound up</em> from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for <strong>directions</strong> to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers."	I always keep my <strong>directions</strong> <em>bound</em> to the bottom of my <em>top hat</em> so I won't lose them.	To find the<strong> direction</strong>, the magician waved his <em>top hat</em> over his <em>dagger</em> to make it function as a makeshift magical compass.	Is that a DAGGER under your HAT, of are you just happy to see me? Give me some<strong> DIRECTION</strong> here.	I always have a <em>compass</em> <em>bound</em> underneath my <em>top hat</em>, so I know I'm always headed in the right <em>direction</em>.		
妨		disturb	Imagine a <i>compass</i> that is <b>disturbed</b> every time a <i>woman</i> passes by, sending the needle spinning madly round and round.		7	530	491	19	ボウ	さまた.げる	Capt. 坊		boy	The character for a <b>boy</b> shows us a <b>Boy</b> Scout cleaning the <i>dirt</i> out of his <i>compass</i> - the more <i>dirt</i>, the better.		7	531	492	19	ボウ、ボッ		Little<strong> boy</strong>s always head in the direction of mud and dirt.	<strong>Boy</strong>s thoughts often head in dirty directions. Imagine him crying because he's such a young<strong> boy</strong>, covered with DIRT streaked with tears, and banging his COMPASS against trees, etc. in an attempt to get it to work.	A<strong> boy</strong> scout will generally use the <em>ground</em> to determine <em>directions</em>.		
芳		perfumed	Here we see a special <i>compass</i> used to pick out those <i>flowers</i> most suited for making good <b>perfumes</b>.		7	532	493	19	ホウ	かんば.しい	She used a<strong> perfume</strong> so strong, that you can track her by following the <em>direction</em> of the smell of <em>flowers</em>.	People always seem to overdo it with their<strong> perfume</strong>. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap <em>flowery</em><strong> perfume</strong>. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that <em>flower</em>iness as a compass - it tells me which direction they're in.	A <em>flowery</em> scent spreading in all <em>directions</em> is<strong> perfume</strong>.	"Bees - with their ""built-in"" compass - always pick out the best-perfumed flowers - and so does the human nose, which always turns in the direction of the best-scented flower!"	<em>Flowers</em> use their<strong> perfume</strong> to attract insects in their <em>direction</em>.		
肪		obese	If you eat too much, you may need a <i>compass</i> to find your way around the <b>obese</b> mass of <i>flesh</i> that piles up in the midsection. Compare this with your stories for <i>round</i> (Frame 44) and <i>fat</i> (Frame 494), similar in meaning but distinct in imagery.		8	533	494	19	ボウ		"""<em>Flesh</em> in all <em>directions</em>"" =<strong> obese</strong>." It is always used together with ""shi"" in ""shibou"" for various types of ""fats."" [D2060]." 訪		call on	When making a courtesy <b>call on</b> a dignitary, one has to gauge one's <i>words</i> with great care. Hence the need for a <i>compass</i>.		11	534	495	19	ホウ	おとず.れる、たず.ねる、と.う	When you<strong> call on</strong> someone, you point your words in their direction.	Japanese streets usually don't have names, so finding places can be difficult. So if you plan to<strong> call on</strong> someone you need two things; 1) <em>words</em> (for asking the way) and 2) a <em>compass</em> (in case you get really lost).	When <strong>calling on</strong> a girl, you'd better what what sweet <em>words</em> will turn her fancy in your <em>direction</em>. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).	For this key word '<strong> CALL ON</strong> ' and the more useful meaning of '<strong>visit</strong>', think of: a booty call! Haven't you ever got a late night call from someone (on their <em>mobile</em>), asking for <em>words</em> of <em>direction</em> to your place? Quick, get out your Marvin Gaye record…	"Note: this kanzi means more like ""visit"" 訪ねる 【たずねる】 (v1,vt) to visit; (P). Thus, you VISIT another country that uses different WORDS than yours (language) and you have to find your way around with a COMPASS since you can't ask anyone for directions or read any signs."

説		explanation	Not inappropriately, this character likens an <b>explanation</b> to the <i>devil's</i> own <i>words</i>.		11	538	499	19	セツ、ゼイ	と.く	The <em>words</em> of a <em>horny teenager</em> typically fall into one of two categories: either <strong>rumors</strong> or<strong> explanation</strong>s. 鋭		pointed	<i>Metal</i> that has been <b>pointed</b> (as an awl, a pick, a nail, or a knife) tends to serve the <i>devil's</i> purposes as well as civilization's: our tools are also our weapons.		15	539	500	19	エイ	するど.い	<strong>Pointed</strong> is the metal devil's pitchfork.	500 kanji…Come on guys we're about 1/4 of the way there.	The <em>Horny teenager</em> who worked part time at a <em>gold</em> smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that<strong> pointed</strong> out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a <em>gold</em> smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a <em>Gold</em>member!	The <em>metal</em> of the <em>devil</em>, his pitchfork, is<strong> pointed</strong>.	<strong>Pointed</strong> metal objects are used by horny teens for devil's play.		
曽		formerly	"This primitive (named for its associations with the kanji of the following frame) is composed of a pair of <i>horns</i> growing out of a <i>brain</i> with a <i>tongue wagging in the mouth</i> beneath. Think of ""<b>former</b>"" in connection with administrators or heads of state who have just left office but continue to make a nuisance of themselves by advertising their opinions on public policy."	* The primitive meaning, <i>increase</i>, comes from the next frame. Always think of something multiplying wildly as you watch.	11	540	501	19	ソウ、ソ、ゾウ	かつ、かつて、すなわち	The Artist <strong>formerly</strong> Known as Prince has the <em>horniest</em> <em>brain</em> around, and I think you can imagine what his <em>wagging tongue</em> is doing…	<strong>Formerly</strong>, <em>horned</em> animals were used to plough the <em>ricefield</em>, and it took all <em>day</em>. Nowadays it's done by machine.	The horns found in the ricefields were<strong> formerly</strong> used in rituals celebrating the sun goddess, amaterasu.	I can't help but see this as the former president of the United Sates, George W. Bush. The horns growing out of his brain with an evil thought, his tongue wagging in his mouth, saying something stupid. (It helps later on. Increase = him increasing the national deficit until we have nothing but dirt left, Hate = Bush's mind). Fun stuff.	This was<strong> formerly</strong> a human, but it has turned into a demon, with only jagged <em>horns</em> sticking out of its <em>brain</em> and a disgusting <em>wagging tongue</em> at the bottom.		
増		increase	This kanji depicts an <b>increase</b> of <i>soil</i>, multiplying so fast that it literally buries everything in its path.		14	541	502	19	ゾウ	ま.す、ま.し、ふ.える、ふ.やす	Prices always<strong> INCREASE</strong> for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.	Farmers work the <strong>land</strong> so they can<strong> INCREASE</strong> their <strong>formerly</strong> puny crop supply.	"Lately, the artist formerly known as ""Formerly Known As Prince"", if you can believe it, has become increasingly <em>dirt</em>ier in his songs."	"This land on which ""The Artist <em>Formerly</em> Known as Prince*"" built his house has<strong> increase</strong>d in value."	Formerly there was lots of land for everyone. But as the world population<strong> increase</strong>s, your own piece of dirt is becoming more and more difficult to secure.		
贈		presents	"The <b>presents</b> offered here are <i>money</i> that <i>increases</i> each time you give it away. Do not confuse with the temporal word ""present"" (Frame 275)."		18	542	503	19	ゾウ、ソウ	おく.る	Imagine if the number of<strong> presents</strong> you get <em>increases</em> with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one <em>shell</em> as a <strong>present</strong>, but the next year it <em>increases</em> to two <em>shells</em> as<strong> presents</strong>, and so on, <em>increasing</em> and <em>increasing</em> so by the time you're elderly, the number of <em>shells</em> you'll get as<strong> presents</strong> will have <em>increased</em> to an awful lot of<strong> presents</strong>. GOT IT YET?<strong> PRESENTS</strong> = SHELLS + INCREASE.	The artist formerly known as Prince gave<strong> presents</strong> to all his fans. Picture him throwing live oysters into the audience as he performs. People are horrified and start gagging from the smell.	SEA SHELLS were FORMALLY great<strong> PRESENTS</strong>. Nowadays kids wants playstation and DS!	The money spent on<strong> presents</strong> increases every Christmas :/.	FORMERLY at Christmas I got<strong> PRESENTS</strong>, but now I just get MONEY.		
東		east	"As a ""Western"" language, English identifies the <b>east</b> with the rising <i>sun</i>. In more fanciful terms, we see the <i>sun</i> piercing through a <i>tree</i> as it rises in the <b>east</b>."	"* Both the direction <i>east</i> and the part of the world called ""the <i>East</i>"" are primitive meanings of this character."	8	543	504	19	トウ	ひがし	Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.	Through the <em>tree</em>s, I watch the <em>sun</em> rising from the<strong> east</strong>.	To the<strong> east</strong>, you'll notice a rather large <em>tree</em> growing in the middle of that <em>ricefield</em>.	Imagine that hugely symbolic Japanese SUN piercing through a TREE as it sets on Tokyo ( 東京 ), the<strong> EAST</strong>ern capital . (with thanks to AndamanIslander, just found it easier to remember this version).	[ <strong>east</strong> = <em>tree</em> overlay <em>sun</em> ] - look <strong>east</strong> and you can see the <em>sun</em> rising through the upper branches of the <em>tree</em>s : (<em>east</em> [dir]; the <em>East</em> [region]).		
棟		ridgepole	If the piece of <i>wood</i> in the roof known as the <b>ridgepole</b> points <i>east</i>, the sunrise will be visible from the front door.		12	544	505	19	トウ	むね、むな-	Feng Shui states that the<strong> ridgepole</strong> of a house should be made of <em>wood</em> and face <em>east</em>.	Ok just a note to the 'ridgepole facing east story' im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a 'sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is', back in those days when people used<strong> ridgepole</strong>s they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).	Way back when, all Japanese houses were made of <em>wood</em> and built with the <strong>ridgepole</strong> facing <em>east</em>. The reason for this is that since there were no alarm clocks yet, everyone needed the rising sun to wake them up every morning.	I need a <strong>ridgepole</strong> for the house I'm building. It's a very important part of the structure, so I need the best <strong>ridgepole</strong> money can buy. That means I need to special order one. The best <strong>ridgepole</strong> is made from a <em>tree</em> grown in the <em>east</em>. When the shipment arrives, I verify that the <strong>ridgepole</strong> is best quality by looking at the <em>tree</em> and seeing the <em>east</em> symbol stamped on it.	Secondo il feng shui la TRAVE PORTANTE di un edificio deve essere fatta di LEGNO e puntare ad EST.		
凍		frozen	"The whole secret to breaking the <i>ice</i> with the <i>East</i> is to peek behind those mysteriously ""<b>frozen</b> smiles."""		10	545	506	19	トウ	こお.る、こご.える、こご.る、い.てる、し.みる	<em>Eastern</em> Siberia is often<strong> frozen</strong> by <em>ice</em>. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself…it made it stick for me!	The <em>ice</em> will stay<strong> frozen</strong> until the <em>sun</em> is visible through the <em>trees</em>.	It is always the <em>east</em> side of anything, mountain, yard, forest, that stays<strong> frozen</strong> with <em>ice</em>.	ICE will stay<strong> FROZEN</strong> during the night, until the SUN rises over the EAST TREES.	Imagine your freezer ( 冷凍庫 れいとうこ) breaking down in the middle of the winter. The temperatures are just around freezing (it'll have to do). So you decide to bury all of your food in the <em>ice</em> outside to keep it fresh. As the sun rises in the <em>east</em> you must quickly move all of your perishables to the other side because of melting (of course remembering to move it back as the sun moves over the trees to the other side). It's tiresome but it'll have to do until you can fix the freezer.		
妊		pregnancy	A <i>woman</i> who is in her <b>pregnancy</b> is a bit like a <i>porter</i>, bearing her new companion wherever she goes.		7	546	507	19	ニン、ジン	はら.む、みごも.る	A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.	A <em>woman</em> becomes <strong>pregnant</strong> when <em>a drop of gentleman</em> gets inside her.	The <em>gentleman</em> gave the <em>woman</em> a <em>bit</em> of sperm…BAM<strong> PREGNANCY</strong>!	In<strong> PREGNANCY</strong>, a <em>woman</em> needs a <em>porter</em> to carry her bags to her room.	(Image: <strong>pregnant</strong> <em>woman</em> in traditional Japanese home yelling at her cowering <em>saumari</em> husband for pickles and ice cream. He dutifully obliges with great bowls of them on his head).		
廷		courts	Those who rule the <b>courts</b>, the <i>porters</i> of justice and order, are often found to <i>stretch</i> the law to suit their own purposes. Recall the kanji for <i>prolong</i> from frame 419 and keep it distinct.		7	547	508	19	テイ		A <em>porter</em> has run away from his master. His punishment is to be <em>stretched out</em> on the rack. So say the<strong> courts</strong> in this barbaric time.	The <em>gentleman</em> <em>stretched</em> the truth a <em>bit</em> in <strong>court</strong>.	Stretching the truth in court caused a drop of sweat on the gentleman's brow.	In court they STRETCHED the PORTER on the rack until he confessed. Torture!!!	[ <strong>courts</strong> = <em>stretch</em>(<em>porter</em>) ] - the <strong>courts</strong>, <em>porters</em> of justice, sometimes <em>stretch</em> the letter of the law for their own ends.		
染		dye	<i>Water</i> . . . <i>nine</i> . . . <i>tree</i>. From those elements you must compose a plot for the key word, <b>dye</b>. Here, as elsewhere, any of the alternate meanings of the primitives may be used, provided they do not require a position other than that of the kanji in question.		9	548	509	20	セン	そ.める、-ぞ.め、-ぞめ、そ.まる、し.みる、-じ.みる、し.み、-し.める	To make this<strong> dye</strong>, I used <em>water</em> and the barks of <em>nine</em> different <em>tree</em>s.	The <em>baseball</em> team hangs their freshly <strong>dye</strong>d <em>dripping</em> jerseys at the top of a <em>tree</em> to dry.	<strong>Dye</strong> is a <em>liquid</em> that has to be applied <em>nine</em> times to stain the <em>wood</em> below.	[dye; color; paint; stain; print] The most common <strong>dye</strong>s are <em>liquids</em> that come in <em>nine</em> colors (the 7 of the rainbow, plus white and black), and are extracted from <em>trees</em>.	<strong>Dye</strong> a <em>tree</em> with the <em>liquid</em> in a lengthy <em>9</em>-step process. I always remember the <em>9</em> because so far it's the number I've seen most used as a third primitive in kanji, especially with <em>tree</em>. For placement, just remember it's the <em>liquid</em> poured <em>9</em> times over the <em>tree</em>.		
燃		burn	<i>Hearth</i> . . . <i>sort of thing</i>. Beware of letting the simple reading off of the primitive elements do your work for you. Unless you make a vivid image of something <b>burning</b> and relate it just as vividly to those primitive meanings, you can count on forgetting this character very quickly.		16	549	510	20	ネン	も.える、も.やす、も.す	Any sort of thing can<strong> burn</strong> in the fire.	The Japanese are very particular about what SORT OF THINGs are considered<strong> BURN</strong>able trash and what's not.	"Somebody from PETA is really angry that they sell dog meat in China, so they've gone to<strong> burn</strong> down the whole cart (my mnemonic for ""sort of thing"" was seeing strips of dog flesh roasting, and saying ""well, that's just the <em>sort of thing</em> they do here in China)."	<em>Fire</em><strong> burn</strong>s any <em>sort of thing</em>.	"The ""hot diggety dog"" <em>sort of thing</em> caught on <em>fire</em> and exploded in the kitchen, causing me to sustain third-degree<strong> BURN</strong>S all over."		
賓		V.I.P.	The <b>V.I.P.</b> indicated here is an important guest making a visit. The elements are: <i>house</i> . . . <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>few</i> . . . <i>shells</i>.		15	550	511	20	ヒン		This <em>house</em> is reserved to<strong> V.I.P.</strong> only. If you are not <em>one of the few</em> with enough <em>money</em> to call you that way, keep out!	The<strong> V.I.P.</strong> visits your <em>house</em>, but your <em>ceiling</em> is too low for his inflated head, which he bumps and hurts. You have to give him your <em>few</em> <em>shells</em> as compensation.	HONEY! We've got a V.I.P visiting tonight!! Let's decorate the <em>house</em> a little why don't we? That <em>ceiling</em> is boring, let's hang a <em>few</em> fancy <em>shells</em> up there, that'll impress them!	There's only <em>one</em><strong> V.I.P.</strong> in the <em>house</em>, and all I can do is <em>focus</em> on her <em>animal legs</em>.	If you are a <strong>VIP</strong>, you are the only <em>one</em> who can enter the <em>house</em> without paying the cover charge (a <em>few</em> <em>shells</em>).		
歳		year-end	<i>Stop</i> . . . <i>march</i> . . . <i>little</i>. Be sure not to forget that final dot in the element for <i>march</i>.		13	551	512	20	サイ、セイ	とし、とせ、よわい	Santa had to put his <em>foot</em> down to stop a <em>march</em> of <em>little</em> guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every<strong> year-end</strong> when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.	At the<strong> year-end</strong>, everything seems to come to a <em>stop</em>. However, there's still enough time for a <em>little march</em> to celebrate.	At<strong> year-end</strong>, we <em>stop</em> for a <em>small</em> celebration before <em>marching</em> ahead into the new year.	At<strong> year-end</strong>, STOP and celebrate with a LITTLE MARCH.	Every<strong> YEAR-END</strong>, its important to STOP and have ONE LITTLE PARADE to celebrate.		
県		prefecture	Above, an <i>eye</i> and a <i>fishhook</i>, and below the primitive for <i>little</i>. Although apparently the simplest of these first six kanji, when you begin to work on its plot and story you will soon find out that the number of strokes and visual complexity of a kanji does not make it easier or harder to remember. It is the primitives you have to work that are the critical factor, as in this case where the meaning of the key word is so seemingly distant from the elements. Remember, you can always break larger elements down (<i>eye of a needle</i> into <i>eye</i> and <i>fishhook</i>) if you think it helps.		9	552	513	20	ケン	か.ける	In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie's boyfriend. He has lovely blue <em>eyes,</em> a girlfriend who is as thin as a <em>straightened out fish hook</em>. But, down where it counts, he has very <em>little</em> to show…	After sticking a <em>fishhook</em> in your <em>eye</em>, the yakuza boss probably has <em>little</em> more to do to convince you to move to a different<strong> prefecture</strong>.	<em>Smaller</em> administrative units, <em>hooked</em> together by a (Sauron's) central <em>eye</em>.	Contradictory to what Heisig says, there is no eye of a needle in this picture, because that would be the top part of 直 . Instead, there is the eye of a fishhook. I will not hazard a guess as to what lives in such a place, but in fact the eye of a fishhook - as it has well-defined borders - makes a small<strong> prefecture</strong> of its own.	<em>Eye</em> (I) live in a <em>small</em> <strong>prefecture</strong> full of <em>hook</em>ers.		
栃		horse chestnut	A tree . . . cliff . . . ten thousand.		9	553	514	20		とち	There are a bunch of<strong> HORSE CHESTNUT</strong> TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.	There is a<strong> horse chestnut</strong> <em>tree</em> that has grown by a <em>cliff</em> for so long, it has deposited <em>10,000</em> <strong>horse chesnut</strong>s that lie at the bottom. Don't worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it.	<strong>Horse chestnut</strong> trees grows in tens of thousands under the cliff.	Strokes 5 and 6 are in reverse order, so it's not an ordinary cliff, but a <em>drag</em> (primitive at the beginning of lesson 50!) Story: When we were kids, we loved collecting the fruits of the <strong>horse chestnut</strong> <em>tree</em>. But because there were so many to collect, we sometimes <em>dragged</em> more than <em>ten thousand</em> of them behind us!	This is NOT a cliff. the first stroke is right to left and slanted a bit. in fact, it's more like the axe blade of the axe character. story: you didn't want to try to chop down the<strong> horse chestnut</strong> tree with an axe because the chestnut kept falling on you. so instead you just stacked up <em>10,000</em> <em>axe-blades</em> next to the tree, and eventually they the stack fell on the tree and sliced it to pieces.		
地		ground	"<i>Soil</i> and a <i>scorpion</i> (an ""earth animal""). This is, of course, the full character from which the primitive for <b>ground</b> derives."		6	554	515	21	チ、ジ		Picture the<strong> ground</strong> as an extent of<em> soil</em> where<em> scorpions</em> are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying 'no trespassing, <em>scorpion</em> mines' if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.	The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the<strong> ground</strong>.	The DIRT SCORPION is a<strong> ground</strong>-type pokémon.	You can't escape the <em>scorpions</em> on the<strong> ground</strong> by jumping into the pond 池 - scorpions like both <em>soil</em> and water!	<strong>Ground</strong> Zero, after the bombings, only scorpions could live there.		
池		pond	"<i>Water</i> . . . <i>scorpion</i>. It would be easy to slip into a ""lazy image"" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a <i>scorpion</i> near the <i>water</i>. But if you picture rather a <i>scorpion</i> letting its venom out <i>drop by drop</i> until it has made a whole <b>pond</b> of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed."		6	555	516	21	チ	いけ	Remember the story of the <em>scorpion</em> that begged the turtle for a ride across the<strong> pond</strong>? Halfway across the <em>water</em>, the <em>scorpion</em> stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.	Water scorpions loves to live in the<strong> pond</strong>.	The<strong> POND</strong> was infested with WATER SCORPIONS.	You thought water snakes were bad…this<strong> pond</strong> has WATER SCORPIONS. One sting and you're dead.	"Take out the 1st layer of <em>soil</em> in ""ground"" 地 , and add <em>water</em>. You've got a<strong> pond</strong>."		
虫		insect	Work with the pictograph as you wish.	* As a primitive, this insect will refer to the whole <i>insect</i> kingdom; it can be further specified for each kanji that contains it.	6	556	517	21	チュウ、キ	むし	I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an <strong>insect</strong> biting <em>into</em> the arm, sucking some blood.	<strong>Insect</strong> in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.	An<strong> insect</strong> stuck its sharp, needle-like mouth <em>in</em> my arm and sucked out <em>one</em> <em>drop</em> of blood.	Just Remember it.	The top part is IN as for<strong> INSECT</strong>. the bottom part is the arm in which the<strong> insect</strong> stings. (thanks Shibo).		
蛍		lightning bug	Schoolhouse . . . insect.		11	557	518	21	ケイ	ほたる	Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become <strong>lightning bugs</strong>. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become <strong>lightning bugs</strong>.	Q: Who's the smartest <em>insect</em> in <em>school</em>? A: The<strong> lightning-bug</strong>. Because he's so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).	In the <em>schoolhouse</em> for <em>insects</em>, the brightest are obviously the<strong> lightning-bug</strong>s.	Think of a small Japanese <em>Schoolhouse</em> in the country. The young children have caught some<strong> lightning-bug</strong>s in a jar and placed it next to window. Long after the children go home and the sun sets, the jar continues to illuminate the room. For me, this Kanji isn't about keywords, but a strong visual.	Poor <em>schoolhouse</em>s can't afford electricity. As you can't teach in the dark the only solution is <strong>lightning-bug</strong>s! It's easy. Catch a thousand or so of them, bunch them together in a box and attach your wires to the box. Electricity flows through the wires as soon as the lightning starts flashing inside the box. Each bug has begun attacking it's neighbour with it's special weapon - the stinging rod of Lightning!		
蛇		snake	Insect . . . house . . . spoon.		11	558	519	21	ジャ、ダ、イ、ヤ	へび	A<strong> snake</strong> eats <em>insects</em> and he does that outside, while we eat in the <em>house</em> and preferably with a <em>spoon</em>.	I use a <em>spoon</em> to feed my pet-snake <em>insects</em> in the house.	"The Far Side cartoon: Picture a <strong>snake</strong> with glasses and a tie inside of his <em>house</em> in the morning. He's staring at the <em>spoon</em> next to his bowl full of <em>insects</em>. ""Dang!"" he mutters. (thanks to Cheesemaster64)."	My<strong> snake</strong> secretly eats <em>insects</em> outside the house, but in the <em>house</em>, he uses a <em>spoon</em> and follow etiquette! (adapted from nilfisq).	Solid<strong> Snake</strong> gets into his <em>insect</em> camouflage ready to infiltrate the <em>house</em> - the insect suit doesn't allow weapons to be carried so he pilfers a <em>spoon</em> and takes out the Patriots within, getting out aliv…Snake?<strong> Snake</strong>? <strong>SNAAAAAAKEEEEE</strong>!		
虹		rainbow	Insect . . . craft.		9	559	520	21	コウ	にじ	Little is it known that a<strong> rainbow</strong> is actually created by <em>insects</em> of different colours flying in formation, a <em>craft</em> they have perfected to create the<strong> rainbow</strong>s we see today.	<strong>Rainbow</strong> is of course created by billions of colored <em>insects</em> (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the <em>insect</em> primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this:<strong> rainbow</strong> is an <em>Insect-Craft</em>. Mnemonic: <strong>I.C.<strong> Rainbow</strong></strong> (I see<strong> rainbow</strong>).	For my arts and CRAFTs project at school, I made a<strong> rainbow</strong> out of dead BUGs spray painted different colors and glued to some paper. The teacher was not amused.	I see<strong> rainbow</strong>. I.C.<strong> rainbow</strong>. Insect Craft<strong> Rainbow</strong>.	"You know Skittles, ""Taste the<strong> RAINBOW</strong>""? The colorant that gives red Skittles their deep crimson color comes from crushing a type of <em>insect</em> called cochineal. So the next time you taste the<strong> RAINBOW</strong>, remember that you're really tasting <em>insects</em> <em>crafted</em> into sweets. (See: <a href=""http://snopes.com/food/ingredient/bugjuice.asp"">http://snopes.com/food/ingredient/bugjuice.asp</a>)."		
蝶		butterfly	Insect . . . generation . . . tree.		15	560	521	21	チョウ		A<strong> butterfly</strong> is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.	"Tip: New primitive: Let <em>Tarzan</em> = <em>generation</em> + <em>tree</em> – because <em>Tarzan</em> lives with several <em>generation</em>s of his family at the top of a <em>tree</em>. (This combination appears five times: <a href=""../v4/228.html"">leaf</a> (#228 葉),<strong> butterfly</strong>, (FRAME 521), <a href=""../v4/2158.html"">chatter</a> (#2158 喋), <a href=""../v4/2726.html"">secret agent</a> (#2726 諜), <a href=""../v4/2926.html"">label</a> (#2926 牒)). Story: You see <em>Tarzan</em> swinging from tree to tree chasing an <em>insect</em>. Later he shows it to you neatly pinned into his<strong> butterfly</strong> collection."	Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).	If an ugly <em>insect</em> can spend many <em>generations</em> in a <em>tree</em>, it will emerge as a beautiful<strong> butterfly</strong>.	Imagine a tree which is weighed down, so much that its bending over, perhaps, by GENERATIONS of accumulated cocoons (this also helps place generation over tree). You know which INSECT is responsible: the<strong> butterfly</strong>.		
独		single	Think of this key word in connection with bachelorhood. The elements: <i>wild dogs</i> . . . <i>insect</i>.		9	561	522	21	ドク、トク	ひと.り	The bachelor's apartment looked like it had been attacked by a <em>pack of wild dogs</em>. There were even <em>insects</em> in the kitchen. No wonder he's<strong> single</strong>!	A<strong> SINGLE</strong> guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.	I'm telling you, <em>A pack of wild dogs</em> were taken down by a<strong> SINGLE</strong> <em>insect</em>!!! Shocking, I know.	Dawg, you're<strong> single</strong> cuz you got fleas in your hair!	The bachelor is<strong> single</strong> because he has a <em>pack of wild dogs</em> with <em>insects</em> (flees) instead of a nice dog.		
蚕		silkworm	<i>Heavens</i> . . . <i>insect</i>. Be sure to do something about the position of the two elements.		10	562	523	21	サン、テン	かいこ、こ	There are no <em>insects</em> in <em>heaven</em> - well, that is, except for <strong>silkworm</strong>s. What, do you expect Jesus to import his fancy robes from China?	In China it was believed that the<strong> silkworm</strong>s were <em>insects</em> sent from <em>heaven</em> because of the beautiful material they produced.	Imagine an <em>insect</em>, the<strong> silkworm</strong> descending from a <em>heavenly</em>, golden, cloud- filled sky on a single string of silk.	Heavenly bug.	The poor<strong> silkworm</strong> <em>insect</em> goes up to <em>heaven</em> after we boil its coccoon to take its silk.		
風		wind	<i>Windy</i> . . . <i>drops of</i> . . . <i>insects</i>. Hint: think of the last two primitives as representing a swarm of <i>gnats</i>, those tiny <i>drops of</i> pesky <i>insects</i>.		9	563	524	21	フウ、フ	かぜ、かざ-、-かぜ	They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of<strong> WIND</strong> that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.	The<strong> WIND</strong> usually carries things around in it - <em>drops</em> of rain or snow, and lots of <em>insects</em>.	Most people don't know that<strong> wind</strong> is actually created by a bunch of insects at the end of the earth. They wake up in the morning, twist their fitted blue baseball caps backwards (see it on top of their head?), and get to work flapping their wings as hard as they can, causing the<strong> wind</strong> shockwave to spread in all directions.	"Ever heard of the butterfly effect? All it takes is <em>one</em> flap of an insect's wings to alter the <em>wind</em> patterns around the world. <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butterfly_effect"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butterfly_effect</a>."	<em>Mediocre insects</em> get caught in the<strong> wind</strong>.		
己		self	The kanji carries the abstract sense of the <b>self</b>, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a <i>snake</i> - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, <i>oneself</i> (frame 36) and <i>I</i> (frame 17).	* As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the <i>snake</i> - of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the <i>snake</i> has in myth and fable.	3	564	525	21	コ、キ	おのれ、つちのと、な	"This kanji looks like the ""s"" of ""self"", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his ""self""."	When Superman looks at him<strong>self</strong> in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.	"I is<strong> self</strong> educated! I drawed this ""S"" all by myself!"	I can't believe I didn't think of this as a primitive before. What word starts with the letter 's' and ends up producing someone like your 'self' later on? Sperm. Sperm are wiggly, like a snake, Contain 記 written dna records of yourself into them like words on a page, 起 rise up and run out of the penis once they ejaculate. require wrapping to prevent having babies, 包 . The task master of the sperm, 改 , make up ya own story. 紀 an era is like a thread line of different sperm that conquered the days.	<em>SSSSSSSSelf!</em>.		
起		rouse	Run . . . snake.		10	565	526	21	キ	お.きる、お.こる、お.こす、おこ.す、た.つ	Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and<strong> ROUSE</strong> a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!	Nothing will<strong> rouse</strong> you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you've never run before!	"Yelling ""<em>Run!!!</em> <em>Snake!!!</em>"" is more than enough to<strong> rouse</strong> anyone nearby."	"I was having a nightmare that I was running from a snake when my mum<strong> rouse</strong>d me from my sleep. ""Wakey, wakey, run from snakey!""."	Whenever I<strong> rouse</strong> myself from bed, I find that all the blood has mysteriously <em>run</em> to my <em>snake</em>. (The same can be said for being a-roused!).

改		reformation	Pluralizing the <i>snake</i> and focusing on a single <i>taskmaster</i> may help recommend the image of Ireland's most famous <b>reformer</b>, St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the <i>snakes</i> from the land.		7	567	528	21	カイ	あらた.める、あらた.まる	The <em>taskmaster</em> of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a <em>snake</em> ) plans a <strong>reformation</strong> of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.	If you want to achieve the<strong> reformation</strong> of your <em>inner self</em> you have to control your desires and correct your flaws; in sum, be your own <em>self taskmaster</em>.	This is a Meiji<strong> reformation</strong> <em>taskmaster</em>, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a <em>snake</em> in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).	The<strong> Reformation</strong> was led by Martin Luther, regarded as a <em>serpent</em>-in-the-grass by the Catholic Church, but as a noble <em>taskmaster</em> by his followers. 改革 かいかく reform,<strong> reformation</strong>, innovation; 改札 かいさつ ticket gate; 改める あらためる to change, alter, reform, revise.	<em>Snake</em>s are so twisted that only the most skilled <em>taskmaster</em> can achieve their<strong> reformation</strong>.		
記		scribe	Words . . . snake.		10	568	529	21	キ	しる.す	A<strong> scribe</strong> writes down the <em>words</em> spoken by a <em>snake</em> (i.e. a lawyer).	<strong>Snakes</strong> have no hands. So, when a <strong>snake</strong> needs to write down something, it has to call in a <strong>SCRIBE</strong>, who will write down all the <strong>say</strong>ings of the <strong>snake</strong>.	This<strong> scribe</strong> was truely badass - to jot down <em>words</em>, he would grab the nearest <em>snake</em> and squeeze it's venom out of it's fangs and use it as ink.. no pen for this guy.	A<strong> scribe</strong> writes down the <em>words</em> using the <em>snakes</em> venom.	The<strong> scribe</strong>s of yore had no pens or paper. To transcribe <em>words</em> they had to train<em> snakes</em> to twist their bodies into letters as they were spoken to.

胞		placenta	Part of the body . . . wrap.		9	570	531	21	ホウ		Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely <em>wrapped</em> by the long piece of <em>flesh</em>, called a <strong>placenta</strong>, that once fed him.	<strong>Placenta</strong> is <em>flesh/part of the body</em> <em>wrapped</em> around the foetus.	<strong>Placenta</strong> is the flesh that wrapped around us when we were in the womb.	"胞子 , 共産党細胞 , 細胞核 , 同胞 ,<a href=""../v4/531.html"">placenta</a> (#531 胞)ホウ( 包 ) … Parts: 月 , 包 … Note: Not<strong> Placenta</strong>; that's 胎盤 <a href=""../v4/748.html"">womb</a> (#748 胎). 胞 is any body sac, of any living thing, including cells ( 細胞 ). … Story: A <em>Part of the body</em> that completely <em>wraps</em> something up: a cell, a <strong>placenta</strong>, a spore. "One possible pictograph for ""<strong>sow</strong>"" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow's legs."	When a mother pig nurses its piglets, we call it a SOW. 嫁		marry into	The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage: it is the <i>woman</i> who leaves her family for another <i>house</i>hold, thus <b>marrying into</b> a man's family.		13	581	542	21	カ	よめ、とつ.ぐ、い.く、ゆ.く	Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the <em>woman</em> feels more like she's married into the <em>house</em> than into a relationship.	Traditionally, it was the <em>women</em> who would <strong>marry into</strong> the <em>households</em> of their husband's families.	Imagine a beautiful <em>woman</em>, say Rihanna, being married inside your <em>house to a pig</em>, an actual pig. Your house is filled with her pig family dressed up like humans. 'I can't believe it, this beautiful woman is about to<strong> marry into</strong> a pig family right in my house!'.	婿嫁婚姻 : Four kanji related to marriage, all with the <em>woman</em> primitive. <strong>Bridegroom</strong>: for the honeymoon, he takes her to the <em>zoo</em> for a <em>month</em>. <strong>Marry into</strong>: since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the <em>house</em> than into a relationship. <strong>Marriage</strong>: is when she gets a new <em>family name</em> on one particular <em>day</em>. <strong>Matrimony</strong>: is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband <em>pent in</em> like a <em>dog</em>… 嫁 [よめ].	A poor woman marrying into the house of a real pig.

美		beauty	Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of <b>beauty</b> with a <i>large sheep</i>.		9	587	548	21	ビ、ミ	うつく.しい	I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of<strong> beauty</strong> is a <em>large</em> <em>sheep</em>.	A <em>Sheep</em> on top of a <em>dog</em> is NOT a <strong>beautiful</strong> thing.	Who is more beautiful, a <em>sheep</em> or a <em>st. Bernhard dog</em>? Imagine a big contest with many judges, then let the sheep win, since it is on top in the kanji (perhaps even let the <em>sheep</em> ride on the <em>st. Bernhard dog</em> because it won).	Sheep dogs are <strong>beautiful</strong> animals.	(Image: a bunch of <em>big sheep</em> in a<strong> beauty</strong> pageant, bikinis and evening dresses and all).		
洋		ocean	<i>Water</i> . . . <i>sheep</i>. Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for <i>sea</i>. (Frame 500).		9	588	549	21	ヨウ		This kanji refers to the <em>water</em>s of the Pa<em>sheep</em>hic<strong> ocean</strong>.	Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across <em>oceans</em> of <em>water</em> in order to recover the fleece of a certain <em>sheep</em>.	If you drop a <em>sheep</em> into an<strong> ocean</strong>, it will soak up all the <em>water</em> with its thick coat of wool.	When you look at the<strong> ocean</strong>, those little whitecaps look like <em>sheep</em> in the <em>water</em>.	<em>Sheep</em> are pretty absorbent. If you had a few billion <em>sheep</em> handy, you could drop them all into the<strong> ocean</strong> and soak up all of the <em>water</em>, thereby creating a big white fluffy <em>sheep</em><strong> ocean</strong>.

""We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you""."	<em>Say</em>!<strong> detailed</strong> <em>sheep</em>, not like that! DE-TAILED <em>sheep</em>. Got it?	Babe had to remember the<strong> detailed</strong> <em>words</em> of the <em>sheep</em> in order to get through to them. Anything less<strong> detailed</strong> and they will just act like crazy <em>sheep</em>.	The next time you can't sleep, instead of counting <em>sheep</em>, think of <em>word</em>y <em>sheep</em>, boring you with <strong>details</strong> of their mundane lives (baa, baa, baa, ………zzzzz). 詳しい (くわしい): knowledgeable,<strong> detailed</strong> 詳細 (しょうさい): details, particulars.	<strong>Detailed</strong> <em>words</em> must not be said <em>sheepishly</em>.		
鮮		fresh	Fish . . . sheep.		17	590	551	21	セン	あざ.やか	"The<strong> fresh</strong>est <em>fish</em> is caught in the middle of the night while most people are ""counting <em>sheep</em>."" (If you've ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean)."	"This one's easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased<strong> fresh</strong>. To remember which foods, take the first letter of<strong> fresh</strong>, ""F"", to stand for fish and the final sound of<strong> fresh</strong>, ""SH"", to stand for sheep:<strong> FreSH</strong>. It even puts the primitives in the right order."	"There was a fisherman living near the coast, who was also raising <em>sheep</em>. I like my FISH 'n' SHEEPS (chips)<strong> FRESH</strong>.	To keep your fish<strong> fresh</strong>, wrap them up in sheepskins.

羨		envious	<i>Sheep</i> . . . <i>water</i> . . . <i>yawn/lack</i>. Although this character looks rather simple, special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for <i>next</i>, which we learned in frame 510. Note, too, that the <i>water</i> comes UNDER the <i>sheep</i>, rather than on its own to the left.		13	592	553	21	セン、エン	うらや.む、あまり	A very thirsty sheep, who always <em>lacked</em> <em>water</em>, spends his days watching his fellow <em>sheep</em> (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very<strong> envious</strong> of their <em>water</em>.	<strong>Envious</strong> of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the <strong>sheep</strong> looks down in disgust at his own dry grass <strong>lacking water</strong>.	Some ppl have to try things like counting SHEEP or DRINKING a glass of water before they can sleep. Some other can just YAWN and fall asleep… you can be<strong> ENVIOUS</strong> of those one.	A <em>sheep</em> that <em>lacks </em> <em>water</em> is<strong> envious</strong> of those who have it.	Unlike cotton, wool is warm even when wet, because it wicks water away from the skin. Many animals have cool adaptations and abilities that I wish I had, but I am most<strong> envious</strong> of <em>sheep</em>, because even if they get wet on the outside, the <em>water</em> is <em>lacking</em> UNDERNEATH. (helps to remember the water-lack part goes on the bottom).		
差		distinction	Wool . . . craft.		10	593	554	21	サ	さ.す、さ.し	This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many <strong>distinctions</strong> playing <em>WoolCraft</em> (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).	The<strong> distinction</strong> between fine and common wool, is the <em>craft</em>smanship of the <em>wool</em>.	Noob players make no<strong> distinction</strong> between what games they play, whether it's the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of <em>Wool</em>-<em>craft</em>!	Since all sheep look alike, it is hard to make a<strong> distinction</strong> between them. You have to learn the <em>craft</em> of telling them apart by their <em>wool</em>.	"A<strong> distinction</strong> must be made between ""World of Warcraft"" and ""<em>Wool</em> over <em>Craft</em>.""."

唯		solely	Mouth . . . turkey.		11	595	556	21	ユイ、イ	ただ	"The <em>mouth</em> of a <em>turkey</em> is used<strong> solely</strong> for saying, ""Gobble."" """We can't prosecutre the murderer based<strong> solely</strong> on what comes from the mouth of this turkey!"" Imagine a turkey who witnessed a murder of his fellow kind (to be eaten) and trying to report it to the cops."	"To be remembered in conjunction with its virtual synonym ""only"". All we need to remember is this: ""only"" gets the <em>turkey</em>'s legs, and<strong> solely</strong> gets the rest of the <em>turkey</em>."	"Remember the episode of Friends, when no one except Joey wanted turkey for thanksgiving? Just picture him sitting there, with a huge <em>turkey</em> on the table in front of him, stuffing it in his <em>mouth</em>. If I recall correctly, he still had some space left for the desert!"		
堆		piled high	Soil . . . turkey.		11	596	2185	21	タイ、ツイ	うずたか.い	After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we<strong> piled high</strong> all the <em>turkey</em> corpses atop the <em>soil</em> of the farmyard.	During the <em>Turkey</em> Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don't recall that it actually happens every single year), <em>turkeys</em> are killed en masse, and their bodies are<strong> piled high</strong>. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of <em>dirt</em> is<strong> piled high</strong> right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.	The farmer awakes Thanksgiving morning to find huge mounds of dirt<strong> piled high</strong> in front all of his doors and windows. He can't get out. Clever turkeys.	<em>Soil</em><strong> piled high</strong> on top of a <em>turkey</em> with only it's gobbler sticking out.	The turkey is making a pile of soil (piled high) trying to hide its doo doo.

I always use<strong> SWEET OAK</strong> WOOD to add flavor to roasted TURKEY.	"無脊椎動物 , 脊椎動物 , 脊椎 , 椎骨 , 椎骨 , 椎茸 , <a href=""../v4/2505.html"">sweet oak</a> (#2505 椎) ツイ,しい … Tree now written ツイ. (mnemonic 2: Oak is Sweeter than Shiit~ake)."	The <em>turkey</em> liked to search for food under the<strong> sweet oak</strong> <em>tree</em>, believing that sweet grains would grow there.		
誰		who	Words . . . turkey.		15	598	2712	21	スイ	だれ、たれ、た	"Do you remember that song where they <em>say</em> ""<strong>Who</strong> let the <em>turkeys</em> out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble""?" 焦		char	Turkey . . . oven fire.		12	599	557	21	ショウ	こ.げる、こ.がす、こ.がれる、あせ.る	When I put the <em>turkey</em> over the <em>oven fire</em>, it always ends up being <strong>charred</strong> beyond recognition. I'm not a very good cook.	<strong>Char</strong> could be any meat over <em>oven fire</em>. So why is it a <em>turkey</em> in this kanji? Because<strong> char</strong>red <em>turkey</em> is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.	We see here the <em>roadrunner</em>, running so fast that it <strong>chars</strong> the ground beneath it, leaving a trace of <em>fire</em>.	Turkey is not very common in Japan. (found only in Subway sandwiches!) So when Japanese try to barbecue turkey on the grill, they always<strong> char</strong> the meat. <em>masaka!</em>.	Unfortunately, Ash Ketchum's<strong> char</strong>mander sucked so bad it devolved into a<strong> char</strong>turkey.<strong> Char</strong>mander has flames on its tail,<strong> char</strong>turkey has flames on its butt.		
礁		reef	Rocks . . . char.		17	600	558	21	ショウ		"<strong>Reef</strong>s are often formed from volcanic rock, or ""rock that has been charred""."	"Coral<strong> reef</strong>s are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like <em>charred stone</em>. For a picture illustrating this, see <a href=""http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg"">http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg</a>."	You may be familiar with this unfortunate natural phenomenon. The Coral <strong>Reef</strong>s are some of the most beautiful habitats in the world, full of color and life. However, recently due to overfishing, the <strong>reef</strong>s have been undergoing something called Coral Bleaching. The algae dies off, and the sun <em>chars</em> the coral, leaving nothing but a barren wasteland that looks like <em>charred rock</em>. The color is gone and all you have left is bone-dry, white <em>rocky charred</em> stuff.	A turkey gets stoned on<strong> reef</strong>ers to prepare itself for the oblivion of the oven.	This character illustrates ancient ideas about the origin of coral <strong>reefs</strong>. Although we now know that coral are in fact marine organisms, the ancients thought that <strong>reefs</strong> looked like a gigantic pile of <em>stones</em> that had been <em>charred</em>.

雌		female	This character for <b>female</b> forms a pair with that for <i>male</i>, which we will learn later (Frame 804). "Tip: <em>stop/footprint</em> + <em>spoon</em> : This combination of primitives appears seven times in Heisig, including as a separate character, which he names <a href=""../v4/2043.html"">this here</a> (#2043 此). REF: feminine/female (FRAME 563), <a href=""../v4/1375.html"">purple</a> (#1375 紫), <a href=""../v4/2044.html"">brushwood</a> (#2044 柴), <a href=""../v4/2045.html"">fort</a> (#2045 砦), <a href=""../v4/2046.html"">whit</a> (#2046 些), <a href=""../v4/2047.html"">beard</a> (#2047 髭)."	Oh I love this one, it's so silly but fun to picture. Imagine a turkey walking in the snow (in the North pole for example) wearing spoons for snowshoes. Turkeys have small feet so they can use spoons as snowshoes, right ? Now you're looking down at the footprints left by the spoon-wearing turkey who is walking off in the distance, and you think to yourself that those footprints look feminine : curvy and slender.	"Mother to daughter - 'You are not a 雌 （めす） <strong>female</strong> animal! Now <em>stop</em> <em>sitting on the ground</em> with those <em>turkeys</em>; its not <strong>feminine</strong>!'———–Building from Katsuo's tip about how (<em>stop spoon</em>) is used often and later becomes (FRAME 2043)=<em>This here</em>； used for the words ここ、これ＆この maybe we should imagine the daughter｀s name is <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%81%93%E3%81%93%EF%BC%9D%E6%AD%A4"">ここ＝此</a> ."

奮		stirred up	St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.		16	607	565	21	フン	ふる.う	The <em>St. Bernard dog</em> pounces on a <em>turkey</em> in a <em>rice field</em> and <strong>stirs up</strong> all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?	Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The <em>St. Bernard</em><strong> stirred up</strong> a crowd of <em>turkeys</em> and caught one. It bit the head, <em>brains</em> spilling onto the <em>rice field</em>.	"Calling my brother/sister ""<em>big turkey brains</em>"" gets her real<strong> stirred up</strong>." (He also<strong> stirred up</strong> a lot of dust). 奪		rob	Whereas <i>burglary</i> (Frame 381) implies clandestine appropriation of another's property, <b>robbery</b> refers to taking by force. The primitive elements: <i>St. Bernard dog</i> . . . <i>turkey</i> . . . <i>glue</i>.		14	608	566	21	ダツ	うば.う	Don't let the neighbor's <em>St.Bernard</em> <strong>rob</strong> tonight's <em>turkey</em>….<em>glue</em> it to the table if you must.	Remember the scene in <strong>A Christmas Story</strong> where the <em>big dogs</em> <strong>robbed</strong> the family of their Christmas <em>turkey</em>? Well, the following year Ralphie's mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.	"The turkey and a St.Bernard dog are going to<strong> rob</strong> a bank. The turkey first, the dog behind him. When they approach the bank the turkey pulls out a tube of glue and says, ""Remember Dawg, it's a<strong> rob</strong>bery, whatever happens we gotta stick together."	The poor <em>turkey</em> was<strong> rob</strong>bed of its virginity when the smart <em>St. Bernard Dog</em> <em>glued</em> its feet to the ground and then pounced on top of it! Disgusting? Yes… easy to forget the story and its primitive order? You decide.	A giant turkey just<strong> rob</strong>bed me- with a glue gun!		
確		assurance	"On the left you see the <i>rock</i>, which is familiar enough. But pay attention to the right. Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the ""chimney"" on the <i>house</i> doubled up with the first stroke of the <i>turkey</i>, we may see the right side as a <i>turkey house</i> (or ""<i>coop</i>""). We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion (Frame 2093), but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive."		15	609	567	21	カク、コウ	たし.か、たし.かめる	To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!	"You've heard the expression ""killing two birds with one stone."" ( 一石二鳥 <em>is-seki-ni-chou</em>). We'll, there's another one that roughly translates as ""killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. "" That's the method that hunters use when they want absolute<strong> assurance</strong> of taking home a bird."	I <strong>assure</strong> you, the <em>rock</em> is big enough to keep the <em>turkey</em> inside the <em>house</em>. And if that's not enuff, I'll tie the tail of the <em>turkey</em> to the chimney.	I assure you, I promise a thousand times over–this rock will be strong enough to keep the killer turkeys inside their turkey house. Stop worrying, I assure you this will work!	If you use <em>stone</em> to build your <em>turkey house</em>, you will have a much better<strong> assurance</strong> that it will last longer.		
午		noon	With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftwards in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of <b>noon</b>. Note how this kanji primitive differs from that for <i>cow</i> (Frame 260).	* As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a <i>horse</i>. Any <i>horse</i> image will do, except that of a <i>team of horses</i>, which will come later (Frame 2132) and get its own primitive.	4	610	568	21	ゴ	うま	<strong>Noon</strong> is a good time for a <em>ten</em> minute <em>nap</em> (using lie down as nap).	<strong>Noon</strong> is a good time to <em>lie down</em> for <em>ten</em> minutes or so.	<strong>Noon</strong> is the hour of the horse.	At<strong> noon</strong>, the cow's head got chopped off. He had to be replaced by the horse.	<strong>Noon</strong> is a good time to <em>lie down</em> for a <em>ten</em> minute nap. (Especially after eating like a <em>horse</em> for lunch.) 午後 【ごご】 (afternoon; p.m); 午前 【ごぜん】 (morning; a.m.).		
許		permit	Words . . . horse.		11	611	569	21	キョ	ゆる.す、もと	If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.	Mr Ed ( a famous talking <em>horse</em> ) was finally at a loss for <em>words</em> when told he would need a<strong> permit</strong> for public speaking.	Everyone knows that a driver's license has some <em>words</em> on the left and your picture on the right. A <em>horse</em>-riding<strong> permit</strong> looks just like a driver's license, except to the right of the <em>words</em> there's a picture of the <em>horse</em> instead of a picture of you.	To <em>speak</em> to me at <em>noon</em> you need a<strong> permit</strong> because I'm eating lunch.	You have to whisper sweet <em>words</em> to the <em>horse</em> before she<strong> permit</strong>s you to ride her.		
歓		delight	"Again I cannot resist sharing my own associations. If you've ever seen Disney's animated interpretation of classical music, ""Fantasia,"" you will recall what was done there with Beethoven's ""Pastoral Symphony"" (the 6th), and the <i>flying horses</i> that figured in it. The mares are bathing in the stream and the stallions begin to gather. As dusk sets in, the <i>flying horses</i> all start <i>yawning</i> and pair off for the night: a perfectly <b>delightful</b> portrait of <b>delight</b>."		15	612	570	21	カン	よろこ.ぶ	Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her<strong> delight</strong> when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday… and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly… hence the yawn.	I would be<strong> delight</strong>ed if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.	A <em>lack</em> of <em>flying horses</em> is a <strong>delight</strong> to those on the ground who get hit with the <em>flying horse</em> poop.	I would be<strong> delight</strong>ed to see an actual <em>pegasus</em>. The world <em>lack</em>s their kind, and is the poorer for it. 歓声 (かんせい) : cheer, shout of joy; 歓迎 (かんげい) : welcome, reception..	Malfoy<strong> delight</strong>s in the lack of hippogriffs (pegasus).		
権		authority	Tree . . . Pegasus.		15	613	571	21	ケン、ゴン	おもり、かり、はか.る	I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”. 観		outlook	Pegasus . . . see.		18	614	572	21	カン	み.る、しめ.す	Microsoft<strong> Outlook</strong> works about as well as a pegasus that can't see: they both crash all the time.	I used to hate birds.They're loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a <em>pegasus</em>. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to <em>look</em> up. I <em>saw</em> it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my<strong> outlook</strong> completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.	This kanji actually means <strong>view</strong>. While on a pegasus you will see a great <strong>view</strong>.	You see a Pegasus flying far above, and wonder what your<strong> outlook</strong> on life would be if you could see what the Pegasus sees.	You can see an amazing<strong> outlook</strong> when riding a pegasus.		
羽		feathers	From the pictograph of two bird-wings, we get <b>feathers</b>.	* The related image of <i>wings</i> can be added as a primitive meaning. It can also take the form <sup>ョョ</sup> when used as a primitive, as we shall see in frames 618 and 619.	6	615	573	21	ウ	は、わ、はね	Pictograph. Easy enough.	These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their<strong> FEATHERS</strong>.	Two wings full of<strong> feathers</strong>.	"Just noting how I use this as a primitive. When it's in this full form, containing the ""ice"" element, I try to think of it as <em>penguins</em> or flightless wings. When it's the variant with straight lines, then it's <em>feathers</em> or flying wings."	This is a picture of two exact<strong> feathers</strong> of the ice bird.		
習		learn	Feathers . . . white bird.		11	616	574	21	シュウ、ジュ	なら.う、なら.い	Imagine a white bird loosing a <em>couple feathers</em> as it is<strong> learn</strong>ing to fly. "Little birds with <em>white feathers</em> still have a lot to<strong> learn</strong>. When their plumage will be mature enough they'll be ready to fly away. I'm<strong> learn</strong>ing to fly…but I ain't got wings…..I just got two feathers….on top of some white thing….

The first thing a bird must do is learn how to <em>stand</em>.<strong> The following</strong> thing it must learn is how to use it's <em>wings</em> to fly.	Help, a flying vase is following me!
