曜		weekday	Day . . . feathers . . . turkey.		18	618	576	21	ヨウ		"Tip: <em>feathers</em> + <em>turkey</em> : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""<em>futon</em>"" (your <em>futon</em> is made from <em>turkey feathers</em>). REF: <em>weekday</em> (FRAME 576) , <a href=""../v4/577.html"">laundry</a> (#577 濯), <a href=""../v4/1285.html"">leap</a> (#1285 躍), <a href=""../v4/2272.html"">outstanding</a> (#2272 擢), <a href=""../v4/2534.html"">twinkle</a> (#2534 燿), <a href=""../v4/2880.html"">shimmering</a> (#2880 耀). Story: On<strong> weekday</strong>s you hang your <em>futon</em> out in the <em>sun</em>."	The poor farmer spends every<strong> weekday</strong> while the <em>sun</em> shines, plucking <em>turkey</em> <em>feathers</em>.	On the<strong> weekday</strong>s, turkeys have to go to work. What do they do at work? Well, just strut their feathers. (It's an easy gig.).	I have a terrible job, on<strong> weekday</strong>s all I do all <em>day</em> is to pluck the <em>feathers</em> from <em>turkeys</em>. Its especially busy around christmas.	Every <strong>day of the week</strong>, I let the <em>sun</em> shine on on my <em>futon</em> so it will be warm by bedtime.		
濯		laundry	Water . . . feathers . . . turkey		17	619	577	21	タク	すす.ぐ、ゆす.ぐ	At the<strong> laundry</strong> you stuff your large <em>futon</em> (made from <em>turkey feathers</em>) in the machine, thereby causing it to break – as shown by the <em>water</em> spurting out the side.	When turkeys do the<strong> laundry</strong>, they put their feathers in water (they don't have clothes).	Wednesday is <strong>laundry</strong> day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 水 + 曜 = 濯 + 日 .	My <em>futon</em> (thanks Katsuo) is in the<strong> laundry</strong> because I <em>wet</em> the bed.	To do the<strong> LAUNDRY</strong> I just stick my <em>futon</em> in the water.. It never really gets that dirty anyway.. (Thanks Katsuo :-) I like the 'futon' idea).		
曰		sayeth	<i>Pent in</i> . . . <i>one</i>. The key word refers to famous sayings of famous people, and is the origin for the primitive meaning of <i>a tongue wagging in the mouth</i> that we learned in frame 12. The size of this kanji, a relatively rare one, is what distinguishes it from <i>day</i>.		4	620	578	22	エツ	いわ.く、のたま.う、のたま.わく、ここに、ひらび	"""Sayeth""?! Who the hell says ""sayeth""? Doesn't seem quite right…just like this kanji, which is just like ""day"" but doesn't seem ""quite right.""."	When <em>pent up</em> alone, <em>one</em><strong> sayeth</strong> little.	"So I don't mix with <a href=""../v4/1117.html"">speaketh</a> (#1117 申).<strong> Sayeth</strong> rhymes with dayeth."	So<strong> SAYETH</strong> we all. They are pent in on galactica, as one family.	One pent up tongue<strong> sayeth</strong> little.		
困		quandary	Pent in . . . trees.		7	621	579	22	コン	こま.る	I'm supposed to make an enclosure for my <em>tree</em>, but if I use its <em>wood</em> for the enclosure, there won't be anything left to be <em>pent-in</em>. What a<strong> quandary</strong>!	Trees need space to grow. If you <em>pent in</em> a <em>tree</em>, it will be in quite a<strong> quandary</strong>!	You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a<strong> quandary</strong> – should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?	To solve a<strong> quandary</strong>, you have to think outside the <em>box.</em> For example, how do I get this huge Christmas <em>tree</em> into through the door?	"A<strong> quandary</strong> is a situation where you are <em>boxed in</em> without knowing what you <em>""wood""</em> do."		
固		harden	<i>Old</i> . . . <i>pent in</i>. Leave the people out of your story to avoid complications later when we add the element for person to form a new kanji (Frame 1047).		8	622	580	22	コ	かた.める、かた.まる、かた.まり、かた.い	Fossils are <em>old</em> things <em>pent in</em> that have<strong> harden</strong>ed.	Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was<strong> harden</strong>, which kept it <em>pent in</em> until it grew <em>old</em> enough to evolve into Butterfree..	An old<strong> harden</strong>ed criminal who is dying pent up in a prison cell.	If you're <em>old</em> and in a <em>box</em> then you've probably<strong> harden</strong>ed from rigor mortis.	If you keep it <em>pent in</em> the breadbox, <em>old</em> bread will surely<strong> harden</strong>.		
錮		weld	Metal . . . harden.		16	623	3013	22	コ	ふさ.ぐ	RTK supplement: <strong>weld</strong> (metal, harden) -<strong> weld</strong>ing the metal bars of a cage together, to <em>harden</em> the cage even more… nothing shall escape now!	You<strong> weld</strong> <em>metal</em> in the knowledge that it will <em>harden</em> again.	<strong>imprison</strong>: <em>Metal hardening</em> describes the method of <strong>imprisoning</strong> people in Star Wars by freezing them in carbonite. (The carbonite as used in Star Wars is a fictional substance and may or may not be metal, but I'll imagine it is.).	The <strong>imprisoned</strong> criminal grew <em>hardened</em> due to the many years he spent behind the <em>metal</em> bars in the prison.	By<strong> weld</strong>ing <em>metal</em> and then subjecting it to refrigeration, it will become very <em>hard</em> by the process known as annealing.		
国		country	Jewels . . . pent in.		8	624	581	22	コク	くに	In my<strong> country</strong> (England) the crown <em>jewels</em> are kept <em>pent-in</em> in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also <em>pent-in</em> (probably for trying to steal those <em>jewels</em>).	Just think of Japan, a<strong> country</strong> which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.	Think of a<strong> country</strong> that has “<em>pent in</em>” all of its <em>jewels</em> so they wouldn't go away. Maybe it was China and its great wall.	Japan was once a<strong> COUNTRY</strong> that went through a period of isolationism; it's JEWELS were PENT-IN and could not be traded.	Picture a map of the world showing all the different <strong>countries</strong> PENT IN with thick borders, each one with an image of a pile of JEWELS proportional to its wealth (like those cute little geography maps from elementary school).		
団		group	Glued . . . pent in.		6	625	582	22	ダン、トン	かたまり、まる.い	When you are admitted into a<strong> group</strong> like the Yakuza, you're well and truly done (だん) for. 因		cause	St. Bernard dog . . . pent in.		6	626	583	22	イン	よ.る、ちな.む	We once had a <em>dog</em> with big paws // and oh what great trouble he'd<strong> cause</strong> // we built a huge pen // to keep him <em>pent in</em> // and stop him from breaking more laws //.	Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the<strong> cause</strong> is that you kept the <em>dog</em> <em>pent in</em> the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.	The<strong> cause</strong> of the big bang (the ultimate<strong> cause</strong>) was a very <em>large</em> amount of matter <em>pent in</em> to a point in space.	<strong>Cause</strong> is a difficult key word, hard to associate with a concrete image. So let 'cause' be associated with 'first<strong> cause</strong>'. Let this be the big bang (not worry about what<strong> cause</strong>d <em>that</em>, since people can't decide what it is so it's no use for an image). The first<strong> cause</strong>, the big bang, is represented by having something <em>large</em> (the universe) <em>pent in</em> inside a tiny space. It's about to explode and<strong> cause</strong> EVERYTHING.	Our<strong> cause</strong> is to rescue the pent in St. Bernard.		
姻		matrimony	"<i>Woman</i> . . . <i>cause</i>. Think here of the ""state of <b>matrimony</b>"" and you will not confuse it with other characters involving marriage, one of which we have already met (Frame 581)."		9	627	584	22	イン		<strong>Matrimony</strong> is the state in which the <em>woman</em> has got you <em>pent</em> <em>in</em> like a <em>dog</em> so that you cannot go after other bitches.	Forget the heisig stuff for this one. To me it looks like a fat girl looking in a mirror and her reflection is skinny, this is how every fat girl should feel on her day of<strong> matrimony</strong>.	When the <em>woman</em> gets angry, she treats her man like a <em>pent in dog</em> (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It's a perfect metaphor for the state of<strong> matrimony</strong>.	<strong>Matrimony</strong> is a <em>cause</em> of <em>women's</em> suffering.	婿嫁婚姻 : Four kanji related to marriage, all with the <em>woman</em> primitive. <strong>Bridegroom</strong>: for the honeymoon, he takes her to the <em>zoo</em> for a <em>month</em>. <strong>Marry into</strong>: since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the <em>house</em> than into a relationship. <strong>Marriage</strong>: is when she gets a new <em>family name</em> on one particular <em>day</em>. <strong>Matrimony</strong>: is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband <em>pent in</em> like a <em>big</em> St. Bernard.		
咽		windpipe	Mouth . . . cause.		9	628	2159	22	イン、エン、エツ	むせ.ぶ、むせ.る、のど、の.む	"You can't breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your <em>mouth</em> to find the <em>cause</em>. The<strong> windpipe</strong> in your <em>mouth</em> is what <em>causes</em> you to breath.	"Let's break this kanji down further into a <em>mouth</em> and a <em>mouth with a dog in it</em>. Picture a T-Rex sitting in the waiting room of an Ear, Eye, and Throat Hospital. 園		park	Pent in . . . lidded crock . . . scarf.		13	629	585	22	エン	その	A nice picnic <em>pent up</em> in the<strong> park</strong>, with your <em>crock pot</em> and <em>scarf</em> (picnic blanket).	You're walking in the<strong> park</strong> and a little ways off the path there is a “pent in” lidded crock on a scarf. Just picture it and it should work. This time it's even more dangerous, because it's <em>pent in</em> the sandbox in the<strong> park</strong>, where children play. Who knows what could be inside! When wearing a nice <em>long kimono</em>, the best thing to do is to go visit the<strong> park</strong> (which is obviously hedged in), and show off your stuff.		
回		-times	"The suffix ""<b>-times</b>"" refers to a number of repetitions. Its elements: <i>a mouth</i> . . . <i>pent in</i>. Hint: you may find it more helpful to forget the primitives and think of one circle revovling inside of another."		6	630	586	22	カイ、エ	まわ.る、-まわ.る、-まわ.り、まわ.す、-まわ.す、まわ.し-、-まわ.し、もとお.る、か.える	Write <em>mouth</em> two<strong> -times</strong>.	Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).	A <em>pent in mouth</em> will curse many <strong>times</strong>.	Recursive <em>enclosure</em> of an <em>enclosure</em> of … how many times?	I've told you x <strong>times</strong> not to eat so many bagles (i love this kanji).		
壇		podium	<i>Soil/ground</i> . . . <i>top hat</i> . . . <i>-times</i> . . . <i>nightbreak</i>. With kanji as difficult as this one, it generally pays to toy with the various connotations of its primitives before settling on one image. Aim for as much simplicity as you can.		16	631	587	22	ダン、タン		A man on the<strong> podium</strong> announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a <em>top hat with dirt as many times</em> as you can by <em>nightbreak</em>.	Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of <em>soil</em> for a<strong> podium</strong>, when he wore his <em>top hat</em> and gave the speech he had practiced many <em>times</em> until <em>nightbreak</em>. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.	"A<strong> podium</strong> is a bit of raised <em>ground</em> where <em>top-hatted</em> ""important people"" go <em>around and around</em> making speeches until <em>nightbreak</em>."	Think of the movie <em>Ground</em> hogs day. The mayor in his <em>top hat</em> takes the<strong> podium</strong> and tries many <em>times</em> to get the ground hog to come out before <em>night break.</em>.	It's the oldest trick in the books. A filibuster! He's not going to give any <em>ground</em> no matter how many <em>times</em> you ask. He is just going to wear his <em>top hat</em> and speak until <em>nightbreak</em>.		
店		store	Cave . . . fortune-telling.		8	632	588	22	テン	みせ、たな	Try to remember all those<strong> store</strong>s from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.	The fortuneteller has a<strong> store</strong> in a cave.	The <em>cavemen</em> ask their <em>fortune-teller</em> about what the future will look like. He goes into a trance, and in it sees a convenience<strong> store</strong> - row after shiny row of completely incomprehensible products…	The first<strong> store</strong> was simply a <em>cave</em> used by a <em>fortune teller</em>.	The<strong> STORE</strong> is in a CAVE run by a really annoying FORTUNE TELLER who just wants to predict your future, preventing you from actually being able to buy anything.		
庫		warehouse	Cave . . . car.		10	633	589	22	コ、ク	くら	I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a<strong> warehouse</strong> to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.	Have you ever worked in a<strong> warehouse</strong>? It's like a giant metal <em>cave</em>. Watch out for that <em>forklift</em>!	With rents high and auto businesses failing, GM chose to use a <em>cave</em> as a<strong> warehouse</strong> for their unsold <em>cars</em>.	I have a secret<strong> warehouse</strong>, set in a cliff cave, with a beautiful view of a turquoise ocean. That's where I keep my Lambhorginis, Ferraris, etc.	This <em>cave</em> was meant to house a <em>car</em>, but is used as a<strong> warehouse</strong> for varios things… and stuff. If there were a car ( 車庫 ), it would make it a garage.		
庭		courtyard	Cave . . . courts.		10	634	590	22	テイ	にわ	When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the<strong> courtyard</strong>.	Back in caveman days, <em>courts</em> were held in <em>caves</em>. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the<strong> courtyard</strong> (the yard outside the <em>cave</em> <em>court </em>) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.	"A<strong> courtyard</strong> (as the name suggests) is a yard where <em>court</em> is held. However, due to frequent inclement weather, the <em>courts</em> were moved to a <em>cave</em>. Old habits die hard, however, and the name ""<em>court cave</em>"" never caught on; people still refer to it as a<strong> courtyard</strong>."	[Thanks to dingomick] The poor porter samurai, being stretched on the rack by order of the court, is being tortured in an ornate ceremonial<strong> courtyard</strong> featuring a large echoing cave, so that his screams are amplified as a warning to potential wrongdoers.	Als die <em>Höhle</em> unter dem <em>Gerichtshof</em> einbrach mußte man stattdessen im <strong>Garten</strong> recht sprechen.		
庁		government office	Cave . . . a spike.		5	635	591	22	チョウ、テイ	やくしょ	Some bureaucrats at a<strong> government office</strong> decided that the tunnels of <em>caves</em> need to get <em>street</em> signs, which are then <em>nail</em>ed to the walls of the <em>cave</em>.	"In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a ""government office"", it's actually a dungeon where they're dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall."	Because of his <strong>cave</strong>man instincts, Clinton tried to <strong>nail</strong> Monica L. in his <em>gov't office</em>.	The<strong> government office</strong> is on cave street.	Kafka portrayed a<strong> government office</strong> as a cavernous space with faceless bureaucrats <strong>nail</strong>ed to their desks.		
床		bed	Cave . . . tree.		7	636	592	22	ショウ	とこ、ゆか	The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a <em>tree</em> and in a <em>cave</em>. So these can be considered as<strong> bed</strong>s.	(based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a <em>tree</em> and in a <em>cave</em>. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a<strong> bed</strong>.	When you take a girl to<strong> bed</strong>, your <em>tree</em> goes in her <em>cave</em>.	The only good way to sleep in a <strong>bed</strong> in the wilderness is to chop down a <em>tree</em>, drag it into a <em>cave</em> and carve it up so you can have some shelter from the elements.	Draculas<strong> bed</strong> is a <em>wood</em>en coffin in a <em>cave</em>.

If it helps, this is the <b>hemp</b> marijuana comes from.		11	637	593	22	マ、マア	あさ	(Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin' a huge doob in a secret corner of the Bat<em>cave</em> where he nurtures his<strong> hemp</strong> <em>grove</em>). (All of this is true.) Unfortunately, because the USDEA is run by a bunch of morons that refuse to distinguish between it and marijuana, you can't get a permit to grow it and thus have to grow your<strong> hemp</strong> groves in a cave to avoid fines and prosecution.	The<strong> hemp</strong> grove is in the cave.		
磨		grind	Hemp . . . stone.		16	638	594	22	マ	みが.く、す.る	If you<strong> grind</strong> the <em>hemp</em> you are bound to get <em>stoned</em> quicker. """<strong>Grind</strong>,<strong> grind</strong>,<strong> grind</strong> the <em>hemp</em>, slowly with the <em>stone</em>""." 心		heart	This character, a pictographic representation of the <b>heart</b>, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.	* As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings. In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the <i>heart</i>.<br> To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, ⺖,  and means a wildly emotional <i>state of mind</i>. And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form ⺗, in which case we give it the meaning of a <i>valentine</i>.	4	639	595	22	シン	こころ、-ごころ、りっしんべん	(mature content: violence) I hung the<strong> heart</strong> of my victim with a <em>hook</em> and three <em>drops</em> of blood spattered me.	<strong>Heart</strong> needs three drops of blood to work.	Pictograph, see book.	こころ！.	When this primitive is on the left as <em>state of mind</em>, I had a hard time visualizing it. Thus I have created the following story. All the smartest people in the country were fed up with their state governments. These great <em>minds</em> joined together and created their own official <em>state</em>: the <em>state of Mind</em>. I visualize it as a small, sectioned off area with brains floating around. A scientific utopia.		
忘		forget	Perish . . . heart.		7	640	596	22	ボウ	わす.れる	You only truly<strong> forget</strong> her when she has <em>perish</em>ed in your <em>heart</em>.	To<strong> forget</strong> means that something perishes from your heart.	<em>Perish</em> my <em>heart</em> if I<strong> forget</strong> this kanji.	A <em>dead heart</em> is the only way to <strong>forget</strong> your love.	We keep the deceased in our hearts so as not to<strong> forget</strong>.		
恣		selfish	Second . . . heart.		10	641	3014	22	シ	ほしいまま	<strong>Selfish</strong> lover breaks your <em>heart</em> and moves on to the <em>next</em> lover. (And <em>yawns</em> with a <em>heart</em> of <em>ice</em> at your suffering).	A <strong>selfish</strong> person doesn't care about the <em>next</em> person's <em>heart</em>, only their own.	I'm born with two hearts? How lucky! Well I could donate one and save the life of someone else, but I'm one <strong>selfish</strong> bastard…. If my first one fails, I'll just move on to my <em>next heart</em>!	"His son is a spoiled, <strong>SELF-INDULGENT</strong> prima-donna, going from one venture to the <em>NEXT</em> (at daddy's expense, of course), whatever takes over his <em>HEART</em> at the moment. (Cf. <a href=""../v4/1590.html"">wish</a> (#1590 念))."	When I have trouble concentrating, it's like my <em>heart</em> runs off to some <em>next</em> <strong>arbitrary</strong> activity, rather than staying focused on what I'm working on!		
忍		endure	Blade . . . heart. <b>Endure</b> here means long-suffering patience.		7	642	597	22	ニン	しの.ぶ、しの.ばせる	A ninja must be able to<strong> endure</strong> the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the <em>blade</em> of his sword into the <em>hearts</em> of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (<em>ninja</em>) which is why I choose to use <em>ninja</em> as its primitive meaning.	忍び （しのび）Shinobi the 忍者 （にんじゃ）Ninja was able to <strong>endure</strong> the massacre of his family & horrors of his training by placing the way of the <em>blade</em> above the way of the <em>heart</em>.	To<strong> endure</strong> unrequited love is like living with a <em>blade</em> in your <em>heart</em>.	Someone with a <em>razor blade</em> stuck in their <em>heart</em> has to<strong> endure</strong> the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.	I doubt you can<strong> endure</strong> a blade in your heart for very long.		
認		acknowledge	Words . . . endure.		14	643	598	22	ニン	みと.める、したた.める	You are given a <em>speech</em> about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to <em>endure</em> the whole thing, because all you can do is<strong> acknowledge</strong>.	"I never read the ""acknowledgements"" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring <em>words</em> that i must <em>endure</em> reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :)."	"You would think that most <em>ninjas</em> (see previous frame) would<strong> acknowledge</strong> each other's presence with something like a silent nod. Imagine the consequences if, while raiding an enemy castle, one stupid <em>ninja</em> chose to<strong> acknowledge</strong> another by <em>saying</em>, ""HELLO!!""."	In Japan, people who make efforts to <em>endure</em> (gaman) can expect to receive <em>words</em> of<strong> acknowledge</strong>ment at some point. The ability to <em>endure</em> is so valued and respected in Japan that <strong>acknowlegement</strong> of some sort is virtually inevitable.	Some Oscar winners go on far too long with their acceptance speech. But we are expected to politely ENDURE their endless stream of WORDS as they<strong> acknowledge</strong> their colleagues and loved ones.		
忌		mourning	Snake . . . heart.		7	644	599	22	キ	い.む、い.み、い.まわしい	Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was<strong> MOURNING</strong> the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.	"You are<strong> mourning</strong> the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. – ""mourning feels like <em>snake</em>-bitten <em>heart</em>""."	<strong>Mourning</strong> is really self-pity. When someone mourns, it seems on the surface that they are feeling sadness for a lost loved one. In reality, they are feeling heavy-hearted because they themselves have permanently lost something very precious.	<strong>Mourning</strong> can feel like a constrictor SNAKE is squeezing your HEART to death.	When <em>Snake</em> finally killed Sniper Wolf, his <em>heart</em> was filled with<strong> mourning</strong>.

"Father: ""What are your<strong> intention</strong>s to my daughter?"". <em>Samurai</em>: ""I intend to give her my <em>heart</em>! (slices out his own heart and hands it over)."		
誌		document	Words . . . intention.		14	646	601	22	シ		This is quite simple: a<strong> document</strong> is a set of <em>words</em> describing your <em>intentions</em>. "A policeman stops you (in Japan) saying, ""<strong>Document</strong>s, please"". You: ""Er, I <em>intended</em> to bring them, but . . ."". 思		think	Brains . . . heart.		9	651	605	22	シ	おも.う、おもえら.く、おぼ.す	<strong>Think</strong> with your <em>brain</em> NOT your <em>heart</em>.	To<strong> think</strong> is to use your brain over your heart.	<strong>Think</strong>ing too much with our brains, and not enough with our hearts, leads to many of our life's pains and sorrows. This kanji reminds us that<strong> think</strong>ing, while an activity of the brain, should always have the support of the heart.	<strong>Think</strong>ing requires the <em>brain</em> and the <em>heart</em>.	<strong>Think</strong> with both your brain and your heart.		
恩		grace	Take <b>grace</b> in its sense of a favor freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: <i>cause</i> . . . <i>heart</i>.		10	652	606	22	オン		<strong>Grace</strong> here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a <em>big dog pent up in a small cage</em> and adopt him. That will <em>cause</em> a warm feeling in your <em>heart</em>!	This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause,<strong> grace</strong> is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a<strong> grace</strong>ful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.	<strong>Grace</strong> is when you give from your <em>heart</em> to serve a higher <em>cause</em>.	"A<strong> grace</strong> is a gift whose only <em>cause</em> for being given comes from the <em>heart</em>. WARNING: Do not confuse with <a href=""../v4/721.html"">graceful</a> (#721 淑) - this kanji and it's meaning have nothing to do with being<strong> grace</strong>ful."	<strong>Grace</strong> Kelly died be<em>cause</em> of her <em>heart</em> condition. I.e., her <em>heart</em> was the <em>cause</em>. It was because of all that dancing… that's how the story goes. But really, what happened is that she accidentally locked in her St. Bernard for 5 days without food, and when she came back home he ripped out and swallowed her heart.		
応		apply	"<i>Cave</i> . . . <i>heart</i>. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence ""<b>applies</b>."""		7	653	607	22	オウ、ヨウ、ノウ	あた.る、まさに、こた.える	"[bravo, scottamus!] To<strong> apply</strong> for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the <em>heart of the cave</em> past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say ""Those who don't make it to the <em>heart of the cave</em> need not<strong> apply</strong>.""."	In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will<strong> APPLY</strong> magic to fill his HEART containers.	"Heisig's keyword doesn't<strong> apply</strong> this kanji directly. 応用する （おうようする）means ""to<strong> apply</strong>"" as in <a href=""midori://search?text=%E5%BD%BC%E3%82%89%E3%81%AF%E6%96%B0%E3%81%97%E3%81%84%E7%A7%91%E5%AD%A6%E6%8A%80%E8%A1%93%E3%82%92%E3%81%9D%E3%81%AE%E7%94%A3%E6%A5%AD%E3%81%AB%E5%BF%9C%E7%94%A8%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F%E3%80%82"">彼らは新しい科学技術をその産業に応用した。</a> ""They applied new technology to the industry."" The most common translation of 応 (on it's own without 用 ) might be ""respond"". As in responding to a question or responding to a situation. Story: Men are <em>CAVE</em>men at <em>HEART</em>. When confronted by emergency situations they RESPOND by<strong> APPLY</strong>ING their primitive power."	Said the doctor: Usual rules<strong> apply</strong>. If you<strong> apply</strong> too much force the <em>heart</em> will <em>cave</em> in.	Batman applied himself to catwoman deep in the <em>heart</em> of bat <em>cave</em>.		
意		idea	Sound . . . heart.		13	654	608	22	イ		When you get a good<strong> IDEA</strong> you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard.	Picture someone who's just had a great<strong> idea</strong>, but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a <em>heart</em> thumping with great <em>noise</em>. Imagine the greater the<strong> idea</strong>, the louder the <em>sound</em> of the beating <em>heart</em>.	The best<strong> idea</strong>s are <em>sound</em><strong> idea</strong>s that come right from the <em>heart</em>!	The Frenchman René-Théophile-Hyacinthe Laennec is best known for a great<strong> idea</strong> he had in 1816, when he invented a device to listen to the <em>sound</em> of a patient's <em>heart</em>: the stethoscope. Until then, doctors simply put their ears against people's chests, which was ineffective for overweight patients and embarrassing for female patients. Laennec's<strong> idea</strong> was so great that doctors still rely on it today.	A good <strong>idea</strong> will always <em>sound</em> right in your heart.		
臆		cowardice	Flesh . . . idea.		17	655	2460	22	オク、ヨク	むね、おくする	<strong>Cowardice</strong> is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your <em>flesh</em> is a good <em>idea</em>.	<strong>Cowardice</strong> is when you are not willing to sacrifice your <em>flesh</em> for your <em>ideas</em>.	"A real brave person would never put their <em>flesh</em> before their <em>ideas</em>. That's why so many people have been killed - for example, in China, where people showed<strong> cowardice</strong> in the face of capitalism. They weren't willing to put their <em>flesh</em> behind their <em>ideas</em>. Note that <em>flesh</em> is the ""strong"" or ""main"" radical in this kanji, which lets you know that this person is emphasizing <em>flesh</em>, and thus, exhibiting <em>cowardice</em>."	"""Er, I've got a good <em>idea</em>, let's hide on the <em>moon</em>"" says the <strong>cowardly</strong> Shaggy in Scooby Doo ( 臆病な )."	"Man 1: ""Hey, enough with the dumb ideas!"" Man 2:""Dumb ideas?! I am just trying to save our flesh!"" Man 1: ""You coward!""."		
想		concept	"To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the ""con-"" in the word ""<b>concept</b>."" Its elements are: <i>inter-</i> . . . <i>heart</i>."		13	656	609	22	ソウ、ソ	おも.う	The<strong> concept</strong> of love is basically two <em>hearts</em> <em>inter</em>-acting as one.	<em>''Inter-heart''</em> is a new therapy <em>CONCEPT</em> that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.	Newton realised the<strong> concept</strong> when he was sitting under a <em>tree</em>, and an apple smacked him in the head. He stood up, <em>eyes</em> wide, <em>heart</em> racing, for he had discovered gravity!	When you find a<strong> concept</strong> that really moves you, such as the <strong>concepts</strong> of mercy, forgiveness and compassion, the reason they do so is the fact that the mental component of these <strong>concepts</strong> <em>inter-</em>act with your <em>heart</em> (to avoid mixing up the keywords for idea and<strong> concept</strong>, remember: <em>sound</em> idea, <em>inter-</em>esting<strong> concept</strong>).	When you finally manage to explain a difficult<strong> concept</strong> to someone, it feels as if your <em>hearts</em> are <em>inter-</em>connected.		
息		breath	Nose . . . heart.		10	657	610	22	ソク	いき	Your<strong> breath</strong> brings oxygen in through your <em>nose</em> which is then pumped around your body by your <em>heart</em>.	I think I've met my dream girl, but there's a problem. her<strong> breath</strong> is horrible! So, do I listen to my <em>nose</em> or my <em>heart</em>?	"From Genesis 2:7 (NKJV): Creating man. God ""breathed into his <em>nostrils</em> the<strong> breath</strong> of life and the man became a living being."" (can't you see his <em>heart</em> start pumping?)."	<strong>BREATH</strong> brings oxygen from your <em>nose</em> to your <em>heart</em>.	Someone has almost drowned. We plug their NOSE as we<strong> breath</strong> into them, then listen to see if the HEART starts beating.		
憩		recess	<i>Tongue</i> . . . <i>nose</i> . . . <i>heart</i>. The sense of <i>breath</i> from the last frame should not be used; it could lead you to put only the <i>nose</i> over the <i>heart</i> and leave the <i>tongue</i> off to one side.		16	658	611	22	ケイ	いこ.い、いこ.う	<strong>Recess</strong> to me is a school break. At<strong> recess</strong> some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. <em>Tongues</em> and <em>noses</em> are nothing special. The new cool is to have your <em>heart</em> done!	At<strong> recess</strong>, little boys stick their <em>tongues</em> out and pick their <em>noses</em> while little girls draw <em>hearts</em> on the ground with chalk. It's winter now, so any <em>tongues</em> –left– out for too long will freeze.	Ah<strong> recess</strong>; <em>tongues</em> slandering, <em>noses</em> being turned up, and beneath it all, young <em>hearts</em> being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of <em>tongues</em>, which helps me remember that in this kanji <em>tongue</em> comes first.	The<strong> recess</strong> is a remote place for meditation. You sit meditating with other monks, breathing though your nose, holding your tongue (keeping quiet), and finding peace in your heart.	"At<strong> recess</strong>…tongues flapping , noses running, hearts racing. wheeee! 休憩 きゅうけい　Imagine the skinny teacher from The Simpsons saying ""we're gonna have<strong> recess</strong> now children, nnnkay"". けい."		
恵		favor	<i>Ten</i> . . . <i>fields</i> (or: <i>needle</i> . . . <i>brains</i>) . . . <i>heart.</i>		10	659	612	22	ケイ、エ	めぐ.む、めぐ.み	Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three<strong> FAVOR</strong>S: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?	"If you would give someone 10 fields as a<strong> favor</strong> then you truly have a big heart. Or, people who do lots of<strong> favor</strong>s for others have a heart as big as 10 fields, a ""10-field-heart""."	"""Igor, do me a<strong> favor</strong>: go down to the morgue and pick me up <em>ten</em> <em>brains</em> – oh, and a <em>heart</em>, if they have any fresh!""."	-Do me a<strong> FAVOR</strong>, give me TEN FIELDS (I am talking to someone who owns a lot of fields), and I will thank you from my HEART !	"""Ten fields and my heart for my lady's<strong> favor</strong>!"" cried Lord Fancypants."		
恐		fear	Craft . . . mediocre . . . heart.		10	660	613	22	キョウ	おそ.れる、おそ.る、おそ.ろしい、こわ.い、こわ.がる	"If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to<strong> fear</strong>. (""Oops, I think I left my scissors in there"")."	My deep dark<strong> fear</strong> at the bottom of my <em>heart</em> is that I am <em>mediocre</em> at my <em>craft</em>.	Some have called the US the culture of<strong> fear</strong>.<strong> Fear</strong> is a craft that mediocre leaders use to control the hearts of the populace.	I have an unusual<strong> fear</strong> - when I'm sleeping, the <em>mediocre I-beam</em> above my bed will fall and crush my <em>heart</em>. The builder was certainly mediocre, the I-beam is not even quite straight! Could fall any time…	<strong>Fear</strong> will <em>craft</em> a <em>mediocre</em> <em>heart</em>.		
惑		beguile	The first three elements, <i>fiesta</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>floor</i>, appeared together once already in frame 380. Beneath them, once again, the <i>heart</i>.		12	661	614	22	ワク	まど.う	She was <strong>beguiled</strong>/<strong>mislead</strong> by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the <em>mouth</em>, they did it on the <em>floor </em>and thus he stole her<em> heart</em>. Poor girl!	"The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to<strong> beguile</strong> women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts."	"I like to think of this character as Guile from Street Fighter 2, <strong>beguiling</strong> Chun Li at the <em>fiesta</em>. He kisses her on the <em>mouth</em>, they do it on the <em>floor</em>. Then, remembering his job, he rips out her <em>heart</em>, Mortal Kombat style. ""which character are you gonna be?"" ""I'm gonna <strong>be Guile</strong>"" (Partly inspired by nilfisq's)."	This kanji actually means <strong>BEWILDERED</strong>. At the fiesta, he was kissing the floor with all his heart. Everyone was <strong>bewildered</strong>.	At the fiesta I decided to<strong> beguile</strong> the crowd by performing a trick where I pull out my heart and throw it on the ground. It worked, their mouths hit the floor!		
感		emotion	Mouths . . . marching . . . heart.		13	662	615	22	カン		<strong>Emotion</strong> is a <em>march of mouths</em> inside your <em>heart</em> telling you what to feel.	Strong<strong> EMOTION</strong>S don't stay hidden. They march right out of one's <em>heart</em> (below) and out <em>one</em>'s <em>mouth</em> (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of<strong> emotion</strong> it is!).	When you get<strong> emotion</strong>al, words come marching out of your mouth from your heart, and it's impossible to stop them.	Picture a site that consists solely of emoticons (represented by the mouth) marching across the screen - you know, hundreds of them. Imagine how much this website would slow down your computer. At this point you might consider stabbing the site's creator in the heart. (inspired by taijuando).	Emoticons held a <em>march</em> to protest against their low status in communication. Along went all those <em>little mouths</em>, shouting as <em>one</em>, riding not on horses but big squidgy <em>hearts</em>, bouncing one pace with each beat. Sadly, many were 'tired and<strong> EMOTION</strong>al' (<em>euphemism for 'drunk' in the British Press</em>) and they all started squabbling, at which point the march fell apart.		
憂		melancholy	<i>Head</i> . . . <i>crown</i> . . . <i>heart</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i>. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of <i>head</i> with the top of the <i>crown</i> serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of <b>melancholy</b> figures should offer plenty of suggestions.)		15	663	616	22	ユウ	うれ.える、うれ.い、う.い、う.き	<strong>Melancholy</strong> makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so 'emo'. In order to play up his feelings he bares his <em>head</em> and holds his <em>crown</em> over his <em>heart</em> then walks (on <em>walking legs</em>) around the palace making everyone see how<strong> melancholy</strong> he is. What a wuss.	This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His <em>crown</em> of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his <em>head</em> and his <em>heart</em>. His <em>walking legs</em> can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How<strong> MELANCHOLY</strong>!	In the middle of <em>summer</em> you lose both your <em>crown</em> and your <em>heart</em>. No wonder you feel<strong> melancholy</strong>.	In the<strong> Melancholy</strong> of Suzumiya Haruhi, reality was all in her <em>head</em>, leading to situations where her melancholic feelings in her <em>heart</em> would be released into bubble-like <em>crowns</em> of negative space where they'd <em>walk around on their legs</em> and wreck havoc.	The most<strong> melancholy</strong> places of all is a funeral. This is a funeral for the Burger King guy, where everybody takes the paper <em>crowns</em> that they were given off of their <em>head</em> and covers their <em>heart</em> with it. <em>Each</em> person then uses their <em>walking legs</em> to come up to the casket and throw in a whopper.		
寡		widow	<i>House</i> . . . <i>head</i> . . . <i>dagger</i>. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the <i>dagger</i> that fits in beneath.		14	664	617	22	カ		The new<strong> widow</strong> sits in the <em>house</em>, her <em>head</em> in her lap (the extended stroke), her <em>dagger</em> in her husband.	The <em>house</em>'s <em>head</em>, her husband, was murdered with a <em>dagger</em>. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a<strong> widow</strong>.	Extending Megaqwerty's story, the<strong> widow</strong> sits in the house with her head leaned forward in her lap so that her long pig-tails are stretched out to the floor. In between her pig-tails lies the dagger used to kill her husband.	"The<strong> widow</strong> is <em>head of the house</em> now that she's been <em>part</em>ed from her husband. <a href=""../v4/781.html"">part</a> (#781 分)."	After I found my husband in the <em>house</em> with his <em>head</em> chopped off by a <em>dagger</em>, I realised I'd become a<strong> widow</strong>.		
忙		busy	State of mind . . . perish.		6	665	618	22	ボウ、モウ	いそが.しい、せわ.しい、おそ.れる、うれえるさま	"<strong>Busy</strong> (as in ""occupied"") means a <em>state of mind</em> where all other thoughts are <em>perished</em>."	"^^^Make the ""state of mind"" primitive <em>Data (from Star Trek)</em> instead right now and save yourself the headache; 'state of mind' is too vague! (<em>Data</em> can stay so <strong>busy</strong> as not to sleep without <em>dying</em>. He's a robot)."	"Some people who are workaholics say, ""I can rest when I'm dead."" That is the sort of state of mind a<strong> busy</strong> person has!"	Poor Japanese people are so<strong> busy</strong>. They work like 80 hour weeks! Slowly, you see them turn into automatons…their bodies still alive, but their <em>state of mind</em> like they've long ago <em>perished</em>… (Mental image: most stressed out salaryman you know.).	"As others have suggested, I personified ""state of mind"" as the android, Data from here on. He is constanly analysing humans and emotions, plus he has an overactive mind for good measure. — <em>Data's</em> is<strong> busy</strong> trying to understand why do humans <em>perish</em> (die). — (If it helps bring Data to mind, think of ""<em>Data</em>-base is<strong> busy</strong>, please try again later"")."		
悦		ecstasy	State of mind . . . devil.		10	666	619	22	エツ	よろこ.ぶ、よろこ.ばす	<strong>ECSTASY</strong> alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.	The state of mind that horny teenagers are looking for.	The <em>devil</em> sells <em>Data</em> some <strong>ecstasy</strong> saying it will make him, like, human, man.	"Someone offers you<strong> ecstasy</strong> at a rave party. Cool, logical <em>Data</em> is on one shoulder saying ""No, don't take it!"". The <em>devil</em> is on your other shoulder saying ""You know you want it!""."	Data was in a state of<strong> ecstasy</strong> on the holodeck when he loaded up the new program full of horny teenagers that he stole from Riker.		
恒		constancy	State of mind . . . span.		9	667	620	22	コウ	つね、つねに	<strong>Constancy</strong> is holding the same <em>state of mind</em> over a long <em>span</em> of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).	<em>Data</em> is the epitome of <strong>constancy</strong>. As a robot, his consistency <em>spans</em> the entire day.	A term used by Kant. Kant says that humans are preconditioned to experience the world in space and time, but God's mind has<strong> Constancy</strong>. That is, God's is a state of mind that spans all time and is not inhibited by it.	Imagine a giant field of grass where a man sits trying to abtain zen, he sit still as a statue, holding his fingertips against eachother, while the day and night (the <em>span</em>ning of the day) shoot pass you like in a 100000x forwarded movie. the seasons change but yet the man does not move. that whole picture combined gives me a feel of<strong> constancy</strong>.	"<em>Data</em> couldn't break the <em>span</em> of his<strong> CONSTANCY</strong> of his <em>state of mind</em> (ooh double reinforcement) if he tried. Just watch: <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mMWoaHyIKMs"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mMWoaHyIKMs</a> See? He is serious from dusk to dawn. He can't break that serious look for one moment."		
悼		lament	To keep this character distinct from others of similar connotation, one need only think of the Prophet Jeremiah whose poetry gave an <i>eminence</i> to <i>the state of mind</i> we call <b>lamentation</b>.		11	668	621	22	トウ	いた.む	When the world's most <em>eminent</em> magician died, everyone's <em>state of mind</em> became that of<strong> lament</strong>ation. He was buried with his famous sun-flower wand in his hand.	<em>Data</em><strong> lament</strong>s that he could never see his <em>eminent</em> father, his creator, ever again. He paints a picture of his father, that looks like a sunflower in the shape of a magic wand.	Closely related to grief, mourning and regret, it was difficult for me to isolate this kanji. A<strong> lament</strong> is a song or poem that deals with loss or regret. This brings to mind the works of the world's most <em>eminent</em> artists, their brilliance and powerful works owed to their <em>emotional states of mind</em>.	<strong>Lament</strong> is the <em>state of mind</em> most <em>eminent</em> people live in, because so many expectations lay on their shoulders.	Instead of using eminent - use its components - <em>divining rod</em> and <em>sunflower</em>. Think of the current state of the environment symbolized by the sunflower and use the divining rod to see the possible future - pollution, global warming, overpopulation - we have a lot to<strong> lament</strong>.		
悟		enlightenment	"I know of an Indian religious sect which teaches that <b>enlightenment</b> is to be had by covering the eyes with one's index fingers, the ears with the thumbs, and the mouth with the little fingers. While these differ a bit from the <i>five holes</i> that we used to represent the ""<i>I</i>"" (frame 17), the idea of achieving a special <i>state of mind</i> by covering those five places can help you learn this kanji. You might try the position out while you are learning this character."		10	669	622	22	ゴ	さと.る	<strong>Enlightenment</strong> is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.	"<em>Data</em> finds <strong>enlightenment</strong> when he discovers the answer to the question, ""Who am <em>I</em>?"". (Image: <em>Data</em> meditating in a sitting lotus position)."	Enlightment, a <em>state of mind</em> that <em>I</em> must find. Only <em>I</em> can find this <em>state of mind</em>.	What the hell is liosama talking about? (under me).	Heisig's was so perfect, getting all that saliva in on my pinkies after having been caught by my mother doing some absolutely stupid sign while looking at a book has shown her that i've reached enlightment too, she walked out. To be honest i would have rather been caught doing something less… obscure..		
怖		dreadful	State of mind . . . linen.		8	670	623	22	フ、ホ	こわ.い、こわ.がる、お.じる、おそ.れる	Someone in a<strong> dreadful</strong> <em>state of mind</em> has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (<em>linens</em>).	From the Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy:<strong> Dreadful</strong>: (n) The <em>state of mind</em> of a frood who doesn't have a <em>towel</em> at his side.	Being an android, <em>Data</em> is white as a <em>sheet</em>. Doctor Crusher always has to remind herself that this is perfectly normal. From a doctor's perspective, he really does look<strong> dreadful</strong>.	What would be your state of mind after seeing some linen animate and fly down a hallway (a ghost) ? Surely, full of dread. Hence,<strong> dreadful</strong>. Picture someone experiencing dread, trying to reach for the big switch on top of their head, to turn off their mind because they are so scared.	"<em>Data</em> goes to the holodeck and loads up <strong>dread</strong>. He's suddenly in a haunted gothic mansion, and a stereotypical ghost made of a mere <strong>linen sheet</strong> flies at him. ""I do not understand this human emotion of dread. This is merely a sheet"" he says."		
慌		disconcerted	State of mind . . . laid waste.		12	671	624	22	コウ	あわ.てる、あわ.ただしい	(re: wazzab) The <em>state of mind</em> of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city's concert hall <em>laid waste</em> can best described as<strong> disconcerted</strong>.	"When I am<strong> disconcerted</strong> my <em>state of mind</em> is ""<em>laid to waste</em>""."	"Data walks in and sees Picard weeping. ""What is the matter, Captain?"" Picard looks up, and replies that his entire home planet has been <em>laid to waste</em>. Data, the master of tact, offers up this consolation: ""Ah. I can see how that would be <strong>DISCONCERT</strong>ing"". It turns out that the <em>flow of tears</em> was really just because Picard had lost his chance at getting at some rare (and thus valuable) <em>flowers</em> on his home planet."	In this kanji we see a<strong> disconcerted</strong> as a mind which has been laid waste by a flood of contradicting information. Try to picture someone's head being flooded, looking left and right in disconcert, and the switch on top of their head turning on and off uncontrollably.	"<em>Data</em> was<strong> disconcerted</strong> to find that he had been <em>laid waste</em> in a robot scrap yard. ""This is very disconcerting"", he says in the calmest possible manner given his unfortunate predicament. Make sure you see him there, looking around trying to analyse how his Captain could have abandoned him."		
悔		repent	<i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>every</i> (See frame 497).		9	672	625	22	カイ	く.いる、く.やむ、くや.しい	"""For all have sinned…"" so <em>every</em>one's <em>state of mind</em> should be to<strong> repent</strong>."	When you<strong> repent</strong>, you heal your <em>state of mind</em> by going over <em>every</em> thing you regret doing.	<strong>Repent</strong>: the state of mind that everyone here will share when they get their 2000 star trek stories mixed up.	"Data in the confessional: the minister says ""repent every sin"". Unfortunately for the minister, Data has perfect memory storage, so he really<strong> repent</strong>s EVERY sin. ""On Jan 1, i stepped on a bacteria, on Jan 2 I forgot to put the toilet seat down…""."	"An evangelical minister screams at <em>Data</em> to, <strong>Repent</strong> of <em>every</em> sin!!"" Data just replies that there is not 'every' sin to<strong> repent</strong> from since as a robot, he cannot sin."		
憎		hate	State of mind . . . increase.		14	673	626	22	ゾウ	にく.む、にく.い、にく.らしい、にく.しみ	Like the saying goes,<strong> Hate</strong> just begets<strong> Hate</strong>. A state of mind that just increases and increases until it explodes.	Your <em>state of mind</em> would turn to<strong> hate</strong> when someone would take away a loved one that was <em>formerly</em> yours.	<em>Data</em>'s one true emotion is <strong>hate</strong> for <em>Prince's</em> music. (Image: Data hunched over hands to his ears and screaming while Picard bobs to Purple Rain).	<strong>Hate</strong> is the <em>state of mind</em> that turned the man who was <em>formerly</em> Anakin Skywalker into Darth Vader.	<strong>Hate</strong> is unfortunately a <em>state of mind</em> on the <em>increase</em> in today's society. You may picture<strong> hate</strong> as a green face with red eyes, multiplying wildly (see frame 501 “formerly”). If the mnemonic doesn't do the job, add the <em>state-of-mind</em> switch.		
慣		accustomed	State of mind . . . pierce.		14	674	627	22	カン	な.れる、な.らす	Some hardcore monks have a <em>state of mind</em> that has become<strong> accustomed</strong> to their self-torture through <em>piercing</em> themselves.	"It took him awhile, but Data finally got<strong> ACCUSTOMED</strong> to his <em>nipple/breast piercings</em>. They were constantly rubbing up against his shirt and his <em>heart-shaped locket</em>. Picture <em>Data</em>, shirtless, squeezing his nipples in front of Picard and saying ""Yes, at first they were a bit shelly, but I've grown quite<strong> ACCUSTOMED</strong> to them"". That last bit should do it for you."	At first I thought that seeing people getting so many piercings was gross, but as time goes by your state of mind gets<strong> accustomed</strong> to it.	The previous generations had the <em>state of mind</em> that <em>piercings</em> were outlandish, but now the general public has become<strong> accustomed</strong> to this practice.	Through a trained <strong>state of mind</strong> one can become<strong> accustomed</strong> to being <strong>pierce</strong>d by sharp objects.		
愉		pleasure	<i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>butchers</i> (See frame 307).		12	675	628	22	ユ	たの.しい、たの.しむ	At the <em>meeting of butchers</em>, in their narrow <em>state of mind</em>, they throw lame jokes around like, 'Oh hello, it's a<strong> pleasure</strong> to <em>meat</em> you', and find this rather pleasing.	Image : <em>Data</em> attending a <em>meeting of the butchers union</em>. As a joke to begin his speech he says, 'Its a <strong>pleasure</strong> to MEAT you all.' (thanx to Shibo & nestOr).	Manson? Bundy? Jack the Ripper? Whichever killer or <em>butcher</em> brings to mind the most graphic image (maybe a meeting of all of them?) - you won't forget this kanji as you peer into their deranged <em>state of mind</em>: can't you just see their vacant stares and smiles on their faces, while they takes great<strong> PLEASURE</strong> in plying their trade? Creepy.	A <em>meeting of butchers</em> has dissolved into an orgy of blood-squirting violence. But since the killing <em>state of mind</em> is the highest<strong> pleasure</strong> a butcher can experience, they are all smiles.	<strong>Pleasure</strong> is the state of mind when flesh meets flesh (especially when one flesh is sabre-like).		
惰		lazy	"<i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>left</i> (i.e. ""sinister"") . . . <i>flesh</i>."		12	676	629	22	ダ		When I am in a<strong> LAZY</strong> <em>state of mind</em> I use my <em>left</em> hand to play with my <em>meat</em>…it feels like someone else is doing it, which is good cause I'm to<strong> lazy</strong> to get a date.	When in a<strong> lazy</strong> state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.	This may only work for me, but I just think that the left side of my body is the<strong> lazy</strong> side. It sometimes takes over and puts my whole body in a<strong> lazy</strong> state of mind.	<em>Data</em> was just being <strong>lazy</strong> when he claimed the <em>left</em> side of his <em>body</em> had malfunctioned and he couldn't help.	"Picard notices that the Enterprise is off course, and shouts, ""<em>Data</em>! I told you to turn <em>left</em> at the <em>moon</em>! What happened?"" Data replies, with his characteristic eyebrow-raise, ""I don't know, sir. I just didn't feel like doing it. Is that what humans call….<strong> lazy</strong>?""."		
慎		humility	State of mind . . . truth.		13	677	630	22	シン	つつし.む、つつし、つつし.み	<strong>Humility</strong> is the <em>state of mind</em> of accepting the <em>truth</em> about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu's).	<strong>Humility</strong> is a state of mind when you consider yourself in accordance with the truth (you neither boast nor demean yourself).	<em>Data</em>, who is convinced he is perfect, is taught a lesson in<strong> humility</strong> when Riker shows him how to extract truth from someone by placing them on a <em>workbench</em> and poking them in the <em>eye</em> with a <em>needle</em>. Data just didn't understand how to play with the person's state of mind.	<strong>Humility</strong> is <strong>the state of mind</strong> of accepting the <strong>truth</strong> no matter how much you don't like it.	<em>Data</em> has great <strong>humility</strong> even though he knows more <em>truth</em> than any human.		
憾		remorse	"<i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>emotion</i>. Hint: the etymology of ""<b>remorse</b>"" indicates a memory that returns again and again to ""bite at"" one's conscience and disturb one's peace of mind."		16	678	631	22	カン	うら.む	<em>Remorse</em> is the <em>state of mind</em> where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and <em>emotional</em>!	"Tip: If you are confusing this keyword,<strong> remorse</strong>, with <a href=""../v4/625.html"">repent</a> (#625 悔) and <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1460"">regret/resentment</a> (#1460 恨), then note that<strong> rEMOrse</strong> contains EMOtion."	<em>Data</em> feels<strong> remorse</strong> for stealing the human <em>emotion</em> chip.	<em>Data</em> feels<strong> remorse</strong> for stealing the human <em>emotion</em> chip. So, he takes it out. Then his<strong> remorse</strong> is gone so he puts it back in.. Then he takes it out. This could go on for a while, couldn't it? (thanks jamiemw!).	This kanji shows<strong> remorse</strong> (regret) as a mind filled with emotions from the past, coming back to “bite at” one's conscience and disturb one's piece of mind.		
憶		recollection	State of mind . . . idea.		16	679	632	22	オク		<strong>Recollection</strong> is about bringing ideas back to your mind.	<em>Data</em>'s <strong>recollection</strong> powers are unparalled. He never loses a single <em>idea</em>.	I have no<strong> recollection</strong> of my <em>state of mind</em> from last night, dude… I must have been drunk or something. Do you have any <em>idea</em> what I did last night, man?	<strong>Recollection</strong> is the <em>state of mind</em> where one brings <em>ideas</em> back in one's mind.	<strong>Recollection</strong> is a <em>state of mind</em> where old <em>ideas</em> are contemplated.		
惧		disquieting	State of mind . . . tool.		11	680	3015	22	ク	おそ.れる	When sitting through laser eye surgery, the surgeon <em>stretches</em> open your <em>eye</em> with a tight-fitting <em>tool</em>. The thought of a laser cutting through the lens of your eye within moments, and possibly blinding you in the case of a mishap, makes for a very<strong> disquieting</strong> <em>state of mind</em>.	<strong>Disquiet</strong>: The feeling <em>Data</em> gets when they bring out the <em>eye-stretching</em> tool to try to give him emotions by forcing him to watch disturbing movies (like they did to Alex in A Clockwork Orange).	<strong>dread</strong>: Dread is the state of mind when you see the odd tool made of stretched human eyes.	What is all that racket!? My <em>state of mind</em> is <strong>disquieted</strong> by <em>extended tool</em> use!	<strong>Disquieting</strong> is the <em>state of mind</em> you get after seeing a table full of <em>tools</em> with little eyes staring at you.		
憧		yearn	Think of the <i>state of mind</i> you were in as a child with a particularly <i>juvenile</i> <b>yearning</b>.		15	681	2280	22	ショウ、トウ、ドウ	あこが.れる	A paedophile's <em>state of mind</em> is to<strong> yearn</strong> for <em>juveniles</em>. He really has to control this<strong> yearn</strong>ing. Picture Data looking wistfully at a computer and imagining himself standing on top of it in a thought bubble to the right.	<em>Data</em><strong> YEARN</strong>S for <em>juveniles</em>- bad robot!	The <em>state of mind</em> of a <em>juvenile</em> tends to<strong> yearn</strong> for things like fortune or fame.		
憬		hanker	State of mind . . . scenery.		15	682	3016	22	ケイ	あこが.れる	I'm in a <em>state of mind</em> where I <strong>desire</strong> to see the <em>sun</em> over the <em>capital</em> for some nice <em>scenery</em> for a change (no more rain!).	Think of a commercial designed at making you <strong>hanker</strong> for the product they're advertising. See how they cleverly use that <em>scenery</em> to put you in the <em>state of mind</em> they desire. I'm often in a <em>state of mind</em> where I <strong>desire</strong> to see some beautiful scenery. That's why traveling is necessary to keep me in a good <em>state of mind</em>.	The <em>scenery</em> of Texas puts <em>Data</em> in the <em>state of mind</em> to<strong> hanker</strong> for a Roy's roast beef burger.		
慕		pining	<i>Graveyard</i> . . . <i>valentine</i>. Note carefully the stroke order of the <i>valentine</i> primitive.		14	683	633	22	ボ	した.う	<strong>Pining</strong>, yearn for… etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the <em>graveyard</em>, placing an old <em>valentine</em> card amonst all the existing tributes.	Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their <em>Valentine's</em> Day at the <em>graveyard</em>,<strong> pining</strong> for each other's affection.	Remember the dead parrot from Monty Python's parrot's sketch? The shop owner said that the Norwegian Blue was<strong> pining</strong> for the fjords! But of course it should have been put in the <em>graveyard</em> already. Poor buyer, he meant to give the bird away as a <em>valentine</em> present…	I am in the <em>graveyard</em> <strong>pining</strong> for my lost <em>valentine</em>.	Imagine an 'emo' kid<strong> pining</strong> away in a <em>graveyard</em> because his <em>valentine</em> didn't turn up… His emo make-up is running because he's crying now. (Emo kids like to hang out in graveyards 'because it's cool' or something and they were going to have a date there).		
添		annexed	Water . . . heavens . . . valentine.		11	684	634	22	テン	そ.える、そ.う、も.える、も.う	Hawaii is a little drop of <em>heaven</em> nestled in the <em>waters</em> of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was<strong> annexed</strong> to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well– albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings.	"Tip 1: 天 and 夭 (<em>heavens</em> and <em>sapling</em>) are different, but RTK confuses them. Sapling appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing <em>angel</em> 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369). Tip 2: The kanji 添 means ""something added/attached"", so think of it as a building annex. Story: While in the <strong>Annex</strong> <em>water</em>ing <em>saplings</em>, you find a <em>valentine card</em> amongst them – addressed to you!"	He drank all the holy water, so god<strong> annexed</strong> his heart to heaven.	First learn 忝 【ＧＲＡＴＥＦＵＬ】 (I was very GRATEFUL to have recieved a VALENTINE straight from HEAVEN.) It's a rare kanji used in かたじけない which means grateful. Then 添 【ＡＮＮＥＸＥＤ】 (You should be GRATEFUL the city just<strong> ANNEXED</strong> some land and is building a new WATER park.).	You shed tears (<em>water</em>) as your departed <em>valentine</em> is <strong>annexed</strong> to the <em>heavens</em>.		
必		invariably	"First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the <i>heart</i>, even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph ""dividing"" <i>the heart</i> in half, then one has one of those <b>invariably</b> true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each <i>heart</i> is divided into two halves."		5	685	635	22	ヒツ	かなら.ず	You swear you'll be in love forever, but<strong> invariably</strong> there comes a time when your <em>heart</em> is <em>divided</em>.	For this kanji I<strong> invariably</strong> got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost <em>heart</em>, but decided to <em>stick</em> (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I<strong> invariably</strong> get it right.	A <em>stake</em> through the <em>heart</em><strong> invariably</strong> kills a vampire. (As a primitive this can take the meaning '<strong>vampire</strong>').	A heart that has been slashed becomes<strong> invariably</strong> altered forever.	When you say 'cross my heart', you will<strong> invariably</strong> keep your word.		
泌		ooze	<i>Water</i> . . . the <i>invariably</i> divided heart.		8	686	636	22	ヒツ、ヒ		Anything full of <em>water</em> will <em>invariably</em> begin to<strong> ooze</strong>.	When you pierce a <em>heart</em> with a <em>stake</em>, it <em>invariably</em> <strong>oozes</strong> <em>blood</em>.	The invariably divided heart is… oozing water? Is it crying because it is broken?	Heisig, your a great man. Don't let people tell you overwise. Don't let them get you down ok?	When you <em>divide</em> Michael Phelps' <em>heart</em>, <em>water</em><strong> ooze</strong>s out instead of blood.		
手		hand	Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a <b>hand</b> in this character. But that it is, and so you must.	* Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive: a single <i>hand</i> all by itself.	4	687	637	23	シュ、ズ	て、て-、-て、た-	This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a<strong> hand</strong> with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.	A<strong> hand</strong> is useful for 千一 (1001) things.	Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die. (the 6-fingered man).	Heisig says it's not a very good pictograph of a human<strong> hand</strong>, but it <em>is</em> a good pictograph of a cartoon<strong> hand</strong>. Picture Mickey Mouse's distinctive white glove with its three fingers and a thumb. The kanji that use this element can also use <em>Mickey Mouse</em> as a primitive element in place of <em>hand</em>.	The slightly bent <em>nail</em> went through <em>two</em> of the <strong>hand</strong>'s fingers (this one is pretty easy to memorize).		
看		watch over	Hand . . . eyes.		9	688	638	23	カン	み.る	It's a hot day of summer with a clear sky, you're sitting outside a cafe (or maybe on a reclining chair in the garden), and you<strong> watch over</strong> the kids with a hand covering your eyes from the sunlight (next time, don't forget the sunglasses).	Think of the monster from Pan's Labrynth, that <strong>watched over</strong> the poor girl with <em>eyes</em> in the palm of his <em>hands</em>.	I picture a lifeguard standing in his tower with his <strong>hand </strong>over his <strong>eyes</strong>, <strong>watching over</strong> the swimmers below (might work better for Australians- picturing that distinctive yellow and red cap).	My parents<strong> watch over</strong> me: whenever bad things are on the TV, they put a <em>hand</em> over my <em>eyes</em>.	"It's a Hamsa, that <strong>hand</strong> shaped trinket from the Middle East that <strong>WATCHES OVER</strong> the wearer and protects against the evil <strong>eye</strong>. If you've never seen one, check this out and this kanji is yours: <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamsa"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamsa</a>."		
摩		chafe	Hemp . . . hand.		15	689	639	23	マ	ま.する、さ.する、す.る	"If you grind the <em>hemp</em> without a stone but use your <em>hand</em> instead it will<strong> chafe</strong>. (Image: ""Robin, why are your hands all<strong> chafe</strong>d?"" 'Uh… (I've been grinding hemp all day)')."	Imagine sliding down a <em>hemp</em> rope, without gloves, just bare <em>hands</em>.<strong> Chafe</strong>s, doesn't it?	When the feds came to bust your little <em>hemp</em> <em>grove</em>, you jumped out the back side of the <em>cave</em> and tried to repel down with a <em>hemp</em> rope. Unfortunately, the rope<strong> chafe</strong>d your <em>hands</em> and you fell .. ouch!	Think of<strong> chafe</strong> in the sense of “friction” for this particular kanji. There are many garments made of <em>hemp</em> (though maybe not gloves). Contemporary <em>hemp</em> clothes are likely very comfortable, but for this story let's imagine rudimentary gloves which are coarse and rough like the unprocessed <em>hemp</em> fiber, and hence,<strong> chafe</strong> your <em>hands</em>.	Growing <em>hemp</em><strong> chafe</strong>s your <em>hand</em>s.		
我		ego	<i>Hand</i> . . . <i>fiesta</i>. Note how the second stroke of the <i>hand</i> is stretched across to double up as the first stroke of the tasseled arrow we use for <i>fiesta</i>. Compare to frames 17, 36, and 564.		7	690	640	23	ガ	われ、わ、わ.が-、わが-	"Someone with a huge<strong> EGO</strong> is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal ""<em>hand</em> <em>fiesta</em>s"" with himself every night."	Did you hear about the guy who had such a big<strong> EGO</strong> that he threw a fiesta for his left hand?	At a truly excellent gay <em>fiesta</em>, <em>hands</em> are used to stroke more than just each other's <strong>egos</strong>. Graphic, perhaps … maybe even disturbing for a few of you more prudish/phobic types … but damned if it won't stick this way.	That guy has such a huge<strong> ego</strong>. He had to have a <em>hand</em> in everything to do with planning the <em>fiesta</em>.	The truly<strong> ego</strong>tistical prefer a <em>hand-fiesta</em> to anything anyone else can give them. Ok, its not a lovely image, but its kind of memorable. Big<strong> ego</strong>: <em>hand-fiesta</em>.		
義		righteousness	Sheep . . . ego.		13	691	641	23	ギ		Righteous Christians are sheep with egos (reworked from raulir, fixes word order to match radical order).	Follow the path of<strong> RIGHTEOUSNESS</strong> like <em>sheep</em> follow the shepherd , let go of your <em>ego</em>.	On the other hand, Woman tend to have too much self-<em>righteousness</em> to allow any man to touch their wooly black <em>sheep</em> this results in similar <em>hand</em> <em>fiesta</em>s.	Putting the lamb of God ahead of your own ego and seeking His will before all else. This is true<strong> righteousness</strong>.	"Christians believe one attains<strong> righteousness</strong> by elevating the Agnus Dei, or ""<em>Lamb</em> of God"", above the whims of one's <em>ego</em> (with thanks to axelb!)."		
議		deliberation	Words . . . righteousness.		20	692	642	23	ギ		Careful<strong> deliberation</strong> produces <em>words</em> of <em>righteousness</em>.	At the worst of times, a jury's<strong> deliberation</strong> descends into a war of <em>words</em> between competing self-<em>righteous</em>, power-tripping bastards.	"Picture Samuel L Jackson's character in Pulp Fiction carefully deliberating over what words to say to freak someone out before killing them. He even browses through a list of bible quotations for inspiration. Then he finds it!… ""the path of the righteous man""."	WARNING: This does NOT mean<strong> deliberation</strong> as in careful consideration before decision. It is the other definition of<strong> deliberation</strong>: formal consultation or discussion, as in 議会 , the Diet. In the<strong> deliberation</strong>s of the diet, only <em>Righteous words</em> are allowed. If you don't speak in <em>righteous words</em>, they kick you out of the discussion.	[+yorkii] Socrates, the righteous man that he is, is <strong>DELIBERAT</strong>ing on whether or not the sheep in front of him has an ego. He is also <strong>DELIBERAT</strong>ing on whether or not to give the sheep a <em>hand fiesta</em>. Tempting….		
犠		sacrifice	<i>Cow</i> . . . <i>righteousness</i>. Do NOT use the image of an animal <b>sacrifice</b> here, as that will have it own character later on.		17	693	643	23	ギ、キ	いけにえ	A cow that is righteous<strong> sacrifice</strong>s her milk for the human race.	<em>Cows</em> are truly <em>righteous</em> animals. They<strong> SACRIFICE</strong> their milk so that we can have some. And if they don't have any left, they give a <em>sheep</em> a <em>hand fiesta</em> (good lord this is going too far) and give us that instead. What <em>righteous</em> <em>cows</em>.	"There are two kanji that need to be kept separate: this one and <a href=""../v4/1559.html"">animal sacrifice</a> (#1559 牲). Think of it this way: here there is a <em>cow</em> and a <em>righteous</em> person (presumably a Hindu). One must be <strong>SACRIFICE</strong>d, so the righteous Hindu takes the place of the holy cow. But by the time frame 1559 rolls around, the Hindu is no longer alive to protect the cow, resulting in the <em>cow's life</em> ending in an <strong>animal<strong> sacrifice</strong></strong>."	Vegetarians<strong> sacrifice</strong> eating steak (<em>cow</em>) because they believe it is a <em>righteous</em> thing to do.	In the old testament times, <em>COWS</em> were<strong> SACRIFICE</strong> for <em>RIGHTEOUSNESS</em>.		
抹		rub	Fingers . . . extremity.		8	694	644	23	マツ		"I like to<strong> RUB</strong> my FINGERS over my EXTREMITIES ….like my extremity-ly long, umm, hair…. This has been edited in response to being reported …you can change ""hair"" to whatever extremity-ly long body part you like."	When you're cold, your<strong> RUB</strong> your FINGERS over your EXTREMITIES vigorously to warm up a bit. I'd still rather go in for a warm fire and some hot cocoa, though.	"Picture Mr. Burn's<strong> rub</strong>bing the <em>extremities</em> of his <em>fingers</em> together and saying ""excellent…""."	This is easy. What other <em>extremities</em> could you possibly use to<strong> RUB</strong> something? We use our <em>fingers</em>, of course. (I do appreciate the tendency to read perverted things into kanji, but sometimes a more logical approach is better).	"This means<strong> rub</strong> as in ""rubbed out"" or ""erased.""– 抹消 【まっしょう】 (n,vs) erasure; delete (e.g., DEL character); (P). 抹殺 【まっさつ】 (n,vs) erasure; denial; obliteration; ignoring (an opinion); (P) 抹茶 (P); 末茶 (iK) 【まっちゃ】 (n) powdered green tea for ceremonies; (P) STORY: Think of God using his huge FINGER to<strong> RUB</strong> OUT/ERASE the unnecessary EXTREMITIES of the world. Similarly to how a young child uses their finger to<strong> rub</strong> out an ant hole ant by ant."		
拭		wipe	Fingers . . . style.		9	695	2254	23	ショク、シキ	ぬぐ.う、ふ.く	Why carry a handkerchief? I <strong>wipe</strong> my nose <em>finger-style</em>.	It is not my STYLE to use my FINGERS to<strong> WIPE</strong> my butt.	If you are going to<strong> wipe</strong> your nose with your <em>fingers</em>, better do it in a grand <em>style</em>.	Using your <em>finger</em> is just one <em>style</em> of <strong>wiping</strong>. I use toilet paper.	We've all seen those hip-hop videos where they<strong> wipe</strong> their shoulder with their <em>fingers</em>, and it's supposed to be the height of <em>style</em>.		
拉		yank	"The sense of this key word is to pull or jerk, as in opening a door or making ""ramen"" noodles. Its elements: <i>fingers</i> . . . <i>vase</i>."		8	696	3017	23	ラ、 ラツ、 ロウ	くだ.く、 ひし.ぐ、 らっ.する	He quickly<strong> yank</strong>ed his <em>finger</em>s out of the <em>vase</em>. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies…	"As well as the meaning of 'taking captive', this also means 'crush' or 'batter'. One also often sees it written in Chinese, with the meaning ""pull"". (I think this is where 拉麺 comes from - 'drawn' or perhaps 'flattened' noodles.) My keyword is <strong>crush</strong> (I <strong>crushed</strong> my <em>fingers</em> trying to lift a heavy <em>vase</em>) but <strong>Ramen</strong> or the other common use for this kanji in Japanese, <strong>Latin</strong> (it's the abbreviation for the Latin language) would also be appropriate, as they help you learn the reading (ラ)."	He<strong> yank</strong>ed his <em>finger</em> out of the <em>vase</em> upon discovering it had a venus fly trap in it.	<strong>kidnapper</strong>: The kidnapper wraps his fingers around the vase and then smashes it on the kid’s head. They carry him away. He’s been kidnapped.	RTK supplement: <strong>yank</strong>: I <em>yank</em>ed with my <em>fingers</em> at my car's steering wheel to avoid hitting someone who was standing in the middle of the road carying a Ming <em>vase</em>. I ended up against a light pole. I was hoping that Chinese would still be intact, but the person got scared and let it fall down… in pieces…		
抱		embrace	Fingers . . . wrap.		8	697	645	23	ホウ	だ.く、いだ.く、かか.える	"When embracing someone, wrap your fingers around her butt for added effect.
