搭		board	The key word refers to <b>boarding</b> vessels for travel. Its elements are: <i>finger</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>fit together</i> (See frame 270).		12	698	646	23	トウ		"Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for <a href=""../v4/254.html"">pagoda</a> (#254 塔). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: ""Now<strong> board</strong>ing the <em>pagoda</em> ride. Please keep your <em>fingers</em> inside at all times…""."	When you<strong> board</strong> the ship on the way out from Hawaii a beautiful crewmember takes her <em>fingers</em> and fits a lei around you ….a lei is <em>flowers</em> <em>fitted together</em> with your <em>fingers</em>.	"A romantic scene. A woman stands near to her sailor, rolling the lone <em>flower</em> that he gave her between her <em>fingers</em> because she is sad that he must leave. When the time comes for the captain to shout, ""All aboard!,"" the sailor bends deeply forward to give her one final ""<em>meeting</em> of the <em>mouths</em>,"" powerful enough to cause her <em>flower</em> to drop out of her <em>fingers</em> and into the sea."	All aboard! <em>Fingers</em> waving goodbye, <em>flowers</em> tossed in the air, and the <em>meeting of mouths</em> as lovers say goodbye.	"A new torture technique called ""flower-boarding"" instead of the popular ""water-boarding"". It's quite simple: Use your fingers to make some flowers fit into the prisoner's mouth. Pretty effective!"		
抄		extract	Fingers . . . a few.		7	699	647	23	ショウ		You can<strong> extract</strong> her juices by inserting a <em>few fingers</em>.	The mafia want to<strong> extract</strong> information from you. You don't say a word, so out comes the knife. They cut of your fingers until you only have a few left and then you speak.	You are at a the university library preparing a summary of some litterature and with your thumb, index and little finger (a <em>few fingers</em>) you point at a <em>few</em> passages to<strong> extract</strong>. Note: this kanji is used in the sense of an “excerpt”, not of an<strong> extract</strong> of some substance.	Breaking a few fingers is an excellent way to<strong> extract</strong> information.	You've heard about that monkey who put his hand in the candy jar and grabbed so many pieces that he couldn't<strong> extract</strong> his hand? This Kanji is a lesson in how to<strong> extract</strong>, because if you put your <em>fingers</em> in the jar and only grab a <em>few</em>, then you will be able to<strong> extract</strong> them easily.		
抗		confront	Fingers . . . a whirlwind.		7	700	648	23	コウ		"Gandalf<strong> confront</strong>s the evil beast, shouting ""you shall not pass!"". He holds up a single finger and sends forth a whirlwind."	The<strong> confront</strong>ation between the two sign-language people looked like a whirlwind of fingers.	Imagine a thumb war. A<strong> confront</strong>ation of fingers in a whirlwind.	<em>Tornados</em> can smell fear. So next time one threatens your town, don't run away or hide like everyone else.<strong> Confront</strong> it! Just give it the <em>finger</em>, tell it to piss off, and watch as it fearfully runs away.	In his<strong> confront</strong>ation with Agent Smith, Neo first gave him the <em>finger</em>, then unleashed a <em>whirlwind</em> of lethal kung fu moves. 反抗 (はんこう) : opposition, resistance, insubordination, defiance, hostility, rebellion.		
批		criticism	Finger . . . compare.		7	701	649	23	ヒ		My<strong> criticism</strong> earned me the FINGER when I COMPARED her cooking to my mother's.	Think of the two most famous critics, Ebert and Roeper. On their show, they <em>compare</em> thumbs (which are technically <em>fingers</em>) with each other before dispensing<strong> criticism</strong>.	<strong>Criticism</strong> is pointing at your finger at someone and comparing them with someone perfect.	<strong>Criticism</strong> is a <em>comparison</em> of <em>fingers</em>: thumbs up or down.	I took it as a<strong> criticism</strong> when my girlfriend <em>compared</em> my…well, you know…to her pinky <em>finger</em>.		
招		beckon	Finger . . . seduce.		8	702	650	23	ショウ	まね.く	A Geisha<strong> beckon</strong>s you with her index <em>finger</em>, and as you approach she runs her <em>fingers</em> all over her body in an attempt to <em>seduce</em> you. Keyword meaning : “invite”. The siren gently <strong>beckons</strong> you with her <em>finger</em> and <em>seduces</em> you to to your death.	This kanji actually means <strong>invite</strong>. A FINGER SEDUCTION is in fact an <strong>invitation</strong> for other things. Oh ho ho….. grrrr…	She/He <strong>beckoned</strong> me with her <em>finger</em>, <em>seductively</em>.

拐		kidnap	Finger . . . mouth . . . dagger.		8	708	656	23	カイ		Wrap your FINGERS around someone's MOUTH to keep them quiet, then put the KNIFE to their throat to ensure their cooperation. This is the best way to<strong> KIDNAP</strong> someone.	"After you <a href=""../v4/650.html"">beckon</a> (#650 招) someone by seducing them, you<strong> kidnap</strong> them and hang them upside down (the reversed positions of <em>seduce</em>)."	<strong>Kidnap</strong>ping goes like this, after you<strong> kidnap</strong> somebody, you send one of their fingers. Then you hold a dagger before the mouth of the victim and have him talk so that people know he's still alive. This balance between cutting of fingers of the victim and having him say he's all right will make a successful<strong> kidnap</strong>ping. Join us next week on how to perform a good back-alley murder.	"You<strong> kidnap</strong> someone by putting a finger on your mouth (""ssh!"") and a dagger under his."	"<strong>Kidnap</strong>ping is related to, but opposite to <a href=""../v4/650.html"">beckon</a> (#650 招). If you beckon someone, you ask them to come to you, rather then going to them (to steal them). The kanji is an illustration of that fact, because the <a href=""../v4/11.html"">mouth</a> (#11 口) is above the <a href=""../v4/83.html"">sword</a> (#83 刀)."

推		conjecture	Fingers . . . turkey.		11	716	663	23	スイ	お.す	In mathematics, a<strong> conjecture</strong> is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the <em>Finger-Turkey</em><strong> conjecture</strong> ? It states that if <em>turkeys</em> had <em>fingers</em>, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.	In the midst of<strong> conjecture</strong> on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her <em>fingers</em> in the <em>turkey</em> to check.	WRONG<strong> conjecture</strong> -> Fingers evolved from turkeys.	"The correct<strong> conjecture</strong> is that <em>fingers</em> evolved INTO <em>turkeys</em>! It may only be<strong> conjecture</strong>, but I think he's fingured the turkey… lol.

提		propose	Fingers . . . just so.		12	718	665	23	テイ、チョウ、ダイ	さ.げる	When a man<strong> PROPOSE</strong>S to a lady, he takes her FINGER and places the ring on it JUST SO, and the moment sweeps her away. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally <em>just so</em>. Business proposals in Japan have to be set out just so. 拠		foothold	Fingers . . . dispose.		8	722	669	23	キョ、コ	よ.る	When rockclimbing, when your weight <em>disposes</em> of the valuble<strong> foothold</strong>, all that's left is your <em>fingers</em> keeping you from death. 描		sketch	Fingers . . . seedling.		11	723	670	23	ビョウ	えが.く、か.く	"A<strong> sketch</strong> is a <a href=""../v4/234.html"">seedling</a> (#234 苗) of things to come. "I'm bad at drawing, so when I try to<strong> sketch</strong> the kanji for cat, you can sort of recognize it, but I don't get the curve of the ""wild dogs"" just right." This kanji shows a kid <em>finger</em> painting a<strong> sketch</strong> of a <em>flowery field</em>.	A <strong>sketch</strong> can be considered the <em>seedling</em> of a full-fledged technical drawing. Contrary to the drawing itself, which require exact measures, rulers, compasses, etc., the <strong>sketch</strong> can be roughly drawn up using only your <em>fingers</em>.		
操		maneuver	Fingers . . . goods . . . tree.		16	724	671	23	ソウ、サン	みさお、あやつ.る	"Tip: <em>goods</em> + <em>wood/tree</em> : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""<em>furniture</em>"" (a common type of <em>wooden goods</em>). REF: <a href=""../v4/215.html"">parch</a> (#215 燥) , <em>maneuver</em> (FRAME 671), <a href=""../v4/1369.html"">winding</a> (#1369 繰), <a href=""../v4/2035.html"">seaweed</a> (#2035 藻). Luke skywalker points his fingers and uses the force to<strong> maneuver</strong> the goods through the tree branches and up over the tree.	"The rare kanji 喿 means ""chirping birds."" Therefore, why not use it since it occurs 4 times in Heisig? (note that it looks like a bunch of mouths up in a tree) Story: Think of <em>Thing</em> from the Adam's family (just a <em>hand</em> walking around) crawling around in a tree. He carefully<strong> maneuver</strong>'s (this way and that) in order to isolate and stalk his pray, the <em>chirping birds</em>. They are quite a nuisance and he<strong> maneuver</strong>s up close and snatches one in his <em>fingers</em>, thus silencing its <em>chirping</em>."	The apple/orange/coconut picker <strong>maneuvers</strong> his way around the <em>tree</em>, grabbing the <em>goods</em> with his <em>fingers</em>.	Being good <strong>maneuvering</strong> using your <em>fingers</em> in <strong>Mario Kart</strong> isn't enough! You still have to avoid all the <em>goods</em> the other players throw at you and hitting the <em>trees</em>.		
接		touch	Fingers . . . vase . . . woman.		11	725	672	23	セツ、ショウ	つ.ぐ	A pervert meets a <em>woman</em>. The pervert tries to<strong> touch</strong> the women with his lustful <em>fingers</em>. These are the perverts who use their <em>fingers</em> to<strong> touch</strong> <em>standing women</em> on crowded trains.	With a<strong> touch</strong> of his <em>fingers</em>, a holy man cures a paralysed <em>woman</em> and allows her to <em>stand up</em> again.	"Heh, Can't believe i didn't think of this any earlier. <a href=""http://www.transitionsabroad.com/publications/magazine/0611/women_in_niger_carrying_water.jpg"">http://www.transitionsabroad.com/publications/magazine/0611/women_in_niger_carrying_water.jpg</a> This image is perfect, some woman need to<strong> touch</strong>, others don't. :) (Vase, bucket, same thinggg :P )."	"Notice: “Do not<strong> touch</strong>!” (please do not <em>finger</em> the <a href=""../v4/2622.html"">concubine</a> (#2622 妾))."

The king can trifle with anything using his two hands (be it objects, his subjects, or himself)."	"When something new is invented, the king is always the first to be able to<strong> tinker with</strong> it. To distinguish from <a href=""../v4/833.html"">penalty</a> (#833 罰), think in terms of 'to<strong> punish</strong>', the actual -application- of the<strong> punish</strong>ment, which only comes after deciding what the penalty shall be." 才		genius	"Whatever one is particularly adept at - one's special ""<b>genius</b>"" - one can do very easily, ""with one finger"" as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for <i>fingers</i> backwards."	* The primitive meaning, <i>genie</i>, derives from the roots of the word <i>genius</i>. Use the <i>genie</i> out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered, and the meaning becomes a <i>genie in the bottle</i>.	3	736	681	23	サイ		"Spinal tap: ""Every other band's amps go to <em>ten</em>. But you see my <em>extra stroke</em> of<strong> genius</strong> - these go to eleven.""."	"A TEN year old had a STROKE of<strong> GENIUS</strong> and wrote this joke: <a href=""midori://search?text=%E4%BD%95%E6%AD%B3%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99%E3%81%8B%EF%BC%9F"">何歳ですか？</a> <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%82%E3%80%82%E3%80%82%E5%A4%A9%E6%89%8D%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99%EF%BC%81"">。。。天才です！</a> ."	Ten is ten, but add a stroke of<strong> genius</strong> and…	Oooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo!<strong> Genius</strong>!	"I use Azumanga Daioh's Mihama Chiyo-chan for this. Not only is this character ""genius"", but it is also the simplified ""years old"" counter, one which children use instead of 歳 . I can imagine Chiyo-chan saying: <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%8C%E5%8D%81%E6%89%8D%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99%E3%82%88%E3%80%8D"">「十才ですよ」</a> ""I'm ten years old."" 財		property	Clam . . . genie.		10	737	682	23	ザイ、サイ、ゾク	たから	If you're a <em>money genius</em>, you can afford a lot of<strong> property</strong>.	The keyword refers to<strong> property</strong> in the sense of money or funds rather than of buildings or real estate. Keep this one distinct from frame 193 (“wealth”) and frame 473 (“assets”). Here we have a genie, gulping down oysters. Someone tries to grab an oyster and the genie puts his big arms around his oysters and states his “right of ownership” : “They're mines, my<strong> property</strong>!”.	<strong>Property</strong> comes in several forms, shells (money) and intellectual<strong> property</strong> (genius).	A genius with money LEFT over buys<strong> property</strong>.	To gain a lot of<strong> property</strong>, you need either a <em>genie</em> or to be a <em>genius</em>. The <em>clam</em> is there to emphasize that this character is more about financial<strong> property</strong> or funds than real estate.

乃		from	"This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the ""hand primitives."" Take note of its rather peculiar drawing. Try to think of drawing a <i>fist</i> (the primitive meaning) ""<b>from</b>"" this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word."	* The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph: a <i>fist</i>.	2	741	686	23	ナイ、ダイ、ノ、アイ	の、すなわ.ち、なんじ	<strong>FROM</strong> a pictograph of a thumbs up. That's how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist.	Pictograph, see book. This kanji, as a chinese character, is in fact the origin for the hiragana possessive particle “no”. Try drawing this kanji fast, in a single stroke and you will end up with の .	"Think Charlton Heston: ""<strong>From</strong> my cold, dead fists"". Speech given to the National Boxing Association, in response to stricter control on boxing gloves."	Imagine fists punching at you<strong> from</strong> all angles.	<strong>FROM</strong>s up!

及		reach out	The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched <i>fist</i> into the kanji for <b>reaching out</b>, much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance.	* As a primitive, this shall stand for <i>outstretched hands</i>. Only take care not to confuse it with that for <i>beg</i> (Frame 501)	3	743	688	23	キュウ	およ.ぶ、およ.び、および、およ.ぼす	I like to think of this as a <em>fist</em> with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug <strong>reaches out</strong> to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.	<strong>Reach out</strong> and fist someone (Do you see the person primitive?).	I like to think of the MATRIX. Now hear me out… Remember the scene when Neo and Mr. Smith fought in the subway? there was this one part where Mr. Smith threw his <em>FIST</em> at Neo, but Neo stopped it. Mr. Smith <strong>reached out</strong> his finger (the line coming from fist) and hit Neo in the throat.	This is an image of the fist getting an arm (the new stroke). The FIST now <strong>reaches out</strong> farther than before.	Dhalism (Street Figher) can<strong> reach out</strong> his <em>fist</em> an <em>extra stroke</em> farther than anyone else, even if their <em>hands are outstretched.</em>.

扱		handle	Finger . . . outstretched hands.		6	745	690	23	ソウ、キュウ	あつか.い、あつか.う、あつか.る、こ.く	"See <a href=""../v4/689.html"">suck</a> (#689 吸): if it's too big to<strong> handle</strong>, just use your <em>fingers</em> instead…"	One of the first thing a baby can do with his hand is to <em>reach out</em> and grab your <em>finger</em> as if it was a little<strong> handle</strong>.	<strong>Handle</strong> with care… carefully hold the Nitroglycerin within your fingers with outstretched hands for fear of it blowing up in your face…	A toddler reaching up with OUTSTRETCHED HANDS for a mug sitting on the table, just barely out of his reach. Straining, he can just barely get his FINGER to brush the<strong> handle</strong>.	"Pay attention to this story because you'll learn how to recall the reading of this kanji as well: We've all heard the expression: ""Too hot to<strong> handle</strong>"" – Well, just imagine you are <em>reaching out</em> your <em>fingers</em> to touch someone's face and it is too hot to<strong> handle</strong>. (Then you can combine the word for hot (atsui) with the word for face (kao) and always remember how this character is read: atsukau - あつかう.)."		
丈		length	The <b>length</b> whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with <i>arms</i> at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from <i>large</i> (Frame 112).		3	746	691	23	ジョウ	たけ、だけ	Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.	"When girls ask about my<strong> length</strong>, I hold out my <em>one arm</em>, and tell them ""you get the idea""."	"This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare ""length"" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn't show ""it"" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your<strong> length</strong>. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji."	This kanji demonstrates the proper technique for throwing a bowling ball the<strong> LENGTH</strong> of the alley. Stroke 1- lift the ball up horizontally to judge the throw Stroke 2 - gently swing the arm back Stroke 3 - whip your arm forward and roll the ball off the tips of your fingers Strike!	ONE ARM<strong> LENGTH</strong>.

The historian is like a <em>mouth</em> <em>tucked under the arm</em>, telling the big man all he needs to know about<strong> history</strong>.		
吏		officer	One . . . mouth . . . tucked under the arm.		6	748	693	23	リ		<em>One</em><strong> officer</strong> can change the course of <em>history</em>.	<em>One</em><strong> officer</strong>, namely Napoleon, changed the course of <em>history</em>. (Thanks, ayoung24). Napoleon is also my primitive meaning.	In a police state, the police<strong> officer</strong>s all speak with <em>one mouth</em> and have a gun tucked <em>under their arm</em>.	"This is not <a href=""../v4/1095.html"">military officer</a> (#1095 尉), but more of a government<strong> officer</strong>, official or bureaucrat, such as Barack Obama, who started out as a lowly government<strong> officer</strong> (communitee organizer) and the broke through the glass <em>ceiling</em> to become president of the United States and make <em>history</em> (I know a glass ceiling generally refers to an obstacle for women, but I wanted to avoid key words such as <a href=""../v4/98.html"">woman</a> (#98 女), <a href=""../v4/1151.html"">lady</a> (#1151 婦) or <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/563"">feminine/female</a> (#563 雌))."	I used HISTORY as a primitive rather than separating it into 'mouth' and 'tucked under the arm'. Think about the Japanese history textbook controversy. The government<strong> OFFICER</strong>S choosing the textbooks are the ONE elite group determining Japan's HISTORY.		
更		grow late	The implication behind the meaning of <b>grow late</b> is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>sun</i> . . . <i>tucked under the arm</i>.		7	749	694	23	コウ	さら、さら.に、ふ.ける、ふ.かす	It's starting to<strong> GROW LATE</strong>, so God will take the SUN, and TUCK IT UNDER HIS ARM, and walk away. In the morning, he'll bring it back, so don't worry.	"At <a href=""../v4/30.html"">nightbreak</a> (#30 旦) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm."	I keep <em>one sun tucked under my arm</em> for light when it grows late.	As it begins to<strong> grow late</strong> the <em>sun</em> projects the shadow of my <em>arm</em> on the <em>ceiling</em>.	When it is <strong>growing late</strong>, the <em>sun</em> sinks below the <em>floor</em>. Time to tuck your belongings <em>under your arm</em> and head home. 更ける (ふける) : get late, advance, wear on; 更に (さらに) : furthermore, again, after all, more and more, moreover; 変更 (へんこう) : change, modification, alteration; 夜更け (よふけ) : late at night.		
硬		stiff	Rocks . . . grow late.		12	750	695	23	コウ	かた.い	A<strong> stiff</strong> drink on the <em>ROCK</em>s after it <em>GROWS LATE</em> is a way to unwind after a long day…	<em>Stones</em> are so<strong> stiff</strong> that even if you spent all day straining trying to change their shape, it would <em>grow late</em> far before you ever accomplished your task.	There's a city whose inhabitants <strong>stiff</strong>en and turn to <em>stone</em> every night when it <em>grows late</em>.	My girlfriend started playing with my <em>stones</em> when it was <em>growing late</em>, and I got a<strong> stiff</strong>y.	The trolls took so much time discussing how to cook their meal that it <em>grew late</em>: they all became<strong> stiff</strong> and turned to <em>stone</em>.		
梗		spiny	This character refers originally to a deciduous, rough tree that grows on mountain plains. From this it gets the secondary sense of rugged or <b>spiny</b>. Its primitive elements: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>grow late</i>.		11	751	2498	23	コウ、キョウ	ふさぐ、やまにれ、おおむね	I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it <em>grows late</em>, <em>trees</em> change shape and become<strong> spiny</strong> creatures! Picture them jumping out of trees instead of being hurled from Lakitu. Lakitu - is the guy who flys the cloud in the Mario games…	Usually the <em>tree</em> you bump into when it <em>grows late</em> happens to be<strong> spiny</strong>.	"梗概 , 梗塞 , 心筋梗塞 , 桔梗 , <a href=""../v4/2498.html"">spiny</a> (#2498 梗) コウ, キョウ … Parts: 木 , 更 <a href=""../v4/694.html"">grow late</a> (#694 更) … Story: Since this is used for infarction ( 梗塞 ), and myocardial infarction ( 心筋梗塞 ), the<strong> Spiny</strong> should tie into that. So when it <em>Grows Late</em> , and the old guy gets <em>Wood</em>, he has a <strong>myocardial infarction</strong> that feels like a<strong> Spiny</strong> monster grabbing his heart."	INFARCTION (new keyword, according to real meaning). If it GROWS LATE and you get an INFARCTION, have someone call an ambulance. In the meantime try to relax, stay under a TREE.		
又		or again	"Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate ""and"" (+, &, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of <b>or again</b>."	* As a primitive, it will mean <i>crotch</i>, as in the <i>crotch</i> of the arm. Or whatever.	2	752	696	23	ユウ	また、また-、また.の-	"This keyword should really be ""again"" not ""or again"" Here is some context: think of the phrase ""Jya mata"" "" じゃ又 "" which is a farewell similar to ""then again"". Also ""Mata ne"" "" 又ね "" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) "" 又明日 ""。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out ""mata"" except for in the last example: 又明日 ."	"After her boyfriend's <em>crotch</em> has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, ""<strong>Or again</strong>, we could fool around . . . ""."	"The crotch is the area of vital ""<strong>or again</strong>s"". (Organs, that is.)."	"As a primitive, instead of using ""crotch"", I also often use ""sat cross-legged"" as this also looks like the kanji."	"I agree with bodhisamaya and sindhikara, this kanji is more like just ""again"". You can change this kanji to ""again"" if you change [ again FRAME 1815 ] to Re- , which is it's real meaning anyways. Also, beware of too many penis euphemisms. Associating crotch with penis is not too bad, but if you associate column, meat, gigantic, etc. with penises, you might find yourself confused as to which euphemism you meant."		
双		pair	The <i>crotch</i> reduplicated gives us a <b>pair</b>.		4	753	697	23	ソウ	ふた、たぐい、ならぶ、ふたつ	The animals boarding Noah's Ark all came in<strong> pair</strong>s – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each<strong> pair</strong> to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.	<em>Crotch to crotch</em> is how many <strong>pairs</strong> spend their private time together. . .	Instead of bringing home 1 girl and enjoying her CROTCH, it's better to bring home a<strong> PAIR</strong> of girls and enjoy 2 CROTCHES!! I've done this several times so I'll remember this kanji easily.	The left <em>crotch</em> looks more like the man's and the right a woman's, the ultimate<strong> pair</strong>.	Hey buddy, grow a<strong> pair</strong>! (two testies) Oops, one is kind of misshaped. :0.

隻		vessels	The key word indicates the Japanese generic term for counting ships. Its elements: <i>turkey</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>.		10	755	699	23	セキ		On<strong> Vessels</strong> that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the<strong> VESSELS</strong>, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey's CROTCH.	Donald Duck is a <em>big bird</em> that does <em>not wear pants</em>. It's good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count<strong> vessels</strong>.	The turky's crotch is a vessel for the stuffing that you fill it with.	The USS Turkeycrotch is a seaworthy vessel.	An ole' pirate <em>turkey</em> sits <em>astride</em> the prow of a vessel (i.e. with his <em>crotch</em> on the prow). Recall from PAGE 211 the old turkey with pipe and monocle : now he takes off his monocle and uses a “field-glass” to count other<strong> vessels</strong> (pirate ships) on the horizon (this kanji is also a counter for ships).		
護		safeguard	Words . . . flowers . . . vessels.		20	756	700	23	ゴ	まも.る	"Think of the <em>flower-vessels</em> as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big <em>flower</em> painted on the hull (this will come back in <a href=""../v4/701.html"">seize</a> (#701 獲) and <a href=""../v4/908.html"">harvest</a> (#908 穫)). (With sarcasm) A Bush speech telling how all the US <em>vessels</em> are always welcomed, covered with <em>flowers</em> and <em>word</em>s of gratitude for<strong> safeguard</strong>ing democracy from the evil doers.	The <em>flower vessel</em> is of course the <em>Mayflower</em> in which the pilgrims came to America in their search for turkeys. During they trip, they prayed non-stop - using <em>words</em> as spells to<strong> safeguard</strong> Mayflower from danger. No, because of their nonviolence pact they have decided they will fend off pirates only with their words.

投		throw	Fingers . . . missile.		7	762	706	23	トウ	な.げる、-な.げ	Well, you usually use your <em>fingers</em> to<strong> throw</strong> objects used as <em>missile</em> weapons. Easy. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers…	"<strong>If you use the primitive ""semen"" (flying in the wind from your crotch) instead of missile then all kanjis with this primitive will hilariously create a perfect story</strong>." I made her<strong> drown</strong> in my in my <em>semen</em>, which was coming down on her like buckets of <em>water</em>. (applying crystal's perfect primitive element).	"I give this Kanji the keyword <strong>go down</strong> (in the sense of something plummeting or going down badly, not in the sense of descending, which is already used) because it is used in sinking ( 沈没 ), dying ( 戦没 ), and sunset ( 日没 ). It seems to me 溺 is the character for<strong> drown</strong>, and in fact it is given the keyword ""drowning"" later, which is just confusing to me. Story: The ship is <strong>going down</strong>! We were hit by a <em>water</em> <em>missile</em> (a torpedo)."	When a torpedo (<em>water missile</em>) hits its target, everyone<strong> drown</strong>s!

In a random version of rock,paper, scissors. 殻		husk	Samurai . . . superfluous . . . missile.		11	767	710	23	カク、コク、バイ	から、がら	Samurai's<strong> husk</strong>/shell/armour is superflous to missile attacks 甲殻 卵殻 貝殻 .	<strong>husk</strong> or <strong>shell</strong>. Japan's recent history in a nut<strong>shell</strong>: first the <em>samurai</em> became<em> superfluous </em>and then the Americans started to <em>throw missiles </em> and bombs during WWII.	"The primitives tie so nicely into a story: upon the use of <em>missiles</em> in warfare, the traditional role of <em>samurai</em> became <em>superfluous</em> in battle. How to tie it to the keyword of ""husk""? Easy! Afterwards, the samurai were demoted (like potato-peeling privates), and they sat around<strong> HUSK</strong>ING corn and cracking eggs and peanut shells (kanji refers to both 'husk' and 'shell'). A strong image to lock in the kanji: imagine samurai using their mighty swords to de-husk corn and split peanuts! Also see <a href=""../v4/917.html"">cereals</a> (#917 穀)."	The samurai, now superfluous since the advent of the missile, was but a<strong> husk</strong> of a man. (Sumarai/Superfluous):Missile =<strong> Husk</strong>.	A samurai<strong> husk</strong>ing corn, which means removing the part that is superfluous, so that he can use the corn as missiles in some upcoming war………		
支		branch	Needle . . . crotch.		4	768	711	23	シ	ささ.える、つか.える、か.う、しんよう、じゅうまた	Picture sliding down the<strong> branch</strong> of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with <em>needles</em>) and getting a bunch of <em>needles</em> stuck in your <em>crotch</em>–ouch!!	A special<strong> branch</strong> of the military called the <em>Needle Crotch</em> Unit. Their only weapon is the <em>needle</em> embedded in their <em>crotches</em>, and they're quite adept at using them.	"Sitting on the<strong> BRANCH</strong> of a coniferous tree, getting sharp <em>needles</em> in my <em>crotch</em>. (Remember there is no tree radical in this kanji, whereas <a href=""../v4/713.html"">bough</a> (#713 枝) ( 枝 ) does because a ""bough"" is a main part of the tree, whereas this kanji refers to a smaller<strong> branch</strong>. It can also be used to refer to the<strong> branch</strong> of a store ( 支店 ) which also has nothing to do with a tree)."	I have a 10 inch<strong> branch</strong> coming out of my crotch.	I would try to steer away from using tree imagery for this kanji: 支 (branch) is not actually used for tree<strong> branch</strong>es, but rather for conceptual<strong> branch</strong>es, like a store<strong> branch</strong> ( 支店 ). 枝 (bough), on the other hand, is an actual <em>branch</em> from a <em>tree</em>.		
技		skill	Fingers . . . branch.		7	769	712	23	ギ	わざ	(Adapted from darg_sama's) Balancing a <em>branch</em> on your <em>finger</em> is the prototypical example of a<strong> skill</strong> that is nothing more than a<strong> skill</strong> (i.e., it is completely useless).	I think of a guy balancing a branch on his finger, which definitely takes some minimal amount of<strong> skill</strong>.	Better be <strong>skilled</strong> with your <em>finger</em> if all you've got is a <em>needle</em> <em>crotch</em>.	Forget balancing branches and stupid shit like that. It takes real<strong> skill</strong> to <em>finger</em> <em>ten</em> <em>crotches</em> at the same time. For real, nobody was ever a hero for balancing branches.	Grasping a BRANCH with their FINGERS was the first<strong> SKILL</strong> that premodern humans learned.		
枝		bough	<i>Tree</i> . . . <i>branch</i>. Take a moment to focus on the differences between a <b>bough</b>, a <i>branch</i>, and a <i>twig</i> (Frame 319).		8	770	713	23	シ	えだ	The <em>tree's</em> primary <em>branch</em> is known as the<strong> bough</strong>.	"Differentiate between<strong> BOUGH</strong> and <a href=""../v4/711.html"">branch</a> (#711 支): 'branch' is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store ( 支店 ), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a<strong> BOUGH</strong> is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large<strong> bough</strong>s, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical."	I think of a<strong> bough</strong> as a <em>branch</em> that's big enough to be a <em>tree</em> itself.	支 (branch) is not actually used for tree branches, but rather for conceptual branches, like a store branch, or a branch of mathematics. 枝 (bough), on the other hand, is an actual <em>branch</em> from a <em>tree</em>.	As James Heisig suggests, let's take a moment to focus on the differences between a<strong> bough</strong>, a branch, and a twig. A twig is “a small, leafless branch of a woody plant”. A<strong> bough</strong> is “a large or main <em>branch</em> of a <em>tree</em>” (a branch is somewhere in between the<strong> bough</strong>s and the twigs).		
肢		limb	Part of the body . . . branch.		8	771	714	23	シ		"The<strong> limb</strong>s that this kanji represents are <em>parts of the body</em> that are connected to the trunk, like the main <em>branches</em> to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words,<strong> limb</strong>s are ""<em>flesh branches</em>""."	<strong>Limb</strong>s are <em>body parts</em> that <em>branch</em> off.	"No Timmy, we don't say ""flesh branches"", we say ""limbs""."	<strong>Limb</strong>s are <em>flesh</em>y <em>branch</em>es.	<strong>Limb</strong> = <em>meat branch</em> (sometimes it's almost too easy).		
茎		stalk	Flower . . . spool.		8	772	715	23	ケイ、キョウ	くき	"Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) <em>Toilet paper/roll</em> usually comes on a <em>spool</em>. (2) <em>Toilet paper</em> is used to clean the <em>soil</em> off your <em>crotch</em>. Story: Just get a <em>flower</em> and carefully wrap some <em>toilet paper</em> around its<strong> stalk</strong>. Spool also appears in <a href=""../v4/716.html"">suspicious</a> (#716 怪), <a href=""../v4/717.html"">lightly</a> (#717 軽), <a href=""../v4/882.html"">diameter</a> (#882 径), <a href=""../v4/1360.html"">sutra</a> (#1360 経)."	PRIMITIVE: <em>soiled crotch</em> = <em>soiled underwear</em>. To precent anyone from picking the beautiful <em>flower</em>, the gardner hung <em>soiled underwear</em> on the <strong>stalk</strong>.	A <em>flower</em>'s<strong> stalk</strong> can be seen as connecting the <em>flower</em> to the <em>soil</em>, <em>or again</em> the <em>soil</em> to the <em>flower</em>. It depends on how you look at it.	Jack and the Bean<strong>stalk</strong>: <em>dirt</em> below, <em>flowers</em> above, and Jack's <em>crotch</em> visible as he climbs up and up. 茎 (くき) :<strong> stalk</strong>.	Flowering vines growing up a post or column. The<strong> stalk</strong>s wrap around the post– again and again– like a <em>spool </em>of thread, and <em>flowers</em> bloom at the very top. At the bottom, of course, is the soil.

This kanji becomes easy if you use its proper meaning as a keyword: <strong>younger sibling of parent</strong>. 坂		slope	Ground . . . anti-.		7	780	723	23	ハン	さか	As the villain (pushed off by the anti-hero) is tumbling down the<strong> slope</strong>, he activates gadget skis to escape, spraying soil everywhere as he flies down the<strong> slope</strong>. 采		grab	Vulture . . . tree.		8	791	2090	23	サイ	と.る、いろどり	You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture<strong> grab</strong>s hold of a <em>tree</em>, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn't shake him loose.	A common meaning for this kanji is 'DICE'. — Ever wonder what <em>vultures</em> do up in the <em>trees</em>? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always <strong>grabbing</strong> the dice away from each other.	The gigantic VULTURE swoops down and<strong> grab</strong>s that huge TREE!! AAAAH!!	Like a VULTURE, she<strong> grab</strong>ed my WOOD! Boy, you cannot stop her.	In a particularly lame X-Men comic, <em>Wolverine</em> is in a <em>tree</em>, and Sabretooth is trying to shake him out of it. <em>Wolverine</em><strong> grab</strong>s the tree trunk as tightly as he can so he doesn't fall out.		
採		pick	Unlike <i>pick up</i> (Frame 720), this character is used for <b>picking</b> fruits from trees. Its elements: <i>finger</i> . . . <i>grab</i>.		11	792	733	23	サイ	と.る	You<strong> pick</strong> cheries with your <em>fingers</em>, then along comes a giant <em>vulture</em> and<strong> pick</strong>s up the whole <em>tree</em> with its <em>claws</em>.	"Tip: <em>vulture</em> + <em>tree</em> : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called <a href=""../v4/2090.html"">grab</a> (#2090 采). Story: As you go to<strong> pick</strong> your nose, your parent <em>grabs</em> your <em>finger</em> and pulls it away (& gives you a lecture on social etiquette). REF: ""grab"" also appears in <a href=""../v4/734.html"">vegetable</a> (#734 菜), <a href=""../v4/1714.html"">coloring</a> (#1714 彩)."	Attempting to use your FINGERS to<strong> PICK</strong> the fruit off the TREE can be hazardous if there's a VULTURE waiting to<strong> PICK</strong> your FINGERS off you!	"采 is grab (FRAME <a href=""../v4/2090.html"">grab</a> (#2090 采))<strong> Pick</strong> is grab but delicately with your fingers only (thanks katsuo)."	Imagine trying to<strong> pick</strong> fruit from a <em>vulture</em>-infested <em>tree</em>, but before you can even get close, the <em>vultures</em> peck at your <em>fingers</em> to stop you.		
菜		vegetable	Flower . . . grab.		11	793	734	23	サイ	な	A vegetarian vulture is munching on a <em>flower</em>, perched on a <em>tree</em>, patiently waiting for a patch of<strong> vegetable</strong>s to grow. He said he only eats<strong> vegetable</strong>s now and last time I saw him sitting in a tree with flowers in his hair.	Nobody likes to eat their<strong> vegetable</strong>s, not even <em>vultures</em> who will eat anything. So they hide in a <em>flower</em>-covered <em>tree</em>, until the scary<strong> vegetable</strong>s disappear. Picture the ugly vulture head peeking out from behind the flowers.	"Tip: vulture + tree : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called grab (<strong>2090). — Story: Many<strong> vegetable</strong>s are roots and so you take their flowers and grab them in order to harvest the<strong> vegetable</strong>. — REF: ""grab"" also appears in pick (</strong>733), coloring (#1714 彩)."

曖		unclear	Sun . . . love.		17	797	2437	23	アイ	くら.い	The <em>sun</em>'s <em>love</em> is<strong> equivocal</strong>: it warms yet burns us. "(Thanks HaaBaato) <a href=""midori://search?text=%E6%9B%96%E6%98%A7%E3%80%82"">曖昧。</a> On a <em>sunny</em> day, a guy professes his <em>love</em> to a girl he admires. However, while he's down on one knee, the sun comes out from behind a cloud and blinds him. The girl takes her opportunity, gives him the common<strong> equivocal</strong> response, ""Let's just be friends,"" and runs away while the poor guy is still blinded."

Here, you bind up the kidnapping victim's arms together at the elbows behind his back when you capture him."

胎		womb	Part of the body . . . pedestal.		9	810	748	23	タイ		"The body part feminists like to put on a pedestal is the<strong> womb</strong>, especially when they hear a man complain about some responsibility. In this kanji pedestal carries a sense of base, or stand. The<strong> womb</strong> is part of the body that acts as a pedestal: a base or stand from which a new human being is brought into life.	"Imagine the <strong>womb</strong> as a <em>part of the body</em> which contains a little <a href=""../v4/744.html"">pedestal</a> (#744 台) for the baby to stand on. The<strong> womb</strong> is the <em>part of the body</em> with a <em>mouth</em> from which the matron took you out when you were born, using her <em>elbow</em>."

去		gone	Soil . . . elbow.		5	812	750	23	キョ、コ	さ.る、-さ.る	"""Going, going,<strong> GONE</strong>!"", said the gravedigger as he shoveled <em>soil</em> onto the body's protruding <em>elbow</em> (the last bit left to cover)."	If you want the soil stains<strong> gone</strong> from your clothes, then you'll need to put some elbow grease into cleaning them.	"A trick they do in war movies is they bury the arm up to the <em>elbow</em> in the soil, then put some fake flesh and blood by the elbow to make it look like the arm is<strong> gone</strong>. ""AAAHHH!!! My arm's<strong> gone</strong>! MEDIC!!""."	<strong>Gone, past, quit, leave, elapse, eliminate, divorce.</strong> When I <em>myself</em> (厶) am under the <em>earth</em> my time will have elapsed and I will be dead and<strong> gone</strong>. 死去 (death). 消去 (elimination, erasure, purge). 一難去ってまた一難 (it's been one thing after another). 歩き去る (walk away). 洗い去る (wash away). この世を去る (to leave the world, die). 引き去る (retreat). 走り去る (run away).	I brush <em>soil</em> off my <em>elbow</em> - now it's<strong> GONE</strong>.		
法		method	Water . . . gone.		8	813	751	23	ホウ、ハッ、ホッ、フラン	のり	This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial<strong> method</strong>, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the <em>water</em> until they were all <em>gone</em>.	"There already was a <a href=""../v4/418.html"">system</a> (#418 制) for butchering cows, a <a href=""../v4/421.html"">technique</a> (#421 芸) for turning smoke into flowers - why can't there be a <em>method</em> of about the same relevance for making <em>water</em> <em>gone</em>? Evaporation anyone?"	Following from the last frame; when rubbing isn't good enough, WATER is the best<strong> METHOD</strong> for making sure the SOIL on your ELBOW is GONE.	If all the water is gone, we must develop new<strong> method</strong>s to survive. (Imagine Earth devoid of water, the opposite of the movie Waterworld).	The Heisig<strong> Method</strong> will Water down your kanji problems, until at some point, they are gone.		
会		meeting	<i>Meeting</i> . . . <i>wall</i>. This is the full character for <b>meeting</b>, from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name.		6	814	752	23	カイ、エ	あ.う、あ.わせる、あつ.まる	At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business<strong> meeting</strong> in a very special room where the walls are …<strong> meeting</strong>. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these<strong> meeting</strong>s, he's the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.	The only thing created in most<strong> meeting</strong>s is a lot of hot air. Imagine a <em>cloud of it rising</em> to the <em>roof</em>.	Easy: (secret)<strong> meeting</strong>s are held between 4 walls.	No business<strong> meeting</strong> during honeymoon! <em>Ha-Ni-Mu</em>(n) ハニム.	When <em>rising clouds</em> want to hold a<strong> meeting</strong>, they need to an <em>umbrella</em> to gather under and keep them from flying everywhere.		
至		climax	<i>Wall</i> . . . <i>soil</i>. The key word allows for the full variety of connotations: to peak, to arrive at the end, and the like.		6	815	753	23	シ	いた.る	Sexual<strong> climax</strong>es don't always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground!	The<strong> climax</strong> of the Berlin Wall affair was the tearing of it to ground.	The Biblical Onan was condemned for his solo<strong> climax</strong>. Working ONE ELBOW furiously, he spilled his seed on the GROUND, and God was angry at his selfishness and wastefulness. (Perhaps the greatest punishment is that his name has been synonymous with such solitary pursuits throughout the ages since.).	He<strong> climax</strong>ed so hard, it spurted up on to the wall, and he soiled his pants in the process.	You put bags of<em> soil</em> against the bedroom <em>wall</em> to drown out the neighbour's <em>climax</em> noises.		
室		room	House . . . climax.		9	816	754	23	シツ	むろ	"You book a<strong> room</strong> in a love hotel called ""<em>Climax House</em>""."	A simple<strong> room</strong> is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.	This is the<strong> room</strong> of a “climax house”, that is, a Japanese love hotel.	"""Jesus, get a <strong>room</strong> you two."" So the couple went back to their <em>house</em> and <em>climaxed</em> there instead."	Under my <em>roof</em>, I've <em>climaxed</em> in every<strong> ROOM</strong>. I also enjoy doing it in different kinds of<strong> room</strong>s: the bedroom ( 寝室 ), Japanese-style<strong> room</strong>s ( 和室 ), even once in a changing<strong> room</strong> ( 更衣室 ).		
到		arrival	Climax . . . saber.		8	817	755	23	トウ	いた.る	"<a href=""Http://img168.imageshack.us/img168/7731/karatesd3.jpg"">Http://img168.imageshack.us/img168/7731/karatesd3.jpg</a> Just look at this image…"	Just as we were about to climax her father arrived with a sword.	<strong>Arrival</strong> of a hero always happens at the CLIMAX of the movie, and of course he carries a SABER to defeat the enemy.	The<strong> arrival</strong> of the main character from Yojimbo back in town with a <em>saber</em> in hand, is the unforgettable <em>climax</em> of the movie.	Musashi's rather late <strong>arrival</strong> for a duel, <em>sabre</em> in hand, is the <em>climax</em> of that novel…		
致		doth	"The archaic English form for ""does"" indicates a humble form of the verb ""to do."" It is made up of <i>climax</i> and <i>taskmaster</i>."		10	818	756	23	チ	いた.す	"This character is used in two very high-frequency words: ""you are welcome"" ( どう致しまして ) and the honorific form of onegaishimasu ( お願い致します ; おねがいいたします). Can't you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who<strong> DOTH</strong> the bidding of his <em>taskmistress</em>, is <em>climaxing</em> and yelling out "" お願い致します "" while she whips and says "" どう致しまして "". (This kanji also means ""to bring about"" and ""do humbly"", which is perfect for this image)."	To reach <em>climax</em> I<strong> doth</strong> the bidding of my dominatrix <em>taskmaster</em>.	"After he had climaxed Shakespeare is reported to have said to his <em>taskmistress</em>, ""The lady<strong> doth</strong> charge too much.""."	Let's have an irreverent take on a line from the play “Hamlet”, by William Shakespeare : “The lady<strong> doth</strong> protest too much.” : “The climaxing taskmistress<strong> doth</strong> whippeth too much”. Our taskmistress is enjoying the whipping so much, she climaxes. My taskmistress image comes from the classic game “Dungeon Keeper”. In this game, the “mistress” character is dressed in a 'domination' outfit, and whips your servants (goblins etc.) to make them work faster.	The <em>taskmaster</em> is my old English teacher. He loved Shakespeare, and the <em>climax</em> if his day was to hear his pupils say<strong> doth</strong>.		
互		mutually	When you draw this character think of linking two <i>walls</i> together, one right side up and the other upside down.		4	819	757	23	ゴ	たが.い、かたみ.に	The 69 position allows both parties to<strong> mutually</strong> give themselves pleasure.	If you can combined your <em>walls</em> with another house's <em>walls</em>, both houses would<strong> mutually</strong> benefit, by the increase in size….	"<strong>Mutually</strong> means ""You and You together""—two katakana ユ (yu)s interlocking top and bottom."	It feels better to imagine two elbows linked together in mutuality.	Pictograph, see book. To me this kanji looks like the T and L of<strong> mutually</strong> (in the first two strokes) mirrored upside-down just like the King/Queen/Valet of a card game. The two L's of<strong> mutually</strong> are there to remind you the pair of TL's are<strong> mutually</strong> joined by the L's (i.e. “two times T and L, joined by the L's”).		
棄		abandon	<i>Infant</i> . . . <i>buckle</i> (See frame 444) . . . <i>tree</i>.		13	820	758	23	キ	す.てる	Think of a really loud and annoying baby, you want to<strong> abandon</strong> it but it keeps coming back…so you take of your belt by the buckle, and buckle the baby to a tree!	"As in <a href=""../v4/415.html"">sash</a> (#415 帯), I treat the <em>one</em> <em>mountain</em> in the middle to mean Mt. Fuji (Japan's ichiban mountain). Now we see an <em>infant</em> being<strong> abandon</strong>ed on top of <em>Mt. Fuji</em> well above the <em>tree</em> line to die of exposure."	A terrible image of an<strong> abandon</strong>ed <em>infant</em>. Here he is in his little car seat <em>buckled</em> to a <em>tree</em>.	<strong>Note</strong>: This Kanji does not contain 山 (mountain) as part of its radicals, it can rather be broken down to 木 厶 凵 亠 一 . Hence, it would be best to avoid using mountain in your story. <strong>Story</strong>: An inhumane way to<strong> abandon</strong> an <em>infant</em> is to <em>buckle</em> him to a <em>tree</em>…	The<strong> abandon</strong>ned <em>infant</em> was <em>buckled</em> to a <em>tree</em>.		
育		bring up	Since the key word has to do with raising children to be strong both in mind and body, it is easy to coordinate the primitive elements: <i>infant</i> . . . <i>meat</i>.		8	821	759	23	イク	そだ.つ、そだ.ち、そだ.てる、はぐく.む	<strong>Bringing up</strong> your offspring means raising them from <em>infant</em> until they are <em>meat</em> ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But <strong>bring up</strong> will forver be <em>infant meat</em> to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs!	I will<strong> bring up</strong> my <em>infants</em> to eat <em>meat</em>. I'll not endure any vegetarian children in my house!	<strong>Bringing up</strong> an <em>infant</em> requires <em>months</em> of hard work.	Bringing up an infant on the Moon is easier than it is on Earth. (month=lunar) Gravity is lower, so they're easier to carry and they don't get hurt if they fall down. Best of all, their little space suits keep all that poopy smell inside!	Remember The Matrix ? There was a spectacular scene where you could see human <em>infants</em> brought up by the machines, as if they were vulgar <em>meat</em>, for the sole purpose of feeding from the human's biological energy.

To<strong> remove</strong> your <em>taskmaster</em>, <em>bring up</em> your middle <em>finger</em>.		
充		allot	Infant . . . human legs.		6	823	761	23	ジュウ	あ.てる、み.たす	"Scene at the baby factory: Manager: ""Good news! Your <em>infant</em> has been<strong> allot</strong>ted <em>human legs</em>"". Picture the “lot” as a parcel, placed near the infant, to be used later. The “lot” of human legs has been<strong> allot</strong>ed by some doctor, to be used later. Mnemonic “infant<strong> allot</strong>ed new pair of human legs”. Note: to<strong> allot</strong> means to apportion by lots, it has the same root as the word “lottery”.	Each <em>infant</em> gets its very own pair of <em>human legs</em>, <strong>allotted</strong> by God.	In China, you are only<strong> ALLOT</strong>ed one <em>INFANT</em> per family. My friends disagreed with that policy and <em>HUMAN LEGGED</em> it out of there!	God decided to<strong> allot</strong> each infant only <em>one pair of legs</em>.

What is a<strong> gun</strong> but a device for <em>allot</em>ting pieces of <em>metal</em>? One for you - BANG!…One for you - BANG!…One for you - BANG!…One for you - BANG!…etc.	During war, all <em>metal</em> is <em>allotted</em> to the effort to make more<strong> gun</strong>s.	If you picture the <em>infant</em> as Stewie from Family Guy, then it's easy to imagine him shaping whatever piece of <em>metal</em> he can get his hands onto into a<strong> gun</strong>. Stewie can already walk, so it's no surprise to see him get out of his cot with his <em>human legs</em>.	Japan doesn't have many<strong> gun</strong>s because they allot their metal to other things like cars and game consoles.		
硫		sulfur	Rock . . . infant . . . flood.		12	825	763	23	リュウ		<strong>Sulphur</strong> is like a <em>rock</em>, but it can stink like a <em>stream</em> of <em>infant</em> doodie.	Infants are baptised in streams inorder to prevent their descent into a place of<strong> sulphur</strong> and brimstone.	<strong>Sulphur</strong> IS a <em>rock</em>, but it often stinks like a <em>stream</em> of <em>infant</em> urine. It is the same color too!!!	"One day a woman found an infant near the brim of a volcanic crater (“brimstone” is another name of<strong> sulphur</strong>) who was made of yellow stone. She brought him back to the village. The next day the village was flooded. The villagers thus cursed the woman for bringing him to the village. – History: In the 8th century AD. Chinese scientists discovered that an explosive mixture could be produced by combining sulfur, charcoal and nitrate. We have learned <a href=""../v4/115.html"">nitrate</a> (#115 硝) and sulfur, charcoal comes in lesson 24."	Imagine an <em>infant</em> stranded on a <em>rock</em> in the middle of a <em>stream</em> of <strong>sulphuric</strong> acid, created by a nearby volcano… (<em>continued in next kanji</em>).

允		license	Elbow . . . human legs.		4	827	765	23	イン	じょう、まこと.に、ゆるす	In some Asian kung-fu version of James Bond, the main protagonist has a “License To Kill” with his deadly <em>elbows</em> and <em>human legs</em>. His suit is always stained of red blood at the <em>elbows</em> and <em>lower legs</em> (this to help create an image that distinguish the two elements).	A midget driver trying to pass the road test to get their driver's<strong> license</strong>. Their <em>elbows</em> are too short to turn the wheel and their <em>legs</em> are too short to reach the gas and breaks.	You need a <strong>license</strong> to show your <em>elbows</em> and <em>legs</em> in mid east countries.	To apply for your drivers<strong> license</strong> in Japan, you have to fill out lots of forms at standing-only counters. This kanji is a pictograph of you standing at the counter filling out the forms for your driver's<strong> license</strong>. Your <em>elbow</em> is bent, writing the necessary information on the form (in kanji, of course!); your <em>human legs</em> are getting tired from standing. Why can't they provide chairs and desks?	She did not pass her driver's <strong>license</strong> test: she steered with her <em>elbows</em> while texting and then with her <em>legs</em> while putting on make-up.		
唆		tempt	Mouth . . . license . . . walking legs.		10	828	766	23	サ	そそのか.す	I named the right part <em>legal prostitute</em> has it represents a walker [<em>walking legs</em>] with the <em>license</em>. It's easy to imagine a <em>legal prostitute</em><strong> tempt</strong>ing a man with her <em>mouth</em>.	Prostitutes in Amsterdam have a <em>license</em> to show off their <em>walking legs</em> and<strong> tempt</strong> customers with their <em>mouths</em>.	"Tip : the right side can be thought of as a profession where one works on the street, for which they require a ""<em>license</em> to work on their <em>walking legs</em>"". This could be a <em>sandwich man</em>, or a <em>prostitute</em> (see gorgon's story). In this case, it's easily remembered as a prostitute<strong> tempt</strong>ing passers-by with her <em>mouth</em>. The combination will appear again in frames 1014, and 1437, and another four times in RTK Volume 3, where it is known as <em>streetwalker</em> (which is very close)."	With a hot <em>mouth</em>, a <em>licence</em> to screw and a <em>pair of legs</em>, Amsterdam prostitutes are sure to<strong> tempt</strong> you.	The cop that pulled me over was such a prick, and I was sooo<strong> tempt</strong>ed to <em>mouth</em> off at him! However, I LEFT my mouth shut because I knew if I didn't, he would suspend my <em>license</em> for quite some time, and I'd be stuck with my <em>walking legs</em>.		
出		exit	The kanji for <b>exit</b> pictures a series of mountain peaks coming out of the <i>earth</i>. The two <em>mountains</em> one on top of the other, point to the only <strong>exit</strong> from Earth.		
山		mountain	Note the clearer outline of a triangular <b>mountain</b> here.		3	830	768	24	サン、セン	やま	YOU CAN'T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!	Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a<strong> mountain</strong> often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the<strong> mountain</strong> (see FRAME 775 for an example).	Chi chi chi chia. P p p penis!	Stroke order: Begin with the center vertical.	I wouldn't have thrown my <em>walking stick</em> in the <em>trash bin</em> if I'd known I'd be climbing a<strong> mountain</strong>!

Horror movie cliche 769: <strong>Bungling</strong> victim's <em>fingers</em> fumble & bungle trying to open the <em>exit</em> door.	You were<strong> bungling</strong> in the darkness and touched the <em>cactus</em> with your <em>fingers</em>. OUCH!!	Here's a guy who's<strong> bungling</strong> his first experience with his hand up a girl's skirt and ends up with his fingers in the exit hole. She yells: get out of my bung-hole!	After the brief press conference in China, the<strong> bungling</strong> President Bush put his <em>fingers</em> on the door to escape, but the <em>exit</em> was locked.		
岩		boulder	Mountain . . . rock.		8	832	770	24	ガン	いわ	A <em>mountain</em>-sized <em>stone</em> is known as a<strong> boulder</strong>. 炭		charcoal	Mountain . . . ashes.		9	833	771	24	タン	すみ	Burn enough<strong> charcoal</strong> and you'll have a <em>mountain</em> of<em> ash</em>.	"You get<strong> charcoal</strong> from volcano (""fire mountain"", 火山 ) ashes."	Imagine a that a <em>mountain</em> fell onto a pile of <em>ashes</em>, compressing it into<strong> charcoal</strong>.	A huge <em>mountain</em> sitting on top of some <em>ashes</em> will compress it into<strong> charcoal</strong> (I know not really - but this makes it easy to remember).	Gas or<strong> charcoal</strong> grill? BBQ aficionados agree:<strong> charcoal</strong> wins. The only downside is the <em>mountain</em> of <em>ash</em> to clean up afterwards.		
岐		branch off	Mountains . . . branch.		7	834	772	24	キ、ギ		On the left, there are three mountains. The road <strong>branches off</strong> to each of them. (Note: This kanji is mostly used for branches in the road).	In a lot of Super Nintendo-era RPGs, there are <em>mountain</em> levels to get through. You view them from overhead, so you can see a mazelike path with many <em>branches</em>. Picture your sprite characters at one such fork in the mountain path, as it <strong>branches off</strong> in two directions.	Mountain branches mean you branched off the mountain path. In other words, once you<strong> branch off</strong> from the mountain path you are going to have to hack your way through the branches.	You want to avoid the mountain road, so you <strong>branch off</strong> to an easier path.	I just picture a tall mountain with many branches growing off its right-hand side. So many, that the mountain loses balance and falls on its side.		
峠		mountain pass	Mountain . . . above . . . below.		9	835	773	24		とうげ	Heisig mentions at kanjiclinic.com that he wishes he'd chosen <strong>mountain pass</strong> for this keyword as it's closer to what the word means. If we do this, the kanji makes complete sense because a <strong>mountain pass</strong> is just <em>below</em> the <em>mountain</em> <em>top</em>.	"To the north of Lorien lies the Misty Mountains, and below their towering peaks are the Mines of Moria. The Fellowship of the Ring first tried for the<strong> MOUNTAIN PASS</strong> that goes above, but were halted by the wizardry of Saruman at Caradhras, and so are forced to take the<strong> MOUNTAIN PASS</strong> that goes below, through the mountain - a path long feared by Gandalf for the ancient evil that lurks there. Note : the kanji does in fact refer to a ""mountain pass""."	The place on the <em>mountain</em> where you stand <em>above</em> and look <em>down</em> upon all creation is the mountain peak.	You're stuck. You look <em>up</em> and see only <em>mountain</em>. You look <em>down</em> and see only <em>mountain</em>. How the hell do you get out of here? Oh, there's a<strong> MOUNTAIN PASS</strong>. Thank God!	The<strong> MOUNTAIN PASS</strong> helps you go <em>up</em> and <em>down</em> the <em>mountain</em>.		
崩		crumble	Mountain . . . companion.		11	836	774	24	ホウ	くず.れる、-くず.れ、くず.す	Sam and Frodo were steadfast <em>companions</em> even as <em>Mount Doom</em><strong> crumble</strong>d above them.	September 11. [lol it also has 11 strokes], whoever reported this story is a loser, get alife. This is the best story on the website.	Sept 11: The <em>twin towers</em> (= 朋 )<strong> crumble</strong> into a <em>mountain</em> of rubble. (thanks liosama).	You and your <em>companion</em> are climbing to the top of the <em>mountain</em> when it suddenly begins to<strong> crumble</strong>. Only one of you can survive - who's it going to be? You or your <em>companion</em>?	The reason to always bring a <em>companion</em> when you go climbing in <em>mountains</em>. It is unsteady and may<strong> crumble</strong> under you at any time. That's when you need that someone to pull you up again.		
密		secrecy	House . . . invariably . . . mountain.		11	837	775	24	ミツ	ひそ.か	To maintain<strong> secrecy</strong>, secret societies invariably have to house themselves in the moutains.	To maintain<strong> secrecy</strong>, secret societies invariably have to house themselves on top of the moutains. (Slight tweak of chamcham's story, using fuaburisa's idea for remembering where to put the mountain primitive.).	"This kanji tells you an original version of ""Brokeback <strong>Mountain</strong>"". Here, the couple of cowboys have fallen in love, and their only way to keep their love in <strong>SECRECY</strong> is by meeting <strong>invariably</strong> at the<strong> house</strong> on the top of the <strong>mountain</strong>."	<strong>Secrecy</strong> in your house, invariably leads to a mountain of trouble.	My lover and I had a <em>house</em> in the <em>mountains</em> so that we could meet in<strong> secrecy</strong>, but it was <em>invariably</em> found out by my wife.		
蜜		honey	House . . . invariably . . . insect.		12	838	776	24	ミツ、ビツ		When I think of<strong> honey</strong>, I think of a bee hive, which is a HOUSE that INVARIABLY has INSECTS.	A <em>house</em> with a lot of<strong> honey</strong> will <em>invariably</em> attract many <em>insects</em>.	The “house” which is invariably divided in hexagons and is full of insects is where<strong> honey</strong> comes from (a bee hive).	<strong>Honey</strong> left in a <em>house</em> will <em>invariably</em> attract <em>insects</em>.	"Think of a queen bee that has been forcefully separated from her ""king bee"" and put in a luxurious beehouse to produce<strong> honey</strong> for a factory. Despite all the homely comforts, she weeps all day from a broken heart, thereby producing some of the most foul-tasting<strong> honey</strong> anyone has ever tried."		
嵐		storm	Mountain . . . winds.		12	839	777	24	ラン	あらし	<strong>Storm</strong> is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here).	<em>Winds</em> are gathering at the base of the <em>mountain</em> (note the hint to primitive placement), going up, and turning into a huge mountain<strong> storm</strong>.	What a<strong> storm</strong>! Even a <em>mountain</em> was carried off by the <em>wind</em>!	A<strong> storm</strong> is <em>winds</em> strong enough to lift a <em>mountain</em>!	You are sitting on top of Fuji, enjoying spectacular view of the<strong> storm</strong> below.		
崎		promontory	<i>Mountain</i> . . . <i>strange</i>. Hint: you might save yourself the trouble of a story here simply by recalling the kanji for <i>cape</i> (Frame 164) and toying around with the differing images suggested by the key words <b>promontory</b> and <i>cape</i>.		11	840	778	24	キ	さき、さい、みさき	This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with <em>mountain</em> in place of <em>soil</em>. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives<em> stone</em> and <em>strange</em>. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which<strong> promontory</strong> is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.	A<strong> promontory</strong> is a small, <em>strange mountain</em> that juts out into the sea.	<strong>Pro<em>mount</em>ory</strong>. A <em>strange</em> word, indeed.	A<strong> promontory</strong> is a <em>mountain strange</em> (not a mountain range) that juts out like Cape Odd.	Ayumi Hamasaki 浜崎 あゆみ will promote her Nagasaki 長崎 concert with a <em>strange</em> promotional stunt: she will ride a Kawasaki 川崎 to the top of a<strong> promontory</strong> <em>mountain</em>.		
崖		bluffs	Mountain . . . cliff . . . ivy.		11	841	2227	24	ガイ、ゲ、ギ	がけ、きし、はて	"Standing at the base of the<strong> bluffs</strong> I announce, ""I'm going to climb those <em>ivy-covered cliffs</em>, and then the <em>mountain</em> on top of them."" My friends don't believe me, ""He<strong> bluffs</strong>!"" they say."	"The <em>ivy</em>-covered <em>cliff</em> we saw on the <a href=""../v4/157.html"">horizon</a> (#157 涯) … the sheer beauty of the <em>mountain</em> that overlooks these<strong> bluffs</strong> is enough to make you want to swim for shore yourself!"	"This is used in the title of the 2008 Studio Ghibli film ""Ponyo on the <em>Cliff</em> by the Sea"" <a href=""midori://search?text=%E5%B4%96%E3%81%AE%E4%B8%8A%E3%81%AE%E3%83%9D%E3%83%8B%E3%83%A7%E3%80%82"">崖の上のポニョ。</a> ""Ponyo on the <em>Mountain-high Ivy-covered</em><strong> Bluffs</strong> by the Sea"" is an alternative title. <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponyo_on_the_Cliff_by_the_Sea"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponyo_on_the_Cliff_by_the_Sea</a>." To get to the MOUNTAIN<strong> BLUFFS</strong> you have to scale the IVY CLIFFS.		
入		enter	"This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to <b>enter</b> someplace. Since the ""in"" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character."	* As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: <i>to go in</i>, <i>to put in</i>, <i>to come in</i>, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for <i>umbrella</i>, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for <i>eight</i>. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form.	2	842	779	24	ニュウ、ジュ	い.る、-い.る、-い.り、い.れる、-い.れ、はい.る	Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.	Gordon Freeman <strong>enters</strong> the Black Mesa corporation's headquarters on that fateful day, after starting up a game of Half-Life (this kanji looks exactly like the lambda from the logo when written).	"Something only a Native American could pull off instead of saying ""Come in please."". When used as a primitive, instead of<strong> enter</strong>, I use a <strong>tepee</strong> for this character. See my stories up to <a href=""../v4/787.html"">sue</a> (#787 訟)."	Note that the printed character and the written character appear very differently.	HAIRU<strong> ENTER</strong> 入る person<strong> enter</strong>s stage left.		
込		crowded	Enter . . . road.		5	843	780	24		こ.み、 -こ.み、 -こ.む、 こ.む、 こ.める	During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to <em>enter</em> the <em>roadway</em> as it is<strong> crowded</strong> with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour.	Everybody tries to <em>enter</em> the <em>road</em> during rush hour. That's why it's so<strong> crowded</strong>.	"There is a Japanese comedy skit where they play a trick on an unaware person who is walking down a quiet empty street. The trick is that a huge <strong>crowd</strong> suddenly <em>enters</em> the <em>road</em> and stampedes towards the person. <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qb7zwr3vQKo"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qb7zwr3vQKo</a> (thanks, decals)."	Don't enter the main roads in Tokyo on weekdays… they are<strong> CROWDED</strong>.	It's so <strong>crowded</strong> that even <em>stepping into</em> the <em>road</em> doesn't relieve the problem. 分		part	Go in . . . dagger.		4	844	781	24	ブン、フン、ブ	わ.ける、わ.け、わ.かれる、わ.かる、わ.かつ	When something is <em>entered</em> by a <em>dagger</em>, it ends up being cut in several <strong>parts</strong>.	"(This kanji also has the meanings of ""understand"" and ""minute""). It's important to understand that were you to <em>enter</em> an hour with a <em>dagger</em> and cut it into <strong>parts</strong>, those <strong>parts</strong> would be minutes."	"Perhaps one of the most read kanji in Japanese. It means to understand, to<strong> part</strong>, fraction, to break up, rate, minute, etc. To understand something completly one must <em>enter</em> a <em>dagger</em> into it to break it up into its <strong>part</strong>s. Imagine understanding a body by doing an autopsy(<em>enter, dagger</em>) and studying the <strong>parts</strong>. <a href=""midori://search?text=%E5%88%86%E3%81%8B%E3%82%8A%E3%81%BE%E3%81%99%E3%81%8B%EF%BC%9F"">分かりますか？</a> ."	I cut the cake in to <em>eight</em><strong> part</strong>s by using a <em>dagger</em>. Then I ate one<strong> part</strong> every minute. (I just found eight easier to use than enter.).	Forget mnemonics for this one. Just look at it, it's a sword<strong> part</strong>ing the line above it (cutting it into two<strong> part</strong>s). Easy!		
貧		poverty	Part . . . shells/money.		11	845	782	24	ヒン、ビン	まず.しい	In the case of true<strong> poverty</strong>, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn't really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole.	Parting with your money will lead to<strong> poverty</strong>.	Nice one darg_sama. Since I imagine <em>part</em> as a section of a pie chart, I'll think of a pie chart representing the causes of<strong> poverty</strong>. <em>Shells</em> (lack of money) is just one <em>part</em> of the pie chart.	<strong>Poverty</strong> is having only a PART of the MONEY you need to get by.	Imagine someone so poor they only have part of a penny(or shell).		
頒		partition	Part . . . head.		13	846	783	24	ハン	わか.つ	The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji<strong> PARTITION</strong>.	The last time I tried to<strong> partition</strong> a hard drive under Linux, I got a severe migraine that parted my head.	There are different <em>parts</em> of the <em>head</em> and they each have their own<strong> partition</strong>s: the corpus callosum, the different hemispheres, etc.	The head is<strong> partition</strong>ed into parts. Thinking of the head as a “hard drive” (where all the information we know is stored) we may imagine the head being<strong> partition</strong>ed just like a 3D pie chart.	"Ｔｈｉｎｋ　ｂａｃｋ　ｔｏ　８２ <a href=""midori://search?text=%E9%A0%85%E3%80%81"">項、</a> the craft of starting a paragraph. This time you want to<strong> partition</strong> the page instead so add 分 part to the front instead."		
公		public	<i>Come in</i> . . . <i>elbows</i>. Use the key word in its adjectival sense, not as a noun.		4	847	784	24	コウ、ク	おおやけ	I always open the doors to the<strong> public</strong> restrooms with my elbows because I don't want to touch the door with my hands.	I always <em>enter</em> the doors to the<strong> public</strong> restrooms with my <em>elbows</em> because I don't want to touch the door with my hands.	The<strong> public</strong> trains in Japan are so crowded, to <em>enter</em> you have to <em>elbow</em> your way in.	It's bad manners to put your <em>elbows</em> on the table when you eat. So, when I <em>come in</em> to<strong> public</strong> restaurants, I always make sure that I keep my <em>elbows</em> down, out of the<strong> public</strong>'s eye. (notice: down helps me keep track of where the elbow primitive goes). 谷		valley	<i>Go in</i> . . . <i>an umbrella</i> . . . <i>a mouth</i>. Because of space restrictions, the element for <i>go in</i> is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a <b>valley</b> stands out more clearly: the <i>mouth</i> of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way.		7	851	788	24	コク	たに、きわ.まる	This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of<strong> valley</strong>: a<strong> valley</strong> <em>mouth</em> open under the <em>umbrella</em> of inner labia, with the outer labia <em>parted</em> above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will <em>enter</em> no further…	Think of the classic anime 風の <strong>谷</strong>のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the <em>Valley</em> of the Wind). We see Nausicaa <em>entering</em> the <em>valley</em> <em>mouth</em> gliding on an <em>umbrella</em>.	Yea, though I <em>enter</em> the<strong> valley</strong> of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for I have brought my <em>umbrella</em> and if anything scares me, I will open my <em>mouth</em> and scream for help!	Pictograph - a little house with mountains behind.	<em>Enter</em> the<strong> valley</strong> with an <em>umbrella</em> and your <em>mouth</em> closed the mist is quite throat irritating.		
浴		bathe	Water . . . valley.		10	852	789	24	ヨク	あ.びる、あ.びせる	This story is quite lascivious, sorry… Now, imagine you are at a 混浴 （こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen ( 温泉 ), and you are watching a woman<strong> bathe</strong>. The mountain man uses the <em>water</em> from the <em>valley</em> to<strong> bathe</strong>.	Cleavage in Japanese is called the <em>valley</em> of the chest, and <strong>bathing</strong> sends <em>water drops</em> into that valley. Memorable image, I think you'll agree.	In a <em>valley</em> full of <em>water</em> you may<strong> bathe</strong>.	Green Giant takes a bath in a <em>valley</em> filled with <em>water</em>.

裕		abundant	This character shows the typical <i>cloak</i> of <i>valley</i> folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free-form. Hence the key word's meaning of <b>abundant</b>.		12	856	793	24	ユウ		"Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called ""<em>valley</em> of the chest"": a woman with<strong> abundant</strong> cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting <em>cloak</em>, but leaving her <em>valley</em> exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I'll be here all week)."	Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are<strong> abundant</strong> in the valley”.	Elven <em>cloaks</em> are<strong> abundant</strong> in the <em>valley</em> of Rivendell.	She used a <em>cloak</em> to hide her<strong> abundant</strong> <em>valley</em> from prying eyes.	[+rtkrtk] It's said that cleavage actually looks like the cleavage of the rear end - in other words, it looks like a bun dent, or <strong>abundant</strong>. Imagine a magazine called<strong> abundant</strong> a-bun-dents, and the winter issue features pretty woman wearing nothing but a heavy trench coat, exposing her<strong> abundant</strong> a-bun-dents, featuring <em>Hidden Valley Ranch</em> seductively poured all over them. 鉛		lead (metal)	Metal . . . gully.		13	857	794	24	エン	なまり	Picture the molten <em>lead</em> (the heavy <em>metal</em>) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a <em>gully</em> behind.	<strong>Lead</strong> is a very poisonous metal, and should not enter your mouth.	<strong>Lead</strong> -> Dental fillings -> Metal that enters the mouth to fill a hole in a tooth.	"One term in Chinese for a pussy is the ""golden gully"". That is exactly the literal meaning of the two parts of this Kanji. Helps me remember that<strong> lead</strong> is used in the word 鉛筆 えんぴつ for pencil.

党		party	Think of this key word as referring to a political <b>party</b>, not a gala affair. Its elements: <i>human legs</i> . . . sticking out of an <i>outhouse</i> window.		10	860	797	25	トウ	なかま、むら	Every major political<strong> party</strong>, if personified, would look like a giant <em>outhouse</em> walking around with <em> human legs</em> spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.	Every political<strong> party</strong> is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here's your answer - a political<strong> party</strong> memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He's grown so accustomed to the taste that he's in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He'll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.	"Here's an easy one from current events. Recently a certain senator, member of a family-values political<strong> party</strong>, was caught in an <em>outhouse</em> touching the <em>human legs</em> of the guy in the stall next to him - who happened to be a police officer. True story, folks - search for ""wide stance senator"" for details."	Politicians in the (insert<strong> party</strong> name here)<strong> party</strong> deliver so much bullcrap, they might as well be outhouses on legs.	Since he refused to become a member of the Chinese Communist<strong> Party</strong>, he was shoved into the outhouse with only his legs sticking out.		
堂		hall	Outhouse . . . land.		11	861	798	25	ドウ		In most communities you will be hauled into city<strong> hall</strong> if you use the <em>ground</em> as an <em>outhouse</em>.	There is a secret<strong> hall</strong> buried in the <em>soil</em> underneath the <em>outhouse</em>.	"The smallest public chamber you can imagine is a public <em>toilet</em> (<em>outhouse</em>): always quite <em>dirty</em>. NB: see also <a href=""../v4/784.html"">public</a> (#784 公)." Imagine going to an election and having to trudge up a mound of dirt, then sit in a cramped, smelly <em>port-a-potty</em> along with several other citizens just to hear this week's minutes.
