俊		sagacious	Person . . . license . . . walking legs.		9	1089	1014	27	シュン		The entire town wants to get rid of <em>legal prostitutes</em>, but the<strong> sagacious</strong> <em>Mr T</em> realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.	(re: sweetneet) Since he is not very<strong> sagacious</strong>, <em>Mr. T</em> failed his driver's <em>license</em> and now needs to resort to his <em>walking legs</em> to get around.	"This is the first time I heard of the word<strong> sagacious</strong>, so I looked it up at dictionary.com and found <a href=""http://dictionary.reference.com/search?db=dictionary&amp;q=sagacious"">http://dictionary.reference.com/search?db=dictionary&amp;q=sagacious</a>. For the definition they give the example of ""a<strong> sagacious</strong> lawyer"". And let a lawyer be a <em>person</em> that has a <em>license</em> to practice law and who <em>walks</em> frantically through the courtroom as he tries to sway the jury. To add some drama: he's defending Osama bin Laden (can be used as the <em>person</em> element)."	People who just get their drivers <em>license</em> think they are better than anyone else. But, in reality, the <em>people</em> who are<strong> sagacious</strong> are the ones who used their <em>walking legs</em> as much as possible (since it's better for their health).	"A <em>person</em> who is has been a <em>streetwalker</em> is probably very<strong> sagacious</strong> about human nature. see <a href=""../v4/766.html"">tempt</a> (#766 唆)."		
傍		bystander	Person . . . stand . . . crown . . . compass.		12	1090	1015	27	ボウ	かたわ.ら、わき、おか-、はた、そば	In Japan, the emperor is a<strong> bystander</strong> - he <em>stands on his crown</em> but can't really affect the <em>direction</em> of the country. (thx shimouma).	Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand… he's asking the<strong> bystander</strong> if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).	<em>Mr. T</em> is tired of being a<strong> bystander</strong>, he <em>stands up</em> and takes the king's <em>crown</em> for himself to change the <em>direction</em> of the country.	"Side Note: The right side of this kanji is itself a kanji (but not a kanji given in Heisig) meaning ""The right hand side of a kanji"" (旁【つくり】). It can also mean ""at the same time."" Not sure if this is useful, but it seemed interesting…"	Many cultures have some traditional story about the <em>sovereign</em> who disguises himself as a peasant or traveler, a<strong> bystander</strong> if you will, to judge the moral <em>compass</em> of his <em>people</em>.		
俺		myself	The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: <i>person</i> . . . <i>St. Bernard</i> . . . <i>eel</i>.		10	1091	2058	27	エン	おれ、われ	<strong>Myself</strong> as used by men – a <em>person</em> who prides himself on how <em>big</em> his “<em>eel</em>” is.	"""I did it all by<strong> myself</strong>!"" <em>Mr T</em> stands there proud as holding a <em>moray eel</em> in his hand. He's brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish… what a guy."	"As astridtops mentions, this is ""Ore"". In Japanese r = l, so could write it ""Ole"". So picture a bullfight with <em>person</em> as the matador and a <em>dachshund</em> replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting ""Ole! (Ore)""."	"(note: this is the kanji for 'ore'). ""I,<strong> myself</strong>, am the <em>person</em> who will kill the <em>Midgard Snake</em>"", the god Thor bellows. Since he's not known for his politeness, you can see him using 'ore' to refer to himself…"	"<em>Mr T</em> is unfortunately bragging a bit here - ""Myself? I have got a pretty big mini-<strong>myself</strong>. It's actually right around the size of a <em>moray eel</em>, sucka."" And as opposed to the Japanese, who point to their noses to refer to their own<strong> myself</strong>, or cultures that point to their body, when <em>Mr T</em> wants to refer to his<strong> myself</strong>, he points to his <em>moray eel</em>."		
久		long time	This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for <i>bound up</i> and a <i>person</i>. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind.		3	1092	1016	27	キュウ、ク	ひさ.しい	Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり .<strong> Long time</strong> no see <em>mummy</em>! (A bound up person).	"This is a picture of a person bowing ""long time no see!""."	"Be careful if you're using alternate primitives for this kanji! There are only three strokes, and the stroke order is similar to <em>bound up</em> with an extra 'leg' like the last stroke of <em>person</em>. Using <em>recline</em> and <em>person</em> would give you four strokes. Using <em>drop</em> and <em>enter</em> would give the wrong stroke order and the wrong shape in handwritten kanji, even though they all look kind of the same in print. See <a href=""http://www.mahou.org/Kanji/3557/"">http://www.mahou.org/Kanji/3557/</a> (bottom of page) for the handwritten style."	That <em>bound up</em> <em>person</em> is a <em>mummy</em>, he's been that way for a<strong> long time</strong>.	A mummy is a <em>person</em> who has been <em>bound up</em> for a <strong>long time</strong>.		
畝		furrow	Think of the three kinds of <b>furrows</b> shown here in this character - a <i>top hat's</i> rim, a <i>rice field's</i> ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a <i>long time</i>.		10	1093	1017	27	ボウ、ホ、モ、ム	せ、うね	Using a TOP HAT to make<strong> FURROW</strong>S in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!	A <em>mummy</em> tries to<strong> furrow</strong> his brow but realizes that he's got no head - just a <em>brain</em> with a <em>top-hat</em> on it. So he <strong>furrow</strong>s his <em>brain</em>. [trigger:<strong> furrow</strong> your <em>brain</em>].	A man from the city, thus wearing a <em>top hat</em>, working in a <em>field</em>, takes a very <em>long time</em> to dig a simple<strong> furrow</strong>.	Correct keyword: <strong>ridge</strong> ( 畔 ->waterside). ( 畝 is used in 畝間 , meaning<strong> furrow</strong>, but that's because the interval between ridges is a<strong> furrow</strong>). Words: 畝 (ridge/rib), 畝織り (ridged fabric). Story: A <em>rice field</em> is actually a secret burial ground for <em>mummies</em>. Each <strong>ridge</strong> is actually a sarcophagus. The <em>mummies</em> are buried under the <strong>ridges</strong>, and each <em>mummy</em> has a <em>top hat</em> which takes up the remaining length of the <strong>ridge</strong>, filled with his riches.	The farmer uses a <em>mummy</em> to plow<strong> furrow</strong>s in the <em>field</em>, but he disguises him with a <em>tophat</em> so he doesn't scare the neighbors.		
囚		captured	Person . . . pent in.		5	1094	1018	27	シュウ	とら.われる	A person <em>pent in</em> is obviously<strong> captured</strong>. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.	Mr. T can't be<strong> captured</strong>. This kanji is lying.	They've finally <em>pent in</em> <em>Mr. T</em>. But don't worry; no one can keep T<strong> captured</strong>, foo!	There is a butt<strong> captured</strong> within this picture. Lol!	"This is a very easy kanji. A PERSON who is PENT IN is obviously<strong> captured</strong>. DO NOT USE MR. T! Why people are using this as a primitive element is beyond me. MR. T is the variant of person when it appears on the left side of a kanji. Do not confuse your PERSON and MR. T or you'll never know which one to use when you have a MR. T story. Keep each version of a primitive distinct in your naming. (Think of the difference between using ""heart"" and ""valentine"")."		
内		inside	<i>Person</i> . . . <i>belt</i>. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of <i>hood</i> here because the <i>person</i> runs THROUGH the element, not under it.		4	1095	1019	27	ナイ、ダイ	うち	<em>Mr. T</em>'s new <em>belt</em> is huge! When he's <strong>inside</strong> it, his feet no longer touch the ground!	A seat<em>belt</em> keeps a <em>person</em><strong> inside</strong> the vehicle.	How is a <em>person</em> ever supposed to get<strong> inside</strong> that girl when she's wearing such a huge chastity <em>belt</em>? I guess that's kinda the point, eh?	A person who fell through the roof of their house, now their legs are<strong> inside</strong>.	In Washington DC someone who is an<strong> inside</strong>r is someone who knows everything within the <em>belt</em> way.		
丙		third class	"Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>belt</i>. The kanji meaning ""<i>inside</i>"" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for ""<i>in</i>."""		5	1096	1020	27	ヘイ	ひのえ	In this<strong> third class</strong> flight, the seat<em>belts</em> are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the <em>persons</em> hit the ceiling. (it's almost pictographic here!).	Travelling by ship <strong>third class</strong> the cabins are all <em>inside</em> (no windows) and the <em>ceilings</em> are so low you hit your head.	But<strong> third class</strong> is so small Mr. T's head hits the celing.	Mr T. hates flying<strong> third class</strong>. His head hits the ceiling, and the buckle on the seatbelts scratch his new belt.	The <em>ceiling</em> <em>inside</em><strong> third class</strong> is exceptionally low.		
柄		design	Tree . . . third class.		9	1097	1021	27	ヘイ	がら、え、つか	Half Way!!!!	"This is a ""<em>design</em>"" as in a ""pattern"", not a verb as in ""to <em>design</em>"". The <strong>tree</strong> grain <em>design</em> was too expensive for the <strong>third class</strong> airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it."	Makes me think of Ikea. Everything is <em>wooden</em> and the<strong> design</strong> is really nice but the quality really is <em>third rate.</em>.	The third class seats on the train are very simply<strong> design</strong>ed. In fact, they're not<strong> design</strong>ed at all. They're just wooden stumps of trees.	<strong>DESIGN</strong> makes me think of 'intelligent<strong> design</strong>', the <em>third class</em> alternative to evolution for the hard-of-thinking. You'd have to have solid <em>wood</em> between your ears to believe it!		
肉		meat	"Let this doubling of one of the elements for ""<i>inside</i>"" yield the sense of ""<i>insides</i>"" to approach the key word, <b>meat</b>. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of <i>flesh</i> or <i>part of the body</i> for the kanji 月."		6	1098	1022	27	ニク	しし	Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.	A <em>person's</em> <em>inside</em> - fleshy, raw, pink,<strong> meat</strong>.	"To avoid confusion with the <em>flesh</em> primitive from <a href=""../v4/13.html"">month</a> (#13 月), I'm nicknaming this one: <em>soylent green</em>. It's easy to remember since ""Soylent green is people!""."	Inside a person is<strong> meat</strong>.	I like narafan's story that captures the primitives nicely, but I'm with Rakushun and fuaburisu - this is just a pictograph of a slab of<strong> meat</strong> (I picture a t-bone steak), and it gets reinforced since you constantly see it on menus.		
腐		rot	Municipality . . . meat.		14	1099	1023	27	フ	くさ.る、-くさ.る、くさ.れる、くさ.れ、くさ.らす、くさ.す	The <strong>rotting</strong> <em>meat</em> <em>adheres</em> to the <em>cave</em> walls.	Smaller <em>municipalities</em> are well known for filling their budgets with <em>pork (meat)</em>. Thats why they are also well known for being<strong> rot</strong>ten.	The <em>municipality</em> workers in their <em>cave</em> are too busy with bueraucracy and <em>adhering</em> to rules so they cannot regulate and measure the huge delivery of <em>meat</em> that was made days ago. So it just lies in the back of the cave to<strong> rot</strong> as more work piles up.	Resident Evil reference: The MUNICIPALITY of Raccoon City has been overrun by<strong> ROT</strong>TEN MEAT (zombies).	There's something<strong> rot</strong>ten in the municipality of Denmark.		
座		sit	Cave . . . assembly line . . . soil.		10	1100	1024	27	ザ	すわ.る	Coal mine (<em>cave</em>); tea break time; the <em>assembly line</em> stops and everyone<strong> sit</strong> or squat on the <em>dirt</em> floor, in a long line, to rest.	CONGRATULATIONS YOU'RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =).	Nice one Gorgon. I thought I would mention that the stroke order is non-standard here. With <em>soil</em> the vertical stroke comes first.	While working on an <em>assembly line</em> in a <em>cave</em>, there no benches on which to<strong> sit</strong>, so everyone just <strong>sits</strong> on the <em>ground</em>.	Tea break on the coal assembly line — Time to all<strong> sit</strong> in the dirt. (Coal mine is a cave of course :) You<strong> sit</strong> DOWN so the vertical downstroke of soil comes first! [—Thanks gorgon & wrightak!].		
挫		sprain	Fingers . . . assembly line . . . soil.		10	1101	2845	27	ザ、サ	くじ.く、くじ.ける	I <strong>sprained</strong> my <em>fingers</em> when I <em>sat in meditation</em> (by sitting in a strange position).	"(Using the primitives in the RTK1 addendum) The workers at the <em>assembly line</em> in the coal cave (<a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1024"">squat/sit</a> (#1024 座)) frequently claim to ""<strong>sprain</strong>"" their <em>fingers</em> because working within all the <em>dirt</em> around them is hard and they'd much rather stay at home."	I<strong> sprain</strong>ed in my <em>finger</em> doing a complicated mudra while <em>sitting in meditation</em>.	You might<strong> SPRAIN</strong> your FINGERS while SITTING IN MEDITATION if you suddenly put your hand out to catch yourself after falling asleep.	With your <em>fingers</em> you try to repair an <em>assembly</em> line that got broken after some <em>soil/dirt</em> got into it. But then the <em>assembly line</em> suddenly starts working. It spurts <em>soil</em> everywhere, and its movement also<strong> sprain</strong>s your poor <em>fingers</em>.		
卒		graduate	Top hat . . . assembly line . . . needle.		8	1102	1025	27	ソツ、シュツ	そっ.する、お.える、お.わる、ついに、にわか	Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(<em>needles</em>) with the cap and tassel(<em>top hat</em>). 傘		umbrella	Umbrella . . . two assembly lines . . . needle.		12	1103	1026	27	サン	かさ	There are two <em>assembly lines</em> at the<strong> umbrella</strong> factory. One is responsible for making the top of the<strong> umbrella</strong>, and the other for making the handle. The two lines <em>cross</em> at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.	FOUR PERSONS can fit under this<strong> UMBRELLA</strong> if they are thin as a NEEDLE.	A pictograph: 4 people sheltering under one big<strong> umbrella</strong>.	<em>Two couples</em> on a double date pool together <em>ten</em> dollars for a huge<strong> umbrella</strong> they can all stand under.	<em>Four people</em> under an<strong> umbrella</strong> is better than <em>ten</em>!		
匁		monme	This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: <i>bound up</i> . . . <i>arm</i>.		4	1104	1027	28		もんめ、め	"""Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!"" ""Yeah man, it's a bummer… with my arm like this I can only lift one<strong> monme</strong>!""."	"""Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!"" ""Yeah man, it's a bummer… with my arm like this I can only lift one<strong> monme</strong>!"" ""You'll never be able to use your dagger now!"" (adapted from ergerg)."	In Jamaica: Hey <strong>mon, may</strong> I have some (3.75 grams to be exact) uh dat leaf? I need it fo medical reasons. Look at my bound up arm!	Either Heisig or the person who put this on the list is an asshole. Most JP people have never seen it. Heisig admits is useless. I hope his arms get bound up by the police for carrying a<strong> monme</strong> of crack.	Very difficult to picture, however, a<strong> MONME</strong> is very light, only 3.75 grams. So, imagine your BOUND UP sore ARM. Now imagine the weight of the cloth that BOUND UP your ARM. Yep, you guessed it. It weighs one<strong> MONME</strong>.		
以		by means of	"Picture a <i>person</i> dragging a <i>plow</i> behind, and the <i>drop of</i> sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living ""<b>by means of</b> the sweat of their brows."""		5	1105	1028	28	イ	もっ.て	"A man earns his living<strong> by means of</strong> the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age ""ard"" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox."	Mr T now makes a living<strong> by means of</strong> a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.	<strong>By means of</strong> a <em>plow</em> and a sweat <em>drop</em> on his brow, a <em>person</em> earns his living.	<strong>By means of</strong> the plow, with sweat on his brow, a man earns his chow.	"以上 , 以前 , 以外 , 以降 , 以下 , 以て =以って=もって, 以心伝心 , <a href=""../v4/1028.html"">by means of</a> (#1028 以) イ, (もって) … Parts: レ, ソ, 丶 (cf: 似ている <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1029"">becoming/similar</a> (#1029 似) … Note: ’Plow’ is only used in 2 character 以 , 瓦 … Story: If you use ""Person"" in this Story, you might end up wanting to put 亻in it; more importantly the shape will be wrong. Learn your レ ソ n : This is written almost like those two Katakana characters then the drop last. Memorize it <strong>By Means of</strong> the Katakana plus a drop."		
似		similar	Be sure to keep this key word distinct from <i>likeness</i> (Frame 104). Its elements: <i>person</i> . . . <i>by means of</i>.		7	1106	1029	28	ジ	に.る、ひ.る	<strong>Mr. T</strong> finds that living <strong>by means of</strong> dragging a <strong>plow</strong> is <em>similar</em> to slavery.	A <em>Mr T</em> impersonator is <strong>becoming</strong><strong> similar</strong>er (more like) <em>by means of</em> plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.	A PERSON can become quite<strong> SIMILAR</strong> to someone else BY MEANS OF plastic surgery.	People / PERSONS when young , BY MEANS OF anything, try to be as<strong> SIMILAR</strong> to their peers as possible.	You can <strong>become<strong> similar</strong></strong> to <em>Mr. T by means of</em> a sweaty <em>plough</em> (your skin will get darker and your body will get more muscular).

"""Why do I gotta <strong>join</strong> these two <em>puzzle</em> pieces? I ain't got time for <strong>joining</strong> no jigsaw-jabba!"" <em>Mr. T</em> apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles."	<strong>Join</strong> <em>people</em> together like a <em>puzzle</em>. How do they fit?	"<em>Mr. T</em> is doing a <em>puzzle</em>. ""Just<strong> join</strong> the pieces , foo!""." 瓦		tile	Ceiling . . . plow . . . fishhook . . . a drop of.		5	1108	1031	28	ガ	かわら、ぐらむ	Horror scene: Hanging from the <em>ceiling</em>, a <em>plough</em> and <em>fishhook</em> <em>dripping</em> with blood down onto the <strong>tile</strong>d bathroom floor.	[<strong>true stroke order</strong>] First draw <em><strong>T</strong></em> for<strong> Tile</strong>, which then becomes <em><strong>I</strong></em>. Then draw an <em>'<strong>L</strong>' fish hook</em> with a <em>dash</em> in the middle to make a mediocre '<strong>e</strong>' that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).	Note: This <strong>tile</strong> means roof-<strong>tile</strong> (e.g. 屋根瓦 ), not the ones you put on the floor. Hanging from the <em>ceiling</em> of an old shed are a rusty <em>plow</em> and some tangled up <em>fishhooks</em>. Since the <strong>tiles</strong> on the roof are old and broken some rainwater is leeking through and you can see <em>drops</em> glistening between the <em>plow</em> and the <em>fishhooks</em>.	As said in errata, this is ceiling+plow+fishhook+a drop of (and stroke order goes accordingly). A plow is fixed on the ceiling and a fishhook is hanging on the plow, drawing a drop of blood from it (if animals can talk, why can't plows bleed? :-).	Simple ~ spell out the word. First draw a T, then add a line on the bottom to change it to an I. Draw an L (the fishhook shape) then go back and add a dash beside the I, like adding the center dash of an E.		
瓶		flower pot	Puzzle . . . tile.		11	1109	1032	28	ビン	かめ	A<strong> flower pot</strong> that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.	To solve this <em>puzzle</em> all you need is to put the<strong> flower pot</strong> on top of the proper <em>tile</em>. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).	Imagine a mosaic like<strong> flower pot</strong> made from <em>puzzle</em>-like pieces of <em>tile</em>.	Puzzle + Tile: A<strong> flower pot</strong> was revealed when I solved the <em>puzzle</em> made out of sliding <em>tiles</em>.	You knock the<strong> flower pot</strong> over and it breaks into pieces all over the floor <em>tiles</em>. You work furiously with your two hands to rearrange the pieces. It's almost like a <em>puzzle</em>. Hurry, your mom is almost home.		
宮		Shinto shrine	Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for <i>spine</i>. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a <b>Shinto shrine</b> is composed of <i>house</i> and <i>spine</i>.		10	1110	1033	28	キュウ、グウ、ク、クウ	みや	"A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: ""house with a spine,<strong> Shinto shrine</strong>""!"	"This<strong> Shinto shrine</strong> is built with human <em>spines</em>. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for ""sedlec ossuary"", it's quite a sight."	The <em>house</em> that serves as the <em>backbone</em> of Japanese religion is the<strong> Shinto shrine</strong>.	"Fact: Most of the traditional japanese Shinto families have a small<strong> Shinto shrine</strong> (kamidana) in their homes. Is very important for them; The<strong> Shinto shrine</strong> is really the <em>spine of the house</em>. <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamidana"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamidana</a>."	"A friend of mine made up this rhyme: ""<em>house with a spine</em>,<strong> Shinto shrine</strong>""! (Now Raichu's whole story rhymes :D)."		
営		occupation	Schoolhouse . . . spine.		12	1111	1034	28	エイ	いとな.む、いとな.み	The <em>schoolhouse</em> is the <em>backbone</em> of a foundation that will allow you to find a good<strong> occupation</strong>.	"During the German<strong> occupation</strong>, this Nazi officer's<strong> occupation</strong> was to manage <em>schools</em> that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect <em>spine</em> (mnemonic : ""the<strong> occupation</strong>'s <em>spine schools</em>""). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also ""barracks; camp; encapment"". This story should help avoid confusion with <a href=""../v4/824.html"">post</a> (#824 職) and <a href=""../v4/1083.html"">employ</a> (#1083 雇). The military<strong> occupation</strong> theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 ""detention barracks""."	Stay in <em>school</em> so you can get an<strong> occupation</strong> that doesnt require breaking your <em>backbone</em> all day.	"I get this confused with <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1792"">business/profession</a> (#1792 業). An<strong> occupation</strong> is something you can get after you leave the <em>schoolhouse</em> with a <em>backbone</em> of knowledge, but to get a profession you need to move on to higher education."	ATCHUNG!!! This keyword stands for <strong>Military<strong> occupation</strong></strong>, and not profession, as it could be (incorrectly) assumed from the primitives. Meanings: <strong>Management</strong>, <strong>Military Camp</strong>.		
善		virtuous	<i>Sheep</i> . . . <i>horns</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>. Pay special attention to the writing of this character.		12	1112	1035	28	ゼン	よ.い、い.い、よ.く、よし.とする	"Imagine a priest's teaching: ""To achieve <strong>virtue</strong> one must first submit himself as a <em>sheep</em> to God's flock, rejecting the <em>horns</em> of Satan and resisting the <em>mouth</em> of Hell."	"To be<strong> virtuous</strong>, a good rule to follow is to put your <em>sheepishness</em> (discretion) over your <em>horns</em> (anger) before using your <em>mouth</em>. In other words, ""discretion is the better part of virtue""."	Sheep proves to be<strong> virtuous</strong> by bringing food to its hungry baby, the two little <em>horns</em> and open <em>mouth</em> that are waiting under it for food.	There once was a beautiful girl. So<strong> virtuous</strong> and chaste. One day, however, she got really <em>horny</em>. Unfortunately, the only living creature was a <em>sheep</em>. Unable to resist her desire, she opened her <em>mouth</em>…	The<strong> virtuous</strong> <em>sheep</em> with the <em>horny</em> <em>mouth</em>.		
膳		dining tray	Flesh . . . virtuous.		16	1113	2468	28	ゼン、セン	かしわ、すす.める、そな.える	The <em>virtuous</em> vegan will not touch this<strong> dining tray</strong> because it has had a piece of <em>meat</em> on it.	Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the<strong> dining tray</strong>s are especially <em>virtuous</em> and never let any man touch their <em>flesh</em>.	As VIRTUOUS cannibals, we serve FLESH on<strong> DINING TRAY</strong>S.	I don't want a <em>virtuou</em>s girl - I want one who will let me use her naked <em>flesh</em> as a<strong> dining tray</strong> for sushi!	Vegetarians are <em>virtuous</em> because they never let any <em>meat</em> touch their<strong> dining tray</strong>. Note: also the counter for bowls (of rice) or pairs (of chopsticks); ーぜん.		
年		year	In an odd fashion, the kanji for <b>year</b> joins together the element for <i>horse</i>, on the top, and the right half of the element for <i>sunglasses</i>. Think of it as a <i>horse</i> wearing <i>sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out</i>. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.		6	1114	1036	28	ネン	とし	A <em>horse</em> wears a pair of <em>sunglasses with one lens popped out</em> after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New<strong> Year</strong>.	"A <strong>horse</strong> wears a <strong>monocle</strong> for New<strong> Year</strong>s to appear dignified for the<strong> year</strong> of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like <a href=""../v4/1308.html"">descend</a> (#1308 降)."	Hint: A pirate horse?	The<strong> year</strong> of the <em>pirate horse</em>!!! Picture it on the zodiac calendar. A horse with an eye patch.	"NOTE: 舛 is actually a radical meaning dancing legs. Can't you see the legs twisted about a pole perhaps? I am uncertain why Heisig chose sunglasses. Consider the last<em> dance </em>that a <em>horse </em>performs in a<strong> year</strong> for some festival. What do you mean, ""horses don't dance""? <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKQgTiqhPbw"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKQgTiqhPbw</a>."		
夜		night	First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of <b>night</b> with those of <i>evening</i> (Frame 114) and <i>nightbreak</i> (Frame 30). Its elements: <i>top hat</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i> . . . <i>drop</i>.		8	1115	1037	28	ヤ	よ、よる	"Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite ""walking legs."" It's a little more like ""evening"" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for<strong> night</strong> as: <em>evening</em> plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the <em>top hat</em> which my special <em>person</em> is wearing out on the town…"	Here we have <em>Mister T</em> sleepwalking, wearing a <em>top hat</em> as if he was the ambassador of the<strong> night</strong>, walking, and walking and walking on his tired <em>walking legs</em>, until he <em>drops</em> (back into his bed).	An elegant vampire. Going out in his<strong> night</strong> suit with a top hat, the creature looks like a person with long walking legs. The drop is the blood that the vampire seeks.	See this as an example of when the oldest profession in the world – prostitution – prefers to work. Even the wealthiest of gentleman in their <em>top hats</em> are ordinary <em>people</em>, and will not decline to deposit their <em>drops</em> between the <em>walking legs</em> of the streetwalkers out in the<strong> night</strong>.	Mr T was taking a stroll during the evening with his brand new top hat, and without even noticing, it turned from evening to<strong> night</strong> in a dash.		
液		fluid	Water . . . night.		11	1116	1038	28	エキ		A wet dream……..water<strong> fluid</strong> that comes out at night….	I imagined some kind of liquid (<em>water</em>) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes<strong> fluid</strong> only at <em>night</em>, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?	<em>water</em> at <em>night</em> => sexual<strong> fluid</strong>! エキ； 精液 せいえき　semen； 液晶 えきしょう　liquid crystal ( 画面 ).	Try not to drink too many<strong> FLUID</strong>S like WATER at NIGHT or you'll have to get up to pee.	Ninja's are<strong> fluid</strong> like <em>water</em> and they come out at <em>night</em>.		
塚		hillock	<i>Soil</i> . . . <i>crown</i> . . . <i>sow</i>. Compare frame 582.		12	1117	1039	28	チョウ	つか、-づか	There's already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the <strong>Hillock</strong>. It's <em>Ms. Piggy</em> sitting on top of a mound of <em>soil</em> in her <em>crown</em>.	The <em>crowned sow</em> (we met her in <em>overpowering</em>) is standing atop her little mound of <em>earth</em> -<strong> hillock</strong> - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.	<em>Napoleon the Pig</em> (from Orwell's Animal Farm) crowns himself king of the farm standing on a little mound (hillock) of <em>earth</em>.	These <em>pigs</em> are searching for truffles in the<strong> hillock</strong>s. Their noses track the <em>dirt</em>, and the one who finds the biggest truffles are <em>crown</em>ed, never to be eaten.	Auf der <em>Erde</em> vor mir liegt der <strong>Haufen</strong> der <em>gekrönten Sau</em> und was soll ich sagen, er sieht genauso aus, wie der <strong>Haufen</strong> jedes anderen gewöhnlichen Schweins.		
幣		cash	Shredder . . . towel.		15	1118	1040	28	ヘイ	ぬさ	A counterfeiter is using a <em>shredder</em> to shred a <em>towel</em> in order to print up some<strong> cash</strong> (he needs some rag paper) .	"In order to create some <strong>cash</strong>, first you feed a <em>towel</em> through a <em>shredder</em> to get the raw materials. (""Paper"" money isn't plain paper; it's mostly linen.)."	(The <em>shredder</em> isn't a mechanical shredder but a little animal kept in servitude by the taskmaster. The <em>little</em> critter has a <em>little belt</em> around its neck which the <em>taskmaster</em> yanks when he has a document to shred).	<em>Shredder</em> from TMNT is the <em>taskmaster</em> who rules over the foot clan. He wears a <em>belt</em> and has <em>little</em> spikes both above it (on his head/arms) and below it (on his legs). Here, a hotel demands that <em>Shredder</em> pay them some<strong> cash</strong> after they found out that he shredded all of their <em>towels</em>!	The Shredder(from Teenage mutant Ninja Turtles) uses his towel as a whip and grabs your<strong> cash</strong> and disappears like all ninjas do…. (story for SHREDDER primitive: the droplets are the pieces of shredder paper flying around. The vertical line is the paper feeder. The belt is to squeeze and pack the shredded paper. The taskmaster is the person shredding illegal documents for fear of a lawsuit.).		
蔽		cover over	Flower . . . shredder.		16	1119	2358	28	ヘイ、ヘツ、フツ	おお.う、おお.い	You<strong> cover over</strong> the <em>shredder</em> with <em>flowers</em> when the FBI comes a-knockin'.	"<em>Shredder</em> is writing a anonymous ransom note to the police. ""Bring me one billion dollars or I'll destroy your city with my Foot Soldiers! Signed, <em>Shredder</em>."" …oops! This was supposed to be anonymous, but he signed his own name! He can't re-write it now, he spent all that time doing the letter in beautiful calligraphy. What to do? …Thinking fast, <em>Shredder</em> grabs a large <em>daisy</em> and some tape, and <strong>covers over</strong> his name, leaving only the ""-er."" Good thinking, <em>Shredder</em>!"	The <em>taskmaster</em> arranges <em>flowers</em> to<strong> cover over</strong> the <em>rags</em> she makes us clean with.	See why the FLOWERS keep on falling into the SHREDDER? You keep on forgetting to put the<strong> COVER OVER</strong> it. After you finished with it dont forget to put the<strong> COVER over</strong> it so that the FLOWERS wont fall into it again.	SHREDDER COVERED OVER himself with FLOWERS so that the TMNT would not find him.		
弊		abuse	Shredder . . . two hands.		15	1120	1041	28	ヘイ		You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to<strong> ABUSE</strong> your plants by shredding them into wood chips.	Mafioso abusing someone to get information. They use a shredder on both of his hands.	<em>Shredder</em> is <strong>abusing</strong> Bebop and Rocksteady by bitch-slapping them with <em>both his hands</em>.	Shoving someone's <em>hands</em> into a <em>shredder</em> surely counts as<strong> abuse</strong>.	This really refers to<strong> abuse</strong> in terms of bad habits. The taskmaster puts your two hands in the shredder when he catches you picking your nose again. That'll fix your bad habits!		
喚		yell	The <i>mouth</i> on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: <i>four St. Bernard dogs bound up</i> in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a <b>yell</b>, provided you are careful to see all <i>four</i> of them. Note how the final stroke of the <i>four</i> is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the <i>St .Bernard</i>.		12	1121	1042	28	カン	わめ.く	Think yelp when you hear<strong> yell</strong> to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I'm imagining lots of yelping.	<strong>Yell</strong>? You mean, Old <strong>Yell</strong>er. Here, we see four <em>St Bernard dogs</em> all <strong>yell</strong>ing for a chance to play a part in Old <strong>Yell</strong>er. They're so loud that you have to <em>bound</em> them, and their <em>mouths</em>, up.	The musher<strong> yell</strong>s at the 4 dogs bound up to the dog sled to get them to run faster and cross the finish line first. (4 St Bernards bound up together makes a dog sled).	"<strong>Note:</strong> 奐 means ""clear; bright."" The keyword <a href=""../v4/20.html"">bright</a> (#20 明) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword <em>clear</em> alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. <strong>Story:</strong> Although I could not hear them, seeing their <em>mouth</em>es, it was <em>clear</em> to me that they are<strong> yell</strong>ing."	You have to<strong> yell</strong> really hard if you want the <em>four St. Bernard dogs</em> to pull the sled: they don't like being <em>bound up</em>.		
換		interchange	Fingers . . . four St. Bernard dogs bound up.		12	1122	1043	28	カン	か.える、-か.える、か.わる	After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling <em>four bound up St. Bernard dogs</em>: one snap of your <em>fingers</em> and they<strong> interchange</strong> their positions.	On the snap of your <em>fingers</em>, the <em>four St. Bernard dogs bound up</em><strong> interchange</strong> places.	"<strong>Note:</strong> 奐 means ""clear; bright."" The keyword <a href=""../v4/20.html"">bright</a> (#20 明) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword <em>clear</em> alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. <strong>Story:</strong> With their fast <em>finger</em> movement, it was not <em>clear</em> that any<strong> interchange</strong> was taking place."	Musher is going to <strong>interchange</strong> dogs in his <em>harness of four sled dogs</em> with four spare ones. Dogs can't reharness themselves, so he has to do it with his own human <em>fingers</em>.	Those <em>four st. bernards</em> all yelping to be Old Yeller? Truth is, they're pretty much<strong> interchange</strong>able…just pick one out with your <em>finger</em>…eeeny meeny miney moe…		
融		dissolve	<i>Ceiling</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>hood</i> . . . <i>human legs</i> . . . <i>spike</i> . . . <i>insect</i>. This is the maximum number of elements <i>to appear in</i> any story in the book.		16	1123	1044	28	ユウ	と.ける、と.かす	"I have created the element ""old camera"" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject's point of view, the light is captured by <em>one</em> <em>mouth</em> (the lens). The photographer is under a big <em>hood</em>, we only see his <em>legs</em>, and he is holding a <em>spike</em> in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little <em>insect</em> is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and<strong> dissolve</strong>s in the air."	I've seen this crazy thing with only <em>one mouth</em> that can<strong> dissolve</strong> up to <em>4 nails</em> and an <em>insect</em> at the same time. Sweet! (It's a venus flytrap, btw).	Just one single mouthful of cola has enough acidic power to<strong> dissolve</strong> 4 nails and one large live insect! Gross! (Not actually true, but meh…).	"鬲 is a ""reki"" <a href=""http://images.google.com/images?oe=utf-8&amp;q=%E9%AC%B2"">http://images.google.com/images?oe=utf-8&amp;q=%E9%AC%B2</a> Its <em>mouth</em> faces the <em>ceiling</em>, it's hooded, and it's got three legs. My magical <em>reki</em> has 2 <em>animal legs</em> in front and a <em>spike</em> in the back. It can <em>dissolve</em> any <em>insect</em> that dares pass between its mouth and the ceiling. My reki can also<strong> dissolve</strong> website designers who <em>bug</em> it by not allowing HTML links."	<strong>Dissolve</strong> (fuse, liquefied by heat) a man is welding a large hole in the <em>ceiling</em>. He sees his wife's <em>mouth</em> yelling at him from the floor above, but he can't hear her from inside the welding <em>helmet</em>. He steps back with his tiny <em>legs</em> onto a <em>nail</em> (ouch), all while a huge nasty stinging <em>insect</em> gets into his helmet. This guy is just having one of those days. :) <em>(This one is an abridged version of Fuaburisu, but I posted it because this kanji is so damn hard to remember by a story)</em>.		
施		alms	Banner . . . scorpion.		9	1124	1045	29	シ、セ	ほどこ.す	Under their <em>banner</em>, volunteers are requesting<strong> alms</strong> for <em>scorpion</em> sting victims.	"""<strong>ALMS</strong> for the poor"" cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl."	"(Note: This kanji also has the meanings ""apply bandages/administer first-aid""). With that sense, you see some poor man who has been stung by a <em>scorpion</em>, so you extract the blood and <strong>make bandages</strong> out of your <em>banner</em> to <strong>administer first-aid</strong> to him. The you take the man to an hospital and give him<strong> alms</strong> to pay for the cure."	The notorious Kane of the Brotherhood of Nod introduces a new policy to gain followers. Instead of making war, they now provide charity under their <em>Scorpion</em> <em>banners</em>. This 'switching from arms to <strong>alms</strong>' is widely criticized among his military officers.	"""Alms!<strong> Alms</strong> for the poor!"" A filthy old man sits under a ratty old <em>banner</em>, trying to get help from passers-by. Instead, he gets stung by a <em>scorpion</em>. Now he needs <strong>first aid</strong>. 施す (ほどこす) : to donate, to give, to conduct, to apply, to perform; 実施 (じっし) : enforcement, enact, put into practice, carry out, operation; 施行 しこう enforcement; 布施 ふせ<strong> alms</strong>."		
旋		rotation	<i>A banner</i> . . . <i>a zoo</i>. Hint: think of a merry-go-round.		11	1125	1046	29	セン		A merry-go-round with a big <em>banner</em> on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual<strong> rotation</strong> accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos…	Don't confuse with revolve or axis! Think of<strong> rotation</strong> as a<strong> rotation</strong> of animals in the <em>zoo</em> - some are on display (in<strong> rotation</strong>), some are in cages in the back (out of<strong> rotation</strong>). The ones currently in<strong> rotation</strong> (on display) are advertised with a large <em>banner</em>.	I had trouble remember this with previous zoo-banner-rotation stories, so here is something a bit more vivid: The future of ZOO technology: There is a giant Ferris Wheel-type contraption with individual plastic cages, each with an animal that ROTATES every 10 minutes. It's built half-way into the ground, can you envision it? The lazy people who watch wouldn't know what animal was what without the colorful BANNERS that accompany each cage.	"The zoo is now open and the electric BANNER that says ""ZOO"" is in full<strong> rotation</strong>."	The zoo banner rotates.		
遊		play	Banners . . . children . . . road.		12	1126	1047	29	ユウ、ユ	あそ.ぶ、あそ.ばす	The BANNER warns that CHILDREN<strong> PLAY</strong> on the ROAD. They mean ""drive slowly"", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) <strong>children</strong> that are at <em>play</em>." "Seeing how drivers ignore the <em>road</em> signs that warn about<strong> play</strong>ng children, the parents took matters in their own hands by making the kids wear bright <em>banners</em> on their backs, much like Japanese medieval soldiers (<a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sashimono"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sashimono</a>)."		
旅		trip	Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for <i>garment</i>, represent a <i>rag</i> as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: <i>banner</i> . . . <i>rag</i>.		10	1127	1048	29	リョ	たび	"The boat starts to leave on it's<strong> trip</strong> across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge <em>banner</em> that spans the width of the ship and says ""Bon Voyage"", the people wave their <em>rags</em> signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic."	After a long long<strong> trip</strong>, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.	When taking a<strong> trip</strong>, people wave goodbye with <em>banner</em>s and <em>rag</em>s.	"So Mr. T is walking down the street when he falls over this Banner. Someone yells ""Hey Mr. T, did you have a nice<strong> Trip</strong>?"". Mr. T gets so angry he rips the banner into Rags."	"When leaving on a short<strong> trip</strong>, some people wave ""Bon Voyage"" <em>banner</em>s, others wave their snot <em>rag</em>s. Don't confuse this with <a href=""../v4/880.html"">journey</a> (#880 往). 旅行 (りょこう) : travel,<strong> trip</strong>; 旅 (たび) : travel,<strong> trip</strong>, journey."		
勿		not	First take the primitive meaning of this character: <i>knot</i>. Think of it as the <i>piglet</i> minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a <i>knot</i>. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, <b>not</b>.		4	1128	1049	29	モチ、ブツ、ボツ	なか.れ、なし	This kanji is<strong> NOT</strong> a piglett.	"The butcher is standing over the piglet. ""This is a piglet…(cuts of head)…<strong>NOT</strong>!""."	"Three strings walk into a bar. The bartender throws them out, yelling ""Can't you read the sign?! I don't serve strings."" The strings try again, and again the bartender kicks them out. Finally, one of the strings gets the idea to mess himself up a little. He walks into the bar. The bartender scowls, ""What's wrong with you? Can't you read? I don't serve strings!"" The string replies, ""I'm a frayed knot!""."	Ceci<strong> NOT</strong> pas une piglette.	"<a href=""../v4/1820.html"">argument</a> (#1820 論)=( 論 )=RON argued, ""(<strong>勿</strong>論) '<strong>MOCHI</strong>'RON, this kanji is<strong> NOT</strong> a piglett…. ""."		
物		thing	Cow . . . knot.		8	1129	1050	29	ブツ、モツ	もの、もの-	"The <em>cow</em>'s ""<strong>thing</strong>"" is tied in a <em>knot</em>! ouch."	A <em>cow</em> is <em>not</em> a<strong> thing</strong>. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and<strong> thing</strong>s are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.	"A <em>cow</em> does <em>not</em> have a ""thing""! (Cows are female)."	It's <em>not</em> a <em>cow</em>, it's <em>not</em> a <em>piglet</em> (no head - it's <em>not</em> even close), it's just some strange -<strong>thing</strong>-.	For Hindus, a <em>cow</em> is <em>not</em> a<strong> thing</strong>, it's a god!		
易		easy	Sun . . . knot.		8	1130	1051	29	エキ、イ	やさ.しい、やす.い	The <em>sun</em> is <em>not</em> an<strong> easy</strong> place to get to.	Under the sun, it is<strong> easy</strong> to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so<strong> easy</strong>.	If you take the <em>ceiling off</em> your <em>piggy bank</em>, you'll have<strong> easy</strong> money!	It is <em>not</em><strong> easy</strong> to tie your <em>tongue wagging in mouth</em> in a <em>knot</em>.	"On a sailing ship, the old sailor challenges a new young recruit to a task and teases him : ""See the <em>sun</em> over there ? When it settles down way over there on the other side of the boat, you have to have untied that <em>knot</em>. You've got all <em>day</em> to untie that <em>knot</em>,<strong> easy</strong> ! ""."		
賜		grant	Shells . . . easy.		15	1131	1052	29	シ	たまわ.る、たま.う、たも.う	A<strong> grant</strong> is <em>easy money</em>.	"Do you want free <em>shells</em> from the government? It's <em>easy</em> with my new book, ""How to Get a Free<strong> Grant</strong> from the Government!"" Call today!"	"This<strong> grant</strong> is <em>shells</em> (money) that were awarded to you, or that someone ""deigned to give"" to you (another kanji meaning). Regardless, they are ""<em>easy shells</em>"" because you won't have to return them, and you didn't have to work for them! – ""grant is <em>easy shells</em>""."	A<strong> grant</strong> may seem like easy money, but then the kanji would be out of order. So you must justify the<strong> grant</strong> <em>money</em> first, then it will be <em>easy</em>.	MONEY that's EASY is a<strong> GRANT</strong>.		
尿		urine	Flag . . . water.		7	1132	1053	29	ニョウ		"Animals use their<strong> urine</strong> to mark their territory. So for them, their body <em>water</em> works as a <em>flag</em> denoting their ""country"" (<em>why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick</em>)."	Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the<strong> urine</strong> is clear it looks like water.	"The flag primitive looks like a big ""P"". And, let's face it,<strong> urine</strong> is just pee water. So, ""Urine = <em>P Water</em>"". Yes, it's stupid, but I don't think I'm gonna forget it now, haha. (I renamed the flag primitive ""pee"", it makes for unforgettable stories)."	"Animals use<strong> urine</strong> as a ""watery flag""."	<strong>Urine</strong> is <em>water</em> that <em>flags</em> your territory.		
尼		nun	Flag . . . spoon.		5	1133	1054	29	ニ	あま	Red cross<strong> nun</strong>s sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry. 尺		shaku	"The key word <b>shaku</b> has actually come into English in the word <i><b>shaku</b>hachi</i>, the ancient Japanese flute that measured ""one <b>shaku</b> and eight <i>sun</i>"" (the ""sun"" being about an inch in length). I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the <em>ceiling</em>." 肩		shoulder	Door . . . flesh.		8	1158	1077	29	ケン	かた	The<strong> shoulder</strong> is the best <em>part of the body</em> to bash a <em>door</em> open with (Don't ever try this. Use your foot). (ボウ)."	When you walk in the DOOR to the sumo stadium you will see the 4<strong> TASSEL</strong>S pointing in 4 DIRECTIONS These<strong> TASSEL</strong>S are always placed in the same order: 白房 (しろぶさ) : southwest corner 黒房 (くろぶさ) : northwest corner 赤房 (あかぶさ) : southeast corner 青房 (あおぶさ) : northeast corner (Thanks transtic).	At graduation, you are about to enter a new <em>door</em> to your future. to signify that, the speaker guy askes the graduates to move the<strong> tassel</strong> on their hands to the other <em>direction</em>.

This<strong> hearth</strong> is Calcifer, from Howl's Moving Castle. He's a pain, so you <em>bolt the door</em> when you leave, so that he can't follow you out.	This is a reminder that when the <em>fire</em> is going in the<strong> hearth</strong>, keep the <em>door</em> closed so we're not heating up the whole outdoors.		
戻		re-	"The key word signals a ""coming back"" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: <i>door</i> . . . <i>St. Bernard dog</i>."		7	1162	1081	29	レイ	もど.す、もど.る	The <em>St. Bernard dog</em> whining at the <em>door</em> of his master’s house in order to<strong> re-</strong>enter /<strong> re-</strong>turn inside.	This is common with cats, but also happens with dogs. They go out the door. 5 minutes later they change their minds and come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. They<strong> re-</strong>come back in. They<strong> re-</strong>go out the door. AAAAAARRRRRGGGHHHH!!!	Think about hachiko, the <em>dog</em> waiting at the <em>door</em> of the station, waiting for his master to <em>re-</em>turn.	"This story can help you remember this Kanji as well as the next frame <a href=""../v4/1082.html"">tears</a> (#1082 涙). When the <em>lost dog</em><strong> re-</strong>turned to his master's <em>doorstep</em>, the two<strong> re-</strong>joiced at their happy<strong> re-</strong>union."	"Hint: This is the kanji used in the verb 戻る [もどる] which means ""to return, to turn back"". I suggest using ""turn back"" as keyword, which is far easier to remember compared to the abstract ""re-"". Do not confuse with <a href=""../v4/725.html"">return</a> (#725 返) which has the meaning of the verb かえる - to return, to come back."		
涙		tears	<i>Water</i> . . . <i>re-</i>. Brings a tear to the eye.	<strong>Tears</strong> are watery (<em>water</em> + <em>re</em>).	When my dog (who was about as big as a <em>St. Bernard</em>) got quite old, he had to be put down. The last thing that I saw was him lying on the table staring at me before the vet shut the <em>door</em>. The way he looked at me, I swear he knew that his time was over. Dogs don't shed<strong> tears</strong> but if he could have I think he would have at that time.	"The master shed<strong> tears</strong> of joy when his lost dog returned to his doorstep. 雇		employ	<i>Door</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. Be sure to keep distinct from both <i>employee</i> (Frame 59) and <i>use</i> (Frame 1065).		12	1164	1083	29	コ	やと.う	Our company has no standards. You keep this up and I'll fire your ass."" ""No, you won't."" ""What damn it, I'll fire you your ass so fast you won't…know…""-. A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. –""The Exec<strong> employ</strong>s the turkey that walked through the door""."	"""Sorry,"" says a store manager, ""We don't<strong> employ</strong> Turkeys here."" He then points to the door. The disappointed turkey hangs his head low and walks out." 啓		disclose	Door . . . taskmaster . . . mouth.		11	1166	1085	29	ケイ	ひら.く、さと.す	Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and<strong> DISCLOSE</strong> information. It's best not to<strong> disclose</strong> what you were forced to do with your <em>mouth</em> behind closed <em>doors</em> for your <em>taskmaster</em>.	Before they go out of the <em>door</em>, the <em>taskmaster</em> makes everyone sign non-<strong>disclosure</strong> forms to keep on top of the possibility that they might open their <em>mouths</em>.	A closed <em>door</em> refuses to<strong> disclose</strong> (dis-close) whatever is happening behind, so someone asked the <em>taskmistress</em> to whip the <em>door</em>, and force it to reveal/disclose what is going on behind. The <em>door</em> gives up (who can resist the <em>taskmistress</em>, hehe) and<strong> disclose</strong>s the information by way of a <em>mouth</em> that appears, just like that (even in imaginary world, doors need a <em>mouth</em> to talk).		
示		show	Although the elements <i>two</i> and <i>little</i> are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on <b>show</b> for all to see.	* As a primitive, this kanji means <i>altar</i>. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the <i>altar</i> in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for <i>cloak</i>, identical except for the one final short stroke.	5	1167	1086	30	ジ、シ	しめ.す	A boy made an <em>altar</em>, but he's afraid to<strong> show</strong> it to God because he thinks it's <em>two little</em>.	"""I'll<strong> SHOW</strong> you mine if you<strong> show</strong> me yours!"", she said. I did & she scoffed because it was <em>TWO LITTLE</em>."	I give this form a primitive of <em>EVIL ALTAR</em>. Imagine a black stone altar used for satanic rituals. I give the left radical form a primitive of <em>CHURCH ALTAR</em>. Imagine a beautiful cathedral altar.	Unrelated: Frankly, I found Chapter 30 BORING. (I guess I was spoiled with Mr. T.) To jazz up the excitement, this ENTIRE chapter is all about one very crazy religion that exists today (in your imagination). What are the specifics? That's for you to find out. The clues? The next 39 kanji. Just look at some of the keywords: Altar, oil, sleeve, collar, speakth, naked!!! Be sure to give altar it's own meaning inside the cult you're creating.	A picture of an altar. <em>Two small things</em> are placed on it to<strong> show</strong> them off (I imagine two watches covered in diamonds).		
礼		salutation	This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of <b>salutation</b> so important in Japanese culture. You should <em>fish hook</em> (bend/bow) your body before an <em>altar</em> as a form of<strong> salutation</strong> to God/gods.	<strong>SALUTATION</strong> (a hand salute in this case) was given to the ALTAR by a veteran with a HOOK for his hand. Just keep that mental picture and you own this kanji.	This cult has a really dumb<strong> salutation</strong>. They form sort of a <em>'fishhook'</em> on their foreheads with their thumb and index finger. They do it whenever they come near the <em>altar</em>. 祥		auspicious	Altar . . . sheep.		10	1169	1088	30	ショウ	さいわ.い、きざ.し、よ.い、つまび.らか	Bringing a <em>sheep</em> to sacrifice on the <em>altar</em> was a sign of an<strong> auspicious</strong> life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more<strong> auspicious</strong> an expensive <em>sheep</em> for an offering.	On this <strong>ewe-spicious</strong> occasion, you sacrifice a <em>sheep</em> at the <em>altar</em>. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.	"Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. If the gods are pleased, they send down a <em>sheep</em> to the <em>altar</em>. The people see this as an<strong> auspicious</strong> gift; the wool and milk from this sheep is considered holy. But the gods think of it as a witty joke, since it's just a metaphor for the people following ancient rituals like blind sheep. Continued in <a href=""../v4/1291.html"">calamity</a> (#1291 禍)."	It's an<strong> auspicious</strong> sign when you go to the <em>altar</em> and the <em>sheep</em> is already beside it, ready to go.	"<strong>Auspicious</strong> (adj): contraction of ""Australia"" and ""delicious""; a sheep is placed on an ""australian altar"", or ""barbie"", on an<strong> auspicious</strong> occasion to celebrate."		
祝		celebrate	Altar . . . teenager.		9	1170	1089	30	シュク、シュウ	いわ.う	When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the <em>altar</em> at their local shrine and<strong> celebrate</strong> no longer being a <em>teenager</em>. Coming of Age Day ( 成人の日 , seijin no hi) is a Japanese holiday held annually on the second Monday of January to<strong> celebrate</strong> those who have turned 20 years old. In this kanji we see someone going to the <em>altar</em> to<strong> celebrate</strong> no longer being a <em>teenager</em>.		
福		blessing	Altar . . . wealth.		13	1171	1090	30	フク		This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave <em>wealth</em> to the <em>altar</em> (i.e. priest) and received a <em>blessing</em>. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (<em>wealth</em>) that is expected when you're called to the ark (<em>altar</em> in the kanji) to give a<strong> blessing</strong> over the torah.	Put all your <em>wealth</em> on the church <em>altar</em> and receive one<strong> blessing</strong>. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).	Wow, this is Scientology put into a kanji. In the Scientology faith the <em>wealthiest</em> members have the highest status in the Church. So basically, the <em>wealthiest</em> person that puts the most money on the <em>alter</em> receives the most<strong> blessing</strong>s….(not really, from what I've heard, the more money you give the better parking spot you get….).	When you pray at the <em>altar</em> be sure to count your <em>wealth </em> as a<strong> blessing</strong>.	This illustrates the idea of tithing… thankful for God's <strong>blessing</strong>s, you give back a tenth of the <em>wealth</em> He has given you at the <em>altar</em>.

奈		Nara	We choose the city of <b>Nara</b> as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in <b>Nara</b>; and also because of <b>Nara's</b> famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: <i>St. Bernard dog</i> . . . <i>altar</i>.		8	1175	1094	30	ナ、ナイ、ダイ	いかん、からなし	It's beautiful place, but the dark side of<strong> Nara</strong> is that they sacrifice <em>St. Bernards</em> on <em>evil altars</em> every night after the tourists leave!	<strong>Nara</strong> is just a <em>big</em> <em>show</em> for tourists. 尉		military officer	Flag . . . altar . . . glue.		11	1176	1095	30	イ、ジョウ		Of course it had to be the<strong> military officer</strong>'s idea to <em>glue</em> a <em>national flag</em> to the <em>altar</em> he's stationed at. A<strong> military officer</strong> keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground. The<strong> military officer</strong> is even patriotic when he watches tv. Whenever there's a <em>flag</em> on the <em>show</em>, he's just <em>glue</em>d to the set.		
慰		consolation	Military officer . . . heart.		15	1177	1096	30	イ	なぐさ.める、なぐさ.む	A <em>military officer</em> must offer<strong> consolation</strong> to the <em>hearts</em> of the families of his fallen men.	"This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II ""comfort women"" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing<strong> consolation</strong> to battle-weary, <em>heartsick military officers and soldiers</em>, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.)."	The MILITARY OFFICER is given a Purple HEART by the army as<strong> consolation</strong> for the wounds he received in the line of duty.	"The <em>military officer</em> consoles the parents: ""Well, your son did not win the war. He died. But, as a<strong> consolation</strong> prize, you get his <em>heart</em>!"" TA-DAAA!! ""Thanks for playing, folks!"" (cue screaming)."	"""My time in the army was complete misery."" - ""Well if it's any<strong> consolation</strong> that bastard <em>military officer</em> had a <em>heart</em> attack.""."		
款		goodwill	Samurai . . . altar . . . yawning.		12	1178	1097	30	カン		Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about<strong> goodwill</strong>. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!	A <em>samurai</em>'s <em>show</em> of<strong> goodwill</strong> is never <em>lacking</em>.	For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The <em>samurai</em> kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his <em>goodwill</em> benefits everyone. No beheadings.	<strong>Goodwill</strong> is something that <em>samurais</em> <em>show</em> and other warriors just <em>lack</em>.	<strong>Goodwill</strong> Hunting, the Japanese version. 禁		prohibition	Grove . . . altar.		13	1179	1098	30	キン		"Similar to radical tyro's story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably ""no smoking"" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a<strong> prohibition</strong> of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will)."	"Hidden in a <em>grove</em> was a church with a secret <em>altar</em> that was stocked full of <strong>prohibited</strong> alcohol during the American<strong> prohibition</strong> period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this <em>altar</em> so he could stock <strong>prohibited</strong> alcohol ""for sacremental purposes"" and share it with his <em>kin</em> (きん)."	Placing trees on this alter is prohibited.	When Chirstianity was prohibited and the christians were being chased in Japan they had to hide their altars under the groves.	During<strong> prohibition</strong>, people drank hidden in <em>groves</em> so that they wouldn't be <em>shown</em> drinking in public.		
襟		collar	Cloak . . . prohibition.		18	1180	1099	30	キン	えり	A<strong> collar</strong> is the part of your <em>cloak</em> that, if tightened too tight, will <em>prohibit</em> breathing.	<strong>Collar</strong>s are <em>prohibited</em> from wizarding <em>cloaks</em>. Blood purists say they're too muggle.	Dress code: all <em>cloaks</em> without<strong> collar</strong>s are <em>prohibited</em>.	In some future anti-Catholic dystopia, a <em>prohibition</em> against <strong>collars</strong> has been enacted, so Catholic priests often conceal them (or <em>cloak</em> them) underneath their <em>cloaks</em>. Imagine a cloaked Catholic priest walking down the street when he sees a police officer approaching him, and the priest nervously tightens his <em>cloak</em> to ensure his<strong> collar</strong> isn't seen.	"Popping the<strong> collar</strong> on any <em>cloak</em> is strictly <em>prohibited</em> because doing so will make you look like an enormous douchebag. <em>Fun fact</em>: the phrase ""pop [one's]<strong> collar</strong>"" is <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%8C%E8%A5%9F%E3%82%92%E7%AB%8B%E3%81%A6%E3%82%8B%E3%80%8D"">「襟を立てる」</a> in Japanese."		
宗		religion	House . . . altar.		8	1181	1100	30	シュウ、ソウ	むね	I never really did figure out what<strong> religion</strong> my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an <em>altar</em> in their <em>home</em>.	All the<strong> RELIGION</strong>S have their own temples, which are <strong>houses</strong> where they place their <strong>altars</strong>. A <em>house</em> with an <em>altar</em>? Perhaps they practice a<strong> religion</strong>.		
崇		adore	Mountain . . . religion.		11	1182	1101	30	スウ	あが.める	In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to<strong> adore</strong> the gods who live on Mount Olympus.	I would<strong> adore</strong> the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.	Several kanji become their 'greater' version when you add 山 on top ( 風 becomes 嵐 , 石 becomes 岩 ). Thus, <em>religion</em> becomes <strong>adoration</strong>.	"The annoying woman from Los Angeles says ""oh I absolutely<strong> adore</strong> those cute little mountain religions, like tibetan buddhism, they shave their cute little heads and wear those bright pretty robes, so adorable.""."	I<strong> adore</strong> <em>mountains</em> over <em>religion</em>.		
祭		ritual	<i>Flesh</i> . . . <i>crotch</i> . . . <i>altar</i>. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character.		11	1183	1102	30	サイ	まつ.る、まつ.り、まつり	A<strong> ritual</strong> such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.	There are many famous penis <strong>matsuri</strong>s(festivals) in Japan. The<strong> ritual</strong>s of these festivals involve placing the <em>flesh</em> of the <em>crotch</em> on an <em>altar</em>.	まつり（ 祭り ）Ritual nude dances (nothing but flesh) involving lots of pelvic thrusts before the altars of ancient Japan. Now they're nothing but festivals, but back in the day they were<strong> ritual</strong>s. Most Japanese festivals have a circle dance, just imagine all the old people doing the except same dance but in the buff, wrinkly flesh flapping in the wind and all. Remembered. Unfortunately, perhaps forever.	This kanji is used for <strong>festivals</strong>. [Flesh from one leg … show] I think of those sexy high slit skirts, the ones that let you see the leg of its wearer.	The top part of this kanji I memorize as <em>circumcision</em>. - - - - - - - – - - - - - - - - - In an ancient<strong> ritual</strong>, people are <em>shown</em> how to <em>circumsize</em> their newborns.		
察		guess	"""<b>Guess</b>"" here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>ritual</i>."		14	1184	1103	30	サツ		I have an informed<strong> guess</strong> about whose <em>house</em> the dark <em>rituals</em> are performet at.	Police ( 警察 ）drive around a street at night trying to<strong> guess</strong> whose house is having a matsuri indoors after complaints from the neighbours.	For our child's circumcision (the <em>ritual</em>) we invited a rabbi to our <em>house</em>. We didn't know it at the time, but he was blind, and he had to<strong> guess</strong> which little squishy thing was the baby's penis.	The POLICE had enough evidence, so they were able to make an informed<strong> GUESS</strong> as to which HOUSE the dark RITUALS were being performed in.	"In our <em>house</em> we have a <em>ritual</em>. When something happens someone says ""Guess what happened."" We ask for some sort of vague hint, but get ""no, go on,<strong> guess</strong>!"" Asking what sort of thing it's about, news, music, catastrophe, just gets ""no, you have to<strong> guess</strong>"". It takes quite a long time to find out what's happened. It's a very annoying ritual."		
擦		grate	Fingers . . . guess.		17	1185	1104	30	サツ	す.る、す.れる、-ず.れ、こす.る、こす.れる	If you mis-guess the cheese you'll<strong> grate</strong> your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).	Ouch! <em>Guess</em> how many <em>fingers</em> I just<strong> grate</strong>d in the<strong> grate</strong>r? (Edit: OR: Ouch! <em>Guess</em> what I just<strong> grate</strong>d in the<strong> grate</strong>r? – my <em>finger</em>!).	When you<strong> grate</strong> something you have to <em>guess</em> where your <em>fingers</em> are so you don't hurt yourself.	It was a cruel form of torture. He would<strong> grate</strong> cheese and by the smell make me guess what sort of cheese it was. If my guess was wrong, he would<strong> grate</strong> one of my fingers. Which is how I know how pretty much every cheese smells now, although I don't have many working fingers left.	"The meaning of this kanji is more like ""rub, scour, scratch, or scrape."" Story: Frustratedly trying to solve a math equation on the classroom chalkboard, the student made a sound that would really<strong> GRATE</strong> on everyone's nerves. She would<strong> GRATE</strong> her FINGERnails on the chalkboard as she GUESSED at the next step in solving the equation."		
由		wherefore	"The ""<b>wherefore</b>"" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a <i>rice field</i> sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and <b>wherefore</b> of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the <i>flower</i> appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full <i>seedling</i>.)"	* As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean <i>shoot</i> or <i>sprout</i>.	5	1186	1105	30	ユ、ユウ、ユイ	よし、よ.る	"""<strong>Wherefore</strong> art thou, <em>Sprouteo</em>?"" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off)."	"""Cogito <strong>ergo</strong> sum.""<strong> Wherefore</strong> is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it's often mistranslated as ""where"" when in fact it's an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought <em>sprouts</em> from my <em>brain</em>. I think, <strong>therefore</strong> I am.]."	"Errata: Stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. The vertical stroke is #3. (story: dingomick)."	"""<strong>Wherefore</strong> art thou Romeo?"" says Juliet on her balcony as she plucks brussel sprouts instead of rose petals. (This takes on the primitive of the much more memorable <em>BRUSSEL SPROUT</em>)."	<strong>Wherefore</strong> art thou, Romeo. He's in the <em>rice field</em>. You can see his hair sticking up above the rice. New Primitive: Romeo.		
抽		pluck	Fingers . . . sprout.		8	1187	1106	30	チュウ	ひき-	"[When I see the word<strong> pluck</strong>, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with <a href=""../v4/733.html"">pick</a> (#733 採):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to <em>sprout</em> out of my chin again, I<strong> pluck</strong> it with my <em>fingers</em>."	If you<strong> pluck</strong> your <em>fingers</em>, new ones will <em>sprout</em> in their place. (try it ;).	If you<strong> pluck</strong> hair from your eyebrows with your <em>fingers</em>, more hair will <em>sprout</em> in it's place.	<em>fingers</em><strong> pluck</strong> a single <em>sprout</em>.	"Every time I see this kanji I think of the snapple commerical: ""White tea is a baby tea leaf, and while it still has a naturally light flavor…. we<strong> pluck</strong> it."" <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=znAoCGATk8w"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=znAoCGATk8w</a>."		
油		oil	Water . . . sprout.		8	1188	1107	30	ユ、ユウ	あぶら	The <em>liquid</em><strong> oil</strong> that <em>sprouts</em> from an<strong> oil</strong> field.	In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified <em>Brussel sprouts</em> (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the <em>water</em> to suck up<strong> oil</strong> spills.	<strong>oil</strong> is the most valuable <em>liquid</em> to <em>sprout</em> from the earth.	When cooking sprouts in water add<strong> oil</strong>.	If you squeeze certain <em>sprouting</em> plants, such as rapeseed, <em>drops</em> of liquid will come out. This is the<strong> oil</strong> you use for cooking.

Then he trips over his <em>cloak</em> and brussel <em>sprouts</em> fall everywhere."	Imagine some magic <em>cloak</em>, that when worn, has little green <em>sprouts</em> appearing on the sides that grow into<strong> sleeve</strong>s.	<strong>Sleeve</strong>s are just what <em>sprouts</em> out of the sides of <em>garments.</em> Duh.	If it had <strong>sleeve</strong>s, it wouldn't be a <em>cloak</em>, now would it? But if you insist, I suppose I could use my majic to have some <strong>sleeve</strong>s just <em>sprout</em> out from the shoulders. . .	What do garments sprout?<strong> Sleeve</strong>s, of course!		
宙		mid-air	House . . . shoot.		8	1190	1109	30	チュウ		Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in<strong> mid-air</strong> suspended on the SPROUT. With new <em>houses</em> <em>sprouting</em> up everwhere,<strong> mid-air</strong> collisions are becoming more common as airplanes have to avoid the new structures. 届		deliver	Flag . . . sprout.		8	1191	1110	30	カイ	とど.ける、-とど.け、とど.く	In the US, when the mail is<strong> deliver</strong>ed, a <em>flag</em> <em>sprouts</em> up on your mailbox. "I tried to<strong> deliver</strong> a clear message to my girlfriend that said ""I don't like brussel <em>sprouts</em>"" by <em>peeing</em> on the bowl of them that she'd just made. 軸		axis	Car . . . shoot.		12	1193	1112	30	ジク		An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a <em>car</em> going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single <em>sprout</em> (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its<strong> axis</strong>.	The Germans manufactured so many <em>cars</em> during World War II that it was almost as if they were <em>sprouting</em> from the factories of the<strong> Axis</strong>.
