James Bond has guns that <em>sprout</em> from the wheel <strong>axes</strong> of his <em>car</em>.		
甲		armor	This kanji reverses the element for <i>sprout</i>, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the <i>rice field</i>. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, <b>armor</b>.	"* The primitive meaning is <i>roots</i>. Important to that word is the image of ""pushing downwards,"" as <i>roots</i> do."	5	1194	1113	30	コウ、カン、カ	きのえ	"Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's<strong> armor</strong>. Then I looked up images of the samurai<strong> armor</strong> and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai<strong> armor</strong> because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess."	It looks like a bird's eye view of a tank (modern<strong> armor</strong>).	Pictograph. Kendo visor with chin guard.	Armour weighs you down like you’re rooted to the ground.	Looks like an<strong> armor</strong>ed helmet. You have the part that protects the <em>brain</em> and a little line beneath that acts as a nose guard.		
押		push	<i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>roots</i>. Compare and contrast with <i>pluck</i> (Frame 1187).		8	1195	1114	30	オウ	お.す、お.し-、お.っ-、お.さえる、おさ.える	<strong>Push</strong> the <em>roots</em> down, instead of plucking the seedling.	Use your <em>fingers</em> to make sure the <em>roots</em> of your plant are deep underground by <strong>pushing</strong> them down, down, down.	<strong>Push</strong> the button with your <em>finger</em> and get <em>root</em> beer!	"For those who liked the ""bird's eye view of the tank"" imagine a tank that has its tracks stuck in the sand. The big green machine is extremely hot from the desert sun as well as the heat its engine has created. With that picture in mind, this Kanji depicts what happens next when the soldiers get around the back of the tank and have to<strong> push</strong> it with their fingers because the surface is too hot for them to put their hands on."	You are wearing your cool new <em>Ninja Turtles Shell Armour</em> and you realize that there's a little button with a <em>finger</em> symbol on it, inviting you to<strong> push</strong> it. You<strong> push</strong> it, and the front wall of the shell <strong>push</strong>es out violently. You've learned a new attack - this isn't just a defense tool anymore, you can now run around and<strong> push</strong> people around for no reason! Cool!		
岬		headland	Like the <i>cape</i> (Frame 164) and the <i>promontory</i> (Frame 840), the <b>headland</b> refers to a jut of land. Its elements: <i>mountain</i> . . . <i>roots</i>.		8	1196	1115	30	コウ	みさき	A<strong> headland</strong> is a <em>mountain</em> that is firmly <em>rooted</em> despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a<strong> headland</strong>!).	<strong>Headland</strong>s are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become <em>armoured mountains</em>. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an <em>armoured mountain</em>).	A <em>mountain</em> that has been <em>pushed</em> into the sea.	The<strong> headland</strong> is <em>mountain</em>ous terrain that provides a natural fortification (or <em>armour</em>) against sea-borne invasion. 岬 (みさき) : cape (on coast).	"Forget confusing the meanings (<strong>headland</strong>, <a href=""../v4/778.html"">promontory</a> (#778 崎), <a href=""../v4/153.html"">cape</a> (#153 埼)) they are synonyms, no way around that. Luckily, all three seem to be used in names most. I used: The<strong> headland</strong> or <strong>head</strong> of the <strong>land</strong> is obviously the part of the land that is placed highest, in the same way our head is highest on the body. <em>Mountains</em> are the <strong>head</strong>s of the <strong>land</strong>s they have planted their <em>roots</em> into."		
挿		insert	<i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>thousand</i> . . . <i>roots</i>. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements.		10	1197	1116	30	ソウ	さ.す、はさ.む	A rice farmer's delicate <em>fingers</em> have<strong> insert</strong>ed <em>1,000 rooted</em> seedlings into his field.	Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and <em>thousand</em> of <em>root</em>-like tentacles are<strong> insert</strong>ing themselves in… well, I think you can fill the rest.	Before you <em>push</em> the button for the <em>ginseng root</em> tea, you must<strong> insert</strong> <em>1000</em> yen.	<em>Fingers</em>, the thief, is trying to get money using my ATM card. After <strong>insert</strong>ing it in the ATM, he tried <em>1000 times</em> to <em>push</em> the right buttons. And got my pin right number on the last try! Notice the long vertical stroke done last!	"Weird arcade machine this one. Instead of reading ""insert coin"", it reads ""<strong>insert</strong> <em>1,000 roots</em>"". I hope you can play until your <em>fingers</em> get sore, for that price!"		
申		speaketh	"The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb ""to speak."" It is written by a <i>tongue wagging in the mouth</i> with a <i>walking stick</i> rammed through it and coming out at both ends."	"* While this kanji has obvious affinities to the ""seed"" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the <i>monkey</i> (the one who <i>speaketh</i> no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take <i>monkey</i> as its primitive meaning."	5	1198	1117	30	シン	もう.す、もう.し-、さる	"I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the ""s"" and<strong> speaketh</strong> like thith becauth they have a <em>cane</em> in their <em>mouth</em>."	"I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 <a href=""../v4/578.html"">sayeth</a> (#578 曰). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in ""moshi moshi"" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say ""hello, this is X <strong>speaking</strong>.""."	The <em>cross</em> in the <em>mouth</em> of the <em>Monkey</em> ensured it<strong> speaketh</strong> no evil.	A MONKEY can't<strong> SPEAKETH</strong> of anything if he has a WALKING STICK driven through his TOUNGE WAGGING IN HIS MOUTH.	"Distinguished from <a href=""../v4/578.html"">sayeth</a> (#578 曰) in that we're surprised that the <em>monkey</em> can speak at all: ""The monkey<strong> speaketh</strong>!""."		
伸		expand	Person . . . monkey.		7	1199	1118	30	シン	の.びる、の.ばす、の.べる、の.す	Here we see Mr. T.<strong> expand</strong>ing his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.	Mr. T wants to show you the incredible<strong> expand</strong>ing monkey trick. He grabs a monkey by the tail and neck, stretches him out a few times, then blows him up like a balloon. The monkey<strong> EXPAND</strong>s until it pops. Haha, sucka monkey, I pity you foo.	A <em>person</em> <em>speaketh</em> and<strong> expand</strong>s my knowledge.	A <em>person</em> is really just a <em>monkey</em> that has been<strong> expand</strong>ed and stretched out a bit to stand up straight and use speech.	"<em>Mr. T</em>'s waistline is<strong> EXPAND</strong>ing because he has been eating too much ""Chunky <em>MONKEY</em>"" ice cream!. ""I pity the foo that doesn't like Ben & Jerry's ice cream!""."

捜		search	Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch.		10	1201	1120	30	ソウ、シュ、シュウ	さが.す	The <em>monkey</em><strong> search</strong>es around with his <em>fingers</em> for his <em>crotch</em>. "If you are familiar with the Monkey legends ( 西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While <strong>search</strong>ing for the end of the universe, <em>monkey</em> reaches to his <em>crotch</em> and urinates on Buddha's <em>fingers</em>. 果		fruit	The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the <i>tree</i>) and comes to fruition, producing <b>fruit</b> full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for <i>brains</i> at the top, which might prove more helpful than <i>rice field</i> for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a <i>sun</i> with a <i>tree</i> whose trunk runs through the <i>sun</i>.		8	1202	1121	30	カ	は.たす、はた.す、-は.たす、は.てる、-は.てる、は.て	If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden<strong> fruit</strong> from the tree.	"There really are <em>brain</em><strong> fruit</strong> <em>trees</em>. See <a href=""http://www.dpchallenge.com/image.php?IMAGE_ID=108312"">http://www.dpchallenge.com/image.php?IMAGE_ID=108312</a>. Enough said."	Just a pictogram of a cluster of<strong> fruit</strong> on a tree.	<strong>Fruit</strong> is like a productive <em>rice field</em> that grows on top of a <em>tree</em>. 悪因悪果 (sewing & reaping evil). 悪果 (bad results). 無花果果 (fig). 因果 (cause & effect). 規模効果 (economies of scale).	Instead of <em>brains</em> use <em>rice field</em> and we see a bunch of <em>fruit</em> trees growing about the perimeter of a <em>rice field</em>.		
菓		confectionary	Flowers . . . fruits.		11	1203	1122	30	カ		This candy is made in the shape of a <em>flower</em>, each petal with the taste of a different <em>fruit</em>.	Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.	I think of Willy Wonka's factory where the flowers all bear <strong>candy</strong> fruits.	Willy Wonka, the<strong> confectionary</strong> wizard, is probably the only man with the <em>brains</em> to develop a <em>tree</em> whose <em>flowers</em> are all <strong>candy</strong>. 菓子 かし pastry; 菓子 みずがし fruit.	In Japan, <strong>candy</strong> can be flavored like <em>fruit</em> or <em>flowers</em> (e.g. rose-flavored gum).		
課		chapter	Words . . . fruit.		15	1204	1123	30	カ		After I finish each<strong> chapter</strong> of RTK, I eat a piece of <em>fruit</em> to celebrate all the new <em>words</em> I've learned. (Thanks Misha!).	"<em>Words</em> signify the written words in a book. The <em>fruit</em> represents something whole, complete. A<strong> chapter</strong> in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It's good to disambiguate the keyword from <a href=""../v4/82.html"">paragraph</a> (#82 項). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each<strong> chapter</strong> of Tolstoy's ""War and Peace"" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you'd very quickly run out of fruit)."	The <em>words</em> of each<strong> chapter</strong> bear a different <em>fruit</em>.	The first<strong> chapter</strong> of the Bible are <em>words</em> telling the story of <em>Adam and Eve</em> and how they ate the forbidden <em>fruit</em>.	"Here we think of the<strong> CHAPTER</strong> of the bible, namely<strong> CHAPTER</strong> three where you hear the lord SAY ""Who has eaten of the forbidden FRUIT?"" Goes well with the Naked frame that talks of the other forbidden FRUIT."		
裸		naked	Cloak . . . fruit.		13	1205	1124	30	ラ	はだか	Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were<strong> naked</strong>, and so clothing themselves in a cloak.	Hey honey, I'm <strong>naked</strong> underneath this <em>cloak</em>. I've got some nice <em>melons</em> and a fresh <em>peach</em> waiting for you. Don't you want to taste my forbidden <em>fruits</em>…?	Eve was<strong> naked</strong> until she ate of the <em>fruit</em> and put a <em>cloak</em> on.	A cloak hides the fruit-bearing parts of one's<strong> naked</strong> body.	"The <em>cloak</em> slipped to her side to reveal her<strong> naked</strong> <em>fruit</em> (don't confuse with <a href=""../v4/498.html"">undress</a> (#498 脱))."		
斤		ax	This character represents a picture of an <b>ax</b>, the two vertical lines being the handle and the horizontal strokes of the blade. Note the writing order carefully.		4	1206	1125	31	キン	おの	Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.	The<strong> axe</strong>-wielding maniac <em>nails</em> a poor victim, right under a <em>cliff</em>. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).	Warning: unlike the nail primitive, notice that the<strong> axe</strong> does not have a hook on the last stroke.	Pictograph, see book.	The<strong> axe</strong>-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!). [Shibo] Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first. [radical_tyro] Warning: unlike the nail primitive, notice that the<strong> axe</strong> does not have a hook on the last stroke. [Ramchip] I just wanted to combine these as they were all very helpful. I take no credit for any of them.		
析		chop	Tree . . . ax.		8	1207	1126	31	セキ		We<strong> chop</strong> down <em>trees</em> with <em>axes</em> to <strong>analyze</strong> their rings.	Wood + axe =<strong> chop</strong>? how much more simple can it get?	How much <em>wood</em> would a <em>wood</em>chopper<strong> chop</strong> if a <em>woodchopper</em> would<strong> chop</strong> <em>wood</em>? (Don't forget to imagine the <em>ax</em>).	"This more accurately means ""take apart"" or ""analyse"", so I guess, once you<strong> chop</strong> down the tree with an axe, you can analyse its structure."	To<strong> chop</strong> the TREE– use an AXE.		
所		place	Door . . . ax.		8	1208	1127	31	ショ	ところ、-ところ、どころ、とこ	You outsiders better learn your<strong> place</strong>! A <strong>place</strong> for everything and everything in its <strong>place</strong>. To the right of the <em>door</em> is the standard <strong>place</strong> for the <em>axe</em>.	When you come over to my<strong> place</strong>, you leave your <em>axe</em> at the <em>door</em>!	"Platz - The ""Shining"" (Jack Nicholson hacks the <em>door</em> with an <em>ax</em>) is not a nice<strong> place</strong> to be."	Heeeeeeere's Johnny! Jack Nicholson breaks down a <em>door</em> with his <em>ax</em> in order to get to his wife's hiding<strong> place</strong>.		
祈		pray	Altar . . . ax.		8	1209	1128	31	キ	いの.る	Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the <em>altars</em> at the local missions, and if anybody refused to<strong> pray</strong>, they would get the <em>axe</em>.	A warrior<strong> pray</strong>s for victory before the battle. He kneels at the <em>altar</em>, his battle <em>axe</em> at the ready.	When you come to the <em>altar</em> to<strong> pray</strong>, you need to leave your <em>axe</em> to one side. Biblical quote, settle your differences with someone before coming before your god.	At the altar ax da Lord and<strong> pray</strong> to help ya! Hallelujah!	D&D: the religious dwarf<strong> pray</strong> at the <em>altar</em>, with his trusty <em>axe</em> at his side.		
近		near	<i>Ax</i> . . . <i>road</i>. Be careful not to confuse with <i>draw near</i> (Frame 204) or <i>bystander</i> (Frame 1090).		7	1210	1129	31	キン、コン	ちか.い	The end is<strong> near</strong>. The <em>axe</em>-murderer is waiting for you on the <em>road</em>…	An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long <em>road</em>. To make A and B<strong> near</strong>, take an <em>ax</em>, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.	Hint: Short- cut.	An <em>axe</em> left in the middle of the <em>road</em>! Dwarves must be<strong> near</strong>!	"When I think of ""<strong> near</strong> "", I always think of that absurd muppet sketch with Grover running back and forth to demonstrate ""<strong> near</strong> "" and ""far"". So, I see grover on the <em>road</em> somewhere and I shout to him and ask him if he can show me ""<strong> near</strong> "". He runs up to me and shouts ""<strong> Near</strong> !""Then I kill him with my <em>axe</em> and sling him over my shoulder. We're having muppet for dinner tonight!Now that you all think I'm insane, you should probably watch this, haha. <a href=""http://video.aol.com/video-detail/eating-muppets/3865632416"">http://video.aol.com/video-detail/eating-muppets/3865632416</a>."		
折		fold	"<i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>ax</i>. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of ""origami"" (paper-<b>folding</b>)."		7	1211	1130	31	セツ	お.る、おり、お.り、-お.り、お.れる	It's the latest Japanese game show: <strong>Forudo</strong>! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to<strong> fold</strong> it into a complex origami shape. If they're not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in<strong> fold</strong>ing, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.	<strong>Fold</strong> some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!	To hold an <em>axe</em>, you need to<strong> fold</strong> your <em>fingers</em> around the handle.	Japanese<strong> fold</strong> with their <em>fingers,</em> but the creases they make are as sharp as an <em>axe</em>.	I' m so strong, I can<strong> fold</strong> the axe with my fingers (works well for me, just imagine it clearly).		
哲		philosophy	Fold . . . mouth.		10	1212	1131	31	テツ	さとい、あき.らか、し.る、さば.く	A two-hour lesson of<strong> philosophy</strong> in high school. All the students, bored to death, are <em>folding</em> sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the <em>mouth</em> of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.	I fold my mouth, therefore I am.	All the<strong> philosophy</strong> that comes out of my <em>mouth</em> I learned from those Chinese fortune cookies with the <em>folded</em> paper inside. 'Confucius say…', et cetera. Come to think of it, the cookie itself looks like a weirdly <em>folded mouth</em>.	This friend of mine once unknowingly popped the whole fortune cookie into his <em>mouth</em>. Then using his <em>fingers</em> he retrieved a <em>folded</em> piece of paper. And it was the only time some<strong> philosophy</strong> came out of his <em>mouth</em>.	Here's a philosophical question: Can you <em>fold</em> a <em>hole</em>?		
逝		departed	"The connotation is of a ""dearly <b>departed</b>"" who has passed away. The elements: <i>fold</i> . . . <i>road</i>."		10	1213	1132	31	セイ	ゆ.く、い.く	One of the dearest of Japan's dearly<strong> departed</strong> is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for <em>folding</em> more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still <em>fold</em> origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire <em>road</em> lined with <em>folded</em> cranes.	The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently<strong> departed</strong> victims who died when the <em>roads</em> <em>folded</em> (from the earthquake).	The<strong> departed</strong> are those who have crossed that <em>fold</em> you cannot see past in the <em>road</em> we all walk.	In the film The<strong> Departed</strong> a guy falls out of the window and ends up <em>folded</em> double on the <em>road</em> below.	Picture the funeral procession of a great head of state (i.e. JFK) a dearly<strong> departed</strong> loved one to a nation. See his coffin drapped with the <em>folded</em> American flag as it is moved through the <em>roads</em> and streets of our nation's Capitol.		
誓		vow	Fold . . . words.		14	1214	1133	31	セイ	ちか.う	"This Japanese couple wrote the<strong> vow</strong>s that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then <em>folded it into an origami</em>, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an <em>origami</em>, but to them it is also a symbol of their<strong> vow</strong>s. – ""the <em>folded words</em> are<strong> vow</strong>s"". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an <em>origami</em> for the primitive ""<em>fold</em>""."	A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with <em>origami cranes</em> with their <strong>vows</strong> <em>written</em> on the BOTTOM.	"Sadako Sasaki<strong> vow</strong>ed to <em>fold</em> 1000 paper cranes and kept her <em>word</em>. (<a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadako_Sasaki"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadako_Sasaki</a>)."	"If you're a sci-fi/fantasy reader –> The Aes Sedai of Robert Jordan's ""The Wheel of Time"" series were famously forced to take three<strong> vow</strong>s, one of which was to never lie. This was next to pointless, however, as the old broads easily got around it by being so skilled at <em>folding</em> their <em>words</em> that while they never TECHNICALLY lied … the absolute truth that they spoke was still highly deceptive."	After cutting himself badly, <em>Socrates</em><strong> vow</strong>ed never to <em>fold</em> origami again.		
斬		chop off	Car . . . ax.		11	1215	2092	31	ザン、サン、セン、ゼン	き.る	I wanted a convertible so I <strong>chopped off</strong> the top of my <em>car</em> with an <em>axe</em>.	"A ""chop shop"" is a place where stolen <em>cars</em> are taken, and parts <strong>chopped off</strong> with an <em>axe</em>, to be sold."	Picture a death-mobile car with rotating axes on the hood that drives by and chops off people's heads. [beheading is another common meaning].	"Seen before in ""Steadily"" and ""Temporarily"". Both stories talked about taking an AXE to a CAR. Here, either take the horror movie approach where a driver in a CAR had his head CHOPPED OFF by a maniac with an AXE, or take the<strong> CHOP OFF</strong> shop approach where a guy is cutting up a CAR with an AXE."	In movies <em>cars</em> often have their tops <strong>chopped off</strong> as if with an <em>axe</em>.		
暫		temporarily	Chop off . . . days.		15	1216	1134	31	ザン	しばら.く	Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are<strong> temporarily</strong> without car.	Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can<strong> temporarily</strong> (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.	"The top kanji is <a href=""../v4/2092.html"">chop off</a> (#2092 斬)."	Axe murderer hiding in a car<strong> temporarily</strong> for a few days after killing someone.	"[<a href=""../v4/2092.html"">chop off</a> (#2092 斬) … day] During daylight saving time, we <strong>temporarily</strong> <em>chop off</em> the <em>day</em> by taking an hour out of it, which we will return back in six months."		
漸		steadily	Water . . . chop off.		14	1217	1135	31	ゼン	やや	I imagine firemen working<strong> steadily</strong> to rescue a man from a crashed <em>car</em>. First, they spray it with <em>water</em>; then, they use an <em>axe</em> to break through the window.	Water + Car + Axe: The<strong> steadily</strong> rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.	<em>Dripping water</em> on your <em>car</em><strong> steadily</strong> builds up rust. Over time, it's just as damaging as taking an <em>ax</em> to it.	"Driving<strong> steadily</strong> down the road in the <em>wet</em> in a <a href=""../v4/2092.html"">chop off</a> (#2092 斬) convertible. Singing in the rain."	The attempt to fix the <em>car</em>'s radiator with an <em>axe</em> did not go well. There was a steady drip drip drip of <em>water</em>.		
断		severance	Fishhook . . . rice . . . ax.		11	1218	1136	31	ダン	た.つ、ことわ.る、さだ.める	[Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some <em>rice</em> on a <em>fishhook</em> as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his <em>axe</em> and <strong>sever</strong> the line lest he be dragged into the depths.	When you get the ax at work, use your<strong> severance</strong> pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.	The <em>axe man</em> is fishing at a nearby river, using a <em>rice-ball on a hook</em> as bait. He catches some real big fish, which is pulling so hard on the line that <em>axe man</em> has to <strong>sever</strong> the line or let go of his pricey fishing rod. And at the same time there is the idea of<strong> severance</strong> in <em>axe man</em> having to let go of his big catch.	Your manager brings you into his office and offers you three<strong> severance</strong> packages. You can take the <em>hook</em> (become a fisherman), take the <em>rice</em> (become a farmer), or take the <em>axe</em> (become a lumberjack). Picture the items laid out on his desk like the shopkeepers in Zelda.	After he got <em>hooked</em> on <em>rice</em> wine the Japanese salaryman got the <em>axe</em> at work. Now all he has to live on is serverance pay.		
質		substance	Two axes . . . shells.		15	1219	1137	31	シツ、シチ、チ	たち、ただ.す、もと、わりふ	What is this <strong>substance</strong> on this <em>clam</em>? I've already broken 2 <em>axes</em> on it! Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird<strong> SUBSTANCE</strong> comes out of the shell…eww (I don't like clams).	"[seems to mean ""substance"" in the sense of essential nature or core quality, most common usage might be 質問 , shitsumon (inquiry)] a pair of scientists are smashing away at a mysterious <strong>shell</strong> with <strong>axes</strong>, pounding it into powder so they can feed it into their analysis machine and discover exactly what<strong> substance</strong> it's made up of." 斥		reject	Ax . . . a drop of.		5	1220	1138	31	セキ	しりぞ.ける	The kids at school used to<strong> reject</strong> me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my <em>axe</em> to school. It freaks out customers, so it doesn't make it to the shops.	My pawn shop<strong> reject</strong>s any axe with even a drop of blood.		
訴		accusation	Words . . . reject.		12	1221	1139	31	ソ	うった.える	I strongly <em>reject</em> the<strong> accusation</strong> implicit in your <em>words</em>.	<em>Words</em> that make you feel <em>rejected</em>. 昨		yesterday	Day . . . saw.		9	1222	1140	31	サク		One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the <em>day</em> that I <em>saw</em> before today was<strong> yesterday</strong>.	Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away…	Today I see.<strong> Yesterday</strong> I saw.	My coworker has an excessive way of updating his daily calendar. Instead of throwing<strong> yesterday</strong>'s page into the trash, he'll pulverize it with a chainsaw he keeps under his desk.	<strong>Yesterday</strong>: a <em>day</em> that has been <em>sawed</em> off from time and can never be lived again.		
詐		lie	The <b>lie</b> in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: <i>words</i> . . . <i>saw</i>.		12	1223	1141	31	サ	いつわ.る	Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a <em>word</em> of a<strong> lie</strong>, his nose grows and he has to get the <em>saw</em> out again.	Her<strong> lie</strong>s are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.	Hint: I think of<strong> lie</strong>s as <em>serrated words</em> for some reason.	This really has the connotation of fraud rather than<strong> lie</strong> but the Pinnochio story works too well.	His words were false; I saw right through his<strong> lie</strong>.

But he's a purist: he only uses <em>saws</em>, no power tools. 雪		snow	<i>Rain</i> that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a <i>broom</i> is <b>snow</b>.		11	1225	1143	31	セツ	ゆき	<strong>SNOW</strong> isn't all that different from <em>RAIN</em>, except it can be removed with a <em>BROOM</em> because it only forms in freezing temperatures.	Unlike <em>rain</em>,<strong> snow</strong> can be swept away with a <em>broom</em>.	"PRIMITIVE: I like to relate the particle for BROOM also as HARRY POTTER on his BROOM. (stories become really easy for the next 11 kanji especially)… . STORY: During the summer Harry Potter on his broom shows off by turning the rain to<strong> snow</strong>. RTK2:　セツ 積雪 せきせつ(pilled up<strong> snow</strong>). <a href=""midori://search?text=%EF%BC%83%EF%BC%8A%E9%9B%AA%E5%B4%A9"">＃＊雪崩</a> なだれ　Avalanche."	It's going to rain tomorrow with a 3% chance of<strong> snow</strong>!	When it<strong> snow</strong>s, you need a broom to clear your porch.		
録		record	<i>Metal</i> . . . <i>broom</i> . . . <i>rice</i>. Note how the final stroke of the <i>broom</i> is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it.		16	1226	1144	31	ロク		A monk won a <em>gold metal</em> for breaking the current<strong> record</strong> for most <em>swept rice</em> in one minute.	This character is about a <strong>record</strong>ing for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a <em>metal</em> <em>broom</em> and the little pins on the cylinder are like <em>metal</em> <em>grains of rice</em>.	Historians have discovered an ancient<strong> record</strong> about Buddhist monastic life<strong> record</strong>ed in <em>gold</em> plates. Sadly, the only thing the monks did was use their <em>brooms</em> to sweep up <em>rice</em>.	"For the combination of broom+rice I'll use Curling <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curling"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curling</a> where the stone has been replaced with an onigiri rice ball (thanks Katsuo). So here, the Canadian team is recieving a GOLD medal for breaking the world<strong> record</strong> for points scored in CURLING."	"The <strong>right part</strong> should be a new <strong>primitive</strong> since it will appear several times (see <a href=""../v4/1371.html"">green</a> (#1371 緑), <a href=""../v4/2145.html"">peel off</a> (#2145 剥) and <a href=""../v4/2602.html"">salarium</a> (#2602 禄)) and can easily confused with similar stroke combinations. I suggest <strong>videotape</strong>, deduced from its Chinese meaning (thx shinclef)."

穏		calm	Wheat . . . vulture . . . broom . . . heart.		16	1230	1147	31	オン	おだ.やか	This whole kanji is a picture of <strong>calm</strong>ness. Even the days are<strong> calm</strong> without storm. A<strong> Calm</strong> day: the <em>vulture</em> is flying above the <em>wheat</em> fields, where there's a a scarecrow made with a <em>broom</em> with an <em>heart</em> painted on the shirt (like oz scarecrow).	The farmer lying in the middle of the wheat field is so<strong> calm</strong> the vultures think he is dead and keep trying to get at his heart. He just lightly brushes them away with a broom, barely noticing their presence.	Creepy but<strong> calm</strong> bucolic scene: In a field of wheat, a vulture sits atop a scarecrow's broom,<strong> calm</strong>ly eating a heart (a mouse heart?).

He hasn't made a single sale today, so he doesn't have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet <em>turtle</em> and cries himself to sleep." 彙		glossary	The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of <i>broom</i>. The remaining elements are: <i>crown</i> . . . <i>fruit</i>.		13	1237	2997	31	イ	はりねずみ	"I was having <em>mutual difficulties</em> in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the <em>crown</em> and I was the one picking the <em>fruit</em>. In order to fix the problem I checked the<strong> glossary</strong> for ""<em>mutual difficulties</em>"" but found nothing. I guess we're going to have to <em>mutually end</em> our relationship."	"When I went to <em>Headless Mutual</em>, the bank for tough London gangsters, I was given a pamphlet that said ""If you try'a rip us off, we'll give you the rough end of a pineapple."" I didn't quite understand this phrase, but it was important that I knew my legal obligations, so I consulted my <strong>Glossary</strong> of British Thieves' Argot. The result: ""'give one the rough end of a pineapple': lit. insert the <em>crown</em> of the <em>fruit</em> into the recipient's anus. Metaphorically used to mean 'to exact vengeance'. Oh, I see now."	"People who read the<strong> glossary</strong> are <em>mutually exclusive</em> (exclude the top line of <a href=""../v4/757.html"">mutually</a> (#757 互) ) from those who eat <em>crowned fruit</em> イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙 ."	"I was reading a recipe book but had trouble figuring out what a ""pineapple"" was. Thanks to the <em>one-way assisting</em><strong> glossary</strong> at the end, I learnt that a pineapple was a <em>crowned fruit</em>."	We had no idea what a <em>crowned fruit</em> was so we <em>mutually</em> checked the<strong> glossary</strong>. Well, I say mutually, but really I did all the work.		
争		contend	Bound up . . . rake.		6	1238	1154	31	ソウ	あらそ.う、いか.でか	This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to <em>bound up</em> his opponents, and with a <em>trident</em>, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific <strong>contenders</strong>, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.	A boxing ring is <em>bound up</em> by the ropes. The<strong> contend</strong>er is cheating and using a <em>rake</em>.	In an episode of the Simpsons, Sideshow Bob is trying to kill Bart, but on the way has to<strong> contend</strong> with a pile of <em>rakes</em> which keep him <em>bound up</em> for some time.	The peasants revolt: if you do weird things to them in your castle, you may have to<strong> contend</strong> with a mob ready to <em>bind you up</em> and beat you to death with <em>rakes</em>.	One of the<strong> contend</strong>ers in Street Fighter 2 is<em>Vega</em> who has <em>rakes bound</em> to his hands.

Note how the <i>rake</i> handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.		8	1240	1156	31	ジ、ズ	こと、つか.う、つか.える	Just <em>one</em> word about this<strong> matter</strong> from your <em>mouth</em> and you will find this <em>rake</em> across it. 唐		T'ang	The key word here refers of course to the <b>T'ang</b> Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: <i>cave</i> . . . <i>rake</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>.		10	1241	1157	31	トウ	から	"Two archeologists are in a <em>cave</em> looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a <em>rake</em> and says, ""What about this – T'ang, do you think?"" The second puts the <em>rake</em> in his <em>mouth</em> and answers, ""Yes, it does <strong>tang</strong> a bit""."	Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical <em>caves</em>, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden <em>rakes</em> to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their <em>mouths</em> to see if it's tasty or not.	(Based on matticus) The <strong>Tang</strong> juice was created in China in the <strong>T'ANG</strong> dinasty. The T'ANG emperor discovered that certain <strong>cave</strong>s walls had a very sweet smell, so he <strong>raked</strong> the walls of one of them and put the <strong>rake</strong> into his <strong>mouth</strong>. This way he discovered that tasty powder that nowadays is known as TANG juice.	Archaeologists found an ancient RAKE from the T'ang dynasty at the MOUTH of the CAVE.	I imagine that people from the T'ang dinasty looked a bit like cartoony asians, with teeth so prominent that looked like <em>rakes</em> on their <em>mouth</em>. They felt ridiculous about that, so they usually hid on <em>caves</em>, wishing for a dinasty with better depictions.		
糖		sugar	Rice . . . T'ang.		16	1242	1158	31	トウ		<strong>Sugar</strong> made from rice has a tangy flavour.	The <em>T'ang</em> are the ones who began using<strong> sugar</strong> in China–of course, the first thing they tried it on was <em>rice</em>.	The ultimate<strong> sugar</strong>y breakfast is a <em>rice krispy treat</em> and a big glass of <em>Tang</em>.	This is what my research yielded on the origin of the kanji: The traditional form of<strong> sugar</strong> in China was maltose, which is a form a<strong> sugar</strong> made from malt (= dried <em>grains</em>). It was still used in the late Han and throughout the Tang period, though during the Tang<strong> sugar</strong> cane substituted <em>grains</em> as the primary source of<strong> sugar</strong>.	<em>Condi Rice</em> wakes up every morning and spoons about three cups of<strong> sugar</strong> into her <em>Tang</em>. Why? Well, she's got to have something to hype her up about facing the American public day after day. Picture her waking up and shaking until she gets her daily<strong> sugar</strong> ration…then things go overboard and she starts to pipe<strong> sugar</strong>-loaded <em>Tang</em> straight into her veins..

People on the <em>cave</em> age became more<strong> sane</strong> after they started using <em>sieves</em> to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康 , health).	Ever since I meditated in the <em>cave</em> and realised that wearing a <em>sieve</em> on my head would stop the C.I.A controlling my thoughts, I've been completely<strong> SANE</strong>. 君		old boy	The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: <i>mop</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>.		7	1246	1162	31	クン	きみ、-ぎみ	"There's a tendency in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. ""Well<strong> old boy</strong>,"" a senpai might say, ""If you did as much work with the <em>mop</em> as you do with your <em>mouth,</em> you would have been done an hour ago""."	The Beatles, english<strong> old boy</strong>s, had hairs like <em>mop</em> and a good singing <em>mouth</em>.	君 [kimi] is said by the<strong> old boy</strong> to the younger boy, never the other way around as it would be an insult.	"For this character I think of the Korean movie ""<strong>oldboy</strong>"", in which the protagonist has hair like a <em>mop</em> and a <em>mouth</em> that screams in agony. If you have not seen it you really should it's great, I won't spoil the ending…you won't see it coming :)."	君 [kimi] is said by the<strong> old boy</strong> to the younger boy, otherwise it would be an insult and someone would end up with a <em>mop</em> to the <em>mouth</em>. (Thank you Raseru).		
群		flock	Old boys . . . sheep.		13	1247	1163	31	グン	む.れる、む.れ、むら、むら.がる	<em>Good ol' boys</em> are like <em>sheep</em>; they tend to<strong> flock</strong> together.	"A little girl herder calls out, "" <a href=""midori://search?text=%E7%BE%8A%E5%90%9B%E3%80%81%E3%81%8D%E3%81%A6%EF%BC%81"">羊君、きて！</a> "" to the sheeps and they<strong> flock</strong> to her at once."	(Thanks Stefanot) Fans<strong> flock</strong>ed like sheep at Beatles - old boys concerts.	"Quentin Tarantino fans are like<strong> flock</strong>s of sheep. He gives the thumbs up for ""Old Boy"" and everyone<strong> flock</strong>s to the theatre to watch."	Kimi! Get back in the<strong> flock</strong>, like a good sheep.		
耐		-proof	"The key word is a suffix used to indicate ""safe from"" or ""protected against,"" as in the words rust<b>proof</b>, water<b>proof</b>, and fire<b>proof</b>. It is composed of: <i>comb</i> . . . <i>glue</i>."		9	1248	1164	31	タイ	た.える	[akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof–and I glued it to myself.	I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.	<em>Glue</em> your hair together and it will be <em>comb</em><strong>-proof</strong>.	"Urushi is one of the hardest lacquers(and glues) known to man. It's<strong> -proof</strong>ed against everything: acid, oil, water, heat, etc. They found a 6,000yo urushi comb in Japan! <a href=""http://www.urushi-kobo.com/history.html"">http://www.urushi-kobo.com/history.html</a>."	My <em>comb</em> is <em>glue</em>-<strong>proof</strong>!		
需		demand	"The sense of <b>demand</b> is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of ""supply and <b>demand</b>."" The primitives: <i>rain</i> . . . <i>comb</i>."		14	1249	1165	31	ジュ		Supply and<strong> demand</strong> is a simple concept: when it <em>rains</em>, the<strong> demand</strong> for <em>combs</em> goes up to deal with wet hair.	If it's raining combs, then the<strong> demand</strong> for them sure does drop.	If it <em>rains</em>, the<strong> demand</strong> for <em>combs</em> will rise. However, if it <em>rains combs</em>, the<strong> demand</strong> for <em>combs</em> will fall. It's all about supply and<strong> demand</strong>. (A combination of radical tyro's and FuduMyo's stories).	It's <em>raining</em> <em>combs</em>?? I<strong> demand</strong> an explanation for this shit.	A smart salesman will know which kind of <em>weather</em> will cause frizzy hair, with the subsequent increase in the<strong> demand</strong> for <em>combs</em>.		
儒		Confucian	Person . . . demand.		16	1250	1166	31	ジュ		"No more <strong>Confucian</strong> jibba-jabba! I <em>demand</em> you tell me why it's <em>raining</em> <em>combs</em>!""."	"One day, <em>Mr. T</em> started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a<strong> Confucian</strong> scholar. He was suddenly in <em>high demand</em> as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, ""You will find happiness with a new love""."	<em>Mr. T</em> <em>demand</em>s to know what<strong> Confucian</strong> means!	Confucius Say: when it rain comb, man have brush with death.	Confucius is a <em>person</em> who <em>demanded</em> that people make an effort to live up to high moral<strong> Confucian</strong> standards and improve society that way.		
端		edge	Vase . . . mountain . . . comb.		14	1251	1167	31	タン	はし、は、はた、-ばた、はな	Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is <em>standing</em> at the <em>edge</em> of a sheer <em>mountain</em> face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully <em>combing</em> his hair so it would fall perfectly.	"When you <em>stand</em> a <em>comb</em> on its<strong> edge</strong>, it looks like the <a href=""../v4/768.html"">mountain</a> (#768 山) kanji."	Jimi Hendrix: Well I stand up next to a mountain, chop it down with the<strong> edge</strong> of my ……… comb?	Standing on the<strong> edge</strong> of a mountain, you throw your comb into the abyss. Head shaved, no need for it anymore. Goodbye comb, goodbye. You're on the<strong> edge</strong> yourself, you look below. The abyss beckons. You watch the comb fall…	He valianty <em>stood</em> at the <em>mountain</em>'s<strong> edge</strong>… and proceed to <em>comb</em> his hair for the photographs.		
両		both	<i>Ceiling</i> . . . <i>belt</i> . . . <i> mountain</i>. Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here.		6	1252	1168	31	リョウ	てる、ふたつ	Primatives <em>celing; belt; mountain</em> as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link.<strong> Both</strong> effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the <em>celing</em> with your <em>belt</em> or jump off a <em>mountain</em>.	Under one <em>ceiling</em><strong> both</strong> took off their <em>belts</em> in Brokeback <em>Mountain</em>.	Be careful with this one. The correct primitive order is <em>ceiling</em> . . . <em>belt</em> . . . <em>mountain</em>. That said, in the Mario video games, there are some levels where spikes hang from the <em>ceiling</em> and there are large conveyor <em>belts</em>. One example is Koopa <em>Mountain</em>. Imagine<strong> both</strong> Mario and Luigi trying to get through the level unscathed.	Matticus, the errata at www.nanzan-u.ac.jp/ SHUBUNKEN/publications/miscPublications/ Remembering_the_Kanji_1.htm reflects your view of how the character should be written. Everyone should take a look and correct all the listed errors in the book.	<strong>Both</strong> the ceiling of heaven and the mountains are belted to the Earth.		
満		full	<i>Water</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>both</i>. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame.		12	1253	1169	31	マン、バン	み.ちる、み.つ、み.たす	Add <em>water</em> THEN the <em>flowers</em>. With <em>both</em> the vase will be <strong>full</strong>.	I was thirsty so I gulped down the <em>water</em>. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the <em>flowers</em>. Yes, I am responsible for <em>both</em> the missing <em>water</em> and the missing <em>flowers</em>. Yes, I'm afraid <em>both</em>. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite <strong>full</strong> now.	"I hate going on dates where a girl says ""I'll have a <em>salad</em> and a <em>water</em>"" and then insists that they <em>both</em> make her<strong> full</strong>!"	Just imagine you and your closest Japanese class rival having a contest to see who can get<strong> full</strong> marks ( 満点 ）in a test, the winner is given <em>Flowers</em>, the looser is drenched with ice cold <em>water</em>, now imagine you <em>both</em> get<strong> full</strong> marks and so <em>both</em> of you get drenched and flowered.	In spring, the <em>water</em> of Kyoto's waterways is<strong> full</strong> of cherry blossom <em>flowers</em>, right up to the banks on <em>both</em> sides.		
画		brush-stroke	In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of <b>brush-strokes</b> in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>sprout</i> . . . <i>shovel</i>.		8	1254	1170	31	ガ、カク、エ、カイ	えが.く、かく.する、かぎ.る、はかりごと、はか.る	You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.	To paint a kanji in your <em>ceiling</em> with only natural materials, you use a <em>sprout</em> as a <strong>brush</strong> and <em>shovel</em> some dirt to use as paint for your <strong>strokes</strong>. [modified from johnskb's].	Start with just <em>one</em> stroke. Soon more will <em>sprout</em>, and then you end up with a whole <em>shovel</em>full!	The first kanji I learnt was just <em>one</em><strong> brush stroke</strong>, but then my knowledge <em>sprouted</em> and I knew a <em>shovel</em>ful.	"New age artist. The canvas is on the <em>ceiling</em>. The floor is covered with bean <em>sprouts</em>. The artist takes a <em>shovel</em> and makes a sweeping motion on the ground, sending a stream of sprouts flying up to the ceiling and sticking to the canvas in strange patterns. ""This is radical calligraphy,"" he says, panting for breath, ""and the act of shoveling is my new-age equivalent of the classical<strong> brush stroke</strong>.""."		
歯		tooth	Footprint . . . rice . . . shovel.		12	1255	1171	31	シ	よわい、は、よわ.い、よわい.する	<em>Stop</em> <em>shoveling</em> <em>rice</em> into your mouth, you'll hurt a<strong> tooth</strong>! Use chopsticks instead.	My dentist used his <em>foot</em> and a <em>shovel</em> to dislodge the <em>rice</em> stuck between my <strong>teeth</strong>.	"My female dentist: ""<em>Stop</em> using a <em>shovel</em> to pick the <em>rice</em> grains from out of your <strong>teeth</strong>! You'll wreck them!"" she (し) said."	A Japanese wife <em>stopped</em> cooking <em>rice</em> one night because she was tired. Her husband complained so she took a <em>shovel</em> to his face and broke all his <strong>teeth</strong>.	I cant believe i didnt see this before …………………………………………………….. ITS A PICTOGRAPH OF A<strong> TOOTH</strong>!!! …a front<strong> tooth</strong> thats <em>white as rice</em>, wedged into the <em>upper gum to stop it</em> moving and the <em>shovel primitive is the shape of the<strong> tooth</strong></em>. …you dont need much imagination to picture this!!……..UPDATE: the stop primitive can even mean <em>foot</em> of the<strong> tooth</strong> (like opposite to head) thus root of the<strong> tooth</strong>.		
曲		bend	Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of <b>bend</b>. If you think of them as deriving from the element for <i>brains</i> beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with <b>bending</b> someone's mind to your own point of view.		6	1256	1172	31	キョク	ま.がる、ま.げる	"It looks like the mouth of <em>Bender the robot</em>, from Matt Groening's animated series ""Futurama"". Thus, I use the character <em>Bender the robot</em> as a primitive."	"Also means ""melody"". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to <strong>bend</strong> the strings to make a <strong>melody</strong>."	When <em>two sprouts sprout</em> at the same place they don't have enough space and have to<strong> bend</strong> in different directions to grow…	"Hannibal Lecter exposes his victim's <em>brains</em> and inserts two <em>walking sticks</em>, using them to<strong> bend</strong> the victim to his will. Note: Heisig implies this, but doesn't show the actual stroke order. Write this in the same order as <a href=""../v4/14.html"">rice field</a> (#14 田) but with two extended vertical strokes in the center instead of one short stroke."	This is a guitar fretboard. You have to<strong> bend</strong> the strings to produce a <em>melody</em>.		
曹		cadet	This character is written in the order of its elements: <i>one</i> . . . <i>bend</i> . . . <i>sun</i>.		11	1257	1173	31	ソウ、ゾウ	つかさ、ともがら、へや	A space<strong> cadet</strong> eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).	<em>Bender</em> lasted just <em>one day</em> in the space<strong> cadet</strong>s.	Japanese<strong> cadet</strong>s have to constantly do <em>one</em> thing–<em>bend</em> OVER all <em>day</em>, bowing to their superiors.	"Hint : As a primitive I use the image of Bender the robot from the animated series ""Futurama"" (by the same creator as ""The Simpsons""). Here Bender is a<strong> cadet</strong> at the army, and the sergeant who is blinded by the sun reflected on Bender's metallic body, keeps saying ""this<strong> cadet</strong> is <em>one</em> -insert random expletive- <em>bend</em>er of the <em>sun</em>!"" (meaning Bender bends the sun's rays)."	"This is from back in <em>Bender</em>'s early days, when he was a promising young space<strong> cadet</strong> at the evil empire academy. He had one task - blow up <em>one</em> <em>sun</em>. <em>One</em>. <em>Sun</em>. That they had set up for him beforehand. Well, he ended up blowing up the entire solar system his outfit was stationed in. When he got called in for a meeting, the commander said: ""Cadet <em>Bender</em>, you were asked to blow up <em>one</em> <em>sun</em>. At this rate, you'll never be more than a<strong> cadet</strong>"". <em>Bender</em>: ""Screw this, I'm outta here""."		
遭		encounter	Cadet . . . road.		14	1258	1174	31	ソウ	あ.う、あ.わせる	Close<strong> encounter</strong>s of the third kind. The space <em>cadet</em><strong> encounter</strong>s aliens on the <em>road</em>.	"<em>Bender the cadet</em> (see frame 1172) has an ""encounter of the third kind"" on the <em>road</em>. Reference to Steven Spielberg's 1977 movie ""Close<strong> Encounter</strong>s of the Third Kind"". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO's while driving on the road."	"Close<strong> encounter</strong>s of the third kind. You<strong> encounter</strong> a space <em>cadet</em> on the <em>road</em>. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. Having ""alien"" in the story made me want to use 玄 in place of 曹 )."	"You<strong> encounter</strong> cadets on the road as they march ""hut 2-3-4"" (frame 1173)."	While traveling the Milky <em>road-way</em>, <em>Bender the space cadet</em> had an alien <em>encounter</em>. However, he's used to them by now, so it wasn't really a big deal.		
漕		rowing	Water . . . cadet.		14	1259	1175	31	ソウ	こ.ぐ、はこ.ぶ	<em>Bender the cadet</em> (see frame 1172) is<strong> rowing</strong>, during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of <em>water</em> (Bender is a robot).	The space <em>cadet</em> is in training,<strong> rowing</strong> in the <em>water</em> (see it splash).	A space <em>cadet</em> has crashed on an unknown planet. Fortunately he crashed in <em>water</em> so he's unharmed, but now he has to do some<strong> rowing</strong> to get out of the <em>water</em>.	"When the <em>cadets</em> are ordered into the <em>water</em>, it can only mean one thing -<strong> rowing</strong>. (Make sure to picture this as the verb<strong> rowING</strong>, so as to not confuse with <a href=""../v4/1785.html"">row</a> (#1785 並), which means 'a row of something')."	<strong>Water</strong> <strong>cadet</strong>s (a freshwater branch of the sea scouts), love to go <em>rowing</em>. Stroke! Stroke!		
槽		vat	Tree . . . cadet.		15	1260	1176	31	ソウ	ふね	Also as part of some army survival exercise, the <em>cadets</em> (including <em>Bender</em> see frame 1172) are sent into the <em>woods</em> to build a<strong> vat</strong> (for collecting water for example).	<em>Bender the Cadet</em> (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a <em>tree</em>, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey<strong> Vat</strong> 69.	"A true (?) story about Captain Cook and sauerkraut. Cook was convinced that sauerkraut would prevent the disease scurvy among his sailors, but his problem was getting his sailors to eat the stuff. He tricked the low-ranking <em>cadets</em> into eating sauerkraut by storing it in <em>wood</em><strong> vat</strong>s labeled ""for officers' use only"". The <em>cadets</em> thus believed that they were being unfairly denied access to the officers-only<strong> vat</strong>s, so they secretly stole and ate the sauerkraut - which was exactly what Cook wanted them to do."	Space <em>cadets</em> are decompressed in <em>wooden</em><strong> vat</strong>s when they return to Earth.	Cadets have to bathe in wooden<strong> vat</strong>s.		
斗		Big Dipper	The <b>Big Dipper</b> here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation.	"* Since we already have a primitive element for a ""dipper"" - namely, the <i>ladle</i> - we shall let this one stand for a <i>measuring cup</i>. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters!"	4	1261	1177	31	ト、トウ		"Since the meaning of ""big dipper"" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of <strong>measuring cup</strong>. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup."	Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?	I looked out my window frame and saw two shooting stars slashing through the<strong> big dipper</strong>. Primitive: Big Gulp cup from 7-11.	This does not look like the<strong> big dipper</strong> or 18 liters of anything in any way, shape, or form.	The<strong> Big Dipper</strong> is a celestial measuring cup.		
料		fee	Measuring cup . . . rice.		10	1262	1178	31	リョウ		When buying <em>rice</em>, the<strong> fee</strong> is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper <em>measuring cup</em>.	Samurai(s) once received their<strong> fee</strong> in the form of <em>rice</em> that had been carefully weighed in a <em>measuring cup</em> beforehand.	Ancient Japan mobile promises no monthly<strong> fee</strong>s for long distance but I hate the fact that they don't take credit cards. I'm tired of mailing them a <em>measuring cup</em> full of <em>rice</em> every month.	Hidden <strong>fees</strong> are everywhere nowadays. Just the other day, I bought some rice, and they charged me for using the <em>measuring cup</em>!	This kanji is used in 料理 (cooking). Imagine a <strong>cooking</strong> recipe: Telling you how many <em>cups of rice</em> (measuring cups, of course) you need, and what the <strong>fee</strong> at the supermarket is.		
科		department	Think here of the faculty or <b>department</b> you entered in university, using the elements: <i>measuring cup</i> . . . <i>wheat</i>.		9	1263	1179	31	カ		University<strong> department</strong>s study things like <em>wheat</em> (agriculture) and the <em>big dipper</em> (physics/astronomy), and exact <em>measuring cups</em> (engineering).	The national<strong> DEPARTMENT</strong> of <em>WHEATS</em> and <em>MEASURES</em>. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.	The science<strong> department</strong>s at universities are trying to grow one wheat plant that can fill a whole measuring cup. (genetic engineering).	"An alphabetical list of the university's<strong> department</strong>s reads ""Agriculture (<em>wheat</em>), Astronomy (<em>Big Dipper</em>)…."" and so on."	The<strong> Department</strong> of <em>Wheat</em> Measurement has heard some strange things about <em>Cap 'n Crunch Cereal</em> recently - namely, that the amount of <em>wheat</em> in <em>Cap 'n Crunch Cereal</em> may not be as high as is claimed on the box. So here they are at the factory with a huge <em>garbage pail-sized measuring cup</em>, putting the appropriate amount of <em>wheat</em> into each box.		
図		map	"<i>Pent in</i> . . . <i>Big Dipper</i>. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called ""Follow the Drinking Gourd."" It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those <i>pent in</i>) who had no <b>maps</b> other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant <i>Big Dipper</i>, the ""Drinking Gourd."""		7	1264	1180	31	ズ、ト	え、はか.る	"Can't see direct relation to <a href=""../v4/1177.html"">Big Dipper</a> (#1177 斗) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure<strong> map</strong>. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them."	A pictograph of a treasure<strong> map</strong>. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず<strong> map</strong>; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do; 図々しい ずうずうしい impudent, shameless; 図書館 としょかん library.	"When I arrived in Hollywood, I bought what they call a ""star<strong> map</strong>."" Much to my dismay, it didn't even show the location of the <em>big dipper</em>!"	A PENT IN BIG DIPPER is an astronomy<strong> MAP</strong>.	Ahem, it looks like a Trea-<em>tsu me</em>p, er a treasure<strong> map</strong>…		
用		utilize	<i>Meat</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i>. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for <i>use</i> (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.	* As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a <i>screwdriver</i>, perhaps the most <i>utilized</i> of all tools around the house.	5	1265	1181	31	ヨウ	もち.いる	To tenderize <em>meat</em> in an emergency wilderness situation, just<strong> utilize</strong> your <em>walking stick</em>!	"I'll confuse this with <a href=""../v4/990.html"">use</a> (#990 使), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, ""utilize"" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only<strong> utilize</strong> ""utilize"" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: ""BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, <strong>utilizing</strong> the our latest <em>Flesh</em>Grip(tm) technology!"" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of <em>flesh</em>, a short <em>shaft</em>, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it."	When your flesh is weak you must<strong> utilize</strong> a walking stick.	We have to<strong> utilize</strong> different tools for different jobs. If some object in your kitchen needs to be be screwed, you would<strong> utilize</strong> a <strong>screwdriver</strong>. If your woman needs to be screwed, you would<strong> utilize</strong> your <em>meat stick</em>.	NASA<strong> utilize</strong>s a giant laser to cut the moon in half. Very shortly, the Earth will have two <em>companion</em> moons.		
庸		comfortable	Cave . . . rake . . . screwdriver.		11	1266	1182	31	ヨウ		To live a<strong> comfortable</strong> life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.	"When I first moved in to my new <em>cave</em>, all I had was a bed (see <a href=""../v4/592.html"">bed</a> (#592 床)). But now I've settled in, got myself a few handy things like a <em>rake</em> and a <em>screwdriver</em>, and made myself more<strong> comfortable</strong>."	To make your cave more<strong> comfortable</strong>, you'll need to do some work with a rake and screwdriver. Clean it up. Fix a few things.	"Commonplace seems like a better keyword for this, though it's easier to confuse with others like ""usual"" and ""mediocre"". In this case, commonplace refers to something ordinary and non-exceptional. I picture a commonplace caveman's cave, with very ordinary, non-fancy, cave drawings he did with a screwdriver because he couldn't afford a writing brush. You have to visualize him etching the drawings with the screwdriver."	(Thanks rtkrtk) To live a<strong> comfortable</strong> life, the Flintstones need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.		
備		equip	<i>Person</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>cliff</i> . . . <i>screwdriver</i>. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character.		12	1267	1183	31	ビ	そな.える、そな.わる、つぶさ.に	Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He<strong> equip</strong>s himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.	An RPG where you're using <em>Mr T</em> as a character. Before you enter a battle, you<strong> equip</strong> the <em>flower cliff screwdriver</em>. This is a small <em>screwdriver</em> obtained at the bottom of a <em>cliff</em> that, when used in battle, shoots out pink <em>flowers</em>. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and<strong> EQUIP</strong>ping this item just before facing a tough boss.	A <em>person</em><strong> equip</strong>ping themselves with <em>flowers</em> they will <em>utilize</em> to beautify the barren <em>cliff</em>.	"<em>Mr. T</em> falls from the edge of a <em>cliff</em> but grabs hold of a <em>flower</em> to save his life. He then shoves a <em>screwdriver</em> into the dirt and lifts himself up to safety. ""I pity the fool who doesn't come<strong> equip</strong>ed,"" he quips."	<em>Jedi</em> Anakin wanted to present Padme with some rare <em>flowers</em> which only grow at the top of a high <em>cliff</em> on Naboo. To<strong> equip</strong> himself for the climb, he only carried a sonic <em>screwdriver</em>, since he was able to <em>utilise</em> his Jedi powers. 準備 じゅんび preparation; 備える (そなえる) : to furnish, to provide for, to<strong> equip</strong>, to install, to have ready, to prepare for, to possess, to have, to be endowed with, to be armed with; 守備 (しゅび) : defense.		
昔		once upon a time	<i>Salad</i> . . . <i>days</i>. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin.		8	1268	1184	32	セキ、シャク	むかし	<strong>Once upon a time</strong>, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.	"For those who don't know the expression, ""salad days"" means the time of one's youth. (originally from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra - see <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days</a>). I suspect Heisig chose ""salad"" as the name for the radical just for this phrase…"	<strong>Once upon a time</strong> there was a McDonald's <em>salad</em> and it was left out in the sun for a whole <em>day</em>. But … nothing happened because it was a McDonald's salad, chock full of preservatives and other garbage. The salad lived happily ever after (and so did the person who didn't eat it). The end. [I didn't write this… the original author deleted it… but it's my favourite story on the whole site.].	"This is the kanji for ""mukashi"". Often used for ""once upon a time"" or ""long time ago"". I will take this kanji to mean ""really fucking long time ago""……A really fucking long time ago, I use to eat <em>salad</em> every <em>day</em> and was very slim…..those days are long gone and I'm now fat as a pig…"	<strong>Once upon a time</strong> there was a ruler called <em>ceaser</em> (shiza sarada). He ruled everything under the <em>sun</em>, even the <em>sun</em> worshiping egyptians, until one <em>day</em> he was killed and then his <em>sun</em> Augustous took over. I think Ceaser will be an easier primitive than<strong> once upon a time</strong>. N.B. It's worked really well for me over the next couple of kanji.		
錯		confused	Metal . . . once upon a time.		16	1269	1185	32	サク、シャク		A long time ago, people of the world got<strong> confused</strong> because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.	"<em>Once upon a time</em>, it was thought that the ancient ""art"" of alchemy could transform anything into <em>gold</em>. At that time, people were obviously<strong> confused</strong> about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as<strong> confused</strong> as ever, just about different things now.)."	<em>Once upon a time</em> there were some very<strong> confused</strong> alchemists. They couldn't understand why they couldn't turn other metals (i.e. lead) into gold. (adapted from Raichu).	<em>Once upon a time</em> Metallica used to be a great <em>metal</em> band. Somewhere around 1990 they got<strong> confused</strong> and now they write shitty pop rock songs.	Ahhh senility, when you are<strong> confused</strong> by the everything in the world . . . your <em>golden</em> years are not at all like your <em>salad days</em>.		
借		borrow	Person . . . once upon a time.		10	1270	1186	32	シャク	か.りる	"<em>Once upon a time</em> I let <em>Mr T</em><strong> borrow</strong> my <em>salad</em> bowl, but he won't give it back. Do you think I'm going to ask for it back? No way!	<em>Back in the day</em>, you'd<strong> borrow</strong> from a <em>person</em>. These days you go to a bank.		
惜		pity	"<i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>once upon a time</i>.
