窪		depression	<i>Hole</i> . . . <i>water</i> . . . <i>ivy</i>. The <b>depression</b> referred to here is a sunken place in the ground, rather than in one's spirits.		14	1421	1323	35	ワ、ア	くぼ.む、くぼ.み、くぼ.まる、くぼ	A<strong> depression</strong> is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.	The<strong> depression</strong> in the ground become a trap: the <em>hole</em> was filled with <em>water</em> and covered with <em>ivy</em>.	The meaning of this character is an indentation in the ground, not emotional<strong> depression</strong>. It's best to avoid using the latter in your story because it will give you the wrong meaning (keep in mind the eventual goal is to read kanji and understand the actual meaning of them). This particular<strong> depression</strong> is a <em>hole</em> in the ground that collects water, and ivy is growing out of it.	(<strong>WARNING</strong>: Sexual content) Being the dirty girl that she is, I came upon <em>Paris Hilton</em> having sex in a<strong> depression</strong>, or <em>hole</em>, in the ground. At this point, however, she and her unfortunately partner were tangled up in some <em>ivy</em> and couldn't get out. So I filled it with <em>water</em> and watched them both drown.	This kanji reminds me of video games. There's a big <em>sink hole</em> in the ground that is now filled with <em>water</em> that you can swim in and <em>vines</em> growing all around that you can climb on.		
搾		squeeze	Fingers . . . hole . . . saw.		13	1422	1324	35	サク	しぼ.る	You have trouble squeezing your hand through the hole so you use a saw to enlarge it.	(Thanks DrJones) You<strong> squeeze</strong> the teats of the cow with your <em>fingers</em> but it's your first try and you don't have any milk come through the <em>holes</em>, so you take a <em>saw</em> and cut the teats to make bigger <em>holes</em>. Poor cow, this story<strong> squeeze</strong>s my heart.	Very simple visual image makes this an easy kanji to remember. Just picture that you<strong> SQUEEZE</strong> your FINGERS going through the HOLE in the handle of the SAW. You then<strong> SQUEEZE</strong> your FINGERS tight to use the SAW to cut a HOLE.	"To<strong> squeeze</strong> is to hold something <a href=""../v4/2614.html"">tight</a> (#2614 窄) in your <em>fingers</em>."	Oh no! You cut a <em>hole</em> in your <em>finger</em> with a <em>saw</em>!<strong> Squeeze</strong> your <em>finger</em> to stop the bleeding!!		
窯		kiln	Hole . . . sheep . . . oven fire.		15	1423	1325	35	ヨウ	かま	Be sure to put a <em>hole</em> in that ceramic <em>sheep</em> before you put it over the <em>fire</em>. Otherwise, it'll just explode in the<strong> kiln</strong>. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.).	You put the sheep in the hole of the<strong> kiln</strong> and turn on the flames.	True story: when I was a kid if there were lambs born in the winter we'd put them in a cardboard box and put them in the oven (on low!) to keep them warm. I guess this only really helps me out hehehe…	Oh Boy! A craft project indeed! Thru the <em>hole</em> in the top of the <strong>kiln</strong>, put in the <em>sheep</em> you sculpted from clay. Turn on the <em>fire</em> underneath and voila!	"I kept forgetting the <em>sheep</em> in smithsonian's story, so just imagine the sound effects: ""Baaa…"" (bleating)/Baaam! (explosion)."		
窮		hard up	Hole . . . somebody . . . bow.		15	1424	1326	35	キュウ、キョウ	きわ.める、きわ.まる、きわ.まり、きわ.み	<strong>Hard up</strong> = nothing but your body, living in a hole, with just a bow to hunt for your food.	<strong>Somebody</strong> so <strong>hard up</strong> for cash, the volunteered to explore a <em>black hole</em> with nothing but a <em>bow</em>.	Ok, picture a HOLE (well, more a pit trap) that SOMEBODY (well, a hunter with a BOW) just fell in. He's dangling over the HOLE holding onto his BOW across it. SOMEBODY finds it's HARD to get UP out of the HOLE. That great visual image should grant mastery of this kanji.	"With the research to plug up a <em>black hole</em> going nowhere and funding slashed, (see <a href=""../v4/1320.html"">research</a> (#1320 究)), the team can not afford to launch any more probes due to the high cost of the fuel. <em>Somebody</em>, probably one of the<strong> hard up</strong> scientists desperately in need of more funding, tries using a <em>bow</em> to shoot a probe into the centre of the <em>block hole</em> – and funnily enough it succeeds!"	A girl is so<strong> hard up</strong> for cash she lets <em>somebody</em> use her <em>hole</em> with a <em>bow</em>, it's a fetish-thing I guess; makes the guy hard and up.		
探		grope	Fingers . . . paper punch . . . tree.		11	1425	1327	35	タン	さぐ.る、さが.す	A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting<strong> grope</strong>d by perverts on the train. "Note: ""<em>crown+human legs</em>"" appears 7 times in RTK. In 4 cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) <em>crown</em> is above <em>human legs</em>, and in the other 3 (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. I call the 1st pattern ""<em>Miss World</em>"" (who is wearing a <em>crown</em> & has long <em>human legs</em>) and the 2nd ""<em>garter</em>"" (one <em>human leg</em> passes through the <em>crown</em> wearing it as a <em>garter</em>). (based on gorgon's story) a pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting<strong> grope</strong>d by perverts on the train. I don't know why, but this is a pictograph of someone groping about in the dark (with his fingers, obviously) for his beloved wooden paper punch.	"As esaulgd said, this kanji DOES NOT mean ""touch"" like <a href=""midori://search?text=%E8%A7%A6%E3%82%8B%E3%80%82"">触る。</a> Here is my story: Imagine a blind detective who must<strong> GROPE</strong> for answers in by reading old police reports. But because he is blind, he must use brail books, you know, the ones that have been PAPER PUNCHED on PAPER (wood). Naturally, he uses his FINGERS for this."

丘		hill	Since this supposedly pictographic representation of a hill looks like anything but, picture a row of <i>axes</i> driven into the ground up to their heads, and see if that doesn't present a more memorable image of <b>hill</b> - at least a riskier one sliding down!		5	1427	1329	35	キュウ	おか	Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. 岳		Point	Think of the key word as referring to proper names of mountains, but do not confuse with <i>mountain pass</i> (Frame 835). The elements are: <i>hill</i> . . . <i>mountain</i>.		8	1428	1330	35	ガク	たけ	A<strong> point</strong> is a extra little <em>hill</em> at the top of a <em>mountain</em>. We'll call it 'Fireman's<strong> Point</strong>'.	This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it's surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as<strong> Point</strong>, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It's as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height.	"There's a movie called ""The Englishman who went up a hill but came down a mountain"". The story is that English cartographer says that the mountain near a Welsh village is actually a hill (too low for a mountain), but the locals decide to make it a mountain (by making it higher). Let's say that in the end the <em>hill</em> got the title<strong> Point</strong> to mark it as a <em>mountain</em>."	I chopped off the<strong> point</strong> of the <em>mountain</em> with my <em>axe</em>. Now it is just a hill.	At some<strong> point</strong>, a <em>hill</em> becomes a <em>mountain</em>.

糸		thread	Remember when your granny used to ask you to bend your arms at the <i>elbows</i> and hold them out so that she could use them like a rack to hold a skein of string or yarn (here <b>thread</b>) while she rolled it up into a <i>little</i> ball? Now can you see the two <i>elbows</i> (with the second stroke doubling up) at the top, and the character for <i>little</i> below?		6	1431	1333	36	シ	いと	"I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I've opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as <a href=""../v4/1363.html"">dainty</a> (#1363 細) and <a href=""../v4/1364.html"">accumulate</a> (#1364 累)."	You'll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.	On left with nothing on top of it –> SPIDERMAN. everywhere else….SPIDERPIG.	I'll stick with Spiderman. He's a very memorable character, and don't forget that he can shoot strings from both arms. What happens to the relative primitive when Spiderman comes along? If you can clearly picture his<strong> thread</strong>s winding, pulling, yanking, sticking to, filling, tying, and strangling objects, then you'll never confuse this primitive with another one.	Hate to be pedantic, but it's spelt <em>Spider-man</em>, not <em>Spiderman</em>. Stan Lee added the hyphen to differentiate him from <em>Superman</em>..

繕		darning	Thread . . . virtuous.		18	1433	1335	36	ゼン	つくろ.う	After a day being <em>virtuouos</em> and keeping the city safe, <em>Spiderman</em>'s outfit is in need of some repair. "<strong>Darning</strong> socks instead of buying new ones shows the virtousness of the person - it exhibits the Japanese virtue of thrift (the Meiji emperor would refuse to buy new boots, constantly having them repaired. The Showa emperor would refuse to buy books he wanted because he ""couldn't afford them."")."	The <em>thread</em> is too <em>virtuous</em> for damning; it can only be used for<strong> darning</strong>.

羅		gauze	Eye . . . fiber.		19	1442	1342	36	ラ	うすもの	Lots of girls in Japan wear<strong> gauze</strong> patches over one <em>eye</em> made of course white <em>fibers</em>. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too.	"Rocky won the match but left with a nasty <em>eye</em> injury, and needs some<strong> gauze</strong> for it. I use a modified version of the Rocky theme song to remember this one – ""the <em>eye</em> and the <em>fiber</em>""."	The <em>eyes</em> on Spiderman's mask are made of carbon <em>fibre</em><strong> gauze</strong>. Light, strong and see-through.	<strong>Gauze</strong> is a <em>net</em> of <em>fiber</em>.	"This is also used to mean ""web"" (e.g. in 網羅 ) and ""ordered"" (e.g. in 羅列 ). The web meaning is the basic one, and a web consists of fibers and the ""eyes"" (holes, 網の目 ; like ""eye"" of a needle) between them.<strong> Gauze</strong> is just a form of web. ""Ordered"" comes from the order inherent in the matrix formed by the holes. Think of ghastly eyes peeking at you from between the fibers (and fabric of space?) when you're not looking, and you won't look webs the same way ever again."

All those Asian cities with skyscrapers and low crime rates make it easy for him to<strong> practice</strong>. After being defeated one too many times, Spiderman heads East to the Orient in order to<strong> practice</strong> various martial arts.	PRACTICING Japanese every day is the THREAD that binds me to the EAST.

Wierd, eh!	A<strong> thong</strong> is no more than a <em>thread</em> used by <em>someone</em> as underwear!	"Instead of puppet I like to think of ""someone"" as ninja (since it is the second kanji in ninja). A <strong>ninja</strong> must be able to steal a <strong>thread</strong> from a woman's<strong> thong</strong> without her noticing."	<em>Spidey</em> and a <em>Ninja</em> fight over a sexy<strong> thong</strong> they found, but then they realize that together ( 一緒 ) they could easily get another… ショ 一緒 いっしょ(together) チヨ 情緒 じょうちょ(heartstrings)….	Spiderman's girlfriend throws a<strong> thong</strong> she found in his bed at him. And who's is this then she asks, and Spiderman replies, uhh… someone's?		
続		continue	Thread . . . sell.		13	1445	1345	36	ゾク、ショク、コウ、キョウ	つづ.く、つづ.ける、つぐ.ない	Even though Peter Parker has become <em>Spiderman</em>, he<strong> continue</strong>s to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer.	"Here's how Spiderman comics sell: At the end of the comic they leave with with a cliffhanger and say ""to be<strong> continue</strong>d"". In fact, the japanese verb 続く is used in comics and tv shows to mean ""to be<strong> continue</strong>d"". They have adapted the model created by Spiderman to hook the readers so that they can sell more comics."	Spiderman's comics<strong> continue</strong> to sell after several decades. (Even the goofy samurai with his log-crown toys is selling spiderman).	Your thread had better sell if you want to<strong> continue</strong> to be a weaver!	If you attach <em>strings</em> to the things you <em>sell</em>, you will be able to<strong> continue</strong> making profit from them even after the fact.		
絵		picture	Thread . . . meeting.		12	1446	1346	36	カイ、エ		There's never a<strong> picture</strong> of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker… I wonder why?	"Peter Parker's editor tells him ""Next time you have a <em>meeting</em> with <em>spiderman</em> take a goddamn<strong> picture</strong>, you're a photographer after all""."	A<strong> picture</strong> is just a matter of the harmonious <em>meeting</em> of lines. The many <em>threads</em> of a brush <em>meet</em> together on paper, finally forming a <strong>painting</strong>.	By coercing fine, colorful <em>threads</em> to <em>meet</em> other threads in a needlepoint, it's entirely possible to create a very nice<strong> picture</strong>.	"A word of <strong>caution</strong>: This kanji's on-yomi is ""え”, and it's meaning is that of a <strong>picture</strong>, painting, drawing… However, it's not, strictly speaking, a photograph. The kanji for photograph is 写真 （しゃしん）「keyword 1: copy, 2: truth」. Try to remember this kanji without using the image of a photograph, to distinguish them further. The top two stories right now (by PacifistGod and joesan) sort of make you think of a photograph, so bear this in mind!"		
統		overall	Thread . . . allot.		12	1447	1347	36	トウ	す.べる、ほび.る	<em>Spidey</em> is <em>alloted</em> the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his<strong> OVERALL</strong> arrest record is the best.	According to Greek mythology, there's a <em>thread</em> <em>alloted</em> to everyone, and its length is the<strong> overall</strong> determinant of your fate.	SPIDERMAN was originally ALLOTTED some<strong> overall</strong>s by the Superheroes' Guild, but he rejected them in favor of his current outfit.	<strong>Overall</strong> I allot the Spiderman movies an average rating. Spiderman - Great, Spiderman 2 - Average, Spiderman 3 - ass.<strong> Overall</strong> they are average.	"[smithsonian(I have to nitpick your story, sorry)] According to Norse mythology, there's a <em>thread</em> <em>alloted</em> to everyone, and its length is the<strong> overall</strong> determinant of your fate. Info: The belief is that the 3 Norns (Goddesses) of the past, the present and the future, weave the thread of fate beneath Yggdrasil (the world tree) for every person, the pattern that results is the ""fabric"" of reality."

級		class	Threads . . . outstretched hands.		9	1453	1353	36	キュウ		"This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu ( 一級 ) The Kanji doesnt describe<strong> class</strong> as in a ""class of students"" or ""classroom,"" but rather a grade of quality or ability. ———- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend's answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a<strong> class</strong> above him. Looks like this test is above his<strong> class</strong> of knowledge."	Spiderman with his arm stretched out showing the<strong> class</strong> how he produces webs.	<em>Spider-Man reaches out</em> to every<strong> class</strong>, rich and poor.	Spiderman stretching his arms at different length produces a different<strong> class</strong> of web.	<strong>Class, grade, rank.</strong> Members of a particular<strong> class</strong> or rank are connected (as if by a <em>thread</em>) by their similarities and common circumstances; and often, by the extent to which they will <em>reach out and exert</em> themselves to new heights. 下級 (low grade). 学級 (school<strong> class</strong>). 勤労階級 (working<strong> class</strong>). 最高級 (top<strong> class</strong>). 審級 (instance). 上級 (advanced level, senior). 中級 (intermediate level). 飛び級 (skipping a grade). 上の級に進む (to move up to a higher grade).

"As this kanji is used to describe black (or ""crimson"") English tea, think of the craftsmanship involved in the production of the tea, from the tea leaves, to the paper bag, right down to the thread you use to dangle it in the cup."	This artisan <em>crafted</em> the finest <em>thread</em> you could imagine. So fine it was that it had to be tinted in the deepest red (crimson) otherwise you wouldn't see it.	A person's first piece of <em>thread</em> <em>craft</em> is often stained<strong> crimson</strong> due to bleeding from the needle wounds sustained in the process.		
納		settlement	Thread . . . inside.		10	1456	1356	36	ノウ、ナッ、ナ、ナン、トウ	おさ.める、-おさ.める、おさ.まる	Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? One theory about the name says it was used as a form of payment to <strong>settle</strong> debts to your lord. Picture the little styrofoam natto package and when you open it up it's full of <em>threads</em> of sticky, stringy goo <em>inside</em>… 納金 [のうきん] payment <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E7%B4%8D%E5%93%81"">、納品</a> [のうひん] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E7%B4%8D%E5%BE%97"">、納得</a> [なっとく] <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%81%E7%B4%8D%E3%82%81%E3%82%8B"">、納める</a> [おさめる]."		
紡		spinning	For the kanji that means the <i>spinning</i> of <i>thread</i> and other fibers we have the elements: <i>thread</i> . . . <i>compass</i>.		10	1457	1357	36	ボウ	つむ.ぐ	<em>Spiderman</em> can <strong>spin</strong> his webs in any <em>direction</em>.	"""You keep me<strong> spinning</strong> right round, baby right round, like a <em>compass</em> baby."" <em>Spidey</em> is making a retro 80s music video,<strong> spinning</strong> right round on his giant <em>compass</em>, singing his favourite song."	"The easiest way to spin some <em>threads</em> is to hook them up to a <em>compass</em> and take them to the North Pole. The compass will spin like crazy and the threads will spin with it. I confuse this with <a href=""../v4/1967.html"">swing</a> (#1967 揺)."	Spiderman is<strong> spinning</strong> around, shooting webs in every direction.	A normal spider <strong>spins</strong> a web into a specific pattern in order to catch prey. <em>Spiderman</em>, however, uses his web primarily as a mode of transportation, shooting it in all <em>directions</em>.

Six men, six women, and six <em>threads</em>. The threads are mixed together and thrown into a bowl. Each person takes one end of a <em>thread</em>, thereby matching that person up with a random partner. Obviously, the couples try to <em>seduce</em> each other.	The prostitute wore little more than a few <em>threads</em>, quickly <em>seduced</em> her client and left without even <strong>introduc</strong>ing herself.		
経		sūtra	Thread . . . spool.		11	1460	1360	36	ケイ、キョウ	へ.る、た.つ、たていと、はか.る、のり	The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a <em>spool</em> that is holding the <em>threads</em> together.	"Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) <em>Toilet paper/roll</em> usually comes on a <em>spool</em>. (2) <em>Toilet paper</em> is used to clean the <em>soil</em> off your <em>crotch</em>. Story: <em>Spiderman</em> (= thread) has a roll of <em>toilet paper</em> with the words of a<strong> sutra</strong> printed on each sheet (picture <em>Spiderman</em> saying the<strong> sutra</strong> as he tears sheets off the <em>toilet roll</em>). Spool also appears in <a href=""../v4/715.html"">stalk</a> (#715 茎), <a href=""../v4/716.html"">suspicious</a> (#716 怪), <a href=""../v4/717.html"">lightly</a> (#717 軽), <a href=""../v4/882.html"">diameter</a> (#882 径)."	<em>Spiderman</em> is intriqued by some of the positions of the karma<strong> sutra</strong>, but reluctant to take part in an<strong> sutra</strong> orgy as he'd have to reveal his <em>soiled underwear</em>.	A<strong> sutra</strong> reads: time <strong>flows</strong> as a <em>thread</em> constantly <strong>flowing</strong> out of a <em>spool</em>.	<em>Spider-Man's</em> kama<strong> sutra</strong> technique is so crazy that he always needs a whole roll of <em>toilet paper</em> to clean up afterward. Mary Jane is always soaked in a sticky white substance, and it isn't Spidey's webs.

約		promise	"Consider for a moment the etymology of the word ""<b>promise</b>"" in order to notice its roots in the activity of putting one thing (e.g., one's word of honor) in place of another (e.g., the fulfillment of a task). For as it turns out, this character also means ""to abridge, economize, and abbreviate"" - all activities that involve putting one thing in place of another. With that in mind, we may now work with the elements: <i>thread</i> . . . <i>ladle</i>."		9	1462	1362	36	ヤク		Anytime <em>Spiderman</em> breaks a<strong> promise</strong>, Aunt Mae hits him one over with her <em>ladle</em>.	"Spiderman<strong> promise</strong>d to get Aunt Mae's ladle back. He started to do a blood oath by spilling drops of blood but Aunt Mae stopped him and bound up the wound. ""It's only a ladle Peter""."	Thread + bound + drop of blood. Blood oath is a<strong> promise</strong>, where a drop of blood turns into a binding thread.	<em>Spiderman</em> broke his<strong> promise</strong> to be home in time for dinner. When he came in late, Aunt Mae beat him viciously with a <em>ladle</em>. She just kept hitting, and hitting, and hitting until he lost consciousness, and even then she still kept <em>ladling</em> his pulpy carcass for like fifteen more minutes. Don't break<strong> promise</strong>s to Aunt Mae.	<em>Spiderman</em> and Spiderwoman share a <em>drop</em> of blood (the blood handshake thing, like in Natural Born Killers) to <em>bind</em> their<strong> promise</strong> that they'll always fight crime. Ladle was too hard. <em>Spiderman</em><strong> PROMISE</strong>S to get MJs cooking <em>ladle</em> back.

The threads of the brain (neurons) are<strong> dainty</strong>.		
累		accumulate	<i>Rice field</i> . . . <i>threads</i>. Make use of the position of the elements to distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame.		11	1464	1364	36	ルイ		(dingomick) <em>Venom</em> is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to<strong> accumulate</strong> as many <em>brains</em> as he can, snatching them out of people's heads and storing them on top of his own, till there's just one massive <em>brain</em> on top of his head!	When you<strong> accumulate</strong> knowledge in your <em>brain</em>, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of <em>thread</em> tangled together. The more knowledge you<strong> accumulate</strong> the more <em>threads</em> you throw into the mix!!	Like a jellyfish, a floating BRAIN<strong> accumulate</strong>s THREADS beneath it– a weird collection.	<em>Venom</em> is accumulating <em>brains</em> (much like Sylar in Heroes).	I found billyclyde's a bit abstract so I picture a <em>brain</em> rolling about the floor, accumulating <em>threads</em> scattered around and getting bigger as it rolls. (this is easy if you've played Katamari).		
索		cord	<i>Chapel</i> (see frame 930) . . . <i>thread</i>.		10	1465	1365	36	サク		Spiderman has been captured and given the ultimate torture: they forced a crown of needles on his head and attached it to an electrical<strong> cord</strong>, which they are about to plug into an outlet…	(modified akrodha's great story) VENOM has been captured by scientists and is being experimented on: they forced a CROWN of NEEDLES on his head and attached it to multiple electrical<strong> cord</strong>s, which are connected to a big machine.	An electrical<strong> cord</strong> has two (or three) prongs - <em>needles</em> - sticking out of it, a housing for the prongs that can be thought of as a <em>crown</em>, and the long <em>thread</em>-like wire leading to the appliance.	That's <em>venom</em> for you! Since he can't make webs like spiderman can, he's now desperately hanging from a thin<strong> cord</strong> that he bought cheap in Sweden. It cost him only <em>10 Kroner</em> (Crowns). I'm sure the<strong> cord</strong> will rip in a second or two. (Thanks desmidus).	A<strong> cord</strong> is made of <em>ten</em> <em>threads</em> <em>belted</em> together.		
総		general	This kanji, meaning universal or widespread, is composed of three elements: <i>thread</i> . . . <i>public</i> . . . <i>heart</i>.		14	1466	1366	36	ソウ	す.べて、すべ.て、ふさ	<em>Spiderman</em> could not achieve<strong> general</strong> acceptance by the media even after winning the <em>public</em>'s <em>heart</em>.	"<strong>NOTE</strong>: This kanji stands for [<strong>Total</strong>, All, whole, gross]. The Kanji commonly used for ""In<strong> general</strong>"" will appear later as <a href=""../v4/1871.html"">carrier</a> (#1871 般)."	To win<strong> GENERAL</strong> approval THREAD your way into the PUBLIC's HEART.	In <strong>general</strong>, spidey is accepted in the public's heart (see Spiderman1,2 and 3) Its only Jameson of the daily bugle that hates him (and a bunch of super villains). But in <strong>general</strong>, Spidey is in the public's heart, and the public is in Spidey's heart.	<strong>General</strong> or universal refers to the common thread running through the public's heart.		
綿		cotton	Thread . . . white . . . towels.		14	1467	1367	36	メン	わた	<em>Spiderman</em>'s polyethylene suit starts to ride up after a while, so he always looks forward to the <em>white</em><strong> cotton</strong> <em>towels</em> he wears while lounging around his apartment.	<strong>Cotton</strong> is the preferred <em>thread</em> for making <em>white</em> <em>towels</em>.	Spiderman has a dark secret - he has stolen all the white<strong> cotton</strong> towels from every hotel he has ever been in.	Thread customarily used to make white towels with.	"Compare with <a href=""../v4/411.html"">brocade</a> (#411 錦). If the <em>white</em> <em>towel</em> is made of plain <em>threads</em> with no golden decoration, then it's just a plain towel. But at least it's a good fluffy<strong> cotton</strong> towel, not one of those cheap synthetic fibers. Remember: if it can't be golden (as in <a href=""../v4/411.html"">brocade</a> (#411 錦)), at least make it<strong> cotton</strong>."		
絹		silk	Thread . . . mouth . . . flesh.		13	1468	1368	36	ケン	きぬ	Spider-man loves to run his mouth all over Mary Jane's<strong> silk</strong>y flesh.	Spiderman has little squares in the flesh of his wrists that the<strong> silk</strong> webbing comes out of.	[silk] <strong>Silk</strong> is a <em>thread</em> that a larvae produces from its <em>mouth</em> to involve its <em>body</em>.	<em>Spider-Man</em> barged in on our honey<em>moon</em>, stuffing our<strong> silk</strong> sheets in his <em>mouth</em>–apparently he was out of webbing and needed to refuel.	Spider-man loves to use his <em>mouth</em> to remove Mary Jane's<strong> silk</strong> stockings and kiss the <em>flesh</em> underneath. (thanks Zazen666!).		
繰		winding	Thread . . . goods . . . tree.		19	1469	1369	36	ソウ	く.る	After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen<strong> winding</strong> his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.	"Tip: <em>goods</em> + <em>wood/tree</em> : This combination appears 4 times. I suggest calling it ""<em>furniture</em>"" (a common type of <em>wooden goods</em>). REF: <a href=""../v4/215.html"">parch</a> (#215 燥) , <a href=""../v4/671.html"">maneuver</a> (#671 操), <em>winding</em> (FRAME 1369), <a href=""../v4/2035.html"">seaweed</a> (#2035 藻). Story: You are<strong> winding</strong> up your new <em>furniture</em> using a <em>thread</em> to get it through the window of your high-rise apartment."	<em>Spiderman</em> often accidentally breaks his <em>furniture</em> (thanks Katsuo!) with his spider strength, so he is often seen <strong>winding</strong> his webbing around various pieces to repair them.	Primary meaning of this kanji has to do with turning pages/leafing through a book so I focus on that meaning. Also taking the furniture suggestion from Katsuo about the primitive on the right and making it even more concrete by having it refer to IKEA. Here I see Spiderman reading an IKEA catalogue, he's lost in thought leafing through the pages.	<strong>Winding</strong> <em>thread</em> around <em>wood</em>en <em>goods</em> to ready them for safe transport.

緑		green	Thread . . . broom . . . rice grains.		14	1471	1371	36	リョク、ロク	みどり	<em>Spiderman's</em> nemesis the<strong> Green</strong> Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a <em>broom</em> and is throwing <em>grains of rice</em> instead of bombs. 縁		affinity	Thread . . . broom . . . sow.		15	1472	1372	36	エン、ネン	ふち、ふちど.る、ゆかり、よすが、へり、えにし	There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. The pig felt such<strong> affinity</strong> for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.	Spiderman has no<strong> affinity</strong> for a broom hence his house is a pig sty.	I hate doing this, since the Simpson's Movie was recent. But think of the<strong> AFFINITY</strong> Homer had with the PIG that was to be killed. The<strong> AFFINITY</strong> first had SPIDER PIG (Spiderpig, spiderpig, does whatever a spiderpig does). Then Homer dressed the PIG up with a BROOM and glasses making him Harry PORKER. Homer had more<strong> AFFINITY</strong> for that PIG than his family, hence hilarity ensues.	There is an<strong> affinity</strong> between the THREADS of a BROOM and a SOW's hair.	Spiderman, though genuinely a good person, had an<strong> affinity</strong> for beating <em>pigs</em> with a <em>broom</em>. (I know it's random, but the mental picture is both vivid and hilarious).		
網		netting	Thread . . . glass canopy . . . animal horns . . . perish.		14	1473	1373	36	モウ	あみ	<em>Spiderman</em> traps The Rhino under the <em>hood</em> of his famous<strong> netting</strong>, where even Rhino's <em>horns</em> can not break free, in fact if the<strong> netting</strong> did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even <em>perish</em> in there.	You use a 糸 to make a net shaped like a hood. A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.	Sadly, sometimes <strong>nettings</strong> have a <em>thread</em> so strong, the net gets caught like a <em>hood</em> on an animal's <em>horns</em>, and stays there until the poor thing <em>perishes</em>.	Spider-woman dies of a mosquito bite. They replace the (ineffectual)<strong> netting</strong> over her bed with a glass canopy, and put a viking's horned helmet on her dead head, so she can lie in state with dignity.	<em>Spiderman</em> caught The Rhino, under a <em>glass canopy</em>; instead of his usual webbed<strong> netting</strong>. But unfortunately, the <em>horned one perished</em>: he couldn't breathe. 緊		tense	Slave . . . crotch . . . thread.		15	1474	1374	36	キン		Whenever <em>Venom</em> is<strong> tense</strong>, he loses control of his sex drive and becomes a <em>slave</em> to his <em>crotch</em>.	You'd be<strong> tense</strong> too if you were a <em>slave</em> and your owner removed the <em>threads</em> covering your <em>crotch</em>.	"TIP: This is the first kanji in ""kinbaku"" ( 緊縛 ), the art of Japanese rope bondage. STORY: The <em>slave's</em> <em>crotch</em> is tied up with rope (<em>thread</em>) to heighten the sado-erotic <strong>tension</strong>… 緊張 [きんちょう]."	"The crotch-slave from ""intelligent"" this time has hidden some thread as part of her elaborate plan to escape from her owner. Now she's being searched, and is afraid they'll find where she hid the thread – she is quite<strong> tense</strong>, and it shows."	<em>Spiderman</em> is <em>slave</em> to his <em>crotch</em>, literally, because of that leotard he uses. If he get's just a little too excited in public, the situation would become very<strong> tense</strong> (if you know what I mean).

"If you use <strong>Venom</strong> for the lower primitive, this kanji is a piece of cake. So,<strong> PURPLE</strong> is the color of Agony, the <strong>female</strong> offspring of <strong>Venom</strong> <a href=""http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_hmOfolKlLFI/SN1l3LqagTI/AAAAAAAAA1Q/7tEpxy-Bfu0/s1600-h/agony.jpg"">http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_hmOfolKlLFI/SN1l3LqagTI/AAAAAAAAA1Q/7tEpxy-Bfu0/s1600-h/agony.jpg</a> <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agony_%28comics%29"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agony_%28comics%29</a>."	<em>Stop</em> <em>spooning</em> <em>spiderpig</em>. 縛		truss	Threads . . . acupuncturist.		16	1476	1376	36	バク	しば.る	<em>Spidey</em> received good word that the <em>acupuncturist</em> working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! <em>Spidey</em> headed over to the clinic, and<strong> truss</strong>ed the <em>acupuncturist</em> Doc Oc up using the maniac's own metal limbs! Ok, I already finished RtK, I'm coming back to warn you about this one - the right primitive is <em>acupuncturist</em>, not <em>specialty</em>. Trust me, mixing these up will mess you up later.	Spiderman's specialty:<strong> truss</strong>ing up villains of course.	Spiderman gets <strong>truss</strong>ed/binded, tied by the new villain: the acupuncturist. 縄		straw rope	Thread . . . eels.		15	1477	1377	36	ジョウ	なわ、ただ.す	"The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a<strong> straw rope</strong>, but all that's left of the rope are some torn <em>threads</em>, and the <em>unbound tortoise</em> is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not ""eels"". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in <a href=""../v4/537.html"">waterfall</a> (#537 滝) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as ""eels"". It is much better to call the right half of this character an ""unbound tortoise"".)."	When <em>Spiderman</em> fights the giant <em>tortoise</em>, he grabs a<strong> straw rope</strong> from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the <em>tortoise</em> quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the <em>tortoise</em>).	A<strong> straw rope</strong> is made from <em>threads</em> and has about the thickness of an <em>eel</em>.	Our friendly neighborhood <em>Spider-Man</em> takes off the<strong> straw rope</strong> that was <em>binding</em> the <em>tortoise</em>.	<em>Spiderman's</em> threads conduct electricity a bit too well, so when he has to bind up <em>electric eels</em>, he just buys some<strong> straw rope</strong> at the post office and shoots it out of his arm. Ouch, that stuff sure leaves a rash.		
幼		infancy	Cocoon . . . muscle.		5	1478	1378	36	ヨウ	おさな.い	In its<strong> infancy</strong>, a butterfly is protected by a <em>cocoon</em>, as it doesn't yet have any <em>power</em> of its own.	During their<strong> infancy</strong>, children are often wrapped up tight like a <em>cocoon</em> (i.e. in those Snugli carriers) and supported by the <em>muscle</em> of their parents.	During<strong> INFANCY</strong> the moth in its COCOON gains its POWER.	In<strong> infancy</strong> it is the struggle to break out of the <em>cocoon</em> that develops a butterfly's <em>muscles</em>.	Your<strong> infancy</strong> starts when you have enough <em>power</em> to break your <em>cocoon</em> (amniotic sac).		
後		behind	Line . . . cocoon . . . walking legs.		9	1479	1379	36	ゴ、コウ	のち、うし.ろ、うしろ、あと、おく.れる	Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self<strong> behind</strong>.	<strong>after</strong> a grub <em>goes</em> through the <em>cocoon</em> stage, it leaves its <em>walking legs</em><strong> behind</strong> for a life of flight.	Think of a <em>column</em> of ants moving to a new nest. The soldiers are in front. The workers are<strong> behind</strong> carrying the <em>cocoons</em> on their long <em>walking legs</em>. 幽		faint	<i>Two cocoons</i> . . . <i>mountain</i>. Observe how the two vertical strokes of <i>the mountain</i> are extended upwards to serve as a kind of enclosure.		9	1480	1380	36	ユウ、ヨウ	ふか.い、かす.か、くら.い、しろ.い	The villagers haven't the <strong>faint</strong>est idea that giant <em>coccoons</em> resting in the <em>mountain</em> are soon to hatch.	Frodo and Sam<strong> faint</strong>ed in the mountains and the spider wrapped them in cacoons.	Hint: this is<strong> faint</strong> as in dim, weak or indistinct, not the verb.	<strong>Two cocoons</strong> set out to climb a <strong>mountain</strong>, but they get separated. They shout to each other, but their voices, blocked by the mountain, are so <em>faint</em>. Notice that the first stroke of <strong>mountain</strong> is first, followed by the 2 <strong>cocoons</strong>, then the conclusion of <strong>mountain</strong>.	Two people wrapped in their sleeping bags like <em>cocoons</em> are <strong>seclude</strong>d in the <em>mountains</em> and can't hear the<strong> faint</strong>est sound.		
幾		how many	<i>Two cocoons</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>fiesta</i>.	* As a primitive, this kanji will mean an <i>abacus</i>, the bead-instrument used in the Orient to calculate <i>how many</i>.	12	1481	1381	36	キ	いく-、いく.つ、いく.ら	At the Mexican <em>fiesta</em>, there is a <em>coccoon</em> eating competition.<strong> How many</strong> <em>coccoons</em> can one <em>person</em> eat? No one has managed more than two before giving up…	<strong>How many</strong> went to the party? Two aliens and one person (I feel sorry for that person).	It is a little awkward when you are at a <em>fiesta</em> and the host serves some rare delicacy, like moth <em>cocoons</em>, the guests must decide <strong>how many</strong> it would be polite to eat. You do the math in your head and it comes out to two <em>cocoons</em> per <em>person</em>. This is why the horizontal line is a fraction bar with two <em>cocoons</em> on the top, and one <em>person</em> the bottom.	There's a <em>cocoon</em> on each side of the entrance to the <em>fiesta</em> that can detect when a person crosses the threshold. They are the two <em>cocoon</em>s that determine <strong>how many</strong> people are attending the fiesta. So<strong> how many</strong> were there? The answer is displayed on an <strong>abacus</strong>.	At the Mexican <em>fiesta</em>, there is a <em>cocoon</em> eating competition.<strong> How many</strong> <em>cocoons</em> can <em>Mr.T</em> eat? Mr.T currently holds the record at two. Took misha's and edited for Mr. T purposes.		
機		mechanism	Tree . . . abacus.		16	1482	1382	36	キ	はた	An <em>abacus</em> is a<strong> mechanism</strong> made of <em>wood</em> used to calculate <em>how many</em> 'anythings'.	"To avoid confusing with <a href=""../v4/677.html"">contraption</a> (#677 械), focus on the ""ism"" of<strong> mechanism</strong>. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish;<strong> mechanism</strong> here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable <em>tree</em> (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching <em>abacus</em> that smashes enemies between its giant beads."	[synewave]An <em>abacus</em> is a<strong> mechanism</strong> made of <em>wood</em> used to calculate <em>how many</em> 'anythings'. Important geek note: This is used as the counter for your remaining lives in video games, as it also means chance/opportunity.	Tolkien's ents are actually ancient robot-like<strong> mechanism</strong>s made of <em>wood</em>. Picture a pilot sitting inside, furiously sliding away at an <em>abacus</em> to steer the ent.	Uh-oh. You accidentally hit the self-destruct<strong> mechanism</strong> on your <em>abacus</em>. You hide behind a <em>tree</em> and wait for the explosion.		
畿		capital suburbs	Two cocoons . . . field . . . fiesta.		15	1483	2887	36	キ	みやこ	People aside, I wonder <em>how many rice fields</em> there are in the<strong> capital suburbs</strong>.	<em>How many brains</em> does it take to run the<strong> capital suburbs</strong>?	This keyword refers to Japan's Kinki Region, a historic name for present-day Kansai. 近畿 きんき Just <em>how many rice fields</em> are in the<strong> capital suburbs</strong>? (The kinky (Kinki) <em>people</em> are hidden in the fields so you can't see them).	The<strong> capital suburbs</strong> were the five areas that around the kyoto nara osaka area that were under direct imperial rule (not ruled by the feudal lords) (the capital being first nara then kyoto) in this time the most important thing was how many rice fields you had. and as the area grew in the large cities that emporer had less and less rice fields (the latter half is not true).	"While exploring the capital you come across a <em>cocoon fiesta</em> being held in a <em>paddyfield</em>. ""There's no space for this kind of thing in the city centre, we must be in the<strong> capital suburbs</strong>,"" you think."		
玄		mysterious	Top hat . . . cocoon.		5	1484	1383	36	ゲン		What could be more<strong> mysterious</strong> than a <em>cocoon</em> in a <em>top hat</em> trying to sneak in…? (Pimitive: <em>GANDALF</em>).	The invisible man in his <em>top hat</em> and <em>cocoon</em> of white bandages is the most<strong> mysterious</strong> man in the world.	As romanrozhok said, this kanji has little to do with <strong>mysterious</strong>. It has the meanings [dark, abstruse, calm] (in Spanish, [moreno and recóndito]). As for the story, the union of a <em>hat</em> and a <em>coccoon</em> is obviously a fakir <em>turban</em>. India was maybe an <strong>abstruse</strong> place far away from China. Visualize a <strong>mysterious</strong>, <strong>dark-skinned</strong> fakir with a <em>turban</em> (in <strong>calming</strong> meditation) and the kanji is yours!	"This kanji does not really mean ""mysterious."" In fact, out of all the words this kanji in used in, only one, an uncommon word, has that meaning faintly. If you look the kanji up, you will see that it is used in: 玄関 【げんかん】 (n) entranceway; entry hall; (P)–and– 玄米 【げんまい】 (n) unpolished rice; unmilled rice; brown rice; (P) (as well as other ""unpolished grains."" (EDIT: I removed my story and am using DrJones's story)."	Even more<strong> mysterious</strong> than this huge alien <em>cocoon</em> is the fact that it is wearing a <em>top hat</em>.		
畜		livestock	Mysterious . . . rice field.		10	1485	1384	36	チク		This <em>mysterious</em> <em>rice field</em> grows not only rice, but<strong> livestock</strong> too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!	The <strong>livestock</strong> are disappearing! I've placed <em>Gandalf</em> over the <em>rice field</em> to protect them.	<strong>Livestock</strong> has been mysteriously disappearing from the field. Aliens?	Top part, 玄 , means <em>dark color</em>. There's a certain <em>dark-colored</em> thing that<strong> livestock</strong> produce that farmers traditionally used as fertilizer on their <em>rice fields</em>. What could this <em>mysterious</em> thing be? Mmh…	In Japan there is no Bermuda triangle but there is a <em>mysterious rice field</em> where<strong> livestock</strong> disappear.		
蓄		amass	Flowers . . . livestock.		13	1486	1385	36	チク	たくわ.える	One sneaky farmer wanted to<strong> amass</strong> a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and<strong> amass</strong>ed in his field.	It may seem illogical, but the fact is, you need to plant <strong>flowers</strong> if your aim is to <em>amass</em> <strong>livestock</strong>.	"To keep the difference between<strong> amass</strong> and <a href=""../v4/559.html"">gather</a> (#559 集) and <a href=""../v4/1364.html"">accumulate</a> (#1364 累), I emphasize the MASS. To<strong> amass</strong> MASSIVE <em>livestock</em>, always feed them <em>flowers</em>. They'll get nice and plump. 蓄え = たくわえ = store; reserve; stock; savings."	Farmers in Japan grow flowers in the summer and rear livestock in the winter, in this way they<strong> amass</strong> a fortune.	I<strong> amass</strong>ed so many flowers from my many boyfriends, I had to feed them to my livestock to get rid of them.		
弦		bowstring	Bow . . . mysterious.		8	1487	1386	36	ゲン	つる	A magic <em>bow</em> that only <em>Gandalf</em> can yield: there is no<strong> bowstring</strong> on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows.	A bow with a mysterious invisible<strong> bowstring</strong>.	TIP: This is used for string instruments, <strong>NOT</strong> bow & arrow. STORY: The greatest master of the violin <em>bow</em> and<strong> bowstring</strong> was the <em>mysterious</em> Paganini… 弦 [つる].	It was always (and still is) a bit <em>mysterious</em> to me just what type of<strong> bowstring</strong> was supposed to be used on Chewbacca's laser bolt cross<em>bow</em>.	Legolas asks Gandalf to conjure him a new<strong> bowstring</strong>.		
擁		hug	<i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>mysterious</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. Note that the <i>top hat</i> is extended across both elements, though it belongs only to the <i>cocoon</i>. This means that you may either use <i>mysterious</i> - as we did here - or take the three elements separately.		16	1488	1387	36	ヨウ		A <em>mysterious</em> <em>turkey</em> with human <em>finger</em>s wants to<strong> hug</strong> me… I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!	Imagine Gandalf<strong> hug</strong>ging a turkey….ouch! It bit off his finger!	Ok sweetheart, I want you to point your finger at the mysterious turkey who<strong> hug</strong>ged you inappropriately.	As you peer even more closely at the <em>top-hat</em> clad <em>cocoon</em> from frame 1383 you realise that it's actually ET in disguise, back on earth for Christmas (carrying a <em>turkey</em> from his home planet), and holding out a luminescent brown <em>finger</em> towards you. You leap up and give him a<strong> hug</strong>.	You can also break this into primitives as conjecture with mysterious stuck in the middle (I have enough finger and turkey primitives going through my head that I don't need any more…). As you<strong> hug</strong> your loved one who's going off on a mysterious mission, your conjecture is that you won't see them again.		
滋		nourishing	<i>Water</i> . . . double-<i>mysterious</i>. Note the doubling up of the element for <i>top hat</i> in the primitive for <i>mysterious</i> and assign it a special image, as it will come up in the next two frames.		12	1489	1388	36	ジ		Water is doubly mysterious. It's in all our nourishment…and yet, it's really not<strong> nourishing</strong> at all.	Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I've decided to make the right side be <em>Gremlins</em>, those little <em>mysterious</em> creatures that <em>double</em> rapidly. <em>Gremlins</em> find <em>water</em> a little too<strong> nourishing</strong>, as it makes them instantly multiply.	Because <em>Siamese twins</em> need twice as much fluid as their single body produces, the most<strong> nourishing</strong> thing they can have is <em>water</em>.	It’s <em>doubly mysterious</em> how <em>water</em> can be so<strong> nourishing</strong>—it doesn’t seem to have any substance and yet we would die without it.	"Gandalf (<a href=""../v4/1383.html"">mysterious</a> (#1383 玄)) finds<strong> nourishing</strong> water that reflects an evil double Gandalf looming beneath the surface."		
慈		mercy	Double-<i>mysterious</i> . . . <i>heart</i>.		13	1490	1389	36	ジ	いつく.しむ	<strong>Mercy</strong> comes from the doubly mysterious heart of God.	Two gremlins are atop a victim, tearing out his heart while he begs for<strong> mercy</strong>.	Here we see the DOUBLE-MYSTERIOUS Siamese twins again, at the<strong> MERCY</strong> of the machines that pump blood through their veins, since the single HEART they share won't do the job…	"Gandalf (<a href=""../v4/1383.html"">mysterious</a> (#1383 玄)) shows no<strong> mercy</strong> and rips his evil double's heart out. Instead of destroying evil, his malevolent act has merged the two of them into the grey Gandalf."	<strong>Mercy</strong> is a <em>doubly mysterious</em> turn of the <em>heart</em>. On the one hand, everybody wants it, but on the other hardly anybody gives it.		
磁		magnet	<i>Stone</i> . . . double-<i>mysterious</i>.		14	1491	1390	36	ジ		A<strong> magnet</strong> is a <em>rock</em> with two sides; one that <em>mysteriously</em> pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops' story).	STONE + BAND OF NIGGERS: Band of niggers throwing rocks. Now that's a police<strong> magnet</strong>.	The gremlins have this mysterious rock the use to attract yet more gremlins.	I found some <em>stones</em> on the <em>siamese twins</em>. Turns out the <em>stones</em> were <strong>magnetic</strong>, and they weren't <em>siamese twins</em> at all!	In the old days, people didn't know what<strong> magnet</strong>s were. They just thought of them as <em>stones</em> that were <em>double mysterious</em>.		
系		lineage	The single stroke added to the beginning of the primitive for <i>thread</i> gives the image of threads woven into a single cord. Hence the meaning, <b>lineage</b>.	* As a primitive, we shall give this kanji the meaning of <i>yarn</i>, as the uniting of many threads into a single strand is most obvious with <i>yarn</i>.	7	1492	1391	36	ケイ		(Primitive: <em>DNA</em>, a drop of looong spiraled thread that is the key to your <strong>lineage</strong>).	Spiderman's<strong> lineage</strong> (who his family is etc…) can be found in his DNA in a drop of blood. The villain that gets blood of Spidey will be able to find out who is family and<strong> lineage</strong> is. be carfefull spidey…	A single <em>drop</em> of your blood holds the proof of the unbroken <em>thread</em> of your<strong> lineage</strong>.	One <em>drop</em> of <em>Venom</em>'s blood created a<strong> lineage</strong> of evil spiders.	Your<strong> lineage</strong> can be found in your DNA, a loooong molecular <em>thread</em> that can pulled from a single <em>drop</em> of blood.		
係		person in charge	Person . . . yarn.		9	1493	1392	36	ケイ	かか.る、かかり、-がかり、かか.わる	<em>Mister T</em> gets a <em>DNA</em> test, and discovers that he was meant to be the<strong> person in charge</strong> after all.	The<strong> person in charge</strong> usually must come from a long standing <em>lineage</em> of persons in charge.	<em>Mr. T</em> is the <strong>person in charge</strong> of the <em>DNA</em> research center.	<em>chuck norris</em> is always the<strong> person in charge</strong>! it's written in his <em>DNA</em>!	We think we have control over our own lives. But our DNA is the<strong> PERSON IN CHARGE</strong>. Our DNA controls our looks, and basically who we are.		
孫		grandchild	Child . . . yarn.		10	1494	1393	36	ソン	まご	Your <strong>grandchild</strong> is the child of your <em>DNA</em>.	Your <em>child</em> continues the family <em>lineage</em> by passing on your <em>DNA</em>, giving you a<strong> grandchild</strong>.	<strong>Grandchild</strong> is a kid of your directe lineage.	I didn't find out that child was my<strong> grandchild</strong> until I got a DNA test… I didn't even know I had a child until I got a DNA test for that matter!	"The child took a DNA test and found out that he was his own<strong> grandchild</strong>. ""What the fuck?! This doesn't even make sense with time travel involved. How did you figure this out with a DNA test anyway?""."		
懸		suspend	Prefecture . . . yarn . . . heart.		20	1495	1394	36	ケン、ケ	か.ける、か.かる	The <em>prefecture</em> has <strong>suspend</strong>ed all <em>DNA</em> research for <em>heart</em> disease because of corruption. All involved will be <strong>suspend</strong>ed by their wrists.	In a very racist <em>prefecture</em> of Japan, they screen everyone's <em>DNA</em>. If they find out you are of a different <em>lineage</em>, they rip out your <em>heart</em> and<strong> suspend</strong> it in the Hall of Shame.	Hint:<strong> suspend</strong> as in hang up.	The prefecture has<strong> suspend</strong>ed all research into inheritable (lineage) heart disease.	<strong>Suspend</strong>ed in the middle of the <em>prefecture</em> is a chart of the area's <em>lineage</em>. But, since this is Japan, it has to be cute, so the chart has been covered with little <em>hearts</em>.		
遜		modest	Grandchild . . . road.		13	1496	2422	36	ソン	したが.う、へりくだ.る、ゆず.る	My parents aren't at all<strong> modest</strong> about their <em>grandchildren</em>, at every opportunity they take them on the <em>road</em> showing them off to their friends!	"He wasn't at all<strong> modest</strong> when telling us about his <em>grandchildren</em> - ""They're all on the <em>road</em> to success"" he said."	"Swift wrote in ""A<strong> Modest</strong> Proposal"" that Ireland should solve its economic problems by collecting the nation's <em>grandchildren</em> from off the <em>streets</em> and eating them."	When grandparents take their grandchildren out on the <em>road</em>, they want them to be<strong> modest</strong> little children.	To instill a<strong> MODEST</strong> mindset in his GRANDCHILD, the grandpa sent him down the ROAD to find work instead of just giving him money.		
却		instead	Gone . . . stamp.		7	1497	1395	37	キャク	かえ.って、しりぞ.く、しりぞ.ける	[instead; on the contrary; rather] <em>Gone</em> is the time for <em>stamps</em> - use e-mail <strong>instead</strong>.	We use e-mail now<strong> instead</strong> of regular mail. My e-mail is <em>gone</em> before you can even put a <em>stamp</em> on your snail mail.	If you tried to attach money to an envelope to pay for postage it would be GONE before it arrived at the post office. That's why we use STAMPS<strong> instead</strong>.	"Having accidentally sent his children a home made sex video<strong> instead</strong> of the family Christmas tape, the man ran to the post office to switch packages. ""I'm sorry sir, but your package was <em>gone</em> moments after you paid for the <em>stamp</em>.""."	Lick soiled-elbow<strong> instead</strong> of stamp ?		
脚		shins	<i>Part of the body</i> . . . <i>instead</i>. This character has more or less the same meaning as that for <i>leg</i> learned back in frame 1372. It can also indicate the part of the legs from the <b>shins</b> down, which explains the choice of the key word.		11	1498	1396	37	キャク、キャ、カク	あし	<strong>Shins</strong> are the <em>part of the body</em> that Japanese traditionally sit on <em>instead</em> of their asses.	<strong>Shins</strong> are the <em>part of the body</em> that one uses <em>instead of</em> one's eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!).	This is one of the key aspects of soccer. At the beginning of every game you start by trying to kick the opponent's<strong> shins</strong>; their <em>flesh, instead</em> of the ball (lets them know you mean business).	In Western countries, women show who want to show a <em>part of their body</em> usually show cleavage. In Japan, they show their<strong> shins</strong> <em>instead</em>.	When you want to say<strong> shins</strong> you can use this kanji for that <em>part of the body</em> <em>instead</em> of the kanji for leg.		
卸		wholesale	The left primitive is a union of <i>a horse</i> and <i>footprint</i>. To the right, the <i>stamp</i>.		9	1499	1397	37	シャ	おろ.す、おろし、おろ.し	Selling<strong> WHOLESALE</strong> HORSES over the internet had to be STOPPED because the cost of STAMPS was too much.	If you need <em>horseshoes</em> (shoes that fit your <em>horse</em>'s <em>footprint</em>), buy them at the<strong> wholesale</strong> shop. They lick and paste <em>stamps</em> in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.	A horse as a<strong> wholesale</strong>r: It <em>stamps</em> every contract with its <em>horse-footprint</em> (horseshoe) since it obviously can't write with its hooves.	"<strong>Wholesale</strong> refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by <em>horses</em> who left steep <em>footprints</em> because of the weight they carried. The<strong> wholesale</strong> goods needed a special <em>stamp</em> to indicate that they were legal for resale. See <a href=""../v4/1398.html"">honorable</a> (#1398 御)."	At Costco you can buy horses<strong> wholesale</strong>. Just remember that they charge you by the size of the <em>horse's footprint</em>, and you need to bring your own <em>stamps</em> for delivery.		
御		honorable	Line . . . wholesale.		12	1500	1398	37	ギョ、ゴ	おん-、お-、み-	An<strong> honorable</strong> man will not try to cut in front of the <em>line</em> at the <em>wholesale</em> stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).	In front of the COLUMNS of the Capitol, the<strong> HONORABLE</strong> congressmen can be bought WHOLESALE.	When buying wholesale the<strong> honorable</strong> thing to do would be to wait in line like everyone else.	"Salesman: ""I'm <em>going</em> to do the<strong> honorable</strong> thing and sell you this item <em>wholesale</em>.""."	"<em>The Flash</em>, being an<strong> honorable</strong> person, zoomed around Costco <em>wholesale</em> helping everyone quickly find everything. (They honored him by using 御 (ご) a lot in their speech. <a href=""midori://search?text=%E5%BE%A1%E3%82%86%E3%81%A3%E3%81%8F%E3%82%8A%E3%80%81%E5%BE%A1%E3%82%81%E3%82%93"">御ゆっくり、御めん</a> etc.)."		
服		clothing	<i>Flesh</i> . . . <i>stamp</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>. Note how the <i>stamp</i> is stretched out here.		8	1501	1399	37	フク		It's customary to cover the <em>flesh</em> with<strong> clothing</strong>, but some designs are so outrageous they're not bigger than a <em>stamp</em> that just covers your <em>crotch</em>.	Modern<strong> clothing</strong> shows a lot of <em>flesh</em> – some is practically no more than a <em>postage stamp</em> covering your <em>crotch</em>!	The latest hype in<strong> CLOTHING</strong>, straight from the catwalk - models covered in STAMPS, revealing FLESH only at the CROTCH - hot!!!	On TV, people with no<strong> clothing</strong> on, <em>meat</em> swinging freely, have a black bar <em>stamped</em> on their <em>crotch</em>. ======.	The PART OF THE BODY that you must STAMP<strong> clothing</strong> on, no matter what, is your CROTCH!		
命		fate	This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is <b>fated</b> one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: <i>fit</i> . . . <i>stamp</i>. The bottom portion of <i>fit</i> is nudged to the left in order to make room for the <i>stamp</i>.		8	1502	1400	37	メイ、ミョウ	いのち	When you're born, your<strong> fate</strong> is measured, <em>fitted</em>, and <em>stamped</em> onto your soul. Good luck defying it.	It is your<strong> fate</strong> to <em>meet</em> with a <em>mouth</em>, young <em>postage stamp</em>.	It is my<strong> fate</strong>/life to <em>fit</em> <em>stamps</em> together.	Was it<strong> fate</strong> that I was born with an <em>umbrella</em> hair-do, an <em>unibrow</em>, no pupils, and an eye shaped like a <em>stamp</em>?	Your<strong> FATE</strong> is sealed with your first kiss! (meeting of mouths). Just imagine a STAMP between the mouths that are meeting in the kiss…..(thanks CharleyGarret).		
令		orders	Meeting . . . chop-seal.		5	1503	1401	37	レイ		"(re: dingomick) ""These are your<strong> orders</strong>,"" declares the general while passing out documents at the <em>meeting</em>. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims ""Oh wait! I need to certify these<strong> orders</strong>!"" and went around stamping each paper with his personal <em>chop-seal</em>."	"""These are your <strong>orders</strong>,"" declares the general at the <em>meeting</em> as he stamps them with his <em>chop-seal</em>. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one's they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.)."	"Take note that this is written differently from how it looks in the typed font. See: <a href=""http://kakijun.main.jp/"">http://kakijun.main.jp/</a> for the next kanji or <a href=""http://www.saiga-jp.com/cgi-bin/dic.cgi?m=search&amp;sc=0&amp;f=0&amp;j=%E4%BB%A4&amp;g=&amp;e=&amp;s=&amp;rt=0&amp;start=1&amp;sid=1240981825_91321"">http://www.saiga-jp.com/cgi-bin/dic.cgi?m=search&amp;sc=0&amp;f=0&amp;j=%E4%BB%A4&amp;g=&amp;e=&amp;s=&amp;rt=0&amp;start=1&amp;sid=1240981825_91321</a>, for example."	I assigned this the primitive meaning of President Bush, giving crazy<strong> orders</strong> and letting everything go to his head.	At the <em>meeting</em> the chairman put a <em>chop-seal</em> mark on the official<strong> orders</strong>.		
零		zero	Rain . . . orders.		13	1504	1402	37	レイ	ぜろ、こぼ.す、こぼ.れる	The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.	Despite the <em>rain</em>, the <strong>zero</strong> pilot flies on. He has kamikaze <em>orders</em>.	<strong>Zero</strong> from Code Geas gives his <em>orders</em>, and as usual there's a <em>rain</em> of bullets and blood.	When it RAINS out, the ice cream store gets<strong> ZERO</strong> ORDERS.	<em>President Bush</em>'s <strong>zero</strong>-tolerance policies even apply towards the <em>rain</em>. He tries to <em>order</em> it around, as if it'll do any good…		
齢		age	This character is used to express the years of one's <b>age</b>. Its elements: <i>teeth</i> . . . <i>orders</i>.		17	1505	1403	37	レイ	よわ.い、とし	You know you are fast approaching a ripe old<strong> AGE</strong> when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.	"""Pull all their <em>teeth</em> to count their<strong> age</strong>!"" <em>orders</em> the insane Nazi general."	<em>Teeth</em> are an indicator of<strong> age</strong>: 1) None = baby, 2) milk teeth = child, 3) 2nd teeth = adult, 4) False = old. 1~3 are on <em>orders</em> from God, 4 is on <em>orders</em> from your dentist.	'What is your<strong> age</strong> Mr President' Bush opens his mouth and starts counting his teeth. (You role your eyes and expect him to say 32) '62' Bush says. Did he pull a joke on you are does he have trouble counting?	At your<strong> age</strong> false TEETH are the ORDER of the day.		
冷		cool	Ice . . . orders.		7	1506	1404	37	レイ	つめ.たい、ひ.える、ひ.や、ひ.ややか、ひ.やす、ひ.やかす、さ.める、さ.ます	To keep your water<strong> cool</strong>, just <em>order</em> some <em>ice</em>.	The Japanese boss gives an <em>order</em> at the meeting: eat <em>ice</em> to stay<strong> cool</strong> (since they won't be running the air conditioning anymore).	"<em>President Bush</em>'s drink isn't<strong> cool</strong> enough, and the Whitehouse is out of <em>ice</em>. ""Time to invade Alaska!"", <em>President Bush</em> says. ""But sir… we already own it!""."	"My superior says to me, ""You need to<strong> cool</strong> off, and that's an <em>order</em>!"" Just for emphasis, he dumps a bunch of ice cubes on my head."	Vanilla <em>Ice</em> <em>orders</em> you to stay<strong> cool</strong>.		
領		jurisdiction	Orders . . . head.		14	1507	1405	37	リョウ	えり	Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this<strong> Jurisdiction</strong> there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu).	<em>Orders</em> are given by the <em>head</em> person in any<strong> jurisdiction</strong>.	<em>President Bush</em>, with his swelled <em>head</em>, thinks everything is under his<strong> jurisdiction</strong>.	You're outside of your<strong> jurisdiction</strong>, Johnson! Show me your orders or I'll have your head.	"<strong>Jurisdiction</strong> just makes me think of ""sheriff"". So my story takes place in the<strong> jurisdiction</strong> of some sheriff. The sheriff goes into a bar and calls the waitress. He looks at one of those ""WANTED"" posters, with the portrait of a criminal he's been trying to catch for such a long time. When asked for his <em>orders</em>, still staring intently at the picture, he says : ""I want the <em>head</em> of that guy on a plate, yep, right now!"". The waitress scurried away and brought him just that : <em>orders</em> with a <em>head</em>."		
鈴		small bell	Gold . . . orders.		13	1508	1406	37	レイ、リン	すず	Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.	In high society, people ring a <strong>small</strong> <em>golden</em> <strong>bell</strong> to call their servants and give their <em>orders</em>.	<em>President Bush</em> has a<strong> small bell</strong>. It's made of <em>gold</em>. And everytime he has an <em>order</em> to give, he rings it to summon someone to write it down.	I use a <strong>small golden bell</strong> to issue <strong>orders</strong> to my underlings!	"This kanji refers to the <em>golden</em>,<strong> small bell</strong>s ( 鈴 =すず) that people ring at Shinto Shrines to communicate with gods who give <a href=""../v4/1401.html"">orders</a> (#1401 令) on how to acquire authority and repel evil spirits!"		
勇		courage	Chop-seal . . . man.		9	1509	1407	37	ユウ	いさ.む	I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young <em>man</em> has to show his<strong> courage</strong>. They then receive a <em>chopseal</em> which is a mark of their<strong> courage</strong>.	Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the <em>brain</em>, and you receive the <em>chop seal</em> if you have the <em>power</em> to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered <em>chop seal</em> and vertical placement.	A <strong>MA</strong> （マ） raises a <strong>man</strong> to have<strong> courage</strong>.	After showing sufficient<strong> courage</strong>, the young <em>male</em> gets a マ marked on their forehead with a hanko, to show they are now a マン.	"<strong>Note:</strong> Interesting kanji. It's actually not マ + 男 , but rather, this is an abbreviated form of 甬 + 力 , which gives it more of a meaning of 'path of power' or 'run through with power' or something like that. But if you don't care about the real origins and formation, either way of thinking of it works ^-^. (Source: <a href=""http://tinyurl.com/oj4jes"">http://tinyurl.com/oj4jes</a> + <a href=""http://tinyurl.com/rcmnss"">http://tinyurl.com/rcmnss</a>). <strong>Story:</strong> To have<strong> courage</strong> is to <em>run through</em> (甬) with <em>power</em>. When that happens, a マ becomes a man ( 男 ). (Thx Captal)."		
湧		bubble up	Water . . . courage.		12	1510	2284	37	ユウ、ヨウ、ユ	わ.く	The <em>courageous</em> man who went into the <em>water</em> to save a drowning victim couldn't be seen, except by the air that <strong>bubbled up</strong>.	<strong>Bubble up</strong> the WATER and see who has the COURAGE to jump into it.	[+astrid] A very <em>courageous</em> man dove to the bottom of the <em>water</em> to save someone who had fallen in (and couldn't swim). The whole crowd was watching..30 seconds…a minute…1:20…are they both dead? Suddenly, a huge bubble rose to the surface, with the nearly-drowned victim - he <strong>bubble</strong>d <strong>up</strong> to the surface, in a bubble blown by the <em>courageous</em> man! And then soon after, the hero him self <strong>bubble</strong>d <strong>up</strong>. What a great story!	<em>Water</em> <strong>bubbling up</strong> is like a metaphor for being <em>courageous</em>, having a strength that will<strong> bubble up</strong> in times of need.	Think of the first time someone has to<strong> bubble up</strong> enough <em>courage</em> to take that first step into the <em>water</em>.		
通		traffic	<i>Chop-seal</i> . . . <i>utilize</i> . . . <i>road</i>. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately.		10	1511	1408	37	ツウ、ツ	とお.る、とお.り、-とお.り、-どお.り、とお.す、とお.し、-どお.し、かよ.う	I bounce down the <em>road</em> on my <em>pogo stick</em>, easily getting through the dense<strong> traffic</strong>. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a <em>chop-seal</em> is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could <em>utilize</em> it as a <em>pogo stick</em>). [Edit: <em>pogo stick</em> also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].	Building on gorgon's story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the<strong> traffic</strong>. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge <em>chopseal</em> that they <em>utilize</em> to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the <em>road</em>.	<strong>MA</strong> （マ） drinks one too many <em>screwdriver</em>s and then drives off down the <em>road</em>. Unfortunately, she's so inebriated she causes a<strong> traffic</strong> accident.	They have built a new road downtown. It bypasses all the<strong> traffic</strong>. If your papers have been <em>chop seal</em>ed, you can <em>utilize</em> it.	"Same as Katsuo, but I remember ""utilize"" better as ""philips screw driver"". A long <em>screw driver</em> with a <em>chop-seal</em> on the end makes an interesting <em>pogo stick</em>."		
踊		jump	Wooden leg . . . chop-seal . . . utilize.		14	1512	1409	37	ヨウ	おど.る	The winner of the long<strong> jump</strong> competition was disqualified when they found he used a <em>pogo stick</em> tied to his <em>leg</em> to<strong> jump</strong> further.	"The high <strong>jump</strong>er has his <em>wooden leg</em> fitted with a <em>pogo stick</em>, and can now<strong> jump</strong> even higher. (See my note at <a href=""../v4/1408.html"">traffic</a> (#1408 通) for <em>pogo stick</em>). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword ""jump"" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256's post), <strong>""Dancing""</strong> would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from <a href=""../v4/1774.html"">dance</a> (#1774 舞)). New Story: I was no good at <strong>dancing</strong> due to my <em>wooden leg</em>… until I had it fitted with a <em>pogo stick</em>!"	"This is totally wrong. It doesn't mean ""jump"", it means ""dance""! 踊 <a href=""../v4/1409.html"">jump</a> (#1409 踊) and 曜 <a href=""../v4/1285.html"">leap</a> (#1285 躍) are homonyms, so it is easy to become permanently confused about which one DOES NOT mean ""jump/leap"". Caveat Lector! Note: 舞 <a href=""../v4/1774.html"">dance</a> (#1774 舞) is quite a bit rarer (and not a homonym)."	"Heisig is triiippppiiiin'. This means dance, not<strong> jump</strong>. I named the other ""dance"" kanji ""interpretive dance"" because it is used in all sorts of concepts figuratively related to dance, like stages, fluttering, etc. One of my<em> legs is wooden</em>, the other is a <em>pogo stick</em>. Surprisingly, I'm actually a pretty good at <strong>dancing</strong>."	My wooden leg has a chop-seal at the end, but I have to<strong> jump</strong> so as to utilize it (so the chop-seal hits the right spot from above).		
疑		doubt	Spoon . . . dart . . . chop-seal . . . zoo.		14	1513	1410	37	ギ	うたが.う	(Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. 'Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.' cool 'and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong' ….' please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.' 'lion feeding time is. bla bla' You are having serious<strong> doubt</strong>s about if you still want to go into this zoo.	A very<strong> doubt</strong>ful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special <em>spoon</em> (to feed the animals) and a <em>dart</em> gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then <em>hanko</em> (<em>seal</em>) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the <em>zoo</em>. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I<strong> doubt</strong> they’ll let you in).	Unless they use <em>spoons</em> to feed and <em>darts</em> to subdue the animals, I<strong> doubt</strong> the new <em>zoo</em> will get the WWF <em>seal</em> of approval.	In her spare time ( = ヒマ), Gwen Stefani of 'No<strong> Doubt</strong>' likes to throw <em>darts</em> at the critters in the <em>zoo</em>.	Hmm… I<strong> doubt</strong> he is as busy as he claims to be. Yesterday, he looked like he had plenty of ヒマ (free time) - I saw him shooting darts and going to the zoo!		
擬		mimic	Fingers . . . doubt.		17	1514	1411	37	ギ	まが.い、もど.き	Ask a<strong> MIMIC</strong> to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER.	"I <em>doubt</em> you can<strong> mimic</strong> all these animals with just your <em>fingers</em>: <a href=""http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Raymond"">http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Raymond</a>+Crowe%22+Letterman (shadow puppets – you'll love it!)."	Think of a<strong> mimic</strong> in Dungeons and Dragons, or a doppleganger: If you have <em>doubts</em> as to whether one of your party is genuine or a<strong> mimic</strong>, examine his fingers – they'll lack fingernails or finger prints, and in fact are a poor<strong> mimic</strong>ry of real fingers.	((<em><strong>Mimic</strong>: TREASURE CHEST WITH TEETH</em>)) If you try to loot a<strong> mimic</strong>, I <em>doubt</em> you'll be keeping your <em>fingers</em>.	I <em>doubt</em> that using my <em>fingers</em> to<strong> mimic</strong> rock stars on Guitar Hero will actually make me a good guitarist.

Is there any <em>doubt</em> that <em>ice</em> is<strong> congeal</strong>ed stuff?	I <em>doubt</em> that<strong> congeal</strong> is the right word to use when <em>ice</em> freezes.	When in <em>doubt</em>, <em>ice</em> your wound so the blood will<strong> congeal</strong>.	My blood<strong> congeal</strong>ed in my veins when I heard the cracking noise underfoot. I'd had <em>doubt</em>s about the condition of the <em>ice</em>, but… 凝る (こごる) : to<strong> congeal</strong>, to freeze; 凝らす (こごらす) : to freeze, to<strong> congeal</strong>.

氾		widespread	Water . . . fingerprint.		5	1518	2301	37	ハン	ひろ.がる	It's a<strong> widespread</strong> belief that they cannot find <em>fingerprints</em> on a body that has been deposited in the <em>water</em>.	It's a<strong> widespread</strong> belief that <em>water</em> takes away <em>fingerprints</em>.	To foil 犯人 , the use of <em>watermarks (water + fingerprint)</em> on banknotes is<strong> widespread</strong>. 氾 foils 犯 .	Warning: 氾濫 (flood) seems to be the only compound known to the WWWJDIC, so I propose this as an alternative keyword. The burglars <em>flooded</em> the mansion they broke into with <em>water</em>, thus leaving no <em>fingerprints</em> behind.	<strong>Widespread</strong> panic arises when they discover the WATER has FINGERPRINTS all over it– water thieves! And now,<strong> widespread</strong> water shortages.		
厄		unlucky	Cliff . . . fingerprint.		4	1519	1415	37	ヤク		Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that<strong> unlucky</strong> person was.	<em>Sherlock Holmes</em> is very<strong> unlucky</strong>: he just fell off a <em>cliff</em> while he was looking around for fingerprints.	She sure was <em>unlucky</em>! First of all, her car went off the <strong>cliff</strong>, right? After miraculously surviving the car crash, she managed to climb back up to the very edge of the <strong>cliff</strong>. See her <strong>fingerprints</strong> there? But then she sneezed, lost her grip, and fell to her death.	See a cliff with fingerprints on the edge? That means someone was<strong> unlucky</strong>.	At first the police thought it was murder when that guy fell off the cliff. They couldn't turn up any fingerprints so said it was just<strong> unlucky</strong>.		
危		dangerous	Bound up . . . unlucky.		6	1520	1416	37	キ	あぶ.ない、あや.うい、あや.ぶむ	You're <em>bound up</em> by ropes to an <em>unlucky</em> person. While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it's so<strong> dangerous</strong>.	…. continuing from the previous frame : it was very<strong> dangerous</strong> for the policeman to go down the <em>cliff</em> side to gather <em>fingerprints</em>, so his colleagues <em>bound</em> him with a rope just in case.	Being unlucky is bound to be<strong> dangerous</strong>. 危ない （あぶ）ない.	The <em>unlucky</em> person, the jinx, was <em>bound up</em> as he was considered<strong> dangerous</strong>.

Mailbox - i never get my evening paper but the paperboy says he delivers it. so here i am dustin gfor fingerprints everyevening checking for his new prints . roof and mailbox. superman is the newpostamn so the local people write their<strong> address</strong>es on their rooftops as well as their mailboxes.	Nowadays when you're asked your adress it has a double meaning : it's your HOUSE and your EMAIL BOX. 卵		egg	<i>Receipt</i> . . . <i>stamp</i> . . . and <i>a drop</i> in each side to represent a little smear of <b>egg</b> yoke. The third stroke is drawn slightly higher to close the <b>egg</b> up tightly and keep the yoke inside.		7	1526	1422	37	ラン	たまご	The <em>Easter Bunny</em> dropped an <strong>egg</strong> on my desk and got yolk all over my <em>receipts</em> and <em>stamps</em>. 留		detain	Receipt . . . dagger . . . rice field.		10	1527	1423	37	リュウ、ル	と.める、と.まる、とど.める、とど.まる、るうぶる	Got a <em>receipt</em> for that <em>dagger</em>, son? The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with<strong> DETAIN</strong>. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been<strong> DETAIN</strong>ED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.	"""We're<strong> detain</strong>ing you because we found a receipt on you for this dagger we found in the brain of the man your wife was having an affair with. Care to explain?""."	The 留学生 【りゅうがくせい】went over to Japan on an international exchange program, but on his way from the airport he was <strong>detained</strong> by slave traders! They took his student-visa <em>receipts</em> and kept him under <em>knife point</em> working in the <em>rice fields</em>.	We finally have enough evidence to<strong> detain</strong> the susppect.
