貿		trade	<i>Receipt</i> . . . <i>dagger</i> . . . <i>shells</i>. Though the meanings are related, do not confuse with <i>make a deal</i> (Frame 471) or <i>wholesale</i> (Frame 1499).		12	1529	1424	37	ボウ		There's a buyback program where you can<strong> trade</strong> in your <em>dagger</em> for <em>money</em>. But it's quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the <em>original receipts</em> can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.	The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to<strong> TRADE</strong> the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.	Here is my <em>receipt</em> and here is my <em>dagger</em>. Now give me my <em>money</em> back! Isn't that a fair<strong> trade</strong>?	A fair<strong> trade</strong> means some <em>shells</em> (money) and a <em>receipt</em>. An unfair<strong> trade</strong> (robbery) means a <em>dagger</em> and no <em>receipt</em>.	[trade; exchange] The ancient tools-of-the-<strong>trade</strong> for trading are: <em>receipts</em>, <em>shells</em> and a <em>dagger</em> (to persuade a trading part that refuses to give the first or the second).		
印		stamp	At last we come to the general character meaning <b>stamp</b>. Its elements: <i>staples</i> . . . <i>stamp</i>.		6	1530	1425	37	イン	しるし、-じるし、しる.す	Before sticky backs, they had to staple<strong> stamp</strong>s to letters.	Aaaagh, this old<strong> stamp</strong> doesn't <em>stick</em>! Okay I'll just <em>staple</em> it.	A<strong> stamp</strong> for the 印 velope of course!	If you are sending a letter from IN-dia [this Kanji is used for the country name], staple the<strong> stamp</strong> to your letter, or it might get steamed off and resold. イン 印刷 いんさつ(printing).	Staple and<strong> stamp</strong>, staple and<strong> stamp</strong>: the life of your average Japanese いんかん（ 印鑑 ） wielding office worker.		
臼		mortar	The image here is of <i>back-to-back staples</i>. The <b>mortar</b> referred to in this key word is a stone or wooden basin used for grinding with a pestle.		6	1531	2063	37	キュウ、グ	うす、うすづ.く	I removed all the <em>back to back staples</em> and grinded them in a<strong> mortar</strong> to create metal dust.	The<strong> mortar</strong> bomb exploded, ripping the sun in half.	"臼歯 <a href=""../v4/2063.html"">mortar</a> (#2063 臼)キュウ，うす … Parts: Back to back Staples… Or Cracked 白 (cf. 興味 <a href=""../v4/1426.html"">entertain</a> (#1426 興), 輿入れ <a href=""../v4/2860.html"">palanquin</a> (#2860 輿), 新潟 ) … Note: this is simplified to 旧 in the Joyo characters. Ex: 児 =兒<a href=""../v4/58.html"">newborn babe</a> (#58 児), 稲 =稻<a href=""../v4/910.html"">rice plant</a> (#910 稲), but not in 潟 <a href=""../v4/2039.html"">lagoon</a> (#2039 潟) because it is a traditional place name (Niigata). In non-Joyo, the characters are written both ways: 焔 <a href=""../v4/2546.html"">flames</a> (#2546 焔) is often written 焰. … Note2: Stroke order varies since it is not Joyo."	I went pictograph with this one: a <em>cracked white rice grain</em>–one that has been bashed in a<strong> mortar</strong>.	<strong>Mortar</strong> is that goop, prepared on a board (which this pictographically resembles) that works like DOUBLE-STAPLES to hold bricks together.		
毀		break	Mortar . . . soil . . . missile.		13	1532	2067	37	キ	こぼ.つ、こわ.す、こぼ.れる、こわ.れる、そし.る、やぶ.る	Wow, that baker must really be mad! He's trying to<strong> BREAK</strong> his MORTAR by throwing it to the SOIL. Whoa! Now he's aiming a MISSILE at it!	"To ""<strong>break</strong> the <em>soil</em>"" is to make a symbolic gesture that indicates the beginning of construction. Like when a politician in a hardhat gets a shovel and lifts a piece of dirt. This particular project is behind schedule, so to speed things up, they blow it up with <em>mortar</em> and an air-to-ground <em>missile</em>."	"Drawing inspiration from <a href=""../v4/709.html"">beat</a> (#709 撃) by kinkypete, this kanji shows the rules for a bizarre form of janken (paper, stone, scissors). A mortar can<strong> break</strong> soil (grinding it to dust). Soil can<strong> break</strong> a missile (burying it - causing it to eventually rust away). And a missile can<strong> break</strong> a mortar."	You'll<strong> break</strong> everything down to <em>dirt</em> if you use both <em>mortars</em> and <em>missiles</em>.	Someone tried to<strong> break</strong> into <em>Staples</em> using a <em>missile</em>, but it ended up<strong> break</strong>ing the whole store, turning it to <em>dirt</em>.		
興		entertain	<i>Mortar</i> . . . <i>same</i> . . . <i>tool</i>. Be careful to make an image that keeps <i>same</i> in the middle.		16	1533	1426	37	コウ、キョウ	おこ.る、おこ.す	To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be<strong> entertain</strong>ed. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the <em>same: staples</em>. What <em>tools</em>! [ayoung24].	Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) – all this as a tool to<strong> entertain</strong> a group of drunks at a club.	Wacky Japanese TV <strong>entertain</strong>-ment show: a <em>monk</em> is <em>stapled</em> to the wall on both sides with huge <em>staples</em>, whilst contestants throw <em>tools</em> at his face.	This is a pictograph an <strong>entertainment</strong> system (two speakers left and right of the main unit, which has a CD slot and a tape deck) on a table-top.	Whenever I go to <em>Staples</em> I end up looking at the <em>same tools</em> every time (PDAs, printers, etc.) but it manages to<strong> entertain</strong> me.		
酉		sign of the bird	Though we shall later encounter the kanji for <i>bird</i>, we introduce this one for the tenth sign of the zodiac mainly because of its use as a primitive, where it has a different meaning.	"* As a primitive, it means <i>whiskey bottle</i>. In its pictograph, you can see the loosely corked lid, the bottle and the contents (about one-third full). You might also think of the Spanish ""porrón,"" a decanter shaped like a long-necked bird."	7	1534	1427	38	ユウ	とり	The<strong> sign of the bird</strong> on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.	"Normally birds fly south, but <em>one</em> bird flew <em>west</em>. People were worried about it and kept asking ""Is there any<strong> sign of the bird</strong> – you know, the <em>one</em> that flew <em>west</em>?""."	It's time for a drinking game everyone! If you see the<strong> sign of the bird</strong>, take a drink from your whiskey bottle.	The<strong> Sign of the Bird</strong> on Greygoose Vodka. It's got such a fancy bottle, but I think Absolut tastes smoother.	The driver had drunk too much <em>whiskey</em> and was driving too fast, giving all the slow drivers the<strong> sign of the bird</strong>.		
酒		saké	Water . . . whiskey bottle.		10	1535	1428	38	シュ	さけ、さか-	<strong>Sake</strong> is just watered down whisky.	<strong>Sake</strong> is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is <em>whiskey</em> and <em>water</em>.	<strong>Sake</strong>. Looks like <em>water</em>, tastes like <em>whiskey</em>. (thanks Bodhisamaya).	If you forget this Kanji and you watch a lot of Anime then don't study Japanese.	<strong>Sake</strong> is the <em>liquid</em> that comes out of the <em>sake bottle</em> - and when ever there's a<strong> sake</strong> drinking competition, all the delicate women shoo (しゅ) away. (Readings: しゅ、さけ、さか、ざか).		
酌		bartending	Whiskey bottle . . . ladle.		10	1536	1429	38	シャク	く.む	At the local pub, their<strong> bartending</strong> practises are unusual. They serve the <em>whiskey</em> by pouring it from a <em>ladle</em>, like one would from the punch bowl.	Ever seen the anime Bartender?<strong> Bartending</strong> isn't just about <em>bottles of whiskey</em>, it's about <em>ladling</em> out advice.	Old fashioned<strong> bartending</strong> had the server ladle out the alcohol from a giant whiskey bottle.	"Coyote Ugly! The girls <strong>""bartending""</strong> in the bar don't use <em>whiskey bottles</em> - they use <em>ladles</em> and pour everything over their bodies. What a show! Where was the bar exactly?"	<strong>Bartending</strong> consists mainly of giving the customer the proper amount. That's why they dispense from a <em>whiskey bottle</em> into a special <em>ladle</em> to measure the RIGHT amount.		
酎		hooch	This kanji is used for thick, low-grade saké made from various kinds of grains. Its primitives are: <i>whisky bottle</i> . . . <i>glue</i>.		10	1537	2748	38	チュウ、チュ	かも.す	"While the keyword is ""hooch"", this usually means 焼酎 . It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated."	Tastes like whiskey, smells like glue? Then it must be しょうちゅうの「ちゅう」 (<strong> hooch</strong> ). - There you go, reading meaning and a catchy ad jingle, all in one. Possibly the best story I've written. ^^.	I combined WHISKEY and GLUE to make<strong> HOOCH</strong>.	"焼酎 , 酎ハイ , 芋焼酎 <a href=""../v4/2748.html"">hooch</a> (#2748 酎) チュウ … Parts: 酉 , 寸 … Cultural Note: Shochu ( 焼酎 ) now outsells Sake ( 日本酒 ) in Japan, so even though Heisig Calls it<strong> hooch</strong>, and Spahn calls it low-grade liquor, Shochu is more popular than Sake. So don't be comparing it to sniffing glue dammit."	This thick, illicitly-made beverage is actually just <em>whiskey</em> mixed with <em>glue</em>!		
酵		fermentation	Whiskey bottle . . . filial piety.		14	1538	1430	38	コウ		The secrets of<strong> fermentation</strong> are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.	Since <em>filial piety</em> is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a <em>whiskey bottle</em> is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing<strong> fermentation</strong>) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will.	Add a phrase to Raichu's story: The secrets of<strong> fermentation</strong> are written on a <em>whiskey bottle</em> and passed to the child who displays the most <em>filial piety</em>.	In a family of alcoholics, <em>filial piety</em> is saving the more <strong>fermented</strong> <em>whiskey</em> for the elders.	The boy throws the body of the old man in the whiskey barrel. There he lets<strong> fermentation</strong> do his work. The best whiskey ever.		
酷		cruel	Whiskey bottle . . . revelation.		14	1539	1431	38	コク	ひど.い	It's<strong> cruel</strong> to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.	Offering whiskey to people to encourage them to make revelations is<strong> cruel</strong>.	There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a <em>bottle of whiskey</em>, you may get some <em>revelations</em> about their<strong> cruel</strong>ty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.	Some people when they drink too much alcohol start to tell the truth about everything. Unfortuantly some of these revelations can be rather<strong> cruel</strong>, at least you find out exactly what they think of you.	This one seems too obvious. Drinking too much whiskey makes for some<strong> cruel</strong> revelations as you stop watching what you say to your friends. Hey, your girlfriend is a good kisser!		
酬		repay	Whiskey bottle . . . state.		13	1540	1432	38	シュウ、シュ、トウ	むく.いる	Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state<strong> repay</strong>s you with whiskey.	Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will<strong> repay</strong> the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.	If you take your <em>whiskey</em> across a <em>state line</em>, you'll have to<strong> repay</strong> the liquor tax in the new state.	"True story, the former communist <em>state</em> of Russia was once so poor it<strong> repay</strong>ed it's teachers with <em>vodka</em> <a href=""http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/177421.stm"">http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/177421.stm</a>."	<em>States</em> like Michigan<strong> repay</strong> you for returning your <em>whiskey bottles</em>.		
酪		dairy products	Whiskey bottle . . . each.		13	1541	1433	38	ラク		To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some<strong> dairy products</strong> with each bottle of whiskey I drink…	In an attempt to increase sales of<strong> dairy products</strong>, the grocery store is giving away a free miniature <em>whiskey bottle</em> with <em>each</em> dairy product you buy.	The makers of Bailey's Irish Creme <em>add</em><strong> dairy products</strong> to <em>each</em> of their <em>bottles of whiskey</em>, creating one of the most delicious alcoholic beverages known to mankind.	<strong>Dairy products</strong> go bad so often, you can get sick if you eat or drink them, unless EACH one is accompanied afterwards by a shot from a WHISKEY BOTTLE. The alcohol kills the bacteria and warms your innards.	Put a little <em>whisky</em> in baby's<strong> dairy products</strong> at <em>each</em> feeding time to ensure sound sleep.		
酢		vinegar	Whiskey bottle . . . saw.		12	1542	1434	38	サク	す	Drinking alcohol that's turned to<strong> vinegar</strong> feels like a saw going down your throat.	I spent ages <em>saw</em>ing that <em>whiskey bottle</em> open, but when I got in, it had all turned to<strong> vinegar</strong>!	<em>Yesterday</em>'s <em>alcohol</em> turns into today's<strong> vinegar</strong>. (Yesterday = day + <em>saw</em>.).	To determine wether the bottle contains<strong> vinegar</strong> or <em>whiskey</em>, you have to <em>saw</em> it open.	When the <em>whiskey</em> turns to<strong> vinegar</strong>, the taste is sharp like a <em>saw</em>.		
酔		drunk	Whiskey bottle . . . baseball . . . needle.		11	1543	1435	38	スイ	よ.う、よ.い、よ	God you're <strong>drunk</strong>! How many <em>whiskeys</em> did you have? <em>9</em>? <em>10</em>?	Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you<strong> drunk</strong>. I don't care who you are.	As Ernest Hemingway said, it only takes one drink to get me<strong> drunk</strong>. But I'm not sure if it is the ninth or tenth drink that does it. [from dingomick].	99 bottles of beer on the wall, 99 bottles of beer, take one down, pass it around 98 bottles of beer on the wall, etc; getting<strong> drunk</strong>, just remembering the '90' part.	You will get<strong> DRUNK</strong> if you drink WHISKEY that is 90 proof (NINE and TEN).		
配		distribute	Whisky bottle . . . snake.		10	1544	1436	38	ハイ	くば.る	To<strong> DISTRIBUTE</strong> <em>WHISKY</em> during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a <em>SNAKE</em>.	In Japan, it's rude to<strong> distribute</strong> the <em>sake</em> to your <em>self</em> before anybody else.	Those who have studied physics may find this useful. The two parts of the kanji represent the two statistical <strong>distribution</strong>s for bosons and fermions. The Bose-Einstein <strong>distribution</strong> is represented by the <em>sign of the bird</em> because birds, like bosons, are social creatures who like to flock together. The Fermi-Dirac <strong>distribution</strong> is represented by a <em>snake</em>, since <em>snake</em>s, like fermions, are solitary creatures who like to keep to themselves.	"Do a google search for ""Laotian Snake Whisky""… yes snake whisky does exist !. Now you only have to found their distributor to get yourself a botle !"	"Sir, you're under arrest for <strong>distributing</strong> <em>alcohol</em> to <em>snakes</em>. ""WHAT?? They told me they were worms!!""."		
酸		acid	Whiskey bottle . . . license . . . walking legs.		14	1545	1437	38	サン	す.い	The <em>prostitute</em> carries an old <em>whiskey bottle</em> filled with <strong>acid</strong> to throw at any difficult Johns.	Dealing <em>alcohol</em> requires a <em>license</em>, dealing<strong> acid</strong> requires fast <em>legs</em> (to run from the police).	I stopped doing <strong>acid</strong>, and am living the clean life. Well, aside from all the <em>whiskey</em> and <em>prostitutes</em>.	The punishment for people who sell <em>whiskey</em> without a <em>license</em> is harsh:<strong> acid</strong> is poured onto their <em>walking legs</em>.	Sometimes ppl put<strong> acid</strong> into their <em>alcohol</em> to make it taste bad (so you won't want to drink it anymore). this guy uses this technique to give up drinking <em>alcohol</em>, since due to the number of his DUIs he had gotten his driver's <em>license</em> suspended and thus must make use of his <em>walking legs</em> (an inconvenience!).		
猶		waver	Wild dogs . . . animal horns . . . whiskey bottle.		12	1546	1438	38	ユウ、ユ	なお	The<strong> waver</strong> for this kanji means to hesitate. I<strong> waver</strong>ed before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.	For the right primitive: Red Bull (the energy drink). Can be mixed with alcohol and gives you wi- uh, horns. Coincidentally, also the name of the Indian CHIEFTAN in frame 2906. (Thanks Katsuo).	"Tip: <em>horns</em> + <em>whiskey bottle</em> : This combination of primitives appears five times in Heisig, including as a separate kanji 酋 <a href=""../v4/2906.html"">chieftain</a> (#2906 酋). REF: <a href=""../v4/1439.html"">revered</a> (#1439 尊), <a href=""../v4/2425.html"">courtesy</a> (#2425 鄭), <a href=""../v4/2493.html"">Japanese oak</a> (#2493 楢). Edit: Note that in some fonts <em>horns</em> are replaced by <em>eight</em> 八 ."	. Have you ever had Wild Dog brand whiskey? That stuff is downright evil. So evil, the bottle has horns, and you need to sign a<strong> waver</strong> before you drink it. Because of this warning you will surely<strong> waver</strong> as you bring the shot glass to your lips.	I<strong> waver</strong>ed when the <em>pack of wild dogs</em> was blocking the way, but then I drank some <em>Red Bull</em> and charged through. (thanks shakkun).		
尊		revered	Animal horns . . . whiskey bottle . . . glue.		12	1547	1439	38	ソン	たっと.い、とうと.い、たっと.ぶ、とうと.ぶ	I drank the <em>Devil Whiskey</em> and was <strong>revered</strong> by all. Too bad I had to have my anus <em>glued</em> shut from the damage it did to my digestive system…	"<em>Red Bull</em>, the <a href=""../v4/2906.html"">chieftain</a> (#2906 酋) is so<strong> revered</strong> in his clan that everyone sticks to him like <em>glue</em>."	Have you seen people who save their empty alcohol bottles? Some of them take the reverence too far, and <em>glue</em> the<strong> revered</strong> <em>bottle of whisky</em> to the wall, mounted like a rack of <em>animal horns</em>.	A <em>whiskey bottle</em> collector discovers a bottle where the glass has been shaped into <em>horns</em>. He likes it so much, he <em>glues</em> it to his mantelpiece. The most<strong> revered</strong> item in his collection.	The<strong> revered</strong> TV evangelist turned out to be nothing but a HORNy, ALCOHOLic degenerate who also sniffed GLUE.		
豆		beans	This kanji depicts a pot of <b>beans</b>, although it looks more like a table on which the pot is resting.	* As a primitive, this kanji will mean <i>table</i>.	7	1548	1440	38	トウ、ズ	まめ、まめ-	If I eat<strong> BEANS</strong>, after <em>ONE</em> <em>MOUTHful</em> I fart like some kind of <em>HORNED ANIMAL</em>.	I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let's call this one Mr. Bean! He's an easy character to build stories with.	Looks like a pot of refried<strong> beans</strong> on top of a stove to me with a top over the pot.	<em>One</em> <em>mouth</em>ful and you spit them on the <em>floor</em> (<em>two drops</em> of spit out<strong> beans</strong>). I'm talking about 納豆 (natto) of course.	<strong>BEANS</strong> are served on the TABLE. It's a simple pictograph, so force the issue here.		
頭		head	Here we meet at last the full kanji on which the primitive for <b>head</b> is based. The elements: <i>table</i> . . . <i>head</i>.		16	1549	1441	38	トウ、ズ、ト	あたま、かしら、-がしら、かぶり	The<strong> head</strong> of the family sits at the<strong> head</strong> of the <em>table</em>.	<em>Mr. Bean</em> has a funny <strong><em>head</em></strong>.	Mr <em>Bean</em>'s <em>head</em>.	Which one is the <strong>head</strong> <em>table</em>? Well, it's the <em>table</em> with the <strong><em>head</em></strong> sitting beside it, isn't it?	Sometimes old men refer to your<strong> head</strong> as your noggin, your noodle, or your <em>bean</em>.		
短		short	Dart . . . table.		12	1550	1442	38	タン	みじか.い	He's so <strong>short</strong>, he can't even throw over a <em>table</em> while playing <em>darts</em>.	Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw <em>darts</em> over a <em>table</em> at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be<strong> short</strong>.———— This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.	<em>Mr. Bean</em> somehow finds himself in an archery contest. He has no arrow's so he uses <em>darts</em>, (even though they are quite too<strong> short</strong>!). All of his shots land extremely<strong> short</strong>! (Picture Mr. Bean trying to shoot a dart and it landing<strong> short</strong>).	A<strong> short</strong> man can DART under the TABLE.	My<strong> short</strong> friend plays darts, but when he goes to pick them out, he has to climb up on the table we put next to the board.		
豊		bountiful	Bend . . . table. Think of a <b>bountiful</b> harvest, and you will not be far from the meaning of this character.		13	1551	1443	38	ホウ、ブ	ゆた.か、とよ	The<strong> bountiful</strong> feast was so<strong> bountiful</strong> that it <em>bent</em> the <em>table</em> below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.	Her bust and bum was so<strong> bountiful</strong> I couldn't resist the urge to <em>bend</em> her over a nearby <em>table</em> and…	<em>Bender</em> stands on top of <em>Mr. Bean</em> to be able to reach the<strong> bountiful</strong> feast on the giant's table. (<em>Mr. Bean</em> didnt know how he even ended up there).	Be careful when people <em>bend</em> over around here: the <em>bean</em> harvest was<strong> bountiful</strong>.	Bender stands over the table,<strong> bountiful</strong>ly covered in loot.		
鼓		drum	The full kanji for the <i>drum</i> adds a <i>branch</i>, apparently to serve as a <b>drum</b>stick, to the primitive for <i>drum</i>.		13	1552	1444	38	コ	つづみ	"Japanese festivals have <strong>drums</strong> so big, a <em>samurai</em> has to SIT (not stand) on a <em>table</em> to beat one with a tree <em>branch</em>! <a href=""http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/"">http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/</a>~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg."	"I really hate the primitive meaning of ""table"" for ""bean."" I just use ""bean."" Anyways, for the<strong> DRUM</strong> primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a<strong> DRUM</strong> with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: ""DRUMing on a<strong> DRUM</strong> with a huge BRANCH""."	<em>Mr. Bean</em> tries to play<strong> drum</strong>s with <em>10</em> different <em>branches</em> he found on the ground.	These SAMURAI, sitting at the TABLE and waiting for their food, grab some BRANCHES to begin<strong> DRUM</strong>MING a rhythm while they wait. (In fact, they stand on the table, removing the top stroke!).	"A <em>drum</em> cannot<strong> drum</strong> without a stick. No stick? Use a <em>branch</em> instead. HINT: For<strong> drum</strong> primitive - Our samurai has eaten loads of beans and now his LOWER HALF (tummy full of beans) is bloated and stretched taut like a<strong> drum</strong>. We can see him tapping contentedly on his ""drum"". In Japanese folklore, tanuki are believed to play music by<strong> drum</strong>ming ""ponpoko pon no pon"" on their tummies."		
喜		rejoice	Drum . . . mouth.		12	1553	1445	38	キ	よろこ.ぶ、よろこ.ばす	The <em>samurai</em> sitting on the <em>drum</em> is on a stage, and the people below him are <strong>rejoicing</strong> with their <em>mouths</em> in unison. 樹		timber-trees	Trees . . . drum . . . glue.		16	1554	1446	38	ジュ	き	The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the<strong> timber-trees</strong> and are beating their drums.	"To the cutting down of<strong> timber-trees</strong> and the destruction of the forest, the hippies have staged a protest demonstration using a <em>drum</em> in the <em>middle of the town</em> (see <a href=""../v4/208.html"">town</a> (#208 村))."	"Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. For this kanji imagine hundreds of spectators <em>glue</em>d to their chairs, then a <em>drum</em> roll and then a cry of ""timber!!!"" as the huge <em>tree</em> crashes to the ground."	<em>Drums</em> are made from<strong> timber-trees</strong> cut down and <em>glued</em> together. (they really are).	Trivia: 尌 (drum+glue) is a rare kanji wih a meaning <em>standing (something) up</em>. Story: Trees that were set to stand up (and grow) at certain places are<strong> timber-trees</strong>. 樹立 【じゅりつ】 (n,vs) establish; create;.		
皿		dish	The kanji for a <b>dish</b> is, clearly, the pictograph of a painted or carved bowl, seen from the side.		5	1555	1447	38	ベイ	さら	Three<strong> dish</strong>es stacked side-by-side in a<strong> dish</strong>washer.	Pictograph of a<strong> dish</strong> with a three-layer cake slice on it.	3<strong> dish</strong>es in a<strong> dish</strong> rack. HINT: To avoid making 4<strong> dish</strong>es, remember that '4' is an unlucky number in Japan so things are rarely in sets of 4.	The Holy Grail.	I eat fast, so all my<strong> dish</strong>es have racing stripes like this one.		
血		blood	The <i>drop</i> in the <i>dish</i> is <b>blood</b>. It is similar to the <i>drop</i> we saw earlier on the <i>dagger</i> in the character for <i>blade</i> (Frame 88).		6	1556	1448	38	ケツ	ち	Vampire orders<strong> blood</strong> in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of<strong> blood</strong> in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of<strong> blood</strong> spraying everywhere.	You cut yourself washing the dishes, drop of<strong> blood</strong>.	Image: <em>Holy Grail</em> with a <em>drop</em> of Jesus<strong> blood</strong> on it.	People used to think that<strong> blood</strong>letting was an effective treatment for many illnesses. The doctor would cut the patient's arm open and let the <em>drops</em> of<strong> blood</strong> fall into a <em>dish</em>.	<strong>BLOOD</strong>?! IS that a SPOT of<strong> BLOOD</strong> on my PLATE!?! asks the infuriated vegetarian when he ordered a salad at a restaurant.		
盆		basin	Part . . . dish.		9	1557	1449	38	ボン		The <em>part</em> of the kitchen sink in which you wash <em>dishes</em> in is the<strong> basin</strong>.	Your mom yells at you to stop throwing dishes in the<strong> basin</strong>. She lifts up (to show primitive order) the broken parts to show you the damage you've done.	If you break a coconut in two <em>parts</em>, you can improvise a kachi-kachi (a kind of castanet that is played at <strong>bon festivals</strong>). After the festival is done you can use them as a curved <em>dish</em>, a <strong>basin</strong> (synonym of bowl).	When the god parted his soup dish in two it created a huge<strong> basin</strong>.	It will take just a minute to wash the<strong> basin</strong>'s dishes.		
盟		alliance	Bright . . . dish.		13	1558	1450	38	メイ		"(re: Raichu) An undercover<strong> alliance</strong> between Japan (the <em>sun</em> on its flag) and Turkey (the <em>moon</em> on its flag) detected by a surveillance satellite <em>dish</em>. <a href=""http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html"">http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html</a>."	"A new<strong> alliance</strong> is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their<strong> alliance</strong> they clean up together one <em>dish</em>, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very <em>bright</em>, and it's pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning's newspapers, with the title ""New<strong> alliance</strong>, one <em>bright dish</em>!""."	The <em>bright dishes</em> in the cupboard form an<strong> alliance</strong> against the others.	In medieval Japan (during Sengoku Jidai) there was an interesting ritual to form an<strong> alliance</strong> between different samurai clans. The warlord, who wanted to propose to form an<strong> alliance</strong> to another warlord, would send him a big ceremonial <em>dish</em> with the <em>sun</em> drawn in the center. If the proposal were accepted, the second warlord would draw an image of the <em>moon</em> next to the <em>sun</em> on the same <em>dish</em>, and then return the <em>dish</em> to the first warlord. (not true story, but helped me to create vivid image).	The <strong>alliance</strong> has built <em>bright</em> satellite <em>dish</em>es to defeat the rebels.		
盗		steal	Next . . . dish.		11	1559	1451	38	トウ	ぬす.む、ぬす.み	You are so poor you dont know where your <em>next dish</em> will come from all you know is that you will have to<strong> steal</strong> it.	The first thing to<strong> steal</strong> is the silverware; <em>next</em>, the <em>dishes</em>.	You're at a revolving sushi restaurant with a famous thief, who's so slick he says he can<strong> steal</strong> anything without anyone noticing. OK, you say, the NEXT DISH that comes by,<strong> steal</strong> it…	This is pretty easy: While he's not looking, imagine<strong> steal</strong>ing food from the dish next to you!	"The <em>next</em> thing on his list of things to<strong> steal</strong> after the <em>dishes</em> was the kitchen sink. Watch out for <a href=""../v4/357.html"">burglar</a> (#357 賊) and <a href=""../v4/566.html"">rob</a> (#566 奪) and <a href=""../v4/1414.html"">crime</a> (#1414 犯). To differentiate it, think that<strong> steal</strong>ing is arbitrary (hence the kitchen sink), <a href=""../v4/566.html"">rob</a> (#566 奪) is more deliberate (and hence the protection of the attack turkey) and <a href=""../v4/357.html"">burglar</a> (#357 賊) is the most professional of them all (it is his full time job), so he knows when to hit (when everyone is at the fiesta)."		
温		warm	Water . . . sun . . . dish.		12	1560	1452	38	オン	あたた.か、あたた.かい、あたた.まる、あたた.める、ぬく	If you leave <strong>water</strong> out in the <strong>sun</strong> in a <strong>dish</strong>, naturally it will get <em>warm</em>.	"I'm mixing this up with <a href=""../v4/1949.html"">warmth</a> (#1949 暖) far too much. Trying to use mnemonic ""Warm Water"" - 温泉 （おんせん） obviously relates to <em>water</em> that is<strong> warm</strong>, from the <em>sun</em> and when you think about it, is kind of like a big <em>dish</em>."	I ate the <em>sun</em> on a <em>plate</em>, and I now feel<strong> warm</strong> inside. I had to drink <em>water</em> to stop this burning.	To<strong> warm</strong> <em>water</em>, leave it in a <em>dish</em> in the afternoon <em>sun</em>.	The<strong> warm</strong> water,<strong> warm</strong> sun, and<strong> warm</strong> dish: the three best things to keep you<strong> warm</strong>.		
蓋		lid	Flowers . . . gone . . . dish.		14	1561	2388	38	ガイ、カイ、コウ	ふた、けだ.し、おお.う、かさ、かこう	The<strong> lid</strong> of this <em>dish</em> is <em>gone</em>! Now the whole room smells of the <em>flowers</em> that were used in the cooking.	The magic<strong> lid</strong> trick: you put flowers in the dish and cover them up with the<strong> lid</strong>. Then you lift and the flowers are gone!	The waiter of a fancy restaurant takes the<strong> lid</strong> away and what you see is - nothing! The food is <em>gone</em> - somebody has stolen it. All what has been left from the <em>dish</em> is the decoration, a single <em>flower</em>…	"You're tunelessly singing, ""Where have all the <em>flowers gone</em>? Gone to <em>dishes</em> every one…"", and someone shouts, ""Put a<strong> lid</strong> on it!""."	When the magician lifted the<strong> LID</strong>, the <em>flowers</em> were <em>gone</em> from the <em>dish</em>.		
監		oversee	Slaves . . . reclining . . . floor/one . . . dish.		15	1562	1453	38	カン		The slavetrader <strong>oversees</strong> the slaves washing <em>dishes</em> int he kitchen. No <em>reclining</em> on the <em>floor</em>!	"The <em>slaves</em> are <em>reclining</em> on the <em>floor</em> when the<strong> oversee</strong>r comes in. They tell him ""We're not goofing off, a <em>dish</em> fell and broke and we're cleaning it off the <em>floor</em>""."	"While the slave-buyer is perusing (<a href=""../v4/855.html"">perusal</a> (#855 覧)) the stack of <strong>slaves reclining on the floor</strong>, the slaves'<strong> oversee</strong>r supplies them with <strong>dishes</strong> of gruel – don't want the slaves starving to death before they can be sold!"	"Mnemonic : ""The<strong> oversee</strong>r<strong> oversee</strong>s that the <em>slaves</em> are washing the <em>dishes</em> instead of <em>reclining</em> on the <em>floor</em> (having a siesta)""."	The plantation master<strong> oversee</strong>s his slaves crawling on the floor and eating from the same plate.		
濫		overflow	Water . . . oversee.		18	1563	1454	38	ラン	みだ.りに、みだ.りがましい	Who's job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It'ts<strong> overflow</strong>ing!	The <em>overseer</em> isn't doing his job and he lets the slaves <strong>overflow</strong> the sink!	When <em>water</em><strong> overflow</strong>s it is usually because someone was not properly <em>overseeing</em> the task. Image: A mother talking on the phone, <em>overseeing</em> the drawing her kid's bath, boiling something on the stove, and breaking up a fight between two of the kids. Something is bound to<strong> overflow</strong>.	This is the <em>overseer</em> from the previous kanji, who was watching the slave wash the dishes. Unfortunately, the reclining <em>overseer</em> fell asleep and didn't notice when the <em>water</em> starting<strong> overflow</strong>ing from the sink. ……………………………………………………………………. An alternate version of this story would be the famous scene from Fantasia where Mickey falls asleep and stops <em>overseeing</em> the brooms bringing in <em>water</em>, so the room<strong> overflow</strong>s.	Water will<strong> overflow</strong>… if you do not oversee.		
鑑		specimen	Metal . . . oversee.		23	1564	1455	38	カン	かんが.みる、かがみ	The <em>overseer</em> tags his slaves with <em>gold</em> earrings, just like <strong>specimens</strong>.	(Thanks bodhisamaya) The authorities are suspicious about the athlete that won GOLD at the olympics. They are now OVERSEEING a thorough drug test, taking all sorts of<strong> SPECIMEN</strong>S. 藍		indigo	Flowers . . . oversee.		18	1565	2371	38	ラン	あい	<strong>Indigo</strong> <em>flowers</em> have to be <em>overseen</em> because they are often picked for their beauty.	"Traditionally, 青 <a href=""../v4/1534.html"">blue</a> (#1534 青) could be used to describe blue OR green. However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑 . This kanji is the ""blue"" counterpart of <a href=""../v4/1371.html"">green</a> (#1371 緑). Story: The <em>overseer</em>, master of the slaves, wore a cloak dyed with<strong> indigo</strong>, and <em>flowers</em> in his hair."	"<a href=""Http://gaijinsmashnet.wordpress.com/2007/06/28/1-kyuu/"">Http://gaijinsmashnet.wordpress.com/2007/06/28/1-kyuu/</a> Reading this rant by a non-RTKer mentioning this particular kanji made me remember it very well."	<strong>Indigo</strong> <em>flowers</em> have to be closely <em>overseen</em> during the growing process, otherwise they'll be useless for making <strong>indigo</strong> dye.	The princess who likes to <em>oversee</em> the making of her dishes, often wears<strong> indigo</strong> coloured clothes.<strong> Indigo</strong> is made from <em>flowers</em>.		
猛		fierce	Wild dogs . . . child . . . dish.		11	1566	1456	38	モウ		The<strong> fierce</strong> WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.	I picture a<strong> fierce</strong> little fat kid, defending his dish of food from a pack of dogs.	If you want to make your wild dogs<strong> fierce</strong>, feed them a child. Children are the holy grail of dogfood you know…	If you want to make your wild dogs<strong> fierce</strong>, put a child in their dish.	Ok, I'll bring in a 300 reference. A<strong> FIERCE</strong> pack of WILD DOGS fight an even<strong> FIERCE</strong>R spartan CHILD over the food left on the PLATE. The CHILD won and was declared king.		
盛		boom	Here <b>boom</b> refers to something that is popular and prospering. Its elements: <i>turn into</i> . . . <i>dish</i>.		11	1567	1457	38	セイ、ジョウ	も.る、さか.る、さか.ん	Japan's economic<strong> boom</strong> turned their empty plates into full ones.	The<strong> boom</strong> of satellite TV has made antennas <em>turn into</em> <em>dishes</em>.	The Chinese kitchen is famous for knowing how to <em>turn</em> anything slightly edible <em>into</em> a good <em>dish</em>. That's one of the reasons why their cuisine<strong> boom</strong>ed all over the world.	"Yoshinoya is enjoying a popularity <strong>boom</strong> because of the promotion where all their <em>dish</em>es are <em>turned into</em> 大 <strong>盛</strong>り sized <em>dish</em>es at no extra charge. [おおもり, ""a large serving""]."	The Japanese have a phrase, マイブーム (my<strong> boom</strong>), which refers to something that a person is currently obsessed with or fascinated by. This kanji depicts the<strong> boom</strong> as a certain <em>dish</em> that has just <em>turned into</em> a national trend.		
塩		salt	Ground . . . reclining . . . mouth . . . dish.		13	1568	1458	38	エン	しお	In the old days,<strong> salt</strong> was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone <em>reclining</em> on the <em>ground</em>, <em>mouth</em> to <em>plate</em>, getting every last grain of that delicious<strong> salt</strong>.	"Remember the mock sushi documentary that circulated a while ago: ""Because some feel that the shoyu was not<strong> salt</strong>y enough, complementary<strong> salt</strong> dishes are provided on the ground outside the sushiya, you can recline and put as much as you desire in your mouth""."	It is bad luck to spill<strong> salt</strong> on the <em>ground</em>, so you better <em>recline</em> and lick it into your <em>mouth</em> or put it back on the <em>dish</em>.	This is a picture of an artificial<strong> salt</strong> lick on the <em>grounds</em> of a nature preserve: animals can go there, <em>recline</em>, and use their <em>mouths</em> to lick the<strong> salt</strong> from a <em>dish</em>.	"In a<strong> SALT</strong> pan, all the <strong>soil</strong> is actually<strong> SALT</strong>. You can <strong>recline</strong>, taste it with your <strong>mouth</strong>, and put it in your <strong>dish</strong>. <a href=""http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG/300px-Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG"">http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG/300px-Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG</a> <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_pan_%28geology%29"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_pan_%28geology%29</a>."		
銀		silver	Metal . . . silver.		14	1569	1459	38	ギン	しろがね	Like <em>gold</em>, <em>silver</em> is a <em>metal</em>.	"Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma's <em>hairpin</em> (just before <a href=""../v4/1920.html"">long</a> (#1920 長)) is made of<strong> silver</strong>, the metal that best reflects <em>sun</em> light. I'm sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (<em>sun</em> and <em>hairpin</em>) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order."	<em>Metal</em> that is<strong> silver</strong> is<strong> silver</strong>!	"<strong>Silver</strong> is almost as <a href=""../v4/1468.html"">good</a> (#1468 良) as gold, but not quite (one stroke missing)."	In order of value, it goes: <em>gold</em>, then <em><strong>silver</strong></em>.		
恨		resentment	State of mind . . . silver.		9	1570	1460	38	コン	うら.む、うら.めしい	The athlete's <em>state of mind</em> is nothing but<strong> resentment</strong> after getting the <em>silver</em> medal.	<em>Data</em>'s greatest <strong>resentment</strong> is getting a <em>silver</em> medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: <em>Data</em> fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).	What is your state of mind when you win silver? You resent that you didn't win gold!	<strong>Regret</strong> at missing the gold means a silver medalist's state of mind =<strong> resentment</strong> [True phenomenon: bronze medalists are happier than silver because they are just glad that they medalled at all.].	Data felt<strong> resentment</strong> toward the Silver Surfer for being able to fly through space freely while he was always trapped on the Enterprise with Picard and Riker doing dumb missions.		
根		root	Tree . . . silver.		10	1571	1461	38	コン	ね、-ね	Since trees eat through their<strong> root</strong>s, one could imagine<strong> root</strong>s as <em>tree silver</em>ware.	The <strong>root</strong>s of the magical <em>tree</em> are <em>silver</em>.	In the kanji for<strong> root</strong> (not the primitive), I imagine a <em>tree</em> whose<strong> root</strong>s end up in <em>silverware</em>, which the <em>tree</em> uses somehow to eat whatever is underground.	Think of how if you look at the<strong> root</strong>s of many trees, they are not brown like the rest of the trunk, they sometimes are a whitish, silver color, because they are full of water and nutrients, rather than course cellulose like what is needed up top to protect from the elements.	The <em>tree</em> with <em>silver</em> on it (the Christmas tree) has NO<strong> root</strong>s.		
即		instant	Silver . . . stamp.		7	1572	1462	38	ソク	つ.く、つ.ける、すなわ.ち	He scratches off the <em>silver</em> <em>stamp</em> and discovers that he is an<strong> instant</strong> winner.	For<strong> instant</strong> postal delivery, buy a <em>silver</em> <em>stamp</em>!	Hint:<strong> Instant</strong> cameras. In photography it only takes an<strong> instant</strong> for the light to reach the <em>silver</em> nitrate on the film and <em>stamp</em> an image on it.	<strong>Instant</strong> ramen always has <em>silver</em> foil <em>stamp</em>ed on the top of the cup, as a lid.	"Forewarned is forearmed: careful 忽 <a href=""../v4/2431.html"">instantaneously</a> (#2431 忽) & 頓 <a href=""../v4/2788.html"">immediate</a> (#2788 頓)."		
爵		baron	Vulture . . . eye . . . silver . . . glue.		17	1573	1463	38	シャク		An <em>eagle</em> stole the <strong>baron</strong>'s <em>eye</em> in the war, but now he has a <em>silver</em> coin <em>glued</em> in the socket instead.	Here we see an evil<strong> baron</strong> - a <em>vulture</em> perched on his shoulder, and a <em>siver</em> <em>eye</em>-patch <em>glued</em> to his <em>eye</em>.	A <em>vulture</em> took the<strong> baron</strong>'s <em>eye</em>, so he <em>glued</em> a <em>silver</em> one in its place.	During the first world war there was a german fighter pilot knicknamed the red<strong> baron</strong> (von Richthofen). He was like a <em>vulture</em>, coming from above you see a huge red <em>eye</em> painted on the plane's wings, you see the glint of his many silver medals as he glues himself to your tail, he sights and shoots… pow pow pow the bullets wizz by, soon it will all be over. (it it helps von Richthofen had <em>silver</em> cups engraved for every 'kill' he made).	Yes, it is I, the venerable<strong> Baron</strong> <em>Vultureye</em> von <em>Silverglue</em>!		
節		node	Bamboo . . . instant.		13	1574	1464	38	セツ、セチ	ふし、-ぶし、のっと	Counting the<strong> node</strong>s on <em>bamboo</em> is an <em>instant</em> way to tell its age.	A certain species of <em>bamboo</em> is considered the fastest growing plant in the world. A new <em>node</em> can be formed in an <em>instant</em>.	Is it just me, or do the<strong> node</strong>s on a <em>bamboo</em> tree look like a stack of Cup Noodle <em>instant</em> soup cups?	"See the legend here - <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bamboo"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bamboo</a>. When you see a bamboo tree with a many<strong> node</strong>s, don't be a fool and touch it - you may be joined to it in an instant."	Forget the quicksort algorithm and tree structures, use a bamboo structure and your<strong> node</strong>s will be sorted instantly.		
退		retreat	Road . . . silver.		9	1575	1465	38	タイ	しりぞ.く、しりぞ.ける、ひ.く、の.く、の.ける、ど.く	You see a huge army of people in silver armour on the road so you<strong> retreat</strong>.	In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the <em>Silver Road</em>.	"In Spanish there is a saying which is useful to remember this kanji. It says: ""A enemigo que huye, puente de plata,"" which translates literally as ""To enemy that<strong> retreat</strong>s, silver bridge,"" meaning one should not stay in the way of a<strong> retreat</strong>ing enemy. In the kanji we just replace the silver bridge by a <em>silver</em> <em>road</em>."	Vampires<strong> retreat</strong> down the <em>road</em> when they see villagers arming themselves with <em>silverware</em>.	Orders in from HQ: <em>Retreat</em>! Grab the <strong>silver</strong> and hit the <strong>road</strong>.

Not just anyone can gain membership into The Pinnacle, it<strong> limit</strong>s its membership to those with the appropriate amount of silver, both to be used as cash and weaponry in their war against the werewolves. (Mnemonic: Pinnacle<strong> limit</strong>s membership to those with enough silver.).	"I'll elaborate on dingomick's story to highlight the importance of ""silver"" in this story so as not to forget. The speed<strong> limit</strong> at The Pinnacle is posted on silver signs… why do you think they are silver? If you remember the top story from <a href=""../v4/1459.html"">silver</a> (#1459 銀), you know that silver is the metal that reflects the most light and therefore draws a lot of attention to it. These people up in the Pinnacle really want you knowin' them<strong> limit</strong>s."	I don't think that my <em>limit</em> is <strong>silver</strong>! I know I can reach the <strong>pinnacle</strong>! gold!!

娘		daughter	Woman . . . halo.		10	1581	1471	38	ジョウ	むすめ、こ	Your<strong> daughter</strong> is a good girl……well, let's hope so… :-). 食		eat	"If <i>halo</i> and <i>umbrella</i> aren't enough, break the <i>halo</i> down into <i>drop</i> and <i>silver</i> - or ""silverware,"" an additional primitive."	* As a primitive, this kanji can mean either <i>eating</i> or <i>food</i>. As with <i>silver</i>, on the left the final two strokes of this element are combined into one.	9	1582	1472	38	ショク、ジキ	く.う、く.らう、た.べる、は.む	That <em>umbrella</em> looks <em>good</em> enough to<strong> eat</strong>!	Umbrella + Good: Let's go<strong> eat</strong> at that restaurant - the table with the <em>umbrella</em> looks <em>good</em>.	I've been waiting for this kanji for so long…	Imagine the <em>halo</em> when you pray before the meal. The people queuing up outside the restaurant in the rain with an <em>umbrella</em> couldn't care less about your sanctimoniousness.	"Note : as a primitive I use the image of a hamburger, or ""fast food""."		
飯		meal	Food . . . anti-.		12	1583	1473	38	ハン	めし	I'm <em>anti</em>-fast<em>food</em>. Sit down and eat a real<strong> meal</strong>! Part of every traditional Italian <strong>meal</strong> is when they <em>eat</em> the <em>anti-</em>pasto first. (Antipasto is not a food, it's the first course; see Wikipedia.).	Before a good<strong> meal</strong>, <em>eat</em> <em>anti</em>pasto!			
飲		drink	Food . . . yawn.		12	1584	1474	38	イン、オン	の.む、-の.み	When you <em>lack food</em>, just<strong> drink</strong> something to fill you up.	In Japan, the one thing I always seem to be <em>lacking</em> with my <em>food</em> is a properer sized<strong> drink</strong>. Instead I have to<strong> drink</strong> that shot glass of water.	Always the same in those restaurants. You've already received your<strong> drink</strong> and you're waiting so long for your <em>food</em> that you begin to <em>yawn</em>.	VERY easy! Food alone is never enough - without a<strong> drink</strong>, our meal would be lacking! After all, food lacks the water that we get from<strong> drink</strong>ing.	After <em>eating</em> I like to have a big <em>yawn</em> and a cool <em>drink</em>.		
飢		hungry	Food . . . wind.		10	1585	1475	38	キ	う.える	The smell of cooked <em>food</em> wafts past you in the <em>wind</em>, making your stomach rumble and feeling<strong> hungry</strong>.	The <em>wind</em> blew away my <em>food</em>, so now I'm<strong> hungry</strong>.	When you feel the <em>wind</em> (or even hear it) in your stomach, that means you're<strong> hungry</strong> and you need to <em>eat</em>. Imagine your stomach like an empty, barren desert, and the <em>wind</em> blowing through it.	If all you had to eat was wind, you'd be<strong> hungry</strong> too.	I was so<strong> hungry</strong> that I <em>ate</em> my <em>fart</em>s.		
餓		starve	Food . . . ego.		15	1586	1476	38	ガ	う.える	All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to <em>eat</em>, but their <em>ego</em> (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!	He<strong> starve</strong>s for FOOD but his EGO won't let him beg.	He was <strong>starving</strong> for <em>food</em>, but he had too much <em>ego</em> and was too proud to ask for <em>food</em>.	A group of high class chefs were trapped in a fast food restaurant. They had such a big ego, they refused to eat any hamburgers, and they all<strong> starve</strong>d to death.	"People use the phrase ""I'm starving"" too casually. They just want some FOOD, and their EGO causes them to magnify their terminology for effect. If they were really to<strong> starve</strong>, they'd lose their EGOs, and absolutely anything would become FOOD."

"In Japanese bukkake movies, an ""actress"" <em>reclining</em> on a <em>towel</em> is<strong> decorate</strong>d in cum, then has the pleasure of <em>eating</em> it!"	You<strong> decorate</strong> your house with pictures of you reclining in a towel surrounded by food.	Hint: a fancy picnic.

Pavlov's dog knew that<strong> FEED</strong> had been set out for him to EAT whenever his EARS heard the bell.	<strong>Feed</strong> him until the FOOD comes out of his EARS.		
館		Bldg.	The abbreviation of <b>Building</b> suggests that this kanji is used in proper names, as indeed it often is. Keep your connotation distinct from <i>Inst.</i> (Frame 1401) when working with the elements: <i>food</i> . . . <i>bureaucrat</i>.		16	1589	1478	38	カン	やかた、たて	A <strong>building</strong> that <em>eats</em> <em>bureaucrats</em>!!!!!!!!	This<strong> Bldg.</strong> is like all the other government buildings - they house <em>bureaucrats</em> who sit around sipping wine and <em>eating</em> expensive meals at the taxpayers expense.	The <em>bureaucrat</em> never goes out for lunch, always choosing to <em>eat</em> in the<strong> Bldg.</strong>	"Empire State <strong>Building</strong> (to avoid confusing with <a href=""../v4/591.html"">government office</a> (#591 庁) and <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1304"">Inst.</a> (#1304 院)). <em>McDonalds</em> lobbies the <em>bureaucrats</em> by treating them to a lavish feast at the top of the Empire State <strong>Building</strong>."	"As this is a type of abbreviation you can assume that the building type is that of a government organisation. And we all know the type of people found in these ""bldgs"" - fat bureaucrats who have eaten too much food."		
餅		mochi	"<i style='""font-weight:' bold>Mochi</i> is the glutinous rice the Japanese pound into cakes. As a promotion, a<strong> MOCHI</strong> manufacturer starts making them as pieces of a jigsaw. Now kids want to buy them not to eat them, but to solve the week's <em>FOOD PUZZLE</em>!

飽		sated	Eat . . . wrap.		13	1592	1480	38	ホウ	あ.きる、あ.かす、あ.く	My gluttony was only <strong>sated</strong> after I ate the <em>hamburger</em> AND the <em>wrapper</em>! 既		previously	<i>Silver</i> . . . <i>waitress</i>. Do not confuse this kanji's key word with <i>before</i> (Frame 263).		10	1593	1481	38	キ	すで.に	"Distinguish from <a href=""../v4/501.html"">formerly</a> (#501 曽). Think of<strong> previously</strong> as ""the previous customer"" in a restaurant. For the waitress primitive, I don't really see the receipt. Story by mspertus.	<strong>Previously</strong>, we left some <em>silver</em> on the table for the <em>waitress</em>.		
概		outline	<i>Roots</i> . . . <i>waitress</i>. Note that the kanji meaning of the two primitives to the right is not used here because we shall later meet a primitive meaning <i>beforehand</i> and want to preempt any confusion. The same holds true in the following frame.		14	1594	1482	38	ガイ	おうむ.ね	A murder has been commited. A corpse was found under a <em>tree</em>. The police chalks the<strong> outline</strong> of the victim, an old <em>silvered</em>-haired <em>waitress</em> working at a restaurant nearby.	If you attempted to<strong> outline</strong> the biography of most famous actresses, you'd find that they have <em>roots</em> working as <em>waitresses</em> before getting their big break.	"If you look at the<strong> outline</strong> (resume/CV) of any professional woman, you'll probably find that while a student she was a <em>waitress</em> part-time so that she could pay the bills, so you could say that most professional women have their ""roots"" in being a <em>waitress</em>."	The chalk<strong> OUTLINE</strong> of a murdered TREE. It was hit by a car and crashed to the ground. All that remains now is a chalk<strong> OUTLINE</strong> where the TREE was PREVIOUSLY laying dead, before being thrown into the chipper.	Some restaurants use <em>wooden</em> signs to<strong> outline</strong> the amount of <em>silver</em> one should leave for the <em>waitress</em>.		
慨		rue	Resentment . . . waitress.		13	1595	1483	38	ガイ		If you don't leave some <em>silver</em> as a tip, you will<strong> rue</strong> the day you earned the <em>resentment</em> of your <em>waitress</em>.	The <em>resentment</em> of a <em>waitress</em> who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She<strong> rue</strong>s that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).	<em>Data</em> is angry…he gave all his <em>silver</em> to the lady who was supposedly his <em>waitress</em>. She ran out the door and left him with no money to pay the bill! He shouts, 'You will<strong> rue</strong> the day you stole my silver!'.	State of mind + Previously: To<strong> rue</strong> something is to let your <em>state of mind</em> be ruled by whatever <em>previously</em> happened.	I'm English so when I go to Paris, they really <em>resent</em> me. Sitting in a cafe on any<strong> rue</strong>, I can see the <em>resentment</em> in the <em>waitresses'</em> faces. After what they do to my food, I<strong> rue</strong> eating there! [after gorgon].		
平		even	This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of <b>even</b>. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.	* As a primitive, this kanji can keep its pictographic meaning of a <i>water lily</i>.	5	1596	1484	39	ヘイ、ビョウ、ヒョウ	たい.ら、-だいら、ひら、ひら-	There's an<strong> even</strong> covering of <em>water lilies</em> on the pond at 金閣寺 （きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.	<strong>Even</strong> if Heisig showed me in person, I still wouldn't believe that this is a <em>water lily</em>. I don't get it.	The graph of an<strong> even</strong> function [f(x)] will be symmetrical over the y-axis, as this kanji appears to be.	If you take scissors and cut off the upper part of its primitive and then close your scissors, you get an<strong> even</strong> kanji.	"This is<strong> even</strong> as in flat, level, smooth, calm (not like ""even if"" or ""even though"")."		
呼		call	"<i>Mouth</i> . . . <i>water lily</i>. Note: this is the one time that the ""stem"" has a barb at the end. Work this fact into your story."		8	1597	1485	39	コ	よ.ぶ	I'm a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a <em>lily pad</em> with a <em>fishing hook at the stem</em> and a <em>mouth</em> to<strong> call</strong> me whenever it catches something.	I just follow the <strong>calls</strong> from the frogs <em>mouths</em> on the <em>lily pads</em> to <em>hook</em> them.	The right portion of this character isn't a water lily at all; we will take it to be a <em>broken hand</em> (see how if you rotate the second and third strokes, you approach the appearance of the character for hand?). In this character, we see someone who is trapped with a <em>broken hand</em> opening their <em>mouth</em> to<strong> call</strong> for help.	"Inspired by dingomick: 'Budd' - 'weis' - 'er'<strong> call</strong> the frogs <em>mouths</em> from the <em>liliy pads</em>, working to get you <em>hooked</em> on beer. <a href=""http://youtube.com/watch?v=f3mXaATLeRM"">http://youtube.com/watch?v=f3mXaATLeRM</a>."	Not really <em>even</em> and first and last strokes are a different stroke type. Frog with open <em>mouth</em><strong> call</strong>ing out as he slips off the <em>water-lily, bending it out of shape</em>.		
坪		two-mat area	This kanji belongs to an old Japanese system of measurement and indicates an area of about 36 square feet, or the <b>area</b> taken up by <b>two</b> tatami <b>mats</b>. Its elements: <i>ground</i> . . . <i>water lily</i>.		8	1598	1486	39	ヘイ	つぼ	A<strong> two-mat area</strong> is just about as much <em>ground</em> as you will need for a <em>lily</em> pond.	A<strong> two-mat area</strong> is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won't be comfortable unless the <em>ground</em> is <em>even</em>.	A<strong> two-mat area</strong> is exactly how much ground a giant lilypad will cover.	Place the two mats on the <em>ground</em> <em>even</em>ly to get a<strong> two-mat area</strong>.	Since one full tatami mat's length is twice as long as its width, a two mat area would create an even, square floorspace: a somewhat more convenient unit of measuring the ground.		
評		evaluate	Words . . . water lily.		12	1599	1487	39	ヒョウ		Good <strong>evaluation</strong> should always be <em>words</em> of <em>even</em> fairness.	You get an <strong>evaluation</strong> copy of MS <em>Word</em> because you want to <strong>evaluate</strong> whether it's worth buying the full version. At the end of the <strong>evaluation</strong> period the CD turns into a <em>lily</em>pad so you can't use it any more (an innovative new copy-protection trick).	Gardeners have developed many <em>words</em> to<strong> evaluate</strong> the health of <em>lilies</em>.	The first time I delivered a speech in japanese it was a mess! The juries (it was contest)<strong> Evaluate</strong>d me and gave me a bad score because the Words were not said in an Even tone. I guess I was too nervous (true story).	<em>Words</em> have to come out in an <em>even</em> tone during a Japanese speaking test, otherwise your <strong>evalutation</strong> will have bad <strong>comments</strong> written all over it, resulting in <strong>criticism</strong> from your teacher. He your (ひょう) teacher though, so it's his fault! NOTE: This kanji also means 'comment' & 'criticism'.

刹		moment	"The key word here is the noun meaning ""a breif moment."" 胸		bosom	Part of the body . . . bound up . . . villain.		10	1604	1491	39	キョウ	むね、むな-	<strong>Bosom</strong> is a Flesh part that should be bound up lest it provoke villian thoughts. One has to wonder how these clothes stay on their body at all…	Just think of the heroine's <strong>bosom</strong> in a movie. The <em>villain</em> <em>ties up</em> the heroine (to the traintracks or the conveyor belt etc) but her <strong>bosom</strong> is the <em>body part</em> that is always left sticking out.	Here's an easy way to defeat the bad guy: have Wonder Woman do topless jumping jacks and quickly <em>bind up the villain</em> while he ogles the most seductive <em>part of her body</em>—her<strong> bosom</strong>.	In Japanese lyrics, 胸 often refers to one's heart, one's soul. It is the part of one's body (metaphorically speaking) which wraps, according to Christian theology, our evil ways.		
離		detach	"<i>Top hat</i> . . . <i>villain</i> . . . <i>belt</i> . . . <i>elbow</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. This is potentially one of the most difficult characters to remember. Tackle it positively and let the image ""sink in"" by carrying it around with you today and calling it up in your spare moments."		18	1605	1492	39	リ	はな.れる、はな.す	I've finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all <em>villains</em>. Finally, I'm about to fight him. But what's this? He's suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the <em>elbow</em>. Strange. I walk up to him and<strong> detach</strong> his left arm. Very strange. I undo his <em>belt</em>, and take off his <em>top hat</em>… BLAST! It was just a decoy <em>turkey</em>!	The most ridiculous character ever dreamt up for a film.<strong> DETACH</strong>O, a top-hat wearing villian who is able to<strong> detach</strong> his body parts for use as weapons. His most powerful weapons are his elbows, which he can<strong> detach</strong>, tie together with his belt and use as nunchucks.<strong> DETACH</strong>O has a sidekick turkey which he uses as an advanced scout as well.	I'm surprised no one has worked Oddjob, the <em>villain</em> from the James Bond movie, Goldfinger into their stories. He's the big oriental guy that killed people by throwing his <em>top hat</em> at them. He practises his technique on turkeys,<strong> detach</strong>ing their heads in the process. Being an assassin, he can also kill people by garroting them with his <em>belt</em> or smashing them with his <em>elbows</em>.	"As for the left element - 离 - i think it'd be interesting to read the following wiki-article <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi_"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi_</a>(mythology). This is <em>chi</em> (in this case <em>ri</em>) - mythological hornless dragon or <em>wyvern</em>. Best to remember it as a primitive, because it appears in a number of rare kanji: 禽 (2049); 璃 (2048); 檎 (2050);擒. Though Heisig defined this element as <em>sheik</em> in RTK3, this is completely arbitrary."	This <em>turkey</em> is a <em>top hat</em>-wearing <em>villain</em>, and he keeps his own <em>elbows</em> in his <em>belt</em>, gunslinger style, ready to<strong> detach</strong> them and throw them one after another like boomerangs when necessary.		
璃		crystal	This kanji refers to one of the seven classical stones of China. Its elements: <i>jewel</i> . . . <i>top hat</i> . . . <i>villain</i> . . . <i>belt</i> . . . <i>elbow</i>.		14	1606	2048	39	リ		The <em>King</em>'s<strong> crystal</strong> got <em>detached</em> from his royal throne, and is missing! Looks like the turkey got away with it. He's no where to be seen!	"In my story for detatch <a href=""../v4/1492.html"">detach</a> (#1492 離), the left side primitive was <em>junkie</em>. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the <em>junkie</em> is getting a fix of<strong> crystal</strong> meth: the <em>jewel</em> in the crown of today's drugs."	"<em>Michael Jackson</em> is the <em>king</em> of pop, wearing his<strong> crystal</strong> rhinestone glove (see <a href=""../v4/1492.html"">detach</a> (#1492 離)."	Primitive: <em>Sheik</em> is too vague for me. How about Prince Ali, Aladdin dressed up like a sheik to impress Princess Jasmine? I'll use Aladdin or Prince Ali for this primitive, whichever works best in a story. Story: Prince Ali holds up a large<strong> crystal</strong> <em>jewel</em> to impress Princess Jasmine. She looks quite bored, but the Sultan looks thrilled!	When Oddjob ran out of shoes to throw he tossed a<strong> crystal</strong> ball.		
殺		kill	Sheaf . . . tree . . . missile.		10	1607	1493	39	サツ、サイ、セツ	ころ.す、-ごろ.し、そ.ぐ	"Wolverine (sheaf, see <a href=""../v4/1488.html"">reap</a> (#1488 刈)) leaps over a tree and with one swipe of his claws<strong> kill</strong>s a bad guy aiming a missle launcher."	I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to<strong> kill</strong> your enemies with <em>sheafs of wood</em> used as <em>missiles</em>.	"This is the Monty Python ""How not to be seen"" sketch (<a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_Not_To_Be_Seen"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_Not_To_Be_Seen</a>) where they use heat seeking <em>missiles</em> to<strong> kill</strong> people first behind <em>sheafs</em> of hay and then behind <em>trees</em>."	Sheaf, tree, missile Someone is trying to<strong> kill</strong> you. They've fired a heat seeking missile at you. You're confused with the stress and think it is a wheat seeking missile - you put a sheaf at the top of a tree to mislead it.	Wolverine, from atop a <em>tree</em>, blasts his <em>semen</em> into the below enemy's mouth, which<strong> kill</strong>s him instantly.		
爽		bracing	The sense of the key word is of something refreshing and invigorating. It is made up of the <i>St. Bernard</i> and a pair of <i>sheaves</i> on each side.		11	1608	2855	39	ソウ	あき.らか、さわ.やか、たがう	The <em>St Bernard</em> is<strong> bracing</strong> itself for an operation requiring <em>four stitches</em>.	A <em>large</em> airship drops parachuting <em>Wolverine</em> clones into the<strong> bracing</strong> night air.	That old <em>St. Bernard</em> was just barely limping around, but me, I <em>stitched</em> up the ol' chap and I dare say that the operation was quite<strong> bracing</strong>.	Often used in shaving lotion and fragrance descriptions 爽やか さわやか refreshing,<strong> bracing</strong>, sweet, clear. Story: Slap some alcohol-based さわやか aftershave lotion onto the <em>4</em> <em>big</em> x-shaped hockey <em>stitches</em> on your face. That's<strong> bracing</strong>!	St. Bernard dog had a refreshing<strong> bracing</strong> bath and now is shaking all the water out of his fur. The drops are thrown in all direction and that's why the have an x shape in the pictogram.		
純		genuine	Thread . . . earthworm.		10	1609	1494	39	ジュン		"<em>Earthworm Jim's</em> prized possession is a<strong> genuine</strong> copy of the #1 issue of <em>Spiderman</em>."	You need to attach a<strong> genuine</strong> earthworm to the thread. With plastic bait you won't catch anything.	The real <em>Spiderman</em> loves to eat <em>earthworms</em>—they provide essential nutrients that make his threads stronger. So next time someone goes around claiming to be the real,<strong> genuine</strong> Spiderman, give him a few earthworms to eat.	For remembering the primitive earthworm: <em>Drops of</em> rain were falling so I took my <em>shovel</em> to dig up some <strong>earthworms</strong> to put them on my <em>fishook</em>….. My story: To have a<strong> genuine</strong> fishing line you don't just pick up a stick but you also attach some<em> thread </em>onto it and at the end an <em>earthworm</em> must be hung.	"<em>Earthworm Jim's</em> prized possession is a<strong> genuine</strong> copy of the #1 issue of <em>Spiderman</em>. And oddly enough, <em>Spiderman</em>'s most prized possession is a<strong> genuine</strong> first edition of <em>Earthworm</em> Jim."

辛		spicy	This character pictures food whose taste is so hot and <b>spicy</b> that it makes the hairs on your body <i>stand up</i> as straight as <i>needles</i>.	* As a primitive, we shall use this meaning of <i>spicy</i>, except when the two extra strokes are added to the bottom, giving it the form of a tree. Then we take its alternate meaning of a <i>red pepper</i> plant. The connection is obvious.	7	1612	1496	39	シン	から.い、つら.い、-づら.い、かのと	Eating<strong> spicy</strong> food makes you <em>stand up</em> <em>ten</em> times faster than usual, 'cause you just need to get something to drink!	Eating<strong> spicy</strong> food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.	This caracter has 2 meaning :<strong> Spicy</strong> -> see book (からい） and heart-breaking painful （つらい） => stand up on barefooted on needles is painful.	After eating really<strong> spicy</strong> food you will probably spend most of the next day <em>stading</em> up because it will feel like you have a <em>needle</em> stuck up your arse. Numbers dont work well for me.	<strong>Spicy</strong> like drinking a vase full of needles.		
辞		resign	Tongue . . . spicy.		13	1613	1497	39	ジ	や.める、いな.む	This guy's job is tasting the <em>spicy curry</em> at the local Indian Food Factory. After my <em>tongue</em> touched the most <em>spicy</em> pepper of all, I had to <strong>resign</strong> from the contest…too hot for me!	"When they guy goes to his boss to<strong> resign</strong> from the Indian Food Factory (see Fuaburisu's story) all he can say is ""Tongue….Spicy"". This helps me remember the stroke order. 辞める 【やめる】 (v1) to retire, (P) 辞意 【じい】 (n) intention to<strong> resign</strong>, (P) お辞儀 【おじぎ】 (n,vs) bow, (P)."	When you're<strong> resign</strong>ing, it's often hard to know what to say. You could say that your tongue( 舌 ) is in pain ( 辛い ).		
梓		catalpa	Tree . . . spicy.		11	1614	1498	39	シ	あずさ	"The<strong> CATALPA</strong> is the tree that bears the SPICY Indian bean (NOTE - The<strong> Catalpa</strong> is also known as the ""Indian Bean"" due to the bean pods that grow from it)."	The <strong>caterpillar's</strong> favorite <em>tree</em> is the <strong>catalpa</strong> because it tastes <em>spicy</em>.	Tree + Spicy; The<strong> catalpa</strong> <em>tree</em> has seed pods that look like <em>spicy</em> peppers.	"I know the <strong>Catalpa</strong> as the ""promise tree"". A young person will cite the person he or she loves under a <strong>Catalpa</strong> <em>tree</em> to declare his or her feelings. The fact that the right primitive means both <em>spicy</em> and <em>bitter</em> illustrates the hesitance and stress that precedes the ultimate reply."	This kanji is barely used. Just rename the keyword to PEPPER TREE (so you don't need a story) and move on. If you do a google image search for the kanji 梓 , you'll find that this character almost exclusively refers to the female name あずさ (by the way, you will see some cute girls).

壁		wall	Ketchup . . . ground.		16	1616	1500	39	ヘキ	かべ	Did anyone else used to put <em>ketchup</em> packets on the <em>ground</em> and jump on them so they spattered on the <strong>wall</strong>? Excited about kanji 1500?	The <strong>ketchup</strong> primitive has an even more saucy true meaning: <em>Flag</em> means buttocks, <em>mouth</em> means hole and <em>spicy</em> means penetrate…	Heisig mentions <em>ketchup</em>, which I remember by imagining that someone is wiping the <em>ketchup</em> from their <em>mouth</em> with a <em>flag</em>, keeping everyone <em>standing</em> on pins and <em>needles</em>, means <em>false</em> as a kanji. So: the <em>false</em><strong> wall</strong> led to a secret lair under<em>ground</em>.		
璧		holed gem	The <b>holed gem</b> to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: <i>ketchup</i> . . . <i>ball</i>.		18	1617	3021	39	ヘキ	たま	This kanji shows a policeman with a <strong>holed gem</strong> (which can be thought of as <em>jewelry</em>, I guess), but he thinks it's a doughnut. For some reason though, he liked his doughnuts with ketchup on them, so he added some, and tried to take a bite. He lost a few teeth on the process.	<strong>perfection</strong>: Only the tomatoes of perfection, comparable to jewels, were used for the expensive ketchup.	"完璧 <a href=""../v4/3021.html"">holed gem</a> (#3021 璧) <strong>Holed Gem</strong> RTK ＃1500.1 ヘキ … Parts: 壁 - 土 , 玉 … Note: This is a new official Kanji added 05/10 to the Japanese lists. Japanese people mix this and 壁 up all the time, so learn them together. <strong>Holed Gem</strong> is the official Heisig Keyword. (though it has nothing to do with IRL usage. IRL this is just the second half of 完璧 . It's only used in that compound, but that compound is very very common, and means <strong>Perfect!</strong> as an exclamation. …"	It's a little known fact that <em>ketchup</em> is highly corrosive and is used to cut <strong>holes</strong> into <strong>gemstones</strong> so they can be put onto chains. This kanji shows a piece of <em>Jade</em> with a blob of <em>ketchup</em> on the top eating a hole through it.	<strong>Holed Gem</strong>, <em>ketchup</em>, <em>jewel</em>. According to Rikichan, this is bi (ancient Chinese artifact, flat jade or glass disc with a circular hole in the centre). It used to be a perfect un<strong>holed gem</strong> until Indiana Jones showed up and replaced the <em>jewel</em> in the center with <em>ketchup</em>. All they were left with was a piece of worthless glass with a hole in middle. But it did taste good.

This is because the spicy peppers cause the metal to erode very quickly, thereby rendering the axe completely useless."

幸		happiness	Simply by turning the dot at the top of the primitive for <i>spicy</i> into a cross shape, we move from things bitter and <i>spicy</i> to things <b>happy</b>.		8	1622	1505	39	コウ	さいわ.い、さち、しあわ.せ	<strong>happiness</strong> is the ONE bite of SPICY curry.	"This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%8C%E5%B9%B8%E3%81%9B%E3%81%8B%E3%82%89%E4%B8%80%E6%9C%AC%E5%8F%96%E3%82%8B%E3%81%A8%E8%BE%9B%E3%81%84%E3%80%8D"">「幸せから一本取ると辛い」</a> – if you take but one stroke away from<strong> happiness</strong>, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百 )."	<strong>Happiness</strong> and pain(spicy) are just one stroke diffence. It's a fine balance.	"A rare instance in which Heisig made a mistake in the primitives. The bottom is not <em>spicy</em>, because there is no <em>vase</em> or <em>standing</em> here–the first horizontal stroke of the ""vase"" is too long. Rather, this is <em>soil</em> and a new primitive below, which we shall call a garden-variety <em>goat</em>. It's like the <em>mountain goat</em> in frame 1959, just not in the mountains. Thus,<strong> happiness</strong> is exemplified by a <em>goat</em> nibbling on <em>soil</em>ed garbage on the <em>ground</em>. (We'll only get to use <em>goat</em> once more, in frame 1613)."	<strong>Happiness</strong> adds a bit of spice to your life.		
執		tenacious	Happiness . . . fat man.		11	1623	1506	39	シツ、シュウ	と.る	<strong>Tenacious</strong>-D is <em>happy</em> band led by a <em>fat man</em>. (It's<strong> Tenacious</strong>-D time, ya muthafucka', gwaoh!).	To be<strong> tenacious</strong>, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don't discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn't drive you to give up). The most<strong> tenacious</strong> person of all time was happy round Buddha!	The <em>fat man</em> Santa Claus is <strong>tenacious</strong> about carrying out his duty to bring <em>happiness</em> to all the children of the world on Christmas day.	<strong>Tenacious</strong> D is a band of happy, round fellows.	If you are<strong> tenacious</strong> about finding <em>happiness</em>, you will become well <em>round</em>ed.
