叫		shout	Mouth . . . cornucopia.		6	1626	1508	39	キョウ	さけ.ぶ	There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he<strong> shout</strong>ed and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.	You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to<strong> SHOUT</strong> lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the<strong> shout</strong>s are 4 letter words.	FOUR!! like in golf, someone<strong> shout</strong>s four and you see the golf ball right in front of you.	"<strong>Note</strong>: the <em>cornucopia</em> primitive is not described adequately in Heisig. It has 3 strokes as opposed to 2 as mentioned in the book, but on the left may have 2 or 3 depending on who you ask… Also, on the left, the long stroke is written first. See <a href=""http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=921"">http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=921</a> and <a href=""http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=185"">http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=185</a> for more."	Your <em>mouth</em> is used <em>4</em><strong> shout</strong>ing.		
糾		twist	Thread . . . cornucopia.		9	1627	1509	39	キュウ	ただ.す	A Pepsi promotion where you<strong> twist</strong> off the cap to find pictures of your favorite heroes like <em>Spider-Man</em> or members of the <em>Fantastic Four</em>.	[twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of <strong>twist</strong>s are difficult to write, because of the <em>cornucopia</em> of <em>threads</em> the author has to manage.	"<em>Spiderman</em> really, really just wants to dance the<strong> twist</strong>. But he doesn't have time to seek out a teacher and go to lessons. So he wishes into his <em>cornucopia</em> and who should appear from the horn of plenty but Chubby Checker himself, already mid way through his famous refrain: ""Come on baby, let's do the<strong> twist</strong>…""."	+++SPOILER ALERT+++ For the <strong>twist</strong> to the next <em>spiderman</em> movie we'll find out that Peter Parker's seemingly endless supply of web is actually produced by a <em>cornucopia</em>.	Spiderman counts in his new cover band singing cheesy golden oldies. 1,2,3,<em>4</em>..Lets<strong> twist</strong> again…		
収		income	<i>Cornucopia</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>. Keep distinct from both <i>fare</i> (Frame 1079) and <i>salary</i> (Frame 1449).		4	1628	1510	39	シュウ	おさ.める、おさ.まる	"Prostitutes can make a veritable <em>cornucopia</em> of<strong> income</strong> by using their <em>crotches</em> – they put the ""come"" in ""income."" (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like <a href=""../v4/906.html"">profit</a> (#906 利) or <a href=""../v4/893.html"">earnings</a> (#893 稼))."	Women love men with money. If you have a high<strong> income</strong> you can get a cornicopia of crotches.	<strong>STROKE ORDER WARNING:</strong> The order in which the <em>cornucopia</em> primitive is written is altered here. First the long vertical bar, then the L part in either one or two strokes (this seems to vary in different reference materials).	The <em>Fantastic Four</em> use Jessica Alba's <em>crotch</em> to gain some extra<strong> income</strong>.	A prostitute with <em>4 crotches</em> could sure pull in a big<strong> income</strong>.		
卑		lowly	A drop of . . . brains . . . cornucopia.		9	1629	1511	39	ヒ	いや.しい、いや.しむ、いや.しめる	A<strong> LOWLY</strong> single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.	<strong>Lowly</strong> people only have a <em>drop of brains</em> and use nothing but <em>4-letter words</em>.	The <strong>lowly</strong> people with <em>a drop of brains</em> are the ones who labor to produce the <em>cornucopia</em>.	"That <em>Fantastic Four</em> movie was so<strong> lowly</strong>, I only needed a <em>drop</em> of <em>brains</em> to watch it. Note: When written with only 8 strokes, this kanji is assigned the meaning ""Chinese pirated DVDs"" (rough copies of already<strong> lowly</strong> movies)."	Even a<strong> lowly</strong> person of low birth can - with a <em>bit of brains</em> - find a <em>cornucopia</em> in this land of plenty.		
碑		tombstone	Rock . . . lowly.		14	1630	1512	39	ヒ	いしぶみ	There is a grave of a <em>lowly</em> man with a<strong> tombstone</strong> made of a simple, small <em>stone</em>. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the <em>stone</em>, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as <em>lowly</em> as I once was”.	A STONE makes a LOWLY<strong> TOMBSTONE</strong>.	Rocks are actually sentient beings with social structure, and it just so happens that the <em>lowliest of stones</em> are chosen to end up as humiliating<strong> tombstone</strong>s.	A simple stone serves as the<strong> tombstone</strong> of a lowly peasant.	The <em>lowly</em> only get a solitary <em>rock</em> upon their resting places as a<strong> tombstone</strong> (while the highly get monuments like Stone Henge).		
陸		land	"The sense of <b>land</b> carried by this kanji is distinct from <i>soil</i> (Frame 161) and <i>ground</i> (Frame 554) in that it is meant to represent <b>land</b> seen from a distance, that is, <i>land</i> as opposed to ""water."" Its elements: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>rice seedlings</i> . . . <i>ground</i>."		11	1631	1513	39	リク、ロク	おか	My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a <em>pinnacle</em>, which the newly-awakened <em>rice-seedlings</em> who are still stuck in the <em>ground</em> can see. Could it be the Promised<strong> Land</strong>?	When sailors see<strong> land</strong> in the distance, they first see the <em>pinnacles</em> of the new<strong> land</strong>, but when they come close enough they'll be able to make out the <em>rice seedlings</em>, and finally the <em>ground</em>!	(圥 is the rare kanji for a mushroom. Sticking out of the <em>ground</em> like little knubby <em>legs</em>, it's pretty easy to remember.) Story ~ The<strong> land</strong> around <em>The Pinnacle</em> has <em>mushrooms</em> covering the <em>ground</em>.	Primitive: Soil covered human legs is the result of planting rice seedlings into rice paddies all day. Poor rice farmers!	The Pinnacle's<strong> land</strong> is so valuable that they cannot afford to let a single rice seedling be planted in the soil.		
睦		intimate	Eye . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.		13	1632	1514	39	ボク、モク	むつ.まじい、むつ.む、むつ.ぶ	I keep an<strong> intimate</strong> relationship with my rice seedlings – I never take my eye from the soil.	"<a href=""../v4/1513.html"">land</a> (#1513 陸) Some of them begin to see <em>eye</em> to eye about the possibility of reaching the promised land. A group of awakened <em>rice-seedlings stuck in the ground</em> becomes<strong> intimate</strong> and starts to form a plan."	Make <em>eye</em> contact with the sexy girl planting <em>rice seedlings</em> and you can get <strong>intimate</strong> with her on the <em>ground</em>.	So are you just <em>eying</em> my <em>mushroom</em>, or do you want to get<strong> intimate</strong>?	Here the EYE of Sauron wants to form an<strong> INTIMATE</strong> bond (I SEE YOU, there is no life in the void!) with FRODO each time he wears the ring. But FRODO, overcome by the intimacy, takes off the ring and throws it to the GROUND.		
勢		forces	Rice seedlings . . ground . . . fat man . . . muscle.		13	1633	1515	39	セイ、ゼイ	いきお.い、はずみ	"<a href=""../v4/1513.html"">land</a> (#1513 陸) The <em>rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil</em> gather <em>round</em> in a circle. Their combined <em>power</em><strong> forces</strong> them out of the ground at last."	<em>Mushroom</em>…<em>Fat man</em>….= <em>Mario</em>. <em>Mario</em> jumps on top of Bowser's<strong> forces</strong>, crushing their evil <em>power</em>.	The <em>fat</em> sumo-farmer<strong> forces</strong> <em>rice seedlings</em> into the <em>ground</em> with his huge <em>muscles</em>. With his combination of mass and strength, it's not suprising very few of the seedlings survive and he is <strong>forced</strong> to diet.	Looks like a physics formula to me: rate of time (rate of growth of <em>rice seedlings</em>) over the rate of (<em>ground</em>) distance <em>round</em>ed and multiplied by <em>power</em> gives you <strong>forces</strong>.	<strong>Halfway</strong> the journey of 3030 kanji (both Heisig 一 & 三 ), you watch the long road that lies ahead of you, and you start to feel down and overwhelmed… like if you were being swallowed by <em>quicksand - grounds</em>… but you soon realize that if you made it this far, you can keep going and eventually finish! You <em>round</em> up all the will-<em>force</em> UNDER your control, and get out of this rut! And just like you, our<strong> FORCES</strong> combined will let us finish this journey! <strong>Let's go users!!</strong>.		
熱		heat	Rice seedlings . . . ground . . . fat man . . . oven fire.		15	1634	1516	39	ネツ	あつ.い	"<a href=""../v4/1513.html"">land</a> (#1513 陸) The <em>rice-seedlings</em> (newly freed from the ground but with <em>soil</em> still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle <em>around</em> an <em>oven fire</em>. They need to<strong> heat</strong> up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?)."	"<strong>Heat</strong> up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for ""atsui"" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather)."	"This is <em>Mario</em> avoiding the <em>fire</em>'s<strong> heat</strong>. <a href=""http://retromedia.ign.com/retro/image/article/870/870378/super-mario-bros-20080429110134449_640w.jpg"">http://retromedia.ign.com/retro/image/article/870/870378/super-mario-bros-20080429110134449_640w.jpg</a>."	"Just a comment on Erikkusan's story: Although one of the pronunciations of this kanji is ""atsui"" this isn't the atsui that you feel in Tokyo in August, (which is Frame 1260's ""sultry' 暑 ). This atsui is the one when you touch something hot, like a fry pan. Another reading of this is ""netsu,"" which is the ""fever"" this fat man may feel after planting the rice seedlings."	"(NB: The top of 熱 (埶) is a rare kanji meaning ""art"". We already have <a href=""../v4/1525.html"">art</a> (#1525 術) so I call it <em>ARTISTRY</em>.) Keeping a primitive dwelling<strong> HEAT</strong>ed ain't easy! It requires much <em>ARTISTRY</em> to keep those <em>EMBERS</em> glowing. (I decompose <em>ARTISTRY</em> as <em>DIVOT</em> (坴) … <em>ROUND</em>: Tiger Woods' uncanny <em>ARTISTRY</em> for whacking <em>DIVOT</em>s as <em>ROUND</em> as golf balls. 坴 is a rare kanji meaning ""clod""; we already have <a href=""../v4/2024.html"">clod</a> (#2024 塊) so I call it <em>DIVOT</em>; I see it pictographically: a golfer [above] whacking a divot [below].)."		
菱		diamond	Named after a <b>diamond</b>-shaped flower (the water caltrop), this key word refers to things shaped like a <b>diamond</b>. Its elements: <i>flower</i> . . . <i>rice seedlings</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i>.		11	1635	1517	39	リョウ	ひし	"<a href=""../v4/1513.html"">land</a> (#1513 陸) Deciding to use the<strong> diamond</strong>-shaped water caltrop <em>flower</em> as cover/protection, the <em>rice-seedlings</em> with their <em>walking legs</em> (now free from soil), can start their journey."	Some girls want<strong> diamond</strong>s, but others will be satisfied with just <em>flowers</em>. However if you think you can win her over with <em>rice seedlings</em>, expect her to get up on her <em>walking legs</em> and walk on out!	I gave her a <em>flower </em> and a <strong>diamond</strong>. We went for a walk through the <em>rice seedlings</em> after she said yes.	"Mitsubishi! In Japanese, 三菱 .. ""Three<strong> Diamond</strong>s"" .. Now look at their logo! THREE<strong> DIAMOND</strong>S. Not really a story for remembering this kanji, just wanted to share how I was just amazed by something obvious."	I would give that lady a<strong> diamond</strong>, if she let me plant a rice seedling in her flower between her walking legs…		
陵		mausoleum	Pinnacle . . . rice seedlings . . . walking legs.		11	1636	1518	39	リョウ	みささぎ	"<a href=""../v4/1513.html"">land</a> (#1513 陸) However, the <em>pinnacle</em> that the <em>rice-seedlings</em> finally reach with the use of their <em>walking legs</em> turns out not to be the Promised Land after all, but simply a<strong> mausoleum</strong> (containing many dead rice-seedlings exhausted from previous quests?). Oh no!"	On top of <em>The Pinnacle</em> is a <strong>masoleum</strong> for rice seedling farmers. They make an annual <em>walking</em> pilgrimage there.	At the pinnicle is a mausolem. The ground is sown with rice seedings to stop the dead from rising on walking legs.	Every year, thousands <em>walk</em> up <em>The Pinnacle</em> to see the <em>Mushroom</em><strong> Mausoleum</strong>. It's shaped like a <em>mushroom</em>, surrounded by <em>mushrooms</em>, and supposedly Toad is enshrined inside (he died in a fiery Rainbow Road accident).	"Ancient Japanese built a<strong> mausoleum</strong> for the ""unknown rice farmer"". It's on the <em>pinnacle</em> of Mt. Fuji, and it has a statue of a guy with huge <em>walking legs</em> planting <em>rice seedlings</em> as he goes."		
亥		sign of the hog	This kanji is the 12th sign of the Chinese zodiac: the <b>sign of the hog</b>. It is best learned by thinking of an acorn-eating <b>hog</b> in connection with the primitive meaning given below.	* The <i>top hat</i> represents the external shape of the <i>acorn</i>, and the unusual but easily written complex of strokes beneath it (which you might also see as distortions of an <i>elbow</i> and <i>person</i>) stands for the mysterious secret whereby the <i>acorn</i> contains the oak tree in a nutshell.	6	1637	1519	39	ガイ、カイ	い	A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.	Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The<strong> sign of the hog</strong> was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a <em>top hat</em>, sticking his <em>elbow</em> into the <em>person</em> next to him.	This is easy, if you know Mr. Peanut, the logo of Planters. Replace his face or body with an acorn and you have Mr. Acorn, the logo /<strong> sign of the hog</strong>. He wears the same <em>top hat</em>, has the same turned out <em>elbow</em> holding a diagonal <em>walking stick</em>, and poses like a <em>human</em>.	Warning: Stroke order in book is wrong. The top hat should be written as normal.	Q: What is the difference between a pig and a hog? A: A hog is the generic term for all swine. Pigs are immature hogs weighing less than 125 pounds. Other swine related terms include the following: Piglet: a baby swine less than ten weeks old (nursing pig) Sow: a female pig that has had a litter Boar: a male hog (with tusks?).		
核		nucleus	Tree . . . acorn.		10	1638	1520	39	カク		The<strong> nucleus</strong> of an oak TREE is an ACORN.	In the<strong> nucleus</strong> of the acorn, all the DNA is stored – the building blocks for a new tree.	Ernest Rutherford discovered the<strong> Nucleus</strong>. Picture him sitting under a tree pondering atoms, after an ACORN falls on him he suddenly understands that each atom has a<strong> nucleus</strong>.	[nucleus; core; kernel] Right in the <strong>nucleus</strong> of the <em>acorn</em>, you can find a future <em>tree</em>.	Imagine the <em>tree</em> as the<strong> nucleus</strong>, and the <em>acorn</em> as the electrons rotating out around it. It's a forest of <strong>nuclei</strong>!		
刻		engrave	Acorn . . . saber.		8	1639	1521	39	コク	きざ.む、きざ.み	This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with <em>sabres</em>, distinct from samurai) used to<strong> engrave</strong> the kanji for his name onto <em>acorns</em>, and throw the <em>acorns</em> to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the <em>acorn</em> and read the<strong> engrave</strong>d kanji, they were already dead.	While it's traditional for lovers to<strong> engrave</strong> their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an <em>acorn</em> with his <em>sabre</em>.	"TIP: This also means ""time""… STORY: The Swiss watchmaker is a master<strong> engrave</strong>r. He<strong> engrave</strong>s the minutes and seconds on an <em>acorn</em> using a tiny <em>saber</em> to make a miniature cuckoo clock… 遅刻 [ちこく]."	"Whenever i think of ""engraving"" i think of wedding invitations. :) well there's this one bride who wanted to be unique, so rather than on paper, she decided to<strong> engrave</strong> their wedding invitations on an <em>acorn</em> with a <em>sabre</em>, and give that out to their guests. (Not true story, but with brides' crazy ideas these days, I wouldn't be surprised…) :-)."	Just picture Zorro using his <em>saber</em> to<strong> engrave</strong> his name out on a giant <em>acorn</em>.		
該		above-stated	Words . . . acorn.		13	1640	1522	39	ガイ		I asked my teacher what this strange <em>word</em> meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the<strong> above-stated</strong> paragraph before throwing an <em>acorn</em> at me!	The<strong> above-stated</strong> <em>words</em> are the <em>acorn</em> from which the following statement grows.	I literally imagined atree with <em>words</em> stuck on <em>acorns</em>. And thus the <em>words</em> are<strong> above-stated</strong> (that is until they fall on your head I guess). (This one really needs a mental picture).	"<strong>ABOVE-STATED</strong> is a synonym with ACORNmentioned. I mean ""aforementioned"". Really easy to remember if you just think of ACORNmentioned."	You, a hog, just asked what the word means. Socrates answers:'The meaning of this word is stated above' 'yes, but I don't understand the kanji.' S:'Well it is stated above' ' I just told you that I dont understand it.' S:'The word is stated above''Yes but…' S:' You dum hog, stated above is the word'… this could go on for a while as the kanji you are pointing to is 該 .

劾		censure	Acorn . . . muscle.		8	1642	1523	39	ガイ		<em>Acorn Power</em> is the people's way to<strong> CENSURE</strong> a congressman you don't agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today. "<strong>Censure</strong> is the political equivalent of a ""strongly worded letter,"" according to Cornell's School of Law. It is a flex of muscle by congress against the current president, but it is a very weak one. Imagine<strong> censure</strong> as congress flexing as hard as it can, only to have a little <em>acorn</em>-sized bump of <em>muscle</em> pop up suddenly."

寒		cold	House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . ice.		12	1645	1526	39	カン	さむ.い	A<strong> cold</strong> lunch: in the <em>house</em>, <em>celery</em>, pre cooked <em>animal legs</em> (i.e. chicken drumsticks) and <em>ice</em> tea.	Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a <em>stalk of celery</em> and a <em>pair of animal legs</em> slipping and sliding clumsily around the <em>ice</em>, and never able to leave the <em>house</em>. Eventually it got so<strong> cold</strong> that the little animal froze to death.	"The story of gordon is really great except that there is a tremendous mistake : this kanji is used for the weather , the temperature (samui 寒い ) …. not for the feeling to the touch : for this one it's tsumetai 冷たい <a href=""../v4/1404.html"">cool</a> (#1404 冷) the jap HOUSE are infamous for being insanely<strong> cold</strong> . How much<strong> cold</strong> ? you don't even need a freezer for keeping your CELERY . Worse it's this much<strong> cold</strong> that there is some ICE on the floor and that you must have arched ANIMAL LEGS like pingoo for moving without falling."	Did you ever see that Tom and Jerry episode where they made it so<strong> cold</strong> that the inside of the <em>house</em> became a winter wonderland, and Jerry grabbed some <em>celery</em> and used his <em>animal legs</em> to skate and sled around on the <em>ice</em>? It was a real <em>celery</em>-bration, ha ha… ha..	When it's freezing<strong> cold</strong> outside (ice everywhere), it's best to stay in the house, eating celery (winter vegetable) and wear your bunny slippers (animal legs).		
塞		block up	House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . soil.		13	1646	2214	39	ソク、サイ	ふさ.ぐ、とりで、み.ちる	The A/C wasn't making the house <em>cold</em> because the filters had been <strong>blocked up</strong> with <em>dirt</em>. It doesn't matter what you<strong> block up</strong> the hole with, even <em>soil</em> will do! Just do it soon, it's freezing in here.	<strong>Block up</strong> <em>cold</em> house with <em>dirt</em>.	Occurs in heart attack ( 心筋梗塞 ). 醸		brew	Whiskey bottle . . . grass skirt.		20	1647	1527	39	ジョウ	かも.す	"On the troical island of JOU, they<strong> brew</strong> <em>whiskey</em> while wearing <em>grass skirts</em> (top hats and scarves too). To me, the grass skirt is composed of six celery sticks and a scarf. Apparently you can<strong> brew</strong> whiskey out of grass skirts. No wonder it tastes horrible.	"Note : up to frame 1530, the kanji share the same chinese reading (JOU), so don't hesitate to group them into the same environment. Here we have the ""brew""-man, who<strong> brew</strong>s some kind of <em>whiskey</em> using palm tree leaves. Instead of collecting them himself, he just buys the <em>grass skirts</em> from the people on this tropical island where he lives (which you may name the JOU island, after the chinese reading)."	"<strong>Grass Skirt</strong> primitive: Picture some Hawaiian girls, wearing <strong>grass skirts</strong> and tropical <em>scarfs</em> (or leis), doing a dance. ""3, 4, 5, <em>6</em> pick up all the <em>celery</em> sticks!""."	This<strong> brew</strong> of whiskey will cause you wear grass skirts and dance around like a maniac!		
譲		defer	Words . . . grass skirt.		20	1648	1528	39	ジョウ	ゆず.る	"(thanks chamcham) A graduate student in anthropology tells the University that he plans to<strong> defer</strong> his studies for a year, and instead conduct ""field research"" on the grass-skirt-wearing native women on the island of Jou."	The islanders<strong> defer</strong> to the <em>word</em>s of their chief Jou in his <em>grass skirt</em>.	"I talked to my Japanese spouse, who confirmed that this kanji does <em>not</em> mean ""defer"" as in ""put off, delay"". It means ""defer"" in the sense of ""submit"" or ""yield""."	OddAndersen is correct. 譲る 【ゆずる】 (v5r,vt) to turn over; to assign; to hand over; to transmit; to convey; to sell; to dispose of; to yield; to surrender; (P) 譲渡 【じょうと】 (n,vs) transfer; assignment; conveyance; (P) STORY: I heard of Japanese Boss who SUBMITTED a new notice saying all the female employees must wear GRASS SKIRTS to work. Naturally, the female employees YIELDED to the man's wishes, unable to say a single WORD.	"The island girl in the grass skirt says demurely ""I<strong> defer</strong> (yield) to your <em>words</em> of judgment, wise one"". Colonization is great."		
壌		lot	<i>Ground</i> . . . <i>grass skirt</i>. The <b>lot</b> of this key word refers to a portion of land.		16	1649	1529	39	ジョウ	つち	My dream is to buy a small <em>lot</em> on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a <em>grass skirt</em>.	On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a<strong> lot</strong>, a <em>ground</em> must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a <em>grass skirt</em>.	(RE: Stormchild) My dream is to buy a small <em>lot</em> on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing surrounded by women in<em>grass skirts</em>.	"Note : the keyword refers to a<strong> lot</strong> of land, as hinted by the <em>soil</em> primitive. This is the<strong> lot</strong> of land owned by the ""brew""-man (see ""brew""). To <em>Groundskeeper Willy</em>, the most important parcel of <em>ground</em> is the<strong> lot</strong> upon which Springfield Elementary is built.

憲		constitution	The key word refers to the fundamental guiding principles of a government or other organization. Its elements: <i>House</i> . . . <i>grow up</i> . . . <i>eyes</i> . . . <i>heart</i>.		16	1674	1554	40	ケン		The <strong>constitution</strong> is important. At least my parents thought so. In the <em>house</em> where I <em>grew up</em>, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) <em>eye</em> of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by <em>heart</em>.	The <em>house</em> of US Congress needs to <em>grow up</em>! Their <em>twisted</em> eyes have lost the <em>heart</em> of the <strong>constitution</strong>.	The original Japanese<strong> constitution</strong> is locked up deep within the Imperial Palace, <em>home</em> of the Emperor. Since its creation, it's gotten <em>bigger and bigger</em>, and it's even grown a <em>pair of eyes</em>, as well as a <em>beating heart</em>. Naturally the Emperor tries to keep this hidden from the public, but what will they do once the<strong> constitution</strong>-monster becomes big enough to destroy the palace?	I <em>grow up</em> in a <em>house</em> which values the<strong> constitution</strong>. My father always told me to look not just with my <em>eyes</em> but with my <em>heart</em> as well.	"[ +CharleyGarret + Growing up=Peter Pan] In Peter Pan's Lost Boys house, they eye the consitution every day and have learned it by heart. ""No Lost Girls, Captain Hook stinks, we'll never grow up! We'll scream till we're pink!"" (Hey, I'm trying here - there are no other Peter Pan stories.)."		
生		life	A single <i>drop</i> added to the element for <i>grow up</i> gives us the character for <b>life</b>.	* As a primitive, we may think of a microscopic cell, that miraculous unit that grows up to become a living being.	5	1675	1555	40	セイ、ショウ	い.きる、い.かす、い.ける、う.まれる、う.まれ、うまれ、う.む、お.う、は.える、は.やす、き、なま、なま-、な.る、な.す、む.す、-う	This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire<strong> LIFE</strong>, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism. Add a <em>drop</em> of miracle <em>grow</em> and a plant really comes to<strong> life</strong>.	<strong>Life</strong> starts with a <em>drop</em> of sperm and then you <em>grow up</em>.

姓		surname	Woman . . . cell.		8	1678	1557	40	セイ、ショウ		When <em>women</em> marry, they adopt the<strong> surname</strong> of their husband, signifiying the start of a new <em>life</em> together. 牲		animal sacrifice	Cow . . . cell.		9	1680	1559	40	セイ		<strong>Animal sacrifice</strong> = taking the life of a cow.	In the 21st century,<strong> animal sacrifice</strong> is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.	The whole <em>life</em> of a <em>cow</em> is like one big long<strong> animal sacrifice</strong>.	<em>Life</em> for a <em>cow</em> in India is pretty good. At least they would never be used as an animal scarifice.	"There are two kanji that should be kept separate: <a href=""../v4/643.html"">sacrifice</a> (#643 犠) ( 義 ), and this one. Think of it this way: in 義 there is a <em>cow</em> and a <em>righteous</em> person (presumably a Hindu). One must be <strong>SACRIFICE</strong>d, so naturally the righteous Hindu took the place of the holy cow. But as the Hindu is no longer alive to protect the cow, so we will now take the <em>cow's life</em> in an <strong>animal sacrifice</strong>."

隆		hump	"This character, used for everything from little <b>humps</b> of hills to camel <b>humps</b>, easily suggests the hunch on the pig's back and hind parts where the best cuts of meat are to be found (and hence the English expression for luxury, ""living high off the hog."") The elements we have to work with are: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i> . . . <i>cell</i>."		11	1682	1561	40	リュウ		You are struggling to the top across the<strong> hump</strong>s, but you suddenly see the <em>pinnacle</em> and you feel new <em>life</em> in your <em>walking legs</em>.	A woman takes her <em>bra</em> off and what happens? Nine months later the<strong> hump</strong> in her belly pops out between her <em>legs</em> as a new <em>life</em>.	I climbed to the pinnacle with my girlfriend and we immediately got to making life between her legs (humping).	<em>The Pinnacle</em>, this perfect place, did have one person with a<strong> hump</strong> on his back. Poor guy spent his whole <em>life</em> aimlessly walking around the Pinnacle, without finding anyone to relate to.	The<strong> hump</strong> of a camel is actually a separate animal resting on top of the camel. It has its own <em>walking legs</em> and its own <em>life</em>. These animals are great as pets but are very expensive. A resident of <em>The Pinnacle</em> has bought one of the expensive pets - a<strong> hump</strong> with <em>walking legs</em> and a <em>life</em> of its own - and is walking it home from the pet store.		
峰		summit	Mountain . . . walking legs . . . bushes.		10	1683	1562	40	ホウ	みね、ね	"""Walking legs"" over ""bushes"" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 <a href=""../v4/1563.html"">sew</a> (#1563 縫), 逢 <a href=""../v4/2417.html"">tryst</a> (#2417 逢), 蜂 <a href=""../v4/2687.html"">bee</a> (#2687 蜂), and 鋒 <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2768"">sword’s point</a> (#2768 鋒), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. ""Pointy"" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a <strong>summit</strong> is the <em>pointy</em> end of a <em>mountain</em>."	Moses climbs to the<strong> summit</strong> of the mountain using his walking legs to talk to the burning bush.	"If you are using the ""walking legs + bushes = pubic hair"" primitive… The nudist colony was banished to the top of the mountain's<strong> summit</strong>, so that nobody would have to see their bushes again!"	"Like in the next frame, the right side element is ""walking through bushes"". This time they're not on the road, but on a mountain, whose<strong> summit</strong> you're trying to reach. (the element will come in at least 逢 again)."	<em>Bush</em> between <em>walking legs</em> = <em>pubic hair</em>!

椿		camellia	Tree . . . springtime.		13	1691	1569	40	チン、チュン	つばき	The <em>tree</em> of <em>spring</em>. Fact: <strong>Camellia</strong> are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter [early spring?].	Anyone who's lived in Japan knows <strong>camellia</strong> are by far the first tree of spring to flower. And how can you miss those shockingly pink flowers!	The<strong> camellia</strong> <em>tree</em> got its name from all the chameleons that cover every part of it during the <em>spring</em>.	The<strong> camellia</strong> is the <em>tree</em> which brings out its own <em>springtime</em>, even when it's not springtime, as it blooms around January.	"The<strong> camellia</strong> is the famous <em>tree</em> you see blooming in early <em>spring</em>, and also, the<strong> camellia</strong> is taken from its <em>tree</em> to be used in ""flowering tea,"" as a small way to bring <em>spring</em> into your tea breaks. —- Ways you've seen<strong> camellia</strong>s that may help memorization: the tree called C. Japonica is in the<strong> camellia</strong> family, flowering teas (where the tea in sewn to a<strong> camellia</strong> flower which ""blooms"" when brewed, and this kanji is read as つばき, which is a very common anime name. similar <a href=""../v4/927.html"">chrysanthemum</a> (#927 菊), <a href=""../v4/1210.html"">wisteria</a> (#1210 藤)."

奉		dedicate	<i>Bonsai</i> . . . <i>cornstalk</i>. Use a ritualistic, religious meaning.		8	1695	1573	40	ホウ、ブ	たてまつ.る、まつ.る、ほう.ずる	To join the temple, you have to <strong>dedicate</strong> yourself to raising <em>bonsai</em> for enlightenment, and <em>cornstalks</em> for sustenance.	"A Japanese farmer who was growing <em>corn</em> tried to<strong> dedicate</strong> himself to the god of <em>corn</em> (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of <em>corn</em> : a <em>bonsai - corn</em> (a <em>corn</em> plant turned into a <em>bonsai</em>). The god was infuriated and yelled at him ""HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!"". The End."	"I used <em>does not equal</em> for the primitve(slant the line as a slash through the ""equals"" sign). Story: Decorating a <em>bonsai tree</em> for Christmas <em>does not equal</em> an <strong>observance</strong> of the real meaning of Christmas. Just like most people who<strong> dedicate</strong> themselves to appeasing the Credit Card gods for Christmas. Just <em>dosen't equal</em> the Christmas I know of."	You have to be really<strong> dedicate</strong>d to make a <em>bonsai tree</em> out of a <em>cornstalk</em>.	Once a year, the Japanese decorate bonsai trees with miniature cornstalks, and<strong> dedicate</strong> them to the Ainu, the indigenous people of Japan. (For the record, I completely made that up, and I don't think corn has anything to do with Ainu, except that it reminds me of natives).		
俸		stipend	Person . . . dedicate.		10	1696	1574	40	ホウ		<em>Mr. T</em> gets a <strong>stipend</strong> every month if he stays <em>dedicated</em> to his temple training, a very hard thing for the impatient T.	People who are highly dedicated to their jobs get good salaries/stipends.	"You must be kidding… yet another source of confusion, with <a href=""../v4/893.html"">earnings</a> (#893 稼), <a href=""../v4/1349.html"">salary</a> (#1349 給), <a href=""../v4/473.html"">assets</a> (#473 資), <a href=""../v4/194.html"">savings</a> (#194 貯) and <a href=""../v4/1510.html"">income</a> (#1510 収). A<strong> stipend</strong>, in English at least, has a connotation of only a small regular payment. Despite a life of <em>dedication</em>, <em>P</em> has to go back to a simple life of tending to <em>bonsai</em> and growing <em>corn</em> after he retires with only a small monthly<strong> stipend</strong>."	Mr. T triked the botanic intruction institute into thinking that he dedicated his whole like in bonsai and corn research. He even manage to get a<strong> stipend</strong> from that institute. In fact he's not dedicated at all when it comes to bonsai or corn… he only water them once in a while.	The<strong> stipend</strong> is given to a <em>person</em> who is very <em>dedicated</em> to his bonsai art so he can study more.		
棒		rod	Tree . . . dedicate.		12	1697	1575	40	ボウ		Ha! If you know anything about Buddhist monks, during meditation, they're slapped with <em>wooden</em> <strong>rod</strong>s to stay <em>dedicated</em> to their task.	The wood from this <em>tree</em> is <em>dedicated</em> to making <strong>rods</strong> to flog naughty kids.	"After crafting his<strong> rod</strong> from the finest <em>tree</em> in the land, Moses broke into a battle rap. ""I <em>dedicate</em> this <em>rod</em>/ To the all mighty God!""."	A<strong> rod</strong> is a piece of <em>wood</em> that is <em>dedicated</em> to a particular purpose… (use your imagination).	I dedicate this tree… to<strong> rod</strong> stuart. fuck knows why.		
謹		discreet	Words . . . cabbage.		17	1698	1576	40	キン	つつし.む	Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I<strong> discreet</strong>ly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.	<em>Cabbage</em> primitive: When a <em>cabbage</em> is <em>growing up</em>, you must put it in your <em>mouth</em> before it <em>flowers</em>, because that's when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it's called 'bolting' or something. When you're<strong> discreet</strong>, you try to make your <em>words</em> like a <em>cabbage</em>: well-layered, but in an unassuming way.	"HOW TO REMEMBER CABBAGE: it's the flower that is shoved in your mouth while you are growing up (parents force feed you cabbage), note how the ""grow up"" primitive is pushed into the mouth primitive overlapping. ""Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I<strong> discreet</strong>ly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.""."	Be<strong> discreet</strong> and don't say to old people that their heads look like cabbages, even if they're all wrinkles.	Instead of cabbage here I see the Piranha Plant from Super Mario bros. It's a flower with a mouth and it grows up out of a pipe! Seems to make sense to me. But instead of regular Mario you have Socrates! So here is what is going on. Two Piranha Plants are<strong> discreet</strong>ly discussing when they will come up out of their pipes to hit Socrates. They have to talk<strong> discreet</strong>ly however becuase Socrates is standing right next to their pipes.

T doesn't look a wee bit scared of the CABBAGE PATCH KID.	<em>Mr. T</em> is a<strong> trifle</strong> annoyed when he finds <em>cabbage</em> in his<strong> trifle</strong> (pun –<strong> trifle</strong> is a kind of dessert in UK). 勤		diligence	Cabbage . . . muscle.		12	1700	1577	40	キン、ゴン	つと.める、-づと.め、つと.まる、いそ.しむ	Growing <em>cabbages</em> takes <em>muscle</em> and<strong> diligence</strong>.	It takes great<strong> DILIGENCE</strong> for a cabbage patch dolly to build up her <em>muscles</em> and win the Miss Universe contest!	"Careful: <a href=""../v4/1722.html"">discipline</a> (#1722 修). Angry parents sued the manager. The main argument was that the manager did not show due<strong> diligence</strong> in researching the effects on <em>muscles</em> of removing <em>cabbage</em> from the diet."	With enough <strong>diligence</strong>, Koreans can turn ordinary <em>cabbage</em> into <em>powerful</em> kimchi.	Bodybuilder<strong> diligence</strong>: Eat <em>cabbage</em>. Build <em>muscles</em>. 漢		Sino-	<i>Water</i> . . . <i>scarecrow</i>. The key word has come to refer to things Chinese in general, including the kanji themselves (for which this character is used).		13	1701	1578	40	カン		In the <em>water</em> between Japan and China, the<strong> Sino-</strong> side has put <em>scarecrows</em> in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.	"Take the left to be ""kanji"" not scarecrow.<strong> Sino-</strong> (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat into learning the kanji. See the drops of sweat coming off."	<em>Kanji</em> came from across the <em>water</em>, on the<strong> Sino-</strong> side of things.	This is the character you have on the left top of this website ;-).	"<strong>Sino-</strong> (Chinese) people had to put a lot of <em>sweat/water</em> into learning the <em>kanji</em>. For right-hand <em>kanji</em> primitive - The dumb Western <em>husband</em> of a Japanese woman buys her <em>flowers</em> to apologise, after he opened his big <em>mouth</em> and said ""<strong>kanji</strong> are a stupid writing system"".."		
嘆		sigh	Mouth . . . scarecrow.		13	1702	1579	40	タン	なげ.く、なげ.かわしい	"A <strong>sigh</strong> escapes the <em>mouth</em> of the <em>scarecrow</em>, who laments: ""…if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji""."	I will let out a huge<strong> sigh</strong> of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.	A <strong>sigh</strong> escapes the <em>mouth</em> everytime I come across yet ANOTHER <em>kanji</em> i have to learn…	"A<strong> sigh</strong> escapes the <em>mouth</em> of the <em>scarecrow</em>, who laments: ""…if I only had a brain.""."	When a manga character<strong> sigh</strong>s, out of his <em>mouth</em> comes a <em>kanji</em>.		
難		difficult	Scarecrow . . . turkey.		18	1703	1580	40	ナン	かた.い、-がた.い、むずか.しい、むづか.しい、むつか.しい、-にく.い	It is<strong> difficult</strong> for a <em>scarecrow</em> to scare a <em>turkey</em> or else they would've been called scareturkeys.	Learning Kanji is<strong> difficult</strong> for Turkeys.	It is<strong> difficult</strong> to get back into the <em>kanji</em> learning groove again after going cold <em>turkey</em> for a month or so.	"The <em>Scarecrow</em> is trying to scare some <em>turkeys</em>, but they all just ignore him. He turns to you and says, ""Scaring crows is easy, but <em>turkeys</em> – now that's<strong> difficult</strong>""."	You think it's<strong> difficult</strong> for you to learn kanji? Think about how<strong> difficult</strong> it would be for a turkey!		
華		splendor	Flower . . . silage . . . needle.		10	1704	1581	40	カ、ケ	はな	The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: 'Excuse me, I couldn't help noticing the <strong>splendour</strong> of the <em>flowers</em> in your garden. Simply splendid. <em>Ten</em> out of ten.' The villager gruffly replies: 'No it 'aint. It's all muck. An' I'm gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for <em>silage</em>.'.	Hint:<strong> Splendor</strong> in the Grass. Compare with 草 . This is just a more <strong>splendid</strong> version of that kanji.	In all its<strong> splendor</strong> a delicate flower arose from the pile of silage on a single needle-think stem.	I couldn't find the <em>needle</em> in the heap of <em>silage</em> but was surprised to find a <em>flower</em> of great<strong> splendor</strong> growing there.	The tourist marvels at the<strong> splendor</strong> of the jungle <em>flowers</em>. Little does she know, the <em>crosshair</em> of a <em>needle</em>-gun is pointing right at her. (As a primitive <em>silage</em> can take the meaning '<strong>crosshair</strong>'… for blindingly obvious reasons).		
垂		droop	<i>A drop of</i> . . . <i>silage</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i> . . . <i>floor</i>. The character is written in the order of its elements.		8	1705	1582	40	スイ	た.れる、た.らす、た.れ、-た.れ、なんなんと.す	For an old man with a <em>walking stick</em>, even a <em>drop</em> of <em>silage</em> to carry on his back will make him <em>droop</em> low down to the <em>floor</em>.	Even a <em>drop</em> of <em>silage</em> is enough to make an old man with a <em>walking stick</em><strong> droop</strong> low down to the <em>floor</em>. (rgravina - fixed up order).	Imagine looking through the sight of a hitman's <em>crosshair</em>. The bullet hits, a <em>drop of</em> blood appears on the target's shirt. The target drops his <em>walking stick</em> and starts to<strong> droop</strong>… finally hitting the <em>floor</em>. (I take '<em>silage</em>' to mean '<em>crosshair</em>').	"Image: a poor shriveled old lady struggling with a ""droop""ing load of <em>silage</em> on her shoulders. A <em>bit</em> falls to the <em>ground</em> and she <em>droop</em>s a little further to pick it up."	Hint : as a primitive, I used the image of <em>Droopy</em> Dog, the cartoon character created by Tex Avery.		
唾		saliva	Mouth . . . droop.		11	1706	2165	40	ダ、タ	つば、つばき	When some people are sleeping, their <em>mouths</em> <em>droop</em> open, and<strong> saliva</strong> drips out.	"Easy to remember if you have read the manga -or watched the anime- 謎の彼女 X「なぞのかのじょX」(""Mysterious Girlfriend X""): a boy who falls in love with a classmate when he sees her dripping <strong>drool</strong> during a nap (BTW astridtops' story fits in perfectly). <strong>Note</strong>: The boy's name, <a href=""midori://search?text=%E6%A4%BF%E3%80%8C%E3%81%A4%E3%81%B0%E3%81%8D%E3%80%8D"">椿「つばき」</a> <a href=""../v4/1569.html"">camellia</a> (#1569 椿), is a wordplay: it's one of the ways you can pronounce this kanji ( 唾き )."	<em>Droopy</em> the dog with<strong> saliva</strong> drooling from his <em>mouth</em>.	When you mouth is drooping<strong> saliva</strong> drools out.	Obviously, the <em>mouth</em> is where<strong> saliva</strong> <em>droops</em> out.		
睡		drowsy	Eyes . . . droop.		13	1707	1583	40	スイ		Our <em>eyes</em> <em>droop</em> when we are<strong> drowsy</strong>.	"Hint : the <em>eyes</em> of <em>Droopy Dog</em> (see <a href=""../v4/1582.html"">droop</a> (#1582 垂)). When you are<strong> drowsy</strong> you have ""<em>droopy eyes</em>"". That is, you have <em>Droopy's eyes</em>!"	When you are<strong> DROWSY</strong> your EYE-lids DROOP, but imagine your whole EYES drooping out of their sockets - Urgh!	Zzzz. (Really, do you need anything more for this, especially after you've made it this far into the book? :) ).	Cuando estamos somnolientos, la única manera de mantenernos despiertos es haciendo que el párpado penda de algún sitio, con un hilo o algo por el estilo.		
錘		spindle	Metal . . . droop.		16	1708	1584	40	スイ	つむ、おもり	Wasn't it a cursed<strong> spindle</strong> that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the<strong> spindle</strong> was the <em>metal</em> that caused her to <em>droop</em> and eventually sleep for 100 years.	<strong>Spindle</strong>: the needle that drops on an LP record player. This is made of metal. It droops. Viola.	Think of a <strong>plumb bob</strong> rather than <strong>spindle</strong> (which are the same shape, and this kanji means both). It's a perfectly literal kanji: <em>droop</em>ing <em>metal</em>.	Once people could buy whole<strong> spindle</strong>s of CD-Roms for a few bucks, the number of <em>gold</em> records really started to <em>droop</em>.	I love this one! It's a classic cartoon episode! The theiving wolf takes the <em>golden</em> <strong>spindle</strong>. Then <em>Droopy Dog</em> takes the <strong>spindle</strong> away from him, thwaks him on the head with it and rolls him up on it.		
乗		ride	The simplest way to remember this character is to find the sprig of <i>wheat</i> in it, hidden because it doubles up with one stroke of <i>silage</i>.		9	1709	1585	40	ジョウ、ショウ	の.る、-の.り、の.せる	It's a <em>hay</em> <strong>ride</strong>! You sit on piles of <em>silage</em> and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of <em>wheat</em> sticking out of their mouths.	[ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to <strong>ride</strong> on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have <em>wheat</em> <em>silage</em> surplus.	"The hardest part about being a farmer is when it comes to the slaughter. ""Come on boys, we're going for a<strong> ride</strong>!"" ""Oh boy, a<strong> ride</strong>!"" say the little <em>wheat</em> sprigs, hopping onto the tractor. The farmer then takes them off to become <em>silage</em>, tears in his eyes."	"On a farm first you <strong>ride</strong> the tractor, cut down the <em>wheat</em>, and finally mix the wheat with <em>silage</em> to make haylage. <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haylage"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haylage</a>."	The closest the kids on the farm ever got to a fairground<strong> ride</strong> was pointing the <em>crosshair</em> of their air-rifles at the <em>wheat</em> to see who could take the head off first. (I take '<em>silage</em>' to mean '<em>crosshair</em>')… (<em>continued in next kanji</em>).		
剰		surplus	Ride . . . saber.		11	1710	1586	40	ジョウ	あまつさえ、あま.り、あま.る	If you go for a <em>ride</em> and find a <em>saber</em> beside you, perhaps you got into an Army<strong> surplus</strong> jeep.	"Recall the wheat sabers we made a <a href=""../v4/906.html"">profit</a> (#906 利) off. We made too many and now there's<strong> surplus</strong>, for sale on this hay <em>ride</em>."	We got a <strong>surplus</strong> of people on the <em>hayride</em>. <em>Chop</em> 'em off.	If there is a<strong> surplus</strong> of people on the <em>ride,</em> they may just need to get rid of a few passengers using a <em>saber</em>.	Hey, wanna take a <em>ride</em> with me to the Army<strong> surplus</strong> store to buy a <em>saber</em>?		
今		now	The final stroke of this kanji is a rare shape, which we have not met before and will only meet in this character and others that include it as a primitive. We are more accustomed to seeing it straightened out as part of other shapes - for instance, as the second stroke of <i>mouth</i>. If you need any help at all with this character, you may picture it as two hands of a clock pointing to what time it is <b>now</b>. The element above it, <i>meeting</i>, should easily relate to that image.	* We shall use <i>clock</i> as the primitive meaning of this character, in line with the above explanation.	4	1711	1587	41	コン、キン	いま	My MEETING is at 7- but that's<strong> NOW</strong>!	(re: ruuku35) The <em>meeting</em> is not at <em>quarter to seven</em> but<strong> now</strong>!	"<em>Doc Brown</em> (primitive) from Back to the Future checks his watch. The meeting with Marty McFly and Biff is <strong>now</strong>. ""Great Scott."" He's late, so he cuts a corner sharply in the DeLorean. It's such a sharp turn that it's found in no other kanji. Only Doc can pull it off."	"Looks like a ラ　with a hat. Like a cowboy saying ""Raaat<strong> now</strong>, pardner.""."	The <em>meeting</em> is<strong> now</strong>, <em>6:45</em>, according to the <em>hands of clock</em>.		
含		include	Clock . . . mouth.		7	1712	1588	41	ガン	ふく.む、ふく.める	This clock<strong> include</strong>s a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches… now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.	Batteries<strong> include</strong>d with this <em>clock</em>. Open the <em>mouth</em> at the back and insert them after purchase.	"#include < <em>time</em>.h >, < <em>stdio</em>.h >//or <em>clock</em>.h , <em>mouth</em>.h."	"(Based on erikkusan's story) For today's urban professionals – who are so busy that they don't even have time to look at their watch – this <em>clock</em><strong> include</strong>s a <em>mouth</em> that will announce the time. Picture the clock; it's in the shape of a face, so the mouth is at the bottom. That should keep it distinct from <a href=""../v4/1589.html"">versify</a> (#1589 吟)."	If you want to be<strong> include</strong>d in the gang, NOW is the time to open your MOUTH and say so.		
貪		covet	Clock . . . shellfish.		11	1713	3023	41	タン、 トン	むさぼ.る	"""Gimme all your <em>money</em> <em>now</em>!"" said the <strong>covet</strong>ous criminal."	One begins one's life <strong>coveting</strong> <em>money</em>. One ends one's life <strong>coveting</strong> time – those precious seconds ticking away on the <em>clock</em>. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).	<strong>Covet</strong>. One can <strong>covet</strong> <em>money</em>. Money can buy a lot but it cannot buy time. Presiding above all, watch the <em>clock</em> ticking… a countdown to one's grave!	Here it shows the two most<strong> covet</strong>ed things. Time and money. You know time is money. Besides people go to work, deceive, kill etc to get money and time goes on top because it's<strong> covet</strong>ed the most. One would buy time when near death but you can. Many have been looking for the elixir of life but they failed. And they go together because many would despise a life without any money.	<strong>Covet</strong> <em>time</em> over <em>money</em>, for <em>money</em> cannot buy <em>time</em>, as the <em>clock</em> keeps ticking.		
吟		versify	As we have already learned characters for <i>poem</i> (Frame 370), <i>chant</i> (Frame 21), and <i>song</i> (Frame 508), it is important to protect this key word with an image all its own. Its elements are the same as those above; only the position has changed: <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>clock</i>.		7	1714	1589	41	ギン		A rapper is trying to <strong>versify</strong>, but sucks: Hickery dickery dock, the <em>mouth</em> spat out the <em>clock</em>. I'm gonna shoot you with my glock, if you don't suck my cock! <strong>Versify</strong>!	To<strong> versify</strong>, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.	Just imagine a rapper using his <em>mouth</em> to <strong>versify</strong> with a big <em>clock</em> around his neck.	On the left-wing, people <em>mouth</em> about de<strong>versifying</strong>, but on the right, they want to turn back the <em>clock</em>.	<strong>Versify</strong> this kanji as follows: Hickery dickery dock, the <em>mouth</em> ran by the <em>clock</em>.		
念		wish	Clock . . . heart.		8	1715	1590	41	ネン		Someone<strong> wish</strong>ing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.	Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man <strong>wished</strong> for a <em>heart</em> and the wizard gave him that dinky little <em>clock</em> instead?	A<strong> wish</strong> is something that your heart desires right now.	I<strong> wish</strong> with all my <em>heart</em> that I knew all the kanji <em>now</em>. This studying sucks!	I<strong> wish</strong> the <em>clock</em> would give me more time to do the things that my <em>heart</em> desires the most.		
捻		wrench	This kanji does not refer to the tool but to the act of twisting. Its elements: <i>fingers</i> . . . <i>wish.</i>		11	1716	2251	41	ネン、ジョウ	ね.じる、ねじ.る、ひね.くる、ひね.る	Ever try<strong> WRENCHING</strong> a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you'll WISH you had a wrench for<strong> WRENCHING</strong> to save your FINGERS.	"""I <em>wish</em> you would accept our friendly offer"", the mob guy said, as he started<strong> wrenching</strong> my <em>fingers</em> one by one."	I have an unfortunate habit of<strong> wrenching</strong> off other people’s <em>fingers</em> when I pull a <em>wish</em>bone with them.	The keyword refers to twirling or spinning something. Use your fingers the spin the hands on the clock wishing it would turn 5 and you can go home.	After your <em>finger</em> got <strong>wrenched</strong> in the lathe, you only have one <em>wish</em>: a new finger.		
琴		harp	A pair of <i>jewels</i> . . . <i>clock</i>.		12	1717	1591	41	キン	こと	Two <em>kings</em> were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a <em>clock</em> built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.	The <em>two kings</em> want to hear a<strong> harp</strong> right <em>now</em>!!	A pair 0f <em>kings</em> exchange gifts: a <em>clock</em> and a <strong>harp(koto)</strong>.	Two <em>kings</em> were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a <em>clock</em> built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.<em> (It helps me to remember that the kings are sitting atop the giant floor clock staring down in anticipation. for placement)</em>.	This is actually the kanji for <strong>koto</strong>. I pictute two mallets with <em>jeweled</em> heads beating on a <strong>koto</strong> in time to a metronome (<em>clock</em>).		
陰		shade	Just as the <i>sunshine</i> (Frame 1397) represents the masculine principle in nature (Yang), the <b>shade</b> stands for the feminine principle (Yin). Its elements are: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>clock</i> . . . <i>rising cloud</i>.		11	1718	1592	41	イン	かげ、かげ.る	The only <strong>shade</strong> at <em>The Pinnacle</em> is in the shadow of the giant <em>clock</em> tower, or from a <em>rising cloud</em>.	Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the<strong> shade</strong>. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!	The <em>pinnacle</em> is in the<strong> shade</strong>, because it has <em>now</em> become <em>cloudy</em>.	"To avoid the confusion with <a href=""../v4/1712.html"">shadow</a> (#1712 影), let's use a rhyme : At <em>The Pinnacle</em>, the only <strong>shade</strong> / is that of thinks that are man-made (The giant <em>clock</em> tower, and the <em>rising cloud</em> from a factory)."	You are now 75% of the way through the 2136 joyo kanji!		
予		beforehand	Think of this character as identical to the <i>halberd</i> (Frame 1311) except that the final stroke has been omitted. Return to that character and devise some image to take this difference into account.		4	1719	1593	41	ヨ、シャ	あらかじ.め	<strong>Beforehand</strong>, this was a <em>halberd</em> but I cut it short so it could <strong>be for hand</strong> to hand combat.	Your <em>halberd</em> doesn't have a handguard? You should have thought of that<strong> beforehand</strong> (i.e., before you were missing your hand).	This is the halberd<strong> beforehand</strong>, i mean: before you draw the hand (the last stroke of halberd).	Be sure to check your <em>halberd</em><strong> beforehand</strong> to make sure it's not missing its final stroke.	As others see it, think of<strong> BEFOREHAND</strong> with Forehand, which easily reminds you of a tennis racket for use as a primitive in later kanji. It even looks like a tennis racket, so all the better.		
序		preface	Cave . . . beforehand.		7	1720	1594	41	ジョ	つい.で、ついで	The<strong> preface</strong> to all human history was written <em>beforehand</em> in <em>caves</em>.	"Rename the ""beforehand"" part to be <em>glove</em> (because you have to wear <em>gloves</em> beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable <em>cave</em>. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the<strong> preface</strong>. But he can't get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on <em>glove</em>s, shivering, but still unable to start his<strong> preface</strong>."	In the<strong> preface</strong> to his latest edition of RTK, Heisig tells us that until he invented his brilliant kanji-learning method, he was living in a <em>cave beforehand</em>. Luckily, the publishing of the book gave him enough money to move out of the <em>cave</em> into an apartment. He could also finally afford to put a handle on his <em>halberd</em>.	Read<strong> preface</strong> on the <em>cave beforehand</em> or you'll be sorry…	I suck at <em>tennis</em> so I picked up a book by Roger Federer. The<strong> preface</strong> tells how he was so awesome that he managed to defeat a <em>cave wall</em> in a one-on-one <em>tennis</em> match. The cave wall eventually gave up and collapsed. The rest of the book was about boring <em>tennis</em> strategies.		
預		deposit	Beforehand . . . head.		13	1721	1595	41	ヨ	あず.ける、あず.かる	<strong>Deposit</strong>ing money into your savings account is something you do <em>beforehand</em> if you use your <em>head</em>. If you're in Japan your passbook says 預金機 （よきんき）when you make a<strong> deposit</strong>.	You bang your <em>head</em> on the ATM, wishing you'd<strong> deposit</strong>ed some money <em>beforehand</em>.	預血 means to<strong> deposit</strong> blood in a blood bank. Imagine bringing a severed <em>head</em> to the blood bank for a blood<strong> deposit</strong>. Of course, you are wearing <em>gloves</em> when handling the bloody <em>head</em>.	(RPG) All of you who enjoy playing RPGs every now and then should be familiar with this. When you accept a risky quest like hunting for the <em>head</em> of some evil monster. You should<strong> deposit</strong> your money (<em>shells</em>) <em>beforehand</em>, so that when you die you don't lose all of your wealth. One of the few good things that Japanese banks do. When<strong> deposit</strong>ing money at an ATM, you must open your book to the right <em>page</em> and insert <em>beforehand</em> to have a record of the<strong> deposit</strong> written in.

兼		concurrently	At the top we have <i>the animal horns</i> and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we see one <i>rake</i> with two handles. Finally, we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles, indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs <b>concurrently</b>, using the same kit of tools to move in two different directions and ending up in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.		10	1723	1597	41	ケン	か.ねる、-か.ねる	Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a <em>rake</em>, is suddenly attacked from both left and right<strong> concurrently</strong> by bulls with <em>animal horns</em>. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (<em>split rake handle</em>) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (<em>split bottom of each rake handle</em>).	You decide to take the bull by the <em>horns</em> and do both chores<strong> concurrently</strong>, grabbing your <em>double-handled rake</em> before attempting to clean up both your's and your neighbours' garden. But unfortunately, it's not long until your <em>rake</em> <em>splits in two</em>.	Special <em>rake</em>, used to hold a bull by both <em>horns</em> <strong>concurrently</strong>. Two handles have V-like ends to set your arms against.	I'm going to use CASANOVA as the signal image here. A HORNY RAKE of a man who wants to date many women and/or men<strong> concurrently</strong>. The final four strokes, if you look carefully, turn the HORNY RAKE into a head on a body with arms open wide to embrace you. Run away!	<strong>Concurrently</strong> Primitive: Sarah Palin. She's<strong> concurrently</strong> Governor of Alaska and the vice presidential nominee. Quite a job. Some days she's shooting moose and mounting the <em>horns</em> on her wall. Other days she's being a maverick and <em>raking</em> up corruption in her own party. There's so much corruption she needs <em>two</em> rakes. She likes to do this all while wearing a <em>red skirt</em>. You can see the skirt flailing out on either side.

西		west	To our way of counting directions, the <b>west</b> always comes fourth. So it is convenient to find the character for <i>four</i> in this kanji. But since we want only <i>one</i> of the <i>four</i> directions, the <b>west</b> adds the <i>one</i> at the top and sucks the <i>human legs</i> a bit out of their <i>mouth</i> in the process.	* As a primitive, the meaning of <i>west</i> can be expanded to refer to the <i>Old West</i> of cowboy-movie fame, just as the meaning of the character for <i>east</i> was expanded into <i>the East</i>. Note, however, that in its primitive form the <i>legs</i> are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the <i>mouth</i>. Hence, we get the shape ⻃. With the exception of one kanji, given in the following frame, this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives.	6	1728	1602	41	セイ、サイ、ス	にし	"The old<strong> west</strong> represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare <a href=""../v4/1427.html"">sign of the bird</a> (#1427 酉) whiskey bottle about one third full)."	Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.	The Spaghetti <strong>Western</strong> movies, typified by <em>empty bottles of whisky</em>, were so-called because it was often an Italian director that shot them. Most of these films however, were actually shot in <strong>Spain</strong> (another meaning this kanji holds).	Only <em>one</em> out of every <em>four</em><strong> west</strong>erns is worth watching. Even that's debatable. The rest are crap.	<em>One</em> of the <em>four</em> directions: The<strong> West</strong>.
