門		gates	The pictograph of two swinging <b>gates</b> is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The <b>gates</b> usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose.	* As a primitive, we shall continue to give it the meaning of <i>gates</i>, but recommend the image of swinging doors (like the kind once common at entrances to saloons) to distinguish it from the primitive for <i>door</i>.	8	1743	1616	42	モン	かど、と	"Heisig's stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful – first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the ""sun"" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you'll get the stroke order exactly correct."	The<strong> gates</strong> to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or … Bill<strong> Gates</strong>?	Bill<strong> Gates</strong> is just about to walk into a saloon.	The<strong> GATES</strong> of Hell make a great primitive for the following frames.	Primitives, Either<strong> gates</strong> to hell, or the pearly<strong> gates</strong> :D.		
問		question	Gates . . . mouth.		11	1744	1617	42	モン	と.う、と.い、とん	"A mouth on the Gates of Hell says ""Answer me these<strong> question</strong>s three, or thru the gates ye soon will be""."	You begin to<strong> question</strong> all of the <em>holes</em> Gates leaves in his software.	The mouth is the gate from which<strong> question</strong>s are asked.	To get access to Bill Gates' supermansion you have to answer several<strong> question</strong>s asked by a weird detached mouth at the entrance. Get a<strong> question</strong> wrong and the mouth will eat you.	"As you walk through the <em>saloon doors</em>, everyone shuts up and stares at you, <em>mouths</em> open… the barman asks the<strong> question</strong> on everyone's mind - ""Who the fuck are you son?""."		
閲		review	<i>Gates</i> . . . <i>devil</i>. Keep the connotation of this key word distinct from those of <i>inspection</i> (Frame 1174), <i>revise</i> (Frame 362), and <i>perusal</i> (Frame 919).		15	1745	1618	42	エツ	けみ.する	A little <em>devil</em> at the <em>gates of hell</em><strong> review</strong>s your record to see if you're evil enough to get in.	As I was <strong>reviewing</strong> for my exam at a quiet saloon, the <em>devil</em> popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that's cheating. Besides, I'm just <strong>reviewing</strong> things I already know. I won't fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance <em>gates</em>.	<em>Gates'</em> IS the <em>devil</em>. He releases software that clearly hasn't gone through any kind of <em>review</em> process.	At the <em>gates</em> of Hell, the <em>Devil</em> greets you with his punishment: to<strong> review</strong> kanji flash cards for the rest of your life! (Not that I think anything is wrong with Heisig, but it does get tiring and I certainly wouldn't want to do it all my life. ;)).	"At the Gates of Hell: ""What did I do to get here?"" you ask in disbelief. ""Well, let's<strong> review</strong>…"" says Satan."		
閥		clique	Gates . . . fell.		14	1746	1619	42	バツ		You set a guard at the gate to fell intruders not of your<strong> clique</strong>.	The <em>felled</em> souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the <em>gates of hell</em> and join the <strong>clique</strong>.	A<strong> clique</strong> is a small exclusive group of people usually gathering around a leader or for a common purpose. Here we see <em>Mr. T</em>'s fan club meeting for a <em>fiesta</em> at a very select club called the 'Perly <em>Gates</em>'.	<em>Bill Gates</em> has been known to <em>fell</em> any rival software company that threatens his little<strong> clique</strong> at the top.	You only get through the <em>gates</em> into <em>that person's</em> <em>fiesta</em> if you are in the same<strong> clique</strong>.		
間		interval	<i>Gates</i> . . . <i>sun/day</i>. This <b>interval</b> applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image.		12	1747	1620	42	カン、ケン	あいだ、ま、あい	The<strong> interval</strong> between star systems (<em>suns</em>) was too large, so the star<em>gates</em> were created to travel between them.	We open the <em>gates</em> at regular <strong>intervals</strong> to let a bit of <em>sun</em> in.	At regular<strong> interval</strong>s the gates of Hell burn like the sun keeping all within nice and toasty.<strong> Interval</strong> paining.	At almost regular<strong> interval</strong>s of a year or so, <em>Bill Gates</em> tries again to take on their rival <em>Sun</em> in the server market, and thankfully UNIX and Linux always prevail.	<em>Lesbians</em> do their thing on one <em>day</em><strong> interval</strong>s because their <em>gates</em> get so sore.		
闇		pitch dark	Gates . . . sound.		17	1748	2777	42	アン、オン	やみ、くら.い	Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all<strong> pitch dark</strong>.	In the<strong> pitch dark</strong>, I can hear the <em>sound</em> of the <em>lesbians</em> rubbing their <em>gates</em> together.	I like to think of a horror movie where the protagonists enter a graveyard when suddenly their flashlights go out and it becomes<strong> pitch dark</strong>, whereupon they hear the <em>sound</em> of the <em>gate</em> creaking shut behind them.	When it is <strong>pitch dark</strong>, you must navi<em>gate</em> by <em>sound</em>.	I opened the gates and it was<strong> pitch dark</strong>. Only a eerie sound could be heard.		
簡		simplicity	Bamboo . . . interval.		18	1749	1621	42	カン		The <strong>simplicity</strong> of <em>bamboo</em> plant is in all its joints being at equal <em>intervals</em>.	[simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a <em>bamboo</em> device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular <em>interval</em>s. Its design is <strong>simplicity</strong> itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).	"Wordplay:<strong> simplicity</strong> -> simcity. You are playing a game of SimCity, a city simulator. You can choose from one of several pre-defined city layouts. One of the city layouts is called ""<strong>SimpliCity</strong> (a simple city for SimCity)"". This layout has nothing but an empty field with <em>bamboo</em> trees planted at regular <em>intervals</em>."	In an existence of utmost<strong> simplicity</strong> you spend time listening to the liquid-filled <em>bamboo</em> tube (ししおどし) clacking at regular <em>interval</em>s.	I imagine one of those little <strong>bamboo</strong> fountains where the bamboo fills with water, tips over and lets out the water, and then tips back to get filled again. In this way, it marks out even <strong>intervals</strong>. THAT is<strong> simplicity</strong>.		
開		open	Gates . . . two hands.		12	1750	1622	42	カイ	ひら.く、ひら.き、-びら.き、ひら.ける、あ.く、あ.ける	Sure you can squeeze through these <em>gates</em> by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide<strong> open</strong>, you need to do that with <em>both your hands</em>.	To<strong> open</strong> the <em>gate</em>, use your <em>both hands</em>.	The <em>lesbians</em> use <em>both hands</em> to<strong> open</strong> each other's <em>gates</em>. Sick, but try forgetting this kanji now.	Bill gates is entering the major gate of his mansion and needs his two hand in order to<strong> open</strong> the gate. (you would probably think that Bill Gates has an electric door and that's the case but the conputer that controls it has crashed!).	To<strong> open</strong> those big heavy <em>Gates of Hell</em> it takes <em>both hands</em>…		
閉		closed	Gates . . . genie.		11	1751	1623	42	ヘイ	と.じる、と.ざす、し.める、し.まる、た.てる	"The <em>gates</em> are too big to be <strong>closed</strong> by man. Only a <em>genie</em> can. ""Close sesame!""."	"You hear <em>lesbians</em> moaning ""オォ~"" from behind<strong> closed</strong> <em>gates</em>, and you ask a <em>genius</em> how to get in there."	Bill GATES keeps his operating system<strong> CLOSED</strong>, does that make him a GENIUS? I think not.	"A <em>genie</em> is making sure that the gates of Ali Baba's Cave are always <em>closed</em>. Picture the genie (who lives in an oil lamp in that cave) grumbling about how Ali Baba is so forgetful, and that it's always him, the genie who has to check that the gates are<strong> closed</strong>. See previous frame 1622 ""open"". – Note : I don't worry about the keyword ""cave"" here because you can't have the ""cave"" enclosure within the same kanji as the ""gates"" enclosure."	"""オー no! I stayed out past curfew, and now the gate has been<strong> closed</strong>!""."		
閣		tower	Gates . . . each.		14	1752	1624	42	カク		"To keep this distinct from other kanji such as ""watchtower"" and ""pagoda"", I use the mnemonic ""<em>towering<strong> tower</strong></em>"". – In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee's last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a <em>gate</em> at <em>each</em> level of the<strong> tower</strong>ing<strong> tower</strong>, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the ""towering<strong> tower</strong>""."	Remember the two<strong> tower</strong>s from lord of the rings… <em>each</em> has it's own - very difficult to master - entrance <em>gate</em>.	"<em>Each lesbian</em> waits for her turn with ""the<strong> tower</strong>""."	There is a<strong> tower</strong> on each side of the gate, they are posts for archers.	Since<strong> tower</strong> confuses me too much with other Kanji, I will use (political) CABINET instead, where this Kanji is frequently used. The CABINET decides that EACH GATE of a saloon has to have a sign saying that you have to be an adult to be allowed to drink there.		
閑		leisure	Gates . . . tree.		12	1753	1625	42	カン		Imagine the <em>gates</em> the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of<strong> leisure</strong>. You're not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see <em>trees</em>.	Getting <em>wood</em> watching <em>lesbians</em> is my idea of<strong> leisure</strong> time.	Beyond the <em>Gates of Hell</em>, there is only one<strong> leisure</strong> spot for all the billions of souls within, a single <em>tree</em> beneath which people can sit for a few seconds. Ah, but that moment of<strong> leisure</strong> makes the rest of Hell that much worse…	Imagine <strong>Leisure</strong> Suit Larry walking through the <em>saloon doors</em> with <em>wood</em> in his pants, hoping to get lucky.	"""You can rest in<strong> leisure</strong>, Master Peregrin Took, until battle begins, because the guards of Gondor defend the <em>Gates</em> of the City and the White <em>tree</em>.""."		
聞		hear	<i>Gates</i> . . . <i>ear</i>. Compare the story you invented for the kanji meaning <i>listen</i> (Frame 890).		14	1754	1626	42	ブン、モン	き.く、き.こえる	Press your ear to the gates and see if you can<strong> hear</strong> what is going on inside.	To distinguish from listen, you<strong> hear</strong> someone at the door (gate).	At the GATES of Hell, along with the mouth that asks the impossible questions there is of course a giant EAR to<strong> HEAR</strong> the answers. The ear doesn't really listen as it knows they will always be wrong.	"The genius tells me to put my <em>ear</em> up to the <em>gates</em> in order to<strong> hear</strong> the <em>lesbians</em> better (see <a href=""../v4/1623.html"">closed</a> (#1623 閉)."	"Your ears are the gates that allow you to<strong> hear</strong>. NOTE: You <a href=""../v4/1626.html"">hear</a> (#1626 聞) with your <em>ear</em> alone, but to <a href=""../v4/827.html"">listen</a> (#827 聴) you need to engage your <em>heart</em> as well."		
潤		wet	Water . . . gates . . . king.		15	1755	1627	42	ジュン	うるお.う、うるお.す、うる.む	Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got<strong> wet</strong>.	(I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of <em>water</em> on top of the huge <em>gates</em>, so that it would fall on the <em>king</em> as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all<strong> wet</strong>, dripping <em>drops of water</em>.	If I was <em>king</em>, I would be<strong> wet</strong> with the <em>water</em> of <em>lesbians</em> rubbing all over me.	Some prankster threw <em>water</em> on the <em>king</em> as he came to the city gates. Now he's all <strong>wet</strong>.	"I immediately thought of Monty Python and the Holy Grail. Imagine <em>King</em> Arthur standing in front of the <em>gate</em> shortly before the end of the movie. When he demands to be let in by the French, they throw dung on him and Belvedere and they get<strong> wet</strong>. (Think of the dung as <em>water</em> in this case, it's liquid anyway) <a href=""http://youtube.com/watch?v=9V7zbWNznbs"">http://youtube.com/watch?v=9V7zbWNznbs</a> The scene I thought of is at the end of the vid."		
欄		column	Tree . . . gates . . . east.		20	1756	1628	42	ラン	てすり	A <strong>column</strong> of text scratched on a black tree beside the <em>gates of Hell</em>: To the <em>East</em> lies The Beast.	[column; handrail; blank; space] I think about <em>oriental</em> (<em>eastern</em>) Torii <em>gates</em>: they have two supporting <strong>column</strong>s made of <em>wood</em>.	"Ancient morning newspaper<strong> column</strong>, posted daily on a <strong>tree</strong> at the <strong>east gate</strong>. Why the <strong>east gate</strong>? Well, it's a morning paper, and the sun rises in the east, so the morning rays shining through the gate illuminate it nicely. I picture all the ojisan who rise in the wee hours gathering around the tree each, waiting for the sun rise so they can read the paper. ""Been coming here every day for 40 years! Can't start the day without my paper!""."	<em>Bill Gates</em> already dominates the software industry in the West, and now he is turning his attention to the <em>East</em>. Trying to gain popularity and a glentler image there he writes a <em>column</em> in newspapers there about how he plans to save the <em>trees</em> using the latest and greatest features of Windows Vista.	This is a <strong>column of text</strong>, as used in a newspaper. The trick for this kanji is that to mark the <strong>columns</strong> in the old printers, you place <em>wooden</em> blocks at certain intervals of the paper. Now, look at the right part; it looks as if you had put a <em>wooden</em> block in an <em>interval</em> primitive. That graphical reminder will help you to remember this kanji!!		
闘		fight	<i>Gates</i> . . . <i>table</i> . . . <i>glue</i>. Do not confuse with <i>contend</i> (Frame 1238).		18	1757	1629	42	トウ	たたか.う、あらそ.う	During the saloon brawl, one guy got <em>glued to a table</em> and was tossed out <em>through the saloon gates</em>. But he really wanted to<strong> fight</strong>, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.	Food<strong> fight</strong>! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.	<em>Bill Gates</em> and <em>Mr. Bean</em> having a <em>glue</em><strong> fight</strong>.	He's<strong> fight</strong>ing to get through the <em>gates</em>, but <em>Mr. Bean</em> doesn't know they are just for show & have been <em>glued</em> together.	In any classic bar<strong> fight</strong> scene, someone crawls under a <em>table</em>, someone sits <em>glue</em>d to the piano, and someone gets thrown clear throught the saloon doors (<em>gates</em>). 戦闘 せんとう battle,<strong> fight</strong>, combat; 闘うたたかう to<strong> fight</strong>; to battle; to combat; to struggle against; to wage war; to engage in contest.		
倉		godown	The single <i>gate</i> is used here not in order to represent one <i>gate</i>, but many of them, indeed a <i>meeting of gates</i>. Add <i>mouth</i> (as an entrance here) and you end up with <b>godown</b>. That should help keep this character distinct from <i>warehouse</i> (Frame 633).		10	1758	1630	42	ソウ	くら	(Warning-this one is crude) Imagine a<strong> godown</strong> (dockside warehouse) where you can <em>meet</em> girls who will <em>godown</em> on you with their <em>mouth</em>. To keep the place a bit of a secert, they only have one <em>gate</em>.	"Hint : the ""godown"" is like a warehouse, it's on the docks and mostly in Asia. To make an image distinct from that of ""warehouse"" or ""storehouse"", etc, I picture the goods stored there, piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to ""godown"" before they can be taken outside. The front of this<strong> godown</strong> is a ""<em>meeting of small gates</em>"", i.e. a row of gates through which goods come in and out. The <em>mouth</em> can be an opening somewhere in the back, or the top, where cranes lift down the goods."	<strong>Note:</strong> this is not <em>gate</em> but actually a variation of <em>door</em> and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.	Imagine a mafia<strong> godown</strong> at the docks where shifty mafia types <em>meet</em> and lots of dodgy deals<strong> godown</strong>. This is a very secret place, so there is only one <em>gate</em>, and to enter you have to say the password with your <em>mouth</em>.	"A <strong>godown</strong> is an old style warehouse where goods were temporarily stacked stacked to the <em>roof</em>(meeting). A series of <em>gates</em> with <em>mouths</em>(doors) were used access them for shipment. (Primitive <em>EAST INDIA TRADING</em>) <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image</a>:WarehousesinAmsterdam.JPG."		
創		genesis	Godown . . . saber.		12	1759	1631	42	ソウ、ショウ	つく.る、はじ.める、きず、けず.しける	Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega<strong> genesis</strong> they looted the godown with sabers.	I prefer to have girls <em>Godown</em> on my <em>sabre</em> to prevent unwanted<strong> GENESIS</strong> of babies………… 創造 そうぞう (creation).	The<strong> genesis</strong> of my hatred of kanji learning is when you get so mad that you have to look up what a <em>godown</em> is, and you end up cutting the book (or even Heisig himself) up with a <em>saber</em>.	"In the story of<strong> Genesis</strong> Adam and Even were kicked out of the Garden of Eden. They had to ""go down"" out of the garden and the entrace was guarded with sabers to prevent their return."	God actually has everything ever conceived in a big <em>godown</em>: if you want to exist, you have to grab a <em>sabre</em> and fight your way out. Such is<strong> genesis</strong>.		
非		un-	"This key word, a negating prefix, is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions, to create the picture of a jail cell. From there to ""<b>un-</b>"" is but a short step."	* As a primitive, we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of <i>jail cell</i>.	8	1760	1632	42	ヒ	あら.ず	This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That's an<strong> un-</strong>believable way to escape from prison OR the<strong> UN-</strong> have a prison in the Hague.	People in the jail cell are<strong> un-</strong>friendly,<strong> un-</strong>comely, and<strong> un-</strong>cooperative.	Ever wanted to have an <strong>un</strong>do button in life? Well, when you're in a <em>jail cell</em>, that's when you most want to press that button.	<strong>Un-</strong>zipped.	This is a pictograph of goatse. Rather<strong> un-</strong>appealing image, huh?		
俳		haiku	This character is used for the <b>haiku</b>, the 17-syllable poem that is one of Japan's best-known literary forms. Its elements: <i>person</i> .. . <i>jail cell</i>.		10	1761	1633	42	ハイ		I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).	I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.	<em>Person</em> is put in <em>jail</em> for writing a<strong> haiku</strong> with the wrong number of syllables.	While in jail, some people find Islam, but Mr T finds<strong> haiku</strong>.	A person stuck in jail has nothing better to do than to compose<strong> haiku</strong>.		
排		repudiate	Fingers . . . jail cell.		11	1762	1634	42	ハイ		When ordered to go to the <em>jail cell</em>, the defendant gave the judge the <em>finger</em> and said he<strong> repudiate</strong>d all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.	He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she<strong> repudiate</strong>d him and left.	Once he had his <em>fingers</em> around the <em>jail cell bars</em> he <strong>repudiated</strong> all ties with his former gang!	排他 【はいた】 (n) exclusion; (P) 排日 【はいにち】 (n) anti-Japanese; (P) 排出 【はいしゅつ】 (n,vs) evacuation; emission (e.g. of CO2, etc.); ejection; (P) 排除 【はいじょ】 (n,vs) exclusion; removal; rejection; (P) STORY: Giving everyone the FINGER in a JAIL CELL is a good way to be EXCLUDED by everyone from the next prison break.	"Sarah Palin finally gets thrown behind bars in a JAIL CELL for being a complete disgrace to the country. Indignant, she points a FINGER at the guards, screaming, ""I refutiate this! I refudiate it!"" Picture the guards and the other prisoners replying, ""Don't you mean,<strong> REPUDIATE</strong>?""."		
悲		sad	Jail cell . . . heart.		12	1763	1635	42	ヒ	かな.しい、かな.しむ	<strong>Sad</strong>dness is like having your <em>heart</em> captured and <em>jailed</em> because of some<strong> sad</strong> or terrible event, etc. Here the<strong> sad</strong> <em>heart</em> waits for someone to come and <em>un</em>-lock their <em>jail cell</em> and set them free again.	Stuck in a <em>jail cell</em> with his <em>heart</em> crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so<strong> sad</strong>.	A <em>jail cell</em> will make any <em>heart</em><strong> sad</strong>.	"For some reason, this kanji makes me think of some Toni Braxton song, but I change the lyrics to ""Un-<em>jail</em> my <em>heart</em>"". Now that mnemonic has stuck in my head."	Imagine the<strong> sad</strong> image of a prisoner in a <em>jail cell</em> feeling<strong> sad</strong> as he looks at all the little <em>hearts</em> his daughter used to draw for him when she was just a child. Now she wants nothing to do with him.		
罪		guilt	Eye . . . jail cell.		13	1764	1636	42	ザイ	つみ	"<strong>Guilt</strong>y under the <em>eye</em>s of the law, therefore sentenced to <em>jail</em>. [note: 'UNDER the eye of the law' works in <a href=""../v4/833.html"">penalty</a> (#833 罰) as well.]."	It is his <strong>guilt</strong> that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where <em>the great (sideways) eye</em> appears at the top of his <em>jail</em> cell, and is staring down intently at him. <strong>Guilt</strong> is a merciless tormentor.	EYE-witnesses helped prove this person's<strong> GUILT</strong> and put them in a JAIL CELL… now constantly under the watchful EYES of the prison guards.	A man who is in <em>jail</em> is so full of<strong> guilt</strong> that every night he is having these nightmares where a <em>great eye</em> appears at the top of his <em>jail cell</em>, and is staring down intently at him.	He is <strong>guilty</strong>! you can see it in his <em>eyes</em>.. Throw that man into a <em>jail cell</em>!		
輩		comrade	Jail cell . . . car.		15	1765	1637	42	ハイ	ともがら、 -ばら、 やかい、 やから	Some man <em>jailed</em> in Russia, is freed by his<strong> comrade</strong> (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the <em>jail cell</em> with a <em>vehicle</em>.	(+fuaburisu) But it's the wrong jail cell! Your<strong> comrade</strong> is one floor <em>above</em>.	When you're in JAIL, your<strong> COMRADE</strong> will come and DRIVE a car through the JAIL CELL, coming FROM BELOW to bust you out.	"後輩 【こうはい】 (n) junior (at work or school); (P) 先輩 【せんぱい】 (n) senior (at work or school); superior; elder; older graduate; progenitor; old-timer; (P) STORY: The worst criminals in the world are being transported to a special JAIL CELL in a fortified CAR. There are all nationalities, but one particular Russian criminal did not know who to address ""senpai"" or ""kouhai"" amongst the caught Japanese Yakuza. So he just called everyone<strong> COMRADE</strong>."	In Mother Russia, self-stimulation isn't enough for <em>goatse man</em>, so he asks his<strong> comrade</strong> to drive a <em>car</em> into his ass.		
扉		front door	Door . . . jail cell.		12	1766	1638	42	ヒ	とびら	The only way out of a <em>jail cell</em> is to serve your time and walk out the<strong> front door</strong>. There are no other <em>doors</em>.	"An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like <em>door</em> at the back of his <em>jail cell</em>, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers ""Which <em>door</em>?"", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - ""The<strong> front door</strong> !""."	It's a sad reflection on modern times that our<strong> front door</strong>s need to be built like <em>jail cell</em>s to keep us safe. 扉 (とびら) : door, opening.	A jail cell only has one door. The<strong> front door</strong>.	Your<strong> front door</strong> leads to a jail cell in order to trick burglers.		
侯		marquis	<i>Person</i> . . . <i>key</i> . . . <i>dart</i>. Hint: the pun suggested by the pronunciation of the key word and the primitive for <i>key</i> may come in helpful.		9	1767	1639	42	コウ		<em>Mr. T</em> is made a <strong>marquis</strong> after he and the A-Team save the life of a duke. The duke also gives Mr. T the key to the gentleman's <em>dart</em> room where one can relax in luxury, smoke a cigar, and play a friendly game of <em>darts</em>. <em>Mr. T</em> eagerly accepts the <em>key</em> and places it on one of the gold chains that hang around his neck which acts as a key chain.	(Going off various) Mr. T. is made a<strong> marquis</strong> and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.	MR.T had one final challenge before he would be promoted to a<strong> MARQUIS</strong>. He must shoot a DART through the hole of a KEY.	<strong>Marquis</strong> Keydartee (make-believe french name, Key+dart+T).	"The French government hires <em>Mr. T</em> to bring the<strong> Marquis</strong> de Sade to justice. The<strong> Marquis</strong> runs away frantically. T pronounces himself ""The Mar-<em>key</em> de <em>Darts</em>"" and throws a bunch at Sade, felling him on the city streets."

決		decide	The etymology of <b>decide</b> (de-cidere = cut off) will help here; the elements are: <i>water</i> . . . <i>guillotine</i>.		7	1770	1641	42	ケツ	き.める、-ぎ.め、き.まる、さ.く	"""<strong>Decide</strong>!"" ""<strong>Decide</strong>?! Death by drowning in polluted <em>water</em> or death by <em>guillotine</em>. How can I <strong>decide</strong>?"" I asked."	To<strong> decide</strong> if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in <em>water</em>. If they don't drown they are a witch and can be sent to the <em>guillotine</em>.	(Seriously, do we really need the guillotine primitive? Surely <em>key</em> and <em>person</em> are adequate…) I have<strong> decide</strong>d that drinking more water is the <em>key</em> to becoming a more healthy <em>person</em>. 決まる きまる be<strong> decide</strong>d, fixed, certain; 決める きめる<strong> decide</strong>, fix, choose; 決心 けっしん determination, resolution; 決定 けってい decision, determination; 解決 かいけつ settlement, solution, resolution.	"<em>Water</em>boarding? <em>Guillotine</em>? The <strong>Decide</strong>r has<strong> decide</strong>d both these are legal and moral. I keep mixing this up with <a href=""../v4/1074.html"">choose</a> (#1074 択). Try associating these negative options with our half-wit ""decider"" to build a distinction."	He was sentenced to death, but at least he was granted the ability to<strong> decide</strong> how: either by <em>guillotine</em>, or by <em>chinese water torture</em>.

偉		admirable	Person . . . locket.		12	1772	1643	42	イ	えら.い	Mr. T is certainly an<strong> ADMIRABLE</strong> PERSON, so much so that parents are buying lockets with his picture in it and having their children wear them like amulets.	"For <em>locket</em>: The <em>locket</em> (<em>key</em> dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a <em>mouth</em>, but you need a jeweler's <em>monocle</em> to make out the pictures within. —– <em>Dracula</em> survives a staking attempt when the <em>locket</em> with Mina's<strong> admirable</strong> picture deflects the blow. ""It was an<strong> admirable</strong> attempt,"" he admits as he sucks his attacker's blood."	<strong>Stroke order:</strong> Heisig says that the added vertical stroke is the third stroke, but it's the first of primitive (so it's the third of <em>this</em> kanji, but in the book he's talking about the primitive).	She thought that <em>Mr. T</em> was a tough, heartless guy, but then she found out that he carries around a <em>locket</em> with a picture of his daughter. Suddenly, she found it<strong> admirable</strong> that he had such a soft side.	"Hint: <em>locket</em> = <a href=""../v4/17.html"">I</a> (#17 吾) + <em>sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out</em> with the top line of 五 left off. <strong>えらい</strong>。."		
違		difference	Locket . . . road.		13	1773	1644	42	イ	ちが.う、ちが.い、ちが.える、-ちが.える、たが.う、たが.える	"You lose your precious <em>locket</em> on the <em>road</em> to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. ""Just buy another one,"" someone says. ""I mean, what's the<strong> difference</strong>?"" Then of course you say ""Well, it makes a huge<strong> difference</strong>!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! "" Then of course they understand."	You loose your LOCKET on the ROAD and report it to the 交番 . They find one, and show it to you. 「これですか？」 But it's the wrong one… You say, 「いいえ。。<strong>違います</strong>。。」.	"An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: ""I found a <em>locket</em> in the <em>road</em>, and that has made all the<strong> difference</strong>.""."	You know what the<strong> difference</strong> is between you and me? I find this expensive locket on the road and I look for the owner. You, on the other hand, look for a pawn shop. THAT's the<strong> difference</strong>.	Noticing a<strong> difference</strong> between the <em>locket</em> hanging around his lover's neck and the <em>locket</em> he had giver her he rips it off her and throws it in the <em>road</em>.		
緯		horizontal	Thread . . . locket.		16	1774	1645	42	イ	よこいと、ぬき	Spiderman buys a <em>locket</em> for Mary Jane because he wants to get<strong> HORIZONTAL</strong> with her.	Spiderman on a boat, marking the Earth's <strong>latitudes</strong>. He first attaches a personal locket to a small piece of thread for ballast and good luck, and shoots with his right hand. After a few minutes (and lots and lots of thread), the <em>locket and thread</em> have flown around the world. Spiderman catches the locket with his left hand, and ties the thread's ends together. Voilà.	"Hint : this kanji also means ""latitude"", which are the<strong> horizontal</strong> lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 ""black ink"" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his ""<em>thread locket</em>"" to mark<strong> horizontal</strong> lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark<strong> horizontal</strong> lines. Imagine the ""thread-locket"" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread."	Spiderman gave up being spiderman and promised Mary Jane to live the<strong> horizontal</strong> life like the rest of us. Whenever he starts to feel like he wants to go back to his spidy ways, he takes out his locket with a mary jane picture to remind him that he will forever live<strong> horizontal</strong>y.	Imagine yourself tie a <em>locket</em> to the end of a <em>thread</em> and spin it<strong> horizontal</strong>ly..

I think of<strong> defense</strong> as an attribute in video games. Like Final Fantasy, for example. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to<strong> Korea</strong> to see his home, started taking<strong> Korea</strong>n language classes, etc. So, imagine here the <em>misty</em> eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their <em>lockets</em> with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his<strong> Korea</strong>n romantic mini series called ""Winter Sonata""." I bomb<strong> Korea</strong> every night, then I send them 10 sunflowers and a locket to apologize the next morning.		
干		dry	It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline (viewed from the side). Spin it around quickly in your mind's eye to give it the connotation of to <b>dry</b>.	* The primitive meaning is <i>clothesline</i>.	3	1777	1648	43	カン	ほ.す、ほ.し-、-ぼ.し、ひ.る	<strong>Dry</strong> <em>one</em> item in <em>ten</em> minutes on the <em>clothesline</em>.	Note: the book shows the strokes for <em>potato</em> rather than<strong> dry</strong>…dry does not have the hook at the end.	<em>Vampire</em>: Upside down samurai. They suck humans<strong> dry</strong>.	"A<strong> dry</strong> <em>water lily</em> with no <em>drops</em> on it (see <a href=""../v4/1484.html"">even</a> (#1484 平)."	Heisig's pictograph of a <em>clothesline</em> is fine, but I also see another pictograph here, that of <em>one</em> <em>needle</em> trying to push its way through the<strong> dry</strong> <em>surface of the earth</em> above it but because of a lack of rain the earth is parched and<strong> dry</strong> thus this <em>one</em> <em>needle</em> stays buried in the earth below. Furthermore, you could say that the earth is so<strong> dry</strong> that there's not even <em>one needle</em> left on it.		
肝		liver	Part of the body . . . dry.		7	1778	1649	43	カン	きも	Well you all know that the<strong> liver</strong> is the <em>part of the body</em> that would be quite grateful if you led a <em>dry</em> lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).	The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried<strong> liver</strong> to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.	"Imagine Hannibal Lecter recounting his <em>flesh</em>-eating days: ""I ate his<strong> liver</strong> with some fava beans and a nice <em>dry</em> chianti""."	Imagine a beat up<strong> liver</strong>(too much alcohol). The doctor takes your<strong> liver</strong> out of your body, and puts it on a clothes line to dry off. Then puts it back in your body, sealing up the flesh. A dry<strong> liver</strong> is a healthy<strong> liver</strong> he chuckles as he puts it back.	The part of the flesh that keeps the blood dry of toxins is the<strong> LIVER</strong>.		
刊		publish	Dry . . . saber.		5	1779	1650	43	カン		The newspaper pages are hung on the <em>clotheseline</em> to dry and then cut down with a <em>sabre</em> to be <strong>publish</strong>ed. Therefore, only state-approved stories are <strong>published</strong>. I can't<strong> publish</strong> this. It's too <em>dry</em>. Don't you have any stories with people getting attacked with <em>sabre</em>s or something?		
汗		sweat	Water . . . dry.		6	1780	1651	43	カン	あせ	The way<strong> sweat</strong> is supposed to work: it gets your skin <em>wet</em>, and then as it evaporates/<em>dries</em>, it cools you off.	When you<strong> sweat</strong> your clothes become soaked with <em>water</em>, prompting you to hang them to <em>dry</em> on a clothesline.	<strong>Sweat</strong> a process to regulate body temperature : <em>water</em> comes out of the pores of the skin, and when it <em>dries</em> it cools you off.	When you want to<strong> sweat</strong>, there are 2 kinds of sauna - wet (<em>watery</em>) and <em>dry</em>.	Vampire trivia: <em>vampire</em>s have no<strong> sweat</strong> glands to secrete <em>water</em>. Have you ever seen a vampire wet with<strong> sweat</strong>? That is why they can't be in the sun. The<strong> sweat</strong> water can't come out so they will just explode.		
軒		flats	This kanji, a counter for houses, is made up of <i>cars</i> . . . <i>dry</i>.		10	1781	1652	43	ケン	のき	<strong>Flats</strong> in the city are crowded. You get a space for your <em>car</em> in front, and a <em>clothesline</em> out back. Nothing else.	Small <strong>flats</strong> (garages) for <em>cars</em> help keeping them <em>dry</em>.	Did you hear about the guy obsessed with his <em>car</em>? He keeps it in his <strong>flat</strong> to keep <em>dry</em>.	A flat/house definition: 'The thing that is between the car (in front) and the clothesline (in back) .	I don't have a garage, so I keep my <em>car</em> in my <strong>flat</strong> to keep it <em>dry</em>.		
岸		beach	Mountain . . . cliff . . . dry.		8	1782	1653	43	ガン	きし	At the base of <em>mountain</em> <em>cliff</em>s, there is usually a<strong> beach</strong>. You often can see people lying there, <em>drying</em> off after a swim.	Three impossibilities for a <strong>beach</strong>: There cannot be a <strong>beach</strong> at the top of a <em>mountain</em>. There cannot be a<strong> beach</strong> on the top of a <em>cliff</em>. There cannot be a<strong> beach</strong> that is completely <em>dry</em>.	"I use a play on words here to help with the similar keywords such as ""strand"", and ""coast"". The<strong> Beach</strong> Boys just had a concert down at the<strong> beach</strong>, and they're all wet after the performance. It's not <em>dry</em> enough down at the<strong> beach</strong> so they climb the nearest <em>cliff</em>. Still, it's not <em>dry</em> enough there so they climb the nearest <em>mountain</em>. Finally, the air seems <em>dry</em> and they take a rest while their clothes <em>dry</em>."	The fastest way to reach the<strong> beach</strong> starting from our mountain cabin is to go down the MOUNTAIN until the CLIFF and slide down the CLOTHESLINE directly onto the<strong> beach</strong>!	A nude<strong> beach</strong> is generally sheltered from sight under a <em>mountains</em> or a <em>cliff</em>, where the bathers can <em>dry</em> in privacy.		
幹		tree trunk	<i>Mist</i> . . . <i>umbrella</i> . . . <i>dry</i>. The meaning of this key word extends beyond <b>tree trunks</b> to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for <i>book</i> (Frame 224) and <i>body</i> (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a <b>tree trunk</b>, as well as the kanji for <i>trunk</i> (Frame 194).		13	1783	1654	43	カン	みき	A fine <em>mist</em> is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the<strong> tree-trunk</strong>, effectively using the rest of the tree as an <em>umbrella</em> in order to keep <em>dry</em>.	By astridtops - In the rainy <em>mist</em>, Totoro is standing in front of a<strong> tree-trunk</strong> at the bus stop, under the <em>umbrella</em> he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains <em>dry</em>! Great story…which I get to by thinking:<strong> tree-trunk</strong>-><strong>TT</strong> -><strong>T</strong>onari no <strong>T</strong>otoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.	The word that you will sure see with this kanji is shinkansen (bullet train). 新幹線 . STORY: Shinkansen is very expensive, so I only use it when a MIST is falling. I prefer the train than an UMBRELLA to stay DRY.	There is no tree in this kanji! So think of a cold, bare, dead<strong> tree-trunk</strong>, with the upper branches all cut off. Residents of the neighboring house have run a <em>clothesline</em> from their window to the dead<strong> tree-trunk</strong>. You are filled with sadness, seeing the greatness of nature being destroyed and exploited by mankind. You are walking by this sad scene on a cold and drizzly day with a fine <em>mist</em> descending, using an <em>umbrella</em> to keep yourself <em>dry</em>.	In the rainy <em>mist</em>, Totoro is standing in front of a<strong> tree-trunk</strong> at the bus stop, under the <em>umbrella</em> he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains <em>dry</em>!		
芋		potato	Flowers . . . potato.		6	1784	1655	43	ウ	いも	If your <strong>potato</strong>s are growing <em>flowers</em> and those little <em>hooked roots</em>, you should either buy less or eat them faster.	If your<strong> potato</strong>es are growing <em>flowers</em>, you need to store them in a more <em>dry</em> place, like hanging them on <em>hooks</em> so they don't accumulate moisture on the floor.	"Believe it or not, originally the <strong>potato</strong> was cultivated because of its beautiful <em>flowers</em> rather than for eating the actual ""<em>potato</em>"" below. (historical fact)."	"Tip : the bottom primitive (<em>potato with hooks</em>) can be thought of as ""Mr<strong> Potato</strong> Head"", the toy patented in 1952 with which you can make faces. This <em>potato</em> has little <em>hooks</em> onto which you can attach ears, noses, glasses, etc. to make all sorts of faces."	"The<strong> potato</strong> plant consists of both flowers and the root below. The root (the part of a plant that hooks into the soil), is all that most people think of when they hear the word ""potato."" Therefore, while the kanji for <strong>potato</strong> contains all parts of the plant - flowers and roots - as a primitive, only focus on the important part - the roots."		
宇		eaves	House . . . potato.		6	1785	1656	43	ウ		Under the<strong> eaves</strong> of the house the poor family has potate plants.	Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the<strong> eaves</strong> of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the<strong> eaves</strong> so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.	This kanji means <strong>universe</strong>, seen here as a <em>roof</em> as that was how it was represented back then the <em>vault of heaven</em>. Today, we know that seen from the <strong>universe</strong>, our planet has the aspect of a <em>potato</em>, and not a perfect sphere.	During christmas, since your family is TOO POOR, you hang potatoes off the<strong> eaves</strong> instead of christmas lights.	"Sam at the beginning of the Lord of the Rings was outside the house in the potato bushes when Gandalf was talking with Frodo, even though he denied it: ""I wasn't dropping no<strong> eaves</strong>, sir. Honest!""."		
余		too much	<i>Umbrella</i> . . . <i>potato</i> . . . <i>little</i>. The last stroke of <i>potato</i> and the first of <i>little</i> coincide in this character.	"* Since the phrase ""<i>too much</i>"" is overly abstract, we shall take the image of a <i>scale</i> whose indicator spins round and round on the dial because <i>too much</i> weight has been set on it. It will help to use this image in learning the kanji itself."	7	1786	1657	43	ヨ	あま.る、あま.り、あま.す、あんま.り	You hang an <em>umbrella</em> upside-down on a hook of the <strong>scales</strong> and fill it with <em>little</em> <em>potatoes</em>. No luck: it weights <strong>too much</strong>.	"This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means <strong>too little</strong> in negative sentences and <strong>too much</strong> in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol "">"" (<strong>more than</strong>, another meaning!!) as the <em>umbrella</em> component, and using <a href=""../v4/2.html"">two</a> (#2 二) and <a href=""../v4/105.html"">little</a> (#105 小) for the <em>potato</em> primitive. So, this kanji either means ""<em>two</em> much"" (more than 2) or ""<em>two little</em>"". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!)."	I was worried that my <em>POTATOES</em> were getting<strong> TOO MUCH</strong> direct sunlight so I stood over them with an <em>UMBRELLA</em>. Now they are getting too <em>LITTLE</em> rain! I clearly have<strong> TOO MUCH</strong> free time on my hands.	<em>Umbrellas</em> for <em>little potatoes</em>??? That's<strong> too much</strong>!	You're weighing potatoes to take from the market but they weigh<strong> too much</strong>. It's windy, so you hook your umbrella onto the scale hoping to subtract weight by catching the wind's force. Still<strong> too much</strong> weight. Just give up and select some smaller potatoes, man. Won't be<strong> too much</strong> weight then.		
除		exclude	Pinnacle . . . scale.		10	1787	1658	43	ジョ、ジ	のぞ.く、-よ.け	To become a member of <em>The Pinnacle</em>, they test you on a <em>scale</em>. If you weigh <em>too much</em>, they <strong>exclude</strong> you.	You won't make it unless you <strong>exclude</strong> something. The climb to the <em>pinacle</em> cannot be completed if you are carrying <em>too much</em>. You just have to decide what you can afford to <strong>exclude</strong>.	Before entering <em>The Pinnacle</em>, one must be weighed on a <em>scale</em>. The authorities have to<strong> exclude</strong> anyone who is over 300 pds since their weight might damage the floor.	Officials at the Acropolis<strong> exclude</strong> access to vehicles that weigh too much. Some gate staff also apply this to people (generally Americans) who weigh over 250 lbs.	(insert fat celeb here) is<strong> exclude</strong>d at <em>The Pinnacle</em> because he/she weighs <em>too much</em>.		
徐		gradually	Line . . . scale.		10	1788	1659	43	ジョ	おもむ.ろに	You can't expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit <em>going</em> to the <em>scale</em> to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss<strong> gradually</strong>.	I set up a <em>column</em> chart next to my <em>scales</em> so I could record my weight<strong> gradually</strong> changing.	Remember the urban legend of the ARMY COLUMN that weighed TOO MUCH with their rythmic marching that the bridge collapsed? Now ARMY COLUMNS will march<strong> GRADUALLY</strong> across so that they do not bear TOO MUCH on the bridge.	<em>Flash</em> didn't get fat overnight. He <strong>gradually</strong> added a pound on the <em>scale</em> here and there until finally he weighed <em>too much</em> to fit into his snazzy red costume. (Credit: CharleyGarrett).	Ever since he's stopped doing Tours, <em>Lance</em> has been<strong> gradually</strong> gaining weight. See him cringe as he steps on a <em>scale</em> and sees it<strong> gradually</strong> go up!		
叙		confer	<i>Scale</i> . . <i>crotch</i>. The key word has to do with <b>conferring</b> ranks, titles, and awards. It should not be confused with <i>bestow</i> (Frame 1335) or <i>impart</i> (Frame 795).		9	1789	1660	43	ジョ	つい.ず、ついで	Amazed at the <em>weight</em> of his <em>crotch</em>, they <strong>confer</strong>red every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.).	"(This kanji stands for <strong>description</strong> in my kanji dictionary) ""At first, I thought it was <em>too little</em>, but soon became <em>too much</em>"", is the <strong>description</strong> that my girlfriend gave of my <em>crotch</em>."	When you<strong> confer</strong> <em>again</em> 又 , you<strong> confer</strong> <em>too much</em> 余 !	When the fighter was weighed, the <em>scales spun wildly</em>. On closer inspection, it seems he is well-endowed and his <em>crotch</em> was pressing against the scales, adding vastly more amounts of weight. The judges then had to<strong> confer</strong> amongst themselves to consider what should be his real weight division.	Having honours<strong> confer</strong>red on him proved to be <em>too much</em>! He overbalanced, so instead of kneeling at the queen's feet, he somehow ended up sitting <em>cross-legged</em>.		
途		route	Scale . . . road.		10	1790	1661	43	ト	みち	On this<strong> route</strong>, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.	There are <em>too many roads</em>, so you need to plan a<strong> route</strong>.	When you’re spending <em>too much</em> time on the <em>road</em>, you’re always en <em>route</em> to somewhere.	Truck drivers in the US have to drive the truck onto some massive scales at state borders, for tax reasons. They have to plan their<strong> route</strong> accordingly; there aren't scales on every road.	Too much traffic on this road, lets take a different<strong> route</strong>!		
斜		diagonal	Scale . . . measuring cup.		11	1791	1662	43	シャ	なな.め、はす	The main bar of an old-fashioned <em>scale(balance)</em> will be very <strong>diagonal</strong> if you place a giant <em>measuring cup</em> on one side.	The <em>scale</em> tilts<strong> diagonal</strong>ly when a <em>measuring cup</em> filled with <em>too much</em> is set on one end.	"The constellation of libra (meaning "" scales"" in latin) is<strong> diagonal</strong> to the handle of the big dipper."	An old scale with <em>measuring cups</em> on both sides: If you put <em>too much</em> in only one of the <em>measuring cups</em>, the bar will change its position to<strong> diagonal</strong> (one <em>measuring cup</em> outweights the other).	If you visit<strong> DiagonAl</strong>ley, you'll find a lot of shops measuring out potion ingredients with <em>scales</em> and <em>measuring cups</em>.		
塗		paint	Water . . . scale . . . ground.		13	1792	1663	43	ト	ぬ.る、ぬ.り、まみ.れる	If you add <em>too much water</em> to the<strong> paint</strong> it will drip onto the <em>ground</em>.	A true artisan mixes his own <strong>paint</strong> from <em>water</em> and <em>soils</em> on a <em>scale</em> in careful proportions.	People ask why the ground of our backyard is entirely white. Well, my cheapskate dad wanted to add a fresh coat of white<strong> paint</strong> to our house. He bought the biggest, cheapest tub, placed it on a scale in our yard, and started diluting it with water. It was working fine, and he was adding water drop by drop and carefully checking the weight each time. However, his hand slipped, and he added <em>too much water</em> and the <em>scale broke down violently</em>, spilling the<strong> paint</strong> <em>all over the ground</em>.	The<strong> paint</strong> was WATERed down and TOO MUCH dripped on the GROUND.	If you put too much water in the<strong> PAINT</strong> mix in some soil to make it thicker.		
束		bundle	In the same way that we were able to see the <i>sun</i> in the <i>tree</i> within the kanji for <i>east</i>, here we see a square container in the shape of a <i>mouth</i>.		7	1793	1664	43	ソク	たば、たば.ねる、つか、つか.ねる	Mnemonic:<strong> Bundle</strong> of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its <em>mouth</em> fly straight into a <em>tree</em>. Painful, but he doesn't drop the<strong> bundle</strong>.	Unlike in 杏 , this big mouth isn't content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in<strong> bundle</strong>s.	A<strong> bundle</strong> of some kind has been stuffed into the <em>opening</em> of a <em>tree</em>.	This is an image of the monster Gojira (AKA Godzilla) that is so mad it has eaten all the trees. So a<strong> bundle</strong> of trees sticks out of Gojiras mouth as it rampages through Tokyo.	"Tip: I was looking for a personification for<strong> bundle</strong> man [+fab] and came across this evocative story from the archives (1889) <a href=""http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9901E5D9163BE033A25755C2A9659C94689FD7CF"">http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9901E5D9163BE033A25755C2A9659C94689FD7CF</a> Caution: the famous vagrant is known as Leather Man so don't confuse with <a href=""../v4/1893.html"">leather</a> (#1893 革). But in the end I couldn't resist both because of the interesting story and the fact one of the possessions found in his mysterious sack (bundle) was an awl as used in subsequent frames 1671-1674!"		
頼		trust	Bundle . . . head.		16	1794	1665	43	ライ	たの.む、たの.もしい、たよ.る	We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to<strong> trust</strong> you.	Don't<strong> Trust</strong> the press just a <em>bundle</em> of lies on every <em>page</em>!	[trust; request] Do you <strong>trust</strong> anything? Actually we do, as long as a <em>bundle</em> of <em>heads</em> say the same thing. If a <em>bundle</em> of scientist's <em>heads</em> say we live in a 12 dimensions universe, why should we not <strong>trust</strong> them?	"Even though the stork didn't drop its <em>bundle</em> when it crashed into the tree, I still don't<strong> trust</strong> it to deliver any more babies - the one I got isn't right in the <em>head</em>. Must be a result of the stork-tree collision (see also <a href=""../v4/1669.html"">quick</a> (#1669 速))."	"<a href=""midori://search?text=%E9%A0%BC%E3%82%80%E3%80%81%E3%81%9F%E3%81%AE%E3%82%80"">頼む、たのむ</a> Godzilla requested a bundle of heads. If we give it, he will spare the rest. Can we <strong>trust</strong> him?"		
瀬		rapids	Water . . . bundle . . . head.		19	1795	1666	43	ライ	せ	You need complete <em>trust</em> in your <em>water</em> guide to attempt Class 5 <strong>rapids</strong>.	You can never trust the water in the<strong> rapids</strong>, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the<strong> rapids</strong> to cross the river.	The water in the<strong> rapids</strong> can't be trusted.	When I saw a <em>bundle</em> of severed <em>heads</em> floating in the water, I didn't <em>trust</em> the<strong> rapids</strong>, or the guide for that matter…	The <em>water</em> of the<strong> rapids</strong> are not to be <em>trusted</em>.		
勅		imperial order	In order to keep this character distinct from that for an <i>imperial edict</i> (Frame 366), we must draw again on a pun. Think of the <b>order</b> here as a mail <b>order</b> or an <b>order</b> of pizza phoned in by the Emperor for delivery to the <b>imperial</b> palace. Then it will not be hard to put together <i>bundle</i> and <i>muscle</i> to form a story about an <b>imperial order</b>.		9	1796	1667	43	チョク	いまし.める、みことのり	This is an<strong> imperial order</strong> for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.	<strong>Imperial order</strong> carries quite a <em>bundle</em> of executive <em>power</em>.	"""Did someone have an<strong> imperial order</strong> for pizza?"" says the muscular delivery boy with a large ""bundle"" in the new adult film, ""The Emperor's Nude Groove""."	The emperor makes an<strong> imperial order</strong>: A <em>bundle</em> of seafood pizzas, mainly with <em>muscles</em> for topping.	A (written)<strong> imperial order</strong>: a little <em>bundle</em> of paper that carries a lot of <em>power</em>.		
疎		alienate	<i>Zoo</i> . . . <i>bundle</i>. Note that the element for <i>zoo</i> is flattened out on the left just as <i>leg</i> (Frame 1372) had been. This is the only time we will meet this form in this book.		12	1797	1668	43	ソ、ショ	うと.い、うと.む、まば.ら	[True story] In Osaka the homeless (the<strong> alienate</strong>d) live in large numbers around the city <em>zoo</em>. Picture them in winter all <em>bundled</em> up in rags trying to keep warm,<strong> alienate</strong>d from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the <em>zoo</em> who at least are <em>bundled</em> in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.	This kanji is so strange that it was<strong> alienate</strong>d at the kanji <em>zoo</em>. The <em>bundle</em> of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.	Think of a Kanji <em>Zoo</em>, where we <em>bundle</em> up all the bizarre and hard to remember kanji, to be ridiculed and <em>alienated</em> from the other more sensible kanji. This kanji definately belongs there!	The cleaner at the ZOO felt<strong> ALIENATE</strong>D by everyone. Granted, he was carrying around the BUNDLE of manure he cleaned from the ZOO cages. (Just picture a zoo cleaner carrying a bundle of dung with the crowd avoiding him).	"Very rarely does this kanji appear in a word meaning ""alienate."" The better meaning is ""sparse,"" such as not dense, very few, scattered, or spread irregularly. It also appears in words that have to do with ""neglect."" 疎ら 【まばら】 (adj-na,n) sparse; (P) STORY: at the ZOO BUNDLES of happy animals are SPARSE."		
辣		bitter	Spicy . . . bundle.		14	1798	3025	43	ラツ	から.い	<strong>bitter</strong>, <em>spicy</em>, <em>bundle</em>: In a desperate attempt of creating a new drink, they decided to mix a <strong>bitter</strong> drink with a <em>spicy</em> one – now <em>bundled</em> together for the same price of one! However,<strong> bitter</strong>ness didn't go well with the spicy, as seen in the misshape to the left.	The<strong> bitter</strong> taste was so awful that I put whole <em>bundle</em> of <em>spice</em> in my mouth to get rid of it.	I'm rather <strong>bitter</strong> that someone stole my <em>spice bundle</em>.	<strong>severe</strong>: When you were forced to put the spicy bundle of Wasabi in your mouth, you experienced severe pain.	Too many spicy things bundled in a meal will make anyone feel<strong> bitter</strong> towards the cook. 辛辣 ; 辛らつ 【しんらつ】 (adj-na,n)<strong> bitter</strong>; sharp; acrimonious 悪辣 ; 悪らつ 【あくらつ】 (adj-na) crafty; vicious; unscrupulous; sharp.		
速		quick	Bundle . . . road.		10	1799	1669	43	ソク	はや.い、はや-、はや.める、すみ.やか	If you find a bundle of money on the road, pick it up<strong> quick</strong> before anyone notices.	Uh oh. The stork just dropped the <em>bundle</em> of joy in the middle of the <em>road</em>. Somebody save it,<strong> quick</strong>!	Jack be nimble, Jack be <strong>quick</strong>, Jack jump over the <em>bundle</em> in the middle of the road.	A <em>bundle</em> of optic fibers running along the <em>road</em> makes for<strong> quick</strong> internet access.	I banged her<strong> quick</strong>, then bundled up and hit the road!		
整		organize	Bundle . . . taskmaster . . . correct.		16	1800	1670	43	セイ	ととの.える、ととの.う	Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your <em>bundles</em> are<strong> organize</strong>d <em>correctly</em> otherwise the <em>taskmasters</em> won't accept them.	When a <em>bundle</em> of <em>taskmasters</em> <strong>organize</strong> something chances are it won't be done <em>correctly</em> because they are constantly arguing.	<strong>Organize</strong>, def: when <em>taskmasters bundle</em> tasks <em>correctly</em>.	At stork headquarters there is a<em> taskmaster</em> who<strong> organize</strong>s all the outgoing <em>bundles of joy</em>. It is very important to<strong> organize</strong> things so that the <em>correct</em> bundle goes to the <em>correct</em> place!!! (Just imagine if the crocodiles opened their bundle to find kittens!!!).	When you have a <em>bundle</em> of things to<strong> organize</strong> appoint a <em>taskmaster</em> to oversee it is done <em>correct</em>ly.		
剣		saber	<i>Awl</i> . . . <i>saber</i>. As we promised way back in frame 87, here at last is the kanji on which the primitive element of the same name is based.		10	1801	1671	43	ケン	つるぎ	If it helps, make the awl primitive <strong>ice pick</strong> instead. They're basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the <strong>icepick</strong> vs. the <em>saber</em>…	"Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of ""The <em>Awl and the Sabre</em>"". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an <em>awl</em> against a <em>sabre</em>! She used to work all day with that <em>awl</em>. However, the bandit using the <em>sabre</em> had no skill. And thus the <em>awl</em> beat the <em>sabre</em>. And from there the saying goes : ""The <em>sabre</em> is powerless against the <em>awl</em>, if one can't use the <em>sabre</em>.""."	ICE PICK primitive: How do you FIT a PERSON into a tight BOX (mouth primitive)? Poke holes in him with a ICE PICK, draining the blood and making the body smaller. STORY: If that does not work, take out your<strong> SABER</strong> and cut them up into neat pieces.	As a non-native speaker of English, I really couldn't work with the awl primitive, since I can't even imagine what kind of tool it would be. So, I had another look at the primitive and it practically screamed a different meaning: <em>fit together</em> and <em>person</em>, i.e. Frankenstein's Monster. // The crowd came after the monster of Frankenstein with sabres!	My light<strong> saber</strong> has an <em>awl</em> setting. When I toggle the switch, the beam shrinks down to a little spike. My light<strong> saber</strong> becomes a light <em>awl</em>.		
険		precipitous	Pinnacle . . . awl.		11	1802	1672	43	ケン	けわ.しい	The edge of <em>The Pinnacle</em> is <strong>precipitous</strong>, so they have a guard posted with an <em>ice pick</em> to poke people and keep them from the edge.	Well I have someone climbing an inflatable<strong> precipitous</strong> <em>pinnacle</em>. Once at the top it is so<strong> precipitous</strong> that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable <em>pinnacle</em> with an <em>awl</em> to get safely and slowly back to the ground.	Frankenstein is chased by the villagers up to the<strong> precipitous</strong> edge of the pinnacle. (ref 1671 astridtops).	The <em>Ice Climbers</em> enjoy<strong> precipitous</strong> climbs - and what better place to climb than the<strong> precipitous</strong> <em>Pinnacle</em>!	The rock climber trying to get up to the pinnacle is dangling from a<strong> precipitous</strong> edge, hanging only one with his icepick.		
検		examination	Tree . . . awl.		12	1803	1673	43	ケン	しら.べる	"You're giving a TREE an<strong> EXAMINATION</strong>. You take a wood sample from the TREE with an AWL (cmp <a href=""../v4/1278.html"">exam</a> (#1278 校))."	"Don't confuse with <a href=""../v4/1278.html"">exam</a> (#1278 校), <a href=""../v4/354.html"">test</a> (#354 試), <a href=""../v4/1487.html"">evaluate</a> (#1487 評). Think of<strong> examination</strong> as a doctor's<strong> examination</strong>. You're having problems getting <em>wood</em> in bed. You go in for a doctor's<strong> examination</strong>. The doctor shoves an <em>icepick</em> into your manhood as part of the<strong> examination</strong>."	"After intense cross-<strong>examination</strong> from the prosecutor, the <em>tree</em> confessed to murdering the <em>wood</em>-pecker with an <em>awl</em>… ""He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!"" The autopsy<strong> examination</strong> revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case."	"The doctor gives a physical<strong> examination</strong> to <em>Frankenstein's Monster.</em> The monster is so big the doctor has to use a <em>tree</em> to hit his knee and check his reflexes. (I am using astridtops' primitive of <em>Frankenstein's Monster</em> (fit (together) and person) in place of ""awl"")."	"Patient goes to see the doctor for an<strong> examination</strong>. he says ""Everytime i walk i fart"". Doc asks him to take a few steps and he farts constantly. Docs puzzled and has never seen this before. He asks him to repeat and it happens again. So the doc tells him to go to the examinatino area and take his pants off. He then gets out a giant wooden awl slightly hooked at the end. What the f*<em>k are you going to do with that!? asks teh patient. ""Open the windows, it f</em>cking stinks in here!"" replies the doc."		
倹		frugal	Person . . . awl.		10	1804	1674	43	ケン	つま.しい、つづまやか	<em>Mr. T</em> is as <strong>frugal</strong> as they come. He uses his one <em>ice pick</em> for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.	<em>Mr. T</em> is so <strong>frugal</strong>, he hires <em>Frankenstein</em> as a butler because he doesn't have to pay him.	Mr T is a<strong> frugal</strong> person in spite of his brash appearance. He brings an awl with him to fight for the A team, not wasting needless ammo and dynamite, since no one ever gets killed anyway in A team series.	"Some <em>n00b</em> spent all the club's money, so <em>Haruhi</em> teaches him how to be<strong> frugal</strong> (see <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1671"">sabre/saber</a> (#1671 剣)."			
重		heavy	<i>Thousand</i> . . . <i>ri</i>. Note how the long vertical stroke doubles up to serve both elements.		9	1805	1675	43	ジュウ、チョウ	え、おも.い、おも.り、おも.なう、かさ.ねる、かさ.なる、おも	The first computer in the world was as<strong> heavy</strong> as thousand computers are now.	"To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very<strong> heavy</strong> vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first ""wheel"" is a bit bent. <a href=""http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html"">http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html</a>."	TRỌNG : A CAR 車 WITH DOUBLE WHEELS , TOO<strong> HEAVY</strong> !!! EASY , YEAH !	<em>1000</em>（ 千 ）<em>computers</em> ( 里 )　are so<strong> heavy</strong>.	A<strong> heavy</strong> duty <em>truck</em> with four-wheel drive.		
動		move	Heavy . . . muscle.		11	1806	1676	43	ドウ	うご.く、うご.かす	Even though the furniture is <em>heavy</em>, it'll be easy to<strong> move</strong> with all the <em>muscles</em> that he has.	His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can<strong> move</strong>…thats ironic.	Heavy things can be<strong> move</strong>d with a bit of muscle.	To<strong> move</strong> something heavy, you need muscles.	Everyone knows that (Force x Mass= acceleration), and as is typical when converting western expressions to eastern expressions this kanji gives us the same equation in reverse order and pictorialized: (Heavy x Muscle =<strong> Move</strong>). ;-p easy peasy.		
腫		tumor	Flesh . . . heavy.		13	1807	2467	43	シュ、ショウ	は.れる、は.れ、は.らす、く.む、はれもの	A<strong> tumor</strong> is a useless <em>body part</em> that is nothing but <em>heavy</em>.	The world's <em>heaviest</em><strong> tumor</strong> ever removed from a human body was a 300-pound stomach<strong> tumor</strong>, removed in 1991 in Stanford Hospital. Now that's a <em>heavy body part</em>!	When <em>flesh</em> clumps together and gets <em>heavy</em>, it forms a<strong> tumor</strong>.	You've got a<strong> tumor</strong> on your <em>flesh</em>? That's <em>heavy</em>, man.	The FLESH of a<strong> TUMOR</strong> is HEAVIER than normal FLESH.		
勲		meritorious deed	<i>Move</i> . . . <i>oven fire</i>. So as not to confuse this kanji with the general character for <i>merit</i> (Frame 1369), you may associate the key word with military decorations and medals of distinction, both of which it is used for.		15	1808	1677	43	クン	いさお	A<strong> meritorious deed</strong>? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.	Prometheus did a meritous deed for humanity by MOVING FIRE from the gods to us humans.	Oskar Schindler is best remembered for his<strong> meritorious deed</strong>: moving 1200 Jews to his factory so that they could be saved from the fires of Auschwitz.	"(from Raichu) The classic<strong> meritorious deed</strong> is saving a damsel in distress from a burning building. You hear her sweet voice crying ""help! help!"" from inside. But when you get inside, you see that she's quite heavy… you'll need some muscles for this deed."	You get a medal if you do some <strong>meritorious deed</strong> in combat. When the shooting starts, some freeze and cannot <em>move</em>. The normal ones can move under <em>fire</em>. But the REAL medal winners are the ones that move over <em>flames</em>!. Not that is a <strong>meritorious deed</strong>!		
働		work	<i>Person</i> . . . <i>move</i>. Do not confuse with <i>labor</i> (Frame 924).		13	1809	1678	43	ドウ、リュク、リキ、ロク、リョク	はたら.く	<em>Mr. T</em>'s real line of <strong>work</strong> is for a <em>moving</em> company.	"Mr T, move. Mr Ts new exercise video called ""Work it suckaz"". Here is shouting ""move it<strong> work</strong> it move<strong> work</strong> it!""."	A person who moves something is doing<strong> work</strong>, physically speaking.	<em>Luke Skywalker</em> had to<strong> work</strong> hard to become a jedi, being forced to <em>move</em> an X-Wing with his mind before leaving Dagobah.	"In his poor days, <em>Mister T</em>, thanks to his healthy build, used to<strong> work</strong> as a (furniture) <em>mover</em> (Br. ""removal man""). He <em>worked</em> 7/7 days, since when he wasn't <em>moving</em> furniture, he was <em>working</em> out !"		
種		species	Wheat . . . heavy.		14	1810	1679	43	シュ	たね、-ぐさ	After the whole low-carb craze, scientists developed a new low-carb<strong> species</strong> of <em>wheat</em>, so that dieters could eat it without getting <em>heavier</em>.	"This kanji also means ""Seed."" STORY: Scientists have developed a new<strong> SPECIES</strong> of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world."	The <em>heavy wheat</em> is a special type or<strong> species</strong> of wheat used to fatten livestock.	This is also the word for <strong>seed</strong>. Wheat seeds are sorted by how heavy they are.	The hot chick from <strong>Species</strong> has been eating a lot of <em>bread</em> lately, and she's really gotten <em>heavy</em>.		
衝		collide	Boulevard . . . heavy.		15	1811	1680	43	ショウ	つ.く	Two <em>heavy trucks</em> in a game of chicken <strong>collide</strong> while racing toward each other on the <em>boulevard</em>.	Something <em>heavy</em> rolling down the middle of the <em>boulevard</em> is definitely going to end up <strong>colliding</strong> with something.	衝 【しょう】 (n) (1) important point (e.g. on a route); (2) important role (responsibility, etc.); (3) (astronomical) opposition. STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they<strong> COLLIDE</strong> when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).	Two heavy sumo wrestlers, in normal clothing while shopping, see each other at opposite sides of the boulevard and suddenly get in their stance and charge at each other until they<strong> collide</strong>, knocking everyone else out of the way.	The LHC (Large Hadron <strong>Collider</strong>) is as wide as a <em>boulevard</em> and so <em>heavy</em> that machinery had to be used to assemble the pieces.		
薫		fragrant	<i>Flowers</i> . . . <i>heavy</i> . . . <i>oven fire</i>. Do not confuse with <i>incense</i> (Frame 977) or <i>perfumed</i> (Frame 532).		16	1812	1681	43	クン	かお.る	"Do you know how they make those<strong> FRAGRANT</strong> air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while… (cmp <a href=""../v4/493.html"">perfume</a> (#493 芳))."	The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.	These <em>flowers</em> emit very <em>heavy</em> <strong>fragrance</strong> when burned <em>over the fire</em> (e.g. the <strong>fragrant</strong> jasmine flowers).	(クン) Steve Jobs does it again. This heavy duty mac computer has a place for flowers on top. When the computer heats up (the fire on the bottom), the flowers release a beautiful<strong> fragrant</strong> smell.	As the <em>heavy duty truck</em> smolders in <em>flames</em>, the<strong> fragrant</strong> smell of <em>flowers</em> is emitted from the pine tree air freshener still hanging from the rear-view mirror.		
病		ill	Sickness . . . third class.		10	1813	1682	44	ビョウ、ヘイ	や.む、-や.み、やまい	<em>Caveman</em> got <strong>ill</strong> after flying <em>third class</em>. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using <em>CAVEMAN</em> instead. ).	If you hang around a <em>third class</em> hospital, you'll get<strong> ill</strong> with the <em>sickness</em> everyone else has.	"Note: according to this <a href=""http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/"">http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/</a>~jwb/cgi-bin/wwwhalsod.cgi?3277_%C9%C2 the stroke order is different to that presented in the Heisig book. 4th and 5th strokes are reversed."	I have this female friend who complains about <em>third class</em> type stuff a lot. She'll say stuff like ''That train ride made me<strong> ill</strong>. Seriously,'' and ''Oh my god, sitting next that dirty guy made me<strong> ill</strong>. Seriously.'' Sometimes I just want to kick her in the cunt.	Hint: The<strong> ill</strong> in<strong> ill</strong> almost looks like the roman numeral <strong>III</strong>. Use as a hint to 3rd class. The<strong> ill</strong> are more abundant in <em>third class</em> countries (<em>third world</em>).		
痴		stupid	Know . . . sickness.		13	1814	1683	44	チ	し.れる、おろか	Of course <em>caveman</em> is <strong>stupid</strong>. He doesn't <em>know</em> anything. He's a <em>caveman</em>!	"This kanji shows<strong> stupid</strong>ity as a ""<em>knowledge-sickness</em>"". Everybody can be<strong> stupid</strong> at times, and it usually happens because of a lack of experience. Hence the<strong> stupid</strong>ity is a ""<em>knowledge sickness</em>""."	"Ever since reading dingomick's story, I've had this dialogue stuck in my head when I come across the keyword: ""<em>Caveman</em> not<strong> stupid</strong>, <em>Caveman</em> <em>know</em> things.""."	You mean you didn't <em>know</em> you'd get <em>sick</em> living in an <em>icy cave</em>? Are you<strong> stupid</strong>?	<strong>Stupidity</strong> is a common <em>illness</em> that afflicts everyone. It is said to cause a lack of <em>knowledge</em>.

"<em>Mr. Bean</em> tries to explain to the <em>caveman</em> that he is covered in chicken<strong> pox</strong> and not to come near him, but the <em>caveman</em> misunderstands and eats him. ""THIS CHICKEN<strong> POX</strong> NOT TASTE GOOD.""."	<strong>Pox</strong> is a very contagious <em>sickness</em>, you'll get it just by sitting at the same table as someone infected.	The <em>Geico caveman</em> gets chicken<strong> pox</strong>. The doctor says the only cure is to take a bath in <em>baked beans</em>.		
症		symptoms	Sickness . . . correct.		10	1816	1685	44	ショウ		Once you have all the<strong> symptoms</strong> right, you have <em>correctly </em> identified the <em>sickness</em>.	A <em>sickness</em> can only be <em>correctly</em> diagnosed if the<strong> symptoms</strong> are identified <em>correctly</em>.	One of the<strong> SYMPTOMS</strong> of being a CAVEMAN is you don't get much CORRECT in a test.	"Doctor: ""let's go over your<strong> symptoms</strong>, <em>caveman</em>., shall we? Do you have a stuffy nose?"" Caveman: ""correct"". Doctor: ""Does your throat hurt?"" Caveman: ""correct"". Doctor: ""well, caveman, it sounds like you have a cold!""."	Checking the<strong> symptoms</strong> helps to identify the <em>correct</em> <em>sickness</em>.		
瘍		carbuncle	Sickness . . . piggy bank.		14	1817	3026	44	ヨウ	かさ	The witches <em>piggy bank</em> was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The <em>illness</em> would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of <strong>carbuncles</strong>. Crime doesn't pay!	<em>Caveman</em> has to open up his <em>piggy bank</em> to receive treatment for his monstrous <strong>carbuncle</strong>.	His <em>sickness</em> caused numerous<strong> carbuncle</strong>s, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his <em>piggy bank</em>.	In this kanji the <em>Caveman</em> has a <em>piggy bank</em>-shaped<strong> carbuncle</strong> under his skin. Hmm, well, at least it looks kind of unique.	There goes the lonely miser, all covered in <strong>CARBUNCLE</strong>s. The local lore says that his hideous <em>ILLNESS</em> is divine retribution for his avarice: the <strong>CARBUNCLE</strong>s are said to be shaped like <em>PIGGY BANK</em>s!		
痩		lose weight	Sickness . . . monkey . . . crotch.		15	1818	2577	44	ソウ、チュウ、シュウ、シュ	や.せる	The <em>sickness</em> that only allows you to eat <em>monkey crotch</em> will surely make you<strong> lose weight</strong>.	<em>Caveman</em> want to<strong> lose weight</strong>… but not know how. He sees a lean <em>monkey</em> playing with its <em>crotch</em>. Ah! So that's how I<strong> lose weight</strong>, and he imitates the monkey.	Simian Immunodeficiency Virus, the precursor to HIV, is a <em>sickness</em> that is transmitted by carnal knowledge of a <em>monkey's crotch</em>. Naturally, it causes one to<strong> lose weight</strong>. <em>Cavemen</em> used to catch it all the time.	The poor <em>monkey</em> obviously had a <em>sickness</em>. He was scratching his <em>crotch</em> the whole time and when he started to<strong> lose weight</strong> heavily, the caretakers knew they couldn't save him anymore.	The most horrific way to<strong> lose weight</strong> is from that devastating sickness that came from a monkey's crotch.		
疾		rapidly	"Be sure to keep this character distinct from <i>quick</i> (Frame 1799) and <i>swift</i> (Frame 298). Picture a succession of poison <i>darts</i> (the sort that inflict <i>sickness</i>) flying out <b>rapid</b>-fire from a blowgun, so that ""<b>rapid</b>-fire"" can conjure up the proper image."		10	1819	1686	44	シツ	はや.い	I picture a sick caveman, and two people<strong> rapidly</strong> blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how<strong> rapidly</strong> they fire.	If shot with a <em>poison dart</em>, <em>sickness</em> develops<strong> rapidly</strong>.	"Hm, it's getting tougher to differentiate similar kanji: <a href=""../v4/280.html"">swift</a> (#280 迅), <a href=""../v4/1146.html"">hurry</a> (#1146 急), <a href=""../v4/1669.html"">quick</a> (#1669 速). Let's consider<strong> rapidly</strong> as a <strong>rapid</strong>-fire weapon: rat-tat-tat-tat-tat-tat. This weapon fires poison <em>darts</em><strong> rapidly</strong> in an automatic rapid-fire fashion. The poison darts are not lethal; they merely induce <em>sickness</em> in the victims."	The <em>sick caveman</em> is deteriorating <strong>rapidly</strong> from the <strong>rapid</strong>-fire gun that shot hime with <em>sickening</em> poison <em>darts</em>.	See book.		
嫉		envy	Woman . . . rapidly.		13	1820	2202	44	シツ	そね.む、ねた.む、にく.む	If you go through <em>women</em> <em>rapidly</em> you will be the object of<strong> envy</strong>.	Ah, puberty … the girl that starts her journey towards <em>womanhood</em> the most <em>rapidly</em> will become the subject of<strong> envy</strong> from all her classmates.	<strong>Envy</strong> (from FMA) is a boy homunculus (though a bit androgynous), but when they dubbed FMA to English, they somehow snipped his pickle and turned him into a <em>girl</em>. Wave of protests from hardcore fans emerged <em>rapidly</em>.	<em>Women</em> get envious very rapidly. Picture one <em>woman</em> walking into a party in a gorgeous dress, and all other <em>women</em> there rapidly getting envious of her beautiful dress.	WOMEN are full of<strong> envy</strong>. It's a Cupid thing– when one is hit with a dart of love, another's hit with a dart of<strong> envy</strong>, a kind of sickness that RAPIDLY infects everything she does.

疲		tired	Sickness . . . pelt.		10	1823	1688	44	ヒ	つか.れる、-づか.れ、つか.らす	I picture an <strong>exhausted</strong> <em>sick caveman</em> snuggling up in a <em>comfy pelt blanket</em>.
