疫		epidemic	Sickness . . . missile.		9	1824	1689	44	エキ、ヤク		"<em>Sickness-missiles</em> are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread<strong> epidemic</strong>s all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those<em> sickness-missiles</em> are built : rows after rows of <em>missiles</em>, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different <em>sickness</em> such as ""flu"", ""plague"", etc."	SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some<strong> EPIDEMIC</strong> or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. [C].	When CAVEMAN first fashions a primitive MISSILE and kills a mammoth with it, the technique spreads like an<strong> EPIDEMIC</strong> across the inhabited world.	An<strong> EPIDEMIC</strong> is a SICKNESS that hits like MISSLES.	When a <em>sick caveman</em> sneezes, the germs shoot out of his mouth like a <em>missile</em>. Ironically, this biological <em>missile</em> is much more deadly than any spear the <em>caveman</em> could throw, especially if it results in an <strong>epidemic</strong>.

Well I wasn't strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the<strong> pain</strong> to prove my mum right.	<em>Caveman</em> feels no<strong> pain</strong> (since he was frozen for so long his<strong> pain</strong> sensors are numbed). Here we see some kids using a <em>pogo stick</em> to jump on his hand.	Think of the phrase<strong> pain</strong> in the xxx. Then think of a <em>pogostick</em> up your xxx. 癖		mannerism	Sickness . . . ketchup.		18	1826	1691	44	ヘキ	くせ、くせ.に	<em>Caveman</em> has a bad <strong>mannerism</strong> of putting <em>ketchup</em> on everything he eats. It was only recently that we started putting <em>ketchup</em> on everything.	Building on inuki's idea: Monk, who suffers from OCD (a <em>sickness</em> involving <strong>mannerisms</strong>) sees a row of <em>ketchup</em> bottles at a restaurant crime scene and spends twenty minutes making the Heinz labels face exactly the same direction. A SICK<strong> MANNERISM</strong> is putting KETCHUP on everything.		
匿		hide	Box . . . young.		10	1827	1692	44	トク	かくま.う	<em>Young</em> kids likes to <strong>hide</strong> in <em>cardboard boxes</em>. (Primitive: <em>CARDBOARD BOX</em>, especially kids playing with them.).	Note that stroke order with <em>box</em> primitive is as follows: first horizontal line, then enclosed element, and then a hook (it's incorrect in 4th edition).	This kanji doesn't really mean <strong>hide</strong> in the sense of<strong> hide</strong> and seek. It is more towards the meaning of hiding one's identity. ————————–AKA <strong>anonymity</strong>———– Schools are getting so strict now about personal identity, that they make <em>young</em> children keep <strong>anonymity</strong> by making them wear <em>cardboard</em> boxes over there heads.	Primitive = Solid Snake. <em>Solid Snake</em><strong> hide</strong>s in a <em>cardboard box</em> so he wont be detected. He's loved hiding in boxes ever since he was <em>young</em>.	"When I was YOUNG I used to play to<strong> hide</strong> and seek ….Everything was good for that : even and old BOX . I was quite innocent at that time …. Later I learned games of adult : especially lies and conceal one's feelings…. NB : In order to avoid confusion with <a href=""../v4/1313.html"">conceal</a> (#1313 隠)<strong> hide</strong> is given a material meaning while conceal will be more intellectual …. The background of youth strenghten this conception."		
匠		artisan	Box . . . ax.		6	1828	1693	44	ショウ	たくみ	Most people don't know that one of the most revered <strong>artisan</strong>s in Japan preserves the ancient art of cutting <em>cardboard boxes</em> with an <em>ax</em>. We here have the axe-man who's an<strong> artisan</strong> at making sculptures with his axe… The only thing is, he never shows anyone, keeping all his sculptures inside a box down in the basement. He doesn't want any attention.	Hint:<strong> Artisan</strong>/Ax Def: An<strong> artisan</strong> is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the<strong> artisan</strong>'s <em>ax</em> stored in his tool<em>box</em>.	The tool <em>box</em> of the<strong> artisan</strong> has an <em>axe</em> within.

The<strong> doctor</strong> is tired of seeing one patient after another wanting vaccinations, so he steps into the waiting room with a big <em>box</em> full of <em>darts</em> loaded with the medicine. Bam, bam, bam, all done.	"A<strong> doctor</strong> is someone who keeps a <em>box</em> full of poison-<em>dart</em>-like syringes. (Careful not to mix up with <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/47"">Dr.</a> (#47 博), from waaay back in lesson 3. This is ""doctor"" as a profession, where as ""Dr."" is a title.)."	This<strong> doctor</strong> is carrying her <em>syringes</em> around in a nice portable <em>cardboard box</em>.		
匹		equal	Box . . . human legs.		4	1830	1695	44	ヒツ	ひき	This kanji is used commonly as a <strong>counter for small animals</strong>. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL'S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He's probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones<strong> EQUAL</strong> fate on the farm: the kitchen table).	Put a <em>box</em> over everyone's heads, letting only the <em>legs</em> show, and we all look pretty much<strong> equal</strong>.	Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a <em>box</em> and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the <em>human legs</em> sticking horizontally out of the <em>box</em> remind you of an<strong> equal</strong> sign?	Four minus one stroke is<strong> equal</strong> to..?	<em>4 - 1</em> <strong>=</strong> this kanji.		
区		ward	The <b>ward</b> referred to here is a subdivision of a large city. Its elements: <i>box</i> . . . <i>sheaves</i>. When used as a primitive element, it may be helpful at times to break it up into these same composite elements.		4	1831	1696	44	ク、オウ、コウ		That's the homeless <strong>ward</strong> of the city. <em>Wolverine</em> lives in a <em>cardboard box</em> there.	In the<strong> ward</strong> office the <em>sheaves</em> of paper of the<strong> ward</strong> registration forms are kept in a <em>box</em>.	In the Akihabara<strong> ward</strong>, it is mandated that every resident own an X-BOX (well more like a PS3 but you get the point).	This is a special<strong> ward</strong> at the hospital for bad crops, where the farmers gently bring in their <em>sheaves</em> tucked away in little <em>boxes</em> for treatment, the poor things.	X man lives in a small BOX apartment in Shibuya<strong> WARD</strong>.		
枢		hinge	Tree . . . ward.		8	1832	1697	44	スウ、シュ	とぼそ、からくり	The <strong>hinge</strong> on <em>Wolverine's</em> <em>cardboard box</em> is made of wood because he doesn't have enough budget to buy metal <strong>hinge</strong>s.	You notice a<strong> hinge</strong> on a <em>tree</em> and realize there's a secret door. You open it up to find an <em>Xbox</em>!!!	The<strong> hinge</strong> in this hospital <em>ward</em> was made of <em>wood</em> because they didn't have enough budget to buy metal<strong> hinge</strong>s.	"I like using ""X Box"" as the primitive instead of ward. The first <em>X Box</em> had a lot of problems. I guess Microsoft was in a hurry to get it out. I even noticed that the<strong> hinge</strong>s were made of <em>wood</em>… what the hell?"	Make sure you install the<strong> hinge</strong> the right way. If it opens <em>treeward</em> (= <em>tree</em> <em>ward</em>), you won't be able to get the fence open, make sure it opens houseward.		
殴		assault	Ward . . . missile.		8	1833	1698	44	オウ	なぐ.る	The city decides to disperse the <em>homeless ward</em> with a precision <em>missile</em> <strong>assault</strong>. They didn't know <em>Wolverine</em> was living in a <em>cardboard box</em> there though…	The biggest<strong> assault</strong> on Japan during WW2 is when the <em>wards</em> in Hiroshima and Nagasaki were wiped out by nuclear <em>missiles</em>.	In this hospital <em>ward</em>, the personnel is<strong> assault</strong>ed by <em>missiles</em>. Kids these days are just<strong> assault</strong>ed by violent games. Just look at these <em>X-Box</em> games - they all have <em>missiles</em> in them! Even Barbie Horse Adventure!	Best game of the year award goes to…. MISSLE<strong> ASSAULT</strong> for the XBOX! What a great game :-D.		
欧		Europe	<i>Ward</i> . . . <i>yawn</i>. Like the kanji of frame 1776, this character is an abbreviation of the name of a geographical region.		8	1834	1699	44	オウ	うた.う、は.く	"""<strong>Europe</strong>? <em>Yawn…</em> I've been to every <em>ward</em>(country/area),"" says <em>Wolverine</em> interviewed from his <em>cardboard box</em>."	[Europe] <em>X-Box</em> was first released in America and Japan (the biggest videogame markets). <strong>Europe</strong> had an <em>X-Box</em> <em>lack</em> for a while…	Do japanese consider<strong> Europe</strong> like just a <em>ward</em>, boring enough to make them <em>yawn</em>?? This kanji is offensive!	The <strong>EU</strong> <em>lacks</em> separate economic <em>wards</em>.	The <em>X-Box</em> wasn't a big hit in<strong> Europe</strong>. They took one look at it and collectively <em>yawn</em>ed.		
抑		repress	Fingers . . . box . . . stamps.		7	1835	1700	44	ヨク	おさ.える	A true <em>stamp</em> collecting nerd won't be able to<strong> repress</strong> the urge to get his <em>fingers</em> on the latest <em>box</em> of collector <em>stamps</em>!	They would <strong>repress</strong> dissents by cutting off their <em>fingers</em> and mailing them to relatives in <em>small boxes</em> (of course including <em>stamps</em> for proper postage).	"A chikan (bus-molester) tries to<strong> repress</strong> his <em>finger</em>-groping desire by refusing to travel by bus anymore. Instead, he seals himself in a <em>box</em>, makes sure there are enough <em>postage stamps</em> on the outside, and mails himself. He's a good man at heart , you see… just a bit of a slave to his libido. (I suggest using this same Chikan as the primitive for the ""box and stamp"" combo on the right side of this kanji, which come up more than once later on)."	I'm just gonna say what we're all thinking. Young women work hard to<strong> repress</strong> their urges to put their <em>fingers</em> in their <em>boxes</em> because if their mothers found out, they could be <em>stamped</em> with a big WHORE stamp across their faces for the rest of their lives. Such a stamping is avoided by severe <strong>repression</strong>.	The right side is a rabbit ( 卯 ) that has lost one ear. He (I'm thinking of a cartoony rabbit who has lost the ear in some battle with an enemy) has to<strong> repress</strong> (concretely, with his fingers!) his urge to revenge, which is hard to contain in his little head.		
仰		faceup	This character is used both for lying on one's back <b>faceup</b>, and for looking up to someone with respect and awe. Its elements: <i>person</i> . . . <i>box</i> . . . <i>stamps</i>.		6	1836	1701	44	ギョウ、コウ	あお.ぐ、おお.せ、お.っしゃる、おっしゃ.る	All <em>stamps</em> in <em>Mr T</em>'s collection <em>box</em> are lied carefully <strong>face-up</strong>.	Mr T with the post package at the post office: 'these stamps don't stick to the box, foo' Postguy:' Try it again but this time with the stamp,<strong> face-up</strong>.'.	<em>Chuck Norris</em> always plays poker with his cards<strong> face-up</strong> because he can't be beat anyway. Try and cheat and you'll end up the recipient of a roundhouse kick to the head and will leave the room in a <em>box</em> with a <em>stamp</em> addressed to the local morge.	A person who is a <em>stamp</em> collector has all of the <em>stamps</em><strong> face-up</strong> in their box.	"If you're using ""chikan"" for the small box + stamp primitive, here's a story for you: chikan's trip in the small box with the stamps all over it is getting boring… good thing he's laying<strong> face-up</strong> though and has a flashlight with him, because he's pasted pictures of Mr. T to the roof of the box. That's his idol who he looks up to in awe, and never grows tired of looking at him (this covers both meanings Heisig mentioned)."		
迎		welcome	Box . . . stamps . . . road.		7	1837	1702	44	ゲイ	むか.える	<em>Stamp-collectors</em> sit and wait on the <em>road</em> to <strong>welcome</strong> new mail arrivals. 登		ascend	<i>Teepee</i> . . . <i>table</i>. Do not confuse with <i>rise up</i> (Frame 43).		12	1838	1703	44	トウ、ト、ドウ、ショウ、チョウ	のぼ.る、あ.がる	When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to<strong> ASCEND</strong> to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.	When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually<strong> ascend</strong>ed in the air!	Stroke order for <em>teepee</em> primitive is incorrect (in 4th edition), 3rd and 4th strokes should be reversed.	<em>Mr Bean</em><strong> ascend</strong>s a <em>teepee</em>, which then collapses, flattening the American Indians trapped inside.	The smell of a <em>bean</em> fart<strong> ascend</strong>s up, up and out the top of the <em>teepee</em>.		
澄		lucidity	Water . . . ascend.		15	1839	1704	44	チョウ	す.む、す.ます、-す.ます	Scuba divers know that when you <em>ascend</em> in the <em>water</em>, your<strong> lucidity</strong> increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you <em>ascend</em> in the <em>water</em>, the<strong> lucidity</strong> of the <em>water</em> improves, too.	Lucid dreams allow me to control what is happening. In a drowning nightmare, I forced<strong> lucidity</strong> and allowed myself ascend to the surface.	A few <em>drops of acid/peyote</em> and the Indians obtain <strong>lucidity</strong> on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the <strong>lucid</strong> sky.	"The keyword refers to limpid <em>water</em>, but also to something that is clear (as in ""crystal clear""). In Buddhism the thinking mind is often compared to a pond : if you stir the <em>water</em>, the mud from the bottom mixes with the water, and the mind is ""muddy"". To attain<strong> lucidity</strong>, one has to let the mud settle, or as in this kanji, take a shortcut and just <em>ascend</em> through the <em>water</em>."	This kanji is also used for CLEAR WEATHER. Imagine the RAIN/WATER ASCENDING back up into the sky, and the clouds floating away, giving you CLEAR WEATHER. (it's like hitting rewind).		
発		discharge	This key word refers to the <b>discharging</b> of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: <i>teepee</i> . . . <i>two</i> . . . <i>human legs</i>. Contrast the writing with frame 63.		9	1840	1705	44	ハツ、ホツ	た.つ、あば.く、おこ.る、つか.わす、はな.つ	I spent some time in her TEEPEE…just the TWO of us…but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty<strong> DISCHARGE</strong>…so I made my 出発 rather hastily.	<em>Two pairs of human legs</em> poking out of a <em>teepee</em>: you know there'll be a<strong> discharge</strong> soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.	The indian chief went into his <em>teepee</em> and found his wife sleeping with a cowboy. He <strong>discharged</strong> his gun at the <em>two</em> people, and left with their <em>legs</em> <strong>discharging</strong> out the door.	The soldier was dishonorably<strong> discharge</strong>d when his commanding officer saw <em>two pairs of legs</em> sticking out of a <em>teepee</em> designed for just one soldier.	Hier sieht man den Akt, der neues Leben <strong>hervorbringen</strong> kann: Ein <em>Tipi</em>, und <em>zwei</em> Paar <em>Menschenbeine</em> ineinander verschlungen.		
廃		abolish	Cave . . . discharge.		12	1841	1706	44	ハイ	すた.れる、すた.る	I think <em>discharging</em> nuclear weapons should be<strong> abolish</strong>ed. That includes underground tests in <em>caves</em>. You listening Kim Jong-il?	Guns were <strong>abolish</strong>ed, so gun enthusiats left for the hills to <em>discharge</em> their guns in <em>caves</em>.	<em>Discharging</em> guns in <em>caves</em> was<strong> abolish</strong>ed because the ricochets were causing too many injuries.	When slavery was<strong> abolish</strong>ed, defiant slave owners knew they had lost the war but as an act of spite herded up all their slaves into a remote <em>cave</em> and killed them all by <em>discharging</em> bullets into their heads. (The dead bodies then <em>discharged</em> various substances/fluids as voluntary muscle control was suddenly gone.).	Slaves have been <em>discharged</em> from the <em>caves</em> where they were kept thanks to the <strong>abolition</strong> of slavery.		
僚		colleague	<i>Person</i> . . . <i>pup tent</i>. Choose some connotation of the key word that will keep it distinct for you from <i>companion</i> (Frame 19), <i>friend</i> (Frame 760), <i>consort</i> (Frame 1287), and <i>comrade</i> (Frame 1765).		14	1842	1707	44	リョウ		Trivia: The right primitive is <em>kagaribi</em> - 尞 - <em>fuel used for sacrifices</em>. I would use <em>sacred bonfire</em> as a primitive . (Mnemonic: Top is a merged image of <em>big</em> and <em>fire</em> - <em>big sacred bonfire</em> that looks like <em>little sun</em>). Story: Your<strong> colleague</strong> got fired literally… in a <em>sacred bonfire</em> by Mr.T.	Some businesses allow pets in the office. Here, my<strong> colleague</strong> is <em>Mr T</em> and he set up a little <em>pup tent</em> for his minidog, then turns around and completes his TPS reports.	"Mr. T began working in a japanese compagny. As he sees that his<strong> colleague</strong> accept to do some extra work during the week-end and even sleep at the office, he says to them: ""I pity da fool who work during week-end! You might as well install a pup tent in the office and forget about your home""."	"(リョウ) When Ned (<em>insert male person here</em>) gets a <em>pup tent</em> (i.e. a woody), he calls it his ""colleague."" (again, sorry for the crudeness of many of my stories)."	"A<strong> colleague</strong> implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your<strong> colleague</strong> helps you to erect your <em>pup tent</em> during a company outing. Note: <strong>Heisig's warning</strong> to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as <a href=""../v4/19.html"">companion</a> (#19 朋), <a href=""../v4/704.html"">friend</a> (#704 友), <a href=""../v4/1203.html"">consort</a> (#1203 伴) and <a href=""../v4/1637.html"">comrade</a> (#1637 輩). That is why I chose to have the <em>person</em> element pictured as someone (the<strong> colleague</strong> in this case) helping with the work of building the <em>pup tent</em>."

寮		dormitory	House . . . pup tent.		15	1844	1708	44	リョウ		This guy would rather use his <em>pup-tent</em> as a <em>house</em>, than sleep in the<strong> dormitory</strong>. Here is a trick they play where if they find that one dorm member has pitched a ""<em>pup tent</em>"" while sleeping, they make it into a <em>house</em> by putting a little roof on top of it – complete with a lit cigarette for a chimney – and wait for the ""fun"" to start (fun meaning…lighting their friend's genitals on fire)."	A<strong> dormitory</strong> room has the same characteristics of a pup tent, meaning that it's small and usually sleeps two people (you and your room mate), however you have an actual roof over your head.	To please gods and pass next exams you set a whole<strong> dormitory</strong> (<em>house</em>) afire. Wow! What a <em>sacred bonfire</em>!	A<strong> DORMITORY</strong> HOUSE has all the same characteristics as a PUP TENT; smelly, old, cramped, etc.

彫		carve	The two primitives here, <i>circumference</i> and <i>shape</i>, belong naturally to the special connotations that differentiate <b>carving</b> from <i>engraving</i> (see frame 1639).		11	1846	1710	45	チョウ	ほ.る、-ぼ.り	Start with a <em>circumference</em> and<strong> carve</strong> away until you get the <em>shape</em> you want. 須		ought	<i>Shape</i> . . . <i>head</i>. Pounding on her <em>flesh</em> can be heard for miles around. <em><em>boom ba-ba-boom ba-ba-boom ba-ba-boom!</em></em>.		
参		visit	Elbow . . . St. Bernard dog . . . shape.		8	1856	1720	45	サン、シン	まい.る、まい-、まじわる、みつ	I'm going to<strong> visit</strong> my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his <em>elbow</em>, and it became really <em>big</em> and contorted into a weird <em>shape</em>. I hope he will be all right!	Whenever the postman has to pay a<strong> visit</strong> to this place, he brings an elbow-shaped thingy that he throws to the St. Bernard.	I paid a<strong> visit</strong> to my neighbour, but I forgot he had this huge <em>St. Bernard dog</em>. The doctor said my <em>elbow</em> will never be the same <em>shape</em>.	"I was a little nonplussed by the inappropriateness of this keyword, so I decided to use ""the three kings"" instead; they are a threesome, and they make a religiously-motivated<strong> visit</strong>, right? Anyway, they travel by night, so they're just these three shapes moving through the gloom. They can't see well, so a St. Bernard dog noses their elbows whenever they start to go the wrong way."	"Hint: This is the humble/old kanji of the verb ""to go/to come"", and also is the kanji for ""three"" on legal documents. I suggest using the ""three musketeers"" for this primitive, raising their three blades with the elbow. (the elbow primitive could be viewed as a pictograph of the musketeer's hat, with a feather on the side, too)."		
惨		wretched	A state of mind . . . visit.		11	1857	1721	45	サン、ザン	みじ.め、いた.む、むご.い	Whenever I have to <em>visit</em> the relatives… that puts me in one hell of a<strong> wretched</strong> <em>state of mind</em>.	Data feels<strong> wretched</strong> because he has no family to visit.	I don't know about you, but it seems to me that whenever I'm in a<strong> wretched</strong> <em>state of mind</em> and just want to be left alone, that's the time that other people always seem to decide to <em>visit</em> me!	Your state of mind at the end of the previous frame.	"<em>Data</em> felt <strong>wretched</strong> his visit to a ""third-world"" and seeing how <strong>wretched</strong> the people lived."		
修		discipline	Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . shape.		10	1858	1722	45	シュウ、シュ	おさ.める、おさ.まる	<em>Mr. T</em> is a harsh <em>taskmaster</em> who will<strong> discipline</strong> you (beat you into <em>shape</em>) with his <em>walking stick</em>.	Note : the meaning is in the positive sense, to cultivate one's character or interests. To work to make yourself or something better.	You may not have known it, but Mr. T is into discispline. Not just self<strong> discipline</strong>, in order to get into shape, but what he really likes is when the Task master spanks him with her walking stick. Don't tell Mr. T I told you. I pity da fool, and da fool would be me!!! Halfway on the way to that remote region, <em>Mr. T</em> was about to give up because of the long and difficult journey when he ran into <em>Bruce Lee</em>, who told him that<strong> discipline</strong> is needed to reach your goal."	<em>Mr. T</em> joins the X-men. When they catch <em>mystique</em>, he beats her with a <em>walking stick</em> like a true <em>taskmaster</em> to<strong> discipline</strong> her. But it turns out mystique has taken the shape of the walking stick, and she then beats him.		
珍		rare	Jewel . . . umbrella . . . shape.		9	1859	1723	45	チン	めずら.しい、たから	The king has a really<strong> rare</strong> umbrella, it can change shape.	"Tip: <em>umbrella</em> + <em>shape</em> : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""<em>parasol</em>"" (because it is the same <em>shape</em> as an <em>umbrella</em>). REF: <em>rare</em> (FRAME 1723) , <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1724"">check-up</a> (#1724 診), <a href=""../v4/2574.html"">measles</a> (#2574 疹), <a href=""../v4/2720.html"">fallible</a> (#2720 謬)."	"<em>Mystique</em> stole the<strong> rare</strong> <em>jewel</em>-encrusted <em>umbrella</em> by simply morphing into a <em>king</em>, marching into the palace and taking it. ""I'll be back, I'd like to take a quick stroll in the rain!' S/he said, and casually strolled off holding the umbrella (pictograph - you can see the umbrella over Mystique)."	It's<strong> rare</strong> to see the <em>king</em> carrying his own <em>parasol</em> - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for <em>umbrella + shape = parasol</em> and to Peppi for the story idea).	The ancient <em>jewel</em> that is <em>shaped</em> like an <em>umbrella</em> is extremely<strong> rare</strong>, and so is hung from the chin (ちん) of the royal <em>king</em> of Mezura (めずら) to signify his importance.		
診		checkup	<i>Words</i> . . . <i>umbrella</i> . . . <i>shape</i>. The key word refers to a medical examination.		12	1860	1724	45	シン	み.る	The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut. 文		sentence	Under the familiar <i>top hat</i> we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with <b>sentence</b> by thinking of a <b>sentence</b> as a grammatical pattern.	* The primitive meaning for this character will be <i>plaid</i>, the familiar crisscross pattern frequently used in textiles.	4	1861	1725	45	ブン、モン	ふみ、あや	A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct<strong> sentence</strong>s, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.	The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect<strong> sentence</strong>s.	I celebrated finishing the Heisig books by buying myself a <em>plaid top hat</em> (<em>top hat</em> with <em>criss cross</em> pattern to symbolize the crisscrossing flashcards) and then I began the AJATT<strong> sentence</strong> method.	"It should not be a problem to see this as<strong> SENTENCE</strong>. For the primitive, think in a Scottish accent and say ""PLAID kilt"". Guess it can look like a Beret wearing scot."	I'm making <strong>sentence/plaid</strong> into a new primitive: <strong>Catholic schoolgirl</strong>. (This should be fun.) // All of the Catholic schoolgirls wear uniforms with <em>top hats</em> and <em>plaid</em> skirts, and sit in school practicing their<strong> sentence</strong>s.		
対		vis-à-vis	Plaid . . . glue.		7	1862	1726	45	タイ、ツイ	あいて、こた.える、そろ.い、つれあ.い、なら.ぶ、むか.う	When sitting <strong>vis-a-vis</strong>, <em>Scots</em> will <em>glue</em> their <em>kilt</em> down to avoid embaressment.	"This is a character that is used in Japanese for ""vs."" (as in, ""Alien vs. Predator"")."	This isn't plaid, it's tophat and sheaf. In the tophatted wheat cutting competition, one contestant gathered more sheafs than anyone else, he had an advantage<strong> vis-a-vis</strong> the rest because he had glued his tophat on, everyone else's hat kept coming off.	The word<strong> vis-a-vis</strong> is like <em>sentence glue</em>, it kind of joins sentences together.	<em>Wolverine</em> has to <em>glue</em> a <em>top hat</em> to his head when sitting<strong> vis-a-vis</strong> on a train so no one recognizes him.		
紋		family crest	Thread . . . plaid.		10	1863	1727	45	モン		Who knew that <em>Spiderman</em> was <em>Scottish!</em> He has sewn his<strong> family crest</strong> onto his uniform.	A<strong> family crest</strong> sown on to a garment with <em>thread</em> sometimes has a Latin <em>sentence</em> as a motto.	"If you look closely, you can see that on SPIDERMAN'S CREST, there is sown in his favorite SENTENCE, ""with great power, comes great responsibility.""."	"On <em>Spiderman's</em><strong> family crest</strong> reads the <em>sentence</em> ""With great power, comes great responsibility""… in Latin of course."	The scotsmen proudly display the <strong>family crest</strong> <em>threaded</em> into their <em>kilts</em>.

(imagine a far side comic strip with a bunch of<strong> mosquito</strong>s at a house party). 斉		adjusted	<i>Plaid</i> . . . <i>fenceposts</i> . . . <i>two</i>. Do not confuse with <i>just so</i> (Frame 414).		8	1866	1729	45	セイ、サイ	そろ.う、ひと.しい、ひと.しく、あたる、はやい	The <em>Scotsman goalkeeper</em> <strong>adjusted</strong> himself. He reached down and <strong>adjusted</strong> the <em>two things</em> between his skinny fencepost <em>legs</em>.	"This kanji means ""symmetry"" not ""adjusted."" STORY: The TWO FENCEPOSTS need to be SYMMETRICAL in size, otherwise you may smash your mouth into the lower side and start saying naughty SENTENCES."	You are trying to stretch a <em>plaid</em> between <em>two</em> <em>fenceposts</em>. It's not easy, as for all wrinkles to go away posts' positions must be carefully <strong>adjusted</strong>.	"HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean <em>goalkeeper</em>. The ""fence posts"" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means <strong>uniform</strong> as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team."	"[+dingomick] The <em>Scottish goalkeeper</em> has lost both of his legs and was forced to replace them with two bent <em>white picket fenceposts</em> nailed together with two boards, but that hasn't stopped him from playing his favorite sport: soccer. Imagine the camera zooming in on him after he makes a great play: ""Great save! Ah, there he is reaching under his <em>kilt</em> - he just<strong> adjusted</strong> his fencepost legs. There he goes again, oop, looks like he just<strong> adjusted</strong> something else as well!""."

塁		bases	The kanji of this frame refers to the four <b>bases</b> that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: <i>field</i> . . . <i>sparkler</i> . . . <i>ground</i>.		12	1871	1734	45	ルイ、ライ、スイ	とりで	Playing baseball in a <em>rice field</em> with <em>sparklers</em> stuck into the <em>ground</em> to act as<strong> bases</strong>.	The traditional New Year's baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a <em>rice field</em>. They stick <em>sparklers</em> in the <em>ground</em> for the <strong>bases</strong> so they can be seen, and to be more festive.	<em>Warning! warning! Base compromised initiating Computer on self destruct mode</em>.	The surprise attack came from left-<em>field</em>! Somebody set us up the <em>sparkler</em>! How are we gentelmen? All your <strong>base</strong> are belong to us! But no, they stood their <em>ground</em> and sent out the ZIG! For great justice!	This means<strong> bases</strong> as in baseball, otherwise a fort. The original form of this kanji is 壘, a pictogram of four<strong> bases</strong>, the home base marked specially.

率		ratio	<i>Mysterious</i> . . . <i>sparkler</i> . . . <i>ten</i>. Do not confuse with <i>proportion</i> (Frame 1673).		11	1874	1737	45	ソツ、リツ、シュツ	ひき.いる	Keep separate from proportion. <em>Gandalf</em> is trying to adjust the aspect<strong> ratio</strong> of his monitor from 4:3 to 16:9 so that he can watch Lord of the Rings in widescreen format. It's quite <em>mysterious</em> how each <em>sparkler</em> gives of sparkles at a precise<strong> ratio</strong> of <em>ten</em> to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.	"A witches spell requires the proper<strong> RATIO</strong> of ingredients: ""TEN SPARKLERS and TEN COCOONS into the HAT ye load, wait TEN minutes and watch it explooooode! hehehehehe""."	When I first started downloading torrents, I thought that<strong> ratio</strong>s were very mysterious. Now I keep a <em>sparkling ten</em> to one<strong> ratio</strong>!	"When the world's<strong> ratio</strong> of women to men <em>mysteriously</em> changed to <em>ten</em> to one overnight, the men all lit <em>sparklers</em> in celebration: ""Hey fellas! We're all gonna get laid!"". 率 りつ rate; 軽率 けいそつ rash, thoughtless, careless, hasty; 率いる ひきいる to lead, to spearhead (a group), to command (troops)."		
渋		astringent	Water . . . footprint . . . sparkler.		11	1875	1738	45	ジュウ、シュウ	しぶ、しぶ.い、しぶ.る	If you eat something<strong> astringent</strong> <em>water</em> will <em>stop</em> the <em>sparkly</em> sensation in your mouth.	"I think that Heisig meant this as the ""slightly bitter but fresh"" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail (<em>water</em>), feeling like he's been kicked in the face (<em>footprint</em>) and <em>sparks</em> are flying from his tongue. 'How did it taste?'. 'Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh""."	An<strong> astringent</strong> is also a medical term for something that causes puckering of the flesh or can stop bleeding. An<strong> astringent</strong> is the <em>liquid</em> you'd need if you <em>step</em> on a <em>sparkler</em>.	Only <strong>astringent</strong> <em>water</em> is strong enough to <em>stop</em> a <em>sparkler</em>.	You ate something<strong> astringent</strong>? Quickly drink this <em>water</em> here to <em>stop</em> the <em>sparkly</em> sensation. (+meolox).		
摂		vicarious	<i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>ear</i> . . . <i>sparkler</i>. Do not confuse with <i>substitute</i> (Frame 1080).		13	1876	1739	45	セツ、ショウ	おさ.める、かね.る、と.る	Now that I'm a responsible adult, I have to get my<strong> vicarious</strong> thrills from watching stupid people put <em>sparklers</em> up to their <em>ears</em> and burn their <em>fingers</em>.	I put my <em>fingers</em> in my <em>ears</em> to avoid going deaf while getting a<strong> vicarious</strong> thrill from watching kids light off <em>sparklers</em> and fireworks on Chinese New Year.	摂る 【とる】 (v5r) to take something into the body; to absorb nourishment. 摂取 【せっしゅ】 (n,vs) (1) intake; absorption; adoption; (2) assimilation; (P) STORY: One way to TAKE IN SOME NOURISHMENT INTO THE BODY is to take your FINGER, dig around in your EAR, then eat whatever SPARKLY matter you may find.	[+mspertus] My friend is too afraid of loud noises, so while we go out to enjoy the <em>sparklers</em> and <em>fireworks</em> on New Years, he stays at home and watches everything on TV so he can have a<strong> vicarious</strong> experience. Just the sight of them freaks him out though, so he watches with the volume low and his <em>fingers</em> firmly planted in his <em>ears</em>.	Old southern joke. It was a<strong> VICARIOUS</strong> situation, the man lights a firecracker (SPARKLES), then stuck his FINGER in his EARS to prepare for the boom. Sadly, he was still holding the firecracker.		
央		center	The elements depict a <i>St. Bernard</i> with its head and paws keeping their stick-like form, but with the middle or <b>center</b> of its body filled out in a box-like shape.		5	1877	1740	45	オウ		A person with a big mouth wants to be the<strong> center</strong> of attention.	Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box).	You must get the explosive into the <strong>center</strong>. The armor will protect him otherwise. The key is to wait for the <em>mouth</em> of the <em>St. Bernard</em> to be open, and then fling the dynamite into the <strong>center</strong> of it.	For the primitive, I'll try a <em>big</em> boxy <em>target</em> - like the kind you use to line up your enemy in a videogame before you blow it up. Here, though - you're given the opportunity to finally kill that <em>St Bernard</em> from <em>Duck Hunt</em> - just make sure to line it up in the <em>center</em> of your <em>target</em>…	"I see this as a modern-day pictogram for someone walking in carrying a big birthday cake, with one fat candle at its <strong>CENTRE</strong> (to remind me that the <strong>CENTRE</strong> vertical juts up from the ""cake""), and to be placed at the <strong>CENTRE</strong> of a table, in honor of the person who's the day's <strong>CENTRE</strong> of attention. (I use the <strong>CENTRE</strong> instead of<strong> CENTER</strong> to promote the connection with <a href=""../v4/1741.html"">England</a> (#1741 英), 英 .)."

映		reflect	Sun . . . center.		9	1879	1742	45	エイ	うつ.る、うつ.す、は.える、-ば.え	In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just<strong> reflect</strong>s it.	"A <em>solar</em> power plant consists of thousands of mirrors<strong> reflect</strong>ing the <em>sun</em>'s rays, concentrating the energy on a focal point at the <em>centre</em>. See here: <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two</a>."	You can build a very powerful camp stove just by using metalic mirrors to <strong>reflect</strong> the <em>sun</em> onto a cooking surface at the <em>center</em>.	Imagine the<em> sun</em>, at the <em>center</em> of our solar system, like a huge disco-ball (a ball made with hundreds of tiny mirrors),<strong> reflect</strong>ing the light from the planets and stars around (instead of emitting light on its own). The kanji refers to images which are<strong> reflect</strong>ed, mirrored and also projected, as in the kanji compound 映画 (eiga) : a movie, film. A projected image is like a<strong> reflect</strong>ion of the original material.	"<a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%8C%E3%81%88%E3%81%84%E3%80%8D%E7%94%BB"">「えい」画</a> A movie <strong>reflects</strong> the <em>central days</em> of the person filmed."		
赤		red	<i>Ground</i> . . . <i>dagger</i> . . . <i>little</i>. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an <i>apple</i>.	7	1880	1743	45	セキ、シャク	あか、あか-、あか.い、あか.らむ、あか.らめる	He was stabbed with a <em>dagger</em>, and <em>little</em> drops of<strong> red</strong> blood dropped onto the <em>ground</em>. The <em>soil</em> was<strong> red</strong> after the hunter used his <em>dagger</em> to cut off the <em>animal's legs</em>.

期		period	<i>Bushel basket</i> . . . <i>month</i>. As the <i>month</i> indicates, this has to do with <b>periods</b> of time.		12	1902	1765	46	キ、ゴ		The slowest remote chess game ever: a one <em>month</em> <strong>period</strong> between every move.	The slowest chess game ever: It took him a one <em>month</em> <strong>period</strong> to move the <em>rook</em>! (Edited from dingomick).	The girl's panties are all in the bushel basket as it's that time of the month again… her<strong> period</strong>.	One BUSHEL BASKET full of rice is enough to sustain a small family for a<strong> PERIOD</strong> of one MONTH.	A woman who doesn't want to throw harmful materials into the landfills might be found using a rook instead of a tampon when it's her time of the month. In other words, her<strong> period</strong>.		
碁		Go	<i>Bushel basket</i> . . . <i>stones</i>. The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored <i>stones</i> on a lined board.		13	1903	1766	46	ゴ		<strong>Go</strong> is <em>chess</em> played with <em>stones</em>.	The ignorant gaijin put a <em>rook</em> on top of his opponent's <em>stone</em> when playing<strong> Go</strong>, much to the consternation of the Japanese players.	The two<strong> Go</strong> masters, playing on a gigantic <em>stone</em><strong> Go</strong> board, take their <em>stone</em> playing chips from huge <em>barrels</em>.	<strong>Go</strong> needs a <em>bushel basket</em> full of <em>stone</em>s to play it.	I wanted to play <strong>Go</strong>, so I wanted to set up the board. I went for my <em>bushel basket</em>, where I keep all of the <em>stones</em>, but they fall out of the bottom! This is the same <em>bushel basket</em> that Charlie used in his escape! Now, I have nowhere to keep my <strong>Go</strong> stones. raulir 30-4-2006.		
基		fundamentals	Bushel basket . . . soil.		11	1904	1767	46	キ	もと、もとい	<strong>Fundamentals</strong> of <em>chess</em>: use the <em>rooks</em> to protect your <em>ground</em>.	A <em>Bushel-basket</em> full of <em>earth</em> contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.	Before playing chess, you must learn the<strong> fundamentals</strong>: begin by placing a <em>rook</em> on the <em>ground</em>.	I took a course on the<strong> fundamentals</strong> of bushel basket-weaving. They teach you everything from the ground up. (sweetneet variation).	One doesn't become a grand master over night. Before he could graduate to using a real chess board, <em>Garry Kasparov</em> had to master the<strong> fundamentals</strong> of the game by drawing chess boards in a pile<em>dirt</em>. (a pile of <em>dirt</em> that he was for some reason straddling, I might add).		
甚		tremendously	<i>Bushel basket</i> . . . <i>equal</i>. Note how the first stroke of <i>equal</i> doubles up with the sixth stroke of the <i>bushel basket</i>, and how the <i>animal legs</i> of the <i>bushel basket</i> are dropped to make room for the <i>human legs</i> of <i>equal</i>.		9	1905	1768	46	ジン	はなは.だ、はなは.だしい	It's a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother's equal.	These two <em>bushel baskets</em> are <strong>tremendously</strong> huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly <em>equal</em> in size.	Losing both your <em>rooks</em> is <strong>tremendous</strong>. It's almost <em>equal</em> to having your queen's <em>legs</em> chopped from under her.	This kanji is<strong> tremendously</strong> difficult to remember because it is not <em>equal</em> to the other bushel baskets in this lesson. Their <em>bushel baskets</em> all have animal legs.	Equal I remember as the counter for small animals. Remember Battle Chess? I just picture a tremendous <strong>rook</strong> from Battle Chess wandering around stomping on <strong>little animals</strong>. Those guys were sweet.		
勘		intuition	Tremendously . . . muscle.		11	1906	1769	46	カン		<strong>Intuition</strong> is a <em>tremendously</em> <em>power</em>ful resource of the mind.	"Using Zareon's story for the previous frame ""tremendously""… The two chessplayers who are eachother's equals are so good at chess that they don't have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don't even have to think, really. Their<strong> intuition</strong> takes control. This is: extreme chess."	A woman's<strong> intuition</strong> is TREMENDOUSLY POWERful.	I had an<strong> intuition</strong> of who would win this fight by judging the size of my opponents <em>tremendously</em> large <em>muscles</em>.	<strong>Intuition</strong>–<em>tremendously powerful</em>.		
堪		withstand	Soil . . . tremendously.		12	1907	1770	46	カン、タン	た.える、たま.る、こ.らえる、こた.える	Because I hid myself behind a huge <em>dirt</em> barrier I dug, I was able to<strong> withstand</strong> the <em>tremendous</em> nuclear blast.	Plain old <em>soil</em> can <strong>withstand</strong> <em>tremendous</em> amounts of pressure.	The two equal chessplayers from the last two frames are duking it out still. Part of this extreme chess match is when the judges dump a huge mound of soil onto them. Watch as they<strong> withstand</strong> the weight of the dirt and how their brainpower keeps all the chess pieces, rooks and all, on the board. Simply astounding.	The Japanese high-rise was built to<strong> WITHSTAND</strong> <em>GROUND</em> tremors of <em>TREMENDOUS</em> force!	Though I had lost both rooks in chess, a <em>tremendous</em> loss, I was able to hold my <em>ground</em> on the chessboard and<strong> withstand</strong> my opponent's attacks.		
貴		precious	Purse . . . shells.		12	1908	1771	46	キ	たっと.い、とうと.い、たっと.ぶ、とうと.ぶ	"Frodo kept the<strong> precious</strong> in the purse but did a switch with some worthless shells when he went to sleep. Heres gollum opening the purse ""ahhh my<strong> precious</strong>ssssss…..why you m<strong>**<em><em> </em></em></strong>**!!!!!."	Inside your <em>purse</em> is all of your <em>money</em> and your keys (き) etc. All of your<strong> precious</strong> valuables.	You put your<strong> precious</strong> <em>shells</em> (money) into your <em>purse</em> for safekeeping.	Frodo kept the<strong> precious</strong> in the purse. When he opens it, he sees… money! Someone's stolen the<strong> precious</strong> (and paid for it)! (thegeezer3).	Ahh, my precciouss… I keeps it in my purse. What, what's this? SHELSSES! THEY REPLACED IT WITH SHELSSES!		
遺		bequeath	Precious . . . road.		15	1909	1772	46	イ、ユイ	のこ.す	"Bilbo<strong> bequeath</strong>es the ""PRECIOUS"" to Frodo, who will carry it on the long ROAD to Mordor."	"""<strong>Bequeath</strong>"" is an odd old word, isn't it? Basically, it just deals with how I want my <em>precious</em> possessions dealt out, after I die, later down the <em>road</em>. ""Being of sound, but antiquated, mind, I <strong>bequeath</strong> this to you!""."	"I'm crossing the road with my <strong>precious</strong> items and suddenly a huge Mac truck springs out of the fog. I know I'm an instant away from certain death, so I scream, ""I<strong> bequeath</strong> these <strong>precious</strong> items to whoever picks them up!"" and fling them onto the road as the truck runs me over."	If sometime down the <em>road</em> I happen to die, I<strong> bequeath</strong> you everything <em>precious</em> I have.	When you're at the end of your ROAD, you<strong> BEQUEATH</strong> what is PRECIOUS to you.		
遣		dispatch	This kanji takes away the <i>maestro</i>'s baton and replaces it with a <i>purse</i>. The <i>road</i> represents his being <b>dispatched</b> on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being <i>chased</i> down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make!		13	1910	1773	46	ケン	つか.う、-つか.い、-づか.い、つか.わす、や.る	<strong>Dispatch</strong> all cars and <em>chase</em> the <em>maestro</em>! He's gone crazy and stolen a ladies <em>purse</em>!	"Apart from meaning<strong> DISPATCH</strong>, this kanji can mean ""to give (to someone lower than you),"" ""to do,"" and to even ""have intercourse."" STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to<strong> DISPATCH</strong> some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO'S baton? You don't wanna know…"	Small additions to dingomick's story: <strong>Dispatch</strong> all cars and chase the <em>maestro</em>! He's gone crazy. He's thrown away his baton and stolen the <em>purse</em> of some lady on the <em>road</em>! 派遣 (はけん):<strong> dispatch</strong>, send 人材派遣会社 (じんざいはけんがいしゃ): temporary staff service (temp agency) 遣わす (つかわす): to send,<strong> dispatch</strong> 小遣い (こづかい): allowance, pocket money 気遣う (きづかう): be concerned about, care about, worry about.	To remember this one, I combine the <em>purse</em> with the key part of <em>bureaucrat</em> to come up with <em>diplomatic pouch</em>, the thing that is used to hold a<strong> dispatch</strong> whenever an emissary is<strong> dispatch</strong>ed on the <em>road.</em>.	<em>Bond</em> has stolen a lady spy's <em>purse</em> while she was asleep after their evening together. When she discovers it's gone, she<strong> dispatch</strong>es some henchmen on the <em>road</em> after him to<strong> dispatch</strong> him, but <em>Bond</em> evades them and escapes with the <em>purse</em>.		
潰		defile	Water . . . precious.		15	1911	2319	46	カイ、エ	つぶ.す、つぶ.れる、つい.える	"…Faramir and Frodo watched the tiny creature far below. ""Shall we shoot him?"" Faramir asked. ""This Gollum has <strong>defiled</strong> the <em>waters</em> of the Forbidden pond, looking for his <em>Precious</em>, and for that the penalty is death""…"	Don't<strong> defile</strong> <em>precious water</em>.	"So much for <a href=""../v4/1548.html"">undefiled</a> (#1548 潔). Not only did the poor girl get<strong> defile</strong>d, she also had her <em>precious purse with money</em> stolen from her. She ended up drowning herself in the <em>water</em>."	The moment <em>Precious</em> was taken out of the <em>water</em>, it started to<strong> defile</strong> the soul of the new owner, turning him into Gollem.	"This kanji means ""smash"" or ""break"" such as to smash or break something; or <a href=""midori://search?text=%E2%80%9D%E9%A1%94%E3%82%92%E3%81%A4%E3%81%B6%E3%81%99%E2%80%9D"">”顔をつぶす”</a> which means ""loose face"" or ""break face"" in the literal sense. STORY: Use PRECIOUS WATER (i.e. holy water) to BREAK/SMASH the face of the undead. STORY 2: If you SMASH something in heaven, you can just pour some PRECIOUS WATER (holy water) on it to fix it."		
舞		dance	The top two strokes show someone <i>reclining</i>, and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken <i>tub</i> ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the <i>sunglasses</i> round off the character.		15	1912	1774	46	ブ	ま.う、-ま.う、まい	The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem<strong> dance</strong>s nakes for him.	"I learned <a href=""../v4/1775.html"">nothingness</a> (#1775 無) first because it is a very common kanji. Probably easier to think of this kanji in that context. Attractive<strong> dance</strong>rs should<strong> dance</strong> wearing <strong>nothing</strong> but <strong>sunglasses</strong>."	I imagine this <em>big oaken tub</em> as being full of grapes being squashed by the feet of the vinyard owners. Each wearing <em>sunglasses</em> and doing that Russian arms crossed <em>dance</em> and squishing all the grapes.	"See <a href=""../v4/1409.html"">jump</a> (#1409 踊). Renamed this kanji <strong>interpretive<strong> dance</strong></strong>. (readapated thegeezer3) The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his タキ(tacky) <em>sunglasses</em> while his personal harem does an <strong>interpretive<strong> dance</strong></strong> for him."	"Heisig, let's get this straight: NEW keywords: 曜 JUMP ex-<a href=""../v4/1285.html"">leap</a> (#1285 躍); 踊 <strong> DANCE</strong>=ODORI ex-<a href=""../v4/1409.html"">jump</a> (#1409 踊); 舞 KABUKI ex-<a href=""../v4/1774.html"">dance</a> (#1774 舞) (used in concepts related to<strong> dance</strong>, like stages, fluttering, etc.). So, KABUKI 歌舞伎 【かぶき】is the keyword here. STORY: We learn <a href=""../v4/1775.html"">nothingness</a> (#1775 無) first because it is a very common kanji. Then we go to see KABUKI en the EVENING wearing SUNGLASSES."		
無		nothingness	This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: <b>nothingness</b>. Make use of the oaken <i>tub</i> from the previous frame, and add to that the <i>oven fire</i> at the bottom.		12	1913	1775	46	ム、ブ	な.い	When I enter the <em>wooden tub</em> heated by <em>flames</em> in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into<strong> nothingness</strong>.	In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into<strong> nothingness</strong>.	As the <em>heat/flames</em> rises up through the <em>oaken tub</em> for a long period of time, all the water evaporates and what's left is<strong> nothingness</strong>.	In the ancient days of Buddhism, philosphers were common. Each of them would deeply ponder the meaning of <strong>nothingness</strong> while <em>reclining</em> in their <em>oaken tubs</em> of hot water. Underneath, there were <em>flames</em> to keep the water from cooling, tended by the non-philosophers. Immacolata 8-5-2006. Nothing too good for pondering the meaning of <strong>nothingness</strong>!	Note: This is the actual kanji for -nai endings.		
組		association	Thread . . . shelf.		11	1914	1776	47	ソ	く.む、くみ、-ぐみ	The leader of the <em>Spiderman</em><strong> association</strong> has tons of <em>Spiderman</em> figurines lined up on his <em>shelf</em>.	"Watch this: <a href=""http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg"">http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg</a> The leader of the Spiderman<strong> association</strong> has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular)."	<strong>Association</strong> means linking things together. This can be made literal by using a <em>thread</em> to bind (associate) stuff which belong on your <em>shelf</em>.	Spiderman is part of an<strong> association</strong> which meets behind the secret revolving <em>shelves</em> (bookcase).	Cat in the Hat for the new primitive. Spiderman forms an<strong> association</strong> with Cat in the Hat to promote literacy while fighting crime.		
粗		coarse	Rice . . . shelf.		11	1915	1777	47	ソ	あら.い、あら-	Refined rice [1535] can only be found in exclusive grocery shops.<strong> Coarse</strong> <em>rice</em> by contrast fills the supermarket <em>shelves</em> - don't go looking for anything else there.	Ugh, why does this <em>shelf</em> feel so<strong> coarse</strong>? Because it's made of <em>rice</em>, of<strong> coarse</strong>! Get it? Of<strong> coarse</strong>?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.	In America they sell<strong> coarse</strong> rice on the shelves. The Japanese are much more discriminating, as they eat rice all the time, so they want finer rice.	Japanese carpenters don't use sandpaper, they use rice-paper(rice glued on to some paper). Here the carpenter is using the<strong> coarse</strong> paper to smooth out the shelf he's making.	"""<em>RICE</em> is not nice,"" said the <em>CAT IN THE HAT</em>, ""it is much to<strong> COARSE</strong>, like food for a horse.""."		
租		tariff	Wheat . . . shelf.		10	1916	1778	47	ソ		The EU and US impose such high<strong> tariff</strong>s on food imports that third world <em>wheat</em> (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket <em>shelves</em>.	According to Henshall, this kanji originally represented the harvested rice (the wheat primitive) that farmers paid as a tithe. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested <em>wheat</em> on a <em>shelf</em> in order to pay the<strong> tariff</strong> to his lord.	All the <em>wheat</em> imports sit on a <em>shelf</em> until the <strong>tariff</strong> is paid and it can be distributed.	Tax. (Heisig is trying to hard to come up with different words) The devil who has collected wheat taxes before, stores these taxes in shelves.	"""If <em>WHEAT</em> you'd like to eat,"" said the <em>CAT IN THE HAT</em>, ""then you'll have to pay the sheriff a<strong> TARIFF</strong>.""."		
狙		aim at	Pack of wild dogs . . . shelf.		8	1917	2344	47	ソ、ショ	ねら.う、ねら.い	When her home was invaded by a <em>pack of dogs</em>, the little girl climbed on the <em>shelf</em> and <strong>aimed</strong> various items <strong>at</strong> the dogs below.	I think the <em>dogs</em> purposely<strong> aim at</strong> your <em>shelves</em> to deal the most damage.	Like a <em>pack of wild dogs</em>, my children<strong> aim at</strong> the top of my <em>bookshelf</em> where I hide my porn.	There's this game at the carnival where you<strong> aim at</strong> prizes on a <em>shelf</em>. In this particular variant, you<strong> aim at</strong> pictures of <em>wild dogs</em> on a <em>shelf</em>. The more you knock down, the better the prize!	Out hunting with my wild dogs, i took<strong> aim at</strong> the beast and fired. now the beast sits on my shelf, taxidermed.		
祖		ancestor	Altar . . . shelf.		9	1918	1779	47	ソ		The<strong> ancestor</strong> worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.	The urns of <strong>ancestors</strong> are kept on <em>shelves</em> next to the <em>altar</em>.	At the partents of my wife's house (she is Japanese) they have a shelf with pictures of their<strong> ancestor</strong>s. Its like a little shrine and they often pray to it.	An altar on the shelf to remember your<strong> ancestor</strong>s.	<strong>Ancestor</strong>s are revered in Japan. Some homes have large family <em>altar</em>s ( 仏壇 (ぶつだん)) with several <em>shelves</em> to accommodate the name plaques (and these days photographs) of all the<strong> ancestor</strong>s. 祖母 (そぼ): grandmother 祖父 (そふ): grandfather 祖国 (そこく): motherland, fatherland, native country 先祖 (せんぞ):<strong> ancestor</strong> 祖先 (そせん):<strong> ancestor</strong> [also used in a broader sense, such as apes were the<strong> ancestor</strong>s of humans].		
阻		thwart	Pinnacle . . . shelf.		8	1919	1780	47	ソ	はば.む	In a last ditch effort to <strong>thwart</strong> the invaders of <em>The Pinnacle</em>, they push glass <em>shelves</em> over the edge onto their heads below.	The shortness of the Japanese<strong> thwart</strong>s their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.	<em>The Pinnacle</em> keeps its pantry <em>shelves</em> locked at nighttime, to<strong> thwart</strong> midnight snackers. No fatties allowed here!	Keeping porn on the <em>pinnacle</em> of a <em>bookshelf</em> can<strong> thwart</strong> snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).	To<strong> thwart</strong> attacks on the Pinnacle, their shelves are always full of various magical weapons.		
査		investigate	Tree . . . shelf.		9	1920	1781	47	サ		A whole team of cops is sent to <strong>investigate</strong> how a <em>tree</em> could grow on top of a <em>shelf</em> with no soil or water.	The result of the inverstigation of the missing <em>Trees</em>? Why, most of them had become <em>shelfs</em>!	"Police suspected that some <em>wooden shelves</em> had come from illigaly lumbered timber in the Amazon. They launched an investigation in to the matter. ""Trees are more important than shelves and therefore should be placed on top"" A spokesman for the police said in an interview."	Why the hell would a <em>tree</em> be growing on a <em>shelf</em>? Time to<strong> investigate</strong>. Also time to think up a story that makes more damn sense.	"I have a little potted <em>tree</em> sitting on my <em>shelf</em>, and I found a note in it that said ""You will die in 3 days."" So, naturally I try to figure out who put it there! Dave Chappelle did a comedy special way back (1997) where he does an impression of a white guy in a horror movie with just one line, 'I'd better<strong> investigate</strong>!' That would be me in this situation."		
助		help	<i>Shelf</i> . . . <i>power</i>. The reason why the <i>shelf</i> appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for <i>add</i> (Frame 932).		7	1921	1782	47	ジョ	たす.ける、たす.かる、す.ける、すけ	<strong>HELP</strong>! Someone's pinned under this bookshelf and it's gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!	Can you <strong>help</strong> me move this <em>shelf</em>? I don't have the <em>muscle</em> to do it alone.	To assemble an <em>IKEA shelf</em>, logic is sometimes not enough. You need <strong>help</strong> from someone with brute <em>muscle</em> strength!	Anna doesn't have the <em>power</em> to reach the merchandise on the top <em>shelf</em>, so she asks a passerby - any old <em>Jo</em> (じょ) - to<strong> help</strong> her.	"While it's always the heroine that discovers the <em>hidden passageway behind the shelves</em>, they never have enough <em>muscle</em> power to open it on their own and they have to call for ""<strong>Help</strong>!""…"		
宜		best regards	This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's <b>best regards</b> to another. Its elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>shelf</i>.		8	1922	1783	47	ギ	よろ.しい、よろ.しく	It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their<strong> best regards</strong>, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I've gotten so many that I had to buy a <em>second house</em> which contains nothing but <em>several fancy shelves</em>. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.	"Noone in japan will admit to this but every house has a secret ""best regards shelf"" hidden away somewhere. Its a shelf full of the tat they are constantly giving each other on return from holidays etc. Heres the house wife looking over her shoulder for the all clear to put another useless present on the<strong> best regards</strong> shelf. Happy Circumcision and<strong> best regards</strong>. Shelved."	The <em>shelf</em> your dad made for my <em>house</em> was fantastic. Give my<strong> best regards</strong> to him.	"When I brought my new <em>IKEA shelf</em> Billy into my <em>house</em>, the assembly instructions read: ""This will be the nightmare of your life. <strong>Best regards</strong> - IKEA.""."	"You are stepping over the threshold of you're new Japanese homestay <em>house</em> You're half way through delivering your<strong> best regards</strong> in REALLY crap Japanese "" d d d <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%81%A9%E3%81%86%E3%81%9E%E3%81%86%E5%AE%9C%E3%81%97%E3%81%8F%E2%80%9D"">どうぞう宜しく”</a> When you accidentally knock over their shelf where they keep their valuable ornaments with a terrible CRASH, not the best first impression."		
畳		tatami mat	Rice field . . . crown . . . shelf.		12	1923	1784	47	ジョウ、チョウ	たた.む、たたみ、かさ.なる	The king is peacefully sleeping on his new<strong> tatami mat</strong> when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.	Making <strong>tatami mats</strong> from <em>rice field</em> waste was Japan's <em>crowning</em> achievement, but for some reason other countries just <em>shelved</em> the idea.	Rice Field + Crown + Shelf:<strong> Tatami mat</strong>s were used by everyone - from the workers in the <em>Rice fields</em> to the <em>crown</em> - and when they were not in used, they were put on the <em>shelf</em>.	To rest on the<strong> tatami mat</strong>, he puts his BRAIN and CROWN on the SHELF. Dont forget to put it on again, when you leave!	After a hard days work in the <em>rice field</em>, the humble king hung his <em>crown</em> upon his <em>shelf</em>, curled up on his<strong> tatami mat</strong>, and slept.		
並		row	This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for <i>stand up</i>. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done.	* The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to <i>upside down in a row</i>.	8	1924	1785	47	ヘイ、ホウ	な.み、なら.べる、なら.ぶ、なら.びに	This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of <em>two</em> people <em>standing</em> in a<strong> row</strong>.	"Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a<strong> row</strong>ing boat. In a<strong> row</strong>ing boat people sit in<strong> row</strong>s, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for ""rowboat"" coming at frame 1876. The<strong> row</strong>ing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for ""rowboat"" has a generic meaning of ""a small boat"". In any case, the kanji for ""rowboat"" will not appear as a primitive in the book."	Roman numeral II with 2<strong> row</strong>s of animal horns.	<strong>Full form:</strong> The image of a <em>viking longboat</em> has the advantage of being both a pictograph and lending to the idea of <em>rowing</em>. <strong>Flattened form:</strong> Here, we simply take the action of <em>rowing</em>, already reinforced by the previous image. <strong>Upside-down-in-a-row form:</strong> The horns on the top of this form follows the other forms as an image of a <em>Viking Berserker</em> with his horned helmet.	"Pictograph of the standing<strong> row</strong> in a theatre. // Primitive: a<strong> row</strong> of standing penguins (since they can't sit). If it's in the top position, the penguins are in a<strong> row</strong> in a balcony above the stage. If it's in the bottom position, the penguins are in the front<strong> row</strong>, lower than the stage. If the top 3 strokes are moved to the bottom (""upside down in a<strong> row</strong>""), then the penguins are in a<strong> row</strong> doing headstands."		
普		universal	Row . . . sun.		12	1925	1786	47	フ	あまね.く、あまねし	People at<strong> Universal</strong> Studios wait in rows so long that the sun goes down.	"To me, <em>row</em> is way too close to <a href=""../v4/812.html"">file</a> (#812 列), so I'm adopting Fab's meaning of <em>rowboat</em> from the previous frame.<strong> Universal</strong> Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters<strong> UNIVERSAL</strong> orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man <em>rowing</em> himself in a boat around the <em>sun</em>."	It is a <strong>universal</strong> human desire to sit in <em>rows</em> to watch the <em>sun</em> go down.	If every planet lined up in a row with the sun there would be a<strong> universal</strong> solar eclipse.	"A song<strong> universal</strong>ly known among the kinder, at least in the English-speaking world, is ""<em>Row, Row, Row</em> Your Boat"" - sung by a row of schoolchildren, <em>tongues wagging in the mouth</em> as in <a href=""../v4/21.html"">chant</a> (#21 唱)."		
譜		musical score	Words . . . universal.		19	1926	1787	47	フ		<strong>Musical score</strong>s are in a universal language.	A <strong>musical score</strong> can be read, but not like <em>ordinary words</em>. Music is a <em>universal language</em>.	<strong>MUSICAL SCORE</strong>S are not written in WORDS, but in a UNIVERSAL language called notes.	Small addition to Raichu's story:<strong> Musical score</strong>s are in a <em>universal</em> language. No <em>words</em> are required. 楽譜 (がくふ):<strong> musical score</strong> 音譜 (おんぷ): musical note, notation (e.g. ♪) 暗譜 (あんぷ): memorizing<strong> musical score</strong>s 棋譜 (きふ): record of a game of shogi/go/chess.	For a<strong> MUSICAL SCORE</strong> to be successful, the WORDS must have UNIVERSAL appeal.

Though it is slowly being dried by the <em>sun</em> high above, the occasional <em>drops of water</em> from it indicate that it is still<strong> damp</strong>. 僕		me	"This key word is yet another synonym for ""I,"" somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Males usually use either ""boku"" or ""ore"" (instead of ""watashi"") to refer themselves. ""Boku"" is slightly boyish and soft; ""ore"" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use ""ore"" – but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to ""boku"" when he pleads ""come on baby, it's<strong> ME</strong>!""." 共		together	<i>Salad</i> . . . <i>animal legs</i>.	* The primitive retains the meaning of <i>together</i>. Imagine things <i>strung together</i> like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with <i>bushel basket</i>, this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure.	6	1934	1795	47	キョウ	とも、とも.に、-ども	"The character for <a href=""../v4/1799.html"">deluge</a> (#1799 洪) gave me the idea to use<strong> together</strong> as a primitive for <em>Noah's Ark</em>. Noah kept plenty of <em>salad</em> on board to entice the animals with their <em>animal legs</em> to scurry on board<strong> together</strong>, two by two."	The conjoined twins, who are always<strong> together</strong>, have trouble eating<strong> together</strong> because one is a vegetarian, eating <em>salad</em> and the other is a avid meat eater, eating <em>chicken legs</em>.[Thanks fuaburisu!].	Imagine yakitori with <em>animal legs</em> and <em>salad</em> skewered on<strong> together</strong>.	"<em>Salad</em> and <em>animal legs</em> just go<strong> together</strong>. This primitive means <em>chicken caesar salad</em>. <a href=""http://www.kfc.com/menu/salads.asp"">http://www.kfc.com/menu/salads.asp</a>."	"After I put animal legs in my vegetarian girlfriend's salad as a joke, she said, ""We can't be<strong> together</strong> anymore.""."		
供		submit	<b>Submit</b> here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. 戴		accept humbly	Thanksgiving . . . uncommon.		17	1938	2702	47	タイ	いただ.く	At <em>Thanksgiving</em>, it’s <em>uncommon</em> for people to<strong> accept humbly</strong> the food: most people just dig in. You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh…<em>uncommon</em> food. Really <em>uncommon</em>. Like just imagine the most <em>uncommon</em> <em>Thanksgiving</em> food ever, and that's what you're given (i don't know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and<strong> accept humbly</strong> their food.	As THANKSGIVING is an American holiday, it is UNCOMMON to say いただきます! before eating.	"""<strong>ACCEPT HUMBLY</strong>"" is a translation for 頂戴する (chōdai-suru), a Japanese expression of <em>THANKS-GIVING</em> that shows an <em>UNCOMMON</em> degree of respect and formality, and is reserved for the most <em>UNCOMMONl</em>y solemn occasions. Ironically, 戴 also appears in 戴きます (いただきます), which is also a form of <em>THANKS-GIVING</em>, but is <em>anything but UNCOMMON</em>. In fact, it is so commonplace to that it borders on formulaic and meaningless. (NB: いただきます is also written 頂きます )."	"During <em>Thanksgiving</em> it is <em>uncommon</em> to see Americans<strong> accept humbly</strong> their meal. Usually they're more like ""Turkeyyy!!! Give me my turkeeeey, bitch!""."

"Only in Hollywood. The new NOAH's ARK movie had the FLAG raised over the ARK signifying it's about to leave. Crowds come to board but Noah aims MISSILES at them to hold them away. His catch phrase ""They Call me MISTER Noah!!!"" Well, better than Evan Almighty I guess."	This is the <strong>Mr.</strong> (との) used when addressing someone at the start of a letter. How letters were delivered to the <em>ark</em> was intersting. Noah would wave a big <em>flag</em> and the post man would fire a <em>flag</em>-seeking <em>missile</em> full of letters for <strong>Mr</strong> Rhino and <strong>Mr</strong> Giraffe etc.		
井		well	Recalling that there are no circular strokes, and that the shape of the square and the square within a square (Frame 630) have already been used, it should be relatively easy to see how this character can be consider a pictograph of a <b>well</b>.		4	1946	1806	48	セイ、ショウ	い	I nearly died by falling in a <strong>well</strong>. Actually, on <em>two</em> separate occasions. I'm glad to see they've added these <em>fence posts</em>. Now the <strong>well</strong> will be much safer.	"Have you ever seen an old fashioned japanese<strong> well</strong>? == <a href=""http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well-at-Osaka-Castle.htm"">http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well-at-Osaka-Castle.htm</a>." 丼		donburi	"<i style='""font-weight:' bold>Donburi</i> is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny <i>drop</i> in the <i>well</i>."		5	1947	2884	48	トン、タン、ショウ、セイ	どんぶり	A little one is eating a<strong> domburi</strong> while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!	I <em>drop</em> a<strong> domburi</strong> down into the <em>well</em> for the goblin living there.	(thx mantixen) I DROP<strong> Domburi</strong> into the WELL to feed Sadako (Ring).	"A <strong>donburi</strong> is rice bowl, with <em>drops</em> of food (other than rice) and garnish on top. The steep-sided shape of the typical <strong>donburi</strong> bowl is depicted in the kanji as a <em>well</em>, which is not a bad comparison. Picture: <a href=""http://www.sushigallery.net/Arts/chicken%20donburi.jpg"">http://www.sushigallery.net/Arts/chicken%20donburi.jpg</a>."	Pictograph of a Yoshinoya beef bowl with a drop of raw egg in the center (thanks Chadoro_K).		
囲		surround	Well . . . pent in.		7	1948	1807	48	イ	かこ.む、かこ.う、かこ.い	The village <strong>surround</strong>ed the <em>well</em> with a <em>wall</em> so kids wouldn't fall in.	You get good<strong> surround</strong> sound when your pent-up in well.	"Tweaking dingomick's story: The village <em>well</em> is <em>pent in</em> by a<strong> surround</strong>ing wall so that kids don't fall in. 囲む (かこむ): to<strong> surround</strong>, encircle 範囲 (はんい): range, extent, scope 周囲 (しゅうい):<strong> surround</strong>ings, environs, periphery, perimeter, circumference 囲う (かこう): to enclose, fence in 囲い (かこい): enclosure, fenced in area (such as a corral or a pen) Careful: <a href=""../v4/1842.html"">enclosure</a> (#1842 郭)."	The best<strong> SURROUND</strong> sound I ever heard was when I was PENT IN a WELL and they lowered a microphone and speaker so we could communicate. (thanks nite_run). 耕		till	Christmas tree . . . well.		10	1949	1808	48	コウ	たがや.す	If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to<strong> till</strong> the soil.	A man was<strong> till</strong>ing a new plot to plant <em>xmas trees</em> but his tractor hit an old covered-up <em>well</em> and fell halfway in, he's asking for a new tractor for xmas..	Note:<strong> till</strong> in the sense of plow or cultivate, not until. (story: ergerg).	Plant a <em>Christmas tree</em> to mark the location of the <em>well</em>, so that those who are<strong> till</strong>ing the soil won't fall in.	"I kept drawing a complete blank every time this Kanji would come up, so I started thinking of the phrase ""don't open<strong> till</strong> Xmas"" that you often see on Christmas presents in cartoons and things. This brought the image of the Christmas tree to my mind, and from there I could use one of the other stories."		
亜		Asia	In this kanji, the abbreviation for <b>Asia</b>, you should be able to see the character for <i>mouth</i> behind the Roman numeral II.		7	1950	1809	48	ア、アシア	つ.ぐ	In<strong> Asia</strong>n countries, people use <em>II</em> chopsticks to get things into their <em>mouths</em>. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.	A mouth barred up and not aloud to speak freely is the sign of<strong> asia</strong> (korea, China, pakistan etc).	In the Roman Empire there were signs marking where you were about to enter<strong> Asia</strong>. This was a dangerous place for Romans, so the sign consisted of a picture of <em>two Romans</em> (= <em>Roman two</em>) being eaten by a <em>mouth</em>.	<em>China</em> ( 中 ) taken two times should be about the total landmass of<strong> Asia</strong>.	There are 'II' things I love about<strong> ASIA</strong>: I) I can use my MOUTH to communicate in exotic languages, and II) I can use my MOUTH to suck on some nice<strong> ASIA</strong>N women's bodies!! Yeah!!

円		circle	This kanji, also used for Yen, is one you are not likely to need to study formally, since you can hardly get around in Japan without it. The connection is that the yennies, like pennies, are <b>circular</b> in shape. In any case, the elements are: <i>glass canopy</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i> . . . <i>one</i>.		4	1952	1811	48	エン	まる.い、まる、まど、まど.か、まろ.やか	The shape of a Yen coin.	"A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge <em>glass hood</em> with his <em>cane</em> (using it as a lever), to get to just <em>one</em> yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced ""en"")."	A pictograph of a bank teller's window. The<strong> circle</strong>s are the coins which are passed back and forth for deposits and withdrawls.	Sometimes I wear my <em>top hat</em> under my <em>hood</em> and it makes my head look like a<strong> circle</strong>.	You may wonder why this character is pronounced 'en' yet is said 'yen' in the west, well this is because when it was first romanized the obsolete ゑ character was used and as such became yen in the west.		
角		angle	<i>Bound up</i> . . . <i>glass canopy</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i> . . . <i>two</i>. If you write the character once, you will see why we avoided using the element for <i>soil</i>, which would prompt you to write it in improper order.	* As a primitive, imagine the tool used by draftsmen and carpenters to draw right-<i>angles</i>.	7	1953	1812	48	カク	かど、つの	A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an<strong> angle</strong>.	[+nuke] As a primitive, a boomerang. This boomerang is used to grab a bunch of meat, or <em>flesh</em>, lying around on the ground at a farm. First, you throw it straight at a <em>walking stick</em>, then it makes a right<strong> angle</strong> and goes to <em>walking stick</em> number <em>two</em>, and wraps around that. A quick tug, and you've got all the <em>flesh</em> flying toward you contained in that tri<strong>angle</strong>. Hooray for free (stolen) food!	[angle; corner; square; horn; antlers] I needed to measure an <strong>angle</strong>, so I improvised a rudimentary protractor by <em>bounding up</em> a <em>walking stick</em> to some <em>body part</em> of mine.	The<strong> ANGLE</strong> of a Boomerang? BOUND UP, thrown by the BODY, but is not a WALKING STICK thanks to that 90 degree<strong> ANGLE</strong> in each one. So as a primitive, use Boomerang.	If you bind up a circle with a rope, tied tightly it will have<strong> angle</strong>s.		
触		contact	Angle . . . insect.		13	1954	1813	48	ショク	ふ.れる、さわ.る、さわ	For <em>insects</em> to get in<strong> contact</strong> with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right <em>angle</em>.	Wow, he threw that BOOMERANG with such skill, it made<strong> CONTACT</strong> with that INSECT in mid flight.	"This is commonly read as 触る （さわる）, meaning to touch or feel something. An <em>insect</em>'s version of <em>horns</em> are its antennae (see <a href=""../v4/1813.html"">contact</a> (#1813 触)). They are it's prime source of<strong> contact</strong> with the world and it uses them to touch and feel its way around."	Th e physics professor explains that, depending on the<strong> contact</strong> <em>angle</em>, the <em>bugs</em> hitting your windshield may splatter really good! 解		unravel	Angle . . . dagger . . . cow.		13	1955	1814	48	カイ、ゲ	と.く、と.かす、と.ける、ほど.く、ほど.ける、わか.る、さと.る	Did you know that you can<strong> unravel</strong> a cow? Remember the most important clue: The <em>dagger</em> was found lodged in the stable above the <em>cow</em>'s head!
