蒸		steam	The <i>flower</i> at the top and the <i>floor</i> with the <i>oven fire</i> beneath are familiar. The problem is what comes in between. It is formed by the character for <i>complete</i>, whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of <i>water</i>.		13	2049	1900	51	ジョウ、セイ	む.す、む.れる、む.らす	This kanji is used in compounds for the<strong> steam</strong>ing of food and also for smoking/fumigation. Here we have the Japanese once again trying to replicate the French cuisine, only with a twist,<strong> steam</strong>ing food with flowers (think of flower-smoked ham for example). Flowers must first be <em>completely soaked in water</em>, and then poured over a thin piece of <em>flooring</em> under which there is an <em>oven fire</em>.	"Note: <em>complete + water + floor</em> are later combined into 丞 <a href=""../v4/2919.html"">helping hand</a> (#2919 丞). Story: The driver of a<strong> steam</strong> train asks you for a <em>helping hand</em> and explains that your job is to throw <em>flowers</em> on the <em>fire</em> to make the<strong> steam</strong>."	(EASY KANJI!) At the top we see hot<strong> steam</strong> forming FLOWERS. At the bottom we see the STOVE FIRE heating the bottom of a pan. So what's in the middle causing all this<strong> steam</strong>? Its all COMPLETELY WATER.	I keep forgetting this primitive, so <em>completely</em>/<em>water</em> for me will be a sort of <em>water sprite</em> or elemental, a <em>child-like</em> creature <em>completely</em> made of <em>water</em>. ——– It used to be thought that to create<strong> steam</strong>, you had to trap the <em>water sprite</em> (using some sort of magical <em>flowers</em> as a lure), and place them over a thin piece of <em>flooring</em> under which there's an <em>oven fire</em>. The<strong> steam</strong> then <em>flowers</em> from the <em>water sprite</em> (re: fuaburisu).	When you want to<strong> steam</strong> some <em>flowers/vegetation</em> you don't cover them <em>completely</em> with <em>water</em>, rather you have just a little at the <em>floor</em> of the saucepan and then <em>heat</em>.		
承		acquiesce	The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word. The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character, with three additional strokes, best thought of as the kanji for <i>three</i>.		8	2050	1901	51	ショウ、ジョウ	うけたまわ.る、う.ける、ささ.げる、とど.める、たす.ける、こ.らす、つい.で、すく.う	To get someone to <em>completely</em> <strong>acquiesce</strong> it takes <em>3</em> dunks in the <em>water</em> before they give.	To get someone to<strong> acquiesce</strong>, duck them <em>completely</em> in <em>aqua</em> (=<em>water</em>) <em>three</em> times. (variation on dingomick's).	Warning, Obscene!! I finally got my girl to<strong> acquiesce</strong> to a lewd act.. But it took <em>3 times</em> to get it in <em>completely</em> and lots of <em>water</em> to clean up afterwards.	"You must ask the trapped <em>water sprite</em> not once, not twice, but <em>thrice</em> (a line from Samuel Taylor Coleridge's ""Kubla Khan"" comes to mind) before it will<strong> acquiesce</strong> to your requests. It's not for any mystical reasons, it's just that it hates being asked the same thing <em>three</em> times, like that character from Austin Powers."	Waterboarding: To <em>completely</em><strong> acquiesce</strong> it usually takes just <em>three</em> sessions with <em>water</em>. (Thanks to dingomick for the idea.).		
函		bin	This is the character from which the element for <i>shovel</i> derives. Within it comes the element for <i>snare</i>, with the <i>sparkler</i> surrounding it.		8	2051	1902	51	カン	はこ、い.れる	Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the<strong> bin</strong> as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my<strong> bin</strong>.	(thegeezer3) Damn racoons… I'll show them. I'll put a SNARE in the<strong> BIN</strong> as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.	A typical German apartment has five different kind of trash<strong> bin</strong>s: paper, plastic, glass, biodegradable, and everything else. Don't you dare throw your trash in the wrong<strong> bin</strong>, or else you'll find yourself on the wrong side of a booby trap: hung by a <em>snare</em>, burned by <em>sparklers</em>, and knocked out cold by a <em>shovel</em>.	(Reformatted from erikkusan) The Windows Recycle<strong> Bin</strong> is like a <em>snare</em> holding onto your trash. When you empty it, a window displays little <em>sparkles</em> as the files are <em>shoveled</em> off of your hard drive.	"This is alternative way of writing 箱 , used in e.g. 函館 (はこだて) and sometimes as is. This<strong> bin</strong> is actually a snare with a powerful sparkler in it that kills rats that enter it, the remains of which are then shoveled away (to a ""recycle<strong> bin</strong>"" perhaps)."		
極		poles	The <b>poles</b> this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field. The elements are: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>snare</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>crotch</i> . . . <i>floor</i>.		12	2052	1903	51	キョク、ゴク	きわ.める、きわ.まる、きわ.まり、きわ.み、き.める、-ぎ.め、き.まる	"Can simplify this using <a href=""../v4/1243.html"">decay</a> (#1243 朽). Then: The expedition to the<strong> poles</strong> is bad for your health, and the <em>decay</em> that started in your <em>mouth</em> spreads to your <em>crotch</em> – at which point you fall to the <em>floor</em>."	"(modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using <a href=""../v4/1243.html"">decay</a> (#1243 朽). You travel to the <em>poles</em>, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is <em>decayed</em> (see story for <a href=""../v4/1243.html"">decay</a> (#1243 朽)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your <em>mouth</em> as your lips turn blue, then your <em>crotch</em> also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the <em>floor</em>."	Santa Claus (from the North <strong>Pole</strong>, of course), has a <em>wooden</em> sled led by reindeer <em>snared</em> at the <em>mouth</em>. One unfortunate night, he jumps down a chimney and burns his <em>crotch</em> on a piece of coal as he hits the <em>floor</em>.	The diverging magnetic fields at the<strong> poles</strong> actually attract cosmic radioactive <em>decay</em>, particularly the kind that causes cancer in the lips or the testicles. But don't worry, you can protect either your <em>mouth</em> or your <em>crotch</em> by digging a hole in the <em>ground</em> and covering it up. Which part do you protect? Imagine coming back home with cancer in the other, unprotected part.	"I remember sharing this joke on the playground back in 1986. ""Did you ear about the dumb polak who climbed a tall tree to see both<strong> poles</strong>? On the way up, stepped in his own snare, fell to the floor and ended up with his crotch in his own mouth. Then he said seeing his own crotch in his mouth… that's not the pole I wanted to see!""."		
牙		tusk	If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a <i>box</i>-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the <i>halberd</i>, a convenient combination for the <b>tusk</b> protruding from the mouth of an animal.	* Since this kanji has 4 strokes, you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4 - but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames (the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes) and reverts to 4 again in frame 2056.	4	2053	1904	52	ガ、ゲ	きば、は、きばへん	The kanji looks like an elephant with<strong> tusk</strong>s. the box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the<strong> tusk</strong>.	He stored the<strong> tusk</strong>s into a <em>box</em>, along with the <em>broken halberds</em>.	"You can save yourself a lot of trouble because Heisig is correct on <a href=""../v4/1904.html"">tusk</a> (#1904 牙) (4), <a href=""../v4/1905.html"">bud</a> (#1905 芽) (8), <a href=""../v4/1906.html"">wicked</a> (#1906 邪) (8) but not <a href=""../v4/1907.html"">gracious</a> (#1907 雅) (5th edition says 12, but WWWJDIC says 13). So: In it's Kanji form, it has four (4) strokes, in it's primitive form (I suggest: ivory because that's what elephant<strong> tusk</strong>s are made of) it has always five (5) strokes for all Kanji in RTK1."	The <em>waitress</em> was charged by the elephant who skewered her legs with its<strong> tusk</strong>s. As a result her right leg had to be amputated (<em>missing right leg</em>), her left leg is crippled, stiff, and limp (<em>straight left leg</em>), and the<strong> tusk</strong> is still embedded in her left leg (<em>final stroke attached to waitress's crippled left leg</em>).	This actually reminds me of <em>waitress</em> more than anything, but that doesn't help much.		
芽		bud	Flowers . . . tusk.		8	2054	1905	52	ガ	め	Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant's <em>tusks</em> keep <strong>budding</strong> into <em>flowers</em>.	<strong>Bud</strong>s while they're still small tend to be tusk-shaped.	An elephant places a big <em>flower</em> on the other elephant's <em>tusks</em>, to show they're best<strong> bud</strong>s.	Unfortunately, this must be a sad story. Poachers lure the elefants with <strong>buds</strong> (of <em>flowers</em>) so they can kill them to get their <em>ivory</em>.	Lets smoke some flower<strong> bud</strong> out of my tusk bong.		
邪		wicked	Tusk . . . city walls.		8	2055	1906	52	ジャ	よこし.ま	The <strong>wicked</strong> queen builds her <em>city walls</em> out of menacing <em>tusks</em>.	As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a<strong> WICKED</strong> city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.	"The battle of Pelennor Fields (Lord of the Rings): The <em>Mumak/Oliphant</em>s are driven by their <strong>wicked</strong> riders to attack the <em>city walls</em> of Minas Tirith. It's easy to say who were the <strong>wicked</strong> ones and who were the good guys. (<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q_EY4JYruC8"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q_EY4JYruC8</a>)."	You can see this is the city of the <strong>wicked</strong> just by the huge <em>tusks</em> adorning the <em>city walls</em>.	Considered a<strong> WICKED</strong> trade by most of the modern world, the TUSK trade is still often carried out in the SLUMS, outside of the influence of the police and government.		
雅		gracious	Tusk . . . an old turkey.		13	2056	1907	52	ガ	みや.び	"""Goodness<strong> gracious</strong>! Such an <strong>elegant</strong> <em>turkey with a tusk</em>."" This mnemonic is meant to join RtK's keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used ""<strong>elegant</strong>"" here, which is not confounded so easily with <a href=""../v4/721.html"">graceful</a> (#721 淑), and accurately represents the character's meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha's Kanji Learner's Dictionary)."	"To not confuse it with <a href=""../v4/606.html"">grace</a> (#606 恩) or <a href=""../v4/721.html"">graceful</a> (#721 淑), think of the phrase ""Goodness<strong> gracious</strong>."" Like: ""Goodness<strong> gracious</strong>! A <em>turkey</em> with <em>tusks</em>!""."	Be<strong> gracious</strong> around the large-<em>tusked turkey</em>. They're emotional at the best of times, so don't excite them with a big weapon like that.	"""Goodness<strong> gracious</strong>! A <em>turkey</em> with <em>tusks</em>!"" screamed the <strong>elegant</strong> lady walking through the GM farm."	"WARNING: there's a kanji for <a href=""../v4/1976.html"">elephant</a> (#1976 象). ………………………….. <em>Elephant Tusks</em> are very <strong>gracious</strong>; <em>Turkey wattles</em> aren't. ……………… <a href=""http://images.google.co.uk/images?q=turkey"">http://images.google.co.uk/images?q=turkey</a>+wattles ."		
釈		interpretation	Animal tracks . . . shakuhachi.		12	2057	1908	52	シャク、セキ	とく、す.てる、ゆる.す	"Mrs. Badger follows the <em>animal tracks</em> to the den where she finds her husband getting a <em>blowjob</em> from a fox. ""I have a good <strong>explanation</strong> for this. Really!""."	<strong>Animal track</strong> primitive: As expected, <strong>animal tracks</strong> were left in place of the trail of <em>rice</em> I'd purposely <em>drop</em>ped the night before. EDIT - also try <strong>the footprint</strong> for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This <em>shakuhachi</em> player is so talented, he can do<strong> interpretation</strong>s of animal noises too. They're so realistic he soon has <em>animal tracks</em> leading straight to wherever he's playing.	The magical shakuhachi can easily give explanation for any animal tracks, just like it can be used to translate words ( 訳 ).	Mrs. Badger follows the <em>animal tracks</em> to the den where she finds her husband getting <em>shakuhachi</em> from a fox. Now, I don't speak badger but judging from the screeching and the gestures, my<strong> interpretation</strong> of the situation is that Mrs. Badger is not pleased. (thanks dingomick! Just trying to use this new keyword).	An <strong>interpretive</strong> dance of some kind where somebody follows <em>animal tracks</em>, a <em>shakuhachi</em> providing the soundtrack, suggesting the tracker's thoughts and intentions.		
番		turn	This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji: a <b>turn</b> of duty, a round, a number, and so forth. Its composite elements: <i>animal tracks</i> . . . <i>rice field</i>.	* As a primitive element, we choose the image of a pair of <i>dice</i> which it is your <i>turn</i> to throw.	12	2058	1909	52	バン	つが.い	The famers take it in<strong> turn</strong>s to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.	(modified thegeezer3) <em>Animal tracks</em> were found in the <em>rice field</em>, now the kids of the farmer take it in<strong> turn</strong>s to keep watch and hinder the animals to make more <em>animal tracks</em> in their precious <em>rice field</em>. They roll the <em>dice</em> to decide in what order they have to keep watch and when everyones<strong> turn</strong> is.	[turn; number in a series] Ok, I'm done - now it's your <strong>turn</strong> to count the <em>drops</em> of <em>rice</em> in the <em>rice field</em>…	"I find ""turn"" alone is too generic to remember, so I add an additional keyword, <strong>numerical order</strong>. This is perhaps the most common context in which this kanji is found, e.g. 1st, 2nd = <a href=""midori://search?text=%E4%B8%80%E7%95%AA%E3%80%81%E4%BA%8C%E7%95%AA"">一番、二番</a> . Story: I see <em>animal tracks</em> leading to the <em>rice field</em> and start to worry, but then see the <strong>numerical order</strong> in which the tracks are made: 一番 mouse tracks, 二番 cat tracks, 三番 dog tracks, then 四番 lion tracks. Looks like the rice is safe."	(I use <em>animal droppings</em> instead of <em>animal tracks</em> to avoid confusion.) Story: Workers slack off in the <em>rice field</em> taking<strong> turn</strong>s at a dice game, using <em>animal droppings</em> as the dice (for lack of other implements). What game are they playing? Craps, of course.		
審		hearing	The <b>hearing</b> referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts. The elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>dice</i>.		15	2059	1910	52	シン	つまび.らか、つぶさ.に	"At your divorce<strong> hearing</strong> the judge tells you to roll <em>dice</em> to see who keeps the <em>house</em>. (""I can't believe what I'm<strong> hearing</strong>!"" you say)."	In the court<em>house</em> the judge decides your <strong>hearing</strong> with a roll of the <em>dice</em>.	The <strong>hearing</strong> was quite informal. We had it at the judges' <em>house</em>. Each party took a <em>turn</em> relating their side of the issues, then the judge concluded the <strong>hearing</strong> with his decision.	In the <em>house</em> of law, both sides take <em>turns</em> during the<strong> hearing</strong>.	If you operate a <em>house</em> of <em>dice</em>, you can expect to end up in front of a Judge at a <strong>hearing</strong>.		
翻		flip	Dice . . . feathers.		18	2060	1911	52	ホン、ハン	ひるがえ.る、ひるがえ.す	Don't play <em>dice</em> with birds. When you're not looking, they'll<strong> flip</strong> the <em>dice</em> with their <em>feathers</em>.	When the birds out the back are playing <em>dice</em>, they<strong> flip</strong> their <em>feathers</em> (not their finger) at their opponents.	"According to my books, this<strong> flip</strong> is related to<strong> flip</strong>ping food in a frying pan or something like that. To <em>flip</em> an omelette, you need first some eggs. But you said it aloud, and when you go to the <em>field</em>, you find it empty except for some <em>animal tracks</em> and some missing <em>feathers</em>. The chickens have escaped!! <em>(music from ""Chicken Run"")</em>."	It's your <em>turn</em> to<strong> flip</strong> the chicken <em>wings</em> on grill.	These are crooked <em>dice</em>, modified using the latest robotic technology. To <strong>flip</strong> right in flight, they momentarily stick out tiny <em>feathered</em> wings to perform few deft flaps.		
藩		clan	Flowers . . . water . . . dice.		18	2061	1912	52	ハン		"This character refers to feudal<strong> clan</strong>s that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures ( 廃藩置県 ), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落 , flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that<strong> clan</strong>s' location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29</a>."	In the particular<strong> clan</strong> depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her <em>turn</em> <em>watering</em> the <em>flowers</em>.	Each member of the<strong> clan</strong> has to take his <em>turn</em> at <em>water</em>ing the <em>flowers</em>. The order they do it in is decided by a roll of the <em>dice</em>. (tweaked Matthew's story).	"This yakuza<strong> clan</strong> controls the ""flower"" trade, the 'water business' ( 水商 ) and the dice gambling."	This is what members of Ku Klux<strong> Clan</strong> is doing when not meeting: pretending to live normal life by watering flowers during the day and playing dice-games with their families at night. What a double-life.		
毛		fur	This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of <i>hand</i> to produce <b>fur</b>. If you reverse your <i>hand</i> and put its palm down, you will have the side on which <b>fur</b> grows.		4	2062	1913	52	モウ	け	I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's <strong>fur</strong>!	Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don't like you rubbing your <em>hand backwards</em> over their<strong> fur</strong>.	<strong>Reverse</strong> stroke of <em>hand</em> disturbs the<strong> fur</strong>.	I touch the<strong> FUR</strong> of the animals only with the reverse of my HAND . Be careful, strokes are not horizontal.	I have a lot of<strong> fur</strong> on the back of my hand.		
耗		decrease	Christmas tree . . . fur.		10	2063	1914	52	モウ、コウ、カウ		"The amount of ""fur"" (needles) on a Christmas tree<strong> decrease</strong>s, until it doesn't look all that good."	Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.	"A marketing survey shows that there has been a<strong> decrease</strong> in Christmas trees sales. It turns out, many very stupid people confused a fir tree with a ""fur"" tree, and because ""fur is murder"" stopped buying the trees."	Christmas Tree + Fur: The<strong> decrease</strong> in the purchases of <em>furry christmas trees</em> is a result of protest from animal rights activists and nature lovers.	Sorry,<strong> decrease</strong> is too generic to remember… I bought my sister a <strong>de-creaser</strong> (a clothing maintenance device similar to an iron) after she complained about her <strong>fur coats</strong> getting all <strong>creased</strong> and wrinkled. But it was only November, so it had to sit for a while under the <strong>Christmas tree</strong> in a wrapped box waiting for someone to open it up and use it to <strong>de-crease</strong> something.		
尾		tail	Flag . . . fur.		7	2064	1915	52	ビ	お	A dog waves its furry<strong> tail</strong> like a flag.	A FLAG of FUR is a<strong> TAIL</strong>.	"I taught my dog to use the toilet. Great, right? Problem: Her<strong> tail</strong> is too long. It dips in the toilet as she tries to sit and now the <em>fur</em> smells like <em>pee</em>. Plus she splatters everyone with pee water when she wags her<strong> tail</strong>. Ew! (Note: I use ""pee"" for the flag primitive)."	Animals wave their furry<strong> tail</strong>s like flags, indicating their mood.	A <em>flag</em>-loving nationalist paints the <em>fur</em> on the<strong> tail</strong> of his <em>furry</em> dog in the colors of the national <em>flag</em>, and together they go to watch the military parade. The nationalist waves his <em>flag</em>, while the dog wags his <em>furry</em><strong> tail</strong>. 尾 (お):<strong> tail</strong>, ridge, caudal 尻尾 (しっぽ):<strong> tail</strong> (of an animal) 追尾 (ついび): following, pursuing, tracking,<strong> tail</strong>ing 尾骨 (びこつ): coccyx (tailbone) 水平尾翼 (すいへい びよく):<strong> tail</strong> plane (of an airplane).		
宅		home	House . . . lock of hair.		6	2065	1916	52	タク		"This kanji is, of course, pronounced ""taku"", and it seems the owner of this<strong> home</strong> is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up <em>locks of hair</em> suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his <em>house</em>. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose<strong> home</strong> you wouldn't want to visit."	"""<strong>Home</strong> is where the <em>hair</em> is""."	At<strong> home</strong>, all the drains in my <em>house</em> are clogged up with <em>locks of hair</em>.	I'm very paranoid when I finally call my <em>house</em> a<strong> home</strong>, so whenever I leave, I cut a <em>lock of hair</em>, divide it into strands, and place it at all the entrances. If one is displaced, then I know someone has been there! Saw that in a James Bond movie.	House and locks of hair (goldilocks) = goldilocks broke into the bears house and treat it like her own<strong> home</strong> the selfish bitch.		
託		consign	Words . . . lock of hair.		10	2066	1917	52	タク	かこつ.ける、かこ.つ、かこ.つける	When you<strong> consign</strong> a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word).	"In ""The Lord of the Rings"", Galadriel<strong> consign</strong>ed a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words."	Through <em>words</em> and a <em>lock of hair</em> the voodoo priestess<strong> consign</strong>s you to a life of pain.	"ENGLISH DEF.: give over to another for care or safekeeping; ""consign your baggage"" /// When you<strong> consign</strong> a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word)."	"Found at a <em>consign</em>ment shop: a <em>lock of hair</em> <em>said</em> to belonging to <em>Socrates</em>. [Using<strong> consign</strong>ment shop helps to distinguish<strong> consign</strong> from <a href=""../v4/1954.html"">entrust</a> (#1954 嘱), especially if you use 'say', 'word', etc. in both stories]."		
為		do	This character rightly belongs to the previous lesson, but we held it until now because of the final element, the <i>tail feathers</i>. After the <i>drop</i> at the outset, the next three strokes are completely novel and should be given special attention.		9	2067	1918	52	イ	ため、な.る、な.す、す.る、たり、つく.る、なり	"In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: ""So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna<strong> DO</strong> it?"" ""Only if you (ユ)<strong> do</strong>"" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS."	<strong>Do</strong> me <em>from</em> behind, says the bird, as she shakes her <em>tailfeathers</em>.	Tell a story - a reluctant magician is asked to<strong> do</strong> a trick. The audience chant 'Do it,<strong> do</strong> it!', so eventually he<strong> do</strong>es one. He takes a <em>drop</em> of water (stroke 1), drops it on the ground where it runs<strong> do</strong>wn and smears out (stroke 2). It drops<strong> do</strong>wn two steps (strokes 3 and 4) (imagine some nice setting with steps), growing and becoming multicoloured, like a petrol drop, as it goes. Then at the bottom the magician touches it with his wand and you see it has turned into a set of peacock's <em>tail feathers</em>.	"The keyword ""do"" is just too generic for me, so I use ""<strong>for the sake of</strong>"", which is perhaps a more common reading; for those familiar with the phrase ために, I believe this is the kanji for ため."	"""I <strong>do</strong>!"" says the bride before tripping over a <em>spear</em>, falling<strong> do</strong>wn the stairs and into the <em>flames</em>."		
偽		falsehood	Person . . . do.		11	2068	1919	52	ギ、カ	いつわ.る、にせ、いつわ.り	"Mr. T doesn’t ""DO""<strong> FALSEHOOD</strong>. It goes against everything he stands for. “I pity da foos who revel in<strong> FALSEHOOD</strong>s!”."	"""It depends on what your definition of <em>do</em>, uh, is,"" says <em>Mr. T</em> giving <strong>falsehood</strong> about his affair with a peacock."	"Not really a story but I believe that giving special attention to a kanji is also a good way to remember it and this one was selected as <strong>""Kanji of the year 2007""</strong>. <a href=""http://www.japanprobe.com/?p=3368"">http://www.japanprobe.com/?p=3368</a>."	[falsehood; lie; deceive; pretend; counterfeit; forgery] A <em>person</em> who claims to have seen a living <em>Dodo</em> bird is telling a <strong>falsehood</strong>. (based on astridtops,17-10-2006).	A <em>person</em> who claims he didn't <em>do</em> something while he actually did, is telling a<strong> falsehood</strong>.

"""Dear Heisig, if I see you misname another kanji I'm going stab you repeatedly in the <em>brain</em> with a <em>hairpin</em>. <strong>Your's truly</strong>, a pissed off member from RevTK""."		
長		long	In line with the story of the preceding frame, the <i>hair</i> that needs the <i>hairpin</i> is <b>long</b>.	* The primitive of this kanji has two more shapes in addition to that of the kanji itself. Above its relative primitive, it is abbreviated form will mean <i>hair</i>. Further abbreviated,  it will mean the long, mangy <i>mane</i> of an animal.	8	2070	1920	52	チョウ	なが.い、おさ	The Geisha with<strong> long</strong> <em>hair</em> uses an ornate lacquered <em>hairpin</em> to bundle it all up.	The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here's my story: The girl's hair was so<strong> long</strong> that she had to use <em>staples</em> instead of <em>hairpins</em>. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.	"As a primitive I use the image of (very)<strong> long</strong> hair. Let this kanji represent a ""Swiss Hairpin"" (similar to a Swiss army knife) : the top part being a pictogram for <em>half a comb</em>, and the lower part being the <em>hairpin</em>. Just make sure not to confuse with the kanji for ""comb"". Think of this one as a ""<em>half a comb</em>"" that can be pulled from the ""Swiss Hairpin""."	HAIRPIN: This is rather similar to that for SCARF. Both a HAIRPIN and a SCARF can be used for holding back<strong> long</strong> hair. STORY: The first 4 strokes could be a pictograph of hair blowing in the wind. It's too<strong> LONG</strong> and getting in your way, so you pin it back.	The<strong> long</strong> haired Geisha <em>staples</em> on an ornate <em>hairpin</em> so it won't slip. (Thanks to Zactacular for the idea.).		
張		lengthen	Bow . . . long.		11	2071	1921	52	チョウ	は.る、-は.り、-ば.り	The longbow is follows the design of a standard <em>bow</em>, only it has been<strong> lengthen</strong>ed.	"<em>Legolas</em> recieves spam telling him that his can <strong>lengthen</strong> his ""bow""…he smirks…he know's it's already <em>long</em> enough."	Wanna<strong> lengthen</strong> the distance you can shoot? Use a <em>longbow</em>!	In desperation, after the <em>Geisha</em> (see long) broke the string on her <em>bow</em>, she<strong> lengthen</strong>ed out one of her own hairs and strung the bow with it.	To make your <em>bow</em> into a <em>long</em>bow, just<strong> lengthen</strong> it.

I put <em>Play-Doh</em> in the <em>hair</em> of my <em>friends</em>. I learned that the<strong> hair of the head</strong> does not go well with Play-Doh.		
展		unfold	Flag . . . salad . . . hairpin.		10	2075	1925	52	テン		You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine<strong> unfold</strong>ing it to open up the bounty you've fixed up for yourself.	<strong>Unfold</strong> <em>flag</em>, take out the <em>salad</em>, pin the flag down with <em>hairpins</em> and have a picnic.	You<strong> unfold</strong> the Stars and Stripes <em>flag</em> in order to hoist it high, but there's a problem! One of the stars has fallen off! With some quick thinking, you pin a <em>flower</em> to the <em>flag</em> using a <em>hairpin</em>, and you're all set. Good thing you don't have to refold the flag once<strong> unfold</strong>ed.	"The farmer girl has made some ready-to-eat salad packs, but has no way to take it to the market. She takes down the <em>flag</em>, wraps the <em>salad</em> packs and ties the bundle with her own <em>hairpin</em>. So she arrives at the market and <strong>unfolds</strong> the bundle to <strong>exhibit</strong> her goods. (Based on ""darg_sama""'s story)."	The <em>flag</em> had been used for a picnic so when I<strong> unfold</strong>ed it, bits of <em>salad</em> and <em>hairpins</em> fell out of the folds.		
喪		miss	<i>Soil</i> . . . two <i>mouths</i> . . . <i>hairpin</i>. Hint: see <i>spit</i> (Frame 162). The key word carries the wide range of meanings readily associated with it: error, loss, absence, and so on.		12	2076	1926	52	ソウ	も	"I <strong>miss</strong> my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big <em>cross</em>, their <em>mouths</em> side by side. I stick <em>hairpins</em> in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. ""Soil"" is not drawn in its stroke order."	<em>Ten</em> days ago, our <em>two mouths</em> met for the last time… then she gave me her <em>hairpin</em> as a sayounara gift. How I<strong> miss</strong> my Geisha girl…	"This kanji means<strong> miss</strong> as in ""miss a (dearly departed) person"", not as in ""miss a target"". Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths."	The miner<strong> miss</strong>es his<strong> miss</strong> (his sweetheart). So much <em>soil</em> is separating his <em>mouth</em> from hers (working as a miner deep below the ground). She left him a <em>hairpin</em> as a good-luck trinket.	We tried to kiss ten times but our 2 mouths<strong> MISS</strong>ED every time. She got upset and threw her hairpin at me.		
巣		nest	Owl . . . fruit.		11	2077	1927	53	ソウ	す、す.くう	<em>Owls</em> only<strong> nest</strong> in <em>fruit trees</em>.	The wise old OWL makes her<strong> nest</strong> out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it's less work: no running back & forth to get food!	If only there had been a wise <em>owl</em> <strong>nesting</strong> in the tree of forbidden <em>fruit</em> to warn Eve about the snake.	The <em>owl</em> with the biggest <em>brain</em> will<strong> nest</strong> at the very top of a <em>tree</em>.	All the little forest creatures bring <em>fruits</em> to the <em>owl's</em><strong> nest</strong> so they don't get eaten.		
単		simple	"<i>Owl</i> . . . <i>brain</i> . . . <i>needle</i>. The sense is ""not complex."""		9	2078	1928	53	タン	ひとえ	Owls are smart…for this <em>owl</em> everything is<strong> simple</strong> coz his <em>brain</em> is <em>ten</em> times more powerful than mine.	For <em>owl</em>s, finding a <em>needle</em> in a <em>rice field</em> is<strong> simple</strong> (much better eyesight than us humans).	"A girl who was working at <em>Hooters</em> thought she was going to be fired because her breasts were too small. She went to an acupuncturist who convinced her that planting <em>needles</em> into her <em>brain</em> would increase the size of her breasts. Of course, all that did is she was fired and although she wasn't very smart to begin with, now she's<strong> simple</strong>-minded for life. As a primitive let this kanji be ""simple-minded blond girl"" (ex-<em>Hooters Girl</em>). Keep the image distinct from ""Hooters Girl"" (top 3 strokes)."	"Careful: <a href=""../v4/1621.html"">simplicity</a> (#1621 簡). There was an 80's pop group called ""Simple Minds"" (simple <em>brains</em>). Their most famous song was ""Don't you forget about me"" which started out with, ""Hey hey hey hey, oouuh oouuh wooah ho-ooh"", which kind of sounds like an <em>owl</em>'s ""hoo hoo"" call. The song became a top <em>ten</em> hit. <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Minds"">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Minds</a> Primitive meaning: imbecilic guards from Monty Python/Holy Grail (who can't even understand the<strong> simple</strong> instruction to ""stay here and guard the prisoner"")."	"""How do you perform a labotomy, <em>Owl</em>?"" Pooh asks one day. In his characteristically supercilious tone, <em>Owl</em> replies, ""<strong>Simple</strong>, my<strong> simple</strong> friend. I shall show you by performing one on myself. You see one just has to remove one's <em>brain</em>, like so, and put it on a <em>needle</em> and then…oh, Pooh, I don't feel very well…."" Alas, Pooh is no longer paying attention, because he's currently watching The<strong> Simple</strong> Life, the primitive reading for this kanji."		
戦		war	Simple . . . fiesta.		13	2079	1929	53	セン	いくさ、たたか.う、おのの.く、そよぐ、わなな.く	George W. Bush's plans for<strong> war</strong> were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA.	What started out as a <em>simple fiesta</em>, turned into a full-scale<strong> war</strong> after arguments about whose potato salad was the best.	So there's this fiesta in downtown Compton. It's a simple party, but someone invited people from the wrong gangs and the simple fiesta turns into an all-out turf<strong> war</strong>.	<em>Simple-minded blond girl</em> (see previous frame) is going to a <em>fiesta</em>, and boy… is this<strong> war</strong> ! She may be simple-minded but she could easily have written The Art of<strong> War</strong>. Only, the woman's version. She has just arrived at the fiesta, she has quickly apprehended the battlefield, taking note of the other competing girls who may pose a threat, and where the good looking guys are. Just watch her dividing the girls, and conquering the boys. I told you, this is<strong> war</strong> !	Think Iraq<strong> war</strong> - Rumsfeld thought it would be <em>simple</em>, but it was no <em>fiesta</em>. セン 戦争 せんそう.		
禅		Zen	Altar . . . simple.		13	2080	1930	53	ゼン、セン	しずか、ゆず.る	Knowing<strong> ZEN</strong>’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a<strong> ZEN</strong> ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE. Because<strong> Zen</strong> is so <em>simple</em>, you don't need an <em>alter</em>, just a quiet place to sit.	"Guys, if you're just going to make your story some variation of ""Zen altars are simple"", do you really need to share it publicly? There's 100 other stories saying exactly the same thing. You don't need to check the ""share this story"" box for every story you make. Don't make people wade through 100 stories that are exactly the same just to find the one that's different and works for them."		
弾		bullet	Bow . . . simple.		12	2081	1931	53	ダン、タン	ひ.く、-ひ.き、はず.む、たま、はじ.く、はじ.ける、ただ.す、はじ.きゆみ	Hunting with a <em>bow</em> is too complicated. Bows are rather simple devices compared to things that use<strong> bullet</strong>s.	<strong>Bullet</strong>s make <em>bows</em> look <em>simple</em> and obselete.

獣		animal	Owl . . . rice field . . . one . . . mouth . . . chihuahua.		16	2083	1933	53	ジュウ	けもの、けだもの	The <em>owl</em> looks for its prey in the <em>rice field</em>. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).	"I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a <em>owl</em> getting into a <em>rice field</em> which serves as a boxing ring. 脳		brain	<i>Part of the body</i> . . . <i>owl</i> . . . <i>villain</i>. By way of exception, the kanji for <b>brain</b> has no connection with the primitive for <i>brains</i>.		11	2084	1934	53	ノウ、ドウ	のうずる	The<strong> brain</strong> is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl… or the wickedness of the villain. The<strong> brain</strong> is the <em>part of the body</em> that can make you wise like an <em>owl</em> or devious like a <em>villain</em>.	While Superheroes and stupider animals rely on brawn, the <em>part of the body</em> that <em>owls</em> and diabolical <em>villains</em> rely on is their <strong>brains</strong>. I know which I like more.	Every full <em>moon</em> the <em>owl</em> swoops down on <em>villains</em>, tearing out their<strong> brain</strong>s.

So he made a <em>tool</em> that looked like a <em>hand</em> which he used when he needed to <strong>raise</strong> his <em>hand</em>. 猟		game hunting	Pack of wild dogs . . . owl . . . wind . . . cornstalk.		11	2090	1940	53	リョウ、レフ	かり、か.る	"[game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (<a href=""../v4/2065.html"">mouse</a> (#2065 鼠)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I'll call <strong>rat</strong>) I have: an <em>owl</em>, flying in the <em>wind</em>, can easily spot a <strong>rat</strong> even if it's hiding in the <em>cornstalks</em>. Now 猟 is easy: <em>wild dogs</em> are having fun by <strong>game-hunting</strong> <em>rat</em>s."	The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.	The hunter, with his WILD DOGs to sniff out prey and his trained OWL to scout from the sky, is out<strong> game-hunting</strong> among the CORNSTALKS in a fierce WIND.	A <em>pack of wild dogs</em> chases an <em>owl</em> gliding on the <em>wind</em>, who drops <em>cornstalks</em> on them. It's hard to tell who's doing the<strong> game-hunting</strong>.	"The right side is also used in 蝋 , meaning ""wax"" (used in e.g. candle, 蝋燭 , and wax doll, 蝋人形 ). The lower right is 用 with wind instead of canopy. The true meaning of the right side is ""many gathering together"", and meaning for 蝋 comes from bee nests (bee wax). So, right side: utilization of a multitude of owls in the wind ==> multitude. Multitude of hunting dogs is used in<strong> game-hunting</strong>."

鶴		crane	<i>Turkey house</i> . . . <i>bird</i>. The first element appears on only one other occasion, back in frame 609.		21	2093	1943	53	カク	つる	"The original version of the ""Ugly Duckling"" was about a<strong> crane</strong> who grew up in a <em>turkey coop.</em> All the other <em>birds</em> made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail…"	I ordered a<strong> crane</strong> to move my <em>turkey coop</em>, but they sent me this damn <em>bird</em> instead. But the<strong> crane</strong> really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the <em>coop</em> trying to be free. 烏		crow	The only thing that distinguishes this character from that for <i>bird</i> is the omission of the one stroke that makes it <i>white</i>. Which is logical enough, when you consider that there are no <b>crows</b> of that color.		10	2094	1944	53	ウ、オ	からす、いずくんぞ、なんぞ	The book's story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As<strong> crow</strong>s are all black, it's hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be.	A<strong> crow</strong> is a <em>bird</em>, but <em>not a white one</em>. MEANING: write <em>bird</em>, but skip writing <em>one</em> in <em>white</em>.	When God made<strong> crow</strong>s he took away their <em>whiteness</em> and gave them big <em>mouths</em> instead.	The <strong>crow</strong> is a bird with a big mouth (caw! caw!) and no white feathers to be seen.	<strong>Crow</strong>s are not white birds. brilliant.		
蔦		vine	Flower . . . bird.		14	2095	1945	53	チョウ	つた	In the jungle there is a flowery<strong> vine</strong> called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the<strong> vine</strong>.	"Note : if you'll remember we already have a primitive for ""ivy"", but it was completely made up from the ""square jewel"" kanji. The kanji here refers to ivy, or<strong> vine</strong>, and is used in a particular compound for ""Hedera rhombea"", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This<strong> vine</strong> here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener."	It's strange that you don't often see <em>flowers</em> on <strong>vines</strong>, that's because those sneaky <em>birds</em> keep swooping in and stealing them!	"""I heard it through the grapevine"" and ""a little birdy told me"" are actually the same metaphor, linked together by a proverbial flower that's since dropped from both expressions! Or so a bird on a flower grapevine told me…"	The <em>flowery</em><strong> vine</strong> is the one that <em>birds</em> gather around.		
鳩		pigeon	Baseball . . . bird.		13	2096	1946	53	キュウ、ク	はと、あつ.める	<strong>Pigeon</strong>s are the birds that come in hordes after baseball games to eat all the trash left by fans. A<strong> PIGEON</strong> defecates <em>NINE</em> times as often as other <em>BIRDS</em>. Or so it seems.	"A<strong> pigeon</strong> is a <em>baseball-bird</em>. You probably all now the ""pigeon explosion"", don't you? <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ZdgOQvKaHU"">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ZdgOQvKaHU</a>."	"<strong>Pigeon</strong>s are birds that say ""ku"" or く . And 九 can be read as　く."		
鶏		chicken	Vulture . . . husband . . . bird.		19	2097	1947	53	ケイ	にわとり、とり	The <em>vulture's</em> <em>husband</em> is a<strong> chicken</strong>…heck…who am I to judge their interspecies love? They're both <em>birds</em> so its cool.	"A continuation of <a href=""../v4/840.html"">mountain stream</a> (#840 渓) (which happens to have the same chinese pronunciation) : the <em>husband</em> who was saved by the <em>great eagle</em> says to his wife that from now on, they will eat<strong> chicken</strong> ! No more fishing hardships and falling in the water.. just raising <em>birds</em>. Every now and then the <em>great eagle</em> comes to visit and the man offers one of his<strong> chicken</strong> to the great eagle who had saved his life."	Ever since that <em>eagle</em> attacked my <em>husband</em> from above, he acts like a <strong>chicken</strong> whenever he sees a <em>bird</em>, fearing that it might be the eagle who has come back to finish the job.	<em>Homer Simpson</em> chases after the <em>vulture</em> who stole his roasted<strong> chicken</strong> dinner.	<em>Homer Simpson</em> circles like a <em>vulture</em> around Marge when she's preparing his favourite bird,<strong> chicken</strong>.		
島		island	The <i>bird's tail</i> is tucked under here, because it has come to stop on a <i>mountain</i> to rest from its journey across the waters. Thus the kanji comes to mean an <b>island</b>.		10	2098	1948	53	トウ	しま	This<strong> island</strong> is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.	On the mountain of the<strong> island</strong>.. there were birds with no tail feathers.	From the <em>bird</em>'s point of view, an<strong> island</strong> is a <em>mountain</em> in the middle of water and it is very suitable for resting its tired <em>tail feathers</em>.	Tweety bird looses his tail feathers and gets stuck on a mountainous<strong> Island</strong>.	Dragon Roost <em>Island</em> (a <em>mountain</em>-based<strong> island</strong> from The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker) is where the <em>bird</em>-people (Rito) live. You could also think of Valoo perched on top of the <em>mountain</em><strong> island</strong> like a <em>bird without feathers</em>.		
暖		warmth	Unlike the character for <i>warm</i> weather learned earlier (Frame 1560), this kanji and its key word can also refer to the <b>warmth</b> of human congeniality. Its elements are: <i>sun</i> . . . <i>migrating ducks</i>.		13	2099	1949	53	ダン、ノン	あたた.か、あたた.かい、あたた.まる、あたた.める	Ducks migrate south for the winter… they follow the<strong> warmth</strong> of the sun.	A massive group of <em>migrating ducks</em> is blocking the<strong> warmth</strong> of the <em>sun</em> as they pass over your house/barbecue/picnic. Their formation is so humongous they block the<strong> warmth</strong> for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the <em>migrating ducks</em> primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of <em>friends</em>, flying together <em>as one</em> (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the <em>great eagles / vultures</em>.	Mnemonic for migrating ducks: ducks always migrate together in pairs to protect themselves from vultures–they become friends in the process.	"This is<strong> warmth</strong> of the weather, opposite of 寒 . 温 is of things and feelings, opposite of 冷 . So darg_sama's story is just fine. For more details, see e.g. <a href=""http://utuzawa.hp.infoseek.co.jp/sannko.atatakai.htm"">http://utuzawa.hp.infoseek.co.jp/sannko.atatakai.htm</a>. Koujien says <a href=""midori://search?text=%E3%80%8C%E6%9A%96%E3%80%8D%E3%81%AF%E6%B0%97%E6%B8%A9%E3%83%BB%E7%A9%BA%E6%B0%97%E3%81%AA%E3%81%A9%E3%81%AB%E3%80%81%E3%80%8C%E6%B8%A9%E3%80%8D%E3%81%AF%E8%BA%AB%E4%BD%93%E3%83%BB%E6%96%99%E7%90%86%E3%83%BB%E6%B0%97%E6%8C%81%E3%81%AA%E3%81%A9%E3%81%AB%E4%BD%BF%E3%81%86%E3%81%93%E3%81%A8%E3%81%8C%E5%A4%9A%E3%81%84%E3%80%82"">「暖」は気温・空気などに、「温」は身体・料理・気持などに使うことが多い。</a> ."	If <em>ducks migrate</em> in search of<strong> warmth</strong>, I wonder why they don't just migrate to the <em>sun</em>.		
媛		beautiful woman	Woman . . . migrating ducks.		12	2100	1950	53	エン	ひめ	You want to know about a<strong> beautiful woman</strong>? There's a <em>woman</em> that's so beautiful, the <em>birds migrate</em> to her instead of the sun!	As I saw the most<strong> beautiful woman</strong> on Earth, a flock of <em>migrating ducks</em> passed by and let their poop fly. That just ruined the moment…	Ever seen Fly Away Home? It's the true story about a girl who took in a flock of baby ducks whose parents died, and taught them how to migrate by flying an airplane over their usual migration route. I imagine this girl has become a<strong> beautiful woman</strong>, inside and out.	"Helen of Troy was known for her beauty – as the ""face that launched a thousand ships."" In this slightly mangled version of the story, she's the <em>woman</em> who launched a thousand <em>migrating ducks</em>."	<strong>Beautiful women</strong> are like <em>migrating ducks</em>. (They come and go.).		
援		abet	Fingers . . . migrating ducks.		12	2101	1951	53	エン		You<strong> abet</strong> the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.	"""Aiding and<strong> abet</strong>ting:"" You are accuse of<strong> abet</strong>ting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in <em>migrating ducks</em>. Of course, this means you have to stick your <em>fingers</em> in their mouths."	"This kanji is in the word 援助 (えんじょ) which means to <strong>support</strong> or assist. The word<strong> abet</strong> suggests that you are helping or <strong>support</strong>ing something that is morally wrong. <strong>Support</strong> is a much better choice for this kanji. Story: The <em>migrating ducks</em> left a little early this year, leaving one duck behind. He gives them the finger and says thanks ""Thanks for the <strong>support</strong>, assholes!""."	"<strong>Abet</strong>? Nobody uses that word.<strong> Abet</strong> is an onomatopoeia for when you stick your fingers down migrating ducks' throats. That's the noise they make as they gag: ""aBET!<strong> aBET</strong>!"" Bet you won't forget this now."	Bird Criminal!! Wanted for: Aiding and<strong> ABET</strong>ting, the wrongful MIGRATION OF DUCKS by pointing them in the wrong direction with his FINGERS.		
緩		slacken	Thread . . . migrating ducks.		15	2102	1952	53	カン	ゆる.い、ゆる.やか、ゆる.む、ゆる.める	Oh no <em>Spiderman</em> has some <em>migrating ducks</em> stuck in his web, he has to<strong> slacken</strong> it so they can get out.	[slacken; loosen; relax; lessen; be moderate; ease] The <em>thread</em> in this story is a cable line, something like a power or phone line. The <em>thread</em> was tense with all the <em>migrating ducks</em> perched on it, but got back to being <strong>slacken</strong>ed when the entire flock flew away. (darg_sama-modified,2-11-2005).	A flock of migrating ducks has been complaining that their leader is flying too fast. So they attach a thread to him, whenever they want him to<strong> slacken</strong> his pace they just give a tug on the thread.	<em>Spiderman</em> is flying a flock of <em>migrating ducks</em> as one would fly a kite, using his web lines as the <em>thread</em>. But he notices the ducks are pulling away hard, threatening to break the line. Then he remembers the advice of dear Aunt May, a noted kite freak: you've gotta<strong> slacken</strong> it. Put some <strong>slack</strong> in it!	"When <em>Daffy</em> and <em>Spiderman</em> go rock climbing, <em>Spidey</em><strong> slacken</strong>s the rope too much, so that when <em>Daffy</em> falls, he slams on the ground. ""Your desp-p-p-picable!"", he yells."		
属		belong	<i>Flag</i> . . . <i>gnats</i> (see frame 563) . . . with a <i>belt</i>.		12	2103	1953	53	ゾク、ショク	さかん、つく、やから	These bugs<strong> BELONG</strong> TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war.	[WARNING: violent story] Two teams of <strong>insects</strong> are playing “capture the <strong>flag</strong>” (ala Unreal Tournament). All of them wear ammunition <strong>belts</strong>. Here you try to take the <strong>flag</strong> of the opponent team, when you are faced by an <strong>insect</strong>: “You’ll get our <strong>flag</strong> over my dead body!”. You reply: “All your base are<strong> BELONG</strong> to us!”, shoot him on the head, take the <strong>flag</strong> and run away. See the <strong>drop</strong> of blood flowing from his head?	This kanji is often used like this: The frog<strong> BELONG</strong>S to the amphibian species. STORY: A scientist is trying to classify all the different INSECTS in the forest to find out which species they<strong> BELONG</strong> to. He does this by going from rock to rock, tree to tree, putting a FLAG where he already went, while taking INSECT sample DROPS (small insects/beetles look like DROPS) and DROPPING them into his BELT which is rigged with little jars.	"Great picture with a story: <a href=""http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=64390#p64390"">http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=64390#p64390</a>."	"""You don't<strong> BELONG</strong> here!"", cried the crowd to the stranger they tied to the FLAG pole with a BELT as swarms of GNATS ate at his flesh. ""You don't<strong> BELONG</strong> here!"" At that moment, the man began to believe them ^_^."		
嘱		entrust	Mouth . . . belong.		15	2104	1954	53	ショク	しょく.する、たの.む	"The commando gnats<strong> entrust</strong>ed their <em>mouths</em> to the translators and what came out was ""All your base are <em>belong</em> to us!""."	If you<strong> entrust</strong> me with something, my <em>mouth belongs</em> to you.	You should only open your <em>mouth</em> to<strong> entrust</strong> someone with a secret if they <em>belong</em> in your family.	"""I have to go out for a few hours. Can I<strong> entrust</strong> you with my two-year-old?"" ""Okay, sure!"" …three hours later… ""I'm back … HEY!! Get that thing out of the baby's <em>mouth</em>! It doesn't <em>belong</em> there!"" (try to make a vivid picture of whatever object you decide the baby is chewing on - pen, razor blade, drill, Picasso painting, whatever… but be careful so that it doesn't get confused with another primitive.)."	<strong>Entrust</strong> is to confer trust in someone else. My <em>mouth belongs</em> to you and your secret is safely<strong> entrust</strong>ed with me.		
偶		accidentally	"The <i>person</i> on the left is familiar. As for the right side, we may combine the <i>insect</i> with a <i>brain</i> (observe the writing) and a <i>belt</i> to create the <i>Talking Cricket</i> who served as Pinocchio's conscience. (<i>The belt</i> is there because he pulls it off to give unrepentant little Pinocchio a bit of ""strap"" now and again.)"		11	2105	1955	53	グウ	たま	"<em>Mr. T</em> <strong>accidentially</strong> stepped on <em>Jiminy Cricket</em> (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his ""conscience"" badge)."	<em>Mr. T</em><strong> accidentally</strong> steps on <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>. // Primitive: right side: <em>Talking cricket</em> = <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>, a <em>brainy insect</em> with a <em>belt</em> to whip little kids who misbehave.	<em>Mr. T</em><strong> accidentally</strong> the whole <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>.	禺 is actually a kanji itself, albeit a rarely used one. Despite its several meanings, the most common seems to be a red-eyed, long-tailed, big-headed monkey. Since we already have a primitive that means monkey, I'm going to call this one the <em>long-tailed, talking monkey</em> (borrowing from Heisig a little). STORY: After suffering a slow period of work, <em>Ace Ventura</em><strong> accidentally</strong> discovered the rare <em>long-tailed, talking monkey</em> and life has been good to him ever since.	<em>Mr. T</em> <strong>accidentally</strong> <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>.		
遇		interview	Talking Cricket . . . road.		12	2106	1956	53	グウ	あ.う	I was finally able to score an<strong> interview</strong> with the wisest being around: <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short—after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the <em>interstate</em>. But man, it was worth it!	On the <em>road</em> to my <strong>interview</strong> I <em>accidentally</em> bump into <em>Jiminy Cricket</em> who gives me some good advice.	"""Interview"" is a bit of a stretch, as this means ""to meet accidentally"". The place where person accidentally met the crickety fellow was on the road somewhere. It was, in a way, like a sudden<strong> interview</strong>: in both cases person just wants to get away fast."	"I see Jiminy Cricket standing on the side of he road, holding out his thumb. ""Where are you going?"" I ask. ""To a job<strong> interview</strong>!"" he says. Even conscience's are losing their jobs lately!"	JIMINY CRICKET is on the ROAD doing a promotional tour. He's doing lots of impromptu<strong> INTERVIEW</strong>S, smoking lots of dope, and having lots of chance encounters with hot groupie bitches.		
愚		foolish	Talking Cricket . . . heart.		13	2107	1957	53	グ	おろ.か	"""Don't be <strong>foolish</strong>!"" says <em>Jiminy Cricket</em> as he lashes you with his belt. After all, you never see him around any girl crickets, do you?	"""Do you think I'll ever have an <em>heart</em> like a real child"" asks Pinoccio to <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>. In an unexpected reaction, he laughs at him:""My dear child, that's the<strong> foolish</strong> thing I ever heard"". Boy, those old fairy tales sure were crude." 隅		corner	Pinnacle . . . Talking Cricket.		12	2108	1958	53	グウ	すみ	<em>Jiminy Cricket</em> has a favorite <strong>corner</strong> he likes to slip into at <em>The Pinnacle</em> for a long drink. In the<strong> corner</strong> of the <em>Acropolis</em> lives the famous sooth sayer <em>Jiminy Cricket</em>, who people from all over come to visit to hear their fortune.		
逆		inverted	Mountain goat . . . road.		9	2109	1959	53	ギャク、ゲキ	さか、さか.さ、さか.らう	There's a road that's been<strong> inverted</strong>- it's gone from horizontal to directly vertical! The only beast that could possibly climb it is a mountain goat of course.
